CENS201.name: Contrasts and Conflicts: The Cultures of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English)
CENS201.desc: An introduction to the cultural history of the peoples of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe as reflected in their literature, art and music.

CENS202.name: Great Works of Literature from Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English)
CENS202.desc: Major works of Central, Eastern and Northern European literature from the eighteenth century to the present in their European context.

CENS303.name: Representations of the Holocaust (in English)
CENS303.desc: The Nazi Holocaust in film and literature from Central, Eastern, and Northern European Countries.

CENS307.name: Witches: Myth and Reality
CENS307.desc: Examination of the cultural, social, and historical construction of the witch in central and northern Europe with comparisons to recent history, current events, and popular culture.

CENS404.name: Gender and Nation: Women's State in Modern Central, Eastern and Northern European Literatures and Cultures
CENS404.desc: Cultural and social discourses of gender in literary works written in Central, Eastern and Northern Europe roughly between 1850 - 1930.

RUSS100.name: First-Year Russian
RUSS100.desc: Introduction to contemporary Russian Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.

RUSS101.name: Basic Russian I
RUSS101.desc: Introduction to contemporary Russian with emphasis on specialized vocabulary for science, commerce, law, etc. Oral practice, grammar, reading and writing. Note: Students who intend to use RUSS 101, 102 and 200 to satisfy the Faculty of Arts language requirement must register for both RUSS 101 and 102 in the same year.

RUSS112.name: Russian for Singers
RUSS112.desc: Study of Russian language and culture for opera students.

RUSS200.name: Second-Year Russian
RUSS200.desc: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students.

RUSS206.name: Nineteenth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
RUSS206.desc: The writings, lives, and thought of selected authors.

RUSS207.name: Twentieth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
RUSS207.desc: The writings, lives, and thought of major Russian authors.

RUSS215.name: Russian Practice
RUSS215.desc: Emphasis on oral practice and reading. It is recommended that this course be taken concurrently with RUSS 200.

RUSS300.name: Third-Year Russian
RUSS300.desc: Intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition.

RUSS305.name: Readings in Russian Literary Texts
RUSS305.desc: Texts are selected from 19th-, 20th-, and 21st-century sources.

RUSS306.name: Russian Literature in Translation
RUSS306.desc: A comprehensive historical and critical presentation with emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

RUSS315.name: Advanced Russian Practice
RUSS315.desc: Continuation of RUSS 215. May be taken concurrently with RUSS 300.

RUSS316.name: Russian through Film (in Russian)
RUSS316.desc: Conversation and composition using Russian film.

RUSS321.name: Imagining Location in Russian Literature (in English)

RUSS400.name: Fourth-Year Russian
RUSS400.desc: Advanced oral practice, reading and composition.

RUSS401.name: Russian for Reading Knowledge
RUSS401.desc: Russian for Reading Knowledge This course provides a reading knowledge of Russian, sufficient to enable students to understand scientific and scholarly material. Basic grammar and practice in the translation into English of texts in the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities. Intended primarily for upper-year and graduate students.

RUSS410.name: Women in Russian Literature and Culture
RUSS410.desc: Analysis of translated texts by and concerning women from folklore to contemporary society.

CNPS312.name: Career Education for Teachers
CNPS312.desc: Introduction to career education practices and standards program content, and principles for the design of career education programs. [3-0]

CNPS362.name: Basic Interviewing Skills
CNPS362.desc: Development of basic interviewing skills for counselling and guidance. [3-3]

CNPS363.name: Career Counselling
CNPS363.desc: Critical survey of career counselling theory and practice. [3-0]

CNPS364.name: Family Education and Consultation
CNPS364.desc: Examination of current theories and practices in family education and consultation. [3-0]

CNPS365.name: Introduction to Theories of Counselling
CNPS365.desc: An overview of selected theories of counselling. [3-0]

CNPS426.name: The Role of the Teacher in Guidance
CNPS426.desc: This course is designed to assist the teacher in understanding and using guidance techniques for day-to-day use in the classroom. The emphasis will be on techniques for working with people towards better self-understanding and better perspectives of alternatives. [2-1]

CNPS427.name: Guidance: Planning and Decision-making
CNPS427.desc: The work of the beginning counsellor and guidance worker in assisting students with educational, vocational, and personal planning and decision-making. [3-0]

CNPS433.name: The Personal and Social Development of the Adult
CNPS433.desc: Personal and social adjustment issues for professional counsellors; basic skills necessary for effective group counselling. [3-3]

DENT407.name: Special Oral Care in the Community
DENT407.desc: Provision of special oral health services in community settings.
DENT407.prer: All of DHYG 405, DHYG 435. Prerequisites may be waived for non-program dental hygienists and others.

DENT410.name: Dentistry I: Foundations of Clinical Dentistry
DENT410.desc: Fundamentals of human biology, body systems, diseases, and supporting basic oral health sciences. Learning in small groups, classroom, laboratory, and clinical settings utilizing technology.  Professionalism, ethics, inter-professional education and the social contract, communication skills, and critical evaluation of the literature. Begin to apply foundation knowledge and skills to patient assessment and care.

DENT420.name: Dentistry II: Basic Clinical Dentistry
DENT420.desc: Continued exposure to body systems and the supporting biomedical sciences with applications in dental clinical sciences, integrated into small group learning, classroom, laboratory, and community settings utilizing technology; continued engagement in professionalism, ethics and communication skills.

DENT430.name: Dentistry III: Intermediate Clinical Dentistry
DENT430.desc: A multi-disciplinary course integrating didactic, simulation, clinical, and community service learning. Students function as team members in clinical group practices with individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships.

DENT440.name: Dentistry IV
DENT440.desc: A continuing integrated, multi-disciplinary course with ongoing participation in clinical group practices and individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships and community service learning.

PORT101.name: First-Year Portuguese I
PORT101.desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 101 or PORT 110.

PORT102.name: First-Year Portuguese II
PORT102.desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 102 or PORT 110.

PORT110.name: Elementary Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers
PORT110.desc: A single-term alternative to PORT 101 and 102 for students with heritage Portuguese or another Romance language. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 110, PORT 101, or PORT 102.

PORT201.name: Second-Year Portuguese I
PORT201.desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 201 or PORT 210

PORT202.name: Second-Year Portuguese II
PORT202.desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit may be granted for only one of PORT 202 or PORT 210.

PORT210.name: Intermediate Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers
PORT210.desc: A single-term alternative to PORT 201 and 202 for students with heritage Portuguese or another Romance language. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 210, PORT 201, or PORT 202.
PORT210.prer: PORT 110. Heritage speakers who feel ready to enter PORT 210 directly should consult the undergraduate adviser in Portuguese.

PORT222.name: Introduction to the Analysis of Portuguese and Brazilian Cultures
PORT222.desc: Critical analysis of different cultural genres, including music, film and visual art through the study of selected Portuguese and Brazilian texts. This course is taught in English.

PORT301.name: Advanced Portuguese
PORT301.desc: Advanced work in composition for students who have reached the Language-Requirement level of Portuguese.

PORT308.name: Portuguese for Business (in Portuguese)
PORT308.desc: Communicative Portuguese for students studying Commerce or otherwise preparing for a career in business.

PORT392.name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Literature

PORT405.name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Culture
PORT405.desc: Selected topics on Portuguese and Brazilian Culture. Please refer to section details for up to date course offering information. This course is taught in English.

NURS300.name: Theoretical and Professional Foundations for Nursing Practice
NURS300.desc: Introduction to knowledge fundamental to the discipline and practice of nursing. Students who take NURS300 may not also earn credit for NURS302.

NURS301.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Primary Health Care
NURS301.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice in the context of primary health care. Students who take NURS 342 cannot earn credit for NURS 336 or NURS 402.
NURS301.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS302.name: Foundations for Professional Nursing Practice
NURS302.desc: Introduction to fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to the discipline and practice of nursing.
NURS302.crer: All of NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS303.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: People Living with Mental Health Challenges and Their Families
NURS303.desc: Theory informing a life course perspective on nursing practice with people living with mental health challenges and their families is introduced. Students who take NURS 303 cannot earn credit for NURS 335 or NURS 424.

NURS304.name: Introduction to Relational Practice
NURS304.desc: Introduction to relational theories to guide nursing practice within the socio-political, historical, economic and cultural context of health and health care.
NURS304.crer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS305.name: Introduction to Critical Inquiry and Research
NURS305.desc: Introduction to fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to scientific inquiry, evidence-based and informed practice, and research utilization in health care.
NURS305.crer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 306.

NURS306.name: Introduction to Leadership, Ethics, and Policy in Health Care
NURS306.desc: Introduction to fundamental theories, concepts, evidence and competencies pertaining to health care leadership, ethics and policy.
NURS306.crer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305.

NURS310.name: Basic Principles of Pharmacology for Nursing Practice
NURS310.desc: Basic principles of pharmacology and the basic structure and function of each body system will be explored to demonstrate how drug interactions occur within systems.

NURS321.name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice I
NURS321.desc: Skills and competencies for clinical practice using a variety of modalities and learning activities.
NURS321.crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS322.name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice II
NURS322.desc: Clinical practice through a variety of modalities and learning activities in the laboratory environment.

NURS323.name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice III
NURS323.desc: Skills and competencies for clinical practice across the lifespan and health care continuum through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
NURS323.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS330.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Adults/Older Adults and their Families
NURS330.desc: Fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to nursing practice with adults/older adults and their families.
NURS330.crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 360.

NURS331.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Adults/Older Adults Experiencing Acute Health Challenges and Their Families
NURS331.desc: Consolidation of fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to acute care nursing practice with adults/older adults and their families. Students who take NURS 331 cannot earn credit for NURS 303, NURS 337 or NURS 420
NURS331.crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 360.

NURS333.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Childbearing Individuals and Families
NURS333.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with childbearing individuals and families during the transition to parenthood in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
NURS333.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS333.crer: Either (a) one of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) one of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. (depending on sequencing of NURS 333 with other professional practice courses.)

NURS334.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Infants, Children, Youth, and their Families
NURS334.desc: Analysis and application of theories concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with infants, children, youth, and their families through childhood and adolescence in a variety of practice setting and contexts.
NURS334.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS334.crer: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 334 with other professional practice courses.

NURS335.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Adults Living with Mental Illness and their Families
NURS335.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with mental illness and their families in a variety of practice settings and contexts. [3-0-9]
NURS335.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS335.crer: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 335 with other professional practice courses.

NURS336.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Communities and Populations
NURS336.desc: Analysis and application of theories and strategies for working in partnership with populations, health professionals, and community services providers. Students use primary health care principles and population health promotion approaches during community nursing practice. [3-0-9]
NURS336.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS336.crer: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 336 with other professional practice courses.

NURS337.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Adults, Older Adults, and their Families
NURS337.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with older adults and their families in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
NURS337.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS337.crer: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 337 with other professional practice courses.

NURS338.name: Relational Nursing Practice Across Diverse Health Experiences
NURS338.desc: Exploration and analysis of opportunities and challenges of relational practice across multiple diverse health experiences and sites of health care.
NURS338.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS339.name: Critical Inquiry and Research in Health Care Practice
NURS339.desc: Exploration of the application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies pertaining to scientific inquiry, and the role of evidence informed practice in supporting health care across the range of healthcare disciplines.
NURS339.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS340.name: Leadership, Ethics, and Policy in Health Care Practice
NURS340.desc: Exploration and application of the interrelationship of leadership, ethics and policy in a variety of healthcare contexts.
NURS340.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS341.name: Relational Nursing Practice as Praxis
NURS341.desc: Critical analysis of the enactment of relational practice toward promotion of health and wellbeing at multiple levels.
NURS341.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 338.

NURS342.name: Critical Inquiry and Research in Nursing Practice
NURS342.desc: Critical analysis of theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to scientific inquiry, evidence-based and informed practice, and research utilization in nursing.
NURS342.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 339.

NURS343.name: Leadership, Ethics, and Policy in Nursing Practice
NURS343.desc: Critical analysis of the enactment of nursing leadership, ethics, and policy in practice.
NURS343.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 340.

NURS344.name: Critical Inquiry and Leadership Synthesis
NURS344.desc: Evidence is examined and synthesized to understand and identify theoretical insights to address a leadership challenge in professional practice.
NURS344.prer: Seven of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 350, NURS 351, NURS 352, NURS 360.

NURS345.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Childbearing Individuals and their Families
NURS345.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with childbearing individuals and families during the transition to parenthood in a variety of practice settings and contexts. Students who take NURS 345 cannot earn credit for NURS 333 or NURS 422.

NURS346.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Infants, Children, Youth and their Families
NURS346.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with infants, children, youth and their families in a variety of practice settings and contexts. Students who take NURS 346 cannot earn credit for NURS 334 or NURS 423
NURS346.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS350.name: Critical Inquiry and Research in Health Care Practice
NURS350.desc: The significance of critical inquiry and research in nursing and health care, and the fundamental concepts and processes pertaining to scientific inquiry, evidence-based practice, and research utilization in nursing. Students who take NURS 350 cannot earn credit for NURS 305, NURS 339 or NURS 342.
NURS350.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS351.name: Leadership, Policy, and Informatics
NURS351.desc: The enactment of nursing leadership and policy within different health sectors and jurisdictions and the relevance and application of informatics competencies to the delivery of nursing care. Students who take NURS 351 cannot earn credit for NURS 306, NURS 340 or NURS 343.
NURS351.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS352.name: Relational and Ethical Nursing Practice
NURS352.desc: Relational theoretical underpinnings of nursing practice and healthcare ethics are critically examined. Students who take NURS 352 cannot earn credit for NURS 304, NURS 338 or NURS 341.
NURS352.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS353.name: Promoting the Health of Indigenous People
NURS353.desc: Foundations to contribute to supporting and providing high quality, ethical, respectful and culturally safe health care in partnership with Indigenous people in Canada and around the globe.

NURS354.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Complexities in Seniors Care
NURS354.desc: Research and clinical practice innovations in the care of Seniors and their families (e.g., philosophies of care; age-friendly initiatives) and provide strategies for improving their health through the purposeful integration of such practices in clinical settings.
NURS354.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS360.name: Nursing Practice with Adults/Older Adults and their Families
NURS360.desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of adults/older adults with stable or expected health care challenges and their families. Students who take NURS 360 cannot earn credit for NURS 303, NURS 337 or NURS 420
NURS360.crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330.

NURS361.name: Nursing Practice with Adults/Older Adults Experiencing Acute Health Challenges and their Families
NURS361.desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of adults/older adults experiencing acute health challenges and their families. Students who take NURS 361 cannot earn credit for NURS 303, NURS 337 or NURS 420.
NURS361.crer: Four of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS362.name: Nursing Practice in Primary Health Care Contexts
NURS362.desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the context of primary health care. Students who take NURS 362 cannot earn credit for NURS 336 or NURS 425.
NURS362.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS363.name: Nursing Practice with People Living with Mental Health Challenges and Their Families
NURS363.desc: Students will apply theory and concepts from a life course perspective in the provision of nursing care to persons living with mental health challenges and their families. Students who take NURS 363 cannot earn credit for NURS 335 or NURS 424
NURS363.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS365.name: Nursing Practice with Childbearing Individuals and Families
NURS365.desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of childbearing individuals, infants, and their families. Students who take NURS 365 cannot earn credit for NURS 333 or NURS 422.
NURS365.crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS366.name: Nursing Practice with Infants, Children, Youth and their Families: Practicum
NURS366.desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of infants, children, youth and their families. Students who take NURS 366 cannot earn credit for NURS 334 or NURS 423.
NURS366.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330.

NURS401.name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice IV
NURS401.desc: Students are prepared with the skills and competencies for clinical practice in simulated acute and community settings through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
NURS401.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS402.name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice V
NURS402.desc: Students are guided to consolidate skills and competencies for clinical practice through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
NURS402.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 321, NURS 322, NURS 323, NURS 353, NURS 360, NURS 361, NURS 362, NURS 363, NURS 365, NURS 366, NURS 401.

NURS410.name: Supplemental Guided Study
NURS410.desc: Supplemental guided study to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies. For Bachelor of Science Nursing students only. Pass/Fail.

NURS420.name: Clinical Nursing Focus: Adults Experiencing Acute or Chronic Health Conditions
NURS420.desc: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
NURS420.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

NURS422.name: Clincial Nursing Focus: Childbearing Families
NURS422.desc: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
NURS422.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

NURS423.name: Clincial Nursing Focus: Children and their Families
NURS423.desc: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
NURS423.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

NURS424.name: Clincial Nursing Focus: Individuals and Families with  Mental Health Concerns
NURS424.desc: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
NURS424.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

NURS425.name: Clinical Nursing Focus: Community and Population Health
NURS425.desc: Credit is given for one of NURS 420, 422, 423, 424, or 425.
NURS425.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 333, NURS 334, NURS 335, NURS 336, NURS 337, NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340, NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343.

NURS430.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Special Topics in Complex and Urgent Health Challenges across Settings/Populations
NURS430.desc: Consolidation of fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to nursing practice across the life-span and care context. Students who take NURS 430 cannot earn credit for NURS 420, 422, 423, 424 or 425
NURS430.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 301, NURS 303, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 322, NURS 323, NURS 330, NURS 331, NURS 344, NURS 345, NURS 346, NURS 350, NURS 351, NURS 352, NURS 353, NURS 354, NURS 360, NURS 361, NURS 362, NURS 363, NURS 365, NURS 366, NURS 401.

FOPR261.name: Basic Geomatics for Natural Resources
FOPR261.desc: Techniques of measuring and surveying as they are applied in assessing and managing natural resources. [2-2-0]

FOPR262.name: Forest Access and Transportation
FOPR262.desc: Introduction to the physical attributes of forest access and transportation and how they best integrate with the objectives of resource sustainability. [2-3-0]

FOPR264.name: Geomatics, Forest Access and Transportation
FOPR264.desc: Geomatics, the physical attributes of forest access and transportation and how they best integrate with the objectives of resource sustainability. [2-4-0]

FOPR362.name: Forest Harvesting Systems
FOPR362.desc: The mechanics and productivity of a broad range of forest harvesting systems. [3-0-1]

FOPR388.name: Analytical Methods in Forest Hydrology
FOPR388.desc: Analytical methods in forest hydrology and their applications in the planning of forest operations with a focus on the hydrologic and hydraulic design procedures for stream crossings. [3-2]

FOPR459.name: Economics, Contracts, and Finances in Forest Operations
FOPR459.desc: A capstone project-based course with applications of engineering economics, contract preparation, and financial planning in the context of Forest Operations. [2-2]

FOPR464.name: Forestry Machines
FOPR464.desc: A detailed examination of the performance of heavy trucks used in forestry plus highlights of particular aspects of the performance of hydraulic tracked machines and cable logging machines. [2-2-0]

VISA101.name: BFA Studio Practice
VISA101.desc: Introduction to a broad range of contemporary studio practice. Intended for first year Bachelor of Fine Arts VISA students.

VISA110.name: Foundation Studio: Digital Media
VISA110.desc: Foundation instruction in techniques and approaches to digital practice. The nature of digital technologies and their role in contemporary culture will be examined. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

VISA180.name: Foundation Studio: Approaches to Media
VISA180.desc: Drawing, painting, and related media in an introduction to studio practice. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

VISA183.name: Foundation Studio: Ideas as Practice I
VISA183.desc: Contemporary art practices, emphasizing the relationship between meanings and materials, art historical contexts and concepts, and non-traditional materials. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

VISA210.name: Digital Arts
VISA210.desc: Examination of current art practices and issues related to digital technologies and contemporary culture, with an emphasis on the theoretical conceptualization of digital artistic media.
VISA210.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA220.name: Drawing
VISA220.desc: Development of skills in drawing including life drawing. Introduction to the development of personal style and concepts.
VISA220.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA230.name: Painting
VISA230.desc: Development of a variety of techniques and approaches to painting. Emphasis on developing a strong paint vocabulary as well as acquiring knowledge of historical and contemporary issues in painting.
VISA230.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA240.name: Photography
VISA240.desc: Introduction to photography techniques and image-making. Emphasis on camera techniques and film and darkroom production. Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Art.
VISA240.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA241.name: Digital Photography
VISA241.desc: Introduction to digital photography image creation in relation to contemporary art. Emphasis on digital camera use, file management, and digital print production.  Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Art.
VISA241.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA250.name: Print Media
VISA250.desc: Visual print culture, and contemporary and historical technical print practices. Emphasis on hand-drawn intaglio, relief, screen and/or stencil printing, and graphic digital applications.
VISA250.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA260.name: Sculpture
VISA260.desc: Contemporary sculpture practice and theory. Various sculpture materials and technologies including machinery use.
VISA260.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA270.name: Special Studies
VISA270.desc: Introduction to various aspects of contemporary studio practice. Not offered every year.
VISA270.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA280.name: Contemporary Art: Ideas as Practice II
VISA280.desc: Development and history of contemporary art practice, with a focus on how artists realize and exchange ideas. Intended for second year BFA VISA students.
VISA280.prer: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.

VISA310.name: Intermediate Digital Arts I
VISA310.desc: Exploring issues and topics in interactive digital media and culture through the creation of critical contemporary art. Includes technical instruction with a focus on the development of individual and group projects.

VISA311.name: Intermediate Digital Arts II
VISA311.desc: Investigation of issues and topics in digital media and visual culture through the production of contemporary video art. Technical instruction in video manipulation software. Individual and/or group projects.

VISA320.name: Intermediate Drawing I
VISA320.desc: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art. Emphasis on expanding definitions of the drawing practice while focusing on technical and conceptual development.

VISA321.name: Intermediate Drawing II
VISA321.desc: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art and theory. Emphasis on self-directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

VISA330.name: Intermediate Painting I
VISA330.desc: Development of techniques and personal style in relation to ideas. History and contemporary issues in painting will be introduced  to assist students in conceptualizing their painting practice.

VISA331.name: Intermediate Painting II
VISA331.desc: Further investigation of painting in the context of contemporary art.  Emphasis on self directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

VISA340.name: Intermediate Photography I
VISA340.desc: An investigation of approaches to photography and its meaning in the context of contemporary art. The term theme will be determined by the instructor. B & W, colour and digital production.

VISA341.name: Intermediate Photography II
VISA341.desc: An investigation of contemporary photography production and approaches to the constructed image with emphasis on medium and large format camera use and studio lighting techniques.

VISA350.name: Intermediate Print Media I: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA350.desc: Intaglio and relief print applications (i.e., etching, wood and/or lino cut, and collagraph) in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing; discussion of contemporary and historical visual print culture.
VISA350.prer: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 290, VISA 283, VISA 284, FINA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284.

VISA351.name: Intermediate Print Media II: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA351.desc: Screen printing and other print applications in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing, explored within the context of contemporary art.
VISA351.prer: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

VISA352.name: Intermediate Print Media III: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA352.desc: Lithographic printing; suitable for students interested in drawing and print media interface in context of contemporary art; related digital and photographic technologies employed.
VISA352.prer: Either (a) one of VISA 220, VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 281, FINA 281, VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

VISA360.name: Intermediate Sculpture I
VISA360.desc: Investigation of contemporary practices in sculpture and the use of scale. Emphasis on public sculpture.
VISA360.prer: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

VISA361.name: Intermediate Sculpture II
VISA361.desc: Development of personal concerns in three-dimensional work. Emphasis on the integration of diverse materials and techniques.
VISA361.prer: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

VISA370.name: Special Studies I
VISA370.desc: Intermediate tutorial. Not offered every year.

VISA371.name: Special Studies II
VISA371.desc: Intermediate tutorial. Not offered every year.

VISA375.name: Artists in Society
VISA375.desc: Exploring artistic practice through community-engaged partnerships and critical study.
VISA375.prer: Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students majoring in Visual Arts or Art History.

VISA380.name: Studio Theory
VISA380.desc: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students.

VISA381.name: Studio Seminar
VISA381.desc: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students.

VISA390.name: Performance Art
VISA390.desc: Seminar-based studio focusing on performance and actions in the field of contemporary art.
VISA390.prer: 6 credits of 200-level VISA with an average of at least 72%.

VISA401.name: Advanced Open Studio
VISA401.desc: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
VISA401.prer: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.

VISA410.name: Advanced Digital Arts I
VISA410.desc: Development of contemporary art works utilizing digital technologies including 3-dimensional applications, spatial, interactive and time-based installations. Focus on student-generated projects, either individual or group.
VISA410.prer: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.

VISA411.name: Advanced Digital Arts II: Video
VISA411.desc: Contemporary practices in video media examined through individual projects and directed study.
VISA411.prer: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.

VISA430.name: Advanced Drawing and Painting I
VISA430.desc: Interdisciplinary studio practice with emphasis on drawing, painting, and related media.
VISA430.prer: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331.

VISA431.name: Advanced Drawing and Painting II
VISA431.desc: Interdisciplinary studio practice with emphasis on drawing, painting, and related media.
VISA431.prer: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331.

VISA440.name: Advanced Photography I
VISA440.desc: Photography practice in the context of contemporary art. Interdisciplinary connections to other media will be encouraged.

VISA441.name: Advanced Photography II
VISA441.desc: The production of self-directed projects investigating photography as art. Focus on integrative approaches including conventional, digital and multi-media.

VISA450.name: Advanced Print Media and Sculpture I
VISA450.desc: Studies in contemporary trends in studio practice and theory. Emphasis on advanced two and three-dimensional work developed out of experimental approaches to sculpture, installation art and print-based media.
VISA450.prer: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.

VISA451.name: Advanced Print Media and Sculpture II
VISA451.desc: Further studies in advanced two and three-dimensional work developed out of experimental approaches to sculpture, installation art and print-based media.
VISA451.prer: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.

VISA469.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
VISA469.desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

VISA470.name: Advanced Special Studies I
VISA470.desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Not offered every year.

VISA471.name: Advanced Special Studies II
VISA471.desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Not offered every year.

VISA475.name: Exhibition Theory and Practice
VISA475.desc: Exhibition course focusing on current curatorial practices and theories with an emphasis on contemporary visual art with the aim of preparing students to engage in the active organization of a large exhibition. Restricted to 4th year Majors in either VISA or ARTH, or permission of the instructor.

VISA479.name: Performance Actions and Approaches
VISA479.desc: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies.

VISA480.name: Advanced Seminar I
VISA480.desc: Readings in art theory and criticism.

VISA481.name: Advanced Seminar II
VISA481.desc: Readings in art theory and criticism.

VISA490.name: Advanced Tutorial in Studio I
VISA490.desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required. Not offered every year.
VISA490.prer: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.

VISA491.name: Advanced Tutorial in Studio II
VISA491.desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required.
VISA491.prer: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.

ITST110.name: Introduction to Italian Literature and Culture

ITST231.name: Introduction to Italian Culture I: From the Middle Ages to the Early Modern Period

ITST232.name: Introduction to Italian Culture II: From the Modern to the Post-Colonial Age

ITST333.name: Masterpieces of the Novella in Italian Literature
ITST333.desc: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age.

ITST345.name: Italian Fascism in Interdisciplinary Perspective
ITST345.desc: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures.

ITST413.name: Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy in Translation
ITST413.desc: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works:

ITST414.name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Middle Ages in Translation
ITST414.desc: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Precludes credit for ITAL 404.

ITST415.name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance in Translation
ITST415.desc: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Precludes credit for ITAL 405.

ITST416.name: Classics of Seventeenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
ITST416.desc: Classics of the Italian literature of the Mannerist and Baroque age in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context.  Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 416 or ITAL 406.

ITST417.name: Classics of Eighteenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
ITST417.desc: Classics of the Italian literature of the age of the Enlightenment in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context.  Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 417 or ITAL 407.

ITST418.name: Topics in Nineteenth-century Italian Literature and Culture in Translation
ITST418.desc: Italian literature of the 19th century in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 408.

ITST419.name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture in Translation
ITST419.desc: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 409.

ITST421.name: Special Topics in Italian Studies
ITST421.desc: Course content will vary. May be taken twice for a total of 6 credits.

ITST432.name: Italian Cinema and Its Cultural Background
ITST432.desc: Films with English subtitles. Precludes credit for ITAL 430. Course content will vary. May be taken twice for a total of 6 credits.

ITST495.name: Research Intensive Seminar in Italian Literature and Culture
ITST495.desc: Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 495 or ITST 495.

INFO250.name: Networks, Crowds, and Communities
INFO250.desc: Introduces network concepts and methods for exploring social and organizational connectivity for work, socializing, and knowledge production. Examines impact of social media on connections that span space and place; peer production on authority structures; ubiquitous mobile connectivity on daily life.

INFO419.name: Information Visualization
INFO419.desc: Basic theory and practice required to visually represent information. Introduces design principles and practical skills to create effective information visualizations. Examines effect of different visual representations on understanding and meaning.

INFO456.name: Information Policy and Society
INFO456.desc: Develops capabilities required to assess the need for information policies in professional contexts, evaluate relevant socio-technical dimensions and envision likely implications for specific communities and practice settings.

FNIS100.name: Indigenous Foundations
FNIS100.desc: The historical, cultural, political, economic and legal issues that inform the experiences of Indigenous peoples in Canada, examined from both Indigenous and non-Indigenous perspectives. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 100, FNSP 100, or FNSP 200.

FNIS210.name: Indigenous Politics and Self-Determination
FNIS210.desc: The cultural, historical, political, economic, and gender dynamics that structure the relationship between Indigenous peoples and the state in Canada; Indigenous self-determination struggles in relation to constitutional recognition, self-government, land claims, and economic development. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, or FNSP 210.

FNIS220.name: Representation and Indigenous Cultural Politics
FNIS220.desc: Representation, identity, and cultural politics through Indigenous literature, film, and the visual arts; the relationship between these sites of cultural production and the self-determination struggles of Indigenous peoples. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 220, or FNSP 220.

FNIS260.name: Applied Learning: Collaborative Place-Based Research
FNIS260.desc: Topic and community/location of instruction will vary from year to year. Applied, intense delivery experiential learning course designed and implemented in collaboration with faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). Examines the importance of Indigenous place-based research and learning for student and community empowerment.

FNIS300.name: Writing First Nations
FNIS300.desc: A writing-intensive course examining approaches to writing Indigenous research: Representation & the Other; Indigenous critiques of research & representation; Indigenous, feminist and cultural studies approaches to writing ethnography, oral history, and related research methods. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 300 or FNSP 300.
FNIS300.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220.

FNIS310.name: Critical Indigenous Theory Seminar
FNIS310.desc: Adapting and integrating current conceptual paradigms in the humanities, social sciences, performing arts, and Indigenous studies into approaches in First Nations/Indigenous Studies, including identity construction, political and cultural self-determination, representation, essentialism/authenticity, ethics, and decolonization. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 310 or FNSP 310.
FNIS310.prer: Either (a) FNSP 200 or (b) all of FNIS 210, FNIS 220 or (c) all of FNSP 210, FNSP 220.

FNIS320.name: Critical Indigenous Methodologies and Ethics
FNIS320.desc: Responsible and community-based research from a critical Indigenous perspective; methods for identifying and assessing research materials, critical analysis, oral history/qualitative research interviewing and analysis, and research ethics in the design and implementation of community-based student research projects. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 320 or FNSP 320.

FNIS360.name: Applied Learning: Collaborative Place-Based Research
FNIS360.desc: Topic and community/location of instruction will vary from year to year. Applied, intense delivery experiential learning course designed and implemented in collaboration with faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). Examines the importance of Indigenous place-based research and learning for student and community empowerment.
FNIS360.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. And Permission of the Instructor.

FNIS400.name: Practicum/Advanced Research Seminar
FNIS400.desc: Applied research/community oriented project designed and implemented in collaboration with student, faculty and Aboriginal community organization. Emphasis on examining ethical issues and developing culturally respectful and academically rigorous forms of research. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 400 or FNSP 400.
FNIS400.prer: Either (a) all of FNIS 310, FNIS 320 or (b) all of FNSP 310, FNSP 320. Students must pass FNIS 320 or FNSP 320 with a B- or higher or request program approval.

FNIS401.name: Special Topics
FNIS401.desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website: http://fnsp.arts.ubc.ca.
FNIS401.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220 or third-year standing.

FNIS451.name: Indigenous Feminisms
FNIS451.desc: The historical, cultural, political, and activist roots of contemporary Indigenous feminisms. Indigenous feminist methodologies, theory, and praxis in relation to contemporary Indigenous politics and social justice movements. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401D, FNIS 451, or FNSP 451.
FNIS451.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220 or third-year standing.

FNIS452.name: Indigenous Social Movements
FNIS452.desc: Draws on Indigenous and non-Indigenous intellectual traditions to explore the theoretical, cultural, political, economic, and historical bases of Indigenous peoples decolonization struggles in Canada. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401A, FNIS 452, or FNSP 452.
FNIS452.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220 or third-year standing.

FNIS453.name: Indigenous Legal Traditions
FNIS453.desc: Socio-historical, political and cultural context of Indigenous legal traditions and strategies for ethical engagement within state and Indigenous polities. Methods include oral history analysis, legal theory, literary/narrative studies, and philosophy from an Indigenous studies perspective.
FNIS453.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220 or 3rd year standing.

FNIS454.name: Indigenous New Media
FNIS454.desc: New media and digital storytelling works designed and implemented by Indigenous artists, authors, and programmers.
FNIS454.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220, or third year standing.

FNIS455.name: Indigenous Geographies: Our Home on Native Land
FNIS455.desc: Indigenous people's place-based relations, colonial processes of de-territorialization, and spatial negotiations of settler colonialism.
FNIS455.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220, or third year standing.

WRDS150.name: Research and Writing in the Humanities and Social Sciences
WRDS150.desc: Writing and reading in the social sciences and humanities, focusing on practices which the research disciplines share, and those which differentiate them. Credit will be granted for only one of WRDS 150 or ASTU 150.

CSIS200.name: Critical Engagements in Sexuality Studies
CSIS200.desc: Introductory survey to sexuality studies that emphasizes how sexuality intersects with race, gender, class, ability, and geography.

CSIS300.name: Introduction to Critical Studies in Sexuality
CSIS300.desc: A multidisciplinary, team-taught course which provides an introduction to the study of sexuality, including  lesbian, gay, bisexual, heterosexual, and transgender issues and related topics.

CSIS301.name: Introduction to Trans* Studies
CSIS301.desc: How race, citizenship, gender, sexuality, culture and dis/ability are materially and socially constructed together to give meaning to the category trans*. (Trans*: transgender, transsexual, gender variant and other articulations.)

CSIS450.name: Topics in Critical Studies in Sexuality
CSIS450.desc: A thematic course, which explores current questions and issues in relation to the study of sexuality. Topics may vary from year to year.

CSIS490.name: Directed Topics
CSIS490.desc: Designed to allow a student to develop an individual course of study in a specific area as approved by a faculty member affiliated with the CSIS program.

COEC126.name: Data: Description, Display, and Inference
COEC126.desc: Use of data and statistics to convey information on important issues of the world economy. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 126 or COMM 126.

COEC293.name: Financial Accounting
COEC293.desc: Construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 293 or COMM 293.

COEC298.name: Introduction to Finance
COEC298.desc: Basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 293 or COMM 298.

COEC365.name: Market Research
COEC365.desc: The process of marketing research including problem/opportunity formulation, research objectives, data sources, research instrument design, sampling, data collection and processing and methods of data analysis.

COEC370.name: Corporate Finance
COEC370.desc: Corporate enterprise decisions including capital budgeting; capital structure choice; and financial policies, tools, and valuation.

COEC371.name: Investment Theory
COEC371.desc: Basic concepts of finance, including security valuation, security markets, and financial decisions concerning risk and return. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 371 or COMM 371.

COEC377.name: International Financial Markets and Institutions
COEC377.desc: Structure, nature and institutions of foreign exchange markets, including spot, forward, futures, options, and offshore currency markets. Factors affecting exchange rates are also discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 377 or COMM 377.

COEC394.name: Government and Business
COEC394.desc: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 394 or COMM 394.

COEC491.name: Strategic Management
COEC491.desc: Concepts and processes for the strategic management of single- and multi-business unit private sector enterprises, analyzed using the case method. Integrates methodologies from economic and organizational theory to form the foundations for strategic analyses.

COEC497.name: New Enterprise Development
COEC497.desc: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing, and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies.

COEC498.name: International Business Management
COEC498.desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 498 or COMM 498.

ARCH403.name: Themes in Architecture and Design
ARCH403.desc: Introduction to a broad range of themes in architecture and design. Restricted to B.En.D. students.

ARCH404.name: Architectural History I
ARCH404.desc: Architecture from 1400 to 1900 and the design theory and practice that have shaped it.  Restricted to B.En.D. students.  Credit will be given for only one of  ARCH 405 or ARCH 505.

ARCH405.name: Architectural History II
ARCH405.desc: Critical analysis of developments in modern and contemporary architectural thought and practice.   Restricted to B.En.D. students. Credit will be given for only one of ARCH 405 or ARCH 505.

ARCH407.name: Research Methods
ARCH407.desc: Motivations and techniques which underpin environmental design research.

ARCH410.name: Design Methods
ARCH410.desc: Techniques for environmental design, including architecture.

ARCH411.name: Materials and Methods of Construction
ARCH411.desc: An investigation of building materials and systems considering design objectives, environmental conditions, historical context, regulatory controls, and economic constraints. The major building systems of light wood frame, steel, and concrete and the technical and expressive opportunities inherent in each.  Restricted to B.En.D. students.

ARCH437.name: Geometric Modeling
ARCH437.desc: Advanced modeling, rendering and image processing applications; the construction of geometric models, their viewing transformations, light and material attributes; mapping and rendering are introduced. Restricted to B.En.D. students.

ANTH100.name: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
ANTH100.desc: Basic concepts and methods of anthropology; culture and race; comparative study of social systems, religion, symbolism, art, and other institutions. Examples are drawn from a variety of cultures.

ANTH200.name: Introduction to Problems in Method and Theory in Anthropology
ANTH200.desc: A survey of basic concepts and procedures in the cross-cultural study of human societies.

ANTH201.name: Ethnic Relations
ANTH201.desc: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

ANTH202.name: Contemporary Social Problems
ANTH202.desc: Cultural background to contemporary events; problems of nationalism and regional conflicts, economic and social development, gender, religion and social change. Course may stress a different region of the world in different years.

ANTH210.name: Eating Culture
ANTH210.desc: An anthropological exploration of how the collection, cultivation and consumption of food shapes human society and culture.

ANTH213.name: Sex, Gender, and Culture
ANTH213.desc: An anthropological exploration of how understandings of sex and gender are culturally and historically shaped.

ANTH214.name: The Family in Cross-Cultural Perspective
ANTH214.desc: A cross-cultural comparison of family and kinship to provide an understanding of variations in the structure and meaning of marriage relations; forms of domestic organization; and the sexual division of labour, property, and inheritance.

ANTH215.name: Japanese Popular Culture
ANTH215.desc: Television shows, dramas, movies, advertising, marketing, manga (Japanese style "comics"), anime (Japanese animation), theatrical forms, popular literature, popular music, fashion fads, tourism, toys, and sports.

ANTH217.name: Culture and Communication
ANTH217.desc: The study of communication; the relation between communication and its cultural context with emphasis on verbal and non-verbal communication, cross-cultural communication, and cultural differences in the use of oral, literate, and electronic media.

ANTH220.name: First Nations of British Columbia
ANTH220.desc: The cultures, languages, and resources of First Nations, with anthropological perspectives on colonization and development.

ANTH221.name: Contemporary Indigenous Cultural Expressions
ANTH221.desc: Forms and styles of indigenous expressive arts, and their current place in the lives of Indigenous Peoples.

ANTH227.name: Introduction to Medical Anthropology
ANTH227.desc: An examination of health and illness, in their social and cultural contexts.

ANTH241.name: Introduction to Museums and Museology
ANTH241.desc: The critical study of anthropology museums as social institutions and material culture research and classification from the late 19th century to the present day.

ANTH300.name: Contemporary Anthropological Theory
ANTH300.desc: Contemporary approaches to society and culture in anthropology.

ANTH301.name: Ethnography of Eurasia
ANTH301.desc: Eurasia, including the Russian Federation, Central Asia, and Mongolia, with an emphasis on issues of power, identities, and transnational mobility in the region.

ANTH302.name: Ethnography of South Asia
ANTH302.desc: A specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems relating to South Asia.

ANTH303.name: Ethnography of Special Areas
ANTH303.desc: A specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems in one area. Different culture areas or regions may be selected each term. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

ANTH304.name: Ethnography of the Northwest Coast
ANTH304.desc: Specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems of the region.

ANTH307.name: Ethnography of Korea
ANTH307.desc: An exploration of ethnographic, topical, and theoretical issues.

ANTH308.name: Ethnography of Sub-Saharan Africa
ANTH308.desc: An exploration of ethnographic, topical, and theoretical issues.

ANTH312.name: Introduction to the Anthropology of Gender
ANTH312.desc: Theoretical approaches to, and the ethnographic study of, gender in cross-cultural contexts.

ANTH315.name: Japanese Culture and Society
ANTH315.desc: Japanese culture and society: patterns of organization, value systems, family, education, work, minorities and diversity, harmony and conflict, urban/rural differences, gender, sexuality, youth, tradition, continuity, change, and future prospects.

ANTH316.name: Political Anthropology
ANTH316.desc: Comparative study of political organization; leadership and non-centralized and centralized political systems.

ANTH317.name: Linguistic Anthropology
ANTH317.desc: A survey of the ethnographic uses of language data and the techniques of linguistic analysis.

ANTH329.name: Contemporary First Nations Issues
ANTH329.desc: Anthropological perspectives on contemporary issues of public policy, law, and political activity, as they affect the place of First Nations people in British Columbia and Canada.

ANTH330.name: Anthropology of Rural Peoples and the Global Economy
ANTH330.desc: A comparative study of rural peoples (such as small-scale horticulturists, artisans and craft workers, peasants, fisherfolk, or industrial/manufacturing workers) in the global economy.

ANTH331.name: Art, Aesthetics and Anthropology
ANTH331.desc: Anthropological perspectives on art, aesthetics, and expressive culture.

ANTH332.name: Oral Tradition
ANTH332.desc: An ethnographic perspective on the dynamics of oral tradition in various oral and literate cultures; the characteristics and roles of oral genres including folktale, genealogy, oral history, autobiography, and myth in these societies; and the relationship between orality and literacy.

ANTH333.name: Language and Power
ANTH333.desc: A sociolinguistic examination of the role of language in articulating, maintaining, and subverting power relations in society.

ANTH341.name: Museums, Heritage and Memory
ANTH341.desc: Museums, galleries, monuments, and other cultural institutions' relations to our perception of history and geography.

ANTH350.name: Ethnography of the Pacific Islands: Polynesia and Micronesia
ANTH350.desc: Major cultural groupings in Polynesia and Micronesia, emphasizing both traditional cultures and the incorporation of the region into modern international institutions.

ANTH351.name: Ethnography of the Pacific Islands: Melanesia
ANTH351.desc: Major cultural groupings in Melanesia, emphasizing both traditional cultures and the incorporation of the region into modern international institutions.

ANTH353.name: Ethnography of Latin America
ANTH353.desc: Indigenous peoples of Latin America, emphasizing both pre-Columbian cultural traditions and socioeconomic and cultural changes from the Colonial period to the present.

ANTH360.name: Introduction to Ecological Anthropology
ANTH360.desc: Analysis of the relations between human societies and the ecological aspects of their environment (including technology, society, and ideology).  Previously ANTH 460.

ANTH378.name: Anthropology of Media
ANTH378.desc: Analysis of contemporary mass media and of the anthropological use of media (photography, film, digital audio and video, etc.).

ANTH400.name: History of Anthropology
ANTH400.desc: The development of anthropological theory and practice in institutional contexts.

ANTH401.name: First Peoples of North America
ANTH401.desc: Anthropological perspectives of indigenous cultures and societies of North America.

ANTH402.name: Ethnography of China
ANTH402.desc: Advanced studies in the ethnography of China, premodern and contemporary. Topics may include kinship, rural and urban social structure, stratification and mobility, religion, national power structures, and social change in Chinese society.

ANTH403.name: Ethnography of Special Areas
ANTH403.desc: An advanced study of ethnographic and theoretical problems. A different region may be studied each term.

ANTH404.name: Ethnography in Circumpolar North: Comparative Perspectives
ANTH404.desc: An examination of relationships between indigenous people and nation states in Greenland, Canada, Alaska and Siberia, using ethnographic methods.

ANTH407.name: Principles of Field Work
ANTH407.desc: An examination of field work as the basic setting for ethnographic research. Research design; relationships with study participants, field techniques, and data analysis and presentation.

ANTH408.name: Field Methods
ANTH408.desc: Intensive examination and application of selected methods of ethnographic data-collection, e.g., visual anthropology, anthropological interviewing, genealogies, ethnographic semantics, life histories, oral traditions. Consult department for current description.

ANTH409.name: Topics in Applied Anthropology
ANTH409.desc: Advanced study of the theory and practice of applied, action, and consultancy anthropology. Topics may include the application of anthropology to questions of aboriginal rights and title, education, medicine, development, women and development, tourism, and other social issues.

ANTH412.name: Advanced Topics in the Anthropology of Gender
ANTH412.desc: Contemporary theory employed in the anthropological study of gender.

ANTH413.name: Relatedness: Family, Kinship, and Social Relations
ANTH413.desc: A cross-cultural survey of the social and cultural bases of relatedness including changing family relationships, kinship, and social organization, based on theoretical analysis and case studies.

ANTH414.name: Anthropology of Globalization
ANTH414.desc: Theories on the global flow of people, commodities, images, and ideas with critical ethnographic attention to the different ways people respond to globalization.

ANTH415.name: Religion and Society
ANTH415.desc: Comparative study of religious beliefs, practices, and movements; relations between religious, social, and political institutions; religion as a force for stability and change; anthropological/sociological theories of religion.

ANTH416.name: The Ethnography of Japan
ANTH416.desc: Ethnographies about Japan and processes of conducting fieldwork on Japan, covering topics such as work, leisure, identity, tradition, popular culture, rural/urban lifestyles, gender, sexuality, internationalization.

ANTH417.name: Language, Culture, and Cognition
ANTH417.desc: The relationships between linguistic and cultural phenomena; how language affects normative and cognitive systems of thought and behaviour.
ANTH417.prer: One of ANTH 100, LING 200. May be taken as co-requisites.

ANTH418.name: Anthropological Statistics
ANTH418.desc: Applications of statistical techniques to quantitative and qualitative data in Anthropology.

ANTH421.name: The Anthropology of Place and Space
ANTH421.desc: An anthropological understanding of the spatial dimensions of social practice, and the relationships of space to culture, history, and power.

ANTH422.name: Modes of Subsistence
ANTH422.desc: The nature of subsistence systems antedating or alternative to modern commercial systems. Introductory survey with basic readings; focus on problems such as the development of complex cultures without agriculture, the ambiguity of hunting and gathering, agricultural and other "intensification", "orchestration" of the use of adjacent microenvironments. Of interest to students of archaeology, anthropology and cultural geography.

ANTH423.name: Ethnography of East Africa and the Swahili Coast
ANTH423.desc: The everyday lives of people who inhabit East Africa and the Swahili Coast, and consideration of slave trade, long distance migration, colonialism, nationalism, independence movements, religion, identity politics, music, gender, sexuality, health, ecotourism and conservation.

ANTH427.name: Topics in Medical Anthropology
ANTH427.desc: Anthropological perspectives on health, illness, and disability as represented by classic and contemporary research in selected topics in medical anthropology including disease and human evolution, illness and human ecology, culture and epidemiology, ethnomedical systems, the relationship between folk and biomedicine and the cultural construction and social organization of health care, illness and disability. Specific content will vary from year to year. Consult the Department brochure.

ANTH428.name: Medicine, Technology, Culture, and Society
ANTH428.desc: A medical anthropological perspective on medical science, technology, translational research, and clinical practice, in laboratory, clinic, family, social, and cultural contexts. Topics include explanatory models of health, acute and chronic illness, disability; social and cultural dimensions genetics; clinical interaction.

ANTH429.name: Global Health in Cross-Cultural Contexts
ANTH429.desc: Includes examination of the social and cultural dimensions of specific life-threatening emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, the political economy of health, cultural interpretations of illness and healing, medical pluralism, therapy management, and the cultural construction of efficacy.

ANTH431.name: Museum Practice and Curatorship
ANTH431.desc: Management of museum collections and their public presentation, addressing questions of access, collaboration, and cultural property. The public interpretation of anthropological concepts and materials utilizing the programs and facilities of the Museum of Anthropology.

ANTH432.name: The Anthropology of Public Representation
ANTH432.desc: The public presentation and interpretation of anthropological concepts and materials utilizing the programs and facilities of the Museum of Anthropology.
ANTH432.prer: ANTH 341. Permission of the department is also acceptable.

ANTH433.name: Directed Studies
ANTH433.desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student. No more than six credits of Directed Studies may be taken for credit toward the Major or Honours program.

ANTH435.name: The Japanese Tea Ceremony: Ethnography of Performance, Practice, and Ritual
ANTH435.desc: An exploration of Chanoyu, Japanese Tea Practice, as a culturally embedded ritual, performance, and aesthetic form, and as a way of understanding underlying elements of Japanese culture. This course has a studio component and a nominal fee may be charged.

ANTH449.name: Honours Tutorial
ANTH449.desc: Will usually require the presentation of at least one research paper.

ANTH451.name: Conservation of Organic Materials
ANTH451.desc: Conservation of organic materials within a museum environment; the nature of materials, mechanisms of deterioration and principles of preventive conservation. Recommended for students intending to work with cultural materials.

ANTH452.name: Conservation of Inorganic Materials
ANTH452.desc: Conservation of inorganic materials within a museum environment; the nature of materials, mechanisms of deterioration and principles of preventive conservation. Recommended for students intending to work with cultural materials.

ANTH461.name: Anthropological Study of Local Ecological Knowledge
ANTH461.desc: Analysis of the concepts of ecological anthropology via the medium of local ecological knowledge. ANTH 360 is recommended as background.

ANTH462.name: Special Topics in Ecological Anthropology
ANTH462.desc: May include environmental discourse and social movements, anthropological contributions to ecological management systems, or examination of emerging issues in the field.  ANTH 360 is recommended as background.

ANTH470.name: Topics in Contemporary Theory
ANTH470.desc: Selected topics in contemporary social and cultural theory which contribute to anthropological analyses. Topics may include Marxist anthropology, critical theory, theories of culture, phenomenology, behavioural ecology, structuralism, hermeneutics, formal theory and examination of specific social theorists.

ANTH471.name: Anthropology of Law
ANTH471.desc: Cross-cultural study of the operation of law within contested systems of meaning, the social organization of law, and forms of consciousness of the participants in legal/justice practices.

ANTH472.name: Anthropological Study of Social Inequality
ANTH472.desc: An anthropological perspective on the historical origins and theoretical explanations of social inequality.

ANTH478.name: Ethnographic Film Methods
ANTH478.desc: Ethnographic digital video production, including methods of ethnographic fieldwork, creation of field notes, and research design; basics of digital video planning, production, and editing. Production fees are charged for this course. Prerequisite: ANTH 378 is recommended.

ANTH480.name: Urban Ethnographic Field School (UEFS)
ANTH480.desc: A combination of approximately 50 hours of volunteering and fieldwork based in community organizations with theoretical approaches to urban spaces.  Students will engage in collaborative research while considering a range of theoretical and methodological approaches.

ANTH495.name: Advanced Studies in Anthropology
ANTH495.desc: An intensive examination of selected topics in Anthropology. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

HINU100.name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu I
HINU100.desc: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100 or 102.

HINU101.name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu II
HINU101.desc: Continuation of HINU 100. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 101 or 102.

HINU102.name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu
HINU102.desc: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100/101 or HINU 102.

HINU200.name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
HINU200.desc: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 201/202 or HINU 200.

HINU201.name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu I
HINU201.desc: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 201.

HINU202.name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu II
HINU202.desc: Continuation of HINU 201. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 202.

HINU205.name: Introduction to the Devanagari Script
HINU205.desc: The writing system of Hindi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as HINU 200.

HINU300.name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu
HINU300.desc: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301/302 or HINU 300.

HINU301.name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu I
HINU301.desc: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301 or HINU 300.

HINU302.name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II
HINU302.desc: Continuation of HINU 301. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 302 or HINU 300.

HINU305.name: Introduction to the Perso-Arabic (Urdu) Script
HINU305.desc: The writing system of Urdu for those with some background in the spoken language.

HINU400.name: Introduction to Hindi and Urdu Literature
HINU400.desc: Readings of various literary genres in Hindi, Urdu and their medieval equivalents. Modern fiction from India and Pakistan; the Urdu ghazal; medieval Hindi bhakti poetry; readings from the Adi Granth of the Sikhs Hindi film. Discussion in Hindi-Urdu of all materials.

HINU450.name: Hindi Film
HINU450.desc: Regional, religious, and historical dialects of Hindi and Urdu as repesented in films.

CIVL200.name: Engineering and Sustainable Development
CIVL200.desc: Implications of a finite biosphere and the complexities inherent in environmental decision-making.

CIVL201.name: Civil Engineering I
CIVL201.desc: The design process; graphical, visualization and computational tools; civil engineering disciplines; decision-making; teamwork; conceptual design project reflecting community, economic, environmental, sustainability and technical considerations.
CIVL201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

CIVL202.name: Civil Engineering II
CIVL202.desc: The social and biophysical context of infrastructure and the impact of technologies on people, the economy, and the environment. Specific topics vary from year to year.

CIVL210.name: Soil Mechanics I
CIVL210.desc: Soil classification, principle of effective stress, analysis of seepage, filter criteria, introduction to shear strength and slope stability analysis.
CIVL210.crer: EOSC 210 and one of CIVL 215, MECH 280, EOSC 329.

CIVL215.name: Fluid Mechanics I
CIVL215.desc: Fluid properties, hydrostatics, kinematics, and fluid dynamics: energy and momentum methods with applications. Dimensional analysis, modelling, introduction to flow in pipes and forces on immersed objects.

CIVL228.name: Introduction to Structural Engineering
CIVL228.desc: Static determinacy, stability, superposition, analysis and design of trusses, deflection of trusses by principles of virtual work, statically indeterminate trusses, beams and frames, cables and arches, design objectives, loads and load combinations, structural safety, load paths, design of simple steel, timber, and reinforced concrete members.

CIVL230.name: Solid Mechanics I
CIVL230.desc: Stress and strain, Hooke's law, axially loaded members, torsion, shear forces and bending moments in beams, bending of beams, shear stresses in beams, shear centre, composite members, introduction to elasto-plastic and statically indeterminate problems.

CIVL231.name: Solid Mechanics II
CIVL231.desc: Deflection of beams, combined axial load and bending moment, inelastic bending, plastic analysis of structures, beam-columns, buckling (stability), principal axes and principal moments of inertia, biaxial stress and strain, Mohr’s circle.

CIVL235.name: Plane Surveying
CIVL235.desc: Theory and application of plane surveying methods. Introduction to and use of compass, transit, tape, and level. Construction and topographic surveys. Reduction of field data and construction of drawings. Demonstration of modern instruments, remote sensing methods and geographical information systems (GIS). This course commences immediately after spring examinations and continues full time for two weeks, including Saturdays. Information on the exact dates will be available in the Civil Engineering Office following publication of the final Examination Timetable.

CIVL300.name: Construction Engineering and Management
CIVL300.desc: Project delivery systems: traditional; construction management; turnkey; project management. Network planning methods. Activity planning, including construction methods selection. Estimating, bidding and bonding. Project control tools and procedures. Human resources, including equity considerations; occupational health and safety and quality control.

CIVL301.name: Optimization and Decision Analysis in Civil Engineering
CIVL301.desc: Review of numerical methods; introduction to systems engineering; application of optimization, probability, and decision-making to civil engineering systems and projects.

CIVL304.name: Fundamentals of Environmental Engineering
