CIVL304.desc: Environmental engineering issues and projects; application of scientific and engineering principles to addressing these; soil, water and air pollution, and remediation.

CIVL305.name: Introduction to Environmental Engineering
CIVL305.desc: Environmental ethics and legislation; risk assessment; urban water sources and sinks; water pollutants and impacts; mass balance and reactor design concepts; water and wastewater treatment; the environmental impact assessment process.

CIVL311.name: Soil Mechanics II
CIVL311.desc: One-dimensional compression and stress-strain response of soils with application to estimation of the settlements and capacities of foundations and of retaining walls.

CIVL315.name: Fluid Mechanics II
CIVL315.desc: Two dimensional flow around immersed objects; velocity and pressure fields; lift and drag on cylinders and aerofoils; fluid loads on structures and structural response; pumps and turbines; analysis and design of pipeline systems; unsteady flow in pipes; frictionless waterhammer analysis.

CIVL316.name: Hydrology and Open Channel Flow
CIVL316.desc: Introduction to open channel hydraulics, engineering hydrology, and water resource systems; estimation of design discharge; flood statistics; nonuniform steady open channel flow; energy and momentum principles, backwater analysis; culvert and bridge hydraulics.

CIVL320.name: Civil Engineering Materials
CIVL320.desc: The structure and properties of common Civil Engineering materials: aggregates, Portland cement, concrete, asphalt, timber and metals. The emphasis is on the relationship between the structure of materials and their mechanical properties.

CIVL331.name: Steel and Timber Design
CIVL331.desc: Introduction to limit states design of steel and timber structures: material properties, design of tension and compression members, beams, columns, and connections.

CIVL332.name: Structural Analysis
CIVL332.desc: Introduction to indeterminate structural analysis; approximate analysis of structures; calculation of displacements using virtual work; flexibility (force) method; stiffness method for frames; moment distribution method; introduction to structural dynamics.

CIVL340.name: Transportation Engineering I
CIVL340.desc: The analysis and design of the elements of transportation facilities in development of transport technology; vehicle motion; vehicle/pavement interaction; elements of road design; principles of queuing and roadway capacity; rail transit performance and capacity analysis; economics as applied to transport.

CIVL402.name: Professionalism and Law in Civil Engineering
CIVL402.desc: The Engineers and Geoscientists Act; professional ethics, conflicts of interest, confidentiality and accountability; health and safety; sustainable development and environmental stewardship; equity considerations; design and construction contracts, specifications and tendering; labour and employment law; dispute resolution; evidence and expert witnesses; torts and legal liability.

CIVL403.name: Engineering Economic Analysis
CIVL403.desc: Time value of money; cash flow analysis; comparing options; depreciation, taxes, and inflation; financial accounting; company structures; public sector projects; decision-making.

CIVL404.name: Introduction to Solid Waste Management
CIVL404.desc: Characteristics of solid wastes; solid waste collection, treatment, and disposal; evaluation and analysis of landfills, composting, combined treatment, recycle, and re-use.

CIVL406.name: Water Treatment and Waste Management
CIVL406.desc: Processes used in water and wastewater treatment. Conditions which necessitate treatment of water or wastewater, water and wastewater treatment processes and plant design. Municipal services required and associated with solid waste management.

CIVL407.name: Environmental Laboratory Analysis
CIVL407.desc: Testing procedures used in water quality studies and in the operation of water and wastewater treatment plants.

CIVL408.name: Geo-Environmental Engineering
CIVL408.desc: Environmental contamination, regulatory requirements, site investigation, migration of contaminants, containment systems, site remediation technologies, design considerations related to soil-contaminant interactions, hydrogeology, geochemistry and types of contaminants. Design and performance case histories.

CIVL409.name: Municipal Engineering
CIVL409.desc: Design of municipal infrastructure, including streets, water supply networks, and sewers, garbage collection and solid waste management. Focus is on solutions for providing an adequate water supply, collecting and disposing of stormwater and sewage, and managing excess stormwater flow.

CIVL410.name: Foundation Engineering I
CIVL410.desc: An introduction to the process of foundation engineering. Empirical and analytical approaches used in current professional practice. Topics include site investigation, preloading, liquefaction assessment, ground improvement, design of shallow and deep foundations, and retaining structures. The importance of geology and technical communication are emphasized.

CIVL411.name: Foundation Engineering II
CIVL411.desc: Aspects of Geotechnical Engineering. Design considerations illustrated by case histories pertinent to BC. Topics include: site investigation, terrain analyses, in situ testing, groundwater problems, deep foundations, tie back walls and bracing, tailings impoundments, Northern construction, ground ice, dikes and dams engineering. Many case histories presented in part by prominent consulting engineers in BC.

CIVL413.name: Design of Earth Dams and Containment Structures
CIVL413.desc: Purpose and types of dams; design criteria; construction sequence; compaction; seepage; filter design; factors influencing the design of earth dams; stability and deformation under static and earthquake loading; slope protection; field instrumentation.

CIVL415.name: Water Resource Engineering
CIVL415.desc: An introduction to the planning and design of water resource systems, stream systems, and municipal and hydropower engineering.

CIVL416.name: Environmental Hydraulics
CIVL416.desc: Application of hydraulic engineering principles to problems of environmental concern. Pollutant transport and dispersion. Mixing in rivers and lakes. Theory of jets and plumes. Design of outfall diffusers.

CIVL417.name: Coastal Engineering
CIVL417.desc: General discussion of waves; linear wave theory; finite amplitude waves; standing waves; seiches; harbour design; wave shoaling, refraction and diffraction; beaches and coasts; wave statistics; wave generation; wave forces on piles, walls and breakwaters; tides; instrumentation and modelling techniques.

CIVL418.name: Engineering Hydrology
CIVL418.desc: Hydrologic processes - weather, precipitation, infiltration, evaporation, snowmelt and runoff generation. Emphasis on quantitative techniques including: hydrograph analysis, reservoir and channel routing, statistical methods and design floods, hydrologic modelling.

CIVL420.name: Concrete Technology
CIVL420.desc: Physical and chemical properties and microstructure of hydrated Portland cement; construction practices; modern use of industrial by-products such as fly ash, blast furnace slag, silica fume and metakaolin; use of chemical admixtures; environmental issues; properties of hardened concrete; issues in standardized and accelerated testing, non-destructive testing.

CIVL422.name: Project Based Learning in Civil Engineering Materials
CIVL422.desc: Some topical problems will be identified and students in groups will carry out experiments to study the materials involved. Site visits and external consultations are an integral requirement. [1-4-0]

CIVL425.name: Case Studies of Construction Methods
CIVL425.desc: Identification and evaluation of solutions to construction site operation problems: the relationship between design and construction; factors affecting productivity and safety; measurement of on-site performance. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 425 or CIVL 493. [3-0-0]

CIVL426.name: Virtual Design and Construction
CIVL426.desc: Creation and use of building information models (BIM) for managing the construction process.  3D parametric modeling, 4D modeling, design coordination, model-based cost estimating, BIM performance measurement, and integrated project delivery methods.

CIVL430.name: Design of Concrete Structures
CIVL430.desc: Non-linear response of reinforced concrete members subjected to axial load, bending and shear; design of simple one-way members including beams, columns, slabs and footings.

CIVL432.name: Advanced Structural Steel Design
CIVL432.desc: Design of steel structures to resist vertical and lateral loads. Floor and roof systems including conceptual layout, floor deck, beams, joists, trusses, and columns. Stability issues and limit states design. Connections and construction aspects. Seismic design.

CIVL433.name: Advanced Concrete Design
CIVL433.desc: Design of continuous reinforced concrete building frames and structures.

CIVL435.name: Advanced Structural Analysis
CIVL435.desc: Shear flow, shear deformation, St. Venant torsion, warping torsion, P-delta and geometric stiffness, buckling of columns and frames, cylindrical shells, beams on elastic foundation, shear wall analysis, elasto-plastic analysis. Introduction to the finite element method.

CIVL436.name: Matrix Structural Analysis and Dynamics
CIVL436.desc: Further techniques in matrix structural analysis; non-rigid supports, temperature-shrinkage effects, computer implementation; matrix representation of structural dynamics; mode shapes, natural frequencies, continuous systems; lumped mass models, modal analysis, response spectra.

CIVL437.name: Introduction to Ship Structures
CIVL437.desc: Structural theory and practice of ship structural design; longitudinal and transverse strength of hull girder; plates and shells; matrix analysis; introduction to classification society rules; ship section design synthesis; finite element analysis.

CIVL439.name: Design of Timber Structures
CIVL439.desc: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls.

CIVL440.name: Transportation Engineering II
CIVL440.desc: Traffic operations and network analysis: traffic studies and data design; traffic stream flow and roadway analysis; weaving and interchange ramp analysis; intersection traffic control measures and control design; progressive signal system design; flows prediction; road network simulation and assignment algorithms; motor vehicle accident analysis; field exercises.

CIVL441.name: Transportation Planning and Analysis
CIVL441.desc: Transportation systems planning and analysis: data needs; surveys and analysis; sampling techniques; trip generation; trip distribution; modal choice; trip assignment; traffic impact studies; system evaluation. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 441, CIVL 583 or PLAN 535.

CIVL445.name: Engineering Design and Analysis I
CIVL445.desc: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions.  Focus on conceptual designs.

CIVL446.name: Engineering Design and Analysis II
CIVL446.desc: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions.  Extends the conceptual design of CIVL 445 into detailed design projects.

CIVL447.name: Environmental Engineering Design and Analysis
CIVL447.desc: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions.  Extends the conceptual design of CIVL 445 into detailed environmental design projects.

CIVL478.name: Building Science
CIVL478.desc: Building science concepts associated with the design of modern buildings, focusing particularly on the building envelope's role in environmental separation, controlling the movement of heat, air, and water in liquid and vapour states.

CIVL492.name: Directed Studies in Civil Engineering
CIVL492.desc: Independent studies on a special topic.

CIVL498.name: Topics in Civil Engineering
CIVL498.desc: Seminar or lecture. Registration will take place on the first day of class by the Instructor.

EDST400.name: Social and Ethical Considerations in Education

EDST425.name: Educational Anthropology
EDST425.desc: Selected concepts from educational anthropology for teachers. Comparative study of school and classroom culture, school teaching, and multicultural education. Pass/Fail.

EDST426.name: History of Education
EDST426.desc: An examination of selected topics in the history of Canadian and British Columbian education and of the relationships between historical development and current educational policy. Pass/Fail.

EDST427.name: Philosophy of Education
EDST427.desc: An introductory course in which consideration is given to the philosophical foundations of education and to the practical bearing of theory upon curriculum content and classroom practice in our schools. Pass/Fail.

EDST428.name: The Social Foundations of Education
EDST428.desc: An application of the social sciences to the study of education. Pass/Fail.

EDST429.name: Educational Sociology
EDST429.desc: Selected theories of society and schooling applied to Canadian education. Pass/Fail.

EDST451.name: Issues and Frameworks in Environmental Education
EDST451.desc: Competing conceptions of environmental education; the social construction of nature and of science; addressing class, race, culture, and gender in developing sound teaching strategies. Pass/Fail.

EDST453.name: Moral Education in Elementary and Secondary Schooling
EDST453.desc: Approaches to moral education; developing educationally and morally justifiable teaching strategies. Pass/Fail.

EDST454.name: Critical Thinking: Frameworks, Methods, and Challenges
EDST454.desc: Competing conceptions of critical thinking, including feminist and post-colonial; teaching and evaluation strategies. Pass/Fail.

EDST493.name: Introduction to the Study of Higher Education
EDST493.desc: An overview of the field of study of higher education in Canada and other countries emphasizing current issues such as accessibility, enrolment, diversity of offerings, and internationalization. [3-0-0]

GEOG121.name: Geography, Environment and Globalization
GEOG121.desc: Human geography of the modern world with particular attention to human-environment relationships, urbanization, and regional growth; trade and communications; environment and war; environmental governance and sustainability.

GEOG122.name: Geography, Modernity and Globalization
GEOG122.desc: The human geography of the modern world since 1945: global interdependence in economic geography, geopolitics, and cultural geography; consequences of modernization, including demography, urbanization and environmental effects; regional case studies; reactions to modernization.

GEOG210.name: Vancouver and Its Region
GEOG210.desc: An integrated approach to the physical and human geography of the Lower Mainland of British Columbia. Field trips.

GEOG211.name: The State of the Earth
GEOG211.desc: The demographic, economic, ecological, and technological factors that underlie current environmental challenges, considering their effects to date and their possible impact in the future.
GEOG211.prer: One of GEOB 102, GEOB 103. GEOG 121, GEOG 122 recommended.  Second-year standing.

GEOG220.name: Geopolitics
GEOG220.desc: Political geographic perspectives on todays interdependent world through three themes: borders, regions, and flows.

GEOG250.name: Cities
GEOG250.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

GEOG281.name: Geography of the Pacific Rim
GEOG281.desc: An introduction to changing geographies (social, economic, and political) of the Pacific Rim, with special emphasis on the relationships between Canada and Japan.

GEOG290.name: Introduction to the Geography of Canada
GEOG290.desc: Selected topics in human geography focusing on the regional distribution of natural resources, population, urban systems, and economic activities.

GEOG310.name: Environment and Sustainability
GEOG310.desc: Concepts of environment, resources and sustainability; the roles of physical and human geography in understanding the interaction of humans and the environment; introduction to management of environment-resource systems.
GEOG310.prer: One of GEOB 102, GEOB 103. Or 6 credits in the Faculty of Science (BIOL, CHEM, EOSC, PHYS).

GEOG311.name: Urban Environments
GEOG311.desc: The impact of urban development on the natural environment and vice versa. Study of the ecology and metabolism of cities and green urban design, using global and local case studies.

GEOG312.name: Climate Change: Science and Society
GEOG312.desc: Climates over the geological, historical and instrument periods. Theories of climatic change. Monitoring and modelling the climate system. Impacts of change on environmental and socio-economic systems.
GEOG312.prer: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102, GEOG 200, GEOB 200, GEOG 204, GEOB 204, ATSC 201, EOSC 112. 3rd year standing.

GEOG315.name: Human and Environmental Geography Field Course
GEOG315.desc: Engage in primary field-based research in British Columbia on important issues concerning intercultural understanding, engagement with local communities and sustainability. Focus will shift on a bi-annual basis in accordance with location and available community partners. Special fees and liability insurance are required. Third year standing is recommended.

GEOG316.name: Geography of Natural Hazards
GEOG316.desc: The role of geophysical events, human ecology, environmental perception, world social and political order in explaining the risk of natural disasters. Assessment of acceptable risk, disaster relief and reconstruction and contrasts between developed and developing nations.
GEOG316.prer: Either (a) GEOG 101 or (b) all of GEOG 102, GEOG 103 or (c) all of GEOB 102, GEOB 103.

GEOG317.name: The Physical Environment of British Columbia
GEOG317.desc: The biophysical processes which are shaping and have shaped British Columbia; characteristic associations between landforms, climate, soil, and vegetation; biophysical constraints on air, land and water use.
GEOG317.prer: 6 credits from GEOG 102 (or GEOG 200 or 204) or GEOB 102 (or GEOB 200 or 204), GEOG 101, 103, 205, 207 or GEOB 103, 205, 207.

GEOG318.name: Sustainability in a Changing Environment
GEOG318.desc: Biophysical and human causes of short- and long-term environmental change at various spatial scales, including measurement, interpretation, and policy.

GEOG319.name: Environmental Impact Assessment
GEOG319.desc: The principles, implementation, and role of environmental impact assessment in environmental management, in Canada and internationally.

GEOG321.name: Historical Geography of Urbanization: Cities, Space, and Power
GEOG321.desc: From the origins of urbanism to the modern era.

GEOG327.name: Creating Canada
GEOG327.desc: Canada from the beginning of European contact to the mid-19th century, stressing the changing geographical patterns of settlement, economy, and culture.

GEOG328.name: Constructing Canada
GEOG328.desc: The construction of Canadian political space after Confederation, aboriginal-newcomer relations, regional development and conflict, industrialization, urbanization, and war.

GEOG329.name: Political Geography
GEOG329.desc: The heritage of political geography; the spatial structure of political organization including regional and global structures.
GEOG329.prer: One of GEOG 121, GEOG 122. Or Major and Honours students in History, International Relations or Political Science.

GEOG345.name: Theory and Practice in Human Geography
GEOG345.desc: A consideration of major intellectual issues and debates in the development of contemporary human geography, in relation to developments in other fields and changes in politics, culture and society.

GEOG350.name: Urban Worlds
GEOG350.desc: City systems and theories of urban location; internal spatial structure of the city; commercial and industrial location; social areas; neighbourhood and land use change; urban trends and public policy.

GEOG352.name: Urbanization in the Global South
GEOG352.desc: Urbanization in the developing countries of Latin America, Africa, and Asia; the role of cities in the development process and the features and problems of rapid urbanization.

GEOG353.name: Geographies of Migration and Settlement
GEOG353.desc: International regimes regulating migration, changes in global demographics, immigration policies of nation states, international migration patterns, settlement policies and outcomes.

GEOG357.name: Introduction to Social Geography
GEOG357.desc: The development of social and behavioural geography, focusing on how places, landscapes, and enviromments both reflect and shape social life.

GEOG361.name: Introduction to Economic Geography
GEOG361.desc: History and methods of economic geography. Location of resource industries, manufacturing, and service activities with emphasis on British Columbia in its North American and world setting. Recommended for students with no previous exposure to Economic Geography, before taking other courses in the 36x and 46x series.

GEOG362.name: Geography of Economic Development
GEOG362.desc: Geographical approaches to economic development; models of economic development and spatial change; influences on spatial economic change; case studies from the developed, third, and socialist worlds.

GEOG364.name: Globalization, Cities, and Regions
GEOG364.desc: Forms of economic development; changing location of economic activities and functions; implications for government and politics; local strategies for growth and equity.
GEOG364.prer: One of GEOG 121, GEOG 122. GEOG 361 is recommended.

GEOG371.name: Research Strategies in Human Geography
GEOG371.desc: Formulating a research problem and selecting an appropriate research strategy. Research strategies range from social scientific survey methods to ethnography. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography.

GEOG374.name: Statistics in Geography
GEOG374.desc: Introduction to statistical techniques and their application to geographical problems. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

GEOG379.name: Field Course in Human Geography
GEOG379.desc: As announced by the department a year in advance.

GEOG380.name: Geography of Asia
GEOG380.desc: A comparative regional analysis stressing the historical development and changing cultural, economic, and political patterns of the area. Special reference to India, Indonesia, China, and Japan.

GEOG390.name: Geography of Selected Regions
GEOG390.desc: A geographical analysis of selected regions not regularly included in the Department's offerings in regional geography (e.g., tropical Africa, Oceania). Students should consult the Department regarding regions to be covered.

GEOG391.name: Modern Europe: Places and Borders
GEOG391.desc: An introductory survey, focusing on the present-day human geography of the area between the Atlantic and the Ural Mountains.

GEOG395.name: Culture, Nature, and Coloniality in Latin America
GEOG395.desc: Socio-ecologies in 1491; Spanish colonialism and biological imperialism; contemporary coloniality and neoliberalism; and social movements.

GEOG410.name: Environment and Society
GEOG410.desc: Geographical analysis of society-environment relations. Relates resource management to environmental politics, political economy, and sustainable development. Perspectives drawn from political ecology and political economy, environmental history and environmental philosophy.

GEOG412.name: Water Management: Theory, Policy, and Practice
GEOG412.desc: Interdisciplinary analysis of critical water issues, in Canada and internationally.  Focus on social science perspectives.  Emphasis on presentation, research, and essay-writing skills.

GEOG419.name: Research in Environmental Geography
GEOG419.desc: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
GEOG419.prer: Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor.

GEOG423.name: Development of Environmental Thought
GEOG423.desc: An examination of how attitudes toward human nature and non-human nature have changed from Mesolithic times to the present in Western society.

GEOG424.name: Feminist Geographies
GEOG424.desc: An introductory survey of contemporary feminist approaches to human geography.

GEOG426.name: Historical Geography of British Columbia, I
GEOG426.desc: Colonialism, resistance, and land use in early British Columbia.

GEOG429.name: Research in Historical Geography
GEOG429.desc: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
GEOG429.prer: Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor.

GEOG442.name: Student Directed Seminar in Human Geography
GEOG442.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in human geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars."  Credit will not be granted for both Geog 442 and Geog 443.

GEOG446.name: Topics in Geography
GEOG446.desc: See the departmental undergraduate adviser for details.

GEOG447.name: Directed Studies: Off Campus Research
GEOG447.desc: Based on project work outside the university. Not available to co-op students. See the departmental undergraduate adviser for details.
GEOG447.prer: Permission of the department head and at least 15 credits of relevant 300- or 400- level Geography courses.

GEOG448.name: Directed Studies in Geography
GEOG448.desc: For fourth-year students in Geography to permit investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.
GEOG448.prer: Permission of the department head and supervising faculty member is required.

GEOG450.name: Urban Research
GEOG450.desc: Individual or group primary research. Instructor and content vary and it may be offered over 2 terms. Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor from April 1preceding the course. Not necessarily offered each year.
GEOG450.prer: Registered as Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits completed.

GEOG453.name: Political Geographic Analysis
GEOG453.desc: Political organization of space; territorial and spatial patterns of power and identity; contemporary geopolitical struggles.

GEOG456.name: Film and the City
GEOG456.desc: The complex interrelations between film and the city; dominant urban theories, film technologies and viewing practices and the intersections between them.

GEOG457.name: Social and Behavioural Geography
GEOG457.desc: Theories of social change in the global city; labour markets; poverty and inequality; social polarization; housing markets; gentrification and housing affordability; immigration and segregation; diversity and multiculturalism; transnationalism; the entrepreneurial state; the convivial city.

GEOG461.name: Political-Economic Geographies
GEOG461.desc: Principal theories and debates in contemporary political-economic geography, with particular emphasis on global and regional transformations.

GEOG468.name: Geography of International Economic Systems: Canada and the Pacific Basin
GEOG468.desc: An introduction to the study of international economic systems illustrated by the study of Canada's relations with the countries located in the Pacific Basin. Normally alternates with GEOG 481.

GEOG481.name: Geography of Japan
GEOG481.desc: A critical analysis of significant human adaptations to changing ecological conditions in the Japanese archipelago. Normally alternates with GEOG 468.

GEOG484.name: Geography of Southeast Asia
GEOG484.desc: A critical analysis of significant features of political, economic, and cultural development in the region from pre-colonial times to the present.

GEOG485.name: Geography of China
GEOG485.desc: An introduction to the changing cultural, social and economic geography of China. Normally alternates with GEOG 425.

GEOG493.name: Contemporary Europe: Identity and Geopolitics
GEOG493.desc: Political, economic, and social geographies of post Cold War Europe with a special emphasis on east-central Europe: societal transformations in the formerly socialist states; European Union and NATO enlargement; the external relations of these two organizations.

GEOG495.name: Geographies of Social Movements in the Americas
GEOG495.desc: The politics of North-South solidarity in theory and practice through community service learning models.

GEOG496.name: Geography of Africa
GEOG496.desc: A critical introduction to social, political and economic geographies of Africa from pre-colonial times to the present, with a focus on contemporary environmental and development issues.
GEOG496.prer: One of GEOG 329, GEOG 350. GEOG 362 is recommended.

GEOG497.name: The Arctic
GEOG497.desc: Physical and biological characteristics of the circumpolar Arctic, emphasizing terrestrial environments and the impacts on and by humans, including: glacial history; climatology; biogeography/ecology of arctic tundra; human-environment interactions, settlement and exploration; and current environmental, social and economic problems.

GEOG498.name: Geographies of the Middle East
GEOG498.desc: Critical analysis of economic, social, and political development and processes defining the modern Middle East region.

CTLN301.name: Catalan Language and Culture
CTLN301.desc: Introduction to the Catalan language and important aspects of the culture of Catalonia. Languages of instruction: English and Catalan.

THTR120.name: Introduction to Theatre
THTR120.desc: Theory and practice of the theatrical arts. Attendance at plays is required.

THTR150.name: Introduction to Technical Production
THTR150.desc: Foundation study of production technologies for the performing arts.

THTR205.name: Graphics for Theatre and Film Design

THTR210.name: Drama: Forms and Ideas I
THTR210.desc: The Anatomy of Drama: Its history, aesthetic principles, performative potential.

THTR211.name: Drama: Forms and Ideas II
THTR211.desc: Topics in comparative drama; drama and the other performing arts; dramaturgy.

THTR245.name: Play-Interpretation and Production-Analysis
THTR245.desc: Basic methods of interpreting dramatic texts and analyzing plays in performance. The plays presented on the Frederic Wood Stage will be studied in this course.

THTR250.name: Technical Production
THTR250.desc: The construction and execution of scenery, costumes, properties, lighting, and sound for the stage.

THTR271.name: Beginning B.F.A. Acting I
THTR271.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

THTR272.name: Beginning B.F.A. Acting II
THTR272.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR273.name: Beginning Voice and Movement I
THTR273.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

THTR274.name: Beginning Voice and Movement II
THTR274.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR301.name: Styles of Decor and Dress
THTR301.desc: Artistic, decorative, cultural, and social contexts of selected theatrical genres and periods.

THTR305.name: Scenery Design I
THTR305.desc: Principles and practice of scenery design for the performing arts.

THTR306.name: Costume Design I
THTR306.desc: Principles and practice of costume design for the performing arts.

THTR307.name: Lighting Design I
THTR307.desc: The optical, distribution, and control systems used in stage lighting design.

THTR308.name: Sound Design
THTR308.desc: Audio design and production for theatre and other performance forms.

THTR310.name: Theory of Drama Performance
THTR310.desc: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on dramatic theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

THTR311.name: Studies in Drama
THTR311.desc: Topics will vary from year to year.

THTR317.name: Introduction to Directing
THTR317.prer: One of THTR 130, THTR 230 and THTR 299.

THTR320.name: History of Theatre I
THTR320.desc: Core concepts in world theatre history and the development of theatre prior to the nineteenth century.

THTR339.name: Creating Theatre I
THTR339.desc: Study and practice of processes and forms used to create ensemble performance.

THTR340.name: Studies in Non-Western Theatre
THTR340.desc: Open to all students in third year and above.

THTR352.name: Scene Painting I
THTR352.desc: Media, techniques, and textural treatments used in scene painting.

THTR354.name: Stage Management
THTR354.desc: Principles and procedures of stage management: organizations, systems, and operations.

THTR356.name: Costume Construction
THTR356.desc: Advanced assembly and specialized construction methods for producing costume for stage and screen.

THTR371.name: Intermediate B.F.A. Acting I
THTR371.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR371.prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR372.name: Intermediate B.F.A. Acting II
THTR372.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR373.name: Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement I
THTR373.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR373.prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR374.name: Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement II
THTR374.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR391.name: Rehearsal and Performance
THTR391.desc: Open only to  B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR391.prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR399.name: Production II
THTR399.desc: Assigned projects in theatre design and production.
THTR399.crer: One of THTR 305, THTR 306, THTR 307, THTR 308, THTR 350, THTR 352, THTR 354, THTR 356.

THTR405.name: Scenery Design II
THTR405.desc: Exploration of complex scenery design and development of design portfolio.

THTR406.name: Costume Design II
THTR406.desc: Complex problems and selected historical studies in costume design.

THTR407.name: Lighting Design II
THTR407.desc: Complex design and advanced technologies in stage lighting and scenography.

THTR408.name: Advanced Study in Design and Scenography
THTR408.desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consent of Department required.

THTR410.name: Dramaturgy
THTR410.desc: Advanced problems in dramaturgy, both in a historical and a contemporary context.

THTR417.name: Directing Lab
THTR417.prer: THTR 317. Permission of the instructor is required for admission to this course.

THTR420.name: History of Theatre II
THTR420.desc: Key movements in world theatre history from the nineteenth century to the present.

THTR421.name: History of Theatre from 1900 to the present
THTR421.desc: The development of Western Theatre from 1900 to the present

THTR430.name: Theory of Drama and Performance
THTR430.desc: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on theatrical theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

THTR439.name: Creating Theatre
THTR439.desc: Ensemble creation culminating in the presentation of a theatrical work. Permission of the instructor is required.

THTR440.name: Topics in Theatre
THTR440.desc: An examination in depth of a selected area of theatre history, theory or practice. Topics will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.
THTR440.prer: 6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above.

THTR443.name: Women in Theatre and Film
THTR443.desc: A course dealing with women's involvement in and contribution to various aspects of Theatre and/or Film Topics will change from year to year.

THTR448.name: Directed Studies in Theatre Theory and Practice

THTR450.name: Scenery Production II
THTR450.desc: Technical direction; complex techniques and problems in scenery production.

THTR452.name: Scene Painting II
THTR452.desc: Study of selected scene painting styles.

THTR454.name: Production and Theatre Management
THTR454.desc: Production and theatre management with emphasis on budgeting, publicity, scheduling, press relations, special events, legal issues, season selection, resumes and interpersonal skills.

THTR456.name: Costume Construction II
THTR456.desc: Pattern development and cutting for costume for stage and screen using flat pattern and draping.

THTR469.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
THTR469.desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

THTR471.name: Advanced B.F.A. Acting I
THTR471.prer: All of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

THTR472.name: Advanced B.F.A. Acting II
THTR472.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR473.name: Advanced Speech and Movement I
THTR473.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR473.prer: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

THTR474.name: Advanced Speech and Movement II
THTR474.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR491.name: Advanced Rehearsal and Performance
THTR491.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR491.prer: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

THTR499.name: Production III
THTR499.desc: Assigned projects in Theatre or Film design and production.
THTR499.crer: One of THTR 405, THTR 406, THTR 407, THTR 408, THTR 450, THTR 452, THTR 454, THTR 456, THTR 470.

SEAL440.name: Supervised Study in Southeast Asian Languages

PHIL100.name: Introduction to Philosophy
PHIL100.desc: Basic problems and methods of Philosophy. Topics such as the existence of God, the nature and scope of human knowledge, the relationship between mind and body, personal identity, free will, issues and problems in moral philosophy. Credit will not be granted for both PHIL 100 and either or both PHIL 101 or PHIL 102.

PHIL101.name: Introduction to Philosophy
PHIL101.desc: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as the nature and scope of human knowledge, the existence of God, and the relationship between mind and body. Credit will not be given for both PHIL 100 and 101.

PHIL102.name: Introduction to Philosophy II
PHIL102.desc: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as morality, personal identity, free will and determinism, and the meaning of life. Credit will not be given for both PHIL 100 and 102.

PHIL120.name: Introduction to Critical Thinking
PHIL120.desc: Tools for dealing with both everyday and more technical arguments and concepts. Analysis and resolution of confusions, ambiguities, and fallacies. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

PHIL125.name: Introduction to Scientific Reasoning
PHIL125.desc: Historical and logical analysis of various types of scientific hypotheses and the data that support or undermine them. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

PHIL211.name: Greek Philosophy I
PHIL211.desc: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato.  Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.

PHIL212.name: Greek Philosophy II
PHIL212.desc: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.

PHIL220.name: Symbolic Logic
PHIL220.desc: Sentential and predicate logic. Translation from natural language; truth tables and interpretations; systems of natural deduction up to relational predicate logic with identity; alternative proof methods. Some sections may use computer-based materials and tests.

PHIL230.name: Introduction to Ethics
PHIL230.desc: Theories of obligation and value; moral reasoning; normative ethics, descriptive ethics and meta-ethics. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL235.name: Contemporary Moral Issues
PHIL235.desc: Moral issues such as life and death decisions, paternalism, markets, animal welfare, technology, and global justice.

PHIL240.name: Introduction to Epistemology
PHIL240.desc: Topics in epistemology such as skepticism, truth, justification, a priori and a posteriori knowledge. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL250.name: Minds and Machines
PHIL250.desc: Philosophical and theoretical issues that pertain to how mental phenomena fit into the material world. Examine questions such as whether a sophisticated enough computer should be deemed a conscious intelligent being. Focus on philosophical literature on consciousness, intelligence, animal minds, and the mind-body relation. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 250 or PHIL 150.

PHIL260.name: Science and Society in the Contemporary World
PHIL260.desc: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year.

PHIL310.name: The Philosophy of Plato
PHIL310.desc: A study of Plato's dialogues and his influence on subsequent philosophy.

PHIL311.name: The Philosophy of Aristotle
PHIL311.desc: A study of Aristotle's writings and his influence on subsequent philosophy.

PHIL313.name: Medieval Philosophy
PHIL313.desc: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the 14th century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham.

PHIL314.name: Philosophy in the 17th Century
PHIL314.desc: Survey of 17th-century philosophy from Bacon to Leibniz, including the writings of Hobbes, Descartes, and Spinoza. The influence of science and religion on philosophical thought.

PHIL315.name: Philosophy in the 18th Century
PHIL315.desc: Survey of 18th-century philosophy from Locke to Kant, including the writings of Berkeley, Rousseau, and Hume. The influence of science and religion on philosophy.

PHIL316.name: Philosophy After 1800
PHIL316.desc: Survey of 19th and 20th century philosophy. May include Hegel, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Mill, Meinong, Brentano, the British Idealists, Russell, and Moore. Social and political currents in 19th century philosophical thought.

PHIL320.name: Logic: Metatheory and Computability
PHIL320.desc: Continuation of PHIL 220. A system of deduction for predicate logic is selected for further study. Completeness of this system and other metatheoretic results are proved. Other topics include computability, recursive function theory, incompleteness and decidability.

PHIL321.name: Induction, Decision and Game Theory
PHIL321.desc: Formal methods relevant to probabilistic and inductive reasoning. Decision theory, game theory, axiomatic probability theory and its interpretations, belief dynamics, simulation and modelling.
PHIL321.prer: One of PHIL 125, PHIL 220 or instructor permission.

PHIL322.name: Modal Logic
PHIL322.desc: Logic of the modal operators "It is necessary that" and "It is possible that." Possible-world semantics and a method of derivation for this logic.

PHIL323.name: Non-Classical Logics
PHIL323.desc: One or more of conditional logic, deontic logic, epistemic logic, many-valued logic, systems of belief dynamics.

PHIL324.name: Philosophy of Logic
PHIL324.desc: Fundamental concepts and methods of logic; the logistic method, syntax and semantics; the conditional; entailment; consequence; modal logic; problems concerning extensionality and intentionality. Frege's distinction between sense and reference; Russell's theory of definite descriptions; Tarski's definition of truth.

PHIL326.name: Philosophy of Language I
PHIL326.desc: Philosophical discussion of language, meaning, and communication. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 326 or PHIL 425.
PHIL326.prer: 9 credits of PHIL/LING at the 200-level or above.

PHIL330.name: Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL330.desc: Theories of political and legal obligation and authority, legal reasoning, society and the state. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL331.name: Business and Professional Ethics
PHIL331.desc: Moral problems in contemporary business and professional practice, general moral theory, the law, and policy formation. Corporate social and environmental responsibility, employee rights, preferential hiring and affirmative action programs, conflicts of interest, advertising, "whistle blowing" and self-regulation. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 331 or PHIL 434.

PHIL332.name: Environmental Ethics
PHIL332.desc: Moral problems arising in the context of human relationships to nature and to non-human living things, considered in terms of both general moral theory and policy formation. Topics include moral standing, animal rights, obligations to future generations, pollution, hazardous materials, the depletion of natural resources and the treatment of non-human living things. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 332 or PHIL 435.

PHIL333.name: Bio-Medical Ethics
PHIL333.desc: Moral problems arising in the health sciences, especially in medicine but also in biology, psychology, and social work. Topics include abortion, death and euthanasia, genetic engineering, behaviour modification, compulsory treatment, experimentation with human beings and animals, and the relationship between professionals and their patients, subjects or clients. No philosophical background is required. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 333 or PHIL 433.

PHIL334.name: Sex, Gender and Philosophy
PHIL334.desc: Relationship between sex, gender, and philosophy. Topics may include ethics, epistemology, science, social relations, law, and personhood.

PHIL335.name: Power and Oppression
PHIL335.desc: Philosophical approaches to historical problems of inequality and social harm, with readings drawn from historical and contemporary sources. Topics to be studied may include slavery, colonialism, labour, and the position of women in society.

PHIL338.name: Philosophy of Law
PHIL338.desc: Concepts of law, constitution and sovereignty; law and morality; natural law theories and legal positivism; obligation, responsibility, and punishment.
PHIL338.prer: Restricted to second- or higher-year standing.

PHIL339.name: Philosophy of Art
PHIL339.desc: Topics include art and perception, art and reality, imagination, expression, censorship, and the role of art in human life.

PHIL340.name: Introduction to Metaphysics
PHIL340.desc: Topics in metaphysics such as the nature of physical reality, personal identity, the mind/body problem, free will, causation and action theory. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL347.name: Philosophy of Religion
PHIL347.desc: A critical and analytical examination of arguments for and arguments against the existence of God, and other related topics. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 347 or PHIL 349.

PHIL360.name: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
PHIL360.desc: An examination of historical, conceptual and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.

PHIL362.name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Aristotle to Adam Smith
PHIL362.desc: The development of economic thought from Aristotle to Adam Smith, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution, and economic growth.

PHIL363.name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes
PHIL363.desc: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present, including such figures as Malthus, Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.

PHIL364.name: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
PHIL364.desc: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

PHIL369.name: Philosophy of Science
PHIL369.desc: Issues common to all sciences. Philosophical questions including the character of scientific laws, theories and revolutions, the nature of scientific confirmation, causality, explanation and prediction, and the use of logic and probability. Difficulties in the interpretation of atomic physics and questions about relationships between biology and psychology. No philosophical background is assumed. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 369 or PHIL 460.

PHIL371.name: Foundations of Chinese Thought
PHIL371.desc: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) in its historical and cultural contexts. Includes among others: Confucius; Mo Zi; the Legalists/Authoritarians; Zhuang Zi; the Lao Zi book.

PHIL375.name: Philosophy and Literature
PHIL375.desc: Philosophical issues in works of literature or arising from theories of literary interpretation. Topics include issues relating to relativism, the nature of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of the emotions.

PHIL378.name: Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
PHIL378.desc: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic Period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems.  Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

PHIL385.name: Existentialism
PHIL385.desc: Meaning, identity and alienation as explored in the works for example of Kierkegaard, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Sartre, and Camus.

PHIL388.name: Buddhist, Brahmanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction
PHIL388.desc: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

PHIL400.name: Morals, Politics and the Individual
PHIL400.desc: Introduction to major themes in moral and political philosophy. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 400, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.

PHIL401.name: Knowledge, Explanation, and the Nature of Things
PHIL401.desc: Introduction to major themes in epistemology and metaphysics. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 401, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.

PHIL410.name: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
PHIL410.desc: Advanced study of the Presocratics, or of a philosopher such as Plato, or of a school such as the Sceptics or Stoics. Topics vary from year to year.

PHIL412.name: Topics in Medieval Philosophy
PHIL412.desc: Advanced study of a medieval philosopher such as Aquinas, or school.

PHIL414.name: Topics in the History of Modern Philosophy
PHIL414.desc: Intensive study of a major philosopher or school such as Descartes, Hume, Empiricism, Rationalism, or the British utilitarians.

PHIL416.name: Topics in 19th-Century Philosophy
PHIL416.desc: Study of a major 19th-century philosopher such as Hegel, Mill or Nietzsche, or school, such as German Idealism.
PHIL416.prer: One of PHIL 314, PHIL 315, PHIL 316, PHIL 340.

PHIL418.name: Topics in Twentieth-Century Philosophy
PHIL418.desc: Intensive study of a major philosopher such as Wittgenstein, Russell, or Heidegger, or school, such as pragmatism or logical empiricism.

PHIL419.name: Philosophy of History
PHIL419.desc: Concepts of history and historical explanation, historical progress, purpose, necessity, law and causation. Hegel, Marx, Vico, Spengler, Pareto, Collingwood, Croce, and Toynbee, as well as contemporary figures. Students will be expected to have an adequate knowledge of ancient or modern history.

PHIL420.name: Topics in Symbolic Logic
PHIL420.desc: Formal semantics, proof theory, incompleteness and decidability, axiomatic set theory, independence results. Consult the Department as to which topics are offered in a given year.

PHIL426.name: Topics in Philosophy of Language
PHIL426.desc: Advanced topics in the philosophy of language.
PHIL426.prer: PHIL 326. And 6 credits of PHIL/LING at the 200-level or above.

PHIL427.name: Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL427.desc: Logicism, formalism and constructivism, implications of metatheorems such as those of Gödel and Church, mathematical truth, mathematics and mental construction, mathematics and the physical world.
PHIL427.prer: Philosophy or mathematics courses totaling 9 credits at the 200-level or above.

PHIL431.name: Topics in Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL431.desc: Central concepts and problems in political life and thought including obligation, citizenship, representation, justice; equality; civil rights and liberty; disobedience.
PHIL431.prer: 9 credits of PHIL/POLI at the 200-level or above.

PHIL432.name: Topics in Ethical Theory
PHIL432.desc: Classic or contemporary works in ethical theory.
PHIL432.prer: 9 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above; PHIL 230 is recommended.

PHIL440.name: Topics in Epistemology
PHIL440.desc: Analysis of the concept of knowledge; problems of justifying ordinary and basic empirical beliefs.

PHIL441.name: Philosophy of Perception
PHIL441.desc: The contribution of the senses to knowledge of the external world; the nature of perception and its contribution to empirical knowledge.
PHIL441.prer: PHIL 240 or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.

PHIL448.name: Topics in Continental Philosophy
PHIL448.desc: A study of European philosophers from amongst Husserl, Heidegger, Habermas, Foucault, Derrida, Lacan, Levinas, and others. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 448 or PHIL 449.

PHIL450.name: Topics in Metaphysics
PHIL450.desc: Topics including ontology, universals and particulars, substance, determinism and indeterminism, identity over time, and theories of truth.
PHIL450.prer: 9 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above. PHIL 340 is recommended.

PHIL451.name: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL451.desc: The nature of the mental and physical; the relation between minds and bodies; the character of psychological explanation.
PHIL451.prer: PHIL 240 or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above.

PHIL452.name: Philosophy of Action
PHIL452.desc: Explanation of human actions; the conditions of responsibility; freedom of the will; the domains of rational and moral appraisal; the category of action and the individuation of actions.

PHIL455.name: Topics in the Philosophy of Cognitive Science
PHIL455.desc: Philosophical topics in the cognitive sciences, such as empiricism vs. nativism, consciousness, mental representation, cognitive architecture, language & thought, and situated cognition.
PHIL455.prer: PHIL 240 or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.  Recommended: PHIL 441 or PHIL 451.

PHIL461.name: Philosophy of Social Science
PHIL461.desc: Topics in the philosophy of science of special concern to the social and behavioural sciences; hypotheses and explanation; principles, theories, models; the formation of scientific concepts; the function of mathematics in social science.
PHIL461.prer: 9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology.

PHIL462.name: Space and Time
PHIL462.desc: Such topics as: Are space and time continuous? Is motion always relative to another body? Does time flow? Is time irreversible?
PHIL462.prer: PHIL 340 or 12 credits of mathematics or science.

PHIL464.name: Philosophy of Biology
PHIL464.desc: Methodological, historical, philosophical and social science questions about biology. Credit will be given for only one of PHIL 464 or BIOL 446.
PHIL464.prer: Fourth-year standing in any degree program or 9 credits of philosophy.

PHIL469.name: Topics in Philosophy of Science
PHIL469.desc: Topics such as probability and induction; foundations of measurement; theory construction.

PHIL470.name: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
PHIL470.desc: Ways in which the 'self' has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsün-tzu), Nietzche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

PHIL491.name: Seminar for Majors in Philosophy
PHIL491.desc: Selected problems in philosophy, with attention to methods of research. Check with the department for specific topics. Primarily for fourth-year Philosophy Major students, but also open to Philosophy Honours.

JRNL100.name: New Media and Society
JRNL100.desc: Development of new media technologies, their applications, and their cultural, political, and social impacts.

CNTO301.name: Basic Cantonese I
CNTO301.desc: Elementary level (part I) course in Cantonese for non-heritage learners with no prior exposure to or background in Cantonese. Focus on training for basic listening and conversational skills in Cantonese.
CNTO301.prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 233, CHIN 108, CHIN 234. Or placement approval.

CNTO303.name: Basic Cantonese II
CNTO303.desc: Elementary level (part II) Cantonese for non-heritage learners. Continuation of CNTO 301. Focus on training for basic listening, conversational, and reading skills.

CNTO311.name: Basic Cantonese for Mandarin Speakers
CNTO311.desc: Basic oral and presentation skills in Cantonese. This is an accelerated course that covers content and topics similar to CNTO 301 and CNTO 303, but is structured specifically for heritage speakers of Mandarin.
CNTO311.prer: One of CHIN 243, CHIN 244. Or placement approval.

CNTO401.name: Intermediate Cantonese I
CNTO401.desc: Intermediate lower level (part I) Cantonese for non-heritage learners.
CNTO401.prer: One of CNTO 303, CNTO 311. Or placement approval.

CNTO403.name: Intermediate Cantonese II
CNTO403.desc: Intermediate lower level (part II) Cantonese for non-heritage learners. Continuation of CNTO 401.

CNTO451.name: Advanced Cantonese through Popular Culture
CNTO451.desc: Popular culture in Hong Kong from media such as television, cinema, popular music, literature, social media, etc., through advanced authentic Cantonese listening and reading materials.  Open to non-heritage and heritage speakers of Mandarin and/or Cantonese.
CNTO451.prer: CNTO 401. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework is strongly recommended.

URST200.name: Cities
URST200.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization.  Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

URST400.name: Seminar in Urban Studies
URST400.desc: A seminar for senior students who wish to explore some common topics of importance to urban studies from the viewpoints of several disciplines.

PERS100.name: Basic Persian I
PERS100.desc: Basic vocabulary and the fundamentals of modern Persian grammar, structure, and pronunciation, as well as reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

PERS104.name: Persian Reading and Writing for Persian-Speaking Students
PERS104.desc: Reading and writing of standard Tehran Persian; lexical and syntactic differences between written and spoken Persian.  This course prepares students for PERS 300.
PERS104.prer: Basic knowledge of spoken Persian and consent of instructor.

PERS200.name: Intermediate Persian I
PERS200.desc: Reading of simple texts with emphasis on reading and writing, conversation skills, grammar, and syntax.

PERS300.name: Advanced Persian I
PERS300.desc: Graded reading, writing, exposure to the writing system, textual history, newspaper reading, and translation. Cultural materials presented as appropriate. The art of calligraphy introduced.

PERS400.name: Persian Short Story for Native and Heritage Speakers
PERS400.desc: Literary works from mid-19th century to present. Restricted to native or heritage speakers of Persian.

SOAL100.name: Khichri: The South Asian Languages of Vancouver
SOAL100.desc: A systematic introduction to the grammars and scripts of Hindi, Urdu, Punjabi and Sanskrit, primarily through the media of Indo-Canadian popular culture (film, radio, bhangra, etc.)

SOAL440.name: Supervised Study in South Asian Languages

ISCI300.name: Interdisciplinary Seminar
ISCI300.desc: Critical analysis of recent scientific literature that combines disciplines that students are integrating in their Integrated Sciences Curriculum.

ISCI311.name: The Size of Things
ISCI311.desc: Scaling as a general approach to laws governing the geometry, kinematics and dynamics of systems. Dimensional analysis, isometry and allometry applied to topics from Biology, Physics, Earth Science and Economics. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
ISCI311.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

ISCI320.name: Research Development Project
ISCI320.desc: Retreat to develop skills in writing scientific research proposals.  Emphasis on formulating and testing hypotheses to explain observations.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to retreat.
ISCI320.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

ISCI322.name: Science of Measurement and Instrumentation
ISCI322.desc: Interactive course integrating diverse aspects of science: semi-quantitative overview of physical principles underlying modern measurement technology; philosophy of measurement; accuracy and limits to measurement, and resultant scientific, sociological and economic consequences. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program.
ISCI322.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

ISCI330.name: Topics in Integrated Sciences
ISCI330.desc: Interactive examination of a theme common to all areas of science. Themes will change from year to year. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [3-0-0]
ISCI330.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI344.name: Theory and Practice of Games in Economics and Evolution
ISCI344.desc: Exploration of human and animal interactions: integrating evolutionary and economic perspectives to investigate individual and social behaviour.  Credit will be given for only one of ECON 221 or ISCI 344. [3-0-0]

ISCI345.name: Integrative Bioinformatics
ISCI345.desc: Storage and processing of information in biological systems. Computational methods for recovering and interpreting stored genetic information. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
ISCI345.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

ISCI350.name: Darwinian Medicine
ISCI350.desc: Using the Darwinian theory of natural selection to explore explanations of infectious diseases, allergies, cancer, mental illness, and other human diseases. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
ISCI350.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

ISCI360.name: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
ISCI360.desc: Application of systems science encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems approaches to study regional sustainability. [3-0-0]
ISCI360.prer: Third-year or higher standing in the Faculty of Science.

ISCI361.name: Field Course: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
ISCI361.desc: Systems science approaches encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems to investigate a selected region of the world.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to field course.

ISCI398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
ISCI398.desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Normally taken in Winter Session of third year or Summer Session after third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students in the ISP Co-op program.

ISCI399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
ISCI399.desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

ISCI422.name: Models in Science
ISCI422.desc: Meaning, nature, use, strengths and limitations of models as investigative tools in all scientific disciplines. Detailed investigation of selected model systems from different scientific disciplines. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
ISCI422.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

ISCI433.name: Ethical Issues in Science
ISCI433.desc: Theoretical and practical consideration of ethics in the practice, reporting, public impact and accountability of science. [3-0-0]

ISCI448.name: Directed Studies
ISCI448.desc: Permission of the Director is required.

ISCI490.name: Student Directed Seminars
ISCI490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. [3-0-0]
ISCI490.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.

ISCI498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
ISCI498.desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months.  Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

ISCI499.name: Co-Operative Work Placement IV
ISCI499.desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

APSC100.name: Introduction to Engineering I
APSC100.desc: An introduction to the engineering profession including: roles and responsibilities of the engineer, the engineering disciplines, sustainability, an introduction to the engineering design process, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, prototyping, engineering graphics, technical communication, and engineering ethics.

APSC101.name: Introduction to Engineering II
APSC101.desc: An introduction to the engineering profession including: the engineering design process, sustainability, prototype testing, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, team functioning, engineering graphics, and technical communication.

APSC110.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC110.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC122.name: Introduction to Engineering
APSC122.desc: Non-credit course designed to introduce students to Engineering. Information on the Faculty, the profession and the particular skills and type of work done by practising engineers in different disciplines. [1-0-0]

APSC150.name: Engineering Case Studies
APSC150.desc: Application of scientific principles and technical knowledge to practical problems. Introduction to the engineering design process and to engineering graphics.

APSC151.name: Computer-Aided Engineering Graphics
APSC151.desc: Orthographic projection, technical sketching, development of the ability to visualize in three dimensions. Standards and conventions of engineering drawing, graphical presentation of engineering data. Micro-computer based graphics aids. Engineering geometry and the solution of space problems.

APSC160.name: Introduction to Computation in Engineering Design
APSC160.desc: Analysis and simulation, laboratory data acquisition and processing, measurement interfaces, engineering tools, computer systems organization, programming languages. Credit will only be given for one of: APSC 160, CPSC 301, or EOSC 211.

APSC172.name: Engineering Analysis I
APSC172.desc: Functions, limits, differentiation, applications of derivatives, integration, applications of definite integrals.

APSC173.name: Engineering Analysis II
APSC173.desc: Integrals and transcendental functions, techniques of integration, applications of integration, polar coordinates, infinite sequences and series, vectors and the geometry of space, and partial derivatives.

APSC176.name: Engineering Communication
APSC176.desc: Purpose, audience, content, format, and tone are studied, as are team-based report writings and presentations. Community Service Learning projects are integrated into existing assignments. An LPI level 5 is required for registration in this course.

APSC178.name: Electricity, Magnetism, and Waves
APSC178.desc: Coulomb's law, electric field, Gauss' law, electric potential, conductors, capacitance, electric currents, resistance, DC circuits, magnetic fields and forces, sources of magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction, mechanical waves, electromagnetic waves, light propagation, geometrical optics.

APSC179.name: Linear Algebra for Engineers
APSC179.desc: Systems of linear equations, Gaussian elimination, engineering application of linear algebra, matrix operations, special matrices, determinants, vector space, orthogonality, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, linear transformation. [3-0-0]

APSC180.name: Statics
APSC180.desc: Force vectors, Cartesian coordinate system, free body diagram, dot and cross products, forces equilibrium of particles, force and moment equilibrium of rigid bodies, analysis of trusses, frames and machines, friction, wedges, pulleys, and belts. Applications of linear algebra in statics.

APSC182.name: Matter and Energy I
APSC182.desc: Thermometry, states of matter and phase change, ideal and real gases, 1st law of thermodynamics, 2nd law of thermodynamics, liquids, solutions.

APSC183.name: Matter and Energy II
APSC183.desc: Atomic structures and bonding, solid crystals, chemical equilibrium, reactions in gas phase and in aqueous solutions, acid-base and redox reactions, kinetics of chemical reactions, thermochemistry, electrochemistry.

APSC201.name: Technical Communication
APSC201.desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
APSC201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

APSC202.name: Technical Communication Engineering Physics I
APSC202.desc: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Engineering Physics Program.
APSC202.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

APSC203.name: Technical Communication Engineering Physics II
APSC203.desc: Continuation of written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Engineering Physics Program.

APSC210.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC210.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC211.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC211.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Program.

APSC212.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC212.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Program.

APSC261.name: Technology and Society I
APSC261.desc: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic, and environmental aspects of society. The specific subject matter varies from year to year. Examples of subjects considered include, resources, energy, nuclear power, technology, the effects of technology on the family, education, agriculture, international policy and others. [3-0-0]

APSC262.name: Technology and Society II
APSC262.desc: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic and environmental aspects of society. The subject matter varies from year to year and differs from APSC 261. It may be taken as a continuation of APSC 261 or taken independently. Examples of subjects considered include pollution, work place health hazards, social impact of computers, problem solving, green revolution, technology and the third world, engineering ethics and others.

APSC263.name: Technology and Development
APSC263.desc: Environmental, economic, political, and social aspects of appropriate technologies in the developing world. Appropriate technology and infrastructure, trade and finance, transportation, energy, water access, communication, health, and gender.

APSC278.name: Engineering Materials
APSC278.desc: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

APSC279.name: Engineering Materials Laboratory
APSC279.desc: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

APSC310.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC310.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC311.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC311.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Program.

APSC312.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC312.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Program.

APSC331.name: Intermediate Engineering Design I
APSC331.desc: Intermediate level engineering design project involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program. For students in the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC332.name: Intermediate Engineering Design II
APSC332.desc: Intermediate level engineering design project involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program. For students in the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC364.name: Applied Sustainability: UBC as a Living Laboratory
APSC364.desc: The role and function of common infrastructures, and the impact of various technological solutions on people, the economy, and the environment.

APSC366.name: The Art of the Possible: An Introduction to Engineering for Non-Engineers
APSC366.desc: An introduction to engineering for the non-specialist. A case-studies approach includes examples from sustainability-related technology, consumer products, structures, and energy conversion. [3-0-0]

APSC377.name: Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
APSC377.desc: The evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
APSC377.prer: Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. programs, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program.

APSC380.name: Introduction to Microcomputers
APSC380.desc: An introductory course intended for potential users of microcomputers in real time or non-computational engineering applications. Topics include: perspective on applications and costs; basic microcomputer hardware; principles of microcomputer operation; introduction to microcomputer programming and software design tools; input-output devices including transducers, analog-to-digital converters, digital-to-analog converters; input-output methods and interface characteristics; selected case studies such as direct digital controllers and sensor-based systems. Limited enrolment. Restricted to engineering students not taking Electrical or Computer Engineering.

APSC410.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC410.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC411.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC411.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education.

APSC412.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC412.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Programs.

APSC440.name: Management Fundamentals for Technology-Based Product Marketing and Development
APSC440.desc: Management topics are presented from the perspective of technology-based industrial practice; project management, marketing and marketing planning, product development and commercialization, introduction to quality management, teamwork and effective individual participation.

APSC450.name: Professional Engineering Practice
APSC450.desc: Legislation affecting the practice of engineering; ethical principles and responsibilities. Management of engineering enterprises; labour relations, safety and environmental legislation. Restricted to engineering undergraduate students in the final year of their program.

APSC461.name: Global Engineering Leadership
APSC461.desc: Introduction to concepts, theory, and practice of engineering leadership, including characteristics; individual and cultural differences, service and management contexts; managing change, conflicts, and crises; real-world ethics and core values.

APSC462.name: Global Engineering Leadership Practicum
APSC462.desc: International service learning (ISL) placement in which concepts, theory, and practice of engineering leadership are applied by working with a community organization on appropriate technology projects.
APSC462.prer: APSC 461 and registration with the Go Global ISL program and successful completion of Go Global program requirements.

APSC486.name: New Venture Design
APSC486.desc: Teams comprising students in APSC 486 and COMM 486 create a business plan and a prototype or engineering solution of a novel product, process, or process component.

APSC496.name: Interdisciplinary Engineering Design Project
APSC496.desc: Projects involving students from several departments.

APSC498.name: Directed Studies
APSC498.desc: Requires approval of a Department Head or Program Director.

ORNT400.name: Orientation to Medical School and Profession
ORNT400.desc: A general introduction to the medical school including beliefs and values embedded within the curriculum. The overall curricular design and expectations regarding evaluation are discussed.

LFS100.name: Introduction to Land, Food and Community
LFS100.desc: Orientation to the programs, learning environment and core values of the Faculty of Land and Food Systems; career programs; survey of professional opportunities and requirements. [1-0-0]
