LFS150.name: Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Land and Food Systems
LFS150.desc: Communicating concepts of food systems and links to human and environmental health through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Enrolment limited to LFS students with first year status and a Language Proficiency Index (LPI) of 4 or equivalent.

LFS250.name: Land, Food and Community I
LFS250.desc: Introduction to managed systems and concepts of sustainability; economic, ecological and social components; managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities; urban and rural systems; the land, food, nutrition and human health continuum. [4-0-4]

LFS252.name: Land, Food, and Community: Quantitative Data Analysis
LFS252.desc: Introduction to tools needed for data analysis of the economic, ecological, health, and scientific components of land and food systems. [3-0-1]
LFS252.prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

LFS301.name: Aquaculture Field Studies
LFS301.desc: An orientation to the aquaculture system in BC. Participating students are assessed a fee.

LFS302.name: International Field Studies
LFS302.desc: Field studies carried out abroad under staff direction. Participating students are assessed a fee.

LFS340.name: First Nations Health and the Traditional Role of Plants
LFS340.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the First Nations medical systems and medicinal plants. Bridging the traditional with modern sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of LFS 340 or IHHS 301.

LFS350.name: Land, Food, and Community II
LFS350.desc: Introduction to tools and skills required to assess the economic, ecological, social, and technological components of managed landscapes, agrifood systems and communities comprising the land, food, nutrition and health continuum. [3-0-0]

LFS398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
LFS398.desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.
LFS398.prer: Must attend all Co-op pre-employment workshops.

LFS399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
LFS399.desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

LFS400.name: Audio Storytelling
LFS400.desc: Adopts a journalistic framework to communicate powerful stories and present academic content in new ways through the use of audio technology. [1-2-0]

LFS450.name: Land, Food, and Community III: Food System Sustainability
LFS450.desc: Problem-based analysis of complex case studies aimed at increasing the sustainability of the UBC Vancouver campus food system. The main activities are integrated into the ongoing UBC Food System Project. Cases are specifically designed to require development of integrated disciplinary and inter-disciplinary analysis. [1-0-3]

LFS490.name: Topics in Land and Food Systems
LFS490.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues related to land and food systems.

LFS496.name: Career Development Internship
LFS496.desc: Technical work experience appropriate to students' career goals. Enrolment subject to competition and availability of work placements.

LFS498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
LFS498.desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

LFS499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
LFS499.desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

GEOB102.name: Our Changing Environment: Climate and Ecosystems
GEOB102.desc: Energy and water in the Earth-Atmosphere system, global climates and climate change, ecosystem properties and processes, human impacts. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2*-0]

GEOB103.name: Our Changing Environment: Water and Landscapes
GEOB103.desc: Physical processes acting at the Earth's surface; water cycle; landforms; human impacts. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2*-0]

GEOB200.name: Atmospheric Environments
GEOB200.desc: Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture and wind climates at scales from valleys to the globe. Daily weather, air pollution, global change. Credit will be given for one only of GEOB 200, 204, GEOG 200, 204, AGRO 244. [3-2*-0]
GEOB200.prer: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102 or first-year science.

GEOB204.name: Introduction to Biometeorology
GEOB204.desc: Basic principles and processes of climatology. Energy and water balance concepts. Weather systems and climate change, microclimate of soils, crops, forests, and animals. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOB 200, 204, APBI 244. [3-2-0]

GEOB206.name: Geomorphic Processes and Hazards
GEOB206.desc: Earth surface processes shaping the landscape; identification of hazards and hazardous areas associated with these processes; introduction to techniques for measurement and analysis at various spatial and time scales; field trips are required. [3-2*-0]
GEOB206.prer: One of GEOB 103, EOSC 110, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

GEOB207.name: Introduction to Biogeography
GEOB207.desc: Geographical ecology emphasizing plant distributions, abiotic-biotic interactions, effects of disturbance, succession, and human impacts across scales. Labs and field trips examine a local site. [3-2*-0]
GEOB207.prer: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102 and one of GEOG 103, GEOB 103.

GEOB270.name: Geographic Information Science
GEOB270.desc: Computer-based graphical methods of data input and analysis. Emphasis on data visualization techniques such as cartographic modelling and exploratory data analysis. Preclusion: Not available to those who completed GEOG 370 before September 2005. [2-2-0]

GEOB300.name: Microscale Weather and Climate
GEOB300.desc: Meteorology and climatology at the micro-, local, and meso-scales. Interactions between land surfaces and atmosphere. Basics of atmospheric turbulence and transfer processes. Microclimates on scales of a leaf to those of a large valley. [3-0-0]

GEOB304.name: Synoptic Meteorology and Climatology
GEOB304.desc: Analysis of meteorological fields, diagnostic analysis of synoptic weather systems, applications of synoptic meteorology. Requires participation in weekly weather map discussion. [2-2-0]

GEOB305.name: Introduction to Hydrology
GEOB305.desc: Principles of hydrology at site, watershed, and larger regional scales. Introduction to techniques of measurement and analysis. Emphasizes surface water hydrology of western North America. [3-2*-0]
GEOB305.prer: One of GEOB 200, GEOB 204, APBI 244, ATSC 201.

GEOB307.name: Biogeography and Global Change
GEOB307.desc: Biogeographic concepts in understanding responses in ecosystems to environmental change at global, regional, and local scales. Conservation issues such as the loss of biodiversity and endangered species. [3-2*-0]

GEOB308.name: Quaternary and Applied Geomorphology
GEOB308.desc: Quaternary landscape development emphasizing the history of glaciation with special reference to western North America; applications of geomorphology in resource development and land management; interpretation of quaternary materials. Weekend field trips required. [3-2*-0]

GEOB309.name: Geographical Sciences Field Course
GEOB309.desc: Field sampling, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, and data analysis; mandatory multi-day field camp in April or May. Special fees and liability insurance are required.
GEOB309.prer: One of BIOL 230, GEOB 207 and one of GEOB 200, GEOB 204.

GEOB370.name: Advanced Geographic Information Science
GEOB370.desc: Theoretical and practical aspects of Geographic Information Systems, including cartographic modeling, digital terrain models, management issues, and spatial interpolation. [2-2-0]
GEOB370.prer: GEOB 270. Or third-year standing in ENSC or GEOB specializations, with some introductory knowledge of GIS.

GEOB372.name: Cartography
GEOB372.desc: Cartographic methods: development of cartography; projections; data ordering, compilation and symbolization; cartographic design, map reproduction. [2-2-0]
GEOB372.prer: 6 credits from GEOB 102, GEOB 103, GEOB 200, GEOB 204, GEOB 207.

GEOB373.name: Introductory Remote Sensing
GEOB373.desc: Aerial photography; measurement from aerial photographs; photo-interpretation in geographic analysis; remote sensing of the earth's surface and atmosphere. [3-2*-0]
GEOB373.prer: GEOB 270. Or third-year standing in ENSC or GEOB specializations.

GEOB400.name: Global Change Science
GEOB400.desc: Processes controlling the planetary cycles of elements like carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus, the human perturbation of these biogeochemical cycles, and the consequences for the atmosphere, terrestrial ecosystems, and aquatic ecosystems. [3-0-1]
GEOB400.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, CHEM 111 or (b) all of BIOL 121, CHEM 121 or (c) SCIE 001. Fourth year standing is also required.

GEOB401.name: Urban Meteorology
GEOB401.desc: The impact of urbanization upon atmospheric processes and climates. The energy and water balances of cities. Meteorological effects (urban heat island, precipitation modification, etc.) and their significance. Models of the urban atmosphere. [3-0-0]
GEOB401.prer: One of GEOG 204, GEOB 204, GEOG 300, GEOB 300, AGRO 244, APBI 244.

GEOB402.name: Air Pollution Meteorology
GEOB402.desc: The nature of atmospheric pollutants. The ability of the atmosphere to disperse, transform, and remove pollutants. Air pollution dispersion models. Air quality monitoring, criteria, and standards. [3-0-0]

GEOB403.name: Catchment Hydrology
GEOB403.desc: Hydrometeorology; runoff processes; streamwater chemistry in relation to runoff processes; effects of climate variations and land cover change on streamflow regimes; models of catchment hydrology. [3-0-0]
GEOB403.prer: One of GEOB 200, GEOB 204 and one of GEOB 305, FRST 385 and one of STAT 200, FRST 231, BIOL 300.

GEOB405.name: Fluvial Geomorphology
GEOB405.desc: Introduction to open channel flow and sediment transport. River morphology and channel types. Palaeohydrology. The development of channel networks. [2-3-0]

GEOB406.name: Watershed Geomorphology
GEOB406.desc: Hillslope and stream channel processes and their rates of operation. Analysis and modeling geomorphic processes and associated hazards at the watershed scale. Applications in geoscience and engineering. [2-2-0]

GEOB407.name: Vegetation Dynamics: Disturbance, Climate and Human Impacts
GEOB407.desc: Investigation of vegetation dynamics integrating theory and research to address contemporary issues of global environmental change. Students will conduct fieldwork and learn to analyze data and interpret results. [2-3-0]

GEOB408.name: Snow and Ice Processes
GEOB408.desc: Formation of snow and ice masses and their evolution including snowpacks, glaciers, and ice sheets. Relationships between snow, ice, and climate including glacier dynamics and avalanche forecasting. Weekend field trip. [3-0-0]
GEOB408.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and one of GEOB 305, GEOB 308.

GEOB409.name: Self-Directed Field Studies in Physical Geography
GEOB409.desc: Advanced research design, field sampling methods, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, data analysis and management; self-directed fieldwork; 1 lecture per week during term and a multi-day field camp in April or May. [2-0-0]
GEOB409.prer: GEOB 309. Third-year standing in Geographical Biogeosciences Major.

GEOB448.name: Directed Studies in Geographical Sciences
GEOB448.desc: For fourth-year students in Geography to permit investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required. Credit will be given for only one of GEOB 448 and GEOG 448.

GEOB449.name: Undergraduate Thesis
GEOB449.desc: Original research on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a faculty member. Open to 4th year students in Geographical Biogeosciences with appropriate background courses related to the research topic, and permission of the directing faculty member. The 3-credit option is only available to students who complete GEOB 449 in tandem with GEOB 409.

GEOB472.name: Research in Cartography
GEOB472.desc: Use of cartography in primary research applications. Discussion of contemporary topics in cognitive, social, and technical cartography and data visualization. [3-2*-0]

GEOB479.name: Research in Geographic Information Science
GEOB479.desc: Students use GIS in primary research applications in conservation biology, crime analysis, and health geography; theoretical and practical aspects considered in a hands-on environment. [2-2-0]

GEOB490.name: Student Directed Seminar in Geographical Sciences
GEOB490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in physical geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars." This course carries science credit. Credit will not be granted for both GEOG 442 and GEOB 490.

ENDS101.name: Introductory Workshop
ENDS101.desc: Week long orientation to the School community, the City and the study of design one week prior to the start of Winter Session Term 1. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 101 or DES 101.

ENDS110.name: Measured Architectural Drafting
ENDS110.desc: Techniques applicable to analytic and technical drawing used in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban design with focus primarily on analog drawing.

ENDS211.name: Introduction to Environmental Design
ENDS211.desc: Survey of the visual, cultural, ecological and spatial literacies in environmental design and planning.

ENDS220.name: Architecture in Context: Vancouver
ENDS220.desc: The unfolding architecture and urbanism of Metro Vancouver. Using Vancouver as a laboratory to examine the historical transformation of the built environment, and how this has affected particular activities, land uses, and social groups within the region.

ENDS221.name: Sustainability by Design
ENDS221.desc: Introduction to interactions between human and natural urban systems using local and international examples of successful sustainable community designs.

ENDS231.name: Thinking by Design
ENDS231.desc: Introduction to design thinking through the analysis of architecture, landscape architecture, urban design, and hands-on design projects.

ENDS281.name: Architecture in Context and Across Cultures: A History
ENDS281.desc: A world survey of architecture, from prehistory to postmodernity, which relates architecture to landscape and city, design principles and cultural values, formal and vernacular practices. It explores the different ways in which history has been conveyed and the purposes it serves. [2-0-1]

ENDS301.name: Environmental Design Studio I
ENDS301.desc: Introduction to the study of relationships of human beings' environments; methods of analysis and composition; physical properties of land, natural and man-made; simple spatial and functional programs deployed in the creation of outdoor spaces.

ENDS302.name: Environmental Design Studio II
ENDS302.desc: Expands the terms of the purposeful transformation of "place" to include modifications to the environment at the scale of the individual; concepts of dwelling and habitation; the human body as an instrument of measure, dimension and design of the private realm.

ENDS320.name: Design, Media and Representation
ENDS320.desc: Theories, histories and techniques of design representation; geometry, design and expression are principle areas of focus.

ENDS401.name: Environmental Design Studio III
ENDS401.desc: The exploration of a complex physical and spatial program for building in the public realm, resulting in an integrative design project.

ENDS402.name: Environmental Design Studio IV
ENDS402.desc: Expands the scale and design enquiry to emphasize the relationships between communities and environment, urban infrastructure, and ecological systems.

ENDS404.name: Environmental Design History
ENDS404.desc: A survey of environmental influences in architecture and landscape architecture design across time, geographies, and cultures, from neolithic settlements to nineteenth-century urbanization. Restricted to students in the Environmental Design program.

ENDS420.name: Technology and Technique
ENDS420.desc: Introduction to fundamental design principles and investigations of buildings, landscape, machines and furniture, including structure, enclosure, envelope and detailing.

ENDS440.name: Environment and Urban Form
ENDS440.desc: Relationships between, and integration of, the natural environment and the physical form, spatial structure, and livability of cities.

GRS290.name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
GRS290.desc: Students interact face-to-face and on-line as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken prior to studying abroad. [0-0-2; 0-0-2]
GRS290.prer: Open only to students in the B.Sc. (GRS) program.

GRS390.name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
GRS390.desc: Students interact face-to-face and on-line as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken while studying abroad. [0-0-2]

GRS397.name: Regional Directed Field Studies
GRS397.desc: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

GRS490.name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
GRS490.desc: Students interact face-to-face and on-line as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken after studying abroad. [0-0-2]

GRS497.name: Regional Directed Field Studies
GRS497.desc: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

RGLA372.name: Topics in Religion, Literature, and the Arts
RGLA372.desc: The topic is selected and announced annually by the RGLA Committee.

RGLA471.name: Advanced Seminar in Religion and Literature
RGLA471.desc: Application of critical methods to one or more major authors.

UFOR100.name: Greening the City
UFOR100.desc: Roles played by urban forestry and greenspace systems in a rapidly changing world; topics include urban ecology, urban forest conservation, urban forest management, climate change, society and human well-being, design and planning, urban/rural interface issues, and urban forest policy. [2-0-2]

UFOR200.name: Urban Forests and Well-Being
UFOR200.desc: Basic relationships between urban residents’ mental and physical well-being and their urban forest environment. [2-0-2]

UFOR300.name: Arboriculture Principles and Practice
UFOR300.desc: Sustainable practice within the arboricultural discipline with emphasis on a comprehensive understanding of techniques and equipment used in a range of arboricultural operations. [3-1-0]

UFOR400.name: Urban Forestry Field School
UFOR400.desc: Development of field skills, professional judgment, critical reflection, and integration of theory, practice, and policy. Offered at Malcolm Knapp Research Forest over a 7-day period in April.
UFOR400.prer: UFOR 200. And third year standing in the B.U.F. program.

UFOR401.name: Integrated Urban Forestry Capstone Studio
UFOR401.desc: Integration of biophysical and socio-economic components of urban greenspace management and planning through within a collaborative holistic group project linked to a real-world urban forestry situation.
UFOR401.prer: All of UFOR 300, UFOR 400. And fourth year standing in the B.U.F. program.

UFOR402.name: Urban Forestry Administration, Policy and Law
UFOR402.desc: The administrative, legal, policy, and business environments for urban forestry governance, management, and planning. [3-1-0]

UFOR403.name: Ecological Restoration
UFOR403.desc: Ecological principles relevant to restoration of ecosystems are applied to the restoration of several types of ecosystems.
UFOR403.prer: One of FRST 201, BIOL 230. And third year standing

UFOR449.name: Directed Studies in Urban Forestry
UFOR449.desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry out directed studies on a specific topic/problems in Urban Forestry and related greenspace planning, management, or governance.

BIOL111.name: Introduction to Modern Biology
BIOL111.desc: Concepts fundamental to biological issues, such as the genetic basis of biological variation, evolution, infectious diseases, causes of cancer, population growth, and human effects on ecosystems.  Not open to students who have credit for Biology 12 (including AP, IB). [3-0-0]

BIOL112.name: Biology of the Cell
BIOL112.desc: The principles of cellular and molecular biology using bacterial and eukaryotic examples. [3-0-0]
BIOL112.prer: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

BIOL121.name: Genetics, Evolution and Ecology
BIOL121.desc: Principles of storage and transmission of genetic variation; origin and evolution of species and their ecological interactions. [3-0-0]

BIOL140.name: Laboratory Investigations in Life Science
BIOL140.desc: Guided experimental investigations of biological questions. [1-2-0]

BIOL153.name: Human Biology
BIOL153.desc: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology). Laboratories include selected experiments on organ physiology and general anatomy. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

BIOL155.name: Human Biology
BIOL155.desc: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology). [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

BIOL200.name: Fundamentals of Cell Biology
BIOL200.desc: Structure and function of plant and animal cells; membrane models, cytoplasmic organelles, biological information from gene to protein, the endomembrane system, secretion, intracellular digestion, endocytosis, transport processes, cytoskeleton and cell motility. [3-0-1]
BIOL200.prer: Either (a) BIOL 112 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 113;  or (b) SCIE 001 or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL and 6 credits of first-year CHEM or (d) one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121 and a corequisite of CHEM 203.

BIOL201.name: Introduction to Biochemistry
BIOL201.desc: Biological molecules, protein structure and enzyme action, energy transfer, central metabolic pathways and their regulation. Examples drawn from plants, animals and microorganisms. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) [3-0-1]
BIOL201.prer: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 233, CHEM 260; or BIOL 200 and a corequisite of CHEM 213; or a corequisite of either CHEM 313 or CHEM 330.

BIOL203.name: Eukaryotic Microbiology
BIOL203.desc: Introduction to the origin and diversity of protists (protozoa and algae) at both cellular and genomic levels, including the role of endosymbiosis in evolution. [3-3-0]
BIOL203.prer: BIOL 140 and one of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. BIOL 200 recommended.

BIOL204.name: Vertebrate Structure and Function
BIOL204.desc: Introduction to the vertebrate phyla and their evolution; a comparative study of vertebrate structure and function, with dissection of representative forms. [3-3-0]
BIOL204.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

BIOL205.name: Comparative Invertebrate Zoology
BIOL205.desc: An introduction to the unity, diversity and evolutionary history of invertebrates. [3-3-0]
BIOL205.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

BIOL209.name: Biodiversity of algae, fungi and bryophytes
BIOL209.desc: Diversity, ecology, cell biology and evolutionary origins of multicellular eukaryotes, illustrated through mosses and liverworts; fungi and slime molds; and fresh water and marine algae. [3-3-0]
BIOL209.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140 or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

BIOL210.name: Vascular Plants
BIOL210.desc: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function and ecology. [3-3]
BIOL210.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

BIOL230.name: Fundamentals of Ecology
BIOL230.desc: Dynamics of plant and animal populations, structure of ecological communities and functioning of ecosystems. Interpretation of research results and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-3*-0]

BIOL233.name: Genetics for Life
BIOL233.desc: How genetic differences determine individual characteristics, and how they are inherited, analyzed, and modified. Emphasis on genetic diversity, human ancestry, personal genomics, and cancer genetics. [3-0-2]
BIOL233.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001; or (c) a corequisite of CHEM 203 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.

BIOL234.name: Fundamentals of Genetics
BIOL234.desc: Genotype and phenotype, mechanisms of inheritance, genetic analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]
BIOL234.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001 or (c) a corequisite of CHEM 203 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.

BIOL260.name: Fundamentals of Physiology
BIOL260.desc: Principles of cellular and organismal physiology illustrated with examples from unicellular organisms, plants and animals, focusing on transport processes, water balance, nutrient acquisition and communication. [3-0-0]
BIOL260.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001 or (c) 8 transfer credits of 1st year BIOL and 6 credits of 1st year chemistry.

BIOL300.name: Fundamentals of Biostatistics
BIOL300.desc: Statistical procedures for biological research; estimation, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit, analysis of variance and regression; use of computers for statistical analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2-0]
BIOL300.prer: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

BIOL301.name: Biomathematics
BIOL301.desc: Introduction to uses of mathematics in the biological sciences; experimental design and modelling of biological processes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]

BIOL306.name: Advanced Ecology
BIOL306.desc: Ecology of populations, communities and ecosystems. Tests of ecological theory with experiments and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-3*-0]

BIOL310.name: Introduction to Animal Behaviour
BIOL310.desc: Animal behavior from an ecological and evolutionary perspective; the methods used to study behaviour and test its adaptive significance. [3-0-2]

BIOL317.name: Weed Science
BIOL317.desc: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventative, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control. [3-2-0]

BIOL320.name: Survey of Algae
BIOL320.desc: A survey of the algae, considering their morphology, life history, classification, and ecology. [3-3-0]

BIOL321.name: Morphology and Evolution of Bryophytes
BIOL321.desc: A study of evolution, taxonomy and morphology of mosses, liverworts and hornworts with emphasis on living plants in their environment. [2-4-0]

BIOL322.name: Structure and Evolution of Ferns and Fern-allies
BIOL322.desc: Anatomy, morphology and relationships of the ferns and fern-allies, with assessment of both fossil and extant taxa. [2-4-0]

BIOL323.name: Structure and Reproduction of Fungi
BIOL323.desc: The evolutionary diversity of the fungi as shown by their morphology and reproductive biology. [2-3-0]

BIOL324.name: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
BIOL324.desc: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection. [2-3-0]

BIOL325.name: Introduction to Animal Mechanics and Locomotion
BIOL325.desc: Comparative aspects of the functional design of skeletal systems and the mechanics of swimming, flying and terrestrial locomotion, with particular reference to the vertebrates. [3-0-0]

BIOL326.name: Experimental Biology of Invertebrates
BIOL326.desc: Behaviour and ecology of invertebrates as revealed by hands-on experiments in the laboratory and field.  Marine emphasis. [1-4-0]

BIOL327.name: Introduction to Entomology
BIOL327.desc: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology, life-histories and insect-plant relations.

BIOL328.name: Introductory Parasitology
BIOL328.desc: Classification, morphology and life histories of animal parasites affecting humans and other animals. [2-3-0]

BIOL331.name: Developmental Biology
BIOL331.desc: Animal development and its underlying causal principles; introductory embryology. [3-3-0]
BIOL331.prer: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

BIOL332.name: Protistology
BIOL332.desc: Cell biology, ecology, and evolution of protists; origins of multicellularity; the role of protists in micropaleontology, parasitology, and oceanography. [3-3-0]

BIOL335.name: Molecular Genetics
BIOL335.desc: Isolation and identification of genes, analysis of gene structure; gene expression and its regulation in prokaryotes and in eukaryotes; developmental genetics. [3-0-2]
BIOL335.prer: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, MICB 322, FRST 302.

BIOL336.name: Fundamentals of Evolutionary Biology
BIOL336.desc: Natural selection; population genetics, quantitative genetics and systematics; classical and molecular approaches to the study of evolution. [3-0-2]

BIOL337.name: Introductory Genetics Laboratory
BIOL337.desc: A laboratory course demonstrating the fundamental principles of inheritance: Mendel's Laws, sex-linkage, mapping, mutagenesis, chromosome structure, developmental biology, biochemical and population genetics. [1-4-0]

BIOL338.name: Introduction to Genomics
BIOL338.desc: An introduction to genome biology and applications of genomics. [3-0-1.5]

BIOL340.name: Introductory Cell Biology Laboratory
BIOL340.desc: Experiments using unicellular eukaryotes or prokaryotes with emphasis on techniques in microscopy and cell biology. [1-3-0]
BIOL340.prer: All of BIOL 140, BIOL 200. And at least third-year standing in Science.

BIOL341.name: Introductory Molecular Biology Laboratory
BIOL341.prer: BIOL 200. And at least third-year standing in Science.

BIOL342.name: Integrative Biology Laboratory
BIOL342.desc: Field-based and laboratory-based investigation of organisms. [1-3-0]
BIOL342.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140 or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology; and third-year standing or higher in Combined Major in Science.

BIOL343.name: Plants and Peoples
BIOL343.desc: The interactions of plants and human societies: the role of people in the origin, evolution and dispersal of food, drug and economic plants, and the influences of plants on human societies. Suitable for upper-level Arts students. [2-2-1]

BIOL344.name: Human Heredity and Evolution
BIOL344.desc: Relates genetic and evolutionary concepts to humans. Primarily for upper-level students in the Faculty of Arts. Credit will be given for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344. Not open to students in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]

BIOL345.name: Human Ecology
BIOL345.desc: Basics of ecology are introduced, focussing on observations of the natural world. Assignments, including a group project, consider connections between research, awareness and practical uses of ecology. Not for credit in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]

BIOL346.name: Microbes and Society
BIOL346.desc: An elementary course in molecular biology primarily for Arts students. The historical development of recent discoveries in molecular biology with emphasis on bacteria and viruses and their interaction with humans. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Not for credit in Life Sciences. [3-0-0]

BIOL347.name: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
BIOL347.desc: Contemporary research in the Botany and Zoology Departments; history and methodology of scientific discovery; seminars on current problems. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. Not to be taken concurrently with BIOL 449. [2-3-0]

BIOL351.name: Plant Physiology I
BIOL351.desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology. [3-3-0]
BIOL351.prer: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113. CHEM 233 is recommended.

BIOL352.name: Plant Physiology II: Plant Development
BIOL352.desc: Introduction to the processes involved in growth and development: cell division, tissue culture, meristems, differentiation, and the action of major growth regulators, and photomorphogenesis. Emphasis on experimental approaches. [2-3-1]
BIOL352.prer: Either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234;  or (b) FRST 302. CHEM 233 is recommended.

BIOL361.name: Physiology of Sensory, Nervous and Muscular Systems
BIOL361.desc: Excitable membranes, neural signaling and transmission; transduction and coding of sensory information; muscle contraction. [3-0-0]
BIOL361.prer: BIOL 200. One of BIOL 260 or BIOL 201 recommended.

BIOL362.name: Cellular Physiology
BIOL362.desc: The cytoskeleton, cell dynamics, and regulation of cellular activities. Preference will be given to Majors or Honours students in Biology and Honours Biophysics. [2-0-1]
BIOL362.prer: Either (a) BIOL 361 or (b) all of BIOL 201, BIOL 351.

BIOL363.name: Laboratory in Animal Physiology
BIOL363.desc: Experimental studies in animal physiology. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology, Nutritional Sciences and Biophysics. [1-3-1]

BIOL364.name: Animal Physiology
BIOL364.desc: Cardiovascular, respiratory, and osmoregulatory physiology. Preference will be given to students who are in Biology, Nutritional Sciences, and Honours Biophysics. [3-0-0]
BIOL364.prer: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361.

BIOL398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
BIOL398.desc: Work experience in an industrial setting, taken during Winter Session (Term 2) of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

BIOL399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
BIOL399.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

BIOL401.name: Theory of Evolutionary Dynamics
BIOL401.desc: Evolution as a dynamical system based on ecological interactions. Adaptive dynamics and evolutionary game theory. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 401 and BIOL 560.
BIOL401.prer: BIOL 301 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

BIOL402.name: Aquatic Ecology
BIOL402.desc: Theoretical and applied limnology; ecology of inland water organisms in relation to physical, chemical and biological factors. One weekend field trip required. [2-4-0]
BIOL402.prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

BIOL404.name: Ecological Methodology
BIOL404.desc: Design, execution, and analysis of ecological surveys and experiments. Practical field methods for estimating population metrics and describing community structure. Computer techniques for the statistical analysis of ecological data. [2-4-0]
BIOL404.prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

BIOL406.name: Plant Ecology I
BIOL406.desc: Plant community ecology including a consideration of the major approaches to sampling, analyzing and interpreting vegetation patterns. Instruction given in field work and computer analysis of field data. [3-3-0]

BIOL408.name: Principles of Applied Ecology
BIOL408.desc: Principles of animal and community ecology applicable to the management of animal resources; application of statistical and computer techniques for measuring, analyzing, modelling, and simulating resource systems; problems of multiple resource use. [2-2-0]

BIOL409.name: Field Course in Ecology
BIOL409.desc: A two-week intensive course in field methods used in ecology. Fieldwork for this course is normally in the summer. A fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration required.
BIOL409.prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200. BIOL 306 is recommended.

BIOL410.name: Current Topics in Animal Behaviour
BIOL410.desc: Lectures and seminar discussions on selected topics in animal behaviour. [2-0-2]
BIOL410.prer: BIOL 310. Permission of the head of Zoology is also acceptable.

BIOL411.name: Insect Ecology
BIOL411.desc: Behavioural, population and community ecology of insects. Interactions between insects and plants and the application of the principles of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds. [3-0-0]
BIOL411.prer: Either (a) BIOL 205 or (b) all of AGRO 327, BIOL 327.

BIOL412.name: Phytogeography
BIOL412.desc: Description and interpretation of present and past floristic vegetational patterns; integration of evolutionary, ecological, and phytogeographical concepts. Terrestrial and aquatic plants are considered. Restricted to students of third and fourth years. [3-0-0]

BIOL413.name: Zoogeography
BIOL413.desc: The role of physical, ecological, and evolutionary processes in determining the geographic distribution of animals including humans, with implications for speciation and conservation. Restricted to students in third and fourth year. [3-0-0]

BIOL415.name: Evolutionary Processes in Plants
BIOL415.desc: Experimental and comparative analysis of evolutionary processes, speciation, and phylogenetic patterns in plants. [2-0-0]

BIOL416.name: Principles of Conservation Biology
BIOL416.desc: Ecological basis of conserving biological diversity and ecosystem services; application of ecological theory to global and local conservation problems in the context of economic, legal, political, and social perspectives. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-0-2]

BIOL417.name: Phylogenetic Biology
BIOL417.desc: Biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective. The evolutionary (phylogenetic) tree of genetic descent that links all organisms: its reconstruction, interpretation, and implications for fields from ecology to molecular biology. [2-0-2]
BIOL417.prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. BIOL 336 is recommended

BIOL418.name: Evolutionary Ecology
BIOL418.desc: Ecological adaptation and evolutionary processes in contemporary populations; natural selection, variation, optimization, foraging theory, coevolution, arms races; life history theory, evolution of sex, sexual selection, evolution in managed populations. [2-2-0]

BIOL420.name: Ocean Conservation and Sustainability
BIOL420.desc: An interdisciplinary conservation course with a solutions-oriented approach to marine issues, drawing from natural sciences, social sciences, business, law, and communication.

BIOL421.name: Plant-Microbe Interactions
BIOL421.desc: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society. [3-0-2]
BIOL421.prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260, BIOL 201.

BIOL423.name: Plant Stress Ecophysiology
BIOL423.desc: Molecular mechanisms of plant responses to extreme environments. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

BIOL425.name: Biomechanics
BIOL425.desc: An analytical approach to the study of skeletal mechanics and animal locomotion. Selected topics in the structure and properties of biological materials, the functional design of skeletons for locomotion, and the fluid mechanics of swimming and flight. [2-3-0]

BIOL426.name: Mammalogy
BIOL426.desc: Natural history, behavioral ecology and conservation of terrestrial mammals. The laboratory includes classification, life histories, and ecology, with particular attention to species from British Columbia. [2-3-0]

BIOL427.name: Ornithology and Herpetology
BIOL427.desc: Ecology, evolution, behavior, and conservation of birds, amphibians, and reptiles.  Laboratories and field projects will focus on identification, systematics, and natural history, with particular attention to species from British Columbia. [2-3-0]

BIOL428.name: Evolutionary Morphology of Marine Invertebrates
BIOL428.desc: Comparative analysis of marine invertebrate morphology from a macroevolutionary perspective.  Origin and evolution of reoccurring adaptations in meiofaunal, benthic, pelagic, and deep-sea invertebrates, including their larval stages. [3-0-0]

BIOL430.name: Genome Evolution
BIOL430.desc: Integration of molecular genetics and genomics with evolutionary biology. Emphasis on the evolutionary dynamics of genomes and the evolutionary implications of recent discoveries in molecular genetics and genomics. [3-0-0]
BIOL430.prer: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 338. Or with instructor permission BIOL 336.

BIOL431.name: Evolutionary Cell Biology
BIOL431.desc: Ultrastructure, biogenesis, and evolution of eukaryotic cells and cell organelles, including their macromolecular basis. [3-0-0]

BIOL432.name: Research Strategies and Techniques in Cell Biology
BIOL432.desc: Major physiological mechanisms that define eukaryotic cells, explored through student visits to UBC research laboratories and discussion of recent scientific literature, with emphasis on the techniques and strategies that enable researchers to test hypotheses and advance new concepts. [3-0-0]
BIOL432.prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. And fourth-year standing.

BIOL433.name: Plant Genetics
BIOL433.desc: Emphasis on molecular aspects. Systems and techniques for genetic analysis in plants; isolation and regulation of plant genes; genetic dissection of plant-specific processes; transposable elements; gene transfer in plants; cytoplasmic inheritance; genetic engineering. [3-0-2]

BIOL434.name: Population Genetics
BIOL434.desc: Theoretical and experimental aspects of population and quantitative genetics. [3-0-2]
BIOL434.prer: BIOL 336 and either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234;  or (b) FRST 302.

BIOL436.name: Integrated Functional Genomics
BIOL436.desc: Global transcript, protein, and metabolite profiling technologies and their integration; applications focus on plant functions and plant interactions with pathogens and pests. [3-0-0]

BIOL437.name: Laboratory in Animal Cell Molecular Biology
BIOL437.desc: The use of recombinant DNA techniques to explore problems in animal developmental biology. [2-4-0]
BIOL437.prer: All of BIOL 331, BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 302, BIOC 303. Permission of the department head is also required.

BIOL438.name: Zoological Physics
BIOL438.desc: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping. [3-0-0]
BIOL438.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended.

BIOL440.name: Plant Genomics
BIOL440.desc: Concepts, principles, applications, and recent discoveries in genome structure, genetics, and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants. [3-0-0]

BIOL441.name: Cell Biology of Intracellular Trafficking
BIOL441.desc: Analysis of cellular organelles and the intracellular traffic between them, concentrating on mammalian cell systems. [3-0-0]
BIOL441.prer: BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 340, BIOL 341 and one of BIOL 361, BIOL 362 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203.

BIOL444.name: Techniques in Plant Molecular Biology
BIOL444.desc: Purification and analysis of nucleic acids, electrophoresis and immunodetection of proteins. Restricted to Honours students with permission of the Head of Botany and the Biotechnology Teaching Laboratory. [0-7-0]

BIOL445.name: Darwin's Fishes
BIOL445.desc: A series of computer-assisted lectures using ichthyology and the work of Charles Darwin to illustrate basic principles of biology, and their practical implementation, i.e., how biologists select research programs, generate and test hypotheses, and present their case to peers and the public. [2-0-2]
BIOL445.prer: Third-year standing in Science is required.

BIOL446.name: History and Philosophy of Biology
BIOL446.desc: The nature of science, this history of evolutionary and molecular biology, philosophical questions about scientific methods and fundamental conclusions of biology. [3-0-0]
BIOL446.prer: Fourth-year standing in any degree program is required.

BIOL447.name: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
BIOL447.desc: Seminars, debates, workshops and tutorials designed to produce competence in specific areas of Biology. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. [2-3-0]

BIOL448.name: Directed Studies in Biology
BIOL448.desc: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

BIOL449.name: Directed Biological Research
BIOL449.desc: A course designed to allow students to undertake a research project in selected fields. Open only to Honours students in Biology, with permission of the supervisor. Presentation of a thesis and an oral examination are required.

BIOL450.name: Molecular Adaptation of Animals to the Environment
BIOL450.desc: Physiological, biochemical, and molecular strategies of adaptation of animals to environmental challenges.  The evolution of genetic and biochemical systems, and their impact on animal structure and function. [3-0-0]
BIOL450.prer: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. BIOL 457 is recommended.

BIOL454.name: Comparative Animal Physiology
BIOL454.desc: Selected topics in physiology emphasizing comparisons between diverse phylogenetic groups of animals. [3-0-0]

BIOL455.name: Comparative Neurobiology
BIOL455.desc: Current approaches in neurobiology, from the cellular to the behavioural level, are examined using representatives of vertebrate and invertebrate nervous systems. [3-0-2*]
BIOL455.prer: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, CAPS 301, PSYC 360.

BIOL456.name: Comparative and Molecular Endocrinology
BIOL456.desc: A comparative study of vertebrate and invertebrate endocrinology. [3-0-0]

BIOL457.name: Comparative Environmental Physiology
BIOL457.desc: A survey of physiological adaptions of animals to different environments. [3-0-0]

BIOL458.name: Developmental Neurobiology
BIOL458.desc: Cellular, molecular and physiological aspects of nervous system development with applications to understanding adult nervous system function and neurological disorders. [3-0-0]

BIOL459.name: Neurobiology of Sensory and Motor Systems
BIOL459.desc: Analysis of the mechanisms of sensory processing and motor orchestration using vertebrate and invertebrate model systems.  Neural circuit structure, specialization, information coding, integration, and behaviour. [3-0-0]

BIOL462.name: Ecological Plant Biochemistry
BIOL462.desc: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites. [3-0-0]
BIOL462.prer: All of BIOL 200, BIOL 201. BIOL 209 or BIOL 210 is recommended.

BIOL463.name: Gene Regulation in Development
BIOL463.desc: Control of gene expression in development; the genetic and physiological basis of epigenetic determination; inductive interactions. [3-0-0]
BIOL463.prer: BIOL 335 and one of BIOC 302, BIOC 303. BIOL 331 is recommended.

BIOL464.name: Animal Developmental Genetics
BIOL464.desc: Role of genes in embryonic development.  Emphasis on tissue specific expression patterns and the role of genetic networks in establishing cell types. [3-0-0]

BIOL465.name: Diversity and Evolution of Fishes
BIOL465.desc: Introduction to fish diversity, with a focus on their phylogenetic interrelationships and the evolutionary, ecological, and biogeographic processes involved in generating patterns of fish biodiversity. [2-3-0]

BIOL466.name: Applied Biology of Fishes
BIOL466.desc: Physiological ecology and exploitation biology of teleost fishes; computer-based analysis and modeling of fish populations.

BIOL490.name: Student Directed Seminars
BIOL490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". Normally not suitable as a specific BIOL program elective. [3-0]

BIOL498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
BIOL498.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

BIOL499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
BIOL499.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

SURG430.name: Surgery
SURG430.desc: Post-operative care of patients, evaluation of pre-operative patients, mastery of technical skills for common ward procedures, assessing ambulatory patients and assisting in the operating room.

ECED380.name: Selected Topics in Infant Development and Supported Child Development

ECED400.name: Introduction to Early Childhood Education and Care

ECED401.name: Supporting Young Children's Health and Well-Being in Early Childhood Settings

ECED405.name: Foundations of Curriculum and Instruction in Early Childhood Education

ECED406.name: Early Learning Curriculum in the Pre-School Years
ECED406.desc: The development of pre-kindergarten programs with reference to recent research, theories of early learning, and curriculum trends and practices.

ECED407.name: Supporting Early Learning in the Pre-School Years
ECED407.desc: Planning and implementing pre-kindergarten learning experiences; resources, materials, curriculum integration, evaluation, scheduling, and classroom design.

ECED415.name: Supporting Learning in The Primary Years
ECED415.desc: Designing environments, experiences, activities, instruction, and assessment to foster children's learning in the primary years (grades 1-3).
ECED415.prer: ECED 405 or teaching experience or successful completion of the extended practicum.

ECED416.name: Kindergarten Curriculum
ECED416.desc: The development of kindergarten programs with reference to recent research, theories of early learning, curriculum trends and practices, and the place of kindergarten in contemporary education.

ECED417.name: Supporting Learning in the Kindergarten Year
ECED417.desc: Designing environments, experiences, activities, instruction, and assessment to foster children's learning in the kindergarten year.
ECED417.prer: One of ECED 405, ECED 416 or teaching experience, or successful completion of extended practicum.

ECED420.name: History of Early Childhood Education
ECED420.desc: Political and social factors which influenced movements and trends in early childhood education in North America, pre-kindergarten through primary.

ECED421.name: Supporting Young Children Through Home, School, and Community Relationships

ECED425.name: Advanced Studies in Early Childhood Education
ECED425.prer: One of ECED 405, or an introductory level early childhood education course, or teaching experience, or successful completion of extended practicum.

ECED438.name: Observation and Documentation in Early Childhood Settings

ECED439.name: Assessment of Infants and Young Children with Special Needs

ECED440.name: Supporting Social and Communication Development in Infants and Young Children with Special Needs

ECED441.name: Early Intervention for Infants and Young Children with Sensory Loss and Motor Impairments

ECED442.name: Supporting Indigenous Infants and Young Children within the Context of Their Communities

ECED480.name: Selected Topics in Early Childhood Education

LATN101.name: First-Year Latin I
LATN101.desc: Classical Latin for students with no previous knowledge of Latin, Part I.

LATN102.name: First-Year Latin II
LATN102.desc: Classical Latin for students with no previous knowledge of Latin, Part II.

LATN201.name: Second-Year Latin I
LATN201.desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part I.

LATN202.name: Second-Year Latin II
LATN202.desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part II, and an introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Latin literature.

LATN350.name: Latin Literature of the Classical Period (Prose)

LATN351.name: Latin Literature of the Classical Period (Verse)

LATN401.name: Latin Prose
LATN401.desc: Studies in history, oratory and/or philosophy. May be repeated for up to 12 credits. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to LATN 401.

LATN402.name: Latin Verse
LATN402.desc: Studies in narrative verse, comedy, satire, elegiac and lyric poetry. May be repeated for up to 12 credits. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to LATN 402.

PUNJ100.name: Introductory Punjabi I
PUNJ100.desc: Spoken and written Punjabi. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 100 for credit.

PUNJ101.name: Introductory Punjabi II
PUNJ101.desc: Continuation of PUNJ 100. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 101 for credit.

PUNJ102.name: Introductory Punjabi
PUNJ102.desc: Spoken and written Punjabi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100/101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 102 for credit.

PUNJ200.name: Intermediate Punjabi
PUNJ200.desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201/202 or PUNJ 200.

PUNJ201.name: Intermediate Punjabi I
PUNJ201.desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201 or PUNJ 200.

PUNJ202.name: Intermediate Punjabi II
PUNJ202.desc: Continuation of PUNJ 201. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 202 or PUNJ 200.

PUNJ205.name: Introduction to the Gurmukhi Script
PUNJ205.desc: The writing system of Punjabi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as PUNJ 200.

PUNJ300.name: Advanced Punjabi
PUNJ300.desc: Advanced grammar and conversation. Major genres of Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 301/302 or PUNJ 300.

PUNJ401.name: Devotional Literature in Punjabi
PUNJ401.desc: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required.

PUNJ402.name: Medieval and Early Modern Punjabi Literature
PUNJ402.desc: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required.

PUNJ403.name: Modern Punjabi Literature
PUNJ403.desc: Popular and literary works in modern Punjabi, with a focus on short stories and poetry. Emphasis on reading, writing, and vocabulary development.

PUNJ404.name: The Punjabi Novel (Advanced Punjabi)
PUNJ404.desc: Study of the modern Punjabi novel to deepen understanding and use of Punjabi, and strengthen analysis in English and Punjabi.

PUNJ457.name: Punjabi Theatre
PUNJ457.desc: Punjabi-language theatre, with emphasis on Canadian forms. Reading, writing, and performance of plays; examination of history of Punjabi theatre.

PUNJ475.name: Oral Histories in Punjabi
PUNJ475.desc: Develops students' oral expression and listening comprehension in Punjabi through Community Based Learning. Students engage in oral history collection in the Punjabi-speaking community and develop short video or sound projects. Analytical reading and writing required.

COHR301.name: Business and Management Values
COHR301.desc: Balancing organizational, personal, and community interests in a global economy. In addition to standard management textbooks and readings, the class will draw from the work of poets, fiction writers, essayists, and social critics.
COHR301.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR302.name: Critical Evaluation of Information, Evidence, and Arguments
COHR302.desc: Strategies to critically evaluate information relevant to Human Resource Managers. This course will examine common errors in logic, decision biases, and cause and effect relationships.
COHR302.prer: All of COMM 291, COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR303.name: Strategic Staffing
COHR303.desc: Processes of workforce recruitment, selection, retention, and renewal. Includes human resources planning, development of an effective staffing strategy and employer brand, job analysis and descriptions, cost-benefit analysis of various recruiting methods, analysis and evaluation of selection methods.
COHR303.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR304.name: Training, Development, and Performance Management
COHR304.desc: Employee training, development and performance management in a variety of employment settings. Application of various training methods to performance enhancement, performance appraisal, feedback, and empirical evaluation of training investments.
COHR304.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR305.name: Strategic Compensation
COHR305.desc: Employee compensation, including pay systems, benefits systems, and rewards and recognition programs. Examination of the motivational underpinnings of compensation administration and the application of compensation principles to the achievement of employer strategic objectives.
COHR305.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR307.name: Introduction to Organizational Consulting
COHR307.desc: Frameworks from the social sciences useful for understanding organizational processes and how to apply these frameworks to particular organizational consulting challenges.
COHR307.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR308.name: Labour Relations
COHR308.desc: Integrated coverage of union-management relations including labour law, collective bargaining, and collective agreement administration.
COHR308.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR310.name: Industrial Relations in an Era of Globalization
COHR310.desc: Comprehensive examination of the Canadian industrial relations system, and its legal foundations, in the context of a global economy.
COHR310.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR311.name: Organizational Analysis
COHR311.desc: An analysis of organizational structures and intraorganizational processes; effects of organizational factors on individual behaviour.
COHR311.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR401.name: Organizational Change
COHR401.desc: The tactics and strategies for implementing constructive modifications in organizations.
COHR401.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR402.name: Leadership
COHR402.desc: Explores the characteristics of effective leadership and examines how to be a better leader.
COHR402.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR403.name: Managing Diversity
COHR403.desc: Explores the business and legal cases for diversity in the workplace. Examines how to effectively manage a diverse work force.
COHR403.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR404.name: Power and Politics
COHR404.desc: Examines the sources and consequences of power in the context of different corporate and national cultures.
COHR404.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR405.name: Managing the Family Business
COHR405.desc: Managing and working in a family business presents unique challenges: family issues can conflict with business issues. This course examines governance structures and tools to manage the interface between the family and the business.
COHR405.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR406.name: International Human Resource Management
COHR406.desc: Application of human resource management practices to multinational enterprises. Comparative analysis of national human resource management systems.
COHR406.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR407.name: Advanced Organizational Consulting
COHR407.desc: Methods and techniques to diagnose and solve a broad range of organizational problems from the perspective of an organizational consultant.
COHR407.prer: All of COMM 292, COHR 307 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR408.name: Organizational Design
COHR408.desc: Techniques and approaches for evaluating and adjusting the structures of organization.
COHR408.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR409.name: Creativity and Innovation
COHR409.desc: Techniques and approaches to managing creativity and innovation in organizations.
COHR409.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR410.name: Knowledge Management
COHR410.desc: Techniques and approaches to managing knowledge and learning in organizations.
COHR410.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR411.name: Managing and Building Teams
COHR411.desc: Techniques and approaches for building effective teams, handling decision-making in teams, creating reward structures, and developing appropriate leadership models.
COHR411.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR412.name: Advanced Topics in Organizational Behaviour
COHR412.desc: Understanding, critiquing, and analyzing behaviour and social processes in organizations. This course focuses on provocative and current topics that could not be covered in depth in the introductory course.
COHR412.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR433.name: Employment Law
COHR433.desc: Introduction to legislation and application of legal principles that govern the employment relationship.
COHR433.prer: All of COMM 292, COMM 393 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR486.name: Special Topics in Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources

FSCT201.name: Introduction to Forensic Science
FSCT201.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7320.

FSCT202.name: Applied Ethics
FSCT202.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT LIBS 7002.

FSCT203.name: Report Writing and Communication for Forensic Investigation
FSCT203.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT COMM 7200.

FSCT280.name: Introductory Forensic Science I
FSCT280.desc: Block registration for the introduction to forensic science course taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT290.name: Introductory Forensic Science II
FSCT290.desc: Block registration for the applied ethics and report writing and communication for forensic investigation courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT301.name: Forensic Biology; DNA Typing Theory
FSCT301.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8150.

FSCT302.name: Quality Assurance for Forensic Science
FSCT302.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8370.

FSCT303.name: Business Management for Forensic Science
FSCT303.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8371.

FSCT310.name: Research Methodology and Measurement Models
FSCT310.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7910.

FSCT311.name: Forensic Biology: Evidence Recovery
FSCT311.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8155.

FSCT312.name: Medico-Legal Aspects of Alcohol
FSCT312.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8230.

FSCT313.name: Crime Scene Investigation
FSCT313.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7310.

FSCT314.name: The Science of Fingerprints - Theory
FSCT314.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8320.

FSCT315.name: Forensic Toxicology I
FSCT315.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8240.

FSCT380.name: Intermediate Forensic Science I
FSCT380.desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: DNA typing theory, quality assurance, and business management for forensic science courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT390.name: Intermediate Forensic Science II
FSCT390.desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: evidence recovery, research methodology, and elective courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT401.name: Forensic Biology: DNA Typing Applications
FSCT401.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8160.

FSCT409.name: Law for Forensic Science
FSCT409.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7009.

FSCT410.name: The Expert Witness - Prepared for Court
FSCT410.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7010. [2-0-0]

FSCT411.name: Population Genetics
FSCT411.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8305.

FSCT412.name: Forensic Chemistry and Toxicology
FSCT412.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8156.

FSCT480.name: Advanced Forensic Science I
FSCT480.desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: DNA typing applications, law and forensic science courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT490.name: Advanced Forensic Science II
FSCT490.desc: Block registration for the expert witness testimony, population genetics, and forensic chemistry and toxicology courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

MTRL201.name: Technical Communication
MTRL201.desc: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Materials Engineering Program.
MTRL201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

MTRL250.name: Principles and Calculations in Materials Engineering
MTRL250.desc: Basic heat and mass balances applied to materials engineering; thermodynamic principles applied to materials processing: heat of reaction, free energy, activity, phase equilibrium.

MTRL252.name: Thermodynamics of Materials I
MTRL252.desc: High temperature equilibria: reactions involving gases, Ellingham diagrams, phase diagrams; thermodynamics of combustion systems relevant to materials engineering; advanced heat and mass balances applied to materials engineering.

MTRL263.name: Transport Phenomena I - Fluid Mechanics
MTRL263.desc: Fluid statics; fluid mechanics; laminar and turbulent flow; equations of continuity and motion; boundary layers; flow in conduits and packed and fluidized beds; flow measurements.

MTRL264.name: Transport Phenomena II - Heat Transport
MTRL264.desc: Conduction, forced and natural convection, and radiation.  Heat transfer with fluid flow, applications of heat exchange, and solidification of castings.

MTRL280.name: Materials in Design
MTRL280.desc: The process of materials selection for different design criteria; the importance of shape and processing variables; the use of computer software in the selection process.

MTRL340.name: Manufacturing in Materials Engineering
MTRL340.desc: Manufacturing processes from a materials perspective; metal casting, heat treating processes, forming processes, machining, and joining. Role of manufacturing in microstructure and material properties development and on component performance.

MTRL350.name: Thermodynamics of Materials II
MTRL350.desc: Low temperature equilibria: solution thermochemistry, electrochemistry, chemical potential and free energy diagrams applied to materials processing and thermodynamic modelling.

MTRL358.name: Hydrometallurgy I
MTRL358.desc: Aqueous extraction of metals from ores and concentrates.

MTRL359.name: Hydrometallurgy I Laboratory
MTRL359.desc: Laboratory exercises on aqueous extraction of metals from ores and concentrates.

MTRL361.name: Modelling of Materials Processes
MTRL361.desc: Mathematical and physical modelling of processes employed in the production of materials. The application of models to analyse, design and improve materials production.

MTRL363.name: Transport Phenomena III - Mass Transport
MTRL363.desc: Diffusion and mass transfer with chemical reaction; gas-liquid, gas-solid and liquid-liquid systems; analysis of mass transfer processes in metallurgical operations; mixing in continuous and batch processes.

MTRL365.name: Mechanical Behaviour of Materials
MTRL365.desc: Polycrystalline and single crystal deformation; dislocation theory; strengthening mechanisms; fracture mechanics; fatigue; high temperature deformation mechanisms.

MTRL378.name: Phase Transformations
MTRL378.desc: Solidification and solid state transformations; nucleation and growth processes; segregation and structure in castings; phase changes in steel; transformation diagrams; diffusion equations.

MTRL381.name: Structure and Properties Laboratory
MTRL381.desc: Structure and properties of ferrous and non-ferrous metals; heat treatment; hardenability; metallography; age hardening.

MTRL382.name: Ceramics
MTRL382.desc: Fundamentals of engineering ceramics focusing on raw materials, forming, sintering and properties, characterization, and design with ceramics.

MTRL392.name: Engineering Technical Communication
MTRL392.desc: Written and oral technical communication. Report preparation and oral presentation of technical information.

MTRL394.name: Polymer and Polymer Matrix Composites
MTRL394.desc: The structure and properties of polymeric materials, reinforced polymers and polymer matrix composites with emphasis on their engineering properties and applications.

MTRL398.name: Engineering Written Communication
MTRL398.desc: Written communication in engineering. Reporting of technical material.

MTRL442.name: Coatings and Surface Modification
MTRL442.desc: Strategies for ceramic and metallic coatings by melting-solidification, from the vapour state and from solution, and methods of surface modification.

MTRL451.name: Microstructural Analysis Laboratory
MTRL451.desc: Basic principles and techniques of microstructural analysis with particular reference to engineered materials including x-ray, SEM microprobe TEM and high energy electron analysis.

MTRL455.name: Economic Aspects of Materials Engineering
MTRL455.desc: Time value of money, cash flows, capital and operating cost estimation, financial decision making and relevant case studies.

MTRL456.name: Environmental Degradation of Materials
MTRL456.desc: Fundamental aspects of environmental degradation of metals (corrosion), ceramics, adn polymers, with an empasis on aqueous environments.

MTRL458.name: Hydrometallurgy II
MTRL458.desc: Leaching, purification, precipitation, regeneration; thermodynamics and kinetics of separation steps; electrochemical applications.

MTRL460.name: Monitoring and Optimization of Materials Processing
MTRL460.desc: Measurement systems for materials processing and evaluation, methods of data collection and analysis in materials engineering, materials processing monitoring and control, design of experiments for materials processing and optimization.

MTRL466.name: Engineering Project I
MTRL466.desc: Design projects to illustrate the full spectrum of design encountered in Metals and Materials Engineering including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials.

MTRL467.name: Engineering Project II
MTRL467.desc: Design projects to illustrate the full spectrum of design encountered in Metals and Materials Engineering including the design of components, structures and processes used to manufacture materials.

MTRL471.name: Nanofibre Technology
MTRL471.desc: Introduction to nanomaterials in the form of fibres and composites, including processing, structure, characterization methods, properties, and modeling. Credit will only be given for one of MTRL 471 or MTRL 571.

MTRL472.name: Welding and Joining of Materials
MTRL472.desc: Case studies addressing temperature modelling in welding and joining, material selection for welds and joints, calculation of properties for welds and joints, mechanical analysis of joints, and design of welding and joining procedures.

MTRL475.name: Microstructure Engineering
MTRL475.desc: Follows the production of metallurgical products, focusing on process design models used to describe solidification, recrystallization, and precipitation.

MTRL478.name: Electronic Materials
MTRL478.desc: Semiconductor materials, MOSFET structure, operation and applications in digital circuits, fabrication techniques, basic mask and fabrication flow design and semiconductor fabrication process theories at an entry level. [3-0-0]

MTRL485.name: Failure of Materials
MTRL485.desc: Failure by excess deformation, fracture, fatigue, and environmental effects. Failure theories and case studies of engineering failures.

MTRL486.name: Nondestructive Evaluation
MTRL486.desc: Principles of test methods; inspection techniques and equipment; quantitative flaw evaluation; reliability analysis.

MTRL489.name: Seminar III
MTRL489.desc: Training and practice in public speaking and presentation of technical papers.

MTRL494.name: Composite Materials
MTRL494.desc: Understanding the properties and the mechanical behaviour of composite materials with emphasis on analysis, design, and manufacturing. Credit will only be given for one of MTRL 494, 594.

MTRL495.name: Biomaterials
MTRL495.desc: Engineered materials in medical applications with an emphasis on material properties, functionality, design, and material response in the biological environment.

LASO204.name: Introduction to Law and Society
LASO204.desc: Ideas, concepts, and frameworks for thinking about the nature of law and legal processes in both Canadian and global contexts.

POLS200.name: Beginner's Polish
POLS200.desc: Introduction to contemporary Polish. Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.

POLS300.name: Intermediate Polish
POLS300.desc: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition.

POLS345.name: Introduction to Twentieth-Century Polish Literature
POLS345.desc: Readings and discussion of selected works of representative writers.

POLS424.name: Polish Literature and Film in Translation
POLS424.desc: Selected films and translated literature by Polish writers and filmmakers, with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

POLS426.name: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film (in English)
POLS426.desc: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and film.

SCAN332.name: Topics in Scandinavian Studies (in English)
SCAN332.desc: Selected issues and topics in Scandinavian cultural studies.

SCAN333.name: Major Works of Scandinavian Literature (in English)
SCAN333.desc: Selected Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, and Icelandic texts ranging from Old Norse sagas to contemporary literary works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in Scandinavia.

SCAN334.name: Contemporary Scandinavian Fiction (in English)
SCAN334.desc: Study of texts, topics, or genres against the background of current Scandinavian literary, social, and political developments.

SCAN335.name: Vikings and Norse Mythology (in English)
SCAN335.desc: History, literature, and mythology of early Scandinavian societies.

SCAN336.name: Scandinavian Crime Fiction (in English)
SCAN336.desc: Crime fictions and films as a mirror of Scandinavian society.

SCAN337.name: Scandinavian Cinema (in English)
SCAN337.desc: An introduction to the cinemas of the Scandinavian region.

SCAN411.name: Scandinavian Drama and Film in Translation
SCAN411.desc: Traces the explosive development of a provincial theatre into one of the seminal forces of twentieth-century drama and film. Emphasis on Ibsen, Strindberg, and Bergman.

SCAN412.name: The Northern European Epic in Translation
SCAN412.desc: Major prose works of the Scandinavian literatures with emphasis on the stylistic qualities of the Old Icelandic sagas and their transformation in the novels of modern Icelandic, Danish, Swedish, and Norwegian writers. Possible authors: Laxness, Blixen, Hamsun, Lindgren.

SCAN413.name: The Literatures of the Baltic in English Translation
SCAN413.desc: An examination through literature of the historical, cultural, and ethnic elements that have made the Baltic area the crossroads of northeastern Europe. The emphasis is on literature from the Germanic  and Finno-Ugric languages. Authors to be studied include Strindberg, Tikkanen, Transtromer, Kaplinski, Grass, Bobrowski, Lenz.

SCAN414.name: Topics in Danish and Northern European Cultural Studies (in English)
SCAN414.desc: Selected topics, such as ethnicity, migration, identity, women's issues, Danish and Northern European film.

SCAN415.name: The World of the Sagas (in English)
SCAN415.desc: Scandinavian contributions to medieval and early modern world literature, culture and history.
