ENVR200.name: Introduction to Environmental Science
ENVR200.desc: Seminars and field trips introducing the major global, regional, and local environmental issues facing human societies. [3-0-0]
ENVR200.prer: Open to all students with second-year, or higher, standing.

ENVR300.name: Introduction to Research in Environmental Science
ENVR300.desc: Environmental research.  Students investigate research methodologies and reporting in a range of scientific disciplines and fields. [3-0-0]
ENVR300.prer: Open to all students with third-year, or higher, standing in the Faculty of Science.

ENVR400.name: Community Project in Environmental Science
ENVR400.desc: Instructor-guided collaboration between student teams and community partners on community-based environmental science projects. Teams articulate project questions and goals, devise methods, conduct research and communicate results. Credit will be given for only one of ENVR 400 or ENVR 449. [3-0-0;3-0-0]

ENVR410.name: Energy, Environment, and Society
ENVR410.desc: The role of energy in human societies throughout history and the environmental and social implications of energy use.  Coverage of both the science and policy of energy use.  Energy supply and demand, energy transitions, analytical tools, impacts, and alternatives. [3-0-0]
ENVR410.prer: Fourth-year standing in B.Sc., B.A.Sc. or related programs.

ENVR420.name: Ecohydrology of Watersheds and Water Systems
ENVR420.desc: Analysis of water resources from a water-in-ecosystem perspective. Application to natural, managed, and urban systems, considering ecological interactions with hydrological processes. Exploration of biogeochemical processes related to water quality, and human impacts on water resources. [3-0-0]

ENVR430.name: Ecological Dimensions of Sustainability
ENVR430.desc: Current issues. Application to agricultural, energy, and resource systems in terrestrial and aquatic contexts. Analysis of complex problems; incorporation of science into novel interdisciplinary solutions. [3-0-0]
ENVR430.prer: One of ENVR 300, BIOL 230. Or fourth year standing in the BSCN program or other demonstrated ecology background.

ENVR440.name: Analytical Methods in Sustainability Science
ENVR440.desc: Sustainability analysis through a series of case studies. Example approaches include cost-benefit analysis, trade-offs analysis, and life-cycle analysis. Active learning in a computer lab using real-world data. [2-2-0]
ENVR440.prer: One of ENVR 200, ASIC 220, SCIE 220, GEOG 211. Third-year standing.

ENVR448.name: Directed Studies in Environmental Science
ENVR448.desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of an ENSC advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required prior to registration.
ENVR448.prer: Third year standing in the Faculty of Science.

ENVR449.name: Environmental Science HonoursThesis
ENVR449.prer: ENVR 300 and fourth-year standing in the B.Sc. Environmental Sciences honours program.

ENVR490.name: Student Directed Seminars in Environmental Sciences
ENVR490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in environmental sciences, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars (www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/sds/sds_handbook.pdf).

EPSE171.name: Education in the Adolescent Years
EPSE171.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EPSE271.name: Teaching Adolescents with Special Learning Needs
EPSE271.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EPSE303.name: Teaching Highly Able Learners
EPSE303.desc: Identification and appraisal of developmental and educational needs of highly able learners. [3-0]

EPSE306.name: Education during the Adolescent Years
EPSE306.desc: Developmental characteristics of persons from pre-school age through adulthood. Physical, social, cognitive, moral, and emotional growth of both normal and exceptional children in grades 8-12. The teacher's role in assisting such students to deal with major developmental issues and problems.  Pass/Fail.

EPSE307.name: Applying Developmental Theories in the Classroom

EPSE310.name: Assessment and Learning in the Classroom

EPSE311.name: Cultivating Supportive School and Classroom Environments

EPSE312.name: Introduction to the Study of Exceptional Children
EPSE312.desc: An examination of all groups of exceptional children in terms of definition, incidence, characteristics, diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite to most other courses in Special Education. Can be taken concurrently with several other introductory courses in Special Education. [3-0]

EPSE313.name: Educational Application of Developmental Theories
EPSE313.desc: Theories of human development; physical, social, cognitive, moral, and emotional developmental characteristics from infancy to adolescence; implications for educational practice with students of different age and developmental status during the elementary school years.  Pass/Fail.

EPSE314.name: Introduction to the Education of the Visually Impaired
EPSE314.desc: An introductory course reviewing the identification and education of blind and partially sighted children. Designed to aid teachers to accommodate visually impaired children in the regular class setting. [3-0]

EPSE315.name: Language Disorders of Exceptional Children
EPSE315.desc: The course deals with severe language disabilities in children. Emphasis is placed on theories of language acquisition as applied to assessment. [3-0]

EPSE316.name: Learning Disabilities
EPSE316.desc: Identification, assessment and needs of children with learning disabilities. [3-0-0]

EPSE317.name: Development and Exceptionality in the Regular Classroom
EPSE317.desc: The teacher's role in dealing with major developmental and special educational issues and problems within the regular classroom program, including working with supportive services, parents, and communities. Designated sections will focus on early childhood, middle childhood or adolescence. Pass/Fail.

EPSE320.name: Classroom Inclusion of Students who are Blind and Visually Impaired
EPSE320.desc: Inclusion issues of students with visual impairments in general education classrooms; information about visual impairment, classroom adaptations and accommodations, and application of Universal Design. Appropriate for education majors and classroom teachers. [3-0]

EPSE342.name: Field Experiences with Individual Atypical Children
EPSE342.desc: Supervised experience working with several atypical children in a community setting. Diagnosing needs, planning programs and integrating instruction and materials on an individual basis. [1-9]
EPSE342.prer: Permission of the department is required.

EPSE344.name: Programming in Special Education: Developing Perspective
EPSE344.desc: An examination of the range of educational methodologies and teaching procedures and a discussion of their implications for the establishment of programs useful in working with exceptional children. The course comprises a practical examination and a detailed comparison of the major special educational methodologies. [3-1]

EPSE348.name: Family-Centred Practice for Children with Special Needs

EPSE390.name: Special Topics
EPSE390.desc: A study of innovative practices, ideas, and theories in special education. The specific topics may change yearly to reflect changing priorities and interests in special education, and the specific interest and competencies of visiting and regular faculty. [3-0]
EPSE390.prer: One of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. Permission of the instructor is required.

EPSE399.name: Education and Culture in the Deaf Community
EPSE399.desc: Designed for students intending to work with deaf persons.

EPSE401.name: Instructional Design
EPSE401.desc: Principles of instructional design and their application to the development, analysis, and evaluation of instructional plans for selected settings, instructional formats, and age groupings of learners. [3-0]

EPSE403.name: Education of Students with Developmental Disabilities in Inclusive Settings

EPSE404.name: Principles of Applied Behaviour Analysis
EPSE404.desc: Credit will be given for only one of EPSE 404 or 405. [3-0-0]
EPSE404.prer: One of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. Or permission of instructor.

EPSE406.name: Typical and Atypical Development in Infants and Children

EPSE408.name: Educational Programming for Highly Able Learners
EPSE408.desc: Planning elementary and secondary level programs for highly able learners. [3-0]

EPSE410.name: Assistive Technologies in Special Education
EPSE410.desc: The use of microcomputers, adaptive technology, and software across age levels and areas of exceptionality in special education and health care settings. [2-1]

EPSE411.name: Augmentative and Alternative Communication for Individuals with Severe Speech and/or Physical Impairments

EPSE415.name: Technology for the Visually Impaired
EPSE415.desc: Preparation of teachers to work with a variety of technological devices designed for students who are blind or visually impaired, e.g., computers, electronic reading devices, and closed circuit television. This course is restricted to students enrolled in a program for Education of Visually Impaired Children. [2-2]

EPSE421.name: Assessment of Learning Difficulties
EPSE421.desc: Theories of learning and instruction; principles and practices of diagnosis and assessment as these relate to students with relevant special needs.

EPSE425.name: Provisions in the Education of the Visually Handicapped
EPSE425.desc: Provisions, procedures and methodology in the teaching of specific curriculum for the blind and visually impaired. Life skills and adjustment to blindness. This course is restricted to students in a program of Education of Visually Impaired Children. [3-0]

EPSE426.name: Principles of Teaching the Hearing Impaired
EPSE426.desc: An introductory course reviewing methods of teaching, administration, and organization of the educational program for the hearing impaired. Pre or corequisite: EPSE 312 or 317. [3-0]
EPSE426.prer: EPSE 312. May be taken as a corequisite.

EPSE431.name: Programming for Children with Specific Learning Disabilities
EPSE431.desc: Methods and programs for learning disabilities are reviewed. Practical experience in the development and execution of a remedial program is required. [3-0]

EPSE433.name: Assessment and Positive Behavioural Support in School and Community Settings

EPSE436.name: Survey of Behaviour Disorders in Children and Adolescents

EPSE437.name: Interventions for Children and Adolescents with Behaviour Disorders

EPSE455.name: Introduction to Orientation and Mobility for the Blind
EPSE455.desc: Understanding the process of teaching independent travel to blind students, including orientation and mobility skills in school. Restricted to students enrolled in a program for Education of Visually Impaired Children or those who hold the Diploma or the equivalent. [2-2]

EPSE461.name: Educational Diagnosis and Remedial Instruction
EPSE461.desc: Interpretation of informal and standardized test scores in educational diagnosis; estimates of actual and optimum levels of individual achievement; individual differences as factors affecting performance; methods of encouraging the optimum achievement of individuals; methods and practice materials for remedial teaching.

EPSE462.name: Human Development in Education
EPSE462.desc: Investigates selected concepts of developmental theory in terms of their influence upon instructional practice. Particular emphasis is placed on social and intellectual development.

EPSE481.name: Introduction to Research in Education
EPSE481.desc: The nature of scientific study and essentials of survey, experimental and other empirical research designs. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work.
EPSE481.prer: EPSE 482. May also be taken as a corequisite.

EPSE482.name: Introduction to Statistics for Research in Education
EPSE482.desc: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work involving quantitative methodology. [3-0]
EPSE482.prer: Proficiency in modern high school algebra.

EPSE483.name: Reading and Interpreting Research in Education
EPSE483.desc: Introductory research methods course for students who wish to be critical readers rather than producers of educational research.  Develops skills for locating, understanding, interpreting and critiquing educational empirical research.  May not be used as a prerequisite to EPSE 592 or EPSE 596. [3-0]

EPSE484.name: Nonparametric and Related Statistics
EPSE484.desc: Distribution-free statistical techniques for analysis of ranked data, and analysis of discrete observations. [3-0]

SANS300.name: Introductory Sanskrit
SANS300.desc: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.

SANS301.name: Introductory Sanskrit I
SANS301.desc: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300.

SANS302.name: Introductory Sanskrit II
SANS302.desc: Continuation of SANS 301. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 302 or SANS 101 or SANS 300.

SANS400.name: Intermediate Sanskrit
SANS400.desc: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402.

SANS401.name: Intermediate Sanskrit I
SANS401.desc: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 401 or SANS 201 or SANS 400.

SANS402.name: Intermediate Sanskrit II
SANS402.desc: Continuation of SANS 401. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 402 or SANS 202 or SANS 400.

SANS450.name: Further Readings in Sanskrit
SANS450.desc: Study of selected texts belonging to a particular period (e.g., Vedic) or representing a specific branch of kavya (poetic literature) or sastra (technical-philosophical literature).
SANS450.prer: One of SANS 200, SANS 202, SANS 400, SANS 402.

SCIE001.name: Science One
SCIE001.desc: An innovative first-year multidisciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines.  See the Science One website (www.scienceone.ubc.ca)  for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE 001.
SCIE001.prer: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12;  and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12 and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

SCIE113.name: First-Year Seminar in Science
SCIE113.desc: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts.  Enrollment limited to students with first-year standing in the B. Sc. program in Science.

SCIE120.name: Topics in Sustainability Science
SCIE120.desc: Topics in sustainability, based on concepts introduced in first-year Science courses. [1-0-0]
SCIE120.crer: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121. Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.

SCIE300.name: Communicating Science
SCIE300.desc: Effective communication and presentation skills in science. [1-0-3]
SCIE300.crer: One of BIOL 300, STAT 200, STAT 241 and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.

SCIE420.name: Sustainability for Community and the World
SCIE420.desc: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations. [3-0-0]
SCIE420.prer: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW  386, LFS  250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, SCIE 120. Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

CONS101.name: Introduction to Conservation
CONS101.desc: Seminars on current natural resources conservation and forest sciences topics. [1-0-0]

CONS127.name: Observing the Earth from Space
CONS127.desc: Exploration of innovative Earth observation and other geospatial technologies and how they allow us to better understand the changing Earth. [3-0-0]

CONS200.name: Foundations of Conservation
CONS200.desc: Conceptual foundations of conservation; means of conserving nature and natural resources. [3-0-0]

CONS210.name: Visualizing Climate Change
CONS210.desc: Introduction to climate change through the lens of local landscapes and future scenarios, using visual media to communicate the underlying science & psychology, and engage communities in local climate change solutions.

CONS302.name: Issues in Genomics and the Environment
CONS302.desc: Current and topical issues, including genetic determinism, environmental DNA, genomics and climate change, revival of extinct species, and applications of genomics in natural environments.

CONS330.name: Conservation Science and Sustainability
CONS330.desc: Fundamental concepts in conservation science. Different philosophies, perspectives, and disciplines used in setting priorities for managing biodiversity at all scales. [3-2-0]

CONS340.name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems for Forestry and Conservation
CONS340.desc: Introduction to principles, practice and context of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) applied to forest management and natural resource conservation issues. Priority enrolment to students in the Faculty of Forestry. [2-2-0]

CONS370.name: Aboriginal Forestry
CONS370.desc: Issues the may be encountered in professional natural resources work with or for Aboriginal communities and organization, including contemporary issues of Aboriginal rights and title, traditional uses, and self-government. [3-0-0]

CONS415.name: Land, Trees, and Property Institutions
CONS415.desc: Exploration of the forces that gave rise to the global variety of systems of property for trees and forestlands; evolution in the governance of property. [3-0-0]

CONS425.name: Sustainable Energy: Policy and Governance
CONS425.desc: Energy as a global policy problem; current energy challenges; energy systems and energy analysis; the politics and policy of energy alternatives. [3-0-0]
CONS425.prer: Third- or fouth-year standing; 100-level MATH course.

CONS440.name: Conservation Policy
CONS440.desc: Contemporary issues are used to examine conservation policies designed to achieve conservation objectives. [3-0]

CONS449.name: Directed Studies in Natural Resources Conservation
CONS449.desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry out directed studies of specific problems in natural resources conservation.

CONS451.name: Integrated Field School
CONS451.desc: Field methods, research and analysis, community oriented projects, and the interactions between biological and social aspects of conservation research. Students may not take any other courses in conjunction with CONS 451. Restricted to B.Sc.N. students in the fourth year of the Science and Management Major.

CONS452.name: Global Perspectives Capstone
CONS452.desc: Examination of global resources and sustainability via scenario evaluation, modelling, and prescription.
CONS452.prer: One of CONS 340, GEOB 270 and fourth year standing in the Global Perspectives Major.

CONS453.name: International Conservation and Forest Ecosystem Management Field School
CONS453.desc: International, experiential learning in conservation and forest ecosystem management. A 300-level ecology course such as CONS 330 is strongly recommended as a prerequisite. Fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration is required.
CONS453.prer: One of FRST 231, BIOL 300 and all of FRST 210, FRST 211. Or 6 credits of ecology based courses (e.g. BIOL 230, BIOL 306, APBI 260, APBI 360). Third-year standing and permission of the instructor are required.

CONS481.name: Conservation Planning and Wildland Recreation
CONS481.desc: Theory and tools needed for the selection and design of protected areas, the designation of land use types, and the management and conservation of wildland recreation resources. [2-2-0]

CONS486.name: Fish Conservation and Management
CONS486.desc: Principles of fish biology, population and community ecology necessary to understand conservation and management; overview of current issues, tactics and institutions involved with fisheries conservation and management. [2-3-0]

CONS491.name: Recreation and Tourism Planning
CONS491.desc: Principles and methods for planning urban and rural recreation and related tourism resources including analyzing recreation resources, applying policies and standards, developing park/recreation area management plans, and understanding benefits to human and community wellbeing and biodiversity. [3-0-0]

CONS495.name: Principles of Managing Problem Wildlife in Forests and Agricultural Environments
CONS495.desc: Impacts of wildlife on crop productivity in temperate and tropical environments, the resiliency of wildlife populations to conventional control methodology, adoption of innovative methods to reduce crop damage, and the impact of introduced species on native fauna. [2-0-1]
CONS495.prer: One of BIOL 230, BIOL 306, APBI 444, APBI 460, FRST 201, FRST 202, FRST 395, FRST 444, FRST 495 and one of FRST 231, BIOL 300.

CONS498.name: Thesis or Special Project
CONS498.desc: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the supervision of a staff member.

ATSC113.name: Applied Meteorology
ATSC113.desc: Atmospheric-science principles elucidated by case studies applied to snow sports, sailing, surfing, soaring, and flying. [3-0-0]

ATSC201.name: Meteorology of Storms
ATSC201.desc: Characteristics and physical processes of thunderstorms, tornadoes, lightning, hail, hurricanes, blizzards, cyclones and other storms. [3-0-0]

ATSC212.name: Earth and Atmospheric Science Introductory Computing Laboratory
ATSC212.desc: Computing tools, including Unix/Linux, Web page creation, programming languages used for numerical calculation, database programs. [0-2]

ATSC301.name: Atmospheric Radiation and Remote Sensing
ATSC301.desc: Energy transfer at infrared, visible, and microwave wavelengths. Analysis of satellite measurements of the atmosphere and surface. [3-0-0]
ATSC301.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158 and familiarity with a programming language.

ATSC303.name: Methods in Atmospheric Science
ATSC303.desc: An introduction to instrumentation used in monitoring the state of the atmosphere; a brief survey of methods of analysis of meteorological data. [2-2-0]
ATSC303.prer: EOSC 211 and one of ATSC 201, GEOB 200.

ATSC398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
ATSC398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Winter Session (Term 2) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

ATSC399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
ATSC399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

ATSC404.name: Dynamic Meteorology
ATSC404.desc: Dynamic principles governing atmospheric motions on a rotating planet. Simplified mathematical models of atmospheric flow based on scale analysis. Application to synoptic-scale and general circulation of the troposphere. [3-0-0]
ATSC404.prer: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316 and one of EOSC 250, MATH 217, MATH 317.

ATSC405.name: Cloud Physics and Chemistry
ATSC405.desc: Cloud thermodynamics, chemistry and microphysics. Computer modelling of droplet growth, convection, and mixing. Application of differential equations to atmospheric problems. [3-0-0]
ATSC405.prer: MATH 215. Familiarity with a programming language is required.

ATSC406.name: Operational Meteorology
ATSC406.desc: Introduction to meteorological prediction, meteorological data analysis, prognosis of weather systems, motion and development, satellite imagery, Doppler radar, numerical weather prediction, synoptic and mesoscale forecasting, applied laboratory exercises. [2-2-0]

ATSC409.name: Numerical Techniques for Ocean, Atmosphere and Earth Scientists
ATSC409.desc: Web-based introduction to the practical numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations including considerations of stability and accuracy. Credit will be granted for only one of ATSC 409 or ATSC 506/EOSC 511. [0-0-3]
ATSC409.prer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265. Familiarity with a programming language is required.

ATSC448.name: Directed Studies
ATSC448.desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of the undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

ATSC449.name: Honours Project
ATSC449.desc: Honours students must submit a graduating report based on a project undertaken with the approval of the Associate Chair of the Atmospheric Science Program.

ATSC490.name: Student Directed Seminars in Atmospheric Science
ATSC490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in atmospheric science, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars (www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/sds/sds_handbook.pdf).

ATSC498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
ATSC498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) after fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.
ATSC498.prer: ATSC 399 and one of ATSC 303, GEOB 304.

ATSC499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
ATSC499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) of the fifth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

STAT100.name: Statistical Thinking
STAT100.desc: Explores the development and use of statistical thinking in the modern world. The aim is to develop statistical literacy and demonstrate applications of statistics in research and society. Students who obtain credit for any of STAT 306, 307, 308, 344 cannot in the same or later term gain credit for STAT 100. [3-0-1]

STAT200.name: Elementary Statistics for Applications
STAT200.desc: Classical, nonparametric, and robust inferences about means, variances, and analysis of variance, using computers. Emphasis on problem formulation, assumptions, and interpretation. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-1-0]
STAT200.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT203.name: Statistical Methods
STAT203.desc: Organizing, displaying and summarizing data. Inference estimation and testing for elementary probability models. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-1-0]

STAT241.name: Introductory Probability and Statistics
STAT241.desc: Probability models, random variables and vectors, estimation, testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit, quality control. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar). [3-1-0]
STAT241.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT251.name: Elementary Statistics
STAT251.desc: Probability, discrete and continuous random variables, joint probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar). [3-1-0]
STAT251.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT300.name: Intermediate Statistics for Applications
STAT300.desc: Further topics in statistical inference, including parametric and non-parametric methods, goodness-of-fit methods, analysis of variance and covariance, regression analysis, categorical data analysis, experimental designs, time series, model fitting, and statistical computing. [3-1-0]
STAT300.prer: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 366.

STAT302.name: Introduction to Probability
STAT302.desc: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-0-0]
STAT302.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 217, MATH 253, MATH 263.

STAT305.name: Introduction to Statistical Inference
STAT305.desc: Review of probability theory. Sampling distribution theory, large sample theory and methods of estimation and hypothesis testing, including maximum likelihood estimation, likelihood ratio testing and confidence interval construction. [3-0-1]
STAT305.prer: Either (a) one of STAT 200, BIOL 300, STAT 241, STAT 251, COMM 291, ECON 325, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 366 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302;  or (b) a score of 65% or higher in one of MATH 302, STAT 302. The Department recommends that students meet the prerequisite through option (a). Note there is credit exclusion between MATH 302, STAT 302 and STAT 241, STAT 251.

STAT306.name: Finding Relationships in Data
STAT306.desc: Modeling a response (output) variable as a function of several explanatory (input) variables:  multiple regression for a continuous response, logistic regression for a binary response, and log-linear models for count data.  Finding low-dimensional structure:  principal components analysis.  Cluster analysis.  (Consult the Credit Exclusion List within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar). [3-0-1]
STAT306.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302.

STAT307.name: Statistics Laboratory I
STAT307.desc: Implementing theory in applications. Problem based learning. Generation and analysis of case data. Modelling, computation and reporting. [0-4-0]

STAT321.name: Stochastic Signals and Systems
STAT321.desc: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems (e.g., communication systems); discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modeling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making. [3-0-2]
STAT321.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from Statistics Student Services.

STAT335.name: Statistics in Quality Assurance
STAT335.desc: Philosophy of quality improvement and total quality control. Definitions of quality. Deming's principles, Ishikawa's tools, control charts, acceptance sampling, continuous improvement, quality design. Credit cannot be obtained for both STAT 335 and WOOD 335. [3-0-1]
STAT335.prer: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300.

STAT344.name: Sample Surveys
STAT344.desc: Planning and practice of sample surveys. Random sampling, bias and variance, unequal probability sampling, systematic, multistage and stratified sampling, ratio and regression estimators, post-stratification, establishing a frame, pretesting, pilot studies, nonresponse and additional topics. [3-0-1]

STAT398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
STAT398.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Winter Session of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.
STAT398.prer: Registration in Statistics Honours or Major Program.

STAT399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
STAT399.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

STAT404.name: Design and Analysis of Experiments
STAT404.desc: Theory and application of analysis of variance for standard experimental designs, including blocked, nested, factorial and split plot designs. Fixed and random effects, multiple comparisons, analysis of covariance. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar). [3-0-1]

STAT406.name: Methods for Statistical Learning
STAT406.desc: Flexible, data-adaptive methods for regression and classification models; regression smoothers; penalty methods; assessing accuracy of prediction; model selection; robustness; classification and regression trees; nearest-neighbour methods; neural networks; model averaging and ensembles; computational time and visualization for large data sets. [3-0-1]

STAT443.name: Time Series and Forecasting
STAT443.desc: Trend and seasonality, autocorrelation, stationarity, stochastic models, exponential smoothing, Holt-Winters methods, Box-Jenkins approach, frequency domain analysis. [3-0-1]
STAT443.prer: One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 302 and one of STAT 200, ECON 325.

STAT445.name: Introduction to Exploratory Data Analysis
STAT445.desc: Methods for exploring and presenting the structure of data: one group of numbers, several groups, bivariate data, time series data and two-way tables. Data displays, outlier identification, transformations, resistant regression, several types of data smoothing, comparisons with standard statistical methods. [3-0-1]

STAT447.name: Special Topics in Statistics
STAT447.desc: Students should consult the Statistics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year.
STAT447.prer: STAT 305. Permission of the instructor is required.

STAT450.name: Case Studies in Statistics
STAT450.desc: Readings and projects in areas of current statistical application including environmental science, industrial statistics, official statistics, actuarial statistics, and medical statistics. [3-0-1]

STAT460.name: Statistical Inference I
STAT460.desc: A detailed theoretical development. Statistical models, exponential families, sufficiency, completeness, and detailed properties of point estimation. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0]

STAT461.name: Statistical Inference II
STAT461.desc: Detailed development of the theory of testing hypotheses and confidence regions, Bayesian models and inference, elements of decision theory and additional topics. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0]

STAT498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
STAT498.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

STAT499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
STAT499.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Term 1 of Winter Session of fifth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

ARCL103.name: Introduction to Archaeology
ARCL103.desc: Survey of world archaeology, from the emergence of humankind to the beginning of state societies.

ARCL140.name: Bones: The Origins of Humanity
ARCL140.desc: The origin and evolution of the human lineage and the emergence of human biological and cultural traits with emphasis on the fossil record before the Pleistocene. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCL 140 or ANTH 225.

ARCL203.name: Archaeological Methods
ARCL203.desc: Introduces the methods and principles applied in anthropological archaeology and cultural-historical research.

ARCL204.name: Great Archaeological Discoveries
ARCL204.desc: An examination of some momentous discoveries in archaeology that have shaped our knowledge of the ancient world and the history of humanity.

ARCL228.name: Forensic Anthropology
ARCL228.desc: The application of methods from biological anthropology and archaeology to the identification, recovery, and analysis of skeletal remains from crime scenes, mass disasters, and unexplained deaths.

ARCL231.name: Ancient North America
ARCL231.desc: Introductory survey of North American archaeology comparing the ancient cultures from all major regions of Canada and the US.

ARCL232.name: Ancient Latin America
ARCL232.desc: The archaeology of ancient Mexico, Central and South America, highlighting recent discoveries about the emergence and growth of civilizations such as the Aztecs, Maya, Zapotec, Inca, Chimor and their ancestors.

ARCL305.name: Archaeological Interpretation
ARCL305.desc: Current theoretical developments explored through the practice of archaeology. Examples drawn from a range of times and places focusing on emerging technologies, food production, colonial encounters and culture contact, materiality and symbolic systems, social inequality and complexity, and human-environmental interactions.

ARCL306.name: Summer Field Training in Archaeology
ARCL306.desc: Intensive training in excavation techniques and interpretation, including mapping procedures, recording, preliminary analysis, and reporting. Students will participate in an excavation for the Summer Session and will use this excavation as a basis for lectures, discussions and reports. Additional Field Trip Fees are charged for this course.

ARCL309.name: The Archaeology of Collapse and Sustainability
ARCL309.desc: An evaluation of the issues of sustainability and collapse of ecological and social systems through the archaeological study of the past.

ARCL318.name: Archaeology of Hunter-Gatherer-Forager-Societies
ARCL318.desc: Early hunter-gatherer-forager societies, spanning the period from the emergence of the first tool-using hominins to the origins of agriculture.

ARCL319.name: The Emergence of Complex Societies in Eurasia and Africa
ARCL319.desc: Archaeological evidence and theories for the origins and spread of settled village life, food production systems, and complex social and political organization: Early Neolithic period through to the appearance of the old world civilizations.

ARCL322.name: Archaeological Foundations of East and Southeast Asia
ARCL322.desc: Survey of the archaeology of East and Southeast Asia, with an emphasis on the beginnings of the economic, social, political, and artistic traditions and systems of the great civilizations, and the conditions in which they arose. Theories of cultural development emphasizing Neolithic and state-level societies will be discussed.

ARCL323.name: Archaeological Foundations of Mesoamerica
ARCL323.desc: The archaeology of Mexico and Central America with an emphasis on the emergence of economic, social, political, and religious organization. Seminar format discussing recent research and current discoveries.

ARCL324.name: Archaeological Foundations of South America
ARCL324.desc: The archaeology of South America with an emphasis on the emergence of economic, social, political, and religious organization, and a primary focus on the Andean region.  Seminar format with lectures discussing recent research and current discoveries.

ARCL325.name: Paleoanthropology
ARCL325.desc: Origin and development of the hominins; the hominin fossil record, and theories relating to hominin evolution.

ARCL326.name: Primatology
ARCL326.desc: A comprehensive survey of primates, with emphasis on evolution, ecology, social organization,  social behaviour, and field studies.

ARCL405.name: Archaeological and Anthropological Mapping
ARCL405.desc: Current methods in mapping spatial information in archaeology and related subfields of anthropology.

ARCL406.name: Analytical Techniques in Archaeology
ARCL406.desc: A survey of methods and techniques in the interpretation of archaeological data; practical experience in processing and analyzing archaeological materials by means of a research project. Students will prepare manuscripts, drawings and photographs for publication and will learn the basics of lithic and faunal analyses.

ARCL410.name: Archaeology of a Special Area in Africa, Eurasia, or Oceania
ARCL410.desc: Analysis of the archaeology of one of the listed areas, including a summary of the literature and examination of specific sites and analytical issues.  The area covered will vary according to the instructor's expertise.
ARCL410.prer: One of ARCL 305, ARCL 318, ARCL 319, ARCL 322.

ARCL411.name: Prehistory of a Special Area in the New World
ARCL411.desc: Analysis of the prehistory of a selected New World area, including a summary of the literature and discussion of relevant problems. The course will provide background for students in North, Central, and South American area studies. Typical offerings include the prehistory of Mesoamerica, the Southwest, North America and the Mayan areas.

ARCL419.name: The Archaeology of Death
ARCL419.desc: A survey of methods, theory, and case-studies in mortuary archaeology.

ARCL420.name: First Nations Archaeology of British Columbia
ARCL420.desc: An advanced study of the prehistoric archaeology of coastal and interior Native Peoples. A critical analysis of the archaeological evidence and interpretations of prehistoric cultural developments from the earliest migrations up to historical contact.

ARCL424.name: Practicing Archaeology and the Management of Cultural Resources
ARCL424.desc: Survey of the use of archaeology in the public context and interest, particularly the identification, evaluation, conservation, and management of archaeological resources.  Laws and policies, principles, methods, and ethical concerns guiding current practices, public involvement, relationships with indigenous communities, and contemporary issues in cultural resources management.

ARCL425.name: Nutritional Archaeology
ARCL425.desc: The archaeological evidence for the change of human diets over time and the methods used to reconstruct past diets.

ARCL430.name: Archaeological Survey Methods
ARCL430.desc: Analytical and practical skills in locating archaeological sites and data leading to spatial patterns and historical interpretation.

WOOD120.name: Introduction to Wood Products and Global Trade
WOOD120.desc: Introduction to forestry, wood products industry, processes, products, markets and global trade policy issues affecting the wood industry. Not available for credit to students in the B.S.F. degree. [2-3]

WOOD225.name: Communications Strategies
WOOD225.desc: Strategies for thinking critically and writing effectively about topics that engage practitioners in Forestry, particularly in Wood Products Processing.  Planning, drafting and editing of professional-quality documents for specialists and other stakeholders. Developing oral presentation skills.

WOOD241.name: Programming for Wood Products Manufacturing Applications
WOOD241.desc: Practical computer and problem solving cases taken from wood products manufacturing industrial applications. [2-4-0]

WOOD244.name: Quantitative Methods in the Wood Industry
WOOD244.desc: Solving practical problems in the wood industry using computer-based mathematical tools including spreadsheets, visual basic programming and relational database systems. [3-2-0]
WOOD244.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

WOOD245.name: Programming for Wood Products Manufacturing Applications
WOOD245.desc: Practical computer and problem solving cases taken from wood products manufacturing industrial applications. [2-4-0]

WOOD249.name: Contemporary Topics in Forestry and Wood Products
WOOD249.desc: Seminars on current forestry and wood products topics.

WOOD271.name: Wood Products Chemistry I
WOOD271.desc: Chemistry relating to wood and wood products: chemistry of lignin, cellulose, hemicelluloses, extractives, and biological degradation of lignocellulosics; wood pressure impregnation procedures. [3-3-0]
WOOD271.prer: WOOD 280 and one of CHEM 113, CHEM 123.

WOOD276.name: Mechanics of Wood Products
WOOD276.desc: Introduction to the strength of materials with emphasis on the elastic properties and ultimate strength of wood and wood products. [3-2-0]
WOOD276.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 117, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

WOOD280.name: Wood Anatomy and Identification
WOOD280.desc: Introduction to tree growth; macroscopic and microscopic anatomy and identification of softwoods and hardwoods; descriptions of cell wall ultra-structure, wood variability and wood quality. [3-2-0]

WOOD282.name: Wood Physics and Mechanics
WOOD282.desc: Wood-moisture relationships, transport phenomena, acoustical and electrical properties of wood. Effects of wood attributes at macro- and micro-levels on the strength properties of solid wood. [3-2-0]

WOOD290.name: Secondary Wood Products Manufacturing
WOOD290.desc: Basic secondary wood products manufacturing. Focus on producing and joining lumber, edging, drilling, veneers and CNC equipment. [2-3-0]

WOOD292.name: Two-Dimensional and Solid Computer-Aided Graphics
WOOD292.desc: Computer-aided graphics software used in the wood products sector.  Visualization of product designs and specifications in two and three dimensions. [0-4]

WOOD300.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
WOOD300.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing who have complete the co-op orientation workshops.

WOOD305.name: Wood Machining Skills
WOOD305.desc: Safe working procedures for wood processing machinery, explanation of various manufacturing equipment, product documentation, product development and manufacturing processes.

WOOD310.name: Co-operative Work Placement
WOOD310.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD311.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
WOOD311.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD312.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
WOOD312.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD330.name: Industrial Engineering
WOOD330.desc: Use of industrial engineering concepts and methods to analyze and improve organizations, including operations strategy and competitiveness, quality control, work measurement, inventory management, linear programming, sensitivity analysis, transportation problems, and capacity planning. [3-2-0]

WOOD335.name: Quality Improvement
WOOD335.desc: Modern techniques for improving quality in the workplace with particular emphasis on the forest products industry. Topics include quality control management, control charting, continuous improvement and analysis of variance techniques. [2-2-0]

WOOD353.name: Mill Site Visits
WOOD353.desc: One week of on-site study of forest products manufacturing plants immediately following Spring examinations of second or third year. Representative sawmills, plywood mills, remanufacturing plants, particleboard manufacturers, pulp mills, laminated timber plants and wood preservation facilities in the Interior are studied. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.

WOOD356.name: Machine Components
WOOD356.desc: Machines used for wood products manufacturing, design, maintenance, purchasing. Selection of components including drives, bearings, brakes, clutches, fasteners, springs.

WOOD373.name: Wood Adhesives and Coatings
WOOD373.desc: Introduction to structure and properties of polymers and wood finishes; chemistry of adhesives and preservatives. [2-3-0]

WOOD384.name: Wood Sawmilling and Drying
WOOD384.desc: Introduction to primary log breakdown systems and lumber material flow in modern sawmills and planermills. Lumber drying equipment and methods. [3-2]

WOOD386.name: Applied Mechanics of Materials
WOOD386.desc: Beam analysis, shaft analysis, columns, stress/strain transformations, thin-walled pressure vessels, material strength failure, criteria, fatigue, design and sizing, ISO standards. [2-2-0]

WOOD400.name: Co-operative Work Placement
WOOD400.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks fulltime.  Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD411.name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
WOOD411.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD412.name: Co-operative Work Placement V
WOOD412.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD430.name: Plant Layout and Design
WOOD430.desc: Techniques for developing a plan,setting goals, and evaluating the impact of changes in the design, layout and operation of the factory with an emphasis on computer simulation.

WOOD440.name: Engineering Economics
WOOD440.desc: Use of engineering economics to evaluate investment proposals of an engineering nature, including decision making processes, time value of money, cash flow analysis, comparison methods, depreciation, replacement analysis, taxes, inflation and sensitivity analysis. [3-1]

WOOD449.name: Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing
WOOD449.desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.

WOOD461.name: Globalization and Sustainability
WOOD461.desc: Examination of globalization and its impact on sustainability, including social, economic, and environmental aspects. [3-1]

WOOD464.name: Wood Finishing and Protection
WOOD464.desc: Introduction to polymeric coatings and finishes used in the wood products industry; surface preparation, application equipment and properties of various coatings; wood deterioration and its protection for external applications. [1-3-2]

WOOD465.name: Wood Industry Business Management
WOOD465.desc: Business management concepts common in the forest products industry including marketing, customer research, product development and design. [3-0-2]

WOOD474.name: Wood Properties and Products Manufacturing
WOOD474.desc: Wood moisture, density and strength properties; manufacturing processes for major forest products. [2-0-0]

WOOD475.name: Wood Properties, Identification and Uses
WOOD475.desc: Elementary chemical, physical and mechanical properties of wood and their variations in relation to structure; identification by hand lens features; manufacture of lumber, pulp and composite wood products. Not available for credit to Wood Products Processing students. [3-2]

WOOD476.name: Design of Timber Structures
WOOD476.desc: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls.

WOOD478.name: Building Science
WOOD478.desc: Building enclosure design considering heat and moisture transmission, air flow and ventilation, condensation, acoustics; roofing systems; diagnostic evaluations; fire protection. [3-0-0]

WOOD482.name: CAD/CAM
WOOD482.desc: Introduction to computer assisted design and manufacturing with a focus on the fundamental issues of geometry and machine tools including an understanding of standard computer tools. Applications to secondary wood products manufacturing.

WOOD485.name: Furniture Construction
WOOD485.desc: The theory and practice of modern construction techniques used in the manufacture of furniture and cabinets. [3-1]

WOOD487.name: Wood Composites
WOOD487.desc: Physical, chemical and mechanical variables involved in adhesive bonding of composite wood products; characteristics of adhesives; plywood, composite wood panels, hardboard, medium density fibreboard, laminated wood and engineered lumber composites manufacturing processes; important physical and chemical properties of products. [2-3-0]

WOOD491.name: Environmental Facilities Design
WOOD491.desc: Introduction to pneumatic and hydraulic power, design and selection of waste recycling systems, boilers, energy generation and environmental legislation. [3-2]

WOOD492.name: Modeling for Decision Support
WOOD492.desc: Applications of mathematical modeling, optimization, and simulation in forest planning and manufacturing; formulating models and interpreting results for decision support. [3-3]

WOOD493.name: Project in Program Major
WOOD493.desc: A report (approved by a faculty supervisor and the Program Director) based on either a technical description of a study, an extension of the senior co-op report, a detailed literature review, a research-based project, or a guided independent study developed by the student.

WOOD494.name: Principles of Wood Cutting and Tooling
WOOD494.desc: Wood cutting fundamentals, chip formation, cutting conditions, cutting edge maintenance, sawing, planing and molding, veneer cutting, chipping, turning. [2-3-0]

WOOD499.name: Wood Products Capstone
WOOD499.desc: Development of a wood products manufacturing start-up company.  Development of comprehensive business plan, marketing strategy, product design, equipment selection and justification, manufacturing plant layout, and economic analyses.
WOOD499.prer: All of WOOD 440, WOOD 465 and fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing.

CRWR200.name: Introduction to Creative Writing
CRWR200.desc: Techniques of and practice in multiple genres of writing, including fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction, screenplay, stageplay, graphic forms, lyric forms, children’s literature, and writing for new media. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR201.name: Introduction to Writing Poetry
CRWR201.desc: An exploration of and practice in the writing of poetry, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of poetry. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR203.name: Introduction to Writing for Children and Young Adults
CRWR203.desc: Techniques of and practice in creating, developing and writing for children and young adults. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR205.name: Introduction to Writing Creative Nonfiction
CRWR205.desc: An exploration of and practice in the writing of creative nonfiction, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of creative nonfiction. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR206.name: Introduction to Writing for the Screen
CRWR206.desc: Techniques of and practice in creating, developing, and writing a screenplay. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR208.name: Introduction to Writing for Graphic Forms
CRWR208.desc: Techniques of and practice in creating, developing, and writing the graphic novel, manga, and other forms of illustrated writing. The ability to draw is not required. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR209.name: Introduction to Writing Fiction
CRWR209.desc: An exploration of the writing of fiction, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of fiction. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR213.name: Introduction to Writing for the New Media
CRWR213.desc: An exploration of and practice in writing for new media, including podcasting, blogging, and writing for websites, games, and online environments. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR216.name: Short Screenplay Workshop
CRWR216.desc: Restricted to B.F.A. Film Production students.

CRWR220.name: Introduction to Creative Writing with an Indigenous Focus
CRWR220.desc: Covers three genres from fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction, radio drama, radio feature, or stageplay.

CRWR230.name: Introduction to Writing for Comedic Forms
CRWR230.desc: An examination of and practice in creative writing in comedic forms, including stand-up, sketch, film, new media, and text. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR301.name: Intermediate Writing Poetry
CRWR301.desc: The writing of poetry in various forms using a combination of workshopping and online modules. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR302.name: Writing for Podcast
CRWR302.desc: Exploration of and practice in writing for podcast.

CRWR303.name: Intermediate Writing for Children and Young Adults
CRWR303.desc: The writing of work for children and young adults in various forms using a combination of workshopping and online modules. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR305.name: Intermediate Writing of Creative Nonfiction
CRWR305.desc: An exploration of and practice in the writing of creative non-fiction, covering four of the more basic forms of this genre: memoir, profile, commentary, and exposition. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR306.name: Intermediate Writing for the Screen
CRWR306.desc: An exploration of and practice in writing for the screen, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of screenwriting. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR307.name: Intermediate Writing for the Stage and Radio
CRWR307.desc: An exploration of practice in the writing of the one-act stage play and short radio drama, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of these dramatic genres. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR308.name: Intermediate Writing for Graphic Forms
CRWR308.desc: The writing of graphica (comics, manga and graphic novels), using a combination of workshopping and online modules. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR309.name: Intermediate Writing Fiction
CRWR309.desc: An exploration of the writing of fiction, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of fiction. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR310.name: Video Game Writing and Narrative
CRWR310.desc: Narrative design and writing for video games.

CRWR311.name: Intermediate Writing for Lyric Forms
CRWR311.desc: Techniques of and practice in writing for lyric forms, including song lyrics, lyrical narratives, and libretti. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR351.name: Intermediate Poetry Workshop
CRWR351.desc: An intermediate level workshop class in writing poetry. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR353.name: Intermediate Children and Young Adult Writing Workshop
CRWR353.desc: An intermediate level workshop class in writing for children and young adults. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR355.name: Intermediate Creative Nonfiction Workshop
CRWR355.desc: An intermediate level workshop class in writing of creative nonfiction. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR356.name: Intermediate Screenplay Workshop
CRWR356.desc: An intermediate level workshop class in writing for the screen. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR358.name: Intermediate Graphic Forms Workshop
CRWR358.desc: An intermediate level workshop class in writing for graphic forms. The ability to draw is not required. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR359.name: Intermediate Fiction Workshop
CRWR359.desc: An intermediate level workshop class in writing of fiction. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR401.name: Writing Poetry I
CRWR401.desc: A workshop class in the writing of poetry.
CRWR401.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR402.name: Writing for New Media I
CRWR402.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing for new media. Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR403.name: Writing for Children and Young Adults I
CRWR403.desc: A workshop class in writing for Children and Young Adults.
CRWR403.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR404.name: Writing for Radio I
CRWR404.desc: A workshop class in writing for the radio.
CRWR404.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR405.name: Writing Creative Nonfiction I
CRWR405.desc: A workshop class in writing creative nonfiction, focused on some of the more popular forms of creative nonfiction: autobiography, rhetoric (commentary), literary journalism, and the personal essay.
CRWR405.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR406.name: Writing for the Screen I
CRWR406.desc: A workshop class in writing for the screen.
CRWR406.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR407.name: Writing of Drama for the Stage I
CRWR407.desc: A workshop class in writing of drama for the stage. Studio work is required, and some plays may be given a live stage production in Brave New Play Rites (adjudication process involved).
CRWR407.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR408.name: Writing for Graphic Forms I
CRWR408.desc: A workshop class in the writing of graphic novel, manga, and other forms of illustrated writing. The ability to draw is not required.
CRWR408.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR409.name: Writing Fiction I
CRWR409.desc: A workshop class in the writing of fiction.
CRWR409.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR411.name: Writing for Lyric Forms I
CRWR411.desc: A workshop class exploring the words that accompany music in varied forms including pop, art, musical theatre, and opera.
CRWR411.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR415.name: Workshop in Literary Translation I
CRWR415.desc: Where a language department is regularly consulted on a project, the language adviser may assign marks equal to 3 credits of the course.
CRWR415.prer: Proficiency in a language other than English.

CRWR416.name: Writing for Television I
CRWR416.desc: A workshop class in writing for television.
CRWR416.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR417.name: Play Development Workshop
CRWR417.desc: An interdisciplinary course, in cooperation with the Theatre program, emphasizing script development through scene work, character development and stagecraft.
CRWR417.prer: Manuscript submission or equivalent theatre experience.

CRWR430.name: Preparation for a Career in Writing

CRWR440.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
CRWR440.desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

CRWR451.name: Writing Poetry II
CRWR451.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing poetry. Assumes a greater level of experience in writing poetry than CRWR 401.
CRWR451.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR452.name: Writing for New Media II
CRWR452.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing for new media. Assumes a greater level of experience in writing for new media than CRWR 402.
CRWR452.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR453.name: Writing for Children and Young Adults II
CRWR453.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing for children and young adults. Assumes a greater level of experience in this form than CRWR 403.
CRWR453.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR454.name: Writing for Radio II
CRWR454.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing for the radio. Assumes a greater level of experience in writing for the radio than CRWR 404.
CRWR454.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR455.name: Writing Creative Nonfiction II
CRWR455.desc: An advanced workshop class focusing on memoir, biography, rhetoric, literary journalism, the personal essay, and some hybrid forms of creative nonfiction. Includes instruction in researching and interviewing techniques. Assumes more writing experience than CRWR 405.
CRWR455.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR456.name: Writing for the Screen II
CRWR456.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing for the screen. Assumes more experience in this form that CRWR 406. Admission is restricted to B.F.A.
CRWR456.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR457.name: Writing of Drama for the Stage II
CRWR457.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing drama for the stage. Studio work is required. Assumes a greater level of experience in writing drama for the stage than CRWR 407.
CRWR457.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR458.name: Writing for Graphic Forms II
CRWR458.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing for graphic forms. The ability to draw is not required. Assumes a greater level of experience in writing graphica than CRWR 408.
CRWR458.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR459.name: Writing Fiction II
CRWR459.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing fiction. Assumes a greater level of experience in writing fiction than CRWR 409.
CRWR459.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR461.name: Writing for Lyric Forms II
CRWR461.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing for lyric forms. Assumes a greater level of experience in writing lyrics than CRWR 411.
CRWR461.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR466.name: Writing for Television II
CRWR466.desc: An advanced workshop class in writing for television. Assumes a greater level of experience in writing fiction than CRWR 416.
CRWR466.prer: Restricted to Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR470.name: Special Projects in Creative Writing
CRWR470.desc: For students who receive permission to do advanced work on a specific project. Admission is restricted to B.F.A. Majors in Creative Writing.

CRWR471.name: Special Projects in Writing Poetry
CRWR471.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR473.name: Special Projects in Writing for Children
CRWR473.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR474.name: Special Projects in Writing Drama for Radio
CRWR474.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR475.name: Special Projects in Writing Non-Fiction
CRWR475.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR476.name: Special Projects in Writing for Screen and Television
CRWR476.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR477.name: Special Projects in Writing Drama for the Stage
CRWR477.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR479.name: Special Projects in Writing Fiction
CRWR479.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR480.name: Special Projects in Literary Translation
CRWR480.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in translation.

CRWR490.name: Directed Reading
CRWR490.desc: The course will emphasize current trends and techniques rather than critical evaluation. Not offered every year.

PSYC360.name: Biopsychology
PSYC360.desc: The relationship between the nervous system and behaviour; the physiological basis of perception, motivation, learning, and memory. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PSYC304.name: Brain and Behaviour
PSYC304.desc: The neurobiological bases of behaviour; brain processes involved in perception, motivation, emotion, psychopathology, learning and memory. Open to all Arts and Science majors except those in the B.Sc. Psychology program. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 304 and PSYC 360.
PSYC304.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) two of PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (d) PSYC 260.

PSYC366.name: Methods in Research
PSYC366.desc: Detailed coverage of basic research methods; the design of experiments and statistical analysis; methods will be applied in laboratory and project work. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List:  www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PSYC218.name: Analysis of Behavioural Data
PSYC218.desc: Use of inferential statistics in psychology and conceptual interpretation of data; experimental design (laboratory, field research methods); presentation of data analyses in reports. PSYC 218 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering.
PSYC218.prer: PSYC 217. And a major in Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences.
PSYC218.crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC306.name: Principles of Animal Behaviour
PSYC306.desc: Theory of evolution; behavioural genetics; social systems as ecological adaptation; mating and parental strategies; instinct and learning; evolution of human behaviour. Credit will be given for only one of BIOL 310 or PSYC 306.
PSYC306.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

BIOC303.name: Molecular Biochemistry
BIOC303.desc: Structure, function and metabolism of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, translation and gene regulation. For students in Biochemistry and Honours programs in other life sciences.  Credit is given for only one of BIOC 300 or 302 or 303. [3-0-0]
BIOC303.prer: One of BIOC 203, BIOL 201 and either (a) one of CHEM 204, CHEM 213 or (b) all of CHEM 205, CHEM 233.

BIOC302.name: General Biochemistry
BIOC302.desc: Metabolic reactions of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry of replication, transcription and translation. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 300 or 302 or 303. [3-0-1]
BIOC302.prer: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203 and either (a) one of CHEM 204, CHEM 213 or (b) all of CHEM 205, CHEM 233 or (c) all of PHAR 220, CHEM 233.

BIOC203.name: Fundamentals of Biochemistry
BIOC203.desc: Amino acids and proteins. Enzymes and enzymology. Human metabolic pathways. Structure, function and metabolism of carbohydrates including glycogen storage and gluconeogenesis. Restricted to students in Biochemistry specializations. [3-0-1]

BIOC202.name: Introductory Medical Biochemistry
BIOC202.desc: Introduction to proteins and enzymes, carbohydrate metabolism, and glucose homeostasis. The course emphasis is on human biochemistry and it is designed for students going into health science fields. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202 or 203 or BIOL 201. [3-0-0]
BIOC202.prer: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233 or (c) all of CHEM 233, PHAR 220. For option (a), a corequisite of CHEM 213 is required. For option (b), a corequisite of CHEM 205 is required.

CHEM413.name: Bioorganic Chemistry
CHEM413.desc: Enzyme catalysis; mechanistic enzymology; chemistry of cofactors; biosynthetic transformations; natural product biosynthesis; topics in chemical biology. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 413, CHEM 569, or BIOC 403. [3-0-0]

BIOC403.name: Enzymology
BIOC403.desc: Kinetic analysis, catalytic mechanisms, transition state stabilization and regulation of activity, strategies for active site characterization and case studies of well-documented enzyme systems. Credit given for only one of BIOC 403, CHEM 413 or CHEM 569. [3-0-0]
BIOC403.prer: BIOC 402. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.

BIOC410.name: Nucleic Acids-Structure and Function
BIOC410.desc: Chemical, physical and biological properties of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and regulation of expression of genetic material. Credit will not be given for both BIOC 410 and 510. [3-0-0]
BIOC410.prer: Either (a) all of BIOC 303, BIOL 335 or (b) BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.

BIOC440.name: Concepts in Molecular Biology
BIOC440.desc: Developing areas of molecular biology, focusing on experimental design and data analysis. Signal transduction, the use of model eukaryotes, and the regulation of gene expression. [3-0-0]
BIOC440.prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

KIN190.name: Anatomy & Physiology I
KIN190.desc: Structure and function of the neuromuscular and skeletal systems of the human body. Special emphasis on movement analysis and the physiological effects of exercise. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477. [2-2]

KIN191.name: Anatomy & Physiology II
KIN191.desc: Structure and function of the digestive, endocrine, urinary, circulatory and respiratory systems. Special emphasis on effects of exercise. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477. [2-2]

APBI210.name: Vascular Plants
APBI210.desc: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function, and ecology. [3-3]
APBI210.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 7 credits of first-year biology.

KIN371.name: Introduction to Statistics in Kinesiology
KIN371.desc: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics, and distribution-free statistical techniques. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477. [3-0-0]

FRST231.name: Introduction to Biometrics
FRST231.desc: Basic theories of probability and statistics. Sampling distribution, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing; goodness of fit and tests for independence; analysis of variance, regression and correlation. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2-0]
FRST231.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 180, MATH 184, MATH 190.

POLI380.name: Quantitative Methods in Political Science
POLI380.desc: An introduction to quantitative methods as utilized in the study of Political Science. Not available for credit in the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

SOCI328.name: Social Statistics I
SOCI328.desc: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics. SOCI 328 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Credit Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering.

APBI328.name: Weed Science
APBI328.desc: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventive, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control. [3-2-0]

APBI324.name: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
APBI324.desc: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection. [2-3-0]

APBI327.name: Introduction to Entomology
APBI327.desc: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology and life-histories of insects; insect-plant relations. [2-3-0]

MICB202.name: Introductory Medical Microbiology and Immunology
MICB202.desc: Introduction to cellular and humoral immune responses, the properties of viruses and the principles of bacterial pathogenesis. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) [3-0-0]
MICB202.prer: One of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, MICB 201, PHAR 201, SCIE 001.

APBI351.name: Plant Physiology
APBI351.desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. [3-3-0]
APBI351.prer: BIOL 121 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113. CHEM 233 is recommended.

FRST311.name: Plant Physiology I
FRST311.desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. CHEM 203, CHEM 213, or CHEM 233 and CHEM 235  is recommended. [3-3-0]

APBI312.name: Reproductive and Digestive Physiology
APBI312.desc: Reproductive and digestive physiology, and current technologies applied to these systems in domestic and wild animals.
APBI312.prer: One of BIOL 204, BIOL 260. 3rd year standing.

CAPS302.name: Human Physiology Laboratory
CAPS302.desc: Physiological techniques and principles. Must be taken in conjunction with CAPS 301. Enrolment limited. Available only to students in the Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences. [0-3]

CAPS303.name: Laboratory in Human Physiology (Honours)
CAPS303.desc: Techniques and principles of human physiology. This course must be taken in conjunction with CAPS 301. Restricted to Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences and Pharmacology Honours students. [0-3]

APBI426.name: Plant-Microbe Interactions
APBI426.desc: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society. [3-2-0]

PHYS438.name: Zoological Physics
PHYS438.desc: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping. [3-0-0]
PHYS438.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended.

APBI440.name: Plant Genomics
APBI440.desc: Concepts, principles, and recent discoveries in genome structure and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants; applications of genomics approaches to questions in plant genetics, evolution, and ecology. [3-0-0]

FRST413.name: Ecological Plant Biochemistry
FRST413.desc: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites. [3-0-0]
FRST413.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201 and one of BIOL 209, BIOL 210;  or (b) all of FRST 200, FRST 210.

CAPS421.name: Advanced Cellular and Molecular Physiology
CAPS421.desc: Recent advancements in cellular and molecular physiology that have revolutionized our understanding of cell function in health and disease.
CAPS421.prer: Either (a) all of ANAT 390, PHYL 301 or (b) all of CAPS 301, CAPS 390 and third-year standing.
