CAPS422.name: Mammalian Cardiovascular and Respiratory Physiology
CAPS422.desc: The control and integration of cardio-pulmonary function in mammals. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences. [3-0-0]
CAPS422.prer: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301 or its equivalent. Permission of the course director is also required.

CAPS423.name: Mammalian Renal and Gastrointestinal Physiology
CAPS423.desc: Control of mammalian renal and gastrointestinal systems. Role in homeostasis. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences. [3-0-0]
CAPS423.prer: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.

CAPS424.name: Mammalian Endocrinology
CAPS424.desc: Hormonal control of homeostatic, metabolic and reproductive function. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences. [3-0-0]
CAPS424.prer: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.

CAPS426.name: Physiological Basis of Central Nervous System Functions
CAPS426.desc: An integrated study of the structural and functional organization of the central nervous system with special emphasis on neurophysiological mechanisms. [3-0-0]
CAPS426.prer: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.

CAPS430.name: Advanced Laboratory in Physiology
CAPS430.desc: Methods, techniques, and use of instruments required for physiological investigation. CAPS 303 or PHYL 303 and the consent of the department are required and enrolment will be limited. [0-6]

CHEM111.name: Structure, Bonding, and Equilibrium in Chemistry
CHEM111.desc: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry and equilibrium with applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-1]
CHEM111.prer: Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12.

CHEM154.name: Chemistry for Engineering
CHEM154.desc: Chemical bonding, properties of matter. Chemical thermodynamics with applications to phase equilibria, aqueous equilibria and electrochemistry. Processes at surfaces. [3-3*-0]

CHEM121.name: Structure and Bonding in Chemistry
CHEM121.desc: Fundamentals of bonding theories and structural chemistry, with applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-0]

CHEM113.name: Principles of Chemistry II
CHEM113.desc: General and ionic equilibrium, solubility, thermodynamics. Introductory organic chemistry: stereochemistry; substitution, elimination and oxidation-reduction reactions. Can be used as prerequisite to subsequent CHEM courses. [3-3-1]
CHEM113.prer: CHEM 111 and Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12 and Not open to students with credit for CHEM 121.

CHEM123.name: Thermodynamics, Kinetics and Organic Chemistry
CHEM123.desc: Fundamentals of chemical reactivity: thermodynamics; kinetics; organic chemistry, including stereochemistry; applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-0]

CHEM205.name: Physical Chemistry
CHEM205.desc: Chemical kinetics and thermodynamics and spectroscopy useful in biological, medical, agricultural, earth, and related sciences. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 201 and 205. [3-0-0]
CHEM205.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154.

CHEM251.name: Physical Chemistry for Engineers
CHEM251.desc: States of matter, properties of gases, phase diagrams. Elementary chemical thermodynamics and kinetics. Reaction equilibria. [3-0-1]
CHEM251.prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

CHEM201.name: Introduction to Physical Chemistry
CHEM201.desc: Principles of chemical kinetics, reaction mechanisms and chemical thermodynamics. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 201 and 205. [2-3*-1]
CHEM201.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123 or (c) CHEM 154. MATH 200 or MATH 217 or MATH 226 or MATH 253 or MATH 263 is recommended.

CHEM202.name: Coordination Chemistry
CHEM202.desc: Coordination chemistry of the transition elements. [2-3*1]
CHEM202.prer: Either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123 or (c) one of SCIE 001, CHEM 154.

CHEM208.name: Coordination Chemistry
CHEM208.desc: Fundamental concepts and principles governing bonding and reactivity of coordination complexes: ligand field theory; symmetry and point groups; frontier molecular orbital theory.

CHEM250.name: Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM250.desc: Chemistry of selected groups of inorganic compounds, considered in relation to industrial processes. [2-0-0]
CHEM250.prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

CHEM233.name: Organic Chemistry for the Biological Sciences
CHEM233.desc: Reactions and properties of carbonyl compounds, carbohydrates, amino acids, nucleic acids. [3-0-0]

CHEM260.name: Organic Chemistry for Engineers
CHEM260.desc: A description of the properties and reactions of organic compounds. [3-0-0]
CHEM260.prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

CHEM203.name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry
CHEM203.desc: Structure, bonding and physical properties of aliphatic and aromatic compounds; mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-heteroatom bond formation; functional group interconversion and oxidation/reduction reactions. Only open to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.  Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 233, 235. [3-3-0]

CHEM213.name: Organic Chemistry
CHEM213.desc: Spectroscopy of organic compounds.  Mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-carbon bond formation; functional group interconversion.  Preference will be given to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations. [3-0-0]
CHEM213.prer: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 233.

PHYS348.name: Frontiers in Physics and Astronomy
PHYS348.desc: Current research topics in physics and astronomy are investigated and explored. Technical communication and research skills are studied and developed via oral presentations and written scientific reports on these current research topics. [3-0-0]
PHYS348.prer: Third-year standing in a physics honours program or fourth-year standing in a physics or astronomy major program.

CHEM300.name: Communicating Chemistry
CHEM300.desc: Effective argumentation and communication skills in chemistry. Only open to students in a Chemistry specialization.

CHEM304.name: Fundamentals of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
CHEM304.desc: Principles of chemical thermodynamics; introduction to statistical mechanics; phase equilibria; electrochemistry. [3-0-1]
CHEM304.prer: CHEM 123 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

PHYS203.name: Thermal Physics I
PHYS203.desc: Fundamentals of thermodynamics and statistical physics; entropy, laws of thermodynamics, heat engines, free energy, phase transitions, Boltzmann statistics, quantum statistics. [4-0-0]
PHYS203.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.
PHYS203.crer: One of MATH 217, MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

PHYS450.name: Quantum Mechanics
PHYS450.desc: Postulates of quantum mechanics, expectation values, hermitian operators, commuting observables, applications to one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, applications in three dimensions, hydrogen atom, time dependent perturbations. Credit will be given for only one of PHYS 304, 450 or CHEM 312. [3-0-0]

CHEM312.name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy
CHEM312.desc: Principles of quantum mechanics; atomic wavefunctions; angular momentum; spin; atomic term symbols. [3-0-1]
CHEM312.prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

PHYS304.name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
PHYS304.desc: Principles and applications of quantum mechanics, wave mechanics, the Schroedinger equation, expectation values, Hermitian operators, commuting observables,  one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, three dimensional systems, time dependent perturbations. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

CHEM412.name: Electronic Structure of Atoms and Molecules
CHEM412.desc: Introduction to variational methods; many-electron systems; semi-empirical methods; perturbation theory; computational methods. [3-0-0]
CHEM412.prer: One of CHEM 312, PHYS 304 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

CHEM402.name: Diffraction Methods
CHEM402.desc: Crystal structures; point and space groups; X-ray diffraction, neutron diffraction, electron diffraction of gases and surfaces. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 402 and 514. [3-0-0]

PHYS403.name: Statistical Mechanics
PHYS403.desc: Principles and applications of  statistical mechanics. Ideal gases, degenerate Fermi gases, Bose-Einstein condensation, black body radiation, fluctuations and phase transitions. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
PHYS403.prer: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, PHYS 257, CHEM 201 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450, CHEM 312. One of MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251 is recommended.

CHEM407.name: Statistical Mechanics in Chemistry
CHEM407.desc: Introductory concepts of statistical mechanics and statistical thermodynamics. Applications to chemistry with emphasis on understanding chemical reactivity. Credit will not be given for CHEM 503/CHEM 407 and PHYS 455. [3-0-0]

PHYS455.name: Statistical Mechanics
PHYS455.desc: Introduction to quantum statistical mechanics and its application to systems of varying complexity from the simple ideal gas to the degenerate gas. Quantum fluids, phase transitions and simulation methods will also be introduced. Credit cannot be given for both PHYS 403 and 455. [3-0-0]
PHYS455.prer: One of PHYS 257, PHYS 203, PHYS 313 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.

CHEM408.name: Chemical Dynamics
CHEM408.desc: Macroscopic and microscopic kinetics; photochemistry; theory of reaction rates; reaction cross sections, energy distributions, experimental methods. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 408 and CHEM 508. [3-0-0]
CHEM408.prer: One of CHEM 304, PHYS 203 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 304.

CHEM410.name: Properties of Materials
CHEM410.desc: Electromagnetic, optical, thermal and mechanical properties, and chemical reactivity of solids; electrons in periodic systems: bands, zones; excitations: excitons, phonons, plasmons, polaritons; crystalline order and disorder; ionic conductivity. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 410 or CHEM 502. [3-0-0]
CHEM410.prer: One of CHEM 304, PHYS 203 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 304.

CHEM411.name: Synthesis and Chemistry of Natural Products
CHEM411.desc: Methods and tactics for the synthesis of biologically active natural products and analogs, particularly alkaloids, polyketides, steroids and terpenes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 411 or CHEM 566. [3-0-0]

CHEM414.name: Coordination Chemistry of the Transition Elements
CHEM414.desc: Molecular and electronic structures and reactivities of coordination compounds of the transition elements. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 414 and CHEM 525. [3-0-0]

CHEM416.name: Physical and Theoretical Organic Chemistry
CHEM416.desc: Energetics and catalysis in organic reactions. Pericyclic reactions. Substituent effects. Linear free energy relationships. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 416 and CHEM 563. [3-0-0]

CHEM418.name: Organometallic Chemistry
CHEM418.desc: The chemistry of compounds containing organic groups directly bonded to metals and metalloids. Emphasis will be placed on the structure and bonding of the compounds and their use in synthetic chemistry. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 418 and CHEM 524. [3-0-0]

CHEM435.name: Bio-Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM435.desc: A discussion of the involvement of inorganic chemistry in biological systems. Chemistry of cations, metalloenzymes, and simpler model systems. Reactions of coordinated ligands, chemistry of sulphur and phosphorus. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 435 and CHEM 526. [3-0-0]
CHEM435.prer: CHEM 304 and one of CHEM 218, CHEM 309.

CHEM460.name: Organic Synthesis: A Mechanistic Approach
CHEM460.desc: Presentation, mechanistic discussion and analysis of modern synthetic methods using principles of physical organic chemistry. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 460 or CHEM 560. [3-0-0]

CPSC101.name: Connecting with Computer Science
CPSC101.desc: Fundamentals of computer science and their connections with the arts, psychology, and biology.  Historical, cultural, and gender  perspectives of important contributions to the field will be discussed.  No prior computing background required. [3-3-0]

GRSJ201.name: Connecting with Computer Science
GRSJ201.desc: Fundamentals of computer science and their connections with the arts, psychology, and biology. Historical, cultural, and gender perspectives of important contributions to the field will be discussed. No prior computing background required.

CPSC121.name: Models of Computation
CPSC121.desc: Physical and mathematical structures of computation.  Boolean algebra and combinations logic circuits; proof techniques; functions and sequential circuits; sets and relations; finite state machines; sequential instruction execution. [3-2-1]

CPEN211.name: Introduction to Microcomputers
CPEN211.desc: Boolean algebra; combinational and sequential circuits; organization and operation of microcomputers, memory addressing modes, representation of information, instruction sets, machine and assembly language programming, systems programs, I/O structures, I/O interfacing and I/O programming, introduction to digital system design using microcomputers.

EECE320.name: Discrete Structures and Algorithms
EECE320.desc: Discrete structures, such as trees and graphs, and their properties; introduction to algorithms and algorithmic complexity. Proof of correctness; design techniques such as greedy algorithms and dynamic programming. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 320 or CPSC 320.

CPSC103.name: Introduction to Systematic Program Design
CPSC103.desc: Computation as a tool for systematic problem solving in non-computer-science disciplines. Introductory programming skills. Not for students with existing credit for or exemption from CPSC 110 or APSC 160. No programming experience expected. [3-0-1]

CPSC189.name: Systematic Program Design in Python
CPSC189.desc: Systematic design of small programs using the Python programming language. [1-1-0]
CPSC189.prer: CPSC 110 and one of Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

CPSC301.name: Computing in the Life Sciences
CPSC301.desc: Basic concepts, tools, and techniques for working with scientific data at larger scales, higher speeds, and lower costs that would otherwise be impossible. Applications and examples drawn from the life sciences. No prior computing background is required. Not for credit for students who have credit for any of the following: APSC 160, Computer Science AP, IB Computer Science, EOSC 211, or 3 credits of CPSC beyond CPSC 101. [3-2-0]

CPEN221.name: Principles of Software Construction
CPEN221.desc: Design, implementation, reasoning about software systems: abstraction and specification of software, testing, verification, abstract data types, object-oriented design, type hierarchies, concurrent software design.

CPSC210.name: Software Construction
CPSC210.desc: Design, development, and analysis of robust software components. Topics such as software design, computational models, data structures, debugging, and testing. [3-2-0]

CPSC213.name: Introduction to Computer Systems
CPSC213.desc: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures.  Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks. [3-3-0]

CPSC261.name: Basics of Computer Systems
CPSC261.desc: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures.  Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks. [3-2-1]
CPSC261.prer: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of CPSC 260, EECE 210, CPEN 221.

CPSC221.name: Basic Algorithms and Data Structures
CPSC221.desc: Design and analysis of basic algorithms and data structures; algorithm analysis methods, searching and sorting algorithms, basic data structures, graphs and concurrency. [3-2-0]
CPSC221.prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, CPEN 221 and one of CPSC 121, MATH 220.

CPSC259.name: Data Structures and Algorithms for Electrical Engineers
CPSC259.desc: Advanced procedural programming.  Fundamental algorithms for sorting and searching.  Data structures including lists, trees, and hash tables.  Introduction to scripting languages and file input/output. [3-2-0]

CPSC260.name: Data Structures and Algorithms for Computer Engineers
CPSC260.desc: Design and analysis of object-oriented programs, emphasizing data structures. Topics include: classes, interfaces, fundamental data structures, algorithmic complexity, basic debugging and testing techniques. [3-1-0]

EOSC211.name: Computer Methods in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
EOSC211.desc: Mathematical computer-based problem solving in the physical, chemical, and biological sciences. Problems drawn from studies of the earth, the oceans and the atmosphere. [2-0-2]
EOSC211.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

COMM437.name: Database Technology
COMM437.desc: Theory and technology of database management from an applications perspective; database design; database administration. Credit will not be granted for both COMM 437 and CPSC 304.

CPSC304.name: Introduction to Relational Databases
CPSC304.desc: Overview of database systems, ER models, logical database design and normalization, formal relational query languages, SQL and other commercial languages,data warehouses, special topics. [3-0-1]
CPSC304.prer: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

CPEN321.name: Software Engineering
CPEN321.desc: Engineering practices for the development of non-trivial software-intensive systems including requirements specification, software architecture, implementation, verification, and maintenance. Iterative development. Recognized standards, guidelines, and models. Credit will only be granted for only one of CPSC 310, EECE 310, or CPEN 321.
CPEN321.prer: One of EECE 210, CPEN 221, CPSC 210, EECE 309.

CPSC310.name: Introduction to Software Engineering
CPSC310.desc: Specification, design, implementation and maintenance of large, multi-module software systems. Principles, techniques, methodologies and tools for computer aided software engineering (CASE); human-computer interfaces, reactive systems, hardware-software interfaces and distributed applications. [3-2-0]

CPSC311.name: Definition of Programming Languages
CPSC311.desc: Comparative study of advanced programming language features. Statement types, data types, variable binding, parameter passing mechanisms. Methods for syntactic and semantic description of programming languages. [3-0-1]

EECE321.name: Languages and Translation
EECE321.desc: Principles and practice of automated language translation. Language syntax and semantics, typing, binding and parameter passing. Syntactic and lexical analysis. Language automata, parsing. Compilers and compiler-compilers.

CPSC313.name: Computer Hardware and Operating Systems
CPSC313.desc: Instruction sets, pipelining, code optimization, caching, virtual memory management, dynamically linked libraries, exception processing, execution time of programs. [3-0-1]
CPSC313.prer: Either (a) all of CPSC 213, CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 210, CPSC 213, CPSC 260, EECE 320.

CPEN333.name: System Software Engineering
CPEN333.desc: Operating systems principles, real-time systems, principles of concurrent and multi-threaded programming, information structures, introduction to object oriented analysis, design, and modeling using UML, testing of software systems.
CPEN333.prer: One of CPSC 259, CPSC 260 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

CPEN331.name: Operating Systems
CPEN331.desc: Operating systems, their design and their implementation. Process concurrency, synchronization, communication and scheduling. Device drivers, memory management, virtual memory, file systems, networking and security.
CPEN331.prer: CPSC 261 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309.

CPEN411.name: Computer Architecture
CPEN411.desc: Modern processors, GPUs, and memory hierarchies; quantitative principles and instruction set design; pipelining, superscalar issue, out-of-order execution, branch prediction and speculation; memory hierarchies, caches, virtual addressing, prefetching, coherence, and consistency; multicores, VLIW, on-chip networks, and other advanced architectures. Credit will be given for only one of CPSC 313 or EECE 476 or CPEN 411.
CPEN411.prer: Either (a) one of EECE 353, CPEN 311 or (b) one of EECE 355, CPEN 312.

CPSC317.name: Internet Computing
CPSC317.desc: Computer networking, basic communication protocols, network infrastructure and routing.  Common application-level protocols and principles associated with developing distributed applications. [3-0-1]

COMM439.name: Business Telecommunications
COMM439.desc: Basic data communications concepts and technology; local area, wide area, and enterprise networks; the Internet; wireless networking; network development life cycle; network security and management.

ELEC331.name: Computer Communications
ELEC331.desc: Analysis, design and implementation of computer networks and their protocols. Application layer protocols, transmission control protocol (TCP), Internet protocol (IP), routing algorithms, reliable data transfer, multiple access, Ethernet.
ELEC331.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, CPSC 261, EECE 359, EECE 315, CPEN 331.

CPSC320.name: Intermediate Algorithm Design and Analysis
CPSC320.desc: Systematic study of basic concepts and techniques in the design and analysis of algorithms, illustrated from various problem areas. Topics include: models of computation; choice of data structures; graph-theoretic, algebraic, and text processing algorithms. [3-0-1]
CPSC320.prer: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320. In addition to above pre-requisites, at least 3 credits from COMM 291, BIOL 300, MATH or STAT at 200 level or above.

CPSC402.name: Numerical Linear Algebra
CPSC402.desc: Investigation of the practical techniques of computational linear algebra. Orthogonal transformations and their application to the solution of linear equations, the eigenproblem, and linear least squares. Complete solution of the symmetric eigenproblem, including bisection and the QR method. Refinements of these techniques for sparse matrices. [3-0-0]

CPSC416.name: Distributed Systems
CPSC416.desc: Concepts and design of distributed systems. Communication architecture and models for interprocess communication. Process migration, naming, distributed file systems, fault tolerance, and concurrency control. [3-0-0]
CPSC416.prer: One of CPSC 313, EECE 315, CPEN 331 and one of CPSC 317, EECE 358, ELEC 331.

CPEN431.name: Design of Distributed Software Applications
CPEN431.desc: Communications, processes, naming, synchronization, consistency and replication, fault tolerance, object-based middleware, and security technologies for distributed applications. [3-2-0]
CPEN431.prer: One of EECE 315, CPEN 331, CPSC 313 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, CPSC 210.

CPSC417.name: Computer Networking
CPSC417.desc: Network protocols and architecture including internetworking, the Internet, layered communication protocols, routing, flow and congestion control, network performance, wired and wireless data communication. [3-0]
CPSC417.prer: All of CPSC 313, CPSC 317 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241.

CPSC444.name: Advanced Methods for Human Computer Interaction
CPSC444.desc: Design and evaluation methodologies and theories; formal models of the user including visual, motor, and information processing; advanced evaluation methods including laboratory experiments and field studies; HCI research frontiers. [2-2-2]
CPSC444.prer: All of CPSC 310, CPSC 344 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241.

CPEN441.name: Human Computer Interfaces in Engineering Design
CPEN441.desc: Practical issues for interfaces for modern software. Task analysis, user modeling, usability engineering, representations, metaphors, prototyping tools. Applications: interactive multimedia systems, engineering, scientific visualization, engineering design.
CPEN441.prer: One of CPSC 260, CPSC 221 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, CPSC 210, EECE 314, CPEN 333.

EOSC110.name: The Solid Earth: A Dynamic Planet
EOSC110.desc: Earth's origin, composition, structure, and natural resources. Plate tectonics as the driving force for volcanism, mountain building, and earthquakes.  Imaging Earth's interior. Environmental geoscience and sustainability. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list for the Faculty of Science section of  the Calendar.) [3-0-0]

EOSC112.name: The Fluid Earth: Atmosphere and Ocean
EOSC112.desc: Introduction to processes in ocean and atmosphere. Heat, current, winds, clouds, marine life, resources. Effects of coupling, climate change, pollution. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list, within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-0-0]

EOSC310.name: The Earth and the Solar System
EOSC310.desc: The Earth as a planet: its composition, internal dynamics, and surface evolution. Rotation, magnetic field, plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes. The ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere as components of a varying geo-environment. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. No background in science or mathematics is required. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

EOSC326.name: Earth and Life Through Time
EOSC326.desc: The fossil record of adaptation and extinction emphasizing the interaction of biological and geological processes. Not for credit in any Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences specialization. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
EOSC326.prer: Biology 100-level and third-year standing in Science.

EOSC222.name: Geological Time and Stratigraphy
EOSC222.desc: Measuring geological time and understanding Earth history using stratigraphic principles, paleontology and radioactive decay. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-2-0]
EOSC222.prer: Second-year standing in Science. One of EOSC 1**, EOSC 210, GEOB 103 is recommended.

MRNE435.name: Introduction to Biological Oceanography
MRNE435.desc: An introduction to the biology of oceans, with supporting coverage of relevant physics and chemistry. Emphasis will be placed on plankton biology, community structure and life histories, and influencing environmental factors. Collections will be made from sheltered inlets, through Barkely Sound to offshore waters. The course will involve both field and laboratory.

EOSC372.name: Introductory Oceanography: Circulation and Plankton
EOSC372.desc: Physical and chemical processes and their controls on the distribution of plankton in the ocean. [3-0-0]
EOSC372.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

EOSC373.name: Introductory Oceanography: Climate and Ecosystems
EOSC373.desc: Physical, chemical, and biological processes in the ocean and their interaction with climate and marine food-webs. [3-0-0]

EOSC433.name: Geological Engineering Practice I - Rock Engineering
EOSC433.desc: Application of rock mechanics, hydrogeology, and engineering design tools in realistically complex geological environments. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty, and use of field data, geotechnical monitoring, and numerical analyses for tunnelling, mining and rock slope engineering projects. Case histories. [2-2-0]

EOSC434.name: Geological Engineering Practice II - Soil Engineering
EOSC434.desc: Application of geomorphology, hydrogeology, and soil mechanics to geotechnical design. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty in geotechnical hazard and risk assessments; multi-disciplinary approaches to geotechnical engineering problems in realistically complex geological environments. Case histories. [2-2-0]

APBI244.name: Introduction to Biometeorology
APBI244.desc: Basic principles and processes of climatology. Energy and water balance concepts. Weather systems and climate change, microclimate of soils, crops, forests, and animals. [3-2-0]

ECON221.name: Introduction to Strategic Thinking
ECON221.desc: An introduction to how people interact in strategic situations drawn from political science, history, psychology, law, biology, military history, economics, business, and anthropology. The focus will be on developing intuition.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 221 or ISCI 344.

MATH184.name: Differential Calculus for Social Science and Commerce
MATH184.desc: Topics as for Math 104; intended for students with no previous knowledge of Calculus. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.  Not for credit for students with AP Calculus AB, AP Calculus BC, or a passing score on the UBC-SFU-UVIC-UNBC Calculus Challenge Examination. [3-0-1.5]
MATH184.prer: One of BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.

MATH120.name: Honours Differential Calculus
MATH120.desc: Limits, derivatives, Mean Value Theorem and applications, elementary functions, optimization, Taylor series, approximation. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [4-0-0]
MATH120.prer: High-school calculus and one of (a) a score of 95% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12; or (b) permission from the Mathematics Department Head.

MATH110.name: Differential Calculus
MATH110.desc: Topics as for MATH 100, but including relevant topics from algebra, geometry, functions, trigonometry, logarithms, and exponentials. [3-0-1.5]
MATH110.prer: Pre-requisite: BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 (or equivalent), plus permission of  the Mathematics Department;  permission will normally be based on a low grade in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 (or equivalent) and a low score in the optional UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test if taken. See http://www.math.ubc.ca/Ugrad/m110.shtml for details.

MATH100.name: Differential Calculus with Applications to Physical Sciences and Engineering
MATH100.desc: Derivatives of elementary functions. Applications and modeling: graphing, optimization. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH100.prer: High-school calculus and one of (a) a score of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.

MATH180.name: Differential Calculus with Physical Applications
MATH180.desc: Topics as for Math 100; intended for students with no previous knowledge of Calculus. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. Not for credit for students with AP Calculus AB, AP Calculus BC, or a passing score on the UBC-SFU-UVIC-UNBC Calculus Challenge Examination. [3-0-1.5]
MATH180.prer: One of BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.

MATH104.name: Differential Calculus with Applications to Commerce and Social Sciences
MATH104.desc: Derivatives and rates of change, exponential and trigonometric functions, Newton's method, Taylor polynomials, maxima and minima, and graphing. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH104.prer: High-school calculus and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12  or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.

MATH102.name: Differential Calculus with Applications to Life Sciences
MATH102.desc: Functions, derivatives, optimization, growth and decay, discrete probability. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH102.prer: High-school calculus and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.

MATH105.name: Integral Calculus with Applications to Commerce and Social Sciences
MATH105.desc: Antiderivatives, the definite integral, techniques of integration, infinite series, partial derivatives, maxima and minima with constraints, discrete and continuous random variables. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH105.prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

MATH103.name: Integral Calculus with Applications to Life Sciences
MATH103.desc: Antiderivatives and definite integrals, infinite series, applications to probability and dynamical systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH103.prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

MATH101.name: Integral Calculus with Applications to Physical Sciences and Engineering
MATH101.desc: The definite integral, integration techniques, applications, modeling, infinite series. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH101.prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

MATH121.name: Honours Integral Calculus
MATH121.desc: Definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, techniques and applications of integration, infinite series. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [4-0-0]
MATH121.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 120 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 180, MATH 184 or (c) a score of 5 in AP Calculus AB.

MATH223.name: Linear Algebra
MATH223.desc: Matrices, eigenvectors, diagonalization, orthogonality, linear systems, applications. Intended for Honours students. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH223.prer: Either (a) MATH 121 or (b) a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, SCIE 001.

MATH152.name: Linear Systems
MATH152.desc: 2D and 3D geometry, vectors and matrices, eigenvalues and vibration, physical applications. Laboratories demonstrate computer solutions of large systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-1*-0]

MATH221.name: Matrix Algebra
MATH221.desc: Systems of linear equations, operations on matrices, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization of symmetric matrices. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH221.prer: Either (a) a score of 64% or higher in one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 or (c) advanced credit for MATH 100.

MATH200.name: Calculus III
MATH200.desc: Analytic geometry in 2 and 3 dimensions, partial and directional derivatives, chain rule, maxima and minima, second derivative test, Lagrange multipliers, multiple integrals with applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH200.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

MATH253.name: Multivariable Calculus
MATH253.desc: Partial and directional derivatives; maxima and minima; Lagrange multipliers and second derivative test; multiple integrals and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH253.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

MATH217.name: Multivariable and Vector Calculus
MATH217.desc: Partial differentiation, extreme values, multiple integration, vector fields, line and surface integrals, the divergence theorem, Green's and Stokes' theorems.  Intended for students in Honours Physics and Engineering Physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [4-0-0]
MATH217.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001 and a score of 68% or higher in one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

MATH226.name: Advanced Calculus I
MATH226.desc: Functions of several variables: limits, continuity, differentiability; implicit functions; Taylor's theorem; extrema; Lagrange multipliers; multiple integration, Fubini's theorem; improper integrals. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH226.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 121 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, SCIE 001.

MATH255.name: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH255.desc: Review of linear systems; nonlinear equations and applications; phase plane analysis; Laplace transforms; numerical methods. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH255.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
MATH255.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH265.name: Linear Differential Equations
MATH265.desc: Linear ordinary differential equations. Complex numbers, Laplace transforms, frequency reponse, resonance, step response, systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-0-1*]
MATH265.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
MATH265.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH256.name: Differential equations
MATH256.desc: Linear ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms, Fourier series and separation of variables for linear partial differential equations. Tutorial session focuses on examples from chemical and biological engineering. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfmtree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
MATH256.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
MATH256.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH215.name: Elementary Differential Equations I
MATH215.desc: First-order equations; linear equations; linear systems; Laplace transforms; numerical methods; trajectory analysis of plane nonlinear systems. Applications of these topics will be emphasized. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH215.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
MATH215.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH227.name: Advanced Calculus II
MATH227.desc: Parametrization of curves and surfaces; line and surface integrals; theorems of Green, Gauss, Stokes; applications to physics and/or introduction to differential forms. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH227.prer: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 226.

MATH317.name: Calculus IV
MATH317.desc: Parametrizations, inverse and implicit functions, integrals with respect to length and area; grad, div, and curl, theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH317.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 253. MATH 221 is recommended.

MATH264.name: Vector Calculus for Electrical Engineering
MATH264.desc: Divergence, gradient, curl, theorems of Gauss and Stokes. Applications to Electrostatics and Magnetostatics. MATH 264 content is strongly coupled to ELEC 211 with topics and student evaluations weighted accordingly.
MATH264.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH310.name: Abstract Linear Algebra
MATH310.desc: Linear spaces, duality, linear mappings, matrices, determinant and trace, spectral theory, Euclidean structure. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfmtree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH310.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

MATH335.name: Introduction to Mathematics
MATH335.desc: Intensive course with required tutorial. Combinatorics, probability, geometry and elementary number theory. Not for credit in the Faculty of Science. Students who obtain credit at UBC for any other mathematics course cannot in the same or later years obtain credit for MATH 335. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]

MATH230.name: Introduction to Finite Mathematics
MATH230.desc: Difference equations, number theory, counting.  Intended primarily for students not in the Faculty of Science who wish to have some exposure to mathematical thinking.  Students who obtain credit for MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184, or SCIE 001 cannot in the same year or in later years obtain credit for MATH 230. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MECH358.name: Engineering Analysis
MECH358.desc: Fourier series; auto- and cross-correlation; power spectra; discrete Fourier transform; boundary-value problems; numerical methods; partial differential equations; heat, wave, Laplace, Poisson, and wave equations.  Applications to mechanical engineering and practical computing emphasized.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 358 and MATH 358.

MATH358.name: Engineering Analysis
MATH358.desc: Fourier series; auto- and cross-correlation; power spectra;  discrete Fourier transform; boundary-value problems; numerical methods; partial differential equations; heat, wave, Laplace, Poisson, and wave equations.  Applications to mechanical engineering and practical computing applications emphasized.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 358 or MATH 358. [3-2*-0]

PHYS312.name: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
PHYS312.desc: The application of ordinary and partial differential equations to physical problems; boundary and initial value problems associated with heat, wave and Laplace equations. Fourier analysis; expansions in Bessel and Legendre functions. Credit will be given for only one of PHYS 312 and MATH 316. [3-0-0]

MATH316.name: Elementary Differential Equations II
MATH316.desc: Power series methods (ordinary and regular singular points, Bessel's equation); boundary value problems and separation of variables (Fourier series and other orthogonal series), applications to the vibrating string, heat flow, potentials. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH257.name: Partial Differential Equations
MATH257.desc: Introduction to partial differential equations; Fourier series; the heat, wave and potential equations; boundary-value problems; numerical methods. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH300.name: Introduction to Complex Variables
MATH300.desc: Functions of a complex variable, Cauchy-Riemann equations, elementary functions, Cauchy's theorem and contour integration, Laurent series, poles and residues. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH300.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.
MATH300.crer: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 263, MATH 317.

MATH305.name: Applied Complex Analysis
MATH305.desc: Functions of a complex variable, Cauchy-Riemann equations, contour integration, Laurent series, residues, integrals of multi-valued functions, Fourier transforms.  See Credit Exclusion List [link to http://www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414]. [3-0-0]
MATH305.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

MATH302.name: Introduction to Probability
MATH302.desc: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems.   Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH302.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH318.name: Probability with Physical Applications
MATH318.desc: Random variables, discrete and continuous distributions. Random walk, Markov chains, Monte Carlo methods. Characteristic functions, limit laws. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH318.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.
MATH318.crer: One of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 267, MATH 316.

MATH303.name: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
MATH303.desc: Discrete-time Markov chains, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, renewal theory. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH312.name: Introduction to Number Theory
MATH312.desc: Euclidean algorithm, congruences, Fermat's theorem, applications. Some diophantine equations. Distribution of the prime numbers. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
MATH312.prer: One of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121 and 9 additional credits of mathematics courses.

MATH437.name: Number Theory
MATH437.desc: Divisibility, congruences, Diophantine equations, arithmetic functions, quadratic reciprocity, advanced topics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH313.name: Topics in Number Theory
MATH313.desc: Topics chosen by the instructor. These might include: division algorithms, group theory, continued fractions, primality testing, factoring.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH406.name: Variational and Approximate Methods in Applied Mathematics
MATH406.desc: Variational and Green's function methods for ordinary and partial differential equations, introduction to finite difference, finite element and boundary element methods.  See Faculty of Science Credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-0-0]
MATH406.prer: One of MATH 307, CPSC 302 and either (a) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316 or (b) MATH 400.

MATH401.name: Green's Functions and Variational Methods
MATH401.desc: Green's functions for partial differential equations. Calculus of variations. Eigenfunction expansions. Rayleigh-Ritz and finite element methods.  See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH401.prer: Either (a) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316 or (b) MATH 400.

MATH405.name: Numerical Methods for Differential Equations
MATH405.desc: Interpolation, numerical integration, numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations. Practical computational methods emphasized and basic theory developed through simple models. See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MICB301.name: Microbial Ecophysiology
MICB301.desc: Dynamics and control of prokaryotic cellular processes in response to the biotic and abiotic environment including metabolic interactions and metabolic cooperation between microorganisms. [3-0-1]
MICB301.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 201, MICB 201 or (b) BIOT 380.

MICB308.name: Paradigms in Bacterial Pathogenesis
MICB308.desc: Mechanisms of bacterial pathogenesis including adherence, invasion, intracellular survival, toxins, host defenses and microbial evasion strategies, antibiotics, and vaccines.  Introduction to experimental approaches used to study bacterial pathogens. [3-0-0]
MICB308.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 201, MICB 202 or (b) BIOT 380.

CHBE381.name: Bioprocess Engineering I
CHBE381.desc: Design of industrial bioreactor systems: organism selection; kinetics of microbial processes and enzyme reactions; design and modeling of single and multi-stage bioreactors.
CHBE381.prer: BIOL 112 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, CHBE 241, CHBE 251. Third or fourth year standing.

MICB325.name: Analysis of Microbial Genes and Genomes
MICB325.desc: Genetic, molecular biological and bioinformatic approaches for the analysis of microbial genomes, gene structure-function and gene expression with emphasis on bacteria. [3-0-0]
MICB325.prer: One of MICB 201, BIOL 234 and third-year standing or higher.

MEDG410.name: Immunogenetics
MEDG410.desc: Molecular basis of lymphocyte development, activation and adhesion; immunogenetics and the major histocompatibility complex. Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar. [3-0-1]
MEDG410.prer: MICB 302 and one of BIOL 334, BIOL 335. A standing of "B" or better is recommended.

MICB402.name: Advanced Immunology
MICB402.desc: Molecular basis of lymphocyte development, activation and adhesion; immunogenetics and the major histocompatibility complex. Consult the credit exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the calendar. [3-0-1]
MICB402.prer: One of MICB 302, BIOT 380. If MICB 302 is used as the prerequisite for MICB 402, students are required to take one of the following as a corequisite: BIOL 234, BIOL 335, MICB 325.

MICB407.name: Viral Infections in Humans
MICB407.desc: Interactions between viruses and humans; pathogenesis; persistence and viral oncogenesis; virological diagnosis and treatment. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) [3-0-0]

PATH437.name: Viral Infections in Humans
PATH437.desc: Interactions between viruses and humans; pathogenesis; prompt virological diagnosis; rationale for antiviral chemotherapy and prophylaxis. [3-0-0]

MICB408.name: Advanced Bacterial Pathogenesis
MICB408.desc: Current and emerging themes in bacterial pathogenesis including cellular microbiology, bacterial cell biology processes and their role in virulence including secretion systems to deliver virulence factors and immune evasion strategies employed by pathogens.  Development of antibiotics and resistance to antibiotics. [3-0-0]
MICB408.prer: MICB 308. MICB 302 and MICB 325 are recommended.

CHBE419.name: Industrial Biotechnology Laboratory
CHBE419.desc: Modern bioreactor technology, upstream and downstream processing of biotechnology products. Restricted to students in the Joint Degree in Biotechnology. [1-4-0]

MICB447.name: Experimental Molecular Biology
MICB447.desc: A laboratory course with a choice of independent, supervised research projects. Students develop protocols to carry out investigation of selected molecular biology problems. [2-4-0]
MICB447.prer: Either (a) BIOT 380 or (b) MICB 323 or (c) all of MICB 322, MICB 398.

MICB421.name: Experimental Microbiology
MICB421.desc: Research in microbial physiology and molecular genetics.  Guided and independent laboratory projects are developed. [2-4-0]

PCTH305.name: Basic Human Pharmacology
PCTH305.desc: Lectures and assigned reading on the effects, mechanisms of action, absorption, distribution, fate and excretion of major classes of therapeutic agents. Indications for the use of particular drugs will be discussed in terms of risk versus benefit for the individual and for society. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

PCTH300.name: Introduction to Pharmacology
PCTH300.desc: The concepts, language and techniques of scientific pharmacology. Intended primarily for Honours and Major students in Pharmacology. [3-3-0]
PCTH300.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 233, CHEM 235 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 203, CHEM 204;  and CHEM 211 and one of CHEM 205, CHEM 201. Permission of the undergraduate adviser is required.

PHYS101.name: Energy and Waves
PHYS101.desc: Fluids, harmonic oscillator, travelling waves, standing waves, sound, and interference of light waves, including diffraction.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-3*-1*]
PHYS101.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS117.name: Dynamics and Waves
PHYS117.desc: Kinematics including curvilinear motion. Forces and Newton's laws of motion. Work-energy theorem, conservation of energy. Conservation of momentum, collisions. Torque, rotational dynamics, angular momentum. Oscillations and waves. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS117.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS107.name: Enriched Physics 1
PHYS107.desc: Classical mechanics including conservation laws, angular momentum of rigid bodies and simple harmonic motion, wave phenomena, with an introduction to special relativity, quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, statistical mechanics and solid state physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-3*-1*]
PHYS107.prer: Either (a) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in MATH 12;  or (b) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 100 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in PREC 12;  or (d) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in CALC 12. MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12, PHYS 12 = Physics 12.
PHYS107.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS108.name: Enriched Physics II
PHYS108.desc: Electricity and magnetism, electrical circuits, induction, electromagnetic waves, Maxwell's equations and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-0-1]
PHYS108.prer: Either (a) PHYS 107 or (b) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 101 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 117.
PHYS108.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS102.name: Electricity, Light and Radiation
PHYS102.desc: Introduction to optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-3*-1*]
PHYS102.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS158.name: Introductory Physics for Engineers II
PHYS158.desc: Electricity and magnetism, DC and AC circuits, optics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS158.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS153.name: Elements of Physics
PHYS153.desc: Thermometry, thermal properties of matter, heat, oscillations, waves, sound, wave optics; geometrical optics, elementary electricity and magnetism, simple DC and AC circuits. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1; 3-3-1]
PHYS153.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS118.name: Electricity, Light and Radiation
PHYS118.desc: Optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS118.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
PHYS118.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS119.name: Experimental Physics Lab
PHYS119.desc: Introductory laboratory course, with emphasis on data collection, data analysis techniques, and scientific reasoning. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [0-3-0]
PHYS119.prer: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 117.
PHYS119.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS109.name: Enriched Experimental Physics
PHYS109.desc: A laboratory course accompanying PHYS 108 with emphasis on data collection and analysis and experimental techniques. [0-3-0]

PHYS200.name: Relativity and Quanta
PHYS200.desc: Special relativity: Lorentz transformation, dynamics and conservation laws. Quantum physics: the experimental evidence for quantization; a qualitative discussion of the concepts of quantum mechanics and their application to simple systems of atoms and nuclei. [4-0-0]
PHYS200.prer: Either (a) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS250.name: Introduction to Modern Physics
PHYS250.desc: Wave-particle duality of matter, special relativity, processes in atomic, nuclear and solid state, and introduction to quantum mechanical devices and techniques. [3-0-1]
PHYS250.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

ENPH257.name: Heat and Thermodynamics
ENPH257.desc: Thermometry, thermal properties of matter; heat transfer by conduction; convection and radiation; kinetic theory of gases and gas laws; heat engines; refrigeration; change of state; first and second laws of thermodynamics. [1-3-1]
ENPH257.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 255, MATH 263;  and either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.

PHYS219.name: Intermediate Experimental Physics I
PHYS219.desc: Analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics, analog-to-digital converters and an introduction to use of computers in data analysis and simulations. [1-3-0]
PHYS219.prer: Either (a) one of PHYS 108, PHYS 118 and one of PHYS 109, PHYS 119;  or (b) PHYS 102 or (c) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) SCIE 001.
PHYS219.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.

PHYS209.name: Intermediate Experimental Physics
PHYS209.desc: Use of analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics and analog-to-digital conversion and the use of computers in data analysis and simulations in thermodynamic, electronic and modern physics experiments. [0-3-1*]
PHYS209.prer: Either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (e) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.
PHYS209.crer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

ENPH259.name: Experimental Techniques
ENPH259.desc: Basic experimental techniques in acquisition, analysis, and presentation and communication of data and technical results. [2-3-0]
ENPH259.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 and either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (e) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.

PHYS229.name: Intermediate Experimental Physics II
PHYS229.desc: Thermodynamics experiments, modern physics experiments and use of computers in data analysis. [0-3-1*]

PHYS354.name: Electric and Magnetic Fields
PHYS354.desc: Applications of electricity and magnetism. Maxwell's equations. [3-0-1]
PHYS354.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317.

PHYS301.name: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS301.desc: Maxwell's equations and their applications, electrical fields and potentials of static charge distributions, current, fields of moving charges, magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction. [3-0-1]
PHYS301.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

PHYS408.name: Optics
PHYS408.desc: Principles and applications of optical physics. Interference, diffraction, coherence, polarization, Fresnel relations, optical coatings, waves in dielectric media, Gaussian beams, waveguides, optical cavities, lasers, fibre optics, and Fourier optics. [3-3-0]
PHYS408.prer: One of PHYS 301, PHYS 354 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

PHYS458.name: Applied Optics
PHYS458.desc: Basic applications of lasers, geometrical optics, fibre optics, diffraction, and Fourier optics. [3-3-0]

PHYS401.name: Electromagnetic Theory
PHYS401.desc: Applications of Maxwell's theory. Wave propagation in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas, wave guides, radiation, antennae, and special relativity. [3-0-0]

PHYS454.name: Applied Electromagnetic Theory
PHYS454.desc: Wave propagation and related phenomena in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas. Wave guides, radiation, antennae, special relativity. [3-0-0]

PHYS405.name: Radiation Biophysics
PHYS405.desc: Physical and chemical interactions of ionizing radiations and their biological effects at the cellular, tissue and whole-animal levels. Credit will be given for only one of PHYS 405, 536. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
PHYS405.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and third year standing in Science or Applied Science.

ASTR101.name: Introduction to the Solar System
ASTR101.desc: General principles of the celestial sphere, laws of motion and light, optics, and telescopes; current knowledge of the Sun and Solar System. [3-2*-0]
ASTR101.prer: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12, PHYS 100. plus Principles of Mathematics 12.

ASTR310.name: Exploring the Universe: The Solar System
ASTR310.desc: A survey of recent discoveries about the planets and other objects in the solar system, without the use of advanced mathematics. The Sun, the existence of planetary systems around other stars, and the search for life. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [3-0-1*]

ASTR311.name: Exploring the Universe: Stars and Galaxies
ASTR311.desc: A survey of recent discoveries in modern astronomy without the use of advanced mathematics. Stars, pulsars, black holes, galaxies, quasars and the origin and evolution of the Universe. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [3-0-1*]

ASTR102.name: Introduction to Stars and Galaxies
ASTR102.desc: Modern stellar and extragalactic astronomy. Stars and stellar evolution from protostars to black holes; galaxies and quasars; cosmology. ASTR 200/205 rather than ASTR 102 are recommended for students who intend to pursue studies in Astronomy. [3-2*-0]
ASTR102.prer: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12, PHYS 100. plus Principles of Mathematics 12.

ASTR407.name: Planetary Science
ASTR407.desc: Structure of planetary systems, planetary interiors, planet formation, planetary atmospheres, meteoritics, impact cratering. [3-0-0]
ASTR407.prer: One of PHYS 210, EOSC 211 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 316, PHYS 312 and one of ASTR 200, EOSC 212.
ASTR407.crer: One of PHYS 206, PHYS 216, PHYS 306, EOSC 352.

ASTR406.name: High-Energy Astrophysics
ASTR406.desc: Radiative processes. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Accreting systems. Gamma-ray bursts. [3-0-0]
ASTR406.prer: All of PHYS 203, PHYS 301, MATH 215 and ASTR 300.

ASTR404.name: Astronomical and Astrophysical Measurements
ASTR404.desc: Astronomical instrumentation and techniques for ground and space-based observations. Theory of measurement, imaging, interferometry and spectroscopy of electromagnetic radiation at optical, radio, infrared, and X-ray wavelengths. Astronomical data analysis. [3-0-0]
ASTR404.prer: All of PHYS 210, PHYS 408 and one of PHYS 312, MATH 316.

ECON325.name: Introduction to Empirical Economics
ECON325.desc: Essentials of probability and statistics for applied work in economics. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, and analysis of variance. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
ECON325.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

COMM291.name: Application of Statistics in Business
COMM291.desc: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

ECON326.name: Methods of Empirical Research in Economics
ECON326.desc: Techniques of empirical economic research. Topics include simple and multiple regression, time series analysis, and simultaneous equation estimation. Students will be required to undertake applied work. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

COMM290.name: Introduction to Quantitative Decision Making
COMM290.desc: Introduction to decision models in business, including basic optimization, linear programming, probability, decision analysis, random variables, simulation, and solving decision problems using spreadsheet tools.
COMM290.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

FRST430.name: Advanced Biometrics
FRST430.desc: Analysis of variance, multiple regression and analysis of covariance. Design and analysis of experiments. [3-2]

PSYC359.name: Advanced Research Methods in Behavioural Sciences
PSYC359.desc: Prepares students for graduate studies or other advanced behavioural research; experimental design and analytic techniques; laboratory with computer applications.
PSYC359.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366.

ELEC321.name: Stochastic Signals and Systems
ELEC321.desc: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems; discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modeling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 321 or STAT 357.
ELEC321.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from Electrical and Computer Engineering Student Services.

ASIC220.name: Introduction to Sustainability
ASIC220.desc: Sustainability examined from scientific, economic, and societal perspectives. [3-0-0]

FRST100.name: Sustainable Forests
FRST100.desc: An overview of forests and forestry.  Survey of the disciplines, areas of study, and values that frame sustainable management of forests in BC and the world.  Assignments focus on critical thinking and written communication skills. [3-0-0]

FRST200.name: Forest Plant Biology I
FRST200.desc: The structure, diversity and development of trees and other plants, with emphasis on the angiosperms. [3-2-0]

FRST201.name: Forest Ecology
FRST201.desc: The structure and function of forest ecosystems, including: energetics; productivity; nutrient, carbon and water cycling; soils; the physical environment; population and community ecology; disturbance ecology; ecological succession; biological diversity and ecological resilience. [3-2-0]

FRST202.name: Forest Ecology
FRST202.desc: The Ecosystem concept; energy biomass and nutrient cycling; the physical environment; population and community ecology; succession, Biogeoclimatic classification and some coastal ecosystems. Available only through Distance Education. [3-2]

FRST203.name: Silvics of Forest Trees of Western Canada
FRST203.desc: Ecological and silvical characteristics of forest trees; assessment of ecological site quality and biogeoclimatic classification; application of silvics in silviculture. A plant herbarium of at least 50 species is required. Only available through Distance Education. [3-2]

FRST210.name: Forest Plant Biology II
FRST210.desc: The functional biology of trees and other forest plants in their environment, with an emphasis on gymnosperms. [3-2-0]

FRST211.name: Forest Classification and Silvics
FRST211.desc: Forest classification and the application of silvics in forest management, including world forest classification systems, the Biogeoclimactic Ecosystem Classification system, and ecosystem diagnosis in the field. [3-2-0]

FRST232.name: Computer Applications in Forestry
FRST232.desc: Techniques involved in solving forestry problems with microcomputers using word processing, spreadsheet, procedural language, and database management tools. [3-2]

FRST239.name: Tree and Stand Level Measurements
FRST239.desc: An introduction to measurement of individual trees and stands; use of aerial photographs, maps, and various measurement instruments. [3-2-0]

FRST248.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST248.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Orientation workshops required. Final work term report required.

FRST270.name: Community Forests and Community Forestry
FRST270.desc: Community forests and community forestry throughout the world, with special attention to participation by aboriginal peoples; emphasis is on forms of governance, public participation, and adaptive learning. [3-0-0]

FRST302.name: Forest Genetics
FRST302.desc: Population genetics and conservation of genetic resources; principles of genetics and their application to forestry. [2-2]

FRST303.name: Principles of Forest Science
FRST303.desc: Introduction to growth of trees and forests with emphasis on evolutionary, ecological and environmental aspects. Not available for credit to undergraduate students in the Faculty of Forestry. [3-0-0]

FRST304.name: The Science Underlying Forestry Issues
FRST304.desc: Examination of current forestry issues with specific reference to their scientific basis. Not available for credit to undergraduate students in the Faculty of Forestry. [3-0-0]

FRST305.name: Silviculture
FRST305.desc: Silviculture concepts and principles; stand dynamics; artificial and natural regeneration; cultural techniques for forest stand establishment and stand tending; silvicultural systems; decision making and development of prescriptions; connections to forest planning. [3-4*]

FRST307.name: Biotic Disturbances
FRST307.desc: Concepts of disturbance ecology with special reference to insects and diseases in the forests of British Columbia; forest health problems in the biogeoclamatic zones of BC; present management strategies and future potentials in a scenario of climate change. [3-3-0]

FRST308.name: Forest Entomology
FRST308.desc: An introduction to insects that cause damage to forests and forest products; how insects live; life cycles and attack symptoms of representatives of major groups of insects; principles for control and management. Available only through Distance Education.

FRST309.name: Forest Pathology
FRST309.desc: Biology and management of forest tree diseases. Available only through Distance Education.

FRST310.name: Soil Biology
FRST310.desc: The diversity and interactions of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; responses to environmental change. [2-3-0]

FRST318.name: Forest and Conservation Economics
FRST318.desc: Practical problem solving of economic issues related to forestry and conservation, touching on investment analysis, capital budgeting, non-timber economics, ecosystem services, and forest certification. Completion of FRST 232 or intermediate knowledge of MS Excel essential. [2-3-0]

FRST319.name: Principles of Forestry Economics
FRST319.desc: Introduction to the economics of production, distribution and consumption of goods and services produced by, and dependent on, the forest resource. Available only through Distance Education.

FRST320.name: Abiotic Disturbances: Fire and Climate
FRST320.desc: Ecological effects of fire and climatic (wind, temperature, and snow) disturbances; fire danger rating, principles of fire management and prescribed fire use; windthrow risk modeling and management. [3-2-0]

FRST339.name: Forest Level Measurement and Productivity
FRST339.desc: Obtaining and forecasting information for stands and forests. [3-2-0]

FRST346.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST346.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Facutly of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST347.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST347.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST348.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST348.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST351.name: Interior Field School
FRST351.desc: Field study at an interior BC location concentrating on land use, management and silviculture. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.

FRST385.name: Watershed Hydrology
FRST385.desc: Measurement and analysis of hydrological processes in response to forest management activities. [3-2-0]

FRST386.name: Aquatic Ecosystems and Fish in Forested Watersheds
FRST386.desc: Effects of forest management activities on fish and aquatic ecosystems. [3-2-0]
FRST386.prer: Third- or fourth-year standing in Forestry, Science or Applied Science.

FRST395.name: Forest Wildlife Ecology and Management
FRST395.desc: Biology of important bird and mammal species resident in forested regions, with particular emphasis on the influences of silvicultural and logging practices. [3-2-0]

FRST399.name: Introduction to Research Methods
FRST399.desc: Lectures and seminars in research philosophies and the scientific method, with special emphasis on field research. [2-1]

FRST403.name: The Sustainability of Production in Managed Forest Ecosystems
FRST403.desc: Study of the functional and dynamic characteristics of forest ecosystems and their response to forest management using ecosystem-level microcomputer simulation models. [3-2-0]

FRST404.name: Advances in Silviculture
FRST404.desc: Fundamental silvicultural problems; the application of research findings to the practice of silviculture. [4-0]

FRST406.name: Advanced Forest Pathology
FRST406.desc: Hereditary, physiological, anatomical, environmental, and microbiological factors influencing forest tree diseases. Given in alternate years. [2-2]

FRST408.name: Problems of Forest Entomology
FRST408.desc: Decision-making in the protection of forests from insects. Insect problems viewed from other disciplines of forestry. Bases of biological and economic evaluation, and choice of control methods. [2-2]

FRST410.name: Introduction to Landscape Ecology and Management
FRST410.desc: Current concepts, methods, and applications of landscape ecology with emphasis on spatial patterning, spatial heterogeneity, and dynamics; problem-solving approaches to natural resource issues through the application of landscape ecological principles and tools.

FRST411.name: Complex Adaptive Systems, Global Change Science, and Ecology Sustainability
FRST411.desc: Concepts of complex adaptive systems (CAS); exploration of how CAS can be used to manage natural and social environments for multiple goals under changing climatic and socio-economic conditions. [3-0-0]

FRST415.name: Sustainable Forest Policy
FRST415.desc: The development, implementation, and analysis of forest policy. [3-0-0]

FRST421.name: Quantitative Forest Management
FRST421.desc: Introduction to the quantitative tools necessary in forest management. Available only through Distance Education.

FRST424.name: Sustainable Forest Management
FRST424.desc: Integration of biophysical and socio-economic components of forest management.
FRST424.prer: Fourth year standing in the B.S.F. program.

FRST432.name: Molecular Ecology
