FRST432.desc: Use of molecular genetic tools to investigate ecological  processes in natural population; DNA variation and its application in landscape genetics, phylogeography, behavioural ecology, conservation genetics, and association genetics. Emphasis placed on statistical and computational data analysis. [3-0-0]

FRST436.name: Growth and Yield
FRST436.desc: Techniques of growth and yield projection and discussion of modelling approaches. Exploration of stand dynamics, quantitative implications of management treatments and environmental limitations to tree and stand growth. [2-2-0]

FRST439.name: International Forestry
FRST439.desc: The socio-economic, biological and technological aspects of forestry within the international frame, in both the developed and developing world. Regional studies and the role of national and international agencies. [2-2-0]

FRST443.name: Remote Sensing for Ecosystem Management
FRST443.desc: Basic biological concepts related to interpretation of remote sensing data for land management, including the use of films and filters, and interpretation of air photographs, and other imagery. [2-2-0]

FRST444.name: Agroforestry
FRST444.desc: Integration of farms and forests, including tropical agroforestry systems, non-timber forest products, forest farming, woodlot management, silvopastoralism, riparian buffers, windbreaks, soil fertility improvement and nutrient cycling. [3-2-0]

FRST446.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST446.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST447.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST447.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST448.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST448.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST449.name: Directed Studies in Forestry
FRST449.desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

FRST452.name: Coastal Field School
FRST452.desc: Site diagnosis and preparation of management options in coastal forests. Extrasessional course; fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
FRST452.prer: Third or fourth year-standing in the B.S.F. program.

FRST470.name: Forests and Society
FRST470.desc: Social aspects of forestry and forest communities. [3-0-1]

FRST485.name: Forest Watershed Management
FRST485.desc: Effects of land management on quality, quantity and timing of water flow. [3-2-0]

FRST490.name: Visual Resource Management and Planning for Aesthetics
FRST490.desc: Methodologies for visual analysis, perceptions, planning & management of urban, natural and working landscapes, and implications for sustainable land-use management & community engagement.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551. [2-2]

FRST491.name: Visualization and Forest Design
FRST491.desc: GIS-based spatial planning and 3D landscape visualization for forest management. [3-0-1]

FRST492.name: Environmental Perception
FRST492.desc: How individuals perceive their environment.  Emphasis will be given visual perception in the context of natural resource issues and the effects of those perceptions on individuals including issues of human wellbeing. [3-0-0]

FRST495.name: Biological Diversity and Forest Management
FRST495.desc: Principles, problems, and practices of managing  forests and nature reserves for biological diversity; integration of forestry and wildlife with particular emphasis on diversity of all life forms. [2-2-0]

FRST497.name: Graduating Essay or Technical Report
FRST497.desc: A technical description of a study or a detailed literature review of at least 4,000 words, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

FRST498.name: B.Sc. Thesis in Forestry
FRST498.desc: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the direction of a staff member. The subject must be appropriate to the student's area of concentration.

FRST499.name: B.S.F. Thesis
FRST499.desc: An independent study or research project on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

WRIT098.name: Preparation for University Writing and the LPI

AFST250.name: Introduction to African Studies
AFST250.desc: Cultural, historical, and geographical issues of African Studies.

AFST351.name: Perspectives in African Studies: Literary and Theoretical Approaches
AFST351.crer: AFST 250. Credit will not be given for both AFST 350 and 351

AFST352.name: Perspectives in African Studies: A Social Science Approach
AFST352.crer: AFST 250. Credit will not be given for both AFST 350 and 352

AFST380.name: Study of Sociolinguistics of a Selected African Language
AFST380.desc: Selected African language with emphasis on major syntactic structures, vocabulary, conversation patterns, reading short texts, and the cultural and historical contexts of language use.

AFST450.name: African Diasporic Culture in African Canadian Communities
AFST450.desc: African diasporic culture in Canadian society, fostering dialogue with members of African Canadian communities on cultural values, traditions, memory, adaptation and change.

ANAT392.name: Gross Anatomy of the Limbs and Trunk
ANAT392.desc: Lectures and laboratory sessions on the human gross and functional anatomy of the limbs and trunk. The course includes the study of predissected specimens. For credit only in the Department of Physical Therapy.

ANAT393.name: Human Anatomy for Physical Therapy Students
ANAT393.desc: Microscopic systems anatomy and regional anatomy of the nervous system. [3-0-0]
ANAT393.prer: Registration in Rehabilitation Sciences (RSPT) is required.

ANAT400.name: Human Anatomy
ANAT400.desc: A correlated course of study for medical and dental students of the structure of the human body including gross and radiological anatomy and embryology. Clinics are held in cooperation with the Departments of Medicine, Orthopaedics, Surgery and Family Practice. Both terms.

ANAT401.name: Microscopic Human Anatomy
ANAT401.desc: A survey course for medical and dental students of the microscopic structure of the human body as studied by light and electron microscopy. Lectures and laboratory sessions. Both terms.

ANAT425.name: Elements of Neuroanatomy
ANAT425.desc: An introduction to the structure of the human nervous system. Given only in conjunction with PHYL 425.  (Open to Medical and Dental students only.)

ANAT448.name: Directed Studies in Anatomy
ANAT448.desc: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

FMST210.name: Family Context of Human Development
FMST210.desc: The influence of family dynamics and social conditions on human development.

FMST238.name: Family Resource Management
FMST238.desc: Conceptual models of resource management as related to families.

FMST312.name: Parent-child Relationships
FMST312.desc: Parent-child interaction over the life span.

FMST314.name: Relationship Development
FMST314.desc: The study of the development, course, and decline of personal relationships.
FMST314.prer: One of SOCI 200, PSYC 100, PSYC 101, PSYC 102, SOCI 240.

FMST316.name: Human Sexuality
FMST316.desc: An examination of human sexual development and behaviour.
FMST316.prer: One of SOCI 200, PSYC 100, PSYC 101, PSYC 102, SOCI 240.

FMST441.name: Social Context of Child Development
FMST441.desc: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes.

BUSI100.name: Micro Foundations of Real Estate Economics
BUSI100.desc: Basic principles of microeconomics and application to current economic problems.

BUSI101.name: Capital Markets and Real Estate
BUSI101.desc: Basic principles of macroeconomics and application to current economic problems.

BUSI111.name: British Columbia Real Estate Law and Real Estate Ethics
BUSI111.desc: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies in British Columbia.

BUSI112.name: Canadian Real Property Law and Real Estate Ethics
BUSI112.desc: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies across Canada.

BUSI121.name: Foundations of Real Estate Mathematics
BUSI121.desc: Introduction to mathematics of real estate finance and statistical measures and methods and their application to practical real estate concepts.

BUSI221.name: Real Estate Finance in a Canadian Context
BUSI221.desc: History, function and mechanics of Canadian mortgage markets.

BUSI290.name: Introduction to Quantitative Decision Analysis
BUSI290.desc: Introduction to decision models in business, including basic optimization, linear programming, probability, decision analysis, random variables, simulation, and solving decision problems using spreadsheet tools.

BUSI291.name: Application of Statistics in Business
BUSI291.desc: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

BUSI293.name: Introductory Financial Accounting
BUSI293.desc: Introduction to the construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use.

BUSI294.name: Introductory Management Accounting
BUSI294.desc: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control, and the development of cost information for financial reports.

BUSI295.name: Managerial Economics
BUSI295.desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision making.

BUSI299.name: Business Communications
BUSI299.desc: Basic communication theory, communications in organizations.  Includes written and oral practice in lab sessions.

BUSI300.name: Urban and Real Estate Economics
BUSI300.desc: Comprehensive treatment of urban and real estate economics; introduction to study of cities and real estate market; analytical microeconomic principles.

BUSI329.name: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
BUSI329.desc: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them.  Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, evironments, group processes, motivation and leadership.

BUSI330.name: Foundations of Real Estate Appraisal
BUSI330.desc: Introduction to concepts and techniques for appraising the value of real estate.

BUSI331.name: Real Estate Investment Analysis and Advanced Income Appraisal
BUSI331.desc: Valuation techniques for income real estate, including income method of appraisal, tax consequences of real property ownership, and portfolio analysis methodology.

BUSI335.name: Information Systems
BUSI335.desc: Introduction to information technology related to business use: design, implementation, and application of information systems.

BUSI344.name: Statistical and Computer Applications in Valuation
BUSI344.desc: Explores creative, practical uses of statistical and computer applications in determining and analyzing real estate value. Through case studies and hands-on computer work, students will learn the fundamentals of exploratory data analysis and appraisal valuation modeling.

BUSI352.name: Case Studies in Residential Valuation
BUSI352.desc: Examines common issues that affect the practice of residential real estate valuation. Credit will be granted for only one of BUSI 352 or both BUSI 442 and BUSI 452.

BUSI353.name: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
BUSI353.desc: An examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

BUSI354.name: Cost Accounting
BUSI354.desc: The provision and analysis of cost accounting information that will assist management in making operating decisions and in evaluating operational performance.

BUSI355.name: Introduction to Income Tax
BUSI355.desc: A study of income tax from the standpoint of the individual and business enterprise.

BUSI370.name: Business Finance
BUSI370.desc: An introduction to the basic principles of financial valuation and an examination of corporate enterprise decisions including working capital management; capital budgeting; capital structures and dividend policy.

BUSI391.name: Introduction to Management Information Systems
BUSI391.desc: Overview of computer technology and terminology; use of computers as managerial and administrative tools; the management of computer resources and the influence of information technology within the organization.

BUSI393.name: Introduction to Business Law
BUSI393.desc: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property, principles of agency, partnership, and company law.

BUSI398.name: Residental Property Guided Case Study
BUSI398.desc: The residential property appraisal process, focusing both on valuation techniques as well as general research and report writing skills.

BUSI399.name: Logistics and Operations Management
BUSI399.desc: The design and management of systems to make products, provide services and deliver them to the end user.
BUSI399.prer: All of BUSI 290, BUSI 291 or equivalents.

BUSI400.name: Residential Property Analysis
BUSI400.desc: Underlying theory and techniques used in design, construction, and inspection of residential properties.

BUSI401.name: Commercial Property Analysis
BUSI401.desc: Underlying theory and techniques used in the design and construction of commercial properties.

BUSI433.name: Real Estate Business
BUSI433.desc: General business skills for real estate practitioners.

BUSI441.name: Real Estate Management I
BUSI441.desc: Examines the day-to-day issues which affect the practice of property management.

BUSI442.name: Case Studies in Appraisal I
BUSI442.desc: Examines the day-to day issues that affect the practice of real estate appraisal.

BUSI443.name: Assessment Administration
BUSI443.desc: Introduces the practice of real property assessment, including the nature of the techniques used, the required duties of assessors, and how an assessment office is administrated.

BUSI444.name: Computer Aided Mass Property Assessment
BUSI444.desc: This course develops and applies the major techniques for valuing real property.
BUSI444.prer: Recommend all of BUSI 121, BUSI 330, BUSI 443.

BUSI445.name: Real Estate Development I
BUSI445.desc: Real estate development process from the project idea to the cursory feasibility stage.  Steps in development planning, including analysis, design and evaluation.  Evaluating development potential, land acquisition, and site planning.

BUSI446.name: Real Estate Development II
BUSI446.desc: Analysis of real estate development process with an examination of economic feasibility studies, approval processes, project financing, construction, project management, and marketing phases.

BUSI450.name: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
BUSI450.desc: A continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

BUSI453.name: Advanced Financial Accounting
BUSI453.desc: An examination of advanced financial accounting topics.

BUSI454.name: Accounting for Management Control and Incentives
BUSI454.desc: Design of accounting systems for facilitating and influencing management decisions, with emphasis on performance evaluation in organizations.

BUSI455.name: Principles of Auditing
BUSI455.desc: Principles of internal control; audit evidence; sampling and testing; audit reports; standards and responsibilities of the external audit.
BUSI455.prer: BUSI 353. Recommended prerequisite or corequisite: BUSI 450.

BUSI460.name: Critical Analysis and Forecasting in Real Estate
BUSI460.desc: Delves into two quantitative decision-making methodologies – decision analysis and forecasting – and explores them using a problem-solving framework.
BUSI460.prer: BUSI 121. BUSI 331 and BUSI 444 are also recommended.

BUSI465.name: Marketing Management
BUSI465.desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services.

BUSI485.name: Taxes and Decision Making
BUSI485.desc: Analysis of business and financial decisions in the presence of taxes.

BUSI493.name: Strategic Management in Business
BUSI493.desc: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of busness strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business.  Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change.
BUSI493.prer: BUSI 293 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 309.
BUSI493.crer: Two of BUSI 294, BUSI 329, BUSI 370, BUSI 465.

BUSI497.name: Guided Case Study in Agricultural Real Estate
BUSI497.prer: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

BUSI498.name: International Business Management
BUSI498.desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems.
BUSI498.prer: BUSI 293 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 309.
BUSI498.crer: Two of BUSI 294, BUSI 329, BUSI 370, BUSI 465.

BUSI499.name: Income Property Guided Case Study
BUSI499.desc: The income property appraisal process, focusing both on valuation techniques as well as general research and report writing skills.
BUSI499.prer: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

PATH300.name: Background to Medical Laboratory Science
PATH300.desc: Introductory lectures and laboratory sessions in clinical chemistry, haematology and blood banking, hospital microbiology, preparation and examination of tissue sections. For Medical Laboratory Science students without previous experience in hospital laboratories. [3-4; 0-0]
PATH300.prer: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 123, CHEM 205, CHEM 233, CHEM 235, MICB 202.

PATH301.name: Basic and Physical Biochemistry for Medical Laboratory Scientists
PATH301.desc: An integrated approach to specific areas of the theoretical and practical aspects of those physical and biological sciences relevant to medical laboratory science. Emphasis will be placed upon the application of basic science to those clinical disciplines practised by the medical laboratory scientist, e.g., histochemistry, clinical chemistry, microbiology, haematology, etc.

PATH303.name: Cytogenetics, Tissue Culture & Cytology
PATH303.desc: Tissue culture techniques in clinical diagnosis; cytological techniques used in the diagnosis and control of cancer. Sex chromatin determination.

PATH304.name: Normal Human Histology
PATH304.desc: An advanced lecture and laboratory course in the microscopic structure of the human body necessary for a complete understanding of histochemistry and histopathology.

PATH305.name: Modern Microscopy
PATH305.desc: A lecture and laboratory course in the theoretical and practical application of modern biological microscopes - compound, dissecting, comparison, dark ground, fluorescent, phase contrast, interference and electron microscopes.

PATH306.name: Laboratory Safety for Medical Laboratory Scientists
PATH306.desc: Control processes for workplace hazards of radiological, chemical, and biological origin.

PATH327.name: Bacteriology, Mycology, Virology and Parasitology
PATH327.desc: Descriptions of each group of human microbial pathogens according to biological attributes, clinical features, pathogenesis and pathology, epidemiology, immunological reactions, laboratory diagnosis, principles of antimicrobial therapy, preventative measures. For students in the Faculty of Medicine B.M.L.Sc.

PATH375.name: Introduction to Human Pathology
PATH375.desc: A lecture-demonstration course designed to acquaint students in the allied health professions with a basic understanding of the causes, natural history, and pathophysiology of common disease processes.
PATH375.prer: 6 credits each first year BIOL and CHEM

PATH402.name: Medical Laboratory Science: Haematology
PATH402.desc: A theoretical and practical examination of those modern concepts of haematology which relate to the practice of medical laboratory science.

PATH404.name: Diagnostic Histochemistry
PATH404.desc: A lecture and laboratory course that encompasses the theory and the practice of currently available histochemical techniques. This course is to supplement the histopathological technique course taken as a requirement for CSLT (RT).

PATH405.name: Seminars in Current Topics
PATH405.desc: Oral and written presentation and critical appraisal of scientific papers.

PATH406.name: Clinical Chemistry
PATH406.desc: This course will review and discuss the methodology of clinical chemistry in order to put these analytical methods into the broad perspective of the pathophysiology of human disease and biochemistry.

PATH407.name: Medical Laboratory Toxicology: Analytical, Clinical
PATH407.desc: A theoretical and practical examination of analytical and pathophysiological aspects of clinical and forensic toxicology.

PATH408.name: Laboratory Administration
PATH408.desc: Personnel management, staff management relationships, stock control, record keeping, etc. Medicolegal aspects of medical laboratory science. Theory and practice of quality control. Use of computers in the medical laboratory.

PATH417.name: Human Bacterial Infections
PATH417.desc: Students acquire content relating to the virulence factors of the bacteria and the pathophysiology of the host while working through case scenarios on their own and in online groups. Students taking this course must be willing to engage in both self-directed and small-group learning.

PATH427.name: Basic Principles of Infection Prevention and Control
PATH427.desc: This course provides the basic principles to prevent the spread of microorganisms pathogenic to humans. It may be taken towards a Certificate in Infection Control.

PATH438.name: Medical Laboratory Science: Directed Studies
PATH438.desc: Investigation of a specific topic in Medical Laboratory Science. Permission of the department head is required.

PATH447.name: Directed Studies
PATH447.desc: An elective in clinical infection control, medical microbiology or molecular biology.

PATH448.name: Introduction to Laboratory Medicine
PATH448.desc: An elective course open to first-year medical students who spend at least three consecutive hours each week in one of the affiliated hospitals of the Department of Pathology, Vancouver Hospital, under the joint supervision of a Senior Resident in Pathology and the Professional Staff of the following Divisions: anatomical pathology, clinical biochemistry, haematology, paediatric pathology. Enrolment is limited.

PATH450.name: Systemic Pathology
PATH450.desc: A series of Pathology discussions in conjunction with various clinical departments designed to illustrate the role of Pathology in the diagnosis and management of various diseases.

PATH451.name: Clerkship in Laboratory Medicine and Infection Prevention and Control
PATH451.desc: May involve attendance at an approved institution and/or a project assigned by the instructor(s). Instructor permission required. Enrolment may be limited.

PATH452.name: Clerkship in Anatomic Pathology
PATH452.desc: An elective course open to third-year medical students, designed to familiarize the student with Anatomic Pathology, including Surgical Pathology, Paediatric Pathology, Autopsy Pathology and Cytology. This elective may involve attendance at one or more affiliated hospitals. Registration requires consent of the Department and enrolment may be limited.

PATH453.name: Clinical Laboratory Haematology
PATH453.desc: Correlative seminars based on haematology case studies relating clinical features to laboratory investigations.

PATH457.name: Clinical Laboratory Microbiology
PATH457.desc: Selected clinical laboratory exercises plus seminars to illustrate the diagnosis and management of patients with microbial infections. Elective course limited to third- and fourth-year medical students.

PATH467.name: Basic Microbiology for Infection Control
PATH467.desc: The identification, clinical significance, and transmission of pathogenic organisms are presented. This course is available by correspondence or webCT. It may be taken towards fulfillment of the Certificate in Infection Control.

PATH477.name: Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control
PATH477.desc: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control.

DHYG106.name: Basics of Oral Microbiology
DHYG106.desc: Basic principles in the study of microorganisms and their relation to human health for dental hygiene students.

DHYG108.name: Oral Health Sciences I
DHYG108.desc: An introduction to normal, healthy facial, oral, and dental structures; oral health records, and charting terminology and symbols.

DHYG110.name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice I
DHYG110.desc: An introduction to the Dental Hygiene profession, practice roles and the process of care model.

DHYG208.name: Oral Health Sciences II
DHYG208.desc: An introduction to desease-related concepts during the study of dental materials, general pathology, plaque biofilm, nutrition, radiology, periodontology, and oral pathology.

DHYG210.name: Dental Hygiene Theory and Practice II
DHYG210.desc: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice in clinical and community-based settings.

DHYG308.name: Oral Health Sciences III
DHYG308.desc: An introduction to concepts and principles of pharmacology and local anesthesia, and further study of oral medicine, oral pathology, and radiology.

DHYG310.name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice III
DHYG310.desc: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice with emphasis on diverse clients with oral health care needs.

DHYG325.name: Applied Pharmacology
DHYG325.desc: Applied pharmacology concepts and principles for the dental health professional.

DHYG400.name: Policy Analysis and Change
DHYG400.desc: Critical reviews of oral health care delivery, oral disease processes and dental hygiene. [3-0-0]

DHYG401.name: Oral Epidemiology
DHYG401.desc: Basic epidemiological and statistical concepts and tests relevant to evidence-based oral health practices.

DHYG402.name: Dental Hygiene Practice I
DHYG402.desc: Dental hygiene concepts, processes, and skills for individuals and communities. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

DHYG404.name: Dental Hygiene Practice II
DHYG404.desc: Advanced dental hygiene concepts, processes and skills in community health, educational or institutional settings.

DHYG405.name: Oral Microbiology and Immunology
DHYG405.desc: Microbiology and immunological concepts relevant for dental hygiene practice.

DHYG406.name: Guided Study in Dental Hygiene
DHYG406.desc: Conduct an in-depth investigation of a health promotion issue.
DHYG406.prer: All of DHYG 400, DHYG 401, DHYG 461. And Faculty approval.

DHYG410.name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice IV
DHYG410.desc: Critical analysis of dental hygiene theory and practice related to diverse clients with complex oral health care needs.

DHYG412.name: Oral Health Care Trends & Topics
DHYG412.desc: Critical analysis of health care trends and oral health care delivery with emphasis on underserved diverse populations.

DHYG433.name: Assessment and Treatment Planning for Advanced Periodontal Diseases
DHYG433.desc: Available in online distance education format only.

DHYG435.name: Oral Medicine and Pathology
DHYG435.desc: Pathobiology of oral diseases. Available in online distance education format only.

PSYC100.name: Introductory Psychology
PSYC100.desc: Introduction to methods and statistics, biopsychology, learning, perception, memory, cognition, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology.  Credit will be given for either PSYC 100 or PSYC 101 and 102.

PSYC101.name: Introduction to Biological and Cognitive Psychology
PSYC101.desc: Introduction to Methods and Statistics, Biopsychology, Learning, Perception, Memory, and Cognition. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 100 and PSYC 101.

PSYC102.name: Introduction to Developmental, Social, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
PSYC102.desc: Introduction to methods and statistics, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 100 and PSYC 102.

PSYC205.name: Contemporary Issues in Psychology
PSYC205.desc: Topics include addiction, culture and evolution in social behaviour, personal relationships, pro- and anti-social behaviour, judgment and decision-making, prejudice and discrimination. Consult the Psychology Department for topics offered each term. May be repeated on a different topic once for credit.

PSYC207.name: Contemporary Topics in Biological and Cognitive Psychology
PSYC207.desc: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in neuroscience, cognition, perception, memory, and learning.

PSYC208.name: Contemporary Topics in Social, Developmental, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
PSYC208.desc: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in social, developmental, personality, and clinical psychology.

PSYC216.name: Questioning Psychological Science in the Media
PSYC216.desc: Use basic principles of quantitative psychological research methods to critique psychological claims presented in the media and to translate psychological science to everyday life.

PSYC217.name: Research Methods
PSYC217.desc: Focus on various research methods used in psychology, with an emphasis on critical thinking and experimental design.  Restricted to students in the Faculty of Arts who have declared their major in one of Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences (Linguistics Department).
PSYC217.crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC260.name: Experimental Psychology and Laboratory
PSYC260.desc: Detailed introduction to experimental and theoretical aspects of motivation, sensation, perception and learning.
PSYC260.prer: Completion of first-year Science program and permission of the department head is also required.
PSYC260.crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC263.name: Contemporary Issues in Biopsychology
PSYC263.desc: Contemporary issues in biopsychology (e.g., neuropsychology, mental illness, brain damage, addiction, hormones and the brain). Consult the Psychology Department for topics offered each term. May be repeated on a different topic once for credit.

PSYC300.name: Behaviour Disorders
PSYC300.desc: The definition, history, and scope of deviant behaviour; emphasis on the psychological factors that control its origins, maintenance, and modification.
PSYC300.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100, or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC301.name: Brain Dysfunction and Recovery
PSYC301.desc: Cognitive and behavioral impairments resulting from brain dysfunction. Focus on the efficacy of various intervention approaches.
PSYC301.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or 6 credits of 200-level PSYC (but not PSYC 205 or PSYC 263).

PSYC302.name: Infancy
PSYC302.desc: Human cognition, perception, motor, social, emotional needs, brain development and their interactions from birth until the emergence of language.
PSYC302.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC303.name: Tests and Measurements I
PSYC303.desc: Theory and practice of mental measurement, test reliability and validity, uses, administration, scoring, and interpretation of psychological tests.
PSYC303.crer: May be taken concurrently with PSYC 366.

PSYC305.name: Personality Psychology
PSYC305.desc: Theory and research on individual differences in motivation, emotion, and social behaviour.
PSYC305.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC307.name: Cultural Psychology
PSYC307.desc: Cultural influences on human thought and behaviour; interactions of culture and self; multicultural experiences; intercultural relations; methodological issues.
PSYC307.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level PSYC (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC308.name: Social Psychology
PSYC308.desc: Theory and research of individual social behaviour; social motivation; attitudes; group interaction; socialization; prejudice.
PSYC308.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC309.name: Cognitive Processes
PSYC309.desc: Contribution of cognitive processes to perception, attention, and memory; cognitive development, language, thinking, and creativity.
PSYC309.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC311.name: Psychology of Sport
PSYC311.desc: Psychological theory, research, and skills training related to sport performance, exercise motivation, and adherence. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 311 and HKIN 231 and 364.
PSYC311.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC312.name: History of Psychology
PSYC312.desc: The principal trends of psychological explanation and events in the history of psychology from the earliest times to the present. Open only to Major or Honours students or by permission of the instructor.
PSYC312.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC314.name: Health Psychology
PSYC314.desc: Health-related behaviours such as smoking and drug use; effects of stressful events on health; methods for coping with stress; impact of chronic illness on the family; social support systems.
PSYC314.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC315.name: Childhood and Adolescence
PSYC315.desc: Human development from the preschool period through adolescence.
PSYC315.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC319.name: Applied Developmental Psychology
PSYC319.desc: Applications of theories and research in developmental psychology to contemporary social issues; topics may include daycare, child abuse, divorce and remarriage, substance abuse, sexuality.
PSYC319.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC320.name: Psychology of Gender and Sex Differences
PSYC320.desc: Theory and research on gender development and the influence of gender on cognition, emotion, motivation, social behaviour, and health.
PSYC320.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC321.name: Environmental Psychology
PSYC321.desc: Psychological theory and research on the interaction between organisms and the physical environment; emphasis on applications to the design and management of constructed and natural environments.
PSYC321.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC322.name: Adulthood and Aging
PSYC322.desc: Issues, theories, and psychological research regarding adulthood and the aging process.
PSYC322.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or  (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC323.name: Tests and Measurements II
PSYC323.desc: A survey of tests for assessing intelligence, abilities, personality, motivation, and interests.

PSYC325.name: Socialization: Media Content and Effects
PSYC325.desc: Examines human development in the context of the socializing role of media.
PSYC325.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC331.name: Forensic Psychology
PSYC331.desc: The application of psychological theory and research to legal issues and the criminal justice system. Credit will not be granted for both PSYC 331 and PSYC 430.
PSYC331.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level psychology (but not PSYC 205 or 263).

PSYC333.name: Memory: Historical, Clinical and Cognitive Perspectives
PSYC333.desc: Classical and contemporary metaphors for memory and their impact on theory development.
PSYC333.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263). Non-PSYC students may substitute LING 460 or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.

PSYC334.name: Memory II
PSYC334.desc: Organic amnesia; remembering childhood events; the self and memory; and the problem of distinguishing genuine from simulated forgetting.

PSYC335.name: Gambling and Decision Making
PSYC335.desc: The psychology of gambling behaviour, with emphasis on relevant work from judgment and decision-making, the cognitive neuroscience of choice, and clinical perspectives on disordered gambling.
PSYC335.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC336.name: The Psychology of Language I
PSYC336.desc: Psychological abilities underlying human language; language processing, lexical representation, and principles of online conversation; animal versus human communication.
PSYC336.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Non-PSYC students may substitute ENGL 329, or LING 420, or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.

PSYC337.name: The Psychology of Language II
PSYC337.desc: Language and thought; deriving psychological principles from language universals; the psychology of literacy, dyslexia, multilingualism, and natural language processing.
PSYC337.prer: PSYC 336 or permission of the instructor.

PSYC340.name: Directed Studies in Psychology
PSYC340.desc: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC340.prer: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.

PSYC348.name: Directed Studies in Biopsychology
PSYC348.desc: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC348.prer: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.

PSYC349.name: Honours Seminar
PSYC349.desc: Orientation to psychological research, with special emphasis on ongoing research within the department; effective presentation of research findings, oral and written; critical evaluation of research. Requires a research project.
PSYC349.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102;  and all of PSYC 217,  218.

PSYC350.name: Psychological Aspects of Human Sexuality
PSYC350.desc: Human sexuality from a biopsychological, behavioural, and psychosocial perspective.
PSYC350.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC358.name: Evolutionary Psychology
PSYC358.desc: Theory and research on the evolution of the human mind, with emphasis on implications for cognition and behaviour in contemporary environments.
PSYC358.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level PSYC (but not PSYC 205 and 263).

PSYC361.name: Motivation
PSYC361.desc: Experimental analysis of hunger, thirst, exploratory and curiosity behaviour, maternal and reproductive behaviour, fixed action patterns, and complex processes involved in social motivation with emphasis on the biological basis of motivation.
PSYC361.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (b) one of PSYC 100, PSYC 260, PSYC 304, PSYC 360.

PSYC363.name: Principles of Animal Learning
PSYC363.desc: Introduction to basic theories of non-associative learning, classical and operant conditioning. Experimental findings from behavioural and biological analyses with animals and humans.

PSYC364.name: Animal Cognition
PSYC364.desc: Investigations of animal cognitive abilities, including spatial learning, timing, counting, concept formation and language use. Experimental findings presented from behavioural and biological approaches with animals and humans.

PSYC365.name: Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYC365.desc: Brain mechanisms underlying cognitive processes such as perception, attention, consciousness, and memory.

PSYC367.name: Sensory Systems
PSYC367.desc: Anatomy and physiology of the sensory pathways and their relation to perception.
PSYC367.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC368.name: Perceptual Processing
PSYC368.desc: Perceptual phenomena and their underlying brain mechanisms.

PSYC398.name: Cooperative Work Placement I
PSYC398.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in Summer Session after third year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC399.name: Cooperative Work Placement II
PSYC399.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 1. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC400.name: Clinical Psychology: A Health Profession
PSYC400.desc: Theory, research, practice, and professional issues in clinical psychology, including a practicum placement. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 400 and 401.

PSYC401.name: Clinical Psychology
PSYC401.desc: Theoretical and research foundations of the processes of assessment and behaviour modification in clinical psychology. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 400 and PSYC 401.

PSYC402.name: Research in Anxiety Disorders
PSYC402.desc: Focus on the cognitive, biological, and motivational underpinnings of anxiety disorders. Topics include current research methods, controversies in the research literature, and directions for future research.
PSYC402.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) all of PSYC 300, PSYC 366.

PSYC403.name: Human Emotion
PSYC403.desc: Developmental, cognitive, and social psychological theories and research on human emotion.
PSYC403.prer: One of PSYC 302, PSYC 305, PSYC 308, PSYC 309, PSYC 315.

PSYC404.name: Psychology of Religion
PSYC404.desc: Cognitive, emotional, and motivational underpinnings of religious behaviour; supernatural beliefs, magical thinking, ritual, sacrifice; religion's role in morality, prosociality, health, violence, and intergroup relations.
PSYC404.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 307, PSYC 308.

PSYC407.name: Cognition and Culture
PSYC407.desc: Cultural learning; cultural variation and universality in cognition and emotion; cognitive and emotional bases of cultural phenomena.
PSYC407.prer: One of PSYC 307, PSYC 308. Or permission of the instructor.

PSYC408.name: Research in Social Psychology
PSYC408.desc: Representative studies on social psychological topics; emphasis on the formulation of significant questions and the design and execution of relevant research.
PSYC408.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) one of PSYC 308, PSYC 366.

PSYC409.name: Cognitive Neuropsychology
PSYC409.desc: The structure of the mind as revealed by brain injury, neurological illness, and surgical intervention.  Topics include attention, memory, language, sense of self, topographic awareness, moral reasoning, emotion, theory of mind, and social awareness.
PSYC409.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 309, PSYC 365.

PSYC412.name: Cognitive Development
PSYC412.desc: The development of fundamental cognitive abilities from infancy through adulthood, including traditional approaches to cognitive development as well as new areas of current investigation.
PSYC412.prer: One of PSYC 302, PSYC 315, PSYC 319, PSYC 322, PSYC 325.

PSYC413.name: Social and Personality Development
PSYC413.desc: Comprehensive overview of the psychological processes in the social and personality development of infants, children, and adolescents.
PSYC413.prer: One of PSYC 302, PSYC 315, PSYC 319, PSYC 322, PSYC 325.

PSYC414.name: Research in Developmental Psychology
PSYC414.desc: Advanced study of current research in a specific area of developmental psychology.
PSYC414.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366;  and one of PSYC 302, PSYC 315, PSYC 319, PSYC 322, PSYC 325.

PSYC415.name: Applied Social Psychology
PSYC415.desc: The application of social psychological research and theory to the solution of social problems.
PSYC415.prer: PSYC 308 and either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 or permission of instructor.

PSYC417.name: Special Topics in Psychology
PSYC417.desc: Intensive examination of selected topics and issues in psychology.
PSYC417.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366.

PSYC418.name: The Self-Concept
PSYC418.desc: Theory and research on the self: development, knowledge, motivation, emotions, presentation.

PSYC420.name: Community Psychology
PSYC420.desc: The relationships between social contexts and wellbeing with a focus on disadvantaged populations.  Students engage in a community service placement to complement academic learning.
PSYC420.prer: Either (a) PSYC 300 or (b) PSYC 308 or (c) PSYC 314 or (d) PSYC 319.

PSYC430.name: Forensic Psychology
PSYC430.desc: The implications of theory and research in psychology for the criminal justice system. Credit will not be granted for both PSYC 331 and PSYC 430.
PSYC430.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC431.name: Special Topics in Forensic Psychology
PSYC431.desc: Selected topics in psychological theory and research applied to the criminal justice system.

PSYC440.name: Directed Studies in Psychology
PSYC440.desc: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC440.prer: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.

PSYC448.name: Directed Studies in Biopsychology
PSYC448.desc: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC448.prer: At least a 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.

PSYC449.name: Honours Seminar and Essay
PSYC449.desc: Students carry out a research project and report on its development during seminars. Students also discuss research by Departmental staff, with emphasis on choice of problems, research design and data analysis.

PSYC460.name: Behavioural Neuroendocrinology
PSYC460.desc: Detailed examination of the interaction between hormones and neural control of reproductive and non-reproductive behaviours; emphasis on gonadal and adrenal hormone effects on learning and memory in the brain.

PSYC461.name: Neuroplasticity and Behaviour
PSYC461.desc: Experimental findings and theory documenting the plasticity of the brain and its relationship to behaviour: emphasis on gene regulation, neurogenesis and cell morphology changes in relation to learning and experience.

PSYC462.name: Drugs and Behavioural Neuroscience
PSYC462.desc: Introduction to neurochemical systems and functional neuroanatomy; animal models of human cognitive processes and mental disorders; neurochemical foundations and treatments for mental disorders. BIOL 205 and/or PCTH 325 recommended.

PSYC463.name: Research in Sensation and Perception
PSYC463.desc: Vision and audition; physical properties and subjective experience of stimuli.
PSYC463.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 260.

PSYC466.name: Research in Animal Learning and Cognition
PSYC466.desc: Examination and evaluation of studies of animal learning and cognition; includes one or more research projects based on material covered.
PSYC466.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 304, PSYC 360, PSYC 363, PSYC 365;  or (c) one of BIOL 355, BIOL 455 or (d) one of PHYL 301, PHYL 426.

PSYC469.name: Psychoneuroimmunology
PSYC469.desc: Research linking psychological characteristics with the immune system, including implications regarding the onset and course of disease.
PSYC469.prer: Either (a) one of PSYC 314, PSYC 360 or (b) MICB 302 and either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC498.name: Cooperative Work Placement III
PSYC498.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 2. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC499.name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
PSYC499.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full time. Normally taken in Summer Session after fourth year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

MRNE400.name: Directed Studies
MRNE400.desc: A research project approved by the supervisor in the field of interest of the student designed to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Note: the supervisor may be teaching at the Marine Centre; or a member of faculty of WCUMSS whether at the Marine Centre as a research investigator or as one of the members of WCUMSS.

MRNE401.name: Special Topics in Marine Biology
MRNE401.desc: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. It is expected that the course will generally be of a specialized nature and be at a level appropriate to graduate or senior undergraduate students.

MRNE402.name: Special Topics in Marine Biology
MRNE402.desc: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. This course will be of a specialized nature and at a level appropriate to graduate or senior undergraduate students.

MRNE410.name: Marine Invertebrate Zoology
MRNE410.desc: A survey of the marine phyla, with emphasis on the benthic fauna in the vicinity of the Marine Station. The course includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.

MRNE411.name: Comparative Invertebrate Embryology
MRNE411.desc: A comprehensive study of development of marine invertebrates available at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre, including all major phyla and most of the minor phyla.

MRNE412.name: Biology of Fishes
MRNE412.desc: Classification, physiology, ecology, behaviour and zoogeography of fishes with particular emphasis on those in the marine environment of the British Columbia coast.
MRNE412.prer: A course in comparative vertebrate anatomy.

MRNE415.name: Structure and Function in Marine Animals
MRNE415.desc: Principles of classification, evolution, morphology, biomechanics, physiology and biochemistry will be illustrated in representatives from a variety of animal phyla. [3-3-0]
MRNE415.prer: Completion of second year in a biology program.

MRNE420.name: Marine Phycology
MRNE420.desc: A survey of the marine algae, with emphasis on the benthic forms in the vicinity of the Marine Centre. The course includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.

MRNE425.name: Ecological Adaptations of Seaweeds
MRNE425.desc: Morphological, physiological, genetic and reproductive adaptations of seaweeds to their environments. [3-3-0]
MRNE425.prer: Completion of second year in a biology program.

MRNE430.name: Marine Ecology
MRNE430.desc: An analytical approach to biotic associations in the marine environment. Opportunities are provided for study of the intertidal realm in exposed and protected areas, and of beaches and estuaries in the vicinity of the Marine Centre; plankton studies and investigations of the subtidal and benthic environments by diving and dredging are envisaged.

MRNE437.name: Population and Community Ecology of Marine Organisms
MRNE437.desc: Emphasis on interactions among organisms and between organisms and their physiochemical environment, and on biological diversity. [3-3-0]
MRNE437.prer: Completion of second year in a biology program.

MRNE440.name: Biology of Marine Birds
MRNE440.desc: Study of interrelationship of birds and the marine environment. Census techniques and observation of birds in the field will be emphasized.
MRNE440.prer: Completion of a course in vertebrate zoology or permission of the instructor.

MRNE445.name: Biology of Marine Mammals
MRNE445.desc: Survey course covering systematics and distribution of marine mammals, their sensory capabilities and physiology, with special emphasis on the Cetacea. The course will involve an independent field study.

MRNE480.name: Seminars and Papers in Marine Science
MRNE480.desc: Instruction in the critical analysis of published research papers and of oral seminars. [2-2-0]
MRNE480.prer: Completion of second year in a biology program.

EDUC141.name: Indigenous Studies
EDUC141.desc: For students in the Indigenous Teacher Education Program (NITEP) only.

EDUC170.name: Reviewing the Principles of Teaching
EDUC170.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC172.name: Language and the Curriculum
EDUC172.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC173.name: Teaching History and Government I
EDUC173.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC174.name: Teaching Geography I
EDUC174.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC175.name: Teaching Secondary English
EDUC175.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC176.name: Teaching Mathematics I
EDUC176.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC177.name: Teaching General Sciences
EDUC177.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC179.name: Practicum I
EDUC179.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.  Pass/Fail.

EDUC211.name: Global Citizenship, Part 2: Community Service Learning and Capstone Conference

EDUC270.name: Communication Skills in Teaching
EDUC270.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC272.name: Teaching Chemistry
EDUC272.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC273.name: Teaching History and Government II
EDUC273.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC274.name: Teaching Geography II
EDUC274.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC275.name: Global Education
EDUC275.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC276.name: Teaching Mathematics II
EDUC276.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC277.name: Teaching Physics
EDUC277.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC278.name: Teaching Biology
EDUC278.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC279.name: Practicum II
EDUC279.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC280.name: English and Reading: Secondary
EDUC280.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EDUC342.name: Teaching First Nations Languages in Elementary Schools
EDUC342.prer: One of LLED 489, LING 200, LING 400. LLED 486 and LING 433 are recommended as pre- or corequisites.

EDUC390.name: Teaching and Learning in Digital Environments: Critical Perspectives

EDUC395.name: Regional Field Studies in Education: Study, Travel, and Community Experience
EDUC395.desc: Not offered on a regular basis.
EDUC395.prer: 12 credits of coursework approved by the Associate Dean (Teacher Education) as being appropriate to the particular study.

EDUC418.name: School-based Extended Practicum: Elementary
EDUC418.prer: Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum

EDUC419.name: School-based Extended Practicum: Middle Years
EDUC419.prer: Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum.

EDUC420.name: Governance, Finance, and School Organization in its Social Context

EDUC421.name: School-based Extended Practicum: Secondary
EDUC421.prer: Normally all requirements set to precede this practicum.

EDUC432.name: Clinical Supervision of Teaching
EDUC432.desc: Recent research on teaching effectiveness. Enrolment limited to persons with teaching or supervisory experience.

EDUC442.name: Critical Issues in Indigenous Education
EDUC442.desc: Post-practicum students will explore how a school program may need to be modified in order to integrate more fully First Nations history, content, and world views.

EDUC449.name: Supervised Research Investigation
EDUC449.desc: Available only to outstanding students approved by the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

EDUC490.name: Special Studies in Education
EDUC490.desc: Topics not covered in a course. A pilot course may be offered under this name for only one year and with permission of the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

EDUC492.name: Critical Analysis of Teaching: Planning for Context Appropriate Instruction

EDUC495.name: Practicum (Elementary) for Previously Certified Teachers
EDUC495.prer: Completion of recent elementary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.

EDUC496.name: Practicum (Secondary) for Previously Certified Teachers
EDUC496.prer: Recent completion of secondary teaching methods courses in the subjects to be taught.

CHBE201.name: Integrated Technical Communication
CHBE201.desc: Written and oral communication in chemical and biological engineering: business correspondence, laboratory reports, technical description, and poster presentations. Restricted to students in second year of the Chemical and Biological Engineering programs.
CHBE201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

CHBE230.name: Computational Methods
CHBE230.desc: Mathematical formulation of chemical and biological engineering problems; standard techniques of numerical analysis and their application to chemical, environmental and biotechnological systems; program development; use of commercial numerical analysis software.

CHBE241.name: Material and Energy Balances
CHBE241.desc: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering; units; stoichiometry; phase equilibria; material balances; energy balances.

CHBE243.name: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering Process and Technology
CHBE243.desc: Processes used in chemical and biological industries, which emphasize underlying physical, chemical, and biological principles.

CHBE244.name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics I
CHBE244.desc: Energy and the first law; second law of thermodynamics; entropy; availability (energy) analysis; thermodynamic properties of fluids, application to power generation, refrigeration, and liquefaction, as well as biological, environmental, and electrochemical systems.

CHBE251.name: Transport Phenomena I
CHBE251.desc: Fluid Mechanics. Momentum-transfer in fluids in laminar and turbulent flow; microscopic and macroscopic material; momentum and energy balances; rheology; dimensional analysis; flow in conduits; pumps; fluid metering.

CHBE262.name: Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry Laboratory
CHBE262.desc: Experiments chosen to illustrate and use material presented in 200-level CHBE and CHEM courses.
CHBE262.crer: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 251, CHEM 250, CHEM 251, CHEM 260.

CHBE344.name: Unit Operations I
CHBE344.desc: Characterization of particles, droplets, and bubbles; comminution, screening and classification; filtration, sedimentation, centrifugal separations and fluidization; thermal operations including evaporation and crystalization.

CHBE345.name: Unit Operations II
CHBE345.desc: Stage-wise mass transfer operations; extraction and absorption; single and stage-wise binary and multi-component distillation; principles and equipment design for continuous contact mass transfer operations including absorption, binary distillation and others such as extraction, drying, humidification, membrane separations.

CHBE346.name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics
CHBE346.desc: Volumetric and thermodynamic properties of fluids; equations of state; heat effects; ideal and non-ideal mixtures; fugacities and activity coefficients; vapor-liquid and liquid-liquid phase equilibrium; solubility of gases and solids in liquids; chemical reaction equilibrium; equilibrium partitioning of pollutants.

CHBE351.name: Transport Phenomena II
CHBE351.desc: Heat and mass transfer; conduction and molecular diffusion; convective transfer; thermal radiation; analogies among heat, mass and momentum transfer; heat exchanger design.

CHBE355.name: Kinetics and Reactor Design
CHBE355.desc: Kinetics of homogeneous chemical and biological reactions, isothermal ideal reactor design, analysis of non-ideal reactors using residence time distribution and mixing models. [3-0-1]

CHBE356.name: Process Dynamics and Control
CHBE356.desc: Introduction to modeling of chemical processes; transient response analysis; design of feedback control systems; stability analysis; frequency response analysis; process control applications; instrumentation; advanced control techniques; distributed control systems.

CHBE362.name: Process and Environmental Engineering Laboratory
CHBE362.desc: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 200 and 300-level CHBE courses.  Field trips may be required.

CHBE364.name: Environmental Engineering Laboratory
CHBE364.desc: Laboratory experiments to illustrate key concepts and measurement techniques in environmental engineering as used by  engineers.

CHBE365.name: Biological Engineering  Laboratory
CHBE365.desc: Laboratory experiments to illustrate key concepts and measurement techniques in biotechnology as used by engineers. Field trips may be required.

CHBE366.name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
CHBE366.desc: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 300-level CHBE process option courses. Field trips may be required.

CHBE373.name: Water Pollution Control
CHBE373.desc: Legal, environmental and physicochemical aspects of industrial water pollution and its abatement will be surveyed; techniques for design of wastewater treatment processes currently used in industry; case studies from chemical and process industries will be considered in detail.
CHBE373.prer: One of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280, MTRL 263.

CHBE376.name: Computer Flowsheeting and Fluid Properties Estimation
CHBE376.desc: Theory and practice of computer flowsheeting in chemical plant design; hands-on use of modern process simulators, prediction of thermodynamic properties of fluids; behaviour of single and multiphase systems.

CHBE401.name: Mechanical Pulping and Papermaking
CHBE401.desc: Process and unit operations in mechanical pulping and papermaking, emphasizing principles and practice of refining, screening, cleaning, papermaking and properties of paper products, key economic and environmental issues.

CHBE402.name: Biomass Fractionation Technology
CHBE402.desc: Process and unit operations in the conversion of wood chips to pulp and green bio-products. Biorefinery concepts and emerging technologies for the production of biomaterials, biochemicals and bioenergy.

CHBE452.name: Environmental Process Design Project
CHBE452.desc: 8-month project-based course, concepts from chemical, biological, and environmental science engineering with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations to solve problems related to the protection of the environment. [2-0-8]
CHBE452.prer: All of CHBE 254, CHBE 344, CHBE 346, CHBE 351, CHBE 356, CHBE 373.

CHBE453.name: Biological Process and Product Design
CHBE453.desc: 8-month project-based course, integrating chemical and biological engineering concepts with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations in the design of major biological processes.
CHBE453.prer: All of BIOL 112, CHBE 346, CHBE 356, CHBE 376, CHBE 381.

CHBE454.name: Chemical Process and Product Design
CHBE454.desc: 8-month project-based course, integrating chemical engineering concepts with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations in the design of major chemical processes.
CHBE454.prer: All of CHBE 346, CHBE 351, CHBE 356, CHBE 376.

CHBE455.name: Kinetics and Reactor Design
CHBE455.desc: Kinetics of homogeneous chemical and biological reactions, isothermal ideal reactor design, analysis of non-ideal reactors using residence time distribution and mixing models.

CHBE456.name: Heterogenous Catalysis and Advanced Reactor Design
CHBE456.desc: Definition of heterogeneous catalysis; properties of catalysts; kinetics of catalytic reactions; ideal heterogeneous reactors; non-isothermal reactor design; mass and heat transfer effects in heterogeneous reactors; examples of industrial reactors.

CHBE457.name: Process Synthesis
CHBE457.desc: Strategy for the conceptual design of industrial chemical and biological processes; rules of thumb for chemical engineers, simulation to assist process synthesis, reactor-separator network synthesis, introduction to product design and molecular structure design, efficiency and sustainability in the chemical industry.
CHBE457.prer: All of CHBE 241, CHBE 346, CHBE 376, CHBE 344.

CHBE459.name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Economics
CHBE459.desc: Estimation of capital and operating costs; interest calculations; taxes; economic comparison of alternatives; economic optimization.

CHBE464.name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Laboratory
CHBE464.desc: Experiments in unit operations relating to process, environmental and biological engineering. Experiments are designed to provide experience in instrumentation and control. Field trips may be required.
CHBE464.prer: All of CHBE 345, CHBE 355, CHBE 356, CHBE 362 and one of CHBE 365, CHBE 366.

CHBE465.name: Rehabilitation and Design of Aquatic Habitat
CHBE465.desc: Modeling the effects of the environment and nutrient availability on growth and waste production; designing closed and open environments for aquatic organisms; developing prescriptions for habitat rehabilitation.
CHBE465.prer: BIOL 112 and third-year standing also required.

CHBE470.name: Transport in Biological Systems
CHBE470.desc: Mass transport and fluid flow, including physiological tissues and tissue constructs. Mass transport deficiencies that lead to the development of pathological tissue and drug delivery to these tissues. Biological engineering for the design of tissue constructs and artificial organs. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 470 or CHBE 570.

CHBE474.name: Process Control Engineering
CHBE474.desc: Frequency response analysis; advanced control techniques; multivariable control systems; mathematical tools for computer control systems; design of computer control systems; engineering design of industrial control applications; plant wide control concepts; distributed control systems concepts.

CHBE476.name: Modelling and Optimization in Chemical Engineering
CHBE476.desc: Mathematical modelling of chemical plants and processes; computer simulation; introduction to numerical optimization techniques.

CHBE477.name: Fuel Cell and Electrochemical Engineering
CHBE477.desc: Stoichiometry, thermodynamics and kinetics of electrode reactions; conductivity and mass transport in electrolytes; material, energy and voltage balances; design of  electrosynthesis, electrorecovery of metals, and energy generation of batteries and fuel cells.

CHBE479.name: Chemical Engineering Aspects of Occupational Health and Safety
CHBE479.desc: Relationship between current engineering practice and worker health and safety. Engineering analysis of industrial health and safety problems.

CHBE480.name: Hazardous Waste Processing Technology
CHBE480.desc: Characterization, treatment and final disposal of hazardous waste with emphasis upon chemical engineering principles. Topics to include relevant legislation, in-plant minimization, treatment options and clean-up of contaminated sites. Case studies to be used for illustration.
CHBE480.prer: Third year Chemical and Biological Engineering.

CHBE481.name: Bioprocess Engineering II
CHBE481.desc: Bioprocess flowsheeting; production-scale fermenter design; product recovery and purification; bioseparations; chromatography; viral inactivation and removal; process validation.

CHBE482.name: Petroleum Refining Process Modeling and Simulation
CHBE482.desc: Petroleum feed stocks testing methods, pseudocomponents, and property methods. Design and simulation of separation and reaction systems. Steady state and dynamic simulation.

CHBE483.name: Energy Engineering
CHBE483.desc: Supply and use of conventional and alternative fuels and energy.  Design and operation of unit operations for processing of fossil fuels, biomass, and other energy sources.  Environmental considerations of energy use.

CHBE484.name: Green Engineering Principles and Applications for Process Industries
CHBE484.desc: Pollution prevention, cleaner production, green chemistry and engineering, industrial ecology, eco-industrial parks, and sustainable development; environmental impact assessment including life-cycle assessment, total cost analysis and environmental systems analysis; reduce/recycling/reuse of wastes and by-products.

CHBE485.name: Air Pollution Prevention and Control
CHBE485.desc: Impacts of air pollutants on health, visibility, smog formation, ozone depletion and global warming; air quality and emission standards; atmospheric dispersion of air pollutants; prevention and control technologies for particulates, SOx, NOx, VOCs, and CO2.

CHBE486.name: Waste Management for Resource Recovery
CHBE486.desc: Physico-chemical, thermal, and biological methods for purification of solid waste and wastewater, and conversion to bioproducts/industrial products, energy and clean water.

CHBE487.name: Interfacial Phenomena
CHBE487.desc: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 357 and CHBE 487. [3-0-0]

CHBE489.name: Pollution Control in the Pulp and Paper Industry
CHBE489.desc: Pollutants of concern in the pulp and paper industry; environmental impact of the industry; technologies used for the control of solid, liquid and gaseous wastes.

CHBE491.name: Thesis Proposal
CHBE491.desc: Literature searching, planning, equipment design, experimental design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation.

CHBE492.name: Thesis
CHBE492.desc: Research project under the direction of a staff member.

CHBE493.name: Thesis Proposal-Environmental Topic
CHBE493.desc: Literature search, planning, equipment design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation. Topic to be chosen from a selection of environmental topics offered by the department.

CHBE495.name: Thesis Proposal-Biotechnology Topic
CHBE495.desc: Literature search, planning, equipment design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation. Topic to be chosen from a selection of biotechnology topics offered by the department.

CHBE498.name: Engineering Report
CHBE498.desc: This should be written on some subject of scientific interest or technical interest, based preferably on personal experience. Specifications are issued by the Department.

ASIA100.name: Introduction to Traditional Asia
ASIA100.desc: A survey of the histories and cultures of Asia before 1600 and the coming of the Europeans. Emphasis will be given to parallel themes in the development of the civilizations of South, Southeast and East Asia.

ASIA101.name: Introduction to Modern Asia
ASIA101.desc: A survey of the emergence of modern Asia. Aims at an understanding of how the various peoples of Asia have maintained distinctive cultural identities despite centuries of political, economic, social and cultural change.

ASIA110.name: Introduction to the Major Eastern Religions
ASIA110.desc: Introduction to the major Asian religious traditions (Islam, Hinduism, Sikhism, Jainism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism, Christianity, Shintoism, and Shamanism); employs theoretical models drawn from religious studies.

ASIA200.name: Cultural Foundations of East Asia
ASIA200.desc: A comparative survey of the beliefs, assumptions and values which have shaped the civilizations of East Asia in both traditional and modern times.

ASIA204.name: Introduction to Asian Religions
ASIA204.desc: The religions of India, China, and Japan in their interactions and cultural contexts, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.

ASIA208.name: Cultural Foundations of South Asia
ASIA208.desc: A survey of South Asian cultures, including language and literature, art, religion, polity and society, as they developed in the past and have been transformed in the modern period.

ASIA209.name: Cultural Foundations of Southeast Asia
ASIA209.desc: A comparative survey of the different cultures found in the communities of Southeast Asia. Focus will be on language and literature, arts, religion, society and polity, ideologies and belief systems in the past as well as in modern times.

ASIA211.name: Sex, Sexual Ethics, and Asian Religions
ASIA211.desc: Sex and sexual ethics in the scriptures, monastic rules, rituals, and narratives of Asian religions, such as Sikhism, Hinduism, Buddhism, and Confucianism.

ASIA212.name: Writing About Japan
ASIA212.desc: Literary, historiographic, religious, and feminist approaches to Japanese myths, legal tracts, religious tales, fiction, and poetry.

ASIA213.name: Myth, Literature, and Film in North India
ASIA213.desc: Indian literary and mythological texts, in genres from epic to lyric, as recast in contemporary Hindi film.

ASIA222.name: Encountering Asia
ASIA222.desc: Introduction to the literary, religious, and philosophical traditions of at least two Asian cultures using foundational texts. Students will learn about these traditions by encountering them historically as well as through the lenses of their own diverse identities and contexts.

ASIA223.name: Writing Asia
ASIA223.desc: This writing-intensive course is to be taken concurrently with ASIA 222. The seminar builds on the materials of ASIA 222. Students must have knowledge of or be enrolled in the study of one of the languages offered in Asian Studies.

ASIA250.name: Introduction to Buddhism
ASIA250.desc: Origins, basic teachings, development of Theravada, Mahayana, and Tantric traditions, historical spread first through Asia and later the world, and Buddhism in contemporary societies.

ASIA254.name: Sex, Gender, and Sexuality in Japanese Literature and Film
ASIA254.desc: The integral role that sex, gender, and sexuality play in literary and cinematic works from Japan. Literary works will be read in translation, movies will be subtitled.

ASIA258.name: Religion in South Asia
ASIA258.desc: The major religious traditions of South Asia, including Hinduism, Islam, Sikhism, and Buddhism; the significance of religious thought and practice in premodern India, as well as the continuing impact of religion in today's globalized South Asia.

ASIA270.name: China in World History
ASIA270.desc: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China.

ASIA300.name: Writing and Culture in East Asia
ASIA300.desc: Practical, aesthetic, historical, technological and political issues pertaining to the use of Chinese characters - hanzi (Chinese), kanji (Japanese), or hanccha (Korean) - throughout the region.

ASIA301.name: Buddhism in the Modern Era
ASIA301.desc: Buddhism from the nineteenth century to present day with special emphasis on its history and character in local settings, including specific traditions such as Tibetan Nyingma and Japanese Zen, as well as the development of a modern and global "Buddhism."

ASIA302.name: Theravada Buddhism
ASIA302.desc: History, story, and culture of the major form of Buddhism primarily focused on the regions of Sri Lanka, and mainland Southeast Asia, including southern Vietnam, parts of southern China, spread to Nepal, and modern global diffusion.

ASIA303.name: Mahayana Buddhism
ASIA303.desc: Historical and philosophical development of Mahayana Buddhism.

ASIA304.name: Survey of South and Southeast Asian Performing Arts
ASIA304.desc: An historical perspective of the performing arts of South and Southeast Asia, highlighting the role of music, dance, and the dramatic arts in the lives of actors and audiences.  Option to complete a practicum performance.

ASIA305.name: Asian Horror Cinema: National Nightmares and Specters of Trauma
ASIA305.desc: Engaging with the ideologies, industrial histories, socio-cultural contexts, and aesthetics of horror films - and the genre itself - from various Asian cinemas.

ASIA306.name: Esoteric Buddhism
ASIA306.desc: Overview of Buddhism's rich and complex esoteric traditions in the Himalayan region and South, Southeast, and East Asia, with particular emphasis on texts, commentaries, and practices from a variety of traditions, locales and time periods.

ASIA307.name: Korean Language and Writing in Culture and Society
ASIA307.desc: An examination of Korean language and writing using approaches from sociolinguistics, the sociology of language, and linguistic anthropology.

ASIA308.name: Myth, Ritual and Epic in Ancient India
ASIA308.desc: Myths of creation Gods and goddesses of the Vedic pantheon. Connections with myths in other parts of the world, particularly in the Indo-European tradition. Literary representations of the myths.

ASIA309.name: South Asian Beyond South Asia
ASIA309.desc: A history of South Asian peoples and communities that emigrated overseas, including Indo-Canadians.

ASIA310.name: Studies in the History of a Major Asian Civilization
ASIA310.desc: Study of an Asian culture area different from those covered in existing courses. Not given every year. Consult Department for details. May be taken multiple times on different subjects for credit.

ASIA311.name: Tibetan Buddhism
ASIA311.desc: Religious terrain of the Tibetan cultural realm, looking at the history and development of Tibetan Buddhism and key ideas of the four main Tibetan Buddhist traditions.

ASIA313.name: Tibetan and Himalayan Culture and Society
ASIA313.desc: History and culture of the Himalayan regions, including India, China, Tibet, Nepal, and Bhutan.

ASIA314.name: Premodern Japan
