ASIA314.desc: Japanese history (political, economic, social and cultural) to 1600.

ASIA315.name: Japan from Feudal to Modern State
ASIA315.desc: Japanese history from 1600 to the Meiji Restoration. Political, economic, social and cultural forces which were involved in transforming Japan.

ASIA316.name: Race and Ethnicity in Japanese Literature and Film
ASIA316.desc: Examines relations between majority and minority groups in Japanese society and changing definitions of "Japan" through literature and film from Japan.

ASIA317.name: The Rise of Korean Civilization
ASIA317.desc: The evolution of a distinctive Korean civilization within the East Asian cultural sphere. Primary focus on cultural, social and political development from the earliest times to the sixteenth century.

ASIA318.name: Premodern India
ASIA318.desc: A survey of the history and culture of India from the earliest historic period to 1200 and the coming of Islam, with emphasis on the evolution of classical Hindu civilization.

ASIA319.name: History of Indonesian Civilization
ASIA319.desc: Survey of the archipelago from the 10th century to the present. Social organization, major religions, economic and political developments from the pre-modern period, through Dutch colonial rule to independence.

ASIA320.name: History of Early China
ASIA320.desc: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society.

ASIA324.name: Literature of Hong Kong
ASIA324.desc: A survey of the literature of Hong Kong, from classical times to the present. Important periods in literary history (imperial, colonial, post-colonial), major authors (locals, visitors, and writers elsewhere), and important genres, including poetry, essays, and fiction.

ASIA325.name: Hong Kong Cinema
ASIA325.desc: A survey of the cinema of Hong Kong from the post-war period to the present. The influence of Hong Kong on global cinema, and the forces (artists, studios, audiences, etc.) that have given rise to filmmaking styles and genres perceived as "distinctively Hong Kong."

ASIA326.name: Critical Approaches to Manga and Anime
ASIA326.desc: A critical introduction to Japanese manga and anime in the 20th and 21st centuries.

ASIA327.name: Korean Popular Music in Context
ASIA327.desc: History, contexts, and the genres of Korean popular music. Students will analyze specific artists and songs using a range of approaches. While an understanding of basic concepts of music will be helpful, no previous exposure to ethnomusicology or music performance is required.

ASIA328.name: Medieval India
ASIA328.desc: The history, culture, and social and economic organization of South Asia from the decline of the classical Hindu empires through the Sultanate period.

ASIA329.name: Gender in Southeast Asia
ASIA329.desc: A critical examination of what it means to be a woman or a man within the social and cultural context of Southeast Asia. What "masculinity" and "femininity" signify in Indonesia's society; how these concepts are reaffirmed or challenged.

ASIA330.name: Islam in South Asia
ASIA330.desc: Islam as a transnational phenomenon with specific reference to its South Asian forms.

ASIA331.name: Islam in Indonesia
ASIA331.desc: Islam as a transnational phenomenon with specific reference to its Indonesian forms.

ASIA332.name: Confucianism in China and Beyond: Reinventions of Tradition
ASIA332.desc: Key ideas and trends in Confucian thought and practice from its origins to modern times through primary sources in translation and secondary scholarship.

ASIA333.name: Contemporary South Asian Gender and Sexuality Studies
ASIA333.desc: Main theories and key concepts with a particular focus on the changing status of women, and gender and sexual minorities.

ASIA334.name: Indonesian Cinema
ASIA334.desc: Representations of social and political relations, cultural traditions and regional differences, marriage, family and kinship ties, and gender politics in Indonesia as shown through Indonesian cinema.

ASIA337.name: The Korean People in Modern Times (1600 to the present)
ASIA337.desc: The transformation of Korea from a Confucian state into an industrial nation. The rise of nationalism and modern ideologies in Korea. Cultural, social and economic changes Korea has undergone as it has entered the modern world.

ASIA338.name: Modern India: From Conquest to Raj
ASIA338.desc: The history of India from the coming of the Europeans to the rise of the nationalist movement with emphasis on the social and economic impact of British imperialism.

ASIA339.name: The Construction of South Asian Communities in the Diaspora
ASIA339.desc: An examination of contemporary South Asian communities in the diaspora. Topics of particular importance are family life, religious life, notions of space, communal memory, literary and visual representation.

ASIA340.name: History of Later Imperial China
ASIA340.desc: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation.  Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China.

ASIA341.name: Classical Chinese Literature in Translation
ASIA341.desc: Poetry, historical and philosophic prose writings and the earliest genres of fiction in classical Chinese (ca. 1100 BC – ca. 750 AD).

ASIA342.name: Chinese Literature in Translation: The Vernacular Tradition
ASIA342.desc: Readings in drama and fiction, 800 to 1800 AD. The emergence of vernacular genres as distinct from and sometimes opposed to the existing classical genres.

ASIA343.name: Film in South Asia
ASIA343.desc: Social and cultural history of South Asian film.

ASIA344.name: Topics in Japanese Cultural History I: Aristocrats and Warriors
ASIA344.desc: Focuses each year on a specific topic related to the courtly or warrior culture of Japan.

ASIA346.name: Topics in Japanese Cultural History II: The Early Modern Age
ASIA346.desc: Focuses each year on a specific topic related to the culture of early modern Japan.

ASIA347.name: Traditional Korean Literature in Translation
ASIA347.desc: An introduction to Korean literature from ancient times to 1900.

ASIA348.name: Great Literary Works of Classical India in Translation
ASIA348.desc: Major Sanskrit and Prakrit literary genres as developed in the Brahmanical, Buddhist and Jaina traditions, including folktales of riddle, intrigue, etc. Ramayana, Mahabharata. Polished poems of the urbane. Plays. Learned novels and long poems.

ASIA349.name: Southeast Asian Literature in Translation
ASIA349.desc: Literary works from the Malay/Indonesian-speaking world (Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore) and some from other regions (mainland Southeast Asia, the Philippines). All readings in English translation.

ASIA350.name: Asian Literature in Translation: A Comparative Approach
ASIA350.desc: A comparative approach to the literatures of East, South and Southeast Asia focusing on a specific theme.

ASIA351.name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation
ASIA351.desc: Reading of selected novels and stories written between 1750 and the present.

ASIA352.name: Topics in Traditional Chinese Vernacular Literature
ASIA352.desc: Traditional Chinese culture as seen through reading and discussion of exemplary literary works in the vernacular language.

ASIA353.name: Introduction to Hindi Film
ASIA353.desc: History, aesthetics, politics, and social roles of Bollywood films. Seminar discussions in English; Hindi films with English subtitles.

ASIA354.name: Introduction to Japanese Cinema
ASIA354.desc: Students will be introduced to the work of the major directors (e.g., Ozu, Mizoguchi, Kurosawa, Itami, Oshima, Shinoda). Ideological uses of literary texts and period pieces (e.g., Ugetsu, Life of Oharu, Double Suicide). Impact of depiction of Japanese in American film.

ASIA355.name: History of Chinese Cinema
ASIA355.desc: Introduction to the work of major directors.

ASIA356.name: Korean Cinema
ASIA356.desc: Introduction to the work of the major film makers.

ASIA357.name: Modern Korean Literature in Translation
ASIA357.desc: Selected fiction and poetry written between 1917 and the present.

ASIA358.name: Literature of Medieval India in Translation
ASIA358.desc: Devotional, mystic, and erotic poetry of medieval Hinduism, Islam, and Sikhism.

ASIA359.name: Gender Relations in Southeast Asian Literature and Cinema
ASIA359.desc: Gender relations as portrayed in Southeast Asian films and writings in English translation by women and men from the Malay/Indonesian-speaking world, mainland Southeast Asia, and the Philippines.

ASIA360.name: A Specific Asian Literature in Translation
ASIA360.desc: Introduction to the literature of a linguistic area of Asia not covered in existing courses. Not given every year. Consult the Department for details. May be taken multiple times on different subjects for credit.

ASIA361.name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation II
ASIA361.desc: A thematic survey of modern Chinese fiction and film in translation.

ASIA362.name: Pre-Modern Japanese Fiction (in translation)
ASIA362.desc: The influential genre of early tales and fiction in pre-modern Japan.

ASIA363.name: Fiction and Film from Modern Taiwan
ASIA363.desc: A reading-intensive survey of literary and cinematic culture in Taiwan since the early 20th century: colonialism, the national divide, nativism, trauma, cosmopolitanism, and utopian imaginings. In English.

ASIA364.name: Modern Japanese Literature in Translation
ASIA364.desc: An introduction to the literature and cultural history of modern Japan, with readings drawn from various literary genres, from 1868 to the present.

ASIA365.name: Punjabi Cinema
ASIA365.desc: Punjabi culture, history, and social values through films.  The class includes film viewings and seminar discussions.  Films will be screened with English subtitles.

ASIA366.name: Edo-Period Theatre
ASIA366.desc: Edo-period puppet and kabuki theaters, with additional attention to the latter’s representation in woodblock prints and the construction of gender roles in theatre.

ASIA367.name: Contemporary Korean Culture
ASIA367.desc: An introduction to the literature, drama, music, and art of Korea today. Particular attention will be paid to the continuing influence of traditional themes and forms.

ASIA368.name: Modern Literatures of South Asia in Translation
ASIA368.desc: Fiction, drama, and poetry of modern India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka, including works in English translation and originally written in English.

ASIA369.name: Asian Folklore
ASIA369.desc: A survey of oral and expressive traditions in Asia, including jokes, superstitions, fairy tales, myths, music, and foodways; practical training in collecting and archiving folklore.

ASIA370.name: The Sanskrit Cosmopolis: India and the World, 200-1500 CE
ASIA370.desc: Languages, religions, art forms, and political structures of Asian societies shaped by creative encounters with Sanskrit.

ASIA371.name: Foundations of Chinese Thought
ASIA371.desc: Chinese thought from its beginnings until the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) in its historical and cultural contexts. Includes, among others: Confucius; Mo Zi; the Legalists/Authoritarians; Zhuang Zi; the Lao Zi book.

ASIA372.name: Development of Traditional Chinese Thought
ASIA372.desc: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) to Wang Yangming (1472-1529) in its historical and cultural contexts.

ASIA373.name: History of Hong Kong
ASIA373.desc: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present.

ASIA374.name: Imagining Punjab
ASIA374.desc: The cultural and linguistic region of Punjab as it has been imagined in different times and places, in South Asia and beyond, in literature, scholarship, film, and popular culture.

ASIA375.name: Global Chinese Cinemas
ASIA375.desc: A survey of Chinese cinemas in global perspective, covering films, filmmakers, producers, audiences, markets, industries, and critical discourse since the early twentieth century. Covers both cinematic culture and filmmaking technique.

ASIA376.name: The Sikhs: Formations, Contexts, and Historical Development
ASIA376.desc: Introduction to the historical development of Sikh traditions in India and Diaspora, from the 15th century to the present, with attention to broader historical contexts.

ASIA377.name: History of Korean Thought
ASIA377.desc: An examination of Korean religious, philosophical, and scientific thought from the earliest written records to the present day, with particular focus on the interaction of Shamanism, Buddhism, Confucianism, and, in the present century, Christianity.

ASIA378.name: Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
ASIA378.desc: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

ASIA379.name: The Sikhs: History, Religion and Society
ASIA379.desc: A historical study of the social and cultural forces that helped shape Sikh religious beliefs and ritual practices over the past four centuries. In dealing with the evolution of Sikh identity, due attention will be given to Sikh ideals, social organization, religious institutions and sacred literature.

ASIA380.name: The Making of Modern China: Nationalism, War, Revolution
ASIA380.desc: The history of China from 1800 to the present including the decline of the Qing empire, the rise of modern nationalism, foreign invasion, and China's multiple revolutions.

ASIA381.name: Daoist (Taoist) Religion and Its Philosophical Background
ASIA381.desc: A study of the Daoist religious traditions from their beginnings in the second century CE in their cultural, intellectual and social contexts.

ASIA382.name: Buddhism in China
ASIA382.desc: History, thought, and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century.

ASIA383.name: Common Religious Traditions in China
ASIA383.desc: A study of the religious practices and beliefs shared by the great majority of people in traditional Chinese culture, including ancestor worship, seasonal festivals, offerings to deities, exorcism of harmful forces.

ASIA384.name: The
ASIA384.desc: Introduction to a foundational text of East Asian thought. Both the primary text and its reception in traditional and modern contexts will be examined.

ASIA385.name: Chan/Zen Buddhism: Doctrine and Practice
ASIA385.desc: The history, doctrines, and practices of Chan Buddhism, particularly the profound influence of Chan Buddhism on various aspects of East Asian culture.

ASIA386.name: Chinese Grammar and Usage I
ASIA386.desc: In-depth examination of modern Chinese grammar and its usage including word formation, syntactic constructions, discourse cohesions, semantics, and stylistic considerations.
ASIA386.prer: All of CHIN 207, CHIN 337, CHIN 208, CHIN 338, CHIN 217, CHIN 347, CHIN 218, CHIN 348 or higher level of Chinese language proficiency.

ASIA387.name: Japanese Religions
ASIA387.desc: An introduction to traditional Japanese religions including Shinto, Buddhism, Shugendo, Confucianism, new religions and folklore, and their roles in Japanese history, culture and society.

ASIA388.name: Buddhist, Brahamanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction
ASIA388.desc: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

ASIA390.name: History of the Indian Ocean World
ASIA390.desc: Societies and empires shaped by voyages of exploration, religious pilgrimages, trading diasporas and forced migration in the world of the Indian Ocean.

ASIA391.name: An Introduction to the Indo-Persian Cosmopolis/Knowledge Systems
ASIA391.desc: Cultural interactions between Delhi and the wider Dar al Islam with indigenous groups and local culture from the 13th to the 19th centuries.

ASIA392.name: Classical Persian Literature in English Translation
ASIA392.desc: Works of classical Persian literature dating from the tenth to the seventeenth century (in English translation).

ASIA393.name: History of Iran from the Sasanians to the Safavids
ASIA393.desc: Iranian history from the fall of the Sasanian empire and the Arab conquest of Iran to the rise of Iranian dynasties in the east, the reign of Turkic and Turko-Mongolian rulers, and the formation of a Shi‘ite Iran under the Safavids.

ASIA394.name: Post-Revolutionary Iranian Cinema
ASIA394.desc: Gender politics, family relationships, and women's social, economic, and political roles in post-revolutionary Iran as shown through Iranian cinema.

ASIA396.name: Chinese Grammar and Usage II
ASIA396.desc: In-depth examination of modern Chinese grammar and its usage including word formation, syntactic constructions, discourse cohesions, semantics, and stylistic considerations. Continuation of ASIA 386.
ASIA396.prer: ASIA 386 or higher level of Chinese language proficiency.

ASIA397.name: The Idea of India
ASIA397.desc: History of cultural ideas that led to India’s transformation from a traditional, colonial society tied to the British empire to a postcolonial, pluralistic, development oriented parliamentary democracy.

ASIA398.name: Narrative Literature in Premodern India
ASIA398.desc: Stories of gods, goddesses and religious heroes from the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Puranas, Avadanas and in classical poetry and drama.

ASIA400.name: Chinese Characters: Script, Languages, and Civilizations
ASIA400.desc: Advanced study of the structure of the Chinese characters in their graphic, phonetic, and semantic aspects.
ASIA400.prer: ASIA 300 and one of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338, CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348, JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361, KORN 300, KORN 301, KORN 302.

ASIA402.name: Language, Writing, and Linguistic Thought in the History of the Sinographic Cosmopolis
ASIA402.desc: History of language, writing and linguistic thought in China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam from a comparative perspective and focusing on the dissolution of this translocal cultural formation with the onset of modernity.
ASIA402.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students.  At least 12 credits of any level of CHIN, JAPN, or KORN or placement approval.  Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

ASIA405.name: The Interaction of Science, Religion, and Philosophy in East Asia
ASIA405.desc: The influence of Confucianism, Buddhism, Daoism, and Christianity on the way peoples of East Asia understood and manipulated the natural world, focussing on the natural sciences.

ASIA408.name: Religion, Society, and Secularism in Modern India
ASIA408.desc: The postcolonial nation-state and the challenge of a multi-religious society.  Religious and secular discourse in colonial India, the partition, the modern constitution, secularism, Hindu and Muslim mobilization, and religious radicalism and communal violence.
ASIA408.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

ASIA410.name: International Relations in Premodern East Asia
ASIA410.desc: International relations, particularly between Korea and Japan in the premodern East Asian context, focusing on migration, trade, diplomacy, war, collective memory, mutual perceptions, and the context of the Sinocentric international order.

ASIA411.name: Chinese Political Thought and Institutions
ASIA411.desc: Chinese theories and practices of government and administration from earliest times to 1949.

ASIA414.name: Architecture and Urbanism in Islamic South Asia
ASIA414.desc: Historical factors shaping Indian architecture from the 13th to the 19th centuries.

ASIA418.name: Social History of India
ASIA418.desc: Fundamental institutions including family, caste and religious organizations, with emphasis on the early modern and British periods.

ASIA428.name: Mughal India
ASIA428.desc: History of the politics, economy, society, and culture of South Asia from the Great Mughals to the British conquest.

ASIA430.name: International Relations in Modern East Asia: Korea and Japan
ASIA430.desc: Trade, diplomacy, war, imperialism, militarism, colonialism, collective memory, mutual perceptions Korean-Japanese relations are examined as an exemplary case for exploring the dimensions of international conflict and partnership.

ASIA433.name: The Cinematic Lives of Muslims in South Asia
ASIA433.desc: Depictions of Muslims in South Asian cinema, with a particular focus on the Hindi film industry.

ASIA440.name: Cultural History of Imperial China
ASIA440.desc: An in-depth examination of the construction, transmission, and transformation of Chinese culture(s) prior to 1800. Completion of at least 9 credits of 300- or 400-level ASIA recommended prior to registration. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 440 or HIST 479.

ASIA441.name: Masterworks of Chinese Fiction and Drama in Translation
ASIA441.desc: Reading of a classic novel or play, with attention to intellectual, social, and political subtexts as well as aesthetic dimensions and problems of interpretation.

ASIA442.name: Lives of Chinese Books
ASIA442.desc: Concepts and methods for understanding the lives of books across time, through an examination of both the material forms of a text and its cultural reception. Focus on one major work from pre-modern China.

ASIA444.name: Topics in Modern Japanese Fiction and Cultural History
ASIA444.desc: Focuses on a limited time period or particular aspect of modern Japanese literature.

ASIA447.name: Korean Women's Literature
ASIA447.desc: Women's voices and issues in the Korean literary tradition, from earliest times to the new millennium, in translation.
ASIA447.prer: One of ASIA 347, ASIA 357. Permission of instructor is also acceptable.

ASIA448.name: Narrative and Performance in South Asia
ASIA448.desc: Key theoretical issues in the production and enactment of folk narratives in traditional and modern South Asian cultures. Intended for advanced undergraduates in Asian folklore studies. Credit will not be granted for both ASIA 448 and 547.

ASIA450.name: Special Topics in Buddhist Studies
ASIA450.desc: For upcoming offerings, including course descriptions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule at https://courses.students.ubc.ca/cs/main.

ASIA451.name: Modern Chinese Authors in Translation
ASIA451.desc: Study of one influential modern Chinese author, such as Lu Xun, Shen Congwen, Eileen Chang, Yu Hua, Mo Yan, or Wang Anyi.
ASIA451.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

ASIA452.name: Literature of the Korean Diaspora
ASIA452.desc: A survey of literature, in translation, from the Korean diaspora, focusing on writing by ethnic Koreans in North America, Europe, and Japan.
ASIA452.prer: One of ASIA 347, ASIA 357, ASIA 447, ASIA 457.

ASIA453.name: Japanese Travel Literature
ASIA453.desc: Japanese travel literature (myths, legends, poetry, tales, diaries, illustrated guides, satiric sermons, haiku, comic fiction, colonial reporting, and ethnography) from the 8th century to present.
ASIA453.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

ASIA454.name: Japanese Poetry in Translation
ASIA454.desc: An introduction to Japanese poetry from its origins in song and myth, to its development from a courtly art (waka) to a popular pastime (haiku). Influences on prose, autobiography, and theatre will also be considered.

ASIA455.name: Adaptations of Japanese Classics
ASIA455.desc: Introduction to literary, stage, and film adaptations of Japanese classics and legends and the ways in which these "new" works appropriate the past to comment on the present.

ASIA456.name: History and Culture of Taiwan
ASIA456.desc: The major social, economic, political, and cultural changes in Taiwan since the seventeenth century; the post-World War II process of democratization and Taiwan’s place in the contemporary world.

ASIA457.name: The Modern Korean Novel
ASIA457.desc: Survey of major single-volume novels, ranging from Yi Kwang-su's
ASIA457.prer: ASIA 357. Permission of instructor is also acceptable.

ASIA460.name: Modern Asian Women in Narrative
ASIA460.desc: Experience of women in the context of a particular Asian culture, as seen through literature, popular culture, film and folklore. Narrative as a medium for the representation and constitution of gender.

ASIA464.name: Japanese Women's Self-Writing
ASIA464.desc: Selected aspects of the more than 1000 years of self-writing (diary, autobiography, personal fiction). Theory and criticism about the use of writing as a medium of self-expression.

ASIA466.name: The History of Christianity in Asia
ASIA466.desc: A survey of Christian proselytizing drives in South, Southeast, and East Asia, focusing on the period since 1500 and the reasons for successes (the Phillipines and Korea, for example) and failures (Japan). Credit will not be granted for both ASIA 466 and 566.

ASIA468.name: Approaches to the Study of Asian Religions
ASIA468.desc: The Western genealogy and problematics of religion, issues in its application to non-Western cultures and traditions, and the practical study of Asian religions, in Asia and its diasporas.
ASIA468.prer: One of ASIA 376, ASIA 381, ASIA 382, ASIA 383, ASIA 387. Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

ASIA470.name: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
ASIA470.desc: Ways in which the "self" has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsün-tzu), Nietzsche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

ASIA475.name: Documenting Punjabi Canada
ASIA475.desc: Exploration of the history of the Punjabi Canadian community through traditional text-based methods and oral history collection (in English or Punjabi).

ASIA476.name: Topics in Sikh and South Asian Studies
ASIA476.desc: Seminar class designed to explore current scholarly debates in South Asian and Sikh Studies. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 476 or ASIA 576.
ASIA476.prer: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.

ASIA477.name: New Religious Movements of East Asia
ASIA477.desc: Examines the rise of new religious movements in China, Japan, and Korea over the last two centuries, from the Taiping, Tonghak, and Tenri-kyo to the Unification Church, SGI International, and Falun Gong. Credit will not be granted for both ASIA 477 and 577.
ASIA477.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

ASIA478.name: The Religious Image in Asia
ASIA478.desc: The religious image and related material culture within Buddhism, Islam, Jainism, Hinduism, Christianity, and Sikhism with special attention to methodological concerns.  Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 478 or ASIA 578.
ASIA478.prer: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.

ASIA484.name: The History of the Choson Dynasty
ASIA484.desc: Political, social, and cultural history of Korea's Choson Dynasty, focusing on how it lasted from 1392 to 1910 and why it collapsed so quickly at the beginning of the twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 484 and 587.

ASIA485.name: Inventing Asian Religions in the West/East Encounter
ASIA485.desc: An examination of how western imperial expansion transformed the descriptions and practices of Asian traditions through systems of classification, missionaries, discovery of languages, modernity, and fragmentation.

ASIA488.name: Religion, Society and State in Modern India
ASIA488.desc: History of secular and religious discourse in post-independent India. Partition, state policy of secularism, religious mobilization among Hindus and Muslims, communal violence and religious radicalism.

ASIA490.name: Asian Classics - Fourth Year Seminar
ASIA490.desc: Focus changes from year to year. Prerequisite: Permission of Instructor and fourth-year standing.

ASIA495.name: Folk Cultures in the Asian Diaspora
ASIA495.desc: The mediation of folklore (e.g. slang, songs, games, dance, foodways) in the everyday lives of immigrant and transnational Asian communities. Emphasis on Asian-Canadian folklore in Greater Vancouver through digital documentary media production and archival folklore research.
ASIA495.prer: Restricted to 4th year students.  Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

ASIA498.name: Asia in Museums/the Museum in Asia
ASIA498.desc: Museological representations of Asia and Asian forms of museological representation in colonial and post-colonial contexts. Credit will not be granted for both ASIA 498 and ASIA 598.
ASIA498.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

ASIA499.name: Honours Thesis
ASIA499.desc: Restricted to fourth-year students admitted to the Honours Program in Asian Studies.
ASIA499.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.

KORN100.name: Basic Korean I
KORN100.desc: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100 or KORN 102.

KORN101.name: Basic Korean II
KORN101.desc: Continuation of KORN 100. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 101 or KORN 102.

KORN102.name: Basic Korean
KORN102.desc: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100/101 or KORN 102.

KORN104.name: Basic Korean Grammar
KORN104.desc: Emphasis on grammar, writing, and reading. For heritage learners and students with prior background in spoken Korean.

KORN161.name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning
KORN161.desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Korean.

KORN200.name: Intermediate Korean
KORN200.desc: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201/202 or KORN 200.

KORN201.name: Intermediate Korean I
KORN201.desc: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201 or KORN 200.

KORN202.name: Intermediate Korean II
KORN202.desc: Continuation of KORN 201. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 202 or KORN 200.

KORN300.name: Readings in Korean Topics
KORN300.desc: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

KORN301.name: Readings in Korean Topics I
KORN301.desc: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

KORN302.name: Readings in Korean Topics II
KORN302.desc: Continuation of KORN 301. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

KORN351.name: Introduction to Sino-Korean Readings
KORN351.desc: Chinese characters in their Korean pronunciations and shapes. Students learn approximately 600 characters, related vocabulary, and do structured readings in mixed scripts on aspects of Korean culture and contemporary life.

KORN410.name: Modern Korean Short Fiction
KORN410.desc: Reading and translating twentieth-century Korean short fiction.
KORN410.prer: Either (a) KORN 300 or (b) all of KORN 301, KORN 302.

KORN411.name: Advanced Readings in Korean Non-Fiction
KORN411.desc: Guided readings on contemporary affairs from the Korean press and/or selected readings in Korean academic prose.

KORN412.name: Korean-to-English Translation
KORN412.desc: Translation into English of Korean writing in various literary genres, including short story, poetry, personal essay, and academic essay. Supplementary readings in translation studies and translation theory.

KORN415.name: Korean Conversation and Composition
KORN415.desc: Structured conversation practice and weekly composition assignments based on viewing one designated Korean television program per week.

KORN420.name: Readings in Middle and Early Modern Korean
KORN420.desc: History and structure of the Korean language through targeted close readings in different editions of an illustrated text from the 15th and 18th centuries.
KORN420.prer: Non-heritage speakers should have completed KORN 410 or be taking it concurrently. Heritage and native speakers of Korean welcome.

KORN440.name: Supervised Study in the Korean Language
KORN440.desc: Primarily for students in Asian Studies and Linguistics.

EDCP210.name: Introduction to Music Education
EDCP210.desc: Role of music education in schools and society, including historical, philosophical, psychological, and sociological perspectives. Includes guided class observations and practice music teaching in elementary and secondary schools. Criminal Record Check required.

EDCP302.name: Art - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP302.prer: A concentration in art or permission of the Head.

EDCP303.name: Ceramic Design and Pedagogical Approaches: Art Education
EDCP303.prer: 6 credits of introductory art studio or art history courses.

EDCP304.name: Textile Design and Pedagogical Approaches: Art Education
EDCP304.prer: 6 credits of introductory art studio or art history courses.

EDCP305.name: Digital Media in Arts Education: Introduction

EDCP306.name: Digital Media in Arts Education: Advanced

EDCP316.name: Contemporary Methods of Instruction in Ear Training, Music Reading, and Musicianship I

EDCP317.name: Contemporary Methods of Instruction in Ear Training, Music Reading, and Musicianship II

EDCP318.name: Canadian Music in the Classroom: Elementary/Secondary

EDCP320.name: Physical Education - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP322.name: Physical Education - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP322.prer: A completed concentration in physical education or permission of the head.

EDCP323.name: Outdoor Environmental Education: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP323.desc: Costs for field trips and an overnight experience are borne by students. Pass/Fail.

EDCP329.name: Agriculture in the Curriculum
EDCP329.desc: Agricultural awareness, understanding the food system, and integration of food and agricultural literacy across the curriculum.

EDCP331.name: Social Studies - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP332.name: Social Studies - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP333.name: Contemporary Issues in Social Studies: Secondary

EDCP341.name: Mathematics across the Curriculum: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP342.name: Mathematics - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP342.prer: A completed concentration in mathematics or permission of the Head.

EDCP350.name: Biological Sciences - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP351.name: Physical Sciences - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP352.name: General Science - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP352.prer: A completed concentration in agricultural sciences, biological sciences, chemistry, earth and space science, or physics, or permission of the Head.

EDCP353.name: Agricultural Sciences - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP353.prer: A completed concentration in Agricultural Sciences or permission of the Head.

EDCP354.name: Biological Sciences - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP354.prer: A completed concentration in biological sciences or permission of the Head.

EDCP355.name: Chemistry - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP355.prer: A completed concentration in chemistry or permission of the Head.

EDCP356.name: Earth and Space Science - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP356.prer: A completed concentration in earth and space science or permission of the Head.

EDCP357.name: Physics - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP357.prer: A completed concentration in physics or permission of the Head.

EDCP360.name: Elementary and Middle Years: Curriculum and Pedagogy
