EDCP371.name: Integrating Design and Technology Across the Curriculum: Elementary and Middle Years

EDCP372.name: Integrating Business Applications across the Curriculum: Elementary and Middle Years

EDCP373.name: Information and Communication Technologies I - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP374.name: Design and Technology I - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP375.name: Business Education I - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP376.name: Information and Communication Technologies II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP377.name: Design and Technology II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP378.name: Business Education II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP390.name: Home Economics - Elementary and Middle Years: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP391.name: Home Economics I - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP392.name: Assessment and Evaluation in Textile Studies: Home Economics
EDCP392.desc: Practical and conceptual issues of developing and evaluating secondary school textile studies curricula in home economics.

EDCP400.name: Studies in an Art Education Studio Area

EDCP401.name: Visual Arts for Classroom Practice: Two-Dimensional Practices and Processes

EDCP402.name: Visual Arts for Classroom Practice: Printmaking Practices and Processes

EDCP403.name: Visual Arts for Classroom Practice: Three-Dimensional Practices and Processes

EDCP404.name: Visual Arts for Classroom Practice: Textile Design

EDCP405.name: Visual Arts for Classroom Practice: New Media and Digital Processes

EDCP406.name: Visual Arts for Classroom Practice: Photography

EDCP407.name: Art Education Curriculum and Pedagogy: Theory and Practice

EDCP409.name: Art Education Theory and Research
EDCP409.prer: Art education as a major or minor and completion of a practicum in Art Education.

EDCP410.name: Music and Movement - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP410.prer: EDCP 308. Or an introductory course in music education.

EDCP411.name: Music - Elementary: Advanced Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP411.prer: EDCP 308 or an introductory course in music education.

EDCP412.name: Conducting and Rehearsal Techniques for Teachers

EDCP414.name: Elementary Choral Music
EDCP414.prer: EDCP 308 or an introductory course in music education.

EDCP415.name: Music Education for Children with Exceptional Needs

EDCP417.name: Music Education: Orff Level I
EDCP417.prer: One of EDCP 309, EDCP 416, EDCP 411, EDCP 414.

EDCP423.name: Advanced Methodology in Outdoor Environmental Education
EDCP423.desc: Costs for field trips and an overnight experience are borne by students.
EDCP423.prer: EDCP 323 or permission of the instructor.

EDCP430.name: Social Studies - Elementary: Advanced Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP431.name: Special Study in Social Studies: History

EDCP432.name: Special Study in Social Studies: Geography

EDCP440.name: Topics in the Curriculum and Pedagogy in Mathematics: Secondary

EDCP446.name: Forest Education
EDCP446.desc: Transportation and living costs for required field experiences will be borne by the student. [3-0]

EDCP448.name: Conceptions of the Natural World: Implications for Science Education

EDCP449.name: Teaching Earth and Space Science Beyond the Textbook

EDCP450.name: Teaching Life Science Beyond the Textbook

EDCP451.name: Teaching Physical Science Beyond the Textbook

EDCP453.name: Biology for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP453.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required. Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiency. Not for credit towards a graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP454.name: Chemistry for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP454.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required. Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiency. Not for credit toward graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP455.name: Earth and Space Science for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP455.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required.  Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiency. Not for credit toward graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP456.name: Botany for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP456.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required. Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiecy. Not for credit toward graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP457.name: Zoology for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP457.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required. Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiency. Not for credit toward graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP458.name: Applied Studies in Mathematics, Science, and Technology II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP460.name: Recent Developments in Elementary Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP467.name: Special Topics in Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP468.name: Directed Study in Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP471.name: Technological Practices in Education: Technical Problems

EDCP473.name: Digital Media in ICT Education: Ethical Uses

EDCP474.name: Digital Media in ICT Education: Design and Pedagogy

EDCP475.name: Digital Media in ICT Education: Development and Assessment

EDCP491.name: Home Economics II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP492.name: Special Study in Home Economics: Textile Studies

EDCP493.name: Special Study in Home Economics: Foods Studies

EDCP494.name: Special Study in Home Economics: Family Studies

EDCP495.name: Special Topics in Home Economics Education

EDCP498.name: Curriculum Inquiry in Home Economics Education
EDCP498.desc: Culminating inquiry in curriculum and pedagogy for the Home Economics Education Diploma.

HESO400.name: Sociocultural Determinants of Health
HESO400.desc: Methods for analyzing population health data and medical research reporting.

CPSC100.name: Computational Thinking
CPSC100.desc: Meaning and impact of computational thinking. Solving problems using computational thinking, testing, debugging. How computers work. No prior computing experience required. Not for students with existing credit for or exemption from CPSC 110 or APSC 160. [3-1-0]

CPSC110.name: Computation, Programs, and Programming
CPSC110.desc: Fundamental program and computation structures. Introductory programming skills. Computation as a tool for information processing, simulation and modeling, and interacting with the world. [3-3-0]

CPSC298.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
CPSC298.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during Winter Session of second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

CPSC299.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
CPSC299.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education.

CPSC302.name: Numerical Computation for Algebraic Problems
CPSC302.desc: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving no discretization, and their analysis. Solution of linear systems, including analysis of round-off errors; norms and condition number; introduction to iterative techniques in linear algebra, including eigenvalue problems; solution to nonlinear equations. [3-0-0]
CPSC302.prer: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPSC 260, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

CPSC303.name: Numerical Approximation and Discretization
CPSC303.desc: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving discretization, and their analysis. Interpolation and approximation, including splines and least squares data fitting; numerical differentiation and integration; introduction to numerical initial value ordinary differential equations. [3-0-0]
CPSC303.prer: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPSC 260, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

CPSC312.name: Functional and Logic Programming
CPSC312.desc: Principles of symbolic computing, using languages based upon first-order logic and the lambda calculus. Algorithms for implementing such languages. Applications to artificial intelligence and knowledge representation. [3-0-0]
CPSC312.prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309, CPEN 221.

CPSC314.name: Computer Graphics
CPSC314.desc: Human vision and colour; geometric transformations; algorithms for 2-D and 3-D graphics; hardware and system architectures; shading and lighting; animation. [3-1-0]
CPSC314.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320.

CPSC319.name: Software Engineering Project
CPSC319.desc: The design, implementation, and test of a large software system, using a team approach. [3-0-2]

CPSC322.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
CPSC322.desc: Problem-solving and planning; state/action models and graph searching. Natural language understanding Computational vision. Applications of artificial intelligence. [3-0-0]
CPSC322.prer: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

CPSC340.name: Machine Learning and Data Mining
CPSC340.desc: Models of algorithms for dimensionality reduction, nonlinear regression, classification, clustering and unsupervised learning; applications to computer graphics, computer games, bio-informatics, information retrieval, e-commerce, databases, computer vision and artificial intelligence. [3-0-1]
CPSC340.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, MATH 302, STAT 302, MATH 318, BIOL 300;  and either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

CPSC344.name: Introduction to Human Computer Interaction Methods
CPSC344.desc: Basic tools and techniques, teaching a systematic approach to interface design, task analysis, analytic and empirical evaluation methods. [2-2-2]
CPSC344.prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309, CPEN 221.

CPSC349.name: Honours Research Seminar
CPSC349.desc: Students will attend a series of research seminars presented by faculty members, produce a thesis proposal, and choose their honours thesis supervisor. Available to Honours students. Majors students with satisfactory standing may also be permitted to enrol. [1-0-0]

CPSC398.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
CPSC398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

CPSC399.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
CPSC399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

CPSC404.name: Advanced Relational Databases
CPSC404.desc: Physical database design, indexing, relational query processing and optimization, transaction processing, concurrency control, crash recovery, data warehouses, data cubes, views, special topics. [3-0-0]
CPSC404.prer: CPSC 304 and one of CPSC 213, CPSC 261.

CPSC406.name: Computational Optimization
CPSC406.desc: Formulation and analysis of algorithms for continuous and discrete optimization problems; linear, nonlinear, network, dynamic, and integer optimization; large-scale problems; software packages and their implementation; duality theory and sensitivity. [3-0]

CPSC410.name: Advanced Software Engineering
CPSC410.desc: Specification, design, construction and validation of multi-version software systems. [3-0-0]
CPSC410.prer: Either (a) CPSC 310 or (b) one of EECE 310, CPEN 321 and one of EECE 315, CPEN 331.

CPSC411.name: Introduction to Compiler Construction
CPSC411.desc: A practical introduction to lexical analysis, syntactic analysis, type-checking, code generation and optimization. This will be used to design and implement a compiler for a small language. [3-0-0]

CPSC415.name: Advanced Operating Systems
CPSC415.desc: Process synchronization and communication schemes, including message-passing and concepts of monitor and serializer. Virtual memory systems management and the problem of information sharing in such systems. The working set principle. Traps and interrupt handling. Elementary queuing theory and its application such as process scheduling, system balancing and load control. File systems and operating system design methodologies. [3-0-0]

CPSC418.name: Parallel Computation
CPSC418.desc: Algorithms, architectures, and programming paradigms for parallel computation.  Shared memory, message passing, and data parallel architectures and programming models.  Parallel algorithms including reduce, scan, and sorting networks.  Reasoning about the correctness of parallel programs.  Performance analysis and measurement for parallel programs. [3-0-0]
CPSC418.prer: One of CPSC 261, CPSC 313, EECE 476, CPEN 411 and one of CPSC 320, EECE 320.

CPSC420.name: Advanced Algorithms Design and Analysis
CPSC420.desc: The study of advanced topics in the design and analysis of algorithms and associated data structures. Topics include algorithms for graph-theoretic; algebraic and geometric problems; algorithms on nonsequential models; complexity issues; approximation algorithms. [3-0-0]

CPSC421.name: Introduction to Theory of Computing
CPSC421.desc: Characterizations of computability (using machines, languages and functions). Universality, equivalence and Church's thesis. Unsolvable problems. Restricted models of computation. Finite automata, grammars and formal languages. [3-0-0]
CPSC421.prer: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320. CPSC 320 is recommended.

CPSC422.name: Intelligent Systems
CPSC422.desc: Principles and techniques underlying the design, implementation and evaluation of intelligent computational systems. Applications of artificial intelligence to natural language understanding, image understanding and computer-based expert and advisor systems. Advanced symbolic programming methodology. [3-0-0]

CPSC424.name: Geometric Modeling
CPSC424.desc: Digital representation of curves and surfaces, including splines, subdivision surfaces and meshes. Principles, algorithms and mathematical foundations for  geometry representation in computer graphics, computer vision, fabrication, CAD/CAM, and medical imaging. Algorithms for acquisition, creation, representation, and processing of 3D shapes. [3-0-1]
CPSC424.prer: CPSC 320 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.

CPSC425.name: Computer Vision
CPSC425.desc: Introduction to the processing and interpretation of images.  Image sensing, sampling, and filtering.  Algorithms for colour analysis, texture description, stereo imaging, motion interpretation, 3D shape recovery, and recognition. [3-0-0]
CPSC425.prer: All of MATH 200, MATH 221 and either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320.

CPSC426.name: Computer Animation
CPSC426.desc: Motion in computer graphics for characters and their environments. Keyframing, inverse kinematics, particle systems, rigid body dynamics, contact and collision, controller-based active motion, motion capture. [3-0-0]

CPSC430.name: Computers and Society
CPSC430.desc: Impact of computer technology on society; historical perspectives; social and economic consequences of large-scale information processing systems and automatic control; legal and ethical problems in computer applications. Computers and the individual: machine versus human capabilities, fact and fancy; problematic interface between man and machine. [3-0-0]
CPSC430.prer: 3 credits of Computer Science and at least third-year standing.

CPSC436.name: Topics in Computer Science
CPSC436.desc: Selected topics in a specific area within Computer Science. May be taken more than once for credit with permission of the department.
CPSC436.prer: Third-year standing in a Computer Science or Computer Engineering specialization, and permission of the department.

CPSC445.name: Algorithms in Bioinformatics
CPSC445.desc: Sequence alignment, phylogenetic tree reconstruction, prediction of RNA and protein structure, gene finding and sequence annotation, gene expression, and biomolecular computing. [3-0-0]
CPSC445.prer: CPSC 320 and six credits of BIOL beyond BIOL 111.

CPSC448.name: Directed Studies in Computer Science
CPSC448.desc: Open ordinarily to students in Computer Science with at least a 72% average and the permission of the head of the department or designate. The course may consist of supervised reading, participation in a seminar, and one or more programming projects.

CPSC449.name: Honours Thesis
CPSC449.desc: Under supervision of a faculty member, students investigate a research topic and prepare a thesis.

CPSC490.name: Student Directed Seminars
CPSC490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". [3-0-0]

CPSC499.name: Co-operative Work Placement V
CPSC499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

PHRM100.name: Foundations of Pharmacy
PHRM100.desc: Scientific concepts and pharmacy practice principles. Role of the pharmacist, patient assessment skills, professional identity, communication skills, and an understanding of legal and ethical responsibilities.

PHRM111.name: Medication Management I
PHRM111.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on: an introduction to infectious diseases; musculoskeletal disorders; dermatology; eyes, ears, nose, and throat disorders; and hematology.

PHRM131.name: Study Design and Interpretation I
PHRM131.desc: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on biostatistical foundations, randomized controlled trials, and systematic review of randomized controlled trials.

PHRM141.name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice I
PHRM141.desc: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice.

PHRM161.name: Technology in Healthcare
PHRM161.desc: Knowledge and skills related to the role and applications of technology in health care.

PHRM170.name: Community Service Learning I
PHRM170.desc: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

PHRM171.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient I
PHRM171.desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Pass/Fail.

PHRM211.name: Medication Management II
PHRM211.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on respirology and cardiovascular disorders.

PHRM212.name: Medication Management III
PHRM212.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on nephrology, endocrinology, and neurology.

PHRM221.name: Nutrition for Pharmacists
PHRM221.desc: Foundations of nutrition, nutrition for healthy individuals through the lifespan, and selected clinical applications of nutrition in pharmacy practice.

PHRM231.name: Study Design and Interpretation II
PHRM231.desc: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, non-inferiority designs, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines.

PHRM241.name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice II
PHRM241.desc: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice, focusing on the roles and training opportunities for pharmacists in specialty areas of outpatient and inpatient practice.

PHRM251.name: Institutional Practice Skills
PHRM251.desc: Preparation for experiential learning in the hospital setting. Focuses on enhancing familiarity with the care environment and developing skills suited for students to apply to patient care during institutional experiential rotations.

PHRM270.name: Community Service Learning II
PHRM270.desc: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

PHRM271.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient II
PHRM271.desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Focus on direct patient care activities. Pass/Fail.

PHRM272.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Inpatient
PHRM272.desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world inpatient environments. Focus on direct patient care activities. Pass/Fail.

PHRM311.name: Medication Management IV
PHRM311.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on psychiatry; gastroenterology disorders; and oncology and palliative care.

PHRM312.name: Medication Management V
PHRM312.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on special infectious diseases; obstetrics, gynecology, sexual health, and genito-urinary disorders; and toxicology.

PHRM341.name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice III
PHRM341.desc: Current and potential roles for pharmacists, and contemporary issues in pharmacy practice. Focus on the role of pharmacists as patient educators, researchers and collaborators in interprofessional teams.

PHRM351.name: Practice Management and Leadership
PHRM351.desc: Application of management and leadership principles and skills to pharmacy operations.

PHRM361.name: Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
PHRM361.desc: Training for authorization to administer injections

PHRM371.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient III
PHRM371.desc: Direct patient care activities in an outpatient setting. Building on existing pharmaceutical knowledge and problem solving ability. Increased involvement in diverse patient care situations. Pass/Fail.

PHRM441.name: Seminar: Advanced Topics in Pharmacy Practice
PHRM441.desc: Roles and skills for pharmacists as preceptors, teachers and mentors; emerging issues in pharmacy practice.

PHRM450.name: Pharm.D. Seminar
PHRM450.desc: Seminar course about current and potential roles for pharmacists. Students will also deliver an individual and a group seminar. Pass/Fail.

PHRM451.name: Critical Appraisal of Pharmacotherapy Literature
PHRM451.desc: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews, epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines. Pass/Fail.

PHRM452.name: Patient Assessment Skills
PHRM452.desc: Principles and practices of patient assessment, applied to the monitoring of drug efficacy and toxicity. Pass/Fail.

PHRM453.name: Applied Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacogenomics
PHRM453.desc: Pharmacokinetic monitoring of drug therapy in common clinical situations with foundations for application to other drugs.  Pharmacogenomics and personalized medicine principles and applications to practice. Pass/Fail.

PHRM454.name: Practice Management
PHRM454.desc: Values, concepts, issues and responsibilities of individuals exercising leadership and management roles in pharmacy practice and health care settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM462.name: Pharmacotherapeutics 2
PHRM462.desc: Respirology, dermatology, and ears, eyes, nose, and throat. Pass/Fail.

PHRM467.name: Pharmacotherapeutics 7
PHRM467.desc: GU, OBS/GYN, endocrine, and renal. Pass/Fail.

PHRM469.name: Pharmacotherapeutics 9
PHRM469.desc: Acute/critical care, neurology, cardiac, GI, infectious diseases, and respiratory. Pass/Fail.

PHRM471.name: Outpatient Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
PHRM471.desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in outpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

PHRM472.name: Inpatient Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
PHRM472.desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in inpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

PHRM473.name: Selected Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
PHRM473.desc: Diverse options available in such domains as patient care (various settings), research, health policy, education, and others. The available placement options will vary from year to year depending on site/preceptor availability. Pass/Fail.

PHRM481.name: Healthcare Quality Improvement
PHRM481.desc: Builds on the foundation of patient care and management learning with knowledge about healthcare system improvement. Focuses on principles of quality measurement and quality improvement in health.

PHRM491.name: Experiential Rotation I Community
PHRM491.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve inceasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of community settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM492.name: Experiential Rotation II Inpatient
PHRM492.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of inpatient settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM493.name: Experiential Rotation III Advanced Practice
PHRM493.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in specialized (advanced practice) settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM494.name: Experiential Rotation IV Ambulatory/Primary Care
PHRM494.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of ambulatory or primary care settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM495.name: Experiential Rotation V Community or Inpatient
PHRM495.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in community or inpatient settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM496.name: Experiential Rotation VI Elective
PHRM496.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in community, inpatient, primary care, ambulatory care, or specialized (advanced practice) settings. This elective rotation requires Program Director approval. Pass/Fail.

PHRM499.name: Comprehensive Examination
PHRM499.desc: Assessment of skills in the clinical problem-solving process. Pass/Fail.
PHRM499.prer: Successful completion of all other coursework

CSPW100.name: Coordinated Science Program Workshop
CSPW100.desc: Students participate in activities related to their CSP courses, including hands-on work, discussion and analysis of scientific topics. Graded Pass/Fail.

APBI100.name: Soil and the Global Environment
APBI100.desc: Soil as the base of the Earth’s ecosystem pyramid. The interconnection between soil, climate change and human activity, the carbon cycle, water resources, food security, food safety, and biofuel production. Strategies for sustaining soil resources.

APBI200.name: Introduction to Soil Science
APBI200.desc: Physical, chemical and biological properties of soils; soil formation, classification, use and conservation. There are no prerequisites for this course, but background in Biology 12, Chemistry 12, and Physics 12 (or first-year university-level) is strongly advised. [3-2]

APBI222.name: Introduction to Horticulture
APBI222.desc: The cultivation of key temperate fruits, vegetables, greenhouse, ornamental and nursery crops in BC, integrated with scientific and practical aspects of their sustainable production and marketing.

APBI235.name: Biotechnology in Agricultural Food Production
APBI235.desc: Genetics, genomics, and biotechnology concepts with applications to agricultural food production and food safety. [3-3]

APBI260.name: Agroecology I
APBI260.desc: Introduction to the biophysical and socioeconomic factors affecting systems management and production in selected agroecosystems. [1-3-6]

APBI265.name: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
APBI265.desc: Principles and practices necessary to understand practical concerns of sustainable food systems.  Credit will be given for only one of APBI 265 or APBI 260. [1-3-0]

APBI290.name: Introductory Topics in Applied Biology
APBI290.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology. Topics will vary from year to year.

APBI311.name: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
APBI311.desc: Cardiovascular, respiratory and osmoregulatory physiology of vertebrates. [1-0-3]
APBI311.prer: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361. And 3rd year standing.

APBI314.name: Animals and Society
APBI314.desc: Contemporary use of animals for food production, companionship, recreation and science; social and ethical issues concerning human impacts on animals; animals in human culture; protection of animals by society and the law.
APBI314.prer: At least third-year standing in any faculty.

APBI315.name: Animal Welfare and the Ethics of Animal Use
APBI315.desc: Scientific assessment of animal well-being, ethical concepts applied to animal use, and animal welfare issues arising in agriculture, biomedical research and other areas. [1-0-3]
APBI315.prer: At least third-year standing in any faculty.

APBI316.name: Equine Biology, Health and Welfare
APBI316.desc: Anatomy, physiology, reproduction, nutrition of the horse; common disease pathology, prevention and treatments; equine behaviour. [3-0]

APBI318.name: Applied Plant Breeding
APBI318.desc: Small-scale classical (i.e., non-biotechnological) plant breeding. Hands-on, application-oriented approach to techniques and procedures for managing seed inventories, designing and implementing a simple plant breeding program, and evaluating the impact of selection on breeding populations and desired outcomes. [3-1-0]

APBI319.name: Aquaculture and the Environment
APBI319.desc: Interactions between aquaculture and the environment. Current issues, comparison of systems, species, production methods, environments, and socioeconomics.
APBI319.prer: One of BIOL 230, APBI 260, APBI 265, CONS 330, ENVR 200, ENVR 300 and third year standing. Or permission of the instructor.

APBI322.name: Horticultural Techniques
APBI322.desc: An introduction to horticultural practice in an experiential learning format. Plant identification, seeding, propagation, pruning, cultivation media, pesticide application and safety are examined in the context of integrated crop management. An additional fee may be required for the pesticide certification examination. [0-3-3]

APBI326.name: Introductory Plant Pathology
APBI326.desc: Study of the ecology of plant pathogenic organisms; principles of disease development and control. [3-2-0]

APBI342.name: Soil Biology
APBI342.desc: The diversity of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; interactions between soil organisms; responses to environmental change. [2-3-0]

APBI360.name: Agroecology II
APBI360.desc: Animals and Plants as Components of Agricultural Ecosystems. A systems approach is used to investigate the functions and interactions of plants and animals in agricultural systems. Field trips for assessment of existing agroecosystems. [3-0-3]

APBI361.name: Key Indicators of Agroecosystem Sustainability
APBI361.desc: A detailed exploration of biophysical, economic, and social ecosystem sustainability indicators for primary production subsystems. [1-0-3]

APBI365.name: Summer Practicum in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
APBI365.desc: Based at the UBC Farm. Application required. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
APBI365.prer: One of APBI 260, APBI 265 and third-year standing.

APBI398.name: Research Methods in Applied Biology
APBI398.desc: Research methods including research design, scientific critique, writing proposals and reports, and oral presentation.
APBI398.prer: Third-year standing in the Applied Biology program and permission of the instructor.

APBI401.name: Soil Processes
APBI401.desc: Integration of soil physics, chemistry, and biology in understanding essential soil processes. [3-0-0]

APBI402.name: Sustainable Soil Management
APBI402.desc: Application of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management. [1-0-3]

APBI403.name: Soil Sampling, Analyses and Data Interpretation
APBI403.desc: Field and laboratory analytical techniques in the chemical, biological and physical assessment of soils. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 503 or APBI 403. [1-3-0]

APBI410.name: Applied Animal Health and Physiology
APBI410.desc: Application of physiology and pathology principles to health and disease of domestic animals. [3-0-0]
APBI410.prer: BIOL 201 and one of APBI 311, CAPS 301.

APBI411.name: Reproductive Physiology and Technology
APBI411.desc: A comparative overview of reproductive physiology and reproductive technologies in domesticated and laboratory animals. [3-2-0]
APBI411.prer: BIOL 201. Third year standing or higher.

APBI412.name: Belowground Ecosystems
APBI412.desc: Concepts, methods, and applications of belowground ecology with emphasis on biotic interactions in soil; roles that aboveground and belowground communities play in regulating the structure and function of terrestrial ecosystems and their responses to global change. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 512 or APBI 412. [3-0-0]
APBI412.prer: Fourth year standing in a Bachelor of Science Program. Permission is required for registration.

APBI413.name: Stress and Coping in Animals
APBI413.desc: Understanding, assessing, and managing stress in farm, companion, captive wildlife, and research animals: sources of stress; behavioural, emotional, cognitive, and physiological responses; effects on growth, reproduction, health.
APBI413.prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and courses in animal physiology and animal behavior recommended.

APBI414.name: Animals and Global Issues
APBI414.desc: Research seminar integrating diverse information to address global animal issues including: animal-source foods and human health, environmental impact of livestock production, trade in exotic animals. [3-0-0]

APBI415.name: Applied Animal Behaviour
APBI415.desc: Application of principles and research methods of animal behaviour to practical problems in the care of farm, companion, wild and research animals, and in animal training, and human-wildlife conflict. [3-0-0]

APBI416.name: Animal Welfare and Conservation Biology
APBI416.desc: Evaluation of humane treatment of individual animals living in the wild and managed within conservation biology. Assessment of attitudes and viewpoints of the role of animal welfare in conservation biology.
APBI416.prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and BIOL 416 or CONS 220/330 recommended.

APBI417.name: Production and Postharvest Physiology of Vegetable Crops
APBI417.desc: Morphology, growth and development, production, compostition, quality, and postharvest physiology of vegetable crops. [3-2-0]

APBI418.name: Intensive Fish Production
APBI418.desc: Management of fin fish throughout the life cycle; broodstock, egg, larvae, and juvenile. Control of environmental factors, including pathogens, for maximum productivity at all life stages. [3-2-0]
APBI418.prer: Third-year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 recommended.

APBI419.name: Fish Health
APBI419.desc: Management of fish health in aquaculture; common fish pathogens, epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of diseases.
APBI419.prer: Third year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 and  APBI 418 strongly recommended.

APBI427.name: Insect Ecology
APBI427.desc: Behavioural, population, and community ecology of insects. Interaction between insects and plants and the application of the principals of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds. [3-0]
APBI427.prer: Either (a) BIOL 205 or (b) all of BIOL 327, APBI 327.

APBI428.name: Integrated Pest Management
APBI428.desc: Development and implementation of multi-disciplinary pest management programs in agricultural crops. [3-2]

APBI442.name: Wine Grape and Berry Biology
APBI442.desc: Grapevine genetics, morphology, and physiology and major biological features of other important berry crops for British Columbia such as blueberry, cranberry, and raspberry. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 442 or PLNT 542.
APBI442.prer: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, APBI 210, BIOL 210.

APBI444.name: Agroforestry
APBI444.desc: An introduction to the application of knowledge and principles of agroecology and forest ecology to global agroforestry systems. The course includes a one-weekend field trip that requires a supplemental fee. [1-0-3]
APBI444.prer: An undergraduate course in ecology or equivalent.

APBI460.name: Advanced Agroecology
APBI460.desc: The relationship between biological diversity and sustainability for the management of agroecosystems; emphasise on ecological interactions between natural ecosystems and agroecosystems, including connections between agroecology and conservation biology. A fee will be assessed each student to cover field trip costs. [1-0-3]

APBI461.name: Applied Agroecology
APBI461.desc: Analysis and solution of problems in agricultural production systems through the integration and application of agroecological knowledge and principles. [1-0-3]

APBI465.name: Capstone in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
APBI465.desc: Integrates classroom and applied learning at the UBC Farm with design project. [1-3-0]

APBI490.name: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology
APBI490.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

APBI495.name: Principles of Wildlife Management in Forests and Agricultural Environments
APBI495.desc: Impacts of wildlife on crop productivity in temperate and tropical environments, the resiliency of wildlife populations to conventional control methodology, adoption of innovative methods to reduce crop damage, and the impact of introduced species on native fauna. [2-0-1]

APBI496.name: Applied Animal Biology Practicum
APBI496.desc: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
APBI496.prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.

APBI498.name: Undergraduate Essay
APBI498.desc: Preparation of a comprehensive and analytical review of an approved topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Consultation with a program adviser is required.

APBI499.name: Undergraduate Thesis
APBI499.desc: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to the preparation of a thesis.
APBI499.prer: Approval of a program adviser; consult before the end of classes in third year.

MEDG419.name: Developmental Origin of Human Disorders
MEDG419.desc: Genetic and epigenetic determinants of development from conception to birth. Topics include development of the neural tube, face, heart, endoderm, blastocyst, embryonic stem cells, gastrulation, genomic imprinting, placental complications, chromosomal abnormalities and prenatal diagnosis. Discussions based on published research articles. [3-0-1]
MEDG419.prer: One of BIOL 234, BIOL 334 and one of BIOL 331, BIOL 335. A standing of 'B' or higher recommended.

MEDG420.name: Human Genomics and Medical Genetics
MEDG420.desc: Sequence and structure of the human genome. Human genetic evolution. Identification of genes affecting normal and pathological variation.  Molecular mechanisms of genetic diseases and disorders. Medical applications of human genetics. [3-0-0]
MEDG420.prer: BIOL 335. A standing of 'B' or higher is recommended.

MEDG421.name: Genetics and Cell Biology of Cancer
MEDG421.desc: Molecular mechanisms of oncogenes and tumor suppressors and the effects of oncogenic mutations on the biology of cancer cells. [3-0-0]
MEDG421.prer: BIOL 335 and one of BIOC 300, BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOL 350.

MEDG448.name: Directed Studies
MEDG448.desc: A supervised individual program of study of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of faculty and the student. Permission of the appropriate supervisor and the department head is required.

OBMS431.name: Endodontics
OBMS431.desc: Application of the basic principles of endodontics. [0-1.5-0; 1-1.5-0]

OBMS434.name: Introduction to Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery

OBMS436.name: Oral Radiology
OBMS436.desc: Radiographic techniques and radiological interpretation with emphasis on extraoral techniques. [0.5-1.5]

OBMS439.name: Oral Medicine and Oral Diagnosis
OBMS439.desc: Oral diagnosis, including orofacial pain and temporomandibular disorders. [1-3-0; 1-3-0]

OBMS443.name: Oral Medicine, Oral Diagnosis and Therapeutics
OBMS443.desc: Assessment and treatment of advanced periodontal diseases. [1-2-2]

OBMS446.name: Advanced Oral Radiology and Oral Radiography

OBMS448.name: Directed Research in Oral Biology
OBMS448.desc: An elective laboratory project taken with the permission of the appropriate supervisor and the department head.

OBMS449.name: Advanced Periodontics
OBMS449.desc: Assessment and treatment of advanced periodontal diseases. [1-3-0]

MDVL210.name: Introduction to Medieval Studies
MDVL210.desc: A survey of the study of the medieval period in Western Europe (400-1550), integrating history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies Advisor.

MDVL301.name: European Literature from the 5th to the 14th Century
MDVL301.desc: Selected works from the 5th to the 14th centuries in their cultural and social contexts.
MDVL301.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Arts.

MDVL302.name: European Literature from the 14th to the 16th Century
MDVL302.desc: Selected works of the Late Middle Ages and Renaissance in their cultural and social contexts.
MDVL302.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Arts.

MDVL310.name: Topics in Medieval Studies
MDVL310.desc: Interdisciplinary approaches to selected topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor.

MDVL490.name: Research Seminar in Medieval Studies
MDVL490.desc: An intensive research seminar in a specific period, area, or issue integrating topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor.

INDE440.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE440.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE441.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE441.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE442.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE442.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE443.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE443.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE450.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE450.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE451.name: Clinical Skills IV
INDE451.desc: Final examination for third year encompassing all clinical subjects.

INDE453.name: Preparation for Medical Practice
INDE453.desc: Diagnostics; therapeutics; information management; evidence-based practice; professionalism and ethics; cultural competence; advanced communication skills; patient safety; health and wellness; and the health care team.

INDE455.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE455.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

ENGL009.name: Preparation for University Writing
ENGL009.desc: Practice-based course in communication skills. Develops university-level skills in composition, critical analysis, grammar, and documentation.  Can be taken to fulfill the prerequisite for UBC Okanagan first-year ENGL courses. Cannot be taken after successful completion of any first-year ENGL course.  Cannot be counted for credit toward the B.A., B.A.Sc., B.Ed., B.F.A., B.H.K., B.Mgt., B.M.S., B.Sc., or B.S.N. degrees. Pass/ Fail. [3-1-0]

ENGL100.name: Reading and Writing about Literature
ENGL100.desc: A writing-intensive introduction to the disciplines of literary studies through the exploration of texts in their critical and theoretical contexts. Fulfils the first-year component of the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement. Open only to students in the Faculty of Arts. Recommended for students intending to become English majors. Essays are required.

ENGL110.name: Approaches to Literature
ENGL110.desc: Study of selected examples of poetry, fiction, and drama. Essays are required.

ENGL111.name: Approaches to Non-fictional Prose
ENGL111.desc: Study of a selection of prose texts ranging in length from the essay to the book, with emphasis on writing of the twentieth century. Essays are required.

ENGL112.name: Strategies for University Writing
ENGL112.desc: Study and practice of the principles of university-level discourse, with multidisciplinary readings and emphasis on processes of research-based writing.  Essays are required.

ENGL120.name: Literature and Criticism
ENGL120.desc: Enriched study of selected works of literature from a number of critical perspectives. Open to students with a BC-equivalent mark of "A" in English 12 or "B+" in English Literature 12. Essays are required.

ENGL121.name: Introduction to Literary Theory
ENGL121.desc: Enriched study of various theories of literature. Open to students with a BC-equivalent mark of A in English 12 or B+ in English Literature 12. Essays are required.

ENGL140.name: Challenging Language Myths
ENGL140.desc: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note: This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts.

ENGL210.name: An Introduction to English Honours
ENGL210.desc: For Honours students accepted by the English Honours Committee on the recommendation of the instructor. Students permitted to take this course must take ENGL 211 concurrently.
ENGL210.prer: Restricted to students in the Honours program.

ENGL211.name: Seminar for English Honours
ENGL211.desc: An introduction to practical criticism; required of and open only to students of ENGL 210. A limited number of texts from a range of genres and periods will be chosen for close critical analysis.

ENGL220.name: Literature in English to the 18th Century
ENGL220.desc: A survey of prose, poetry and drama to the 18th Century.
ENGL220.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL221.name: Literature in Britain: the 18th Century to the Present
ENGL221.desc: A survey of poetry, drama, fiction and non-fiction prose from the 18th century to the present.
ENGL221.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL222.name: Literature in Canada
ENGL222.desc: The major types of Canadian writing: fiction, poetry, non-fictional prose, and drama
ENGL222.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL223.name: Literature in the United States
ENGL223.desc: The major types of American writing: fiction, poetry, drama and non-fictional prose.
ENGL223.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL224.name: World Literature in English
ENGL224.desc: English literature produced outside Britain and North America.
ENGL224.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL225.name: Poetry
ENGL225.desc: Principles, methods, and resources for reading poetry.
ENGL225.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL226.name: Drama
ENGL226.desc: Principles, methods and resources for reading drama.
ENGL226.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL227.name: Prose Fiction
ENGL227.desc: Principles, methods and resources for reading the novel and the short story.
ENGL227.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL228.name: Topics in Literary and/or Cultural Studies
ENGL228.desc: Current research interests in English studies.
ENGL228.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL229.name: Topics in the Study of Language and/or Rhetoric
ENGL229.desc: For an up to date listing of available topics, please see the English Department (http://english.ubc.ca/undergraduate/undergraduate-courses/2016-winter-session/ ).
ENGL229.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL230.name: Biblical and Classical Backgrounds of English Literature
ENGL230.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL231.name: Introduction to Indigenous Literatures
ENGL231.desc: A study of cultural expression in contemporary indigenous contexts.
ENGL231.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL232.name: Approaches to Media Studies
ENGL232.desc: Approaches to the study of media: philosophical; technological; cultural; theoretical.
ENGL232.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL301.name: Technical Writing
ENGL301.desc: Study of the principles of written communication in general business and professional activities, and practice in the preparation of abstracts, proposals, reports, and correspondence. This course is closed to first- and second-year students in Arts.  Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor.
ENGL301.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL302.name: Advanced Practical Writing
ENGL302.desc: Library research in the student's professional field; the writing of articles and research papers; detailed preparation of term or graduating essays required in a number of departments and faculties. Attention will be given to appropriate style. Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor.
ENGL302.prer: ENGL 301. Permission of the course chair is also acceptable.

ENGL303.name: Intermediate Composition
ENGL303.desc: Study of the principles and extensive practice in the writing of effective prose, from arrangement and punctuation to various stylistic strategies. May be taken in the second year. Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor.
ENGL303.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL304.name: Advanced Composition
ENGL304.desc: Special emphasis on rhetoric, with a focus on audience, authorial voice, and range of style.
ENGL304.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL307.name: Studies in Rhetoric
ENGL307.desc: Topics in rhetorical theories and their application.

ENGL308.name: Rhetorical Criticism
ENGL308.desc: A study of literary texts from a rhetorical perspective.

ENGL309.name: Rhetoric of Science, Technology, and Medicine
ENGL309.desc: Exploration of the persuasive dimension of discourse practices in science, technology, and medicine.

ENGL310.name: History and Theory of Rhetoric: Classical Rhetoric
ENGL310.desc: Introduction to classical rhetoric with attention to the analysis of present-day texts.

ENGL311.name: History and Theory of Rhetoric: The Later Theory
ENGL311.desc: Rhetorical theory from Augustine to the 21st century, emphasizing questions of persuasion in everyday life.

ENGL312.name: Discourse and Society
ENGL312.desc: Introduction to theories of language and culture, and to techniques for analysing discourses in their social contexts.

ENGL318.name: History of the English Language: Early History
ENGL318.desc: Principles of language change and language typology. The development of the English language from its Indo-European origins to the end of the Anglo-Saxon period.

ENGL319.name: History of the English Language: Later History
ENGL319.desc: Principles of language change. The development and spread of the English language from the Norman Conquest to the Modern English period.
ENGL319.prer: Third-year standing. Knowledge of the International Phonetic Alphabet. ENGL 318 or ENGL 330 or the equivalent is recommended.

ENGL321.name: English Grammar and Usage
ENGL321.desc: Descriptive approaches to the English Language

ENGL322.name: Stylistics
ENGL322.desc: Application of linguistic theory and method to stylistic analysis.

ENGL323.name: Varieties of English
ENGL323.desc: Study of geographical, social, and/or urban dialects of English.

ENGL326.name: Studies in the English Language
ENGL326.desc: Topics in the history or structure of the English language.

ENGL328.name: Metaphor, Language and Thought
ENGL328.desc: Exploration of the concepts underlying figurative language (in vocabulary as well as in grammar), using data from both colloquial and literary language.

ENGL330.name: The Structure of Modern English: Sounds and Words
ENGL330.desc: An introduction to phonology, morphology, and lexical semantics.

ENGL331.name: The Structure of Modern English: Sentences and Their Uses
ENGL331.desc: An introduction to syntax, pragmatics, and sentence semantics.

ENGL332.name: Approaches to Media History
ENGL332.desc: History of media and technological change; literary, rhetorical, or linguistic methods of inquiry.
ENGL332.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL340.name: Introduction to Old English
ENGL340.desc: Old English grammar, with readings in the prose of the period.

ENGL343.name: Old English Literature
ENGL343.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL344.desc: Please see the Department website for further information on topics offered in the current session.

ENGL346.name: Chaucer and the Middle Ages
ENGL346.desc: A detailed study of Chaucer's major works.
ENGL346.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). ENGL489.name: Language Majors Seminar
ENGL489.desc: Required of all Language Majors.  See department website (http://www.english.ubc.ca/ugrad/majors/compl_lang.htm) for options.

ENGL490.name: Literature Majors Seminar
ENGL490.desc: Required of all Literature Majors. See Department Website (www.english.ubc.ca) for options.

SOWK200.name: Introduction to Social Welfare
SOWK200.desc: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.

SOWK201.name: Introduction to Social Work Practice
SOWK201.desc: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems.

SOWK305.name: Social Work Practice I
SOWK305.desc: An examination of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program.

SOWK310.name: Interviewing Skills
SOWK310.desc: Communication theory and interviewing skills and their application to the Social Work interview.

SOWK315.name: Practicum I
SOWK315.desc: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

SOWK316.name: Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
SOWK316.desc: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.

SOWK320.name: Introduction to Social Work Research
SOWK320.desc: Introduction to theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. The focus is on development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school.

SOWK335.name: Social Analysis for Social Work Practice
SOWK335.desc: Theoretical considerations of relevance to social work practice.

SOWK337.name: Culture and Race in Social Work Practice
SOWK337.desc: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.

SOWK400.name: Canadian Social Policy
SOWK400.desc: Analysis of race, gender, class and culture as factors in the distribution and delivery of Canadian social benefits and social services.

SOWK405.name: Social Work Practice II
SOWK405.desc: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.

SOWK415.name: Practicum II
SOWK415.desc: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

SOWK416.name: Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
SOWK416.desc: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.

SOWK425.name: First Nations Social Issues
SOWK425.desc: Contemporary social issues facing First Nations peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Euro-Canadian/First Nations relations; the impact of Euro-Canadian institutions upon First Nations peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice.

SOWK430.name: Special Studies in Social Work
SOWK430.desc: Lectures, seminars and/or individual tutorials to develop knowledge and skills in relation to a defined theory, policy or practice problem or client population. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the School.

SOWK440.name: Integrative Seminars in Social Work
SOWK440.desc: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

SOWK441.name: Social Context of Child Development
SOWK441.desc: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes.

SOWK442.name: Policy and Practice in Child Welfare
SOWK442.desc: Covers the statutory bases and practices associated with the continuum of child welfare services from prevention through permanency planning.
SOWK442.prer: SOWK 441 or another course in child development.

SOWK450.name: Social Work Practice in Community Mental Health
SOWK450.desc: Online course providing overview of social work services to persons with a mental illness.

SOWK451.name: Health Care Team Development
SOWK451.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400.

SOWK452.name: HIV Prevention and Care
SOWK452.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares senior students to respond effectively to the HIV epidemic and its consequences. The knowledge and skills required for interprofessional and discipline-specific work are explored. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Offered as IHHS 402 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 452 or IHHS 402.

SOWK453.name: Disability and Justice
SOWK453.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.

SOWK454.name: Interdisciplinary Practice with Children and Families
SOWK454.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers interprofessional perspectives, challenges, and strategies. Clinical experience and some knowledge of child protection issues required. Offered as IHHS 403 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 454 or IHHS 403.

SOWK455.name: Palliative Care
SOWK455.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers attitudes, knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary for interprofessional and discipline-specific work in palliative care. For students registered in health and human service programs only. Offered as IHHS 405 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 455 or IHHS 405.

SOWK456.name: Special Topics in Collaborative Healthcare
SOWK456.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares students to practice patient-centred interprofessional collaboration in a specific area of healthcare. Offered as IHHS 480 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 456 or IHHS 480.

PHYS100.name: Introductory Physics
PHYS100.desc: An introduction to fundamental concepts such as force, energy, momentum, and the use of graphs and vectors in physics; geometrical optics; electricity; laboratory exercises to familiarize the student with both the phenomena and the basic laboratory instruments commonly used to measure them. Students with credit for Physics 12 may not obtain credit for this course unless they took AP, IB, or A-level Physics and were offered advanced credit for PHYS 100. [3-3*-1*]
PHYS100.prer: Not open to students with credit for PHYS 12. Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students, strongly recommended for others.

PHYS157.name: Introductory Physics for Engineers I
PHYS157.desc: Heat, thermodynamics, oscillations, waves, and sound. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS157.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS159.name: Introductory Physics Laboratory for Engineers
PHYS159.desc: A laboratory course with emphasis on experimental design, measurement and analysis techniques. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [0-3-0]

PHYS170.name: Mechanics I
PHYS170.desc: Statics of particles, equilibrium or rigid bodies, rigid body statics and internal forces, trusses; kinematics: rectilinear motion; dynamics:  Newton's second law, friction, impulse, momentum, work and energy.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS170.prer: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
PHYS170.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS210.name: Introduction to Computational Physics
PHYS210.desc: Introduction to UNIX/Linux; software tools for processing, fitting and displaying data; numerical methods and application in the physical sciences. [2-3-0]
PHYS210.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

PHYS216.name: Intermediate Mechanics
PHYS216.desc: Review of kinematics, Newton's laws, angular momentum and fixed axis rotation. Rigid body motion, central forces, non-inertial frames of reference. Introduction to Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics. [3-0-1]
PHYS216.prer: One of PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 170, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
PHYS216.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

PHYS298.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
PHYS298.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS299.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
PHYS299.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS305.name: Introduction to Biophysics
PHYS305.desc: Physical principles involved in biological systems at the microscopic and molecular scales. Diffusion, low Reynolds number dynamics, the physicist's view of biomolecular structure, models of molecular motors and membranes. [3-0-0]
PHYS305.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and either (a) PHYS 203 or (b) one of ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302.

PHYS306.name: Advanced Mechanics
PHYS306.desc: Variational calculus, Lagrangian dynamics, rigid body motion including free and forced precession, Hamiltonian mechanics, Poisson brackets, canonical coordinates, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, action angle variables. Introduction to dynamical chaos: determinism, Lyapunov exponents. [3-0-1]
PHYS306.prer: One of PHYS 216, ENPH 270 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

PHYS309.name: Electrical Laboratory
PHYS309.desc: Selected experiments in electromagnetism and electronics; computer data acquisition; advanced data analysis and simulation. [1-4-0]

PHYS314.name: Fluids
PHYS314.desc: Kinetic theory: Diffusion, viscosity and sound waves. Introduction to hydrodynamics: Laminar flow, capillary and gravity waves, convection and turbulence. Dimensional analysis. [3-0-0]

PHYS315.name: Physics of Materials
PHYS315.desc: Crystal structure, elasticity and phonons, elementary electronic transport, defects, alloys, liquid crystals and polymers. [3-0-0]
PHYS315.prer: One of PHYS 203, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of PHYS 200, PHYS 250, CHEM 312.

PHYS318.name: Experimental Acoustics
PHYS318.desc: Experimental techniques of acoustics: data acquisition hardware and software, microphones, loudspeakers, noise, vibration and modal analysis. [2-3-0]

PHYS319.name: Electronics Laboratory
PHYS319.desc: A project-oriented lab introducing the design and construction of microprocessor-controlled devices. [1-4-0]

PHYS330.name: Modern Physics
PHYS330.desc: Quantum physics, nuclear energy and particle physics at a level suitable for third- and fourth-year Science students not proceeding to a physics degree. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. in Astronomy, Biophysics or Physics. [3-0-0]
PHYS330.prer: Either (a) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS333.name: Energy and Climate
PHYS333.desc: The fundamental physics behind global issues of energy use and climate change.  Not to be used to satisfy an upper-level specialization requirement in any Physics & Astronomy major or honours specialization, but may be used as an upper-level science elective. [3-0-0]
PHYS333.prer: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS340.name: From Atoms to the Universe
PHYS340.desc: Ancient Greek ideas of substance and forms and modern concepts of forces and fields. The twentieth-century quantum revolution. The modern universe, from quarks and atoms to the big bang. Quantum paradoxes. Not for credit in the faculties of Science and Applied Science. No mathematics required. [3-0-0]

PHYS341.name: Physics of Music
PHYS341.desc: An introduction to the physical principles important to the production, transmission and perception of musical sounds. The treatment will be non-mathematical; with emphasis on demonstrations. Topics may include the description of sound waves, resonances, scales, physics of hearing, examination of specific musical instruments, etc. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [3-0-0]

PHYS343.name: Physical Science by Inquiry
PHYS343.desc: A guided sequence of hands-on science modules intended primarily for prospective elementary schoolteachers, to help them to work constructively in a science teaching role. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [0-6-0]

PHYS349.name: Directed Research Project in Physics
PHYS349.desc: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report. This course requires  approval of the course instructor  and  program  advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. [1*-6-0]

PHYS350.name: Applications of Classical Mechanics
PHYS350.desc: Review of principles. Particle mechanics: Euler's equations, tops and gyroscopes, motion of the Earth, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian methods. Variational principles in optics and mechanics, Liouville's theorem and statistical mechanics. The relationship between classical and quantum mechanics. [3-0-0]

PHYS399.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
PHYS399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS400.name: Introduction to Elementary Particles
PHYS400.desc: Standard model, classification of elementary particles and forces of nature, symmetries, conservation laws, quark model, quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, and the theory of weak interactions. [3-0-0]

PHYS402.name: Applications of Quantum Mechanics
PHYS402.desc: Spin and angular momentum addition, perturbation methods, and applications in the fields of Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, and Solid State Physics. [3-0-0]

PHYS404.name: Introduction to Medical Physics
PHYS404.desc: Radiotherapy, X-ray imaging, nuclear medicine, magnetic resonance imaging and biomedical optics. [3-0-0]
PHYS404.prer: Third yearstanding in Science or Applied Science is required. MATH 200 (or MATH 217 or MATH 226 or MATH 267) is recommended.

PHYS407.name: Introduction to General Relativity
PHYS407.desc: Physical consequences of Einstein's equations, including the principle of equivalence, curved space-time, geodesics, the Schwarzschild solution, deflection of light, black holes, and gravitational radiation. [3-0-0]
PHYS407.prer: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255. PHYS 301 and one of PHYS 206, PHYS 306 are recommended.

PHYS409.name: Experimental Physics
PHYS409.desc: A laboratory course with a wide choice of experiments for fourth year Honours and Major students. Topics include solid state, nuclear, classical, quantum, electromagnetic and low temperature physics. For six credits, two weekly laboratory periods and completion of a project in second term are required. [0-3-0]

PHYS410.name: Computational Physics
PHYS410.desc: Scientific programming applied to problems in physics. Fundamentals of numerical analysis for continuum problems. Solution of linear and non-linear algebraic systems, ordinary differential equations and stochastic problems. [3-0-1]
PHYS410.prer: One of PHYS 312, MATH 257, MATH 316 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 110, CPSC 111, APSC 160.

PHYS412.name: Quantum Physics
PHYS412.desc: Fundamentals of atomic, nuclear, particle, and condensed matter physics. [3-0-0]
PHYS412.prer: MATH 215 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 200.

PHYS420.name: Physics Demonstrations
PHYS420.desc: The students will prepare, under the supervision of a faculty member, a demonstration or series of demonstrations intended to illustrate physical principles to diverse audiences. Intended for third- or fourth-year Physics Majors and Math/Science Education students.

PHYS437.name: Physics of Biocellular Structure and Machinery
PHYS437.desc: Molecular structure and architecture of biological cells, interactions of molecules in aqueous solution and at interfaces, physical properties of polymers and surfactants, mechanisms of cell membranes and cytoplasmic structures, thermodynamics of molecular machines and mechanical enzymes. Credit can not be given for both PHYS 437 and 537. [3-0-0]
PHYS437.prer: One of PHYS 313, PHYS 403, PHYS 455, CHEM 304.

PHYS447.name: Advanced Topics in Physics
PHYS447.desc: Directed studies available to students in Honours Physics with approval from the Head of the Department.

PHYS449.name: Honours Thesis
PHYS449.desc: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis. [1*-6-0]

PHYS473.name: Applied Nuclear Physics
PHYS473.desc: Radioactive decay and radiations, nuclear properties, interactions of neutrons, physical principles of power reactors, nuclear fusion, radiation monitoring, and safety. [3-0-1*]

PHYS474.name: Applied Solid State Physics
PHYS474.desc: Symmetry of crystal structures, reciprocal lattice, band theory, conduction in metals and semiconductors, phonons and superconductivity. [3-0-0]

PHYS490.name: Student Directed Seminar
PHYS490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars".  Cannot be used as a specialization requirement in any PHYS and/or ASTR specialization.
