PHYS498.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
PHYS498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS499.name: Co-operative Work Placement V
PHYS499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

LING100.name: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
LING100.desc: Study of language as a universal and uniquely human cognitive system: What universals do all languages share and how do languages differ? An investigation of sound systems, word-building, grammatical principles, language change, dialect variation, language acquisition, neurolinguistics. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.

LING101.name: Languages of the World
LING101.desc: A survey of the linguistic map of the world, examining how languages are genetically classified and how different languages evolve. Principles underlying different writing systems and the decipherment of historical documents. Issues of languages in contact, minority language endangerment, language death and the role of English as a world language. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.

LING140.name: Challenging Language Myths
LING140.desc: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note. This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts.

LING170.name: Introduction to How to Learn a Language
LING170.desc: Skills and strategies for second language acquisition, through the foundations of pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and pragmatics, connected to the practical, social, and personal challenges of language learning.

LING200.name: Linguistic Theory and Analysis I
LING200.desc: Introduction to phonetics and phonology; training in the identification and production of speech sounds; principles and methods for describing and writing the sound system of a language; phonological theory with reference to selected languages; the interface between phonology and morphology. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

LING201.name: Linguistic Theory and Analysis II
LING201.desc: Introduction to grammatical analysis; morphology, syntax, semantics; synchronic analysis and description with illustrations from various languages. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

LING209.name: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
LING209.desc: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences, with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.

LING222.name: Language Acquisition
LING222.desc: Audition and speech perception, phonological organization, word learning, syntax, and pragmatics.

LING270.name: Introduction to Studies in Second Language Acquisition
LING270.desc: Linguistic systems that learners of an additional language develop as they approximate towards the target language, and key questions about what this 'interlanguage' system reveals about how we learn languages.
LING270.prer: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170.

LING300.name: Studies in Grammar
LING300.desc: Introduction to syntactic analysis and theory, with emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.

LING311.name: Studies in Phonology
LING311.desc: Introduction to phonological analysis and theory, with a strong emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.

LING313.name: Introduction to Linguistic Phonetics and Speech Science
LING313.desc: The articulatory and acoustic properties of speech production and perception, including practice in phonetic transcription, instrumental recording, and the analysis of normal speech.
LING313.prer: LING 200. Recommended: All of LING 100,  PSYC 100 (or PSYC 101 and 102), PSYC 217 and 218, PHYS 341.

LING314.name: Instrumental Phonetics
LING314.desc: Physiological and/or acoustic phonetics. Focus on experimental methods and analysis techniques. Topics may include: source-filter theory; spectral and temporal acoustic analysis, inter-articulator timing and motor coordination.
LING314.prer: LING 313. Recommended: All of LING 100, PSYC 100 (or PSYC 101 and 102), PSYC 217 and 218, PHYS 341.

LING319.name: Comparative and Historical Linguistics
LING319.desc: The historical study of language.  Linguistic change.  Language families and evidence for genetic relationship.  Comparative method and internal reconstruction.  Emphasis on phonological and morphological reconstruction. Not offered every year.

LING327.name: Introduction to Semantics
LING327.desc: The analysis and theory of linguistic meaning with emphasis on formal techniques for semantic analysis and their application to empirical phenomena in language, including pragmatics.

LING333.name: Research Methods for Linguistics
LING333.desc: Research methods used in linguistics and speech science. Emphasis on scientific reasoning, critical thinking, experimental design, and the ethics and methods of linguistic data-collection.

LING345.name: Pragmatics
LING345.desc: Selected topics in pragmatics and information structure, including variations in their cross-linguistic expression and the corresponding influence of sentence form on context.

LING405.name: Morphology
LING405.desc: Analytic and theoretical consideration of the interrelation of word formation, sound patterning, and meaningful sentence structure. Not offered every year.
LING405.prer: All of LING 300, LING 311. Recommended: LING 327

LING420.name: Introduction to Linguistics
LING420.desc: General background to linguistic studies; the different approaches to the analysis of languages; synchronic and diachronic linguistics; phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours program in Linguistics.

LING430.name: Honours Seminar in Linguistics
LING430.desc: Research papers on general linguistic topics to be read and discussed.

LING431.name: Field Methods I
LING431.desc: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied. Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment.

LING432.name: Field Methods II
LING432.desc: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied.  Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment.

LING433.name: Native Languages of the Americas
LING433.desc: Survey of the indigenous languages of the Americas. Study of the basis of genetic classification and areal similarities. The structure of representative languages will be presented and contrasted. The present status of American Indian languages will be considered. Note: this course is not necessarily offered every year.

LING436.name: Community-based Language Research
LING436.desc: Research methods and partnerships, ethical paradigms, the social, cultural and historical context of language research, and the relation of language research to pedagogy, policy and planning.

LING445.name: Sociolinguistics
LING445.desc: The systematic study of language as a social phenomenon.

LING447.name: Topics in Linguistics
LING447.desc: A capstone course for Linguistics and Speech Sciences majors, normally taken after three years of study.  Individual sections will differ substantially; see online Course List for detailed descriptions and prerequisites. May be repeated for credit when content is different.

LING448.name: Directed Studies
LING448.desc: Supervisor and topic chosen by mutual agreement between student and Linguistics faculty member. Department Advisor approval is required.

LING451.name: Acquisition of Phonology
LING451.desc: Development of the phonological system in typical first language acquisition from the perspective of diverse linguistic topics. Phonetic transcription of child speech.

LING452.name: Acquisition of Syntax
LING452.desc: Central issues in the first language acquisition of syntax, including early lexical and semantic development, acquisition of morphology, and syntactic development (e.g., word order, questions).

LING469.name: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
LING469.desc: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.

DES101.name: Introductory Workshop
DES101.desc: Week long orientation to the School community, the City and the study of design one week prior to the start of Winter Session Term 1. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 101 or DES 101.

DES110.name: Measured Architectural Drawing
DES110.desc: Techniques applicable to analytic and technical drawing used in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban design with focus primarily on analog drawing techniques. Open to all UBC students regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 110 or DES 110.

DES200.name: Design Thinking
DES200.desc: Design thinking through the analysis of architecture, landscape architecture and urban design and through hands-on design projects. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will granted for only one of ENDS 231 or DES 200.

DES201.name: Design Studio I - Context and Site
DES201.desc: Design within the context of various analytical lenses including ecological, climatic, social, political, cultural and historical influences.

DES202.name: Design Studio II - Form
DES202.desc: Essential processes and methods for thinking in three-dimensional spatial terms.
DES202.prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  201.

DES211.name: Design Media I
DES211.desc: Techniques in architectural drawing, two-dimensional representation, three-dimensional representation and general visual literacy. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 320, ARCH 515 or DES 211.

DES212.name: Design Media II
DES212.desc: Advanced techniques in architectural representation and discourse in digital representation and digital making. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 437, ARCH 517 or DES 212.

DES220.name: Architecture in Context: Vancouver and its Region
DES220.desc: The unfolding architecture and urbanism of Metro Vancouver. Using Vancouver as a laboratory to examine the historical transformation of the built environment, and how this has affected particular activities, land uses, and social groups within the region. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 220 or DES 220.

DES230.name: Sustainability by Design
DES230.desc: Interactions between human and natural urban systems using local and international examples of successful sustainable community designs. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 221 or DES 230.

DES231.name: Site Analysis and Planning
DES231.desc: Analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Credit will be given for only one of DES 231, LARC 440, or LARC 540.

DES232.name: Material Culture
DES232.desc: An investigation of building materials and associated design objectives, environmental conditions, historical context, regulatory controls, and economic constraints. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 232 or ARCH 411.

DES301.name: Design Studio III - Building Scale Synthesis
DES301.desc: Design at the architectural scale through the medium of program and site.
DES301.prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  202.

DES302.name: Design Studio IV - Vancouver
DES302.desc: Vancouver as a laboratory for design at the architectural and urban scale with a focused view into how design is implicated in the social, political, and environmental transformation of the city.
DES302.prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  301.

DES321.name: Architectural History I
DES321.desc: A global history of architecture pre-20th century. Credit will be granted for only one of  DES 321, ARCH 404 or ARCH 505.

DES322.name: Architectural History II
DES322.desc: A global history of architecture, 20th and 21st century. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 322, ARCH 405, or ARCH 505.

DES323.name: Histories in Landscape Architecture
DES323.desc: Landscapes from medieval times to the present studied synchronically across design elements as well as chronologically with the development of several key historical concepts.

DES330.name: Structural Systems and Supports
DES330.desc: Basic structural systems in the built world including wood, steel, concrete, composite systems and essential structural logics of soil retention systems and drainage.

DES341.name: Co-operative Education I
DES341.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Experiential Report required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

DES350.name: Design Build
DES350.desc: Direct hands-on confrontation with the realities of design and construction, engaging in both conventional and unconventional building processes.

DES401.name: Design Studio V - Urban Systems Scale Synthesis
DES401.desc: Relationships between communities and environment, urban infrastructure and ecological systems.

DES402.name: Design Studio VI - Away
DES402.desc: A design project engaged with an international context and site. Emphasis placed on mapping, interpretation of the international context as well as methods of construction, notions of program, and policies, regulations and codes that relate to the site.
DES402.prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  401.

DES403.name: Senior Design Project
DES403.desc: Final design project in the Honours Option with an independently conceived methodology allowing a student the opportunity to pursue his/her own set of interests and concerns.
DES403.prer: A score of 80% or higher in DES  401.

DES421.name: Design Theory
DES421.desc: Introduction to a broad range of theories in architecture and design as they relate to the built environment.

DES422.name: Urbanism by Design
DES422.desc: A history of the planning, landscape architecture and urban design of cities, and of how ideas have influenced the design of the city.

DES430.name: Environment, Urban Form, and Infrastructure
DES430.desc: Relationships between, and integration of, the natural environment and the physical form, spatial structure, and infrastructure of livability of cities.

DES442.name: Co-operative Education II
DES442.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Career Development Report required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

DES443.name: Co-operative Education III
DES443.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Oral Presentation required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

DES444.name: Co-operative Education IV
DES444.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Oral Presentation required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

DES445.name: Entrepreneurship and Ethics in Design
DES445.desc: Core business skills, building on students' design capabilities to pursue ethical and sustainable design-based business goals.

MUSC100.name: Principles of Musical Form
MUSC100.desc: Fundamental materials and processes of music - rhythmic, melodic, textural and harmonic - and how they create small-scale structures in a variety of styles. Compositional and analytical applications.

MUSC101.name: Diatonic Harmony and Voice Leading
MUSC101.desc: Harmonic and linear functions of diatonic chords; common progressions and sequences; introduction to tonal hierarchy and prolongation; simple modulation. Compositional and analytical exercises.

MUSC102.name: Class Strings
MUSC102.desc: Group instruction in music performance. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

MUSC103.name: Introduction to the Theory of Music
MUSC103.desc: Concepts of rhythm, pitch, timbre, and texture. Notation and aural recognition of rhythmic and pitch patterns. Basic principles of melody and form. This course is not applicable to the B.Mus.

MUSC104.name: Introduction to Diatonic Harmony
MUSC104.desc: Triads, key and elementary harmony in Western music. Elements of musical form. Aural training and exercises in composition, modeled on historical styles. Not for credit in the B.Mus.
MUSC104.prer: MUSC 103 or permission of the instructor.

MUSC105.name: Aural Skills I
MUSC105.desc: Sight singing; melodic and harmonic dictation; rhythm production; error detection; tuning; perception of harmony, form, and tonality; improvisation in set idioms. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

MUSC106.name: Aural Skills II
MUSC106.desc: Continuation of MUSC 105. Restricted to B.Mus. students.
MUSC106.prer: One of (a) a score of 68% or higher in MUSC 105, or (b) pass the MUSC 105 Challenge Test.  Students may register for MUSC 106 prior to meeting the pre-requisite but will be required to withdraw if the pre-requisite is not met by the first day of class.

MUSC108.name: Introduction to Contemporary Art Music
MUSC108.desc: Contemporary music repertoire, emphasizing music from the past fifty years. Required of undergraduate Composition majors; open to other Bachelor of Music students by permission of instructor.

MUSC110.name: Intensive Tonal Theory and Form I
MUSC110.desc: Continuity and form in tonal music, with attention to the development of aural imagery and writing skills. Foundational concepts are first applied cross-historically, then restricted to styles in which functional harmony emerges as a governing feature.  Limited to B.Mus. students with strong preparation (as determined by B.Mus. admissions procedures) and students in other programs with permission of the instructor.

MUSC111.name: Intensive Tonal Theory and Form II
MUSC111.desc: Two- and three-voice writing based on a four-part foundation; use of motivic diminution and imitation; dissonant chords; prolonging harmonies within phrases; modulating phrases and sequences; chromatic techniques; small binary and ternary forms, and formal functions of component phrases.

MUSC112.name: Class Brasses and Percussion
MUSC112.desc: Group instruction in music performance. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

MUSC119.name: Introduction to Music Technology
MUSC119.desc: Practical and theoretical training in technologies that support current artistic and academic practice, such as MIDI, podcasts/videocasts, websites, social media, and software for score notation, music education, and basic audio/video editing. [2-0-1]

MUSC120.name: History of Music I
MUSC120.desc: An overview of Western music from antiquity through the Middle Ages and Renaissance, providing a framework for understanding musical styles and practices, and examining selected compositions in greater analytical and historical depth.

MUSC121.name: History of Music II
MUSC121.desc: The development of Western music from circa 1600 to circa 1800.
MUSC121.prer: MUSC 120. Or permission of the instructor

MUSC122.name: Class Woodwinds
MUSC122.desc: Group instruction in music performance. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

MUSC128.name: Musical Rhythm and Human Experience
MUSC128.desc: A multidisciplinary survey of musical rhythm in selected world traditions and genres, connecting it to ideas of time, evolution, history, anthropology, philosophy, and contemporary globalised culture.

MUSC131.name: Class Voice
MUSC131.desc: Group instruction in music performance. Required of all first-time secondary voice students. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

MUSC135.name: Opera Repertoire I
MUSC135.desc: A musico-dramatic study and analysis of representative works in the international operatic theatre from 1600 to the present, through musical, literary and graphic sources. Each sequential year of study, the student is expected to show increased facility in musical and dramatic analysis as well as a greater understanding of the works under examination. Open to students outside the B.Mus. program by permission of the instructor.

MUSC136.name: Piano Repertoire I
MUSC136.desc: Performance and discussion of the repertoire for string-keyboard instruments essential to the performer and teacher. Special attention to matters of structure, style, and performance practices. Required of piano performance majors and open to piano concentrators, space permitting. First term prerequisite to second term.

MUSC141.name: Class Piano I
MUSC141.desc: Required of all first-time secondary piano students.

MUSC149.name: Collaborative Piano I
MUSC149.desc: Skills and performance practice with primary emphasis on voice/piano partnership principles and repertoire. Strong sight-reading skills essential. For Piano majors; open to others by audition.

MUSC150.name: Large Instrumental Ensemble
MUSC150.desc: Symphony Orchestra, Symphonic Wind Ensemble, or Concert Winds. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC151.name: University Chamber Orchestra
MUSC151.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC153.name: University Singers
MUSC153.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC154.name: University Choral Union
MUSC154.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC156.name: Vocal Chamber Ensembles
MUSC156.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC157.name: Early Music Ensemble
MUSC157.desc: Performance of early Western instrumental and vocal ensemble music. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC159.name: University Chamber Strings
MUSC159.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC160.name: String Chamber Ensembles
MUSC160.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC161.name: Piano Chamber Ensembles
MUSC161.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus.

MUSC162.name: Wind and Percussion Chamber Ensembles
MUSC162.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC163.name: Contemporary Players
MUSC163.desc: Performance of contemporary music. An ensemble of variable size, including both instrumentalists and singers, will be formed to present several concerts of 20th-century music during the academic year.  May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

MUSC164.name: Jazz Ensemble
MUSC164.desc: Performance techniques and repertoire. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

MUSC165.name: World Music Ensembles
MUSC165.desc: Training on traditional instruments and their techniques, with emphasis on ensemble performance. Different sections focus on the music of different cultures, e.g., Bali, China, Ghana, Korea. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music, or when permitted in other programs.

MUSC167.name: Introduction to Piano Chamber Music
MUSC167.desc: A survey of repertoire and performance issues.

MUSC169.name: Intensive Chamber Ensemble
MUSC169.desc: Intensive coaching in chamber ensemble for advanced players. Performance of works prepared is expected.
MUSC169.crer: Any small ensemble (MUSC 156-166) and permission of the instructor.

MUSC170.name: Lyric Diction
MUSC170.desc: A study of the basic phonetics and accepted principles of lyric diction of the four languages most commonly used in concert and operatic repertoire: French, German, Italian, and English.

MUSC200.name: Chromatic Harmony and Voice Leading
MUSC200.desc: Harmonic and linear functions of common chromatic chords; mixture; chords and progressions of linear origin; tonal plans. Compositional and analytical exercises.

MUSC201.name: Musical Forms
MUSC201.desc: Study of various forms in tonal music and the rhythmic, melodic, textural, and harmonic processes that create them on small and large scales. Compositional and analytical exercises.

MUSC205.name: Aural Skills III
MUSC205.desc: Continuation of MUSC 106. Restricted to B.Mus. students.
MUSC205.prer: One of (a) a score of 68% or higher in MUSC 106, or (b) pass the MUSC 106 Challenge Test.  Students may register for MUSC 205 prior to meeting the pre-requisite but will be required to withdraw if the pre-requisite is not met by the first day of class.

MUSC206.name: Aural Skills IV
MUSC206.desc: Continuation of MUSC 205. Restricted to B.Mus. students.
MUSC206.prer: One of (a) a score of 68% or higher in MUSC 205, or (b) pass the MUSC 205 Challenge Test.  Students may register for MUSC 206 prior to meeting the pre-requisite but will be required to withdraw if the pre-requisite is not met by the first day of class.

MUSC207.name: Composition II
MUSC207.prer: MUSC 107 and permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores.

MUSC210.name: Intensive Tonal Theory and Form III
MUSC210.desc: Writing exercises involving chromaticism and modulation. Theme and inter-theme types in Classical and Romantic music.  Techniques of variation and development.  Model-based composition of small forms and analysis of larger forms. Cultivation of score-reading ability.
MUSC210.prer: MUSC 111. Or MUSC 200 with permission of the instructor.

MUSC220.name: History of Music III
MUSC220.desc: The development of Western music from circa 1800 to circa 1900.
MUSC220.prer: MUSC 121 and one of MUSC 100, MUSC 110.

MUSC221.name: History of Music IV
MUSC221.desc: The development of Western music from circa 1900; an introduction to jazz and popular music and to music of selected non-Western societies.
MUSC221.prer: MUSC 220 and one of MUSC 100, MUSC 110.

MUSC249.name: Collaborative Piano II
MUSC249.desc: Further development of skills and performance practice with primary emphasis on voice/piano partnership principles and repertoire. Strong sight-reading skills essential. For Piano majors; open to others by audition.

MUSC300.name: Compositional and Analytical Approaches to Post-Tonal Music
MUSC300.desc: Concepts essential to understanding and performing art music, since 1900, in which functional triadic harmony is absent or subsidiary to other musical processes. Detailed consideration of works of major composers up to the present, through analysis, composition, and musicianship exercises.

MUSC301.name: Compositional and Analytical Approaches to Music Today
MUSC301.desc: Technical and stylistic perspectives on contemporary art music and popular and world music idioms. Exercises in composition and production. Training in related listening, sight-singing and score reading skills.

MUSC305.name: Readings in Orchestral Repertoire
MUSC305.desc: A laboratory course for orchestral performance majors. Emphasis on reading a large cross-section of standard orchestral repertoire with further emphasis given to music currently being programmed by local professional orchestras. The course is restricted to Orchestral Instruments majors, except by permission of the instructor.

MUSC307.name: Composition III
MUSC307.prer: MUSC 207 and permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores.

MUSC309.name: Instrumentation
MUSC309.desc: The study of string, woodwind, brass and percussion instruments; orchestral sections and scoring for various small ensembles. Activities include demonstrations of instruments, scoring projects, analysis and listening. For credit towards the B.Mus. and the B.A. in Music; not open to other students.
MUSC309.prer: One of MUSC 111, MUSC 200 and completion of the second-year piano requirement.

MUSC310.name: Orchestration
MUSC310.desc: The study of orchestration through the analysis of orchestral works, listening and scoring projects. Activities also include choral arranging and scoring for stage band and wind ensemble.

MUSC311.name: Fundamentals of Conducting
MUSC311.desc: Basic conducting techniques: patterns, cueing, dynamic shading, and physical presentation.
MUSC311.prer: One of MUSC 111, MUSC 200 and completion of the second-year piano requirement.

MUSC312.name: Instrumental Conducting
MUSC312.desc: The relation of conducting gestures to instrumental sound; development of practical skills in directing ensembles and reading scores, considering instruments' special characteristics.

MUSC313.name: Choral Conducting
MUSC313.desc: The relation of conducting gestures to choral sound; development of practical skills in directing ensembles and reading scores; attendant issues of vocal technique and pedagogy.

MUSC319.name: Introduction to Electroacoustic Music
MUSC319.desc: Study of acoustics, audio technology, and electroacoustic composition. Composition of original works using facilities of the UBC Electroacoustic Music Studio.
MUSC319.prer: MUSC 119 and one of MUSC 100, MUSC 110. Permission of instructor is also required.

MUSC320.name: Computer Music
MUSC320.desc: The study of computer applications to music, focusing on digital synthesis techniques and languages, methods of algorithmic composition, and the design of music editors.

MUSC321.name: Music Appreciation, Twentieth-Century
MUSC321.desc: Designed for students with little or no musical background. Not for credit toward the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

MUSC322.name: Topics in Western Music
MUSC322.desc: Study in one major genre of Western music (e.g., "The Symphony", "Women in Opera", "History of the Song Cycle"). No musical knowledge is required. Not for credit toward the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

MUSC323.name: History of Popular Music
MUSC323.desc: Genres of popular music from 1950 to the present and their changing aesthetic, social, cultural, and historical dimensions. Prior experience with music notation and terminology is not required. This course is not acceptable for credit toward the B.Mus., or toward the B.A. major, honours, or minor in Music.

MUSC324.name: The Guitar in History and Practice
MUSC324.desc: Introduction to guitar performance and repertoire for non-majors. Lectures explore guitar repertoires from selected regions and eras. Not for credit toward the B.Mus. or the Major/Minor in Music (B.A., B.F.A., B.Sc.). Students are expected to provide their own guitars.

MUSC326.name: Music Appreciation
MUSC326.desc: An introductory course for which previous musical background is helpful, but not required. Contents include a discussion of musical concepts, evolution of forms, style, and media and detailed study of selected works from the concert repertoire. Popular forms of music (jazz, folk, rock, etc) not included. Not for credit towards the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

MUSC328.name: World Music Cultures
MUSC328.desc: Introduction to the principles of ethnomusicology and an examination of at least two contrasting musical traditions. May be repeated once for credit if different traditions are covered.

MUSC330.name: Music in Vancouver's Ethnic Communities
MUSC330.desc: Examination of music within the ethnic context as found in the urban environment of Vancouver. The musics of several traditions (e.g., Chinese, Jewish, English folk) will be studied together with the social issues surrounding their preservation. For credit toward the B.Mus. and the B.A. in Music, but open to students not majoring in music.

MUSC331.name: Workshop in World Rhythm
MUSC331.desc: Theory and practice of selected rhythmic systems of world music cultures, focusing on West African drumming, and including other systems such as Indian Tala and Peking opera percussion.

MUSC333.name: Accompanying on the Harpsichord I
MUSC333.desc: Basic techniques and styles of continuo playing. Open to keyboard players with no previous harpsichord experience.

MUSC336.name: Opera Theatre Techniques I
MUSC336.desc: Performance techniques associated with the musical theatre of various historical periods. Basic dance. Most operatic excerpts will be in English.

MUSC339.name: Opera Workshop I
MUSC339.desc: Participation in performances by the School. Open also to students outside Music without credit, after audition.

MUSC340.name: Piano Pedagogy I: Theory and Studio Management
MUSC340.desc: Basic principles of teaching piano. Business aspects of establishing and maintaining a music studio. For piano majors.

MUSC345.name: Aesthetics and Practice of Film Music

MUSC349.name: Keyboard Harmony and Transposition
MUSC349.desc: Designed for the keyboard performance major and keyboard concentrator in General Studies.

MUSC352.name: History of Medieval Music
MUSC352.desc: Sacred and secular music, vocal and instrumental.

MUSC353.name: History of Renaissance Music
MUSC353.desc: Sacred and secular music, vocal and instrumental.

MUSC358.name: History of Jazz
MUSC358.desc: Jazz styles and their cultural contexts; the relationship of performers and audiences; issues of race and gender; non-Western influences.

MUSC363.name: History and Repertoire of the Guitar and Related Instruments
MUSC363.desc: A chronological survey, from the Renaissance to the present day, of music for the guitar and related instruments and of the development of the instruments themselves. Instruments considered include Renaissance and Baroque lutes, the vihuela, and early types of guitar as well as the modern six-string guitar. Musical forms and genres, national schools and the works of principal composers of every period are explored and attention is given to national systems, continuo realization, historical ornamentation and pedagogical systems.

MUSC364.name: Chamber Music Repertoire
MUSC364.desc: Perspectives on the performance of selected chamber music.  Specific works vary from year to year.  May be repeated for credit.

MUSC365.name: Song Repertoire I
MUSC365.desc: An exploration of the solo art song repertoire from 1600 to the Romantic period. Repertoire essential to the performer and teacher will be studied through live and recorded performance with special attention given to poetic content and musical style.

MUSC402.name: Special Projects
MUSC402.desc: For fourth-year students who receive permission of the Director of the School of Music to do advanced studies in their major field.

MUSC403.name: Selected Topics in Music
MUSC403.desc: See School of Music schedule for description and prerequisites. Restricted to B. Mus. and B.A. in Music students.

MUSC406.name: Conducting II
MUSC406.desc: Advanced choral and orchestral conducting techniques and rehearsal practices.
MUSC406.prer: One of MUSC 311, MUSC 312. Permission of the instructor is required.

MUSC409.name: Jazz Theory and Arranging
MUSC409.desc: Jazz scales, chord relationships, substitutions, orchestration, listening, and score analysis. Restricted to B.Mus. and B.A. in Music students.

MUSC410.name: Introduction to Schenkerian Analysis
MUSC410.desc: The key concepts of Schenker's theory of tonality. Applications to the analysis of short pieces in various tonal styles, emphasizing clear and correct graphing. Issues of interpretive scope.

MUSC411.name: Analysis of Tonal Music
MUSC411.desc: Analytical approaches that complement Schenkerian analysis, including motivic construction, harmonic rhythm and phrase rhythm, chromaticism and enharmonicism, features of musical form, aspects of structure and hierarchy at the small and large scale.

MUSC412.name: Analytical Studies in the Development of Musical Modernism (1860 - 1940)
MUSC412.desc: Analysis of late- and post-romantic works within a theoretical framework that bridges earlier to later works. Assignments in various formats, emphasizing analysis but possibly including composition.

MUSC413.name: Contemporary Art Music: Theory and Analysis
MUSC413.desc: A technical approach to the diverse concert-music repertoire since 1950, including orchestral, chamber, solo, and electro-acoustic genres. Applicable theories of pitch and rhythm, with reference to composers' own writings.

MUSC414.name: Counterpoint
MUSC414.desc: Analysis and comosition of pieces that rely on the control and development of imitative, polyphonic textures. Models to be taken from one or more European historical repertoires.

MUSC415.name: Imagining Musical Performances
MUSC415.desc: How performance and analysis engage the musical imagination, as complementary activities; how analytical observations can stimulate performance, and vice versa. Selected topics, with special emphasis on temporal factors.

MUSC417.name: Musical Scoring for Film
MUSC417.desc: Addresses the practical aspects of composing music for film through assignments of written scores.
MUSC417.prer: MUSC 319. Permission of instructor is required.

MUSC419.name: Interactive Performance Systems
MUSC419.desc: Collaborative projects developing new connections between sound and gestures in live concert performance or responsive environments using multiple digital technologies. May be repeated once for credit.

MUSC420.name: Music Technology Capstone Project
MUSC420.desc: Supervised individual music technology project on an approved topic. Restricted to students in the Minor in Applied Music Technology
MUSC420.prer: MUSC 419. And permission of the Instructor.

MUSC428.name: Topics in World Music
MUSC428.desc: The history, theory, style, organology, and forms of the music of a particular culture in its aesthetic and cultural context. Students should consult the School as to which music culture will be covered in a particular year. May be repeated once for credit if different cultures are covered.

MUSC430.name: Major Composers
MUSC430.desc: The musical works of no more than two significant composers will be examined. Specific topics will be announced; may be repeated for credit.
MUSC430.prer: All of MUSC 120, MUSC 121, MUSC 220, MUSC 221.

MUSC433.name: Accompanying on the Harpsichord II
MUSC433.desc: Continuation of MUSC 333 with emphasis on more advanced continuo and obbligato techniques.

MUSC436.name: Opera Theatre Techniques II
MUSC436.desc: Advanced studies in acting, movement, gesture, dance and stage combat. Emphasis on communication and the art of singing and acting recitative in foreign languages.

MUSC440.name: Piano Pedagogy II: Applications
MUSC440.desc: Teaching musical concepts and keyboard skills; observation of group and private lessons; supervised practicum.

MUSC441.name: Vocal Techniques
MUSC441.desc: A study of the scientific principles related to vocal performance: acoustical, physiological and psychological. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

MUSC442.name: Song Interpretation
MUSC442.desc: Survey of the literature for voice with keyboard accompaniment, with emphasis on performance problems. Open to piano and voice majors, and to others by permission of instructor. May be repeated once for credit.

MUSC443.name: Opera Coaching
MUSC443.desc: Principles and practice, focusing on current Opera Workshop repertoire. Reproducing orchestrations on the piano; preparing scores; study of the voice and the rehearsal process; coaching languages; related conducting skills.

MUSC444.name: Establishing a Career in Music
MUSC444.desc: Best practices of the contemporary busines of music, focussing on understanding present market conditions, and on targeting specific opportunities through grant-writing, resumés, press kits, publicity, recordings, and marketing. Restricted to fourth-year B.Mus. students.

MUSC450.name: Selected Topics in Vocal or Instrumental Genres
MUSC450.desc: Intensive study of one genre of music (e.g., orchestral music 1760–1849; the Lied in Austria and Germany) through analysis and the consideration of cultural milieu and historical development. Specific topics will be announced. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 credits.

MUSC454.name: History of Opera I
MUSC454.desc: The development of opera between 1600 and 1800.

MUSC455.name: History of Opera II
MUSC455.desc: The development of opera between 1800 and the present.

MUSC465.name: Song Repertoire II
MUSC465.desc: A sequel to MUSC 365, exploring the solo art song repertoire from the Romantic era to the present.

MUSC469.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
MUSC469.desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

MGMT100.name: Introduction to Canadian Business
MGMT100.desc: Introduction to the Faculty of Management and functional areas of business including accounting, economics, finance, marketing, organizational behaviour, business policy, and entrepreneurship. Steps needed to build a successful local, national, and international competitive business. Ethical and policy decisions faced by business and government.

MGMT200.name: Personal and Corporate Social Responsibility
MGMT200.desc: Increase awareness of a wide range of ethical challenges, test the strengths of personal moral beliefs and ethical arguments, and utilize critical thinking skills in making ethical decisions appropriate for corporate social responsibility practices.

ADHE327.name: Teaching Adults
ADHE327.desc: Planning, conducting and evaluating instruction for adults.  Consideration is given to different beliefs and ways of thinking about teaching. [3-0-0]

ADHE328.name: Institutions of Adult Education
ADHE328.desc: The history, roles, and activities of institutions in the field of adult education.  Institutions in Canada, Great Britain, and the United States are emphasized, and some experiences in other countries are examined. [3-0-0]

ADHE329.name: Developing Short Courses, Workshops and Seminars
ADHE329.desc: Organization and administration of adult education events such as short courses, seminars, workshops, conferences and institutes. [3-0-0]

ADHE330.name: The Community Practice of Adult Education
ADHE330.desc: Community based adult education with particular emphasis on the application of knowledge of the social, economic, cultural and political environment in developing and conducting adult education programs with an for individuals and groups. [2-3-0]

ADHE412.name: An Overview of Adult Education
ADHE412.desc: Survey of adult education theory and practice in Canada and the world. The focus is on the purpose and participation in, adult education, characteristics of learners, and the training of adult educators. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

ASTU160.name: International Perspectives on Writing in the Social Sciences and Humanities
ASTU160.desc: Analysis of and practice in writing and reading for research in the social sciences and humanities; national and international aspects of scholarship and of writing cultures. Fulfills the first component of the Arts' Writing and Research Requirement.  Restricted to students in the Sciences Po - UBC Dual Degree.

ASTU260.name: Knowledge Dissemination: Communicating Research to Public Audiences
ASTU260.desc: Research, theory, and practice in the communication of expert knowledge to non-specialist audiences; popular media and dissemination. Restricted to students in the Sciences Po - UBC Dual Degree.

ASTU310.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
ASTU310.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Orientation workshops. Final work term report required. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.
ASTU310.prer: 6 credits first-year English or Arts I; 6 credits of science; 6 credits of literature; satisfaction of Faculty language requirement.

ASTU311.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
ASTU311.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report required.

ASTU360.name: Community-Based Research and Knowledge Creation
ASTU360.desc: Principles and practice of conducting research in community partnership.

ASTU410.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
ASTU410.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

ASTU411.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
ASTU411.desc: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

ASTU412.name: Co-operative Work Placement V
ASTU412.desc: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

AUDI402.name: Neuroanatomy for Audiology and Speech-Language Pathology
AUDI402.prer: As indicated on the website at www.audiospeech.ubc.ca or by permission of the instructor.

BIOC398.name: Internship Work Placement I
BIOC398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic laboratory for three or four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
BIOC398.prer: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major or honours program is required.

BIOC399.name: Internship Work Placement II
BIOC399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

BIOC498.name: Internship Work Placement III
BIOC498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

BIOC499.name: Internship Work Placement IV
BIOC499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

CAPS391.name: Introduction to Gross Human Anatomy
CAPS391.desc: Structure and function of body regions at the macroscopic level. [3-0-0]
CAPS391.prer: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001, KIN  190, KIN  191.

CAPS398.name: Cooperative Work Placement
CAPS398.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).
CAPS398.prer: Co-op Workshops, CAPS 301, CAPS 303 (or, PHYL 301, PHYL 303).

CAPS399.name: Cooperative Work Placement II
CAPS399.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for  a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

CAPS498.name: Cooperative Work Placement III
CAPS498.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

CAPS499.name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
CAPS499.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

CHEM235.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM235.desc: Techniques of organic chemistry. To be taken in conjunction with, or in the term following, CHEM 233. [0-3-0]

CHEM398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
CHEM398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the winter term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

CHEM399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
CHEM399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

CHEM498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
CHEM498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

CHEM499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
CHEM499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the fall term of the fifth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

CHIN134.name: Intensive Basic Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN134.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 500 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 134 or CHIN 104 or both CHIN 101, CHIN 103, or both CHIN 131, CHIN 133.

CHIN233.name: Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN233.desc: Continuation of CHIN 231. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 233 or CHIN 107, or CHIN 234.

CHIN234.name: Intensive Basic Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN234.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 1000 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 234 or CHIN 108 or both CHIN 105, CHIN 107, or both CHIN 231, CHIN 233.
CHIN234.prer: One of CHIN 103, CHIN 104, CHIN 133, CHIN 134.

CHIN464.name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (Intensive)
CHIN464.desc: A combination of CHIN 461 and 463. Classical poetry from pre-Qin to the early Tang Dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 464 or both CHIN 461, CHIN 463.
CHIN464.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN474.name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (Intensive)
CHIN474.desc: A combination of CHIN 471 and 473. Classical poetry from the time of Du Fu (712-770) to the end of the Qing Dynasty, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 474 or both CHIN 471, CHIN 473.
CHIN474.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN481.name: Modern Chinese Literature I (Heritage)
CHIN481.desc: Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to present. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 481 or CHIN 484.
CHIN481.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN484.name: Intensive Modern Chinese Literature (Heritage)
CHIN484.desc: A combination of CHIN 481 and 483. Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to the present. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 484 or both CHIN 481, CHIN 483.
CHIN484.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

COGS402.name: Research in Cognitive Systems
COGS402.desc: Supervised research project in a Cognitive Systems-related laboratory. [0-9-0]

COMM203.name: Managing the Employment Relationship
COMM203.desc: The role of employment relations in enterprise performance. Managing employees under statutory law, collective bargaining, and progressive human resource management. Key issues in forming, developing, and maintaining a work force. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 203 or COMM 392.
COMM203.prer: COMM 292 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100.

COMM204.name: Logistics and Operations Management
COMM204.desc: The design and management of systems to make products, provide services and deliver them to the end user. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 204 or COMM 399.

COMM205.name: Introduction to Management Information Systems
COMM205.desc: Overview of computer technology and terminology; use of computers as managerial and administrative tools; the management of computer resources and the influence of information technology within the organization. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 205 or COMM 391.

COMM280.name: Entrepreneurship
COMM280.desc: Entrepreneurial essentials from creating viable opportunities through building a founding team, strategic planning, going to market, fleshing out an organization and planning the future of the business.

COMM293.name: Financial Accounting
COMM293.desc: Introduction to the construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 293 or COEC 293.

COMM294.name: Managerial Accounting
COMM294.desc: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control and the development of cost information for financial reports.

COMM295.name: Managerial Economics
COMM295.desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, organization of the firm, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 201, ECON 206, ECON 301, ECON 304, FRE 295, COMM 295.
COMM295.prer: Either (a) ECON 100 or (b) all of ECON 101, ECON 102.

COMM329.name: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
COMM329.desc: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them. Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, environments, group processes, motivation and leadership (for non-Commerce students only).

COMM335.name: Information Systems Technology and Development
COMM335.desc: Introduction to information technology related to business use. Design, implementation and application of Information Systems.

COMM380.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
COMM380.desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce. Option-specific prerequisites apply.

COMM381.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
COMM381.desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce.

COMM390.name: Business Writing
COMM390.desc: An activity-focused course providing the opportunity to study and practice forms of writing needed in business.
COMM390.prer: One of ENGL 112, ASTU 150, WRDS 150, ENGL 100, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. ENGL 1st, Arts One, a minimum of 18 cr. of Coordinated Arts Program.

COMM393.name: Commercial Law
COMM393.desc: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property; principles of agency, partnerships and company law.

COMM394.name: Government and Business
COMM394.desc: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 394 or COMM 394.

COMM395.name: Business Communications
COMM395.desc: Understanding non-written communications in day-to-day business.

COMM398.name: Introduction to Business Processes and Operations
COMM398.desc: The design and management of systems that efficiently and effectively supply products and services to the end-user. The concepts apply to a variety of settings such as manufacturing, logistics, healthcare, and others (For non-Commerce students only).

COMM457.name: Fundamentals of Financial Accounting
COMM457.desc: Financial accounting for business organizations; principles and problems of accounting measurements; forms of business organizations; financing of businesses. (For non-Commerce students only).

COMM465.name: Marketing Management
COMM465.desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services. (For non-Commerce students only).
COMM465.prer: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.

COMM473.name: Business Finance
COMM473.desc: Introduction to managerial finance, including the role and functioning of financial markets, procurement of funds and financing strategies, dividend policy, capital budgeting and financial analysis and planning. (For non-Commerce students only).
COMM473.prer: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310;  and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

COMM480.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
COMM480.desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 35 months. Normally taken during the summer term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative. Education Program in Commerce.

COMM481.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
COMM481.desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 35 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce.

COMM491.name: Strategic Management
COMM491.desc: Concepts and processes for the strategic management of private sector, single and multi-business unit enterprises are analysed using the case method. Methodologies which draw on economic and organizational theory are integrated to form the foundations for strategic analyses.
COMM491.prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

COMM493.name: Strategic Management in Business
COMM493.desc: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of business strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business. Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change (For non-Commerce students only in fourth year).
COMM493.prer: One of COMM 293, COMM 457 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (c) ECON 100 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.

COMM498.name: International Business Management
COMM498.desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 498 or COEC 498.
COMM498.prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

CPEN291.name: Computer Engineering Design Studio I
CPEN291.desc: Design projects involving hardware (electronic devices and circuits, microcomputers) and software.

CPEN481.name: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
CPEN481.desc: Time-money relationships; economic analysis of alternatives including the effects of interest rates, inflation, depreciation, taxation and uncertainty; cost estimation and budgeting; financial analysis of engineering operations.

ECON101.name: Principles of Microeconomics
ECON101.desc: Elements of theory and of Canadian policy and institutions concerning the economics of markets and market behaviour, prices and costs, exchange and trade, competition and monopoly, distribution of income.

ECON102.name: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON102.desc: Elements of theory and of Canadian policy and institutions concerning the economics of growth and business cycles, national income accounting, interest and exchange rates, money and banking, the balance of trade.

ECON301.name: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis I
ECON301.desc: Consumer behaviour, producer theory, exchange, monopoly, oligopoly, externalities, public goods, general equilibrium and welfare economics. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 201, ECON 301, or ECON 304.

ECON302.name: Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis I
ECON302.desc: Income and employment theory, monetary theory, the open economy, economic fluctuations and growth. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 302, ECON 305.
ECON302.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

ECON345.name: Money and Banking
ECON345.desc: Financial markets and financial institutions in theory and practice; structure and development of the Canadian financial system; development and theory of the regulation of the financial system; process of monetary control; theory and history of central banking and monetary policy.

ECON351.name: Women in the Economy
ECON351.desc: Economic analysis of markets and policies particularly affecting women. Selected topics drawn from economic discrimination; educational, occupational, and work choices; pay and employment equity; allocation of work time and consumption within the household and in the market; economics of marriage and fertility; poverty; taxation; income security and pension policies; and historical perspectives.

ECON355.name: Introduction to International Trade
ECON355.desc: The determinants of trade patterns, trade policy, tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade, political economy of protectionism, bilateral and multilateral trade disputes, trade liberalization, trade and development. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 355 and 455.

ECON356.name: Introduction to International Finance
ECON356.desc: Exchange rate policy regimes; international financial organizations; the interaction between monetary policy and exchange rate regimes; financial crises.

ECON456.name: International Macroeconomics and Finance
ECON456.desc: Balance of payments; market for foreign exchange; mechanism for adjusting the balance of payments; internal vs. external stability; current problems and issues.

ECON471.name: Economics of Nonrenewable Resources
ECON471.desc: Application of economic analysis to the management of nonrenewable natural resources. Emphasis is placed on the economics of alternative energy sources. Other topics include mineral economics, criteria for the optimal use of resources, and measurement of resources.

ELEC291.name: Electrical Engineering Design Studio I
ELEC291.desc: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, and microcomputers.
ELEC291.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211.

ELEC292.name: Biomedical Engineering Design Studio
ELEC292.desc: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, microcomputers with applications in biomedical engineering. Final group project requiring oral presentation of student-prepared slides.
ELEC292.crer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of EECE 269, ELEC 221.

ELEC341.name: Systems and Control
ELEC341.desc: Continuous time system analysis by Laplace transforms; system modeling by transfer function and state space methods; feedback, stability and sensitivity; control design; frequency domain analysis. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 360, ELEC 341 or EECE 369.
ELEC341.prer: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202, ELEC 204, EECE 269, ELEC 221.

ELEC391.name: Electrical Engineering Design Studio II
ELEC391.desc: Introduction to project management.  Problem definition.  Design principles and practices.  Implementation techniques including circuit design, software design, solid modeling, PCBs, assembling, and packaging.  Testing and evaluation.  Effective presentations.
ELEC391.prer: One of CPEN 291, ELEC 291, ELEC 292, EECE 281 and two of EECE 352, ELEC 315, EECE 356, ELEC 301, EECE 359, EECE 360, ELEC 341, EECE 364, ELEC 311, EECE 373, ELEC 342.

ELEC481.name: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
ELEC481.desc: Time-money relationships; economic analysis of alternatives including the effects of interest rates, inflation, depreciation, taxation and uncertainty; cost estimation and budgeting; financial analysis of engineering operations.

ENPH253.name: Introduction to Instrument Design
ENPH253.desc: Practice in engineering design and instrument development including mechanical and electrical design, and communications with sensors, actuators. Micro-controller implementation and system integration. Engineering design review process and presentations. Engineering communication in design and product release. [3-6-0]

ENPH270.name: Mechanics II
ENPH270.desc: Dynamics: systems of particles, kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies (plane motion), energy and momentum, rotating coordinates. [2-0-1]

EOSC114.name: The Catastrophic Earth: Natural Disasters
EOSC114.desc: Introduction to causes and physical characteristics of disasters such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, storm surge, thunderstorms, tornadoes, landslides, wind waves, meteor impacts, mass extinctions. [3-0-0]

EOSC116.name: Mesozoic Earth: Time of the Dinosaurs
EOSC116.desc: Earth's tectonics, climate, and oceans during the time of the dinosaurs.  Reading the fossil record of Earth from its earliest origins up to and including the Mesozoic, 250 - 65 million years ago. [3-0-0]

EOSC118.name: Earth's Treasures: Gold and Gems
EOSC118.desc: Origin, properties, valuation, prospecting and geology of gold, platinum, silver, diamonds, rubies, emeralds, and other precious metals and gems. [3-0-0]

EOSC315.name: The Ocean Ecosystem
EOSC315.desc: An introduction to life in the oceans, its variety and evolution; primary producers and their links to the environment, zooplankton, marine communities, living marine resources and their role in today's world. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science. [3-0-0]

EOSC398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
EOSC398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

EOSC399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
EOSC399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

EOSC447.name: Thesis
EOSC447.desc: For B.A.Sc. Topic to be approved by the Department. [0-3-0]

EOSC449.name: Thesis
EOSC449.desc: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Required of all honours students. Open to major students with a satisfactory standing, appropriate background courses and permission of the course instructor and the directing faculty member.

EOSC498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
EOSC498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university of government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

EOSC499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
EOSC499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

FNEL483.name: Indigenous Languages of BC: Diversity and Vitality
FNEL483.desc: Genetic affiliation, areal contact, typological diversity, and initiatives to sustain the vitality and diversity of BC First Nations Languages.

FNH200.name: Exploring Our Food
FNH200.desc: Chemical and physical properties of foods; issues pertaining to safety, nutritive value and consumer acceptability; government regulations pertaining to food safety, quality and additives; preservation techniques and transformation of agricultural commodities to food products; foods of the future. [3-0-0]
FNH200.prer: At least second year standing required.

FNH250.name: Nutrition Concepts and Controversies
FNH250.desc: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues. [3-0-0]
FNH250.prer: Either (a) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (b) all of KIN  190, KIN  191. At least second-year standing required.

FNH330.name: Introduction to Wine Science 1
FNH330.desc: Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation. [2-1-0]

FNH355.name: International Nutrition
FNH355.desc: Conceptualization and scientific analyses of global problems in food and nutrition; complexities of food habits and malnutrition in various cultures around the world. [3-0-0]

FNH381.name: Professional Dietetic Practice II
FNH381.desc: Themes include: nutrition communications, professional practice, and dietetic practice environments. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.

FNH460.name: International Nutrition Field Studies
FNH460.desc: Theoretical and practical application of international nutrition and food security knowledge and skills.  International field placement for a minimum of 12 weeks with pre-departure sessions.  Restricted to students in International Nutrition Major or by permission of instructor.

FNH480.name: Professional Dietetic Practice III
FNH480.desc: Themes include practice-based research, clinical practice readiness, and orientation to internship.
FNH480.prer: Fourth-year standing in the Dietetics Major.

FNH483.name: Dietetic Internship III
FNH483.desc: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.

FNH499.name: Undergraduate Thesis
FNH499.desc: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to preparation of a thesis.
FNH499.prer: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.

FREN101.name: Beginners' French I
FREN101.desc: Grammar, composition, reading and oral practice.  Not available to students with the prerequisite for FREN 102.

FREN102.name: Beginners' French II
FREN102.desc: Grammar, composition, reading and oral practice.  Not available to students with prerequisite for FREN 111.

FREN111.name: Intermediate French I
FREN111.desc: Not available for credit to students with FREN 12, FREN 112 or equivalent.
FREN111.prer: One of FREN 11, FREN 102 or equivalent.

FREN112.name: Intermediate French II
FREN112.desc: Not available for credit to students with FREN 12.

FREN220.name: Introduction to Early French Literature and to Textual Analysis
FREN220.desc: Students will familiarize themselves with techniques of literary analysis, as applied to representative works from the Middle Ages to the 17th century, including theatre, fiction, poetry and non-fiction prose. To be taken by all students intending to proceed to the Minor, Major or Honours program.
FREN220.prer: FREN 123 or assignment based on placement test.

GERM100.name: Beginners' German I
GERM100.desc: Introduction to the language.  Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations.  See also GERM 433.

GERM110.name: Beginners' German II
GERM110.desc: Introduction to the language. Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations, speak about past events and express ideas and hypotheses in German. See also GERM 433.

GERM112.name: German for Singers
GERM112.desc: Study of the German language in combination with the study of German lyric diction and musical culture. The course includes translation, phonetic transcription, and the performance of vocal music.

GERM433.name: German for Reading Knowledge I
GERM433.desc: A multimedia introduction to reading skills in German leading to a second year reading knowledge in just one term. Students are expected to work largely independently. Course restricted to beginners or to students with no more than one term of beginner's German (or equivalent).

GRSJ101.name: Introduction to Social Justice
GRSJ101.desc: An overview of intersectional feminist debates and theoretical traditions. Credit will be granted for only one of WMST 100 or GRSJ 101.

GRSJ300.name: Intersectional Approaches to Thinking Gender
GRSJ300.desc: Interdisciplinary exploration of the multiple intersections between gender and (neo)colonialism, racism, poverty, ableism, and heterosexism in a globalized world; historical and cross-cultural aspects, and the social construction of sex and gender, masculinity and femininity.

HIST103.name: World History Since 1900
HIST103.desc: International relations; changes in the nation-state system; the emergence and impact of major political ideologies; genocide; decolonization; the globalization of trade; and the dynamics of economic, social, cultural, and environmental change in a global context.

HIST106.name: Global Environmental History
HIST106.desc: The impact humans have had on the environment, and the ways in which the physical environment has shaped human history: climate, agriculture, energy use, and urbanization.

HIST326.name: Canada Since 1945: Affluence and Anxiety in the Atomic Age
HIST326.desc: Includes immigration policy; the welfare state; Aboriginal peoples; the Cold War; resource economies and national politics; continentalism and free trade; constitutional crises; conflicting nationalisms; and new social movements.  Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 326 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.

HIST339.name: The United States Since 1945: The Limits of Power
HIST339.desc: American military and geo-political power during and after Cold War; wars in Korea, Vietnam, and Middle East; domestic issues including McCarthyism, social movements (blacks, women, youth, gays and lesbians, and Native Americans), consumerism, immigration, and rise of New Right.

HIST357.name: History of Mexico
HIST357.desc: Examines themes in the last five hundred years of Mexican history, with an emphasis on the critical reading of primary sources and the use of a variety of texts that may include letters, diaries, paintings, photographs, novels, and movies.

HIST412.name: The American Impact on Canada
HIST412.desc: An examination of the influence of the United States' rise to continental, hemispheric, and world power upon Canada in the areas of economics, defence, and foreign policy.

HIST425.name: War and Society
HIST425.desc: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime as well as war; not a course in military history.

HIST441.name: History of the Holocaust
HIST441.desc: A study of the systematic attempt to destroy European Jewry during the Nazi regime, 1933-1945. Topics of special importance include: the motivations and behaviour of the perpetrators; the reactions of the victims; the roles of bystanders.

HIST482.name: Chinese Migration
HIST482.desc: This history of Chinese migrations from the founding of the state to the present day. Migration is used as a focus through which to examine some key themes of Chinese history; ethnicity, boundary creation, economic growth and international relations.

ITAL101.name: First-Year Italian I
ITAL101.desc: Grammar, reading, writing, and oral practice for beginners without previous exposure to the Italian language or dialects.

ITAL102.name: First-Year Italian II
ITAL102.desc: Grammar, reading, writing and oral practice for beginners without previous exposure to the Italian language or dialects.
ITAL102.prer: ITAL 101. Or permission of the instructor.

ITAL104.name: Italian for Singers
ITAL104.desc: The study of the Italian language with the study of Italian lyric diction and musical culture; practice in translation, phonetic transcription and the performance of vocal music.

JAPN100.name: Beginning Japanese IA
JAPN100.desc: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 11 and/or JAPN 12. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 100 or JAPN 160.

JAPN101.name: Beginning Japanese IB
JAPN101.desc: Continuation of JAPN 100 (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 101 or JAPN 160.

JAPN200.name: Beginning Japanese II A
JAPN200.desc: Continuation of JAPN 101 (Non-intensive). Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 200 or JAPN 102 or JAPN 260.

JAPN201.name: Beginning Japanese II B
