JAPN201.desc: Continuation of JAPN 200 (Non-intensive). Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 201 or JAPN 103 or JAPN 260.

JAPN320.name: Intermediate Japanese I A
JAPN320.desc: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 320 or JAPN 210 or JAPN 360.
JAPN320.prer: One of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260.

JAPN321.name: Intermediate Japanese I B
JAPN321.desc: Continuation of JAPN 320. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 321 or JAPN 211 or JAPN 360.

JAPN322.name: Intermediate Japanese II A
JAPN322.desc: It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 322 and JAPN 323 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 or JAPN 212 or JAPN 361.
JAPN322.prer: One of JAPN 211, JAPN 250, JAPN 321, JAPN 360.

JAPN323.name: Intermediate Japanese II B
JAPN323.desc: A continuation of JAPN 322. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 322 and JAPN 323 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 and JAPN 212 or JAPN 361.

KIN101.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN101.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN151.name: Biomechanics I
KIN151.desc: Application of elementary principles of physics and math to a quantitative analysis of movement.  Analysis will also focus on the development of forces within muscles and their effect on initiating and controlling human movement. [3-0]

KIN161.name: Leisure and Sport in Society
KIN161.desc: Introduction to the political, economic and social basis of leisure and sport; concepts, theories and problems. [3-0]

KIN201.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN201.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN275.name: Exercise Physiology I
KIN275.desc: Acute and chronic effects of exercise on body systems; basic concepts of cardiovascular, respiratory and muscular responses to physical activity. [2-0-2]

KIN301.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN301.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN375.name: Exercise Physiology II
KIN375.desc: Transport of oxygen during exercise in humans.  Regulation and integration of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems during exercise. [2-0-2]

KIN401.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN401.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN402.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN402.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN499.name: Projects in Kinesiology
KIN499.desc: Provides opportunities to perform research pertaining to a chosen area of kinesiology.
KIN499.prer: Fourth-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.)

LAW372.name: Administrative Law
LAW372.desc: The system of legal control exercised through non-judicial agencies and the relationship of the courts to the administrative process. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 210, LAW 372, or LAW 509.

LAW459.name: Business Organizations
LAW459.desc: A conceptual overview of business organizations in Canada, including partnerships and corporations, and the rights and duties of shareholders and directors. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 230, LAW 459, or LAW 508.

LAW476.name: Evidence
LAW476.desc: The admissibility and use of evidence in litigation. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 280, LAW 476, or LAW 507.

LAW488.name: Clinical Term
LAW488.desc: Designed to explore the legal system in relation to disadvantaged members of society. Under supervision, students will act for clients in a range of legal matters and can expect to appear before courts and tribunals. Students will also work with community-based organisations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 490 or LAW 491. Pass/Fail.

LAW491.name: Law Students Legal Advice Program Credit
LAW491.desc: Restricted to a limited number of upper year students who (a) in their first or second year have participated in the provision of legal services to the public through the Law Students Legal Advice Program, and (b) continue that participation in their second or third year. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 488, LAW 490, or LAW 491.

LIBE461.name: Administration of the School Library Resource Centre
LIBE461.desc: The role, philosophy, and management of school library resource centres in elementary and secondary schools. [3-0-0]

LLED352.name: Introduction to Teaching and Learning French: Elementary

LLED353.name: Teaching and Learning English as an Additional Language: Elementary

LLED423.name: Teaching French Adolescent Literature: Secondary
LLED423.prer: A completed concentration or major in French or permission of Department Head.

LLED433.name: Drama in Education: Creative Approaches and Strategies
LLED433.desc: Drama-based activities relevant to a wide range of classroom contexts; involves reading about, practicing, and discussing various creative drama approaches and strategies developed by contemporary scholars and practitioners. Pass/Fail.

LLED434.name: Drama in Education: Cross-Curricular Learning and Story

LLED439.name: Shakespeare in the Classroom
LLED439.prer: LLED 314. Recommended: at least 3 credit hours of Shakespeare study at the 300- or 400-level in the Faculty of Arts.

LLED444.name: Transcultural Children's Literature
LLED444.desc: Ways in which children's literature is informed by diverse, complex influences including culture(s) and language(s), and related problems, issues and controversies.

LLED445.name: Teaching Poetry
LLED445.desc: Instructional methodologies and theories in teaching all forms of poetry.

LLED449.name: Teaching Adolescents Literature
LLED449.desc: Instructional methodologies and theories in teaching literature to adolescents.

LLED469.name: Inquiry-Based Pedagogy in School Library Programs
LLED469.desc: Principles and practices of teachers and teacher-librarians designing and teaching curriculum using inquiry-based pedagogy. LLED 469 is a core course for the Teacher Librarian Diploma.

LLED481.name: Digital Media in English Language Arts Education

MATH002.name: Pre-Calculus
MATH002.desc: Composite, inverse, polynomial, rational, trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions; sequences and series; and analytical geometry. Non-credit Math course offered by Continuing Studies in consultation with the Mathematics Department and taught by Continuing Studies instructors.
MATH002.prer: MATH 001 or a score of 73% or higher in Principlies of Mathematics 11 or Pre-calculus 11.

MATH220.name: Mathematical Proof
MATH220.desc: Sets and functions; induction; cardinality;  properties of the real numbers; sequences, series, and limits. Logic, structure, style, and clarity of proofs emphasized throughout. [3-0-0]
MATH220.prer: Either (a) a score of 64% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 121, MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH307.name: Applied Linear Algebra
MATH307.desc: Applications of linear algebra to problems in science and engineering; use of computer algebra systems for solving problems in linear algebra. [3-0-0]
MATH307.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MECH224.name: Integration of Engineering Concepts I
MECH224.desc: Integration of the theory and practice of Mechanical Engineering to illustrate the commonality and conceptual connectivity of seemingly different technical areas. Emphasis on dynamics, solid mechanics, materials, electronics, and mathematics.

MECH225.name: Integration of Engineering Concepts II
MECH225.desc: Integration of the theory and practice of Mechanical Engineering to illustrate the commonality and conceptual connectivity of seemingly different technical areas. Emphasis on thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, and mathematics.

MECH227.name: Approaches to Technical Communication for Mechanical Engineers
MECH227.desc: Written and oral communication. Preparation of design, business correspondence, verbal, online and visual presentation of technical material. Focus on the linguistic structure and style of technical communication. Restricted to students in Mechanical Engineering. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 226 or MECH 227.
MECH227.prer: MECH 220 and one of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

MEDD431.name: Clerkship
MEDD431.desc: Core experiences across the breadth of medicine through clinical and academic learning opportunities in ambulatory, hospital-based, and rural/remote settings. Interactions with patients under supervision. Pass/Fail.

MICB201.name: Introductory Environmental Microbiology
MICB201.desc: Prokaryotic diversity and the impact and applications of bacterial and archaeal metabolic, genetic, and growth processes in environmental contexts. [3-0-0]
MICB201.prer: One of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, SCIE 001. For students with BIOL 112, CHEM 121 is recommended.

MICB398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
MICB398.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Term 2) of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

MICB399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
MICB399.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

MICB449.name: Research Problem
MICB449.desc: A laboratory investigation in the final year of the Honours program. The results are presented in a written report, to be reviewed by oral examination.
MICB449.prer: Either (a) MICB 323 or (b) all of MICB 322, MICB 399.

MICB498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
MICB498.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

MICB499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
MICB499.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Term 1) of fifth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

MIDW240.name: Core Midwifery Clinical Care
MIDW240.desc: Clinical education experiences with the preventative and therapeutic midwifery care of normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium with an emphasis on the intrapartum period and assessment and management skills.  A clinical practicum in locations around the provice.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW310.name: Senior Research Project
MIDW310.desc: An original piece of scholarship that builds on knowledge and skills acquired from coursework and in consultation with faculty mentors.

MIDW350.name: Inter-Professional Placement
MIDW350.desc: Opportunities to explore health professions that partner with midwives to care for the childbearing family within the province.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW370.name: Global Clinical Placement
MIDW370.desc: Social and economic determinants of maternal and fetal health worldwide, innovative public health strategies to reducing maternal and infant mortality and morbidity, and the impact of conflict on the health of mothers and babies.  Ethical considerations related to global clinical placements and medical tourism.  A global clinical placement.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW420.name: Advanced Midwifery Clinical Care
MIDW420.desc: Clinical education for midwifery care of pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium with an empahsis on abnormal situations in pregnancy, labour and birth, and in newborns.  Clinical practicum around the province.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW440.name: Clinical Clerkship
MIDW440.desc: Students assume a primary care role in clinical placements in midwifery practices across the provinces.  Demonstration of independent decision making and application of the full range of their academic knowledge to professional practice.  A practicum under the supervision of a registered midwife.  Pass/Fail.

PCTH398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
PCTH398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

PCTH399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
PCTH399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

PCTH498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
PCTH498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

PCTH499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
PCTH499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer after fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

PHAR403.name: Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
PHAR403.desc: Training for authorization to administer injections.

PHAR414.name: Directed Studies in Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
PHAR414.desc: Individual assignments involving library and laboratory investigation of problems involved in the development of pharmaceutical dosage forms.

PHAR444.name: Directed Studies in Pharmacology
PHAR444.desc: Individual assignments involving library and laboratory investigation of certain aspects of drug action.

PHAR469.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience II
PHAR469.desc: A 160-hour pharmacy clerkship focused on delivery of comprehensive patient care and disease management in community practice.
PHAR469.prer: PHAR 369 and promotion to fourth year.

PHAR479.name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Community
PHAR479.desc: A 320-hour pharmacy clerkship emphasizing integration of knowledge and skills in developing and assessing therapeutic plans for patients in community practice.

POLI100.name: Introduction to Politics
POLI100.desc: Political issues and case studies, drawn from Canadian and international contexts, will be used to introduce students to central debates and concepts of politics and political analysis.

POLI101.name: The Government of Canada
POLI101.desc: An examination of the institutions and processes of Canadian government.

POLI110.name: Investigating Politics: An Introduction to Scientific Political Analysis
POLI110.desc: The logic, challenges, and major strategies of empirical political research. Core research tasks including: asking answerable questions, defining concepts, formulating hypotheses, gathering evidence, measuring variables, constructing comparisons, drawing causal inferences, and reporting findings.

POLI240.name: Currents of Political Thought
POLI240.desc: A critical introduction to some major ideologies and traditions of Western political thought that examines their philosophical origins as well as their implications for political life.

POLI260.name: Introduction to Global Politics
POLI260.desc: Applies conceptual tools to topics such as war, conflict management, the global economy, poverty, and civil society.
POLI260.prer: Recommended for prospective students of POLI 360-373.

POLI326.name: European Politics: Selected Cases
POLI326.desc: The politics and government of one or more European countries: political development, institutional structure, party politics, and policy-making. The specific country or countries will vary by section.

POLI373.name: Ethics in World Politics
POLI373.desc: When is it right to wage war?  Who should pay for global warming?  Should the wealthy provide foreign aid- how much?  Analysis of traditions of moral thought to reach reasoned judgments about such dilemmas in global politics.

RHSC420.name: Elements of Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology
RHSC420.desc: An introduction to the structure and function of the human nervous system. [2-3-0]

SOCI100.name: Introduction to Sociology
SOCI100.desc: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

SOCI102.name: Inequality and Social Change
SOCI102.desc: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.

SOCI200.name: Sociology of Family
SOCI200.desc: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.

SOCI217.name: Research Methods
SOCI217.desc: Introduction to research designs and methodologies.
SOCI217.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI312.name: Gender Relations
SOCI312.desc: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality.

SOCI320.name: Diversity in Family Forms
SOCI320.desc: An examination of diversity within and between families and of diverse family forms.
SOCI320.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI371.name: Classical Traditions in Theory
SOCI371.desc: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370.

SOCI380.name: Sociological Methods: Survey Research
SOCI380.desc: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data.
SOCI380.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217 and SOCI 328.

SPAN101.name: Beginners' Spanish I
SPAN101.desc: Fundamentals of the Spanish language; speaking and writing on everyday activities and future plans in the context of common tasks and situations, including interactive communication, grammatical explanations, and cultural awareness.

SPAN102.name: Beginners' Spanish II
SPAN102.desc: Speaking and writing on past events, and expressing desires and wishes in the context of common situations, including interactive communication, grammatical explanations, and cultural awareness.

SPAN201.name: Intermediate Spanish I
SPAN201.desc: Reviews the fundamentals of the Spanish language, and introduces more complex structures; listening, speaking, writing, and reading on a range of situations related to everyday life and Hispanic culture.

SPAN202.name: Intermediate Spanish II
SPAN202.desc: Expands on the fundamentals of the Spanish language, and presents more complex structures in a variety of tenses and modes; interacting through discussions and gaining cultural awareness through literature and film.

SPPH200.name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
SPPH200.desc: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200. [3-0-0]

VANT149.name: Multidisciplinary Research Project
VANT149.desc: Research project that culminates in student-led conference and research presentation. [1-0-1]

VANT151.name: Multidisciplinary Engineering Design Project
VANT151.desc: Design project that culminates in student-led project fair. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [1-0-1]

ACAM350.name: Asian Canadian Community-Based Media
ACAM350.desc: Digital media production in the context of community engagement. Includes critical media literacy, community-based research ethics, project design, training in media forms such audio, video, photography, and web publishing.

ARBC101.name: Introduction to the Grammar and Vocabulary of Classic Arabic

ARBC102.name: Introduction to the Grammar and Vocabulary of Classic Arabic II

ARBC201.name: Classical Arabic (Intermediate) I
ARBC201.desc: Increased reading ability as well as learning the further essentials of grammar.

ARBC202.name: Classical Arabic (Intermediate) II
ARBC202.desc: Increased reading ability as well as learning the further essentials of grammar. Continuation of ARBC 201.

ARTH101.name: Ways of Seeing: Introduction to Visual Studies
ARTH101.desc: Drawing on examples from across history and around the world, this course deals with the role of the visual in society, culture, and everyday experience.

ARTH102.name: Crisis and Contradiction in Art and the Built Environment
ARTH102.desc: Concepts and issues critical to the understanding of art and its histories in a global context.

ARTH225.name: Art in Europe to the Sixteenth Century
ARTH225.desc: A selective survey of painting, sculpture, and architecture.

ARTH226.name: Art in an Era of Global Expansion
ARTH226.desc: A selective survey of painting, sculpture, and architecture from the 16th century to the emergence of the modern era.

ARTH227.name: Art and the Visual Environment in the Modern and Post-modern Periods
ARTH227.desc: A selective survey of visual art, architecture and other visual media since 1900.

ARTH253.name: Asian Architecture: Sacred and Urban Spaces
ARTH253.desc: Select built forms in Asia, such as temples, tombs, palaces, cities and gardens, and their relations to cultural, social and political systems.

ARTH300.name: Seminar on Methods and Approaches in Art History
ARTH300.desc: Theories, problems, and literature in the study of art history. Required of all Major and Honours students in art history.

ARTH311.name: Art in the Early Medieval West
ARTH311.desc: From pagan adornment to Christian devotion to service of Christian or Islamic rule (AD 500 - 1000). Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 311 or ARTH 331.

ARTH321.name: Early Modern Italian Art and Culture (ca. 1350-1550)
ARTH321.desc: Visual art and culture within the social, political, and religious contexts of the Papacy and the city-states.

ARTH338.name: Visual Culture in the Age of Enlightenment and Revolution (1715-1830)
ARTH338.desc: Art, architecture, and social space in Europe and America: redefining gender, identity and nation in the era of industrialization and political change.

ARTH339.name: 19th-Century Art and Social Space
ARTH339.desc: Ideologies of gender, class, race, ethnicity, and economics in 19th-century European and American visual culture.

ARTH340.name: 20th Century Art and Culture: The Triumph and Demise of Modernism
ARTH340.desc: A critical survey of western art and cultural production from the turn of the century to the development of Pop Art.

ARTH341.name: 20th Century Art and Culture: The Postmodern
ARTH341.desc: A critical examination of international visual art and culture from the 1950s to the present;  the role of art in consumerist society and the emergence of postmodernism.

ARTH344.name: Art and Photography in Canada, 1920 to the Present
ARTH344.desc: Art movements and art institutions from the landscape paintings of the Group of Seven to the photo-conceptualist practices of the Vancouver school.

ARTH345.name: History of Photography: Archive, Spectacle, Reality
ARTH345.desc: History and theory of photography, from the competitive context of invention in the 1830s to contemporary uses in social media.

ARTH352.name: Historic India:  Images, Temples and the Construction of Indian Art History
ARTH352.desc: North and South Indian art and architecture with an emphasis on Buddhism and Hinduism.

ARTH353.name: Nepal and Tibet:  Art, Ritual and Performance
ARTH353.desc: Art of the Himalayan region situated within social and religious practices, festivals, and performances.

ARTH358.name: Chinese Art for the Afterlife
ARTH358.desc: Close analyses of Chinese tomb objects and tombs as spatial constructs in their historical, ritual, and social context.

ARTH363.name: Art in Japan: The Problem with Painting
ARTH363.desc: Key debates in the history of painting and its institutionalization.

ARTH368.name: Art in Japan: Print Media
ARTH368.desc: Historical and theoretical questions concerning the development of print media in Japan, from Edo period woodcuts to the advent of digital technologies.

ARTH377.name: Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The South
ARTH377.desc: The histories, historiography and cultural diversity of the Southern  Northwest Coast region; persistence and innovation in the arts in communities, and in cross-cultural and market spheres.

ARTH380.name: Art as Technology
ARTH380.desc: Relationship between artistic practice and media, examined through a history of paradigm shifts in technology.

ARTH432.name: Seminar in the Art of the Middle Ages

ARTH455.name: Seminar in the Art of South Asia

ARTH479.name: Performance Actions and Approaches
ARTH479.desc: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies.

ARTH480.name: Visual and Digital Media Theory
ARTH480.desc: A thematic examination of key arguments in visual and digital media theory, focusing on developments in lens-based and digital media in relationship to twentieth-century and contemporary artistic practice.

ASIC200.name: Global Issues in the Arts and Sciences
ASIC200.desc: Selected global issues explored through the methodologies and perspectives of both the physical and life sciences and the humanities and social sciences. [3-0-0]
ASIC200.prer: Second year standing in the Faculty of Arts or Faculty of Science.

ASTR200.name: Frontiers of Astrophysics
ASTR200.desc: Stellar masses and evolution. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Extrasolar planet formation and detection. Dark matter in the Milky Way and other galaxies. Cosmological observations and principles. [3-0-0]
ASTR200.prer: Either (a) one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

ASTR205.name: Stars and Stellar Populations
ASTR205.desc: Measurement of positions, motions, and distances in astronomy.  Temperature, masses, and spectra of stars.  Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.  Quantitative stellar structure and evolution.  Chemical composition of stars in different Galactic populations. Globular and open star clusters. [3-0-0]
ASTR205.prer: ASTR 200 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.

ASTR300.name: Galaxies
ASTR300.desc: Structure and kinematics of our galaxy. Spiral arms and dynamics of stars in spiral and elliptical galaxies. Galactic formation, evolution, dynamics, and groups. Active galaxies and quasars.
ASTR300.prer: ASTR 205 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.

ASTR333.name: Exoplanets and Astrobiology
ASTR333.desc: Observations and basic characteristics of extrasolar planets, including their formation, evolution, and potential for supporting life. Not to be used to satisfy any Physics and Astronomy major or honours specialization requirement, but may be used as an upper-level science elective. [3-0-0]
ASTR333.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, BIOL 300.

ASTR349.name: Directed Research Project in Astronomy
ASTR349.desc: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report.  Requires approval of the course instructor and program advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. [1*-6-0]

ASTR403.name: Cosmology
ASTR403.desc: Introduction to the study of the Universe as a whole. Foundations of the Hot Big Bang model, the early Universe, nucleosynthesis, the cosmic microwave background, large-scale structure, galaxy formation and quasars. [3-0-0]
ASTR403.prer: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250. ASTR 300 is recommended.

ASTR405.name: Astronomical Laboratory
ASTR405.desc: Experiments in the use of astronomical instrumentation and data analysis. Use of the 40-cm reflector, spectrograph and electronic detectors. Photometric and spectroscopic analysis of digital data. [0-0-3]

ASTR449.name: Honours Thesis in Astronomy
ASTR449.desc: A research project in astronomy, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis. [1*-6-0]

ASTU100.name: 1st Year CAP Seminar
ASTU100.desc: CAP seminar focused on writing and reading, including both literature and introduction to academic scholarship. Topics vary each year. Credits count toward both the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement and the Literature Requirement. Restricted to students in the Coordinated Arts Program.

ASTU101.name: Writing for Research in the Social Sciences and the Humanities
ASTU101.desc: Analysis of and practice in academic writing and reading in the social sciences and the humanities. Restricted to students in the Coordinated Arts Program.

ASTU201.name: Canada, Japan and the Pacific: Cultural Studies
ASTU201.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the cultures of Canada and Japan, and the interrelations between them. Specific topics vary from year to year but will include themes such as constructing the past; nationalism; self-perceptions; cross-cultural perceptions; multiculturalism in Canada and Japan; images in architecture, film and literature; mythologies.

ASTU202.name: Canada, Japan and the Pacific: Political, Economic and Geographical Perspectives
ASTU202.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to political, economic and geographical interactions between Japan and Canada, the links between these countries and other Pacific Rim nations, and the historical origins of these connections. Specific topics will vary from year to year, but will include themes such as economic integration in the Pacific region; the role of resource economies such as Canada's; security relations in the Pacific; the role of Japanese investment in the Asia-Pacific region.

BIOC301.name: Biochemistry Laboratory
BIOC301.desc: Techniques by which the chemical and physical properties of fundamental components of the cell are studied. [0-3-1]

BIOC304.name: Contemporary Biochemical Research
BIOC304.desc: Exploration of the breadth and importance of biochemical research to present day challenges in medicine and biotechnology. Detailed experimental research case studies of novel biochemical methods used to address pressing and ongoing biochemical issues. [3-0-0]

BIOC402.name: Proteins: Structure and Function
BIOC402.desc: Structural components of proteins, classification by primary, secondary and tertiary structure, protein chemistry and purification, peptide and protein synthesis by chemical means and three-dimensional structure determination using X-ray diffraction and NMR. [3-0-0]
BIOC402.prer: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.

BIOC404.name: Biochemical Methods
BIOC404.desc: Theory and application of classical and emerging technologies in biochemical research.  Emphasis on using primary literature and oral presentation skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry or others with permission of the instructor. [1-0; 2-0]

BIOC420.name: Advanced Biochemical Techniques
BIOC420.desc: Multi-week experiments in areas of contemporary biochemistry research using classical and modern techniques.  Emphasis on experimental design, technique, critical analysis of data, and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry and others with permission of the instructor. [0-6-0]

BIOC421.name: Recombinant DNA Techniques
BIOC421.desc: Multi-week experiments involving contemporary nucleic acid research, cloning and recombinant protein engineering. Emphasis is on experimental design, critical analysis of data and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Major students in Biochemistry. [0-6-0]

BIOC450.name: Membrane Biochemistry
BIOC450.desc: Biochemistry of membranes and membrane proteins, membrane fusion, electrical signaling, and the involvement of membrane proteins in disease and drug development. [3-0-0]
BIOC450.prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

BIOC460.name: Advanced Techniques in Biochemistry
BIOC460.desc: Theoretical basis and practical applications of a selection of advanced techniques currently used in biochemical research. Topics will vary. [3-0-0]
BIOC460.prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

BIOT280.name: Introductory Biotechnology
BIOT280.desc: Block registration for the biotechnology, microbiology, physiology, communication for biotechnology, organic chemistry, information technology, plant anatomy, plant physiology and cell biology courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biotechnology.  Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

BIOT380.name: Advanced Biotechnology
BIOT380.desc: Block registration for the microbiology, molecular genetics, biochemistry, management and regulatory affairs, process systems, analytical chemistry and communication courses taken in the BCIT/UBC Joint Degree in Biotechnology.  Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

BMEG410.name: Biomedical Equipment, Physiology, and Anatomy
BMEG410.desc: Principles and operation of biomedical equipment for cardiovascular system, respiratory system, renal dialysis, endoscopy, surgery, and imaging. Functional relationships of biomedical equipment to physiology and anatomy of major body systems. Restricted to students in EECE and MECH Biomedical Engineering options. Credit will be given for only one of BMEG 410 or BMEG 510. [3-0-2*]

BMEG456.name: Clinical and Industrial Biomedical Engineering
BMEG456.desc: Principles of clinical practice, Canadian healthcare system, medical approach to diagnosis, ethics and regulations for clinical trials, medical technology management, medical device development and standards, biostatistics. Restricted to students in EECE and MECH Biomedical Engineering options. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 456 or BMEG 556.

CAPS200.name: Biomedical Research: Essential Skills and Concepts
CAPS200.desc: Analysis of the underlying questions and assumptions, experimental approach, results and significance of work described in selected biomedical research presentations. [3-0-0]
CAPS200.prer: BIOL 200. Limited to students in second year.

CAPS301.name: Human Physiology
CAPS301.desc: Organ systems function with particular reference to mammalian and human physiology.  See credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-0-0]
CAPS301.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

CAPS390.name: Introduction to Microscopic Human Anatomy
CAPS390.desc: Organ system development, structure and function at the microscopic level. [3-0-0]
CAPS390.prer: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. BIOL 200 is recommended.

CAPS449.name: Graduating Essay
CAPS449.desc: Written report and presentation on an independent investigaton approved by the department head.

CHEM211.name: Introduction to Chemical Analysis
CHEM211.desc: Quantitative chemical analysis; chemical and physical principles of spectrophotometry, potentiometry, and chromatography.

CHEM218.name: Fundamentals of Reactivity in Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM218.desc: Chemical reactivity of inorganic systems: oxidation/reduction chemistry; multiply-bonded systems; main group chemistry.

CHEM245.name: Intermediate Synthetic Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM245.desc: Techniques in synthetic organic and inorganic chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.
CHEM245.prer: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) all of CHEM 233, CHEM 235.

CHEM301.name: Aqueous Environmental Chemistry
CHEM301.desc: Properties of natural waters, including gas and solid equilibria, pH, redox, complexation analysis, corrosion treatment, ion exchange, colloids and microbial transformations. [3-0-0]
CHEM301.prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 251 and Third year standing.

CHEM302.name: Atmospheric Environmental Chemistry
CHEM302.desc: Introduction to structure, composition and chemical processes occurring in Earth's atmosphere, including interactions with solar radiation, stratospheric ozone layer, photochemical smog and acid rain. [3-0-0]
CHEM302.prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 251 and Third year standing.

CHEM305.name: Biophysical Chemistry
CHEM305.desc: Diffusion and transport phenomena; interaction of radiation and matter. Methods for determining molecular weight, size, and shape of molecules in solution. [3-0-0]
CHEM305.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 205 or (c) CHEM 304 or (d) PHYS 203.

CHEM311.name: Instrumental Analytical Chemistry
CHEM311.desc: Theory, design, and application of instrumental methods of chemical analysis including spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, electroanalysis, and chemical separations.. [3-0-1]

CHEM313.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry for the Life Sciences
CHEM313.desc: Chemistry of organic substances having particular relevance to the life sciences. [3-0-0]

CHEM315.name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory I
CHEM315.desc: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. [0-4-0]
CHEM315.prer: One of CHEM 201, CHEM 202, CHEM 203, CHEM 208, CHEM 211, CHEM 235.

CHEM318.name: Principles of Catalysis
CHEM318.desc: Fundamental aspects of chemical catalysis: kinetic models; catalytic processes in biochemistry and industry; emerging topics in catalysis.

CHEM319.name: Practical Skills for Chemical Research
CHEM319.desc: The nature of scientific research; practical skills for chemical research; communicating science.  Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

CHEM325.name: Integrated Chemistry Laboratory I
CHEM325.desc: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry specializations. [0-8-0]
CHEM325.prer: All of CHEM 211, CHEM 213, CHEM 245 and either (a) all of CHEM 201, CHEM 202 or (b) CHEM 208.

CHEM327.name: Introduction to Materials Chemistry
CHEM327.desc: Basic principles of materials chemistry: classification; nomenclature; synthetic methods; characterization.
CHEM327.prer: One of CHEM 208, CHEM 250 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

CHEM329.name: Research Ethics and Data Analysis Skills
CHEM329.desc: Research ethics; data analysis skills for chemical research. Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

CHEM330.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
CHEM330.desc: Application of carbonyl group chemistry, cyclization reactions, conformational analysis and rearrangement reactions in organic synthesis. [3-0-0]

CHEM335.name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory II
CHEM335.desc: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. [0-4-0]

CHEM341.name: Global Challenges: A Chemical Perspective
CHEM341.desc: Importance of chemistry in society. Detailed case studies drawn from modern chemistry: human health, energy, commodity chemicals, materials, green chemistry, agriculture. [3-0-0]

CHEM345.name: Integrated Chemistry Laboratory II
CHEM345.desc: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.   Open only to students in Chemistry Major or Honours specializations. [0-8-0]

CHEM401.name: Principles of Spectroscopy
CHEM401.desc: Rotational, vibrational, electronic and magnetic resonance spectroscopy and associated techniques; group theory. [3-0-0]

CHEM403.name: Surface Chemistry and Surface Analysis
CHEM403.desc: Surfaces and phenomena occurring at surfaces and interfaces: adsorption, thermodynamic treatments, technological applications. Methods for characterization and modification of surfaces. Dynamic electrochemistry and its application to understanding fuel cells. [3-0-0]
CHEM403.prer: CHEM 304 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

CHEM405.name: Biophysical Chemistry
CHEM405.desc: Interactions of macromolecules in solution: ligand, antibody and ion binding to macromolecules; thermodynamics of polymer solutions; excluded volume effects; phase separation; partition in two phase polymer solutions. [3-0-0]

CHEM406.name: Polymer Chemistry
CHEM406.desc: Structure and availability of monomers; Propagation mechanisms; synthesis of polymers with predetermined properties; measurement and interpretation of physical properties of polymers. [3-0-0]
CHEM406.prer: One of CHEM 213, CHEM 260 and one of CHEM 304, CHEM 251.

CHEM417.name: Nuclear Chemistry and Radiochemistry
CHEM417.desc: Basic treatment of the nucleus, with analogy to concepts in chemistry. Nuclear stabilities and associated radioactive decay processes. Nuclear structure. Applications of radioisotopes in chemistry. The interaction of radiation with matter. [3-0-0]
CHEM417.prer: CHEM 123 and Third year standing. CHEM 312 is recommended.

CHEM427.name: Applications of Materials Chemistry
CHEM427.desc: Contemporary materials chemistry, including design and synthesis of materials for energy, electronics, and health applications. [3-0-0]

CHEM434.name: Principles of Chemical Separation
CHEM434.desc: Unified theory of separation science; liquid and gas chromatography; capillary electrophoresis; electrochemical and spectroscopic detection; separation methods coupled with mass spectrometry and tandem mass spectrometry; biochemical applications. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 434 or CHEM 534. [3-0-0]

CHEM449.name: Seminar and Thesis
CHEM449.desc: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Weekly seminar. Required of all Honours students. Open to Majors students with a satisfactory standing and permission of the department head.

CHEM473.name: Structure Determination and Reaction Analysis
CHEM473.desc: Application of mass spectrometry and modern spectroscopic techniques, including multidimensional NMR spectroscopy, to reaction analysis and detailed characterization of complex organic and organometallic molecular structures. [3-0-0]
CHEM473.prer: CHEM 245 and one of CHEM 313, CHEM 318, CHEM 330.

CHIN131.name: Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN131.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 250 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 131 or CHIN 101 or CHIN 134.

CHIN133.name: Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN133.desc: Continuation of CHIN 131. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 133 or CHIN 103 or CHIN 134.

CHIN141.name: Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
CHIN141.desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 141 or CHIN 111 or CHIN 144.

CHIN143.name: Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
CHIN143.desc: Continuation of CHIN 141. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 143 or CHIN 113 or CHIN 144.

CHIN231.name: Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN231.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing Mandarin Chinese, active vocabulary of about 750 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 231 or CHIN 105 or CHIN 234.
CHIN231.prer: One of CHIN 103, CHIN 104, CHIN 133, CHIN 134.

CHIN241.name: Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Heritage)
CHIN241.desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 241 or CHIN 115 or CHIN 244.
CHIN241.prer: One of CHIN 113, CHIN 114, CHIN 143, CHIN 144.

CHIN243.name: Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
CHIN243.desc: Continuation of CHIN 241. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 243 or CHIN 117 or CHIN 244.

CHIN331.name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN331.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 331 or CHIN 201 or CHIN 334.
CHIN331.prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234.

CHIN333.name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN333.desc: Continuation of CHIN 331. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 333 or CHIN 203 or CHIN 334.

CHIN335.name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN335.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 335 or CHIN 205 or CHIN 338.
CHIN335.prer: One of CHIN 203, CHIN 204, CHIN 333, CHIN 334.

CHIN337.name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN337.desc: Continuation of CHIN 335. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 337 or CHIN 207 or CHIN 338.

CHIN341.name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
CHIN341.desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 341 or CHIN 211 or CHIN 344.
CHIN341.prer: One of CHIN 117, CHIN 118, CHIN 243, CHIN 244.

CHIN343.name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
CHIN343.desc: Continuation of CHIN 341. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 343 or CHIN 213 or CHIN 344.

CHIN345.name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Heritage)
CHIN345.desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 345 or CHIN 215 or CHIN 348.
CHIN345.prer: One of CHIN 213, CHIN 214, CHIN 343, CHIN 344.

CHIN347.name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
CHIN347.desc: Continuation of CHIN 345. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 347 or CHIN 217 or CHIN 348.

CHIN401.name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN401.desc: Reading and writing skills addressing social, cultural, and economic issues. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 405. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 401 or CHIN 301 or CHIN 404.
CHIN401.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN403.name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN403.desc: Continuation of CHIN 401. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 407. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 403 or CHIN 303 or CHIN 404.

CHIN405.name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN405.desc: More formal styles of oral and written communication. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 401. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 405 or CHIN 305 or CHIN 408.
CHIN405.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN407.name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN407.desc: Continuation of CHIN 405. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 403. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 407 or CHIN 307 or CHIN 408.

CHIN435.name: Business Chinese I (Heritage)
CHIN435.desc: Reading, writing, and presentation skills in business documentation, focusing on technical Chinese as used in the workplace. Emphasis on specialized vocabulary and development of communicative competence as relevant to advertising, the stock market and E-commerce. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 435 or CHIN 321.
CHIN435.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN437.name: Business Chinese II (Heritage)
CHIN437.desc: Reading, writing, and presentation skills in business documentation, focusing on technical Chinese as used in the workplace. Emphasis on specialized vocabulary and development of communicative competence as relevant to legal and financial documents such as contracts, investments, and insurance. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 437 or CHIN 323.
CHIN437.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN441.name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Heritage)
CHIN441.desc: Transition from language to literature. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 435 and CHIN 445. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 441 or CHIN 311 or CHIN 444.
CHIN441.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN443.name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Heritage)
CHIN443.desc: Continuation of CHIN 441. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 437 and/or CHIN 447. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 443 or CHIN 313 or CHIN 444.

CHIN445.name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Heritage)
CHIN445.desc: Public-speaking and writing skills at an advanced level. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 435 and/or CHIN 441. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 445 or CHIN 315 or CHIN 448.
CHIN445.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN461.name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (to Han)
CHIN461.desc: Readings in classical poetry from the pre-Qin to the end of the Han Dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 461 or CHIN 464.
CHIN461.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN463.name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (Han to Tang)
CHIN463.desc: Readings in classical poetry from the Six Dynasties to early Tang, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 463 or CHIN 464.
CHIN463.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN471.name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (Tang)
CHIN471.desc: Readings in classical poetry from the time of Du Fu (712-770) to the end of the Tang Dynasty, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 471 or 474.
CHIN471.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN473.name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (after Tang)
CHIN473.desc: Readings in classical poetry from the Song to the Qing dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 473 or 474.
CHIN473.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN483.name: Modern Chinese Literature II (Heritage)
CHIN483.desc: Historical continuation of CHIN 481. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 483 or CHIN 484.
CHIN483.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN491.name: Classical Chinese I (Heritage)
CHIN491.desc: The development of early Chinese from the classical period through the Six Dynasties (5th century BCE to 6th century CE). Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 491 or CHIN 431 or CHIN 494.
CHIN491.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN493.name: Classical Chinese II (Heritage)
CHIN493.desc: Focus in on the Tang and Song dynasties (617 - 1279). Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 493 or CHIN 433 or CHIN 494.
CHIN493.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CLCH389.name: Introduction to Classical Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
CLCH389.desc: The basics of classical Chinese grammar, with short illustrations from texts of the Warring States and early Han Period. Credit will be granted for only one of CLCH 389 or ASIA 389.
CLCH389.prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234, JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260, KORN 200. Or placement approval.

CLST105.name: Greek and Roman Mythology
CLST105.desc: Greek and Roman mythology and its interpretation. Emphasis on ancient texts read in English translation.

CLST110.name: Golden Age of Athens
CLST110.desc: The history and culture, values, and achievements of fifth-century Athens.

CLST111.name: Late Republican and Early Imperial Rome
CLST111.desc: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Late Republican and Early Imperial Rome.

CLST204.name: Gods, Graves, and Goods: The Archaeology of Ancient Greece and Rome
CLST204.desc: A survey of the material cultures of the pre-classical and classical civilizations of Greece and Rome, illustrating the principles and techniques used to illuminate the archaeological history of these civilizations.

CLST211.name: Greek Philosophy I
CLST211.desc: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato. Recommended as preparation for CLST/PHIL 212 and PHIL 310.

CLST212.name: Greek Philosophy II
CLST212.desc: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310 and PHIL 311.

CLST231.name: Ancient Greece
CLST231.desc: A survey of the ancient Greek world from the Minoan and Mycenaean (about 2000-1000 BCE) to the Hellenistic Period (323-30 BCE).

CLST232.name: Ancient Rome
CLST232.desc: A survey of the ancient Roman world from the foundation of the city to the death of Constantine.

CLST260.name: Gladiators, Games, and Spectacle in the Greek and Roman World
CLST260.desc: History, development, and social function of various forms of spectacle in ancient Greece and Rome, from the Olympic games to the Roman arena.

CLST301.name: The Technical Terms of Medicine and Biological Science
CLST301.desc: Acquaints the student with the Greek and Latin elements from which most specialized terms of modern medicine are constructed. Intended primarily for students planning to enter the medical, pharmaceutical, or biological sciences.

CLST306.name: Applied Science and Technology in Classical Antiquity
CLST306.desc: The origins and achievements of applied technology in the Greek and Roman world from the Bronze Age to late Antiquity, with special attention to archaeological evidence.

CLST307.name: Greek Law
CLST307.desc: The study of Greek legal theory, practice, and institutions from their origin in self-help, through the early lawgivers and their codes, to the developed system of Athens in the fifth and fourth centuries. A variety of test cases from the works of the Greek orators will be explored.

CLST312.name: Women in the Roman World of Republican and Imperial Times
CLST312.desc: Women  in the Roman world in the culture of the Republic and the Empire. Literary, artistic, and mythological sources are compared and contrasted to historical, legal, and archaeological records.

CLST317.name: Classical Tragedy
CLST317.desc: The plays of the Greek and Roman tragic dramatists, in translation.

CLST331.name: Greek Art and Architecture
CLST331.desc: An introduction to the visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE.

CLST332.name: Roman Art and Architecture
CLST332.desc: An introduction to the visual culture of the ancient Roman world from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE.

CLST333.name: Greek Religion
CLST333.desc: A survey of both traditional and exoteric religious practices from the Archaic to the Hellenistic period.  Some knowledge of ancient Greece is recommended.

CLST353.name: The Early Roman Empire
CLST353.desc: Roman imperial history during the Julio-Claudian and Flavian periods (30 BC-96 AD).

CLST355.name: The Athenians and their Empire
CLST355.desc: The sources (literary, epigraphical and other) for Athens' emergence as one of the two leading city-states in late archaic and classical Greece and the stages by which her empire grew.

CLST356.name: Alexander the Great and his Empire
CLST356.desc: The rise of Macedon under Philip II leading to its domination of Greece and the overthrow of the Persian Empire by his son, Alexander; the subsequent spread of Greek civilization in the East.

CNRS370.name: Theories of Myth
CNRS370.desc: Origins, nature, and transmission of myth in the Western tradition, with particular attention devoted to the interpretation of myth from ancient times up to the present. Some background in myth is recommended.

CNRS410.name: The Archaeology of Ancient Cyprus
CNRS410.desc: An overview of the archaeology of ancient Cyprus from the island's initial colonization in the 10th millennium BCE through the period of its rule as part of the Roman Empire (4th century CE).

COGS200.name: Introduction to Cognitive Systems
COGS200.desc: Interdisciplinary examination of human mental processes and how these are mediated by the brain. Will draw on cognitive psychology, linguistics, cognitive neuroscience, philosophy, artificial intelligence. [3-0-0]
COGS200.prer: second-year standing in the Faculty of Arts or Science.

COGS300.name: Understanding and Designing Cognitive Systems
COGS300.desc: Theory and methods for integrating diverse disciplinary content in cognitive systems. [2-3-0]

COGS303.name: Research Methods in Cognitive Systems
COGS303.desc: Examination and comparison of the research methodologies of different disciplines relevant to cognitive systems. [3-0-0]

COGS401.name: Seminar in Cognitive Systems
COGS401.desc: Interdisciplinary seminar integrating theory, methods, and current research topics. [1-0-4]

COMM100.name: Introduction to Business
COMM100.desc: An overview of all functional areas of business. Students will be introduced to the computer and internet tools commonly used in business. For non-Commerce students only.

COMM101.name: Business Fundamentals
COMM101.desc: The different disciplines of business and their combination in management planning and decision-making.

COMM120.name: Business Immersion
COMM120.desc: A broad introduction to the field of business and how the different disciplines within business interact and combine in business decision-making. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

COMM202.name: Career Fundamentals
COMM202.desc: Fundamentals of career management including effective resume and cover letter writing, performing well in interviews and learning about the recruiting cycles, networking and resources available at the Hari B. Varshney Business Career Centre.

COMM220.name: Business Communications and Ethics
COMM220.desc: An experiential course covering a broad range of business writing and communications. Ethical challenges and issues will be presented throughout the course and form an integral part of the content, particularly in the major assignments and in-class activities.

COMM292.name: Management and Organizational Behaviour
COMM292.desc: Behaviour in organizations as it affects people as individuals, their relationships with others, their performance in groups and their effectiveness at work.

COMM296.name: Introduction to Marketing
COMM296.desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services.
COMM296.crer: COMM 293 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

COMM298.name: Introduction to Finance
COMM298.desc: Introduces the basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 298 or COEC 298.
COMM298.prer: All of COMM 290, COMM 293 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

COMM306.name: Urban Land Economics
COMM306.desc: Examines economic factors affecting the urban land market, with an emphasis on determinants of urban land values, the housing market, urban transportation, and land use policies.

COMM307.name: Real Estate Investment
COMM307.desc: Evaluation of investment in real estate assets; proforma analysis, property and asset management, equity securitization, appraisal, and international real estate investment.
COMM307.prer: One of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301 and one of COMM 297, COMM 298.

COMM311.name: Research Theory for Commerce Scholars
COMM311.desc: Social science research: theory, research design, methods, and criticism. For students in the Commerce Scholars Program only.

COMM320.name: Financial Accounting
COMM320.desc: Preparation of financial statements and use of financial information contained in financial statements to make better decisions.

COMM321.name: Organizational Behaviour
COMM321.desc: Effects of individual and group behaviour on organizational processes and outcomes. Application of relevant frameworks from the social sciences to particular organizational situations.

COMM336.name: Introduction to e-Business
COMM336.desc: Fundamental concepts for moving into e-Business including: technology infrastructure; security; electronic payment systems; business-to-consumer and business-to business e-commerce; business models; strategy, behavioral and interface issues; legal and privacy concerns cases.

COMM337.name: Business Programming and Analytics
COMM337.desc: Introduction to object-oriented computer programming; computational thinking; program design; scripting; documentation techniques; file handling; database access; and web crawling techniques. Students will apply data structures and programming constructs to the development of business analytics and other related applications.

COMM353.name: Financial Accounting: Intermediate I
COMM353.desc: An examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.
COMM353.crer: Either (a) all of COMM 297, COMM 397 or (b) COMM 298.

COMM354.name: Cost Accounting
COMM354.desc: The provision and analysis of cost accounting information that will assist management in making operating decisions and in evaluating operational performance. The utilization of statistical analysis and linear models is included.
COMM354.prer: All of COMM 290, COMM 291, COMM 293, COMM 294.

COMM355.name: Income Taxation
COMM355.desc: A study of income tax from the standpoint of the individual and of business enterprise.

COMM362.name: Consumer Behaviour
COMM362.desc: The use of consumer research and theory in marketing and policy decisions. Psychological, sociological and economic theory and research relevant to consumer behaviour are considered.

COMM363.name: Marketing Analysis
COMM363.desc: Analytical methods applicable to marketing management decision making; attention to strategic considerations linking analysis of consumer data, corporate data, environmental factors, and competitive response. The course makes extensive use of micro computers.

COMM365.name: Market Research
COMM365.desc: The process of marketing research including topics such as problem/opportunity formulation, research objectives, data sources, research instrument design, sampling, data collection and processing and methods of data analysis.
COMM365.prer: All of COMM 290, COMM 291 and either (a) COMM 296 or (b) COMM 396;  and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

COMM370.name: Corporate Finance
COMM370.desc: Examination of corporate enterprise decisions including capital budgeting; capital structure choice, and financial policies, tools, and valuation.

COMM371.name: Investment Theory
COMM371.desc: Basic concepts of finance, including security valuation, security markets, and financial decisions concerning risk and return. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 371 or COEC 371.

COMM374.name: Applied Financial Markets
COMM374.desc: Introduction to methodologies and evidence concerning the structure and operation of security markets and the valuation of financial securities including stocks, bonds, options and futures contracts; portfolio management, corporate finance and investment decisions.

COMM377.name: International Financial Markets and Institutions
COMM377.desc: Structure, nature and institutions of foreign exchange markets, including spot, forward, futures, options, and offshore currency markets. Factors affecting exchange rates are also discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 377 or COEC 377.

COMM382.name: Economics of Entrepreneurship and Innovation
COMM382.desc: Fundamental economic issues faced by entrepreneurs who want to commercialize innovations within start-ups and established firms.

COMM387.name: Entrepreneurial Finance
COMM387.desc: Financial issues encountered by those active on the investing side of entrepreneurship, such as working for banks, venture capital firms, or corporate venture organizations, or anyone interacting with entrepreneurs and private equity investors.

COMM388.name: Design Methods for Business Innovation
COMM388.desc: Studio-based experience in thinking strategies and design processes applied to business innovation in the private, public, and social sectors. Emphasis on problem solving, co-creation, and innovation for external clients in a collaborative environment.

COMM389.name: Creativity in Business
COMM389.desc: The role and importance of creativity in developing successful business solutions.

COMM405.name: Real Estate Finance
COMM405.desc: The role of mortgage markets, mathematical analysis of return and valuation issue and methods of dealing with lender and borrower risk exposure.

COMM407.name: Real Estate Economics
COMM407.desc: The economics of real estate markets. Topics include real estate cycles and bubbles, search models and vacancy, the relationship between real estate and the economy, housing demand, and models of housing supply.

COMM408.name: Real Estate Development
COMM408.desc: The development process from theories of development, market analysis, site selection, project design, land use regulation and financial analysis.
COMM408.prer: One of COMM 297, COMM 298 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

COMM412.name: Negotiation
COMM412.desc: Negotiation simulations to provide experience and confidence in the negotiation process and to develop effective skills for achieving objectives.

COMM414.name: Data Visualization and Business Analytics
COMM414.desc: Descriptive analytics including data analysis and visualization. Predictive analytics including forecasting and various statistical techniques. Predictive analytics including optimization, Monte Carlo simulation, decision trees, and discrete event simulation.

COMM415.name: Quantitative Policy Analysis
COMM415.desc: Quantitative evaluation of public policies using statistical evaluation methods, cost benefit, and effectiveness analyses. Public policies affecting service provision and infrastructure investment in air, rail, marine, public transit, and pipelines evaluated on pricing, operating costs, productivity, safety, security, and the environment.

COMM420.name: Marketing
COMM420.desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services. Analytical frameworks and techniques that are used to guide marketing strategy decisions.

COMM421.name: Corporate Finance
COMM421.desc: Introduces the basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions.

COMM431.name: Law of Business Associations
COMM431.desc: The application of various statutes to business entities including corporations, partnerships, societies, co-operatives, credit unions, trust companies and banks; the consequences of bankruptcy on legal entities.

COMM434.name: Land Law
COMM434.desc: Legal principles and concepts relating to real estate and land development.

COMM436.name: Information Systems Analysis and Design
COMM436.desc: The process of information systems development; modern techniques and tools for systems analysis and design.

COMM438.name: Management of Information Systems
COMM438.desc: Managerial issues in the administration of computerized information systems.

COMM443.name: Service Operations
COMM443.desc: This primarily case-based course will cover service operations in general (50%), health care operations (25%), and revenue management (25%). Applications of queuing models will be included in both services in general and healthcare.

COMM444.name: Air Transportation
COMM444.desc: An integrative treatment of air transport management including: demand analysis, sales and marketing, globalization trends, aircraft selection and fleet planning; airport economics and management.

COMM445.name: Maritime and International Transportation
COMM445.desc: The characteristics of shipping services and the role of shipping services in the design and management of international logistics systems.

COMM447.name: Applied Project Management
COMM447.desc: Evaluation of transport projects in the private and public sector; cost benefit analysis and related framework; project management, financing transport infrastructure.

COMM449.name: Supply-Chain Management
COMM449.desc: Integrated management of production and logistics systems; management of inter-organizational  relationships in the supply chain, including vendor selection, bidding and negotiation processes, partnering and performance measurement.

COMM450.name: Financial Accounting - Intermediate II
COMM450.desc: Intermediate II. Continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

COMM452.name: Taxes and Decision Making
COMM452.desc: Analysis of business and financial decisions in the presence of taxes.

COMM453.name: Financial Accounting-Advanced
COMM453.desc: An examination of advanced financial accounting.

COMM454.name: Accounting for Management Control and Incentives
COMM454.desc: Design of accounting systems for facilitating and influencing management decisions, with emphasis on performance evaluation in organizations.

COMM455.name: Principles of Auditing
COMM455.desc: Principles of internal control, audit evidence, sampling and testing; audit reports; standards; responsibilities of the external auditor.

COMM458.name: Fundamentals of Managerial Accounting
COMM458.desc: Use of accounting data in decision making by businesses; financial statement analysis; cash flows; cost behaviour patterns; methods of accounting for costs. (For non-Commerce students only).

COMM459.name: Financial Statement Analysis
COMM459.desc: An examination of financial statement information from the perspective of decision makers external to the firm, e.g., investors and financial institutions.
COMM459.prer: COMM 293 and one of COMM 297, COMM 298 and one of COMM 370, COMM 397.

COMM460.name: Social and Nonprofit Marketing
COMM460.desc: Examines the role, use, and application of marketing in government agencies and nonprofit institutions.

COMM461.name: Business Development
COMM461.desc: Principles and practice of personal selling and leadership of teams: strategy, tactics, and implementation.

COMM462.name: Integrated Marketing Communication
COMM462.desc: Marketing communication campaign strategy, conceptual framework, and practical application for integrated marketing communications, including advertising.

COMM464.name: Digital Marketing
COMM464.desc: Investigation of Internet-based marketing, emphasizing customer-focused perspectives, competitive situations and analysis of the effectiveness of business websites using marketing principles and practices.

COMM466.name: New Venture Design
COMM466.desc: Teams comprising students in COMM 466 and APSC 486 propose a new product, produce a viable prototype, and develop a business plan for the marketplace.  Credit may only be obtained for one of COMM 466 and APSC 486.

COMM467.name: Brand Management
COMM467.desc: Issues and challenges commonly faced by brand managers, including: assessing brand meaning, evaluating brand health, assessing a brand?s leverage potential, evaluating brand extensions, managing brands through a crisis, and assessing brand value.

COMM468.name: Marketing Applications
COMM468.desc: Applied marketing planning with emphasis on a major industrial analysis and the subsequent development of a detailed marketing plan for an operating organization.

COMM469.name: International Marketing
COMM469.desc: An analysis of the scope and significance of contemporary international business operations with particular reference to the marketing management problems encountered by firms with multinational branches and subsidiaries.

COMM471.name: Mergers and Acquisitions
COMM471.desc: Mergers and acquisitions as a focal point in making important corporate decisions deduced from careful study of relevant business cases.

COMM474.name: Fixed Income Markets and Management
COMM474.desc: Fixed income instruments and derivatives. Risk profiles and their use in establishing fixed income investment portfolios. Performance attribution techniques.

COMM475.name: Investment Policy
COMM475.desc: The management of security portfolios for individual and institutional investors; relation of investment policy to money markets and business fluctuations.

COMM477.name: Risk Management and Financial Engineering
COMM477.desc: Principles of financial engineering and risk management. Use of derivatives in risk management. Valuation and hedging models for contingent claims.

COMM482.name: New Product Development
COMM482.desc: How new products are developed and the factors that influence success and failure throughout the various stages of development.

COMM483.name: Leadership and General Management
COMM483.desc: Integration and application of business knowledge to make business decisions across disciplines; development of personal leadership ability and style. Case-based with guest speakers.

COMM484.name: Sustainability Marketing
COMM484.desc: Role of marketing in creating social value. Integration of marketing fundamentals with core social, environmental, and economic principles of sustainability. Analysis of current sustainability trends. Development of strategic and practical marketing recommendations for for-profit enterprises. Potential and pitfalls of sustainability marketing.

COMM485.name: Social Entrepreneurship
COMM485.desc: An applied course that examines the innovative, growing, and rapidly evolving field of social entrepreneurship, which tackles social and environmental challenges through business perspectives and methods.

COMM487.name: Environmental Management
COMM487.desc: Explores corporate environmental strategy by introducing economic principles underlying environmental policy, law, and technologies for pollution prevention and abatement, environmental management systems, ISO-14001, energy systems, eco-marketing, and life-cycle analysis.  Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 487 or COMM 597.

COMM497.name: New Enterprise Development
COMM497.desc: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies.
COMM497.prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

CPEN281.name: Technical Communication
CPEN281.desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
CPEN281.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

CPEN311.name: Digital Systems Design
CPEN311.desc: Advanced combinational and sequential electronic system design. Hardware specification, modeling, and simulation using hardware description languages (HDLs) and CAD tools. Design with programmable logic including FPGA's. Applications include complex state machines, microcontrollers, arithmetic circuits, and interface units. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 353, CPEN 311 and EECE 379.
CPEN311.prer: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

CPEN312.name: Digital Systems and Microcomputers
CPEN312.desc: Data representation in digital computers; boolean algebra; the design and optimization and implementation of combinatorial and sequential circuits; modern digital circuit technologies; memory and programmable logic devices; organization and operation of microcomputers; data/address bus organization; input-output interfacing. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 355, CPEN 312, EECE 259, CPEN 211, and EECE 256.
CPEN312.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 252, ELEC 204, EECE 263, ELEC 203, MECH 221.

CPEN391.name: Computer Engineering Design Studio II
CPEN391.desc: Design and implementation of a hardware platform and software design and implementation at the operating system and application layers.  Project management skills. Effective presentations.
CPEN391.prer: One of CPEN 291, ELEC 291, ELEC 292, EECE 281 and one of EECE 353, CPEN 311.

CPEN421.name: Software Project Management
CPEN421.desc: Advanced project planning, cost estimation and scheduling. Project management tools. Factors influencing productivity and success. Productivity metrics. Analysis of options and risk. Tools. Case studies.

CPEN432.name: Real-time System Design
