CPEN432.desc: Multi-tasking; interrupt-driven systems; task scheduling; schedulability analysis; inter-process communication and synchronization; resource management; performance measurement; hardware/software integration; hardware/software tradeoffs; system reliability.
CPEN432.prer: One of EECE 314, CPEN 333, EECE 315, CPEN 331, CPSC 313.

CPEN442.name: Introduction to Computer Security
CPEN442.desc: Security risks, threats, and vulnerabilities from technical perspectives; confidentiality, integrity, and hybrid policies; cryptography, access control, assurance, accountability, and engineering of secure systems.
CPEN442.prer: One of EECE 314, CPEN 333, EECE 315, CPEN 331, CPSC 313.

CPEN491.name: Computer Engineering Capstone Design Project
CPEN491.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world computer engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

CPEN492.name: Software Engineering Capstone Design Project
CPEN492.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world software engineering problem.  Projects are provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ECON210.name: Microeconomic Policy
ECON210.desc: A survey of policy issues, such as regulation, taxation, environmental and resource policy, health care, education and income distribution.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

ECON211.name: Macroeconomic Policy
ECON211.desc: A survey of policy issues, such as the costs of inflation and unemployment, monetary and fiscal policy, the effects of government debt and exchange rate policy.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

ECON226.name: Making Sense of Economic Data
ECON226.desc: Formulation of a testable hypothesis, identification of relevant data, use of appropriate statistical tools.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing in ECON or COMM. Not available for credit to students already having credit for either of ECON 325 or ECON 326 (or equivalent).

ECON234.name: Wealth and Poverty of Nations
ECON234.desc: Historical approaches to long-run economic growth; international comparisons of income growth and inequality; colonialism; evolution of world capital markets; human migrations; rise of world trading empires; instability in the international economy.  Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 234 or former ECON 334 (6).  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

ECON255.name: Understanding Globalization
ECON255.desc: Social and economic implications for both rich and poor countries of lowered barriers to the international flows of information, capital, labour and goods.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

ECON303.name: Intermediate Microeconomics II
ECON303.desc: Risk and uncertainty, some concepts in game theory, adverse selection, moral hazard, bargaining, auctions. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 303 and 306.

ECON304.name: Honours Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis I
ECON304.desc: Consumer behaviour, producer theory, exchange, monopoly, oligopoly, externalities, public goods, general equilibrium and welfare economics. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 301 or 304 or COMM 295.
ECON304.prer: A score of 68% or higher in all of ECON 101, MATH 104, MATH 105.

ECON305.name: Honours Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis I
ECON305.desc: Income and employment theory, monetary theory, the open economy, economic fluctuations and growth. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 302, ECON 305.
ECON305.prer: A score of 68% or higher in all of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

ECON306.name: Honours Intermediate Microeconomics II
ECON306.desc: Risk and uncertainty, some concepts in game theory, adverse selection, moral hazard, bargaining, auctions. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 303 and 306.
ECON306.prer: A score of 68% or higher in ECON 304. Permission of the School is also acceptable.

ECON307.name: Honours Intermediate Macroeconomics II
ECON307.desc: Theories of economic growth and the business cycle. Intended primarily for prospective honours and other qualified students.
ECON307.prer: A score of 68% or higher in ECON 305. Or permission of the School.

ECON308.name: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
ECON308.desc: Mathematical and graphical models of individual, household, and firm behavior with applications to issues in international economics. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 301, 304, or 308.
ECON308.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 105 and one of MATH 104, MATH 184.

ECON309.name: Intermediate Open Economy Macroeconomics
ECON309.desc: The aggregate economy with emphasis on macroeconomic policy and international economic growth, money and inflation, unemployment, business cycles, and macroeconomic stabilization policy under fixed and flexible exchange rates. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 302, 305, or 309.
ECON309.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 105 and one of MATH 104, MATH 184.

ECON310.name: Principles of Microeconomics
ECON310.desc: The scope of this course is approximately the same as that of ECON101. The course is intended for upper-level students only. Credit will be given for only one of ECON 310 and ECON 101.

ECON311.name: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON311.desc: The scope of this course is approximately the same as that of ECON 102. The course is intended for upper-level students only. Credit will be given for only one of ECON 311 and ECON 102.

ECON317.name: Poverty and Inequality
ECON317.desc: Economic inequality in Canada and other countries; measurement and causes. Inequality in the distribution of wealth; redistribution of income and wealth; notions of distributive justice.

ECON318.name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Aristotle to Adam Smith
ECON318.desc: The development of economic thought from Aristotle to Adam Smith, focusing on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution, and economic growth.

ECON319.name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes
ECON319.desc: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present including such figures as Malthus, Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.

ECON327.name: Introduction to Empirical Methods
ECON327.desc: Basic tools for the statistical analysis of economic data. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 325, ECON 327,or STAT 200.
ECON327.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 105 and one of MATH 104, MATH 184.

ECON328.name: Methods of Empirical Research
ECON328.desc: Empirical tools used in applied research, with emphasis on the linear regression model. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 326, ECON 328, or STAT 306.

ECON334.name: Economic History of Modern Europe
ECON334.desc: Background, causes and effects of economic change in Europe from the 18th century to recent times. Evolution of social and economic institutions; analysis of growth, structural change, the distribution of income, and the spread of industrialization.

ECON335.name: Fertility, Families and Human Migration
ECON335.desc: Traditional fertility and mortality patterns, demographic transition, catastrophes, well-being and nutrition, international and internal migration, epidemics and growth spurts.

ECON336.name: Economic History of Canada
ECON336.desc: The growth of the Canadian economy in relation to development of natural resources, changing markets, industrialism, communications, and technology.

ECON339.name: Economics of Technological Change
ECON339.desc: Application of economic analysis to technological change; the impact of technological change on the growth and distribution of income; economic influences on the invention and diffusion of technology; the interaction between technology, work, skills, and education; public policy toward technological change.

ECON350.name: Public Finance Policy Topics
ECON350.desc: Examination of two or three selected policy problems from areas of taxation, income security, and public expenditures. Topics to be selected each year from areas of current or recent policy debate. Examples include public pension policy, privatization and public services, income tax or sales tax reform, federal-provincial cost sharing programs, tax incentives versus direct expenditures, welfare reform.

ECON365.name: Topics in Canadian Industrial Organization and Regulation Policy
ECON365.desc: Current topics in industrial organization and regulation with emphasis on Canadian federal and provincial policy. The content will differ from year to year. Possible subjects include the regulation of transportation and communications, environmental regulation, marketing boards and other forms of agricultural regulation, competition and anti-combines policy, industrial organization and trade policy, and issues in consumer protection.

ECON367.name: Economic Analysis of Law
ECON367.desc: The economics of market failure, equity and efficiency. Property rights, the economics of accident and contract law, economic theories of law enforcement.

ECON370.name: Benefit-Cost Analysis and the Economics of Project Evaluation
ECON370.desc: Techniques and problems in benefit-cost analysis of public projects. Examination of alternative approaches to public decision-making such as cost-effectiveness analysis and multiple-objective frameworks. Case studies of projects in the areas of natural resources, the environment, human resources, public services, and transportation.

ECON371.name: Economics of the Environment
ECON371.desc: Economic analysis applied to various environmental issues, including sustainable development, quality of life, and environmental impacts of specific industrial and consumption activities. The design and implementation of government policies. Global environmental effects of human economic activity.

ECON374.name: Land Economics
ECON374.desc: Economic analysis applied to problems of land use. Rent theory. Land valuation. Land conservation. Techniques for assessing economic efficiency of land use. Effects of institutions and public policies on land use.

ECON390.name: Introduction to Economic Research
ECON390.desc: Selected topics in economic research.  Application of research methods to economic data.  Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 390, ECON 490, ECON 495, or ECON 499.

ECON406.name: Topics in Microeconomics
ECON406.desc: Selected topics in advanced microeconomic analysis.
ECON406.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 303, ECON 306.

ECON407.name: Topics in Macroeconomics
ECON407.desc: Selected topics in advanced macroeconomic analysis.
ECON407.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305 and one of ECON 303, ECON 306.

ECON420.name: Optimization and Economic Theory
ECON420.desc: An introduction to static and dynamic optimization methods with economic applications.
ECON420.prer: MATH 200 and one of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 303, ECON 306. Permission of the instructor is also acceptable.

ECON421.name: Introduction to Game Theory and Applications
ECON421.desc: Principles of rational behaviour in strategic situations and various notions of equilibrium useful in predicting outcomes. Applications from economics, business, politics, law and biology.

ECON425.name: Introduction to Econometrics
ECON425.desc: Theoretical and applied issues in statistics and econometrics. Statistical distributions, sampling theory, maximum likelihood methods of estimation and hypothesis testing, generalized least squares, measurement errors, non-normal errors, systems of equations, discrete-choice models, outliers, regression diagnostics, and model selection.

ECON441.name: The Process of Economic Development
ECON441.desc: Industrialization of an agrarian economy; how the West grew rich; history of Japanese development; technical progress and growth; evolution of the patterns of income distribution; role of international trade in development; environment and development.

ECON447.name: Monetary Theory
ECON447.desc: Theoretical analysis of economies that use money; the emergence of money; the roles of money in the economy; models of money demand; the optimal quantity of money seignorage and inflation; monetary policy and macroeconomic stability; monetary policy in an open economy.
ECON447.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305.

ECON451.name: Economics of Public Expenditures
ECON451.desc: The role of government in the economy; efficiency and economic justice. Theory of public goods; applications to topics such as education, medical care and social services. Pricing and investment rules for public enterprises.

ECON455.name: International Trade
ECON455.desc: International trade theory and policy in general equilibrium; relative costs, factor proportions, imperfect competition and the pattern of trade; efficiency and distribution. Credit granted for only one of ECON355 and ECON455.

ECON457.name: Seminar in International Economic Relations
ECON457.desc: Selected topics focusing upon various issues arising in international economic relations. Open only to fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

ECON465.name: Market Structure
ECON465.desc: Market structure and social welfare, theory of price discrimination, equilibrium in oligopolistic markets, entry and exit decisions, product differentiation and spatial models, theories of hierarchical organization, agency problem in the modern corporation, vertical integration and control, market structure and technical progress.

ECON466.name: The Economics of Government Regulation of Business
ECON466.desc: Normative and positive theories of government regulation of business. Topics include natural monopoly, socially optimal monopoly pricing, regulation of multi-firm industries, competition policy. Selected empirical studies.

ECON472.name: Economics of Renewable Resources
ECON472.desc: Application of economic analysis to the management of renewable resources. Special attention is given to criteria for the optimal use of depleting resources such as forests and water. Other topics include public policy with regard to environmental quality, conservation, and outdoor recreation.

ECON482.name: The Economic Consequences of Religion
ECON482.desc: Analysis of the economic aspects of religious behaviour, the structure of religious organizations, the effects of competition in the religious marketplace, the economic benefits of religion, and some of the ill-effects of religion (such as religious strife and terrorism).

ECON485.name: Political Economy
ECON485.desc: State and politics in economics. How states emerge, how dictators stay in power. Why groups engage in costly conflict, how countries turn into democracies and what its benefits are.
ECON485.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304, ECON 308 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305, ECON 309 and all of ECON 325, ECON 326.

ECON490.name: Seminar in Applied Economics
ECON490.desc: Selected problems and issues in the theory and practice of Economics. Each section will focus on a different field. Restricted to Economics Majors, and Combined Majors in Economics their final academic session.
ECON490.prer: All of ECON 325, ECON 326 and one of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305. For additional possible prerequisites see individual course descriptions on the School's  website.

ECON493.name: Advanced Empirical Methods for International Economics
ECON493.desc: Econometric methodologies necessary to conduct applied research, including time series analysis and panel data methods; review of empirical work in international economics.  Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program.

ECON494.name: Seminar in Applied International Economics
ECON494.desc: Focus on a particular aspect of applied international economics. Independent empirical research project required.  Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program.

ECON495.name: Honours Seminar
ECON495.desc: Reports and group discussions of selected topics for fourth-year Honours students.

ECON499.name: Honours Essay
ECON499.desc: Essay on some theoretical, applied, or institutional problem. Open only to fourth-year Honours students.

ELEC201.name: Circuit Analysis I
ELEC201.desc: The fundamentals of analysis of lumped linear time-invariant circuits; network theorems; operational amplifiers; first order circuits; DC analysis of diodes, BJT, and FET circuits.
ELEC201.prer: MATH 101 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153, PHYS 158.

ELEC202.name: Circuit Analysis II
ELEC202.desc: Phasor analysis and AC three phase systems power; transfer functions; Bode plots; filters and resonance; Laplace transforms; transformers; two-port networks. First and second order circuits.
ELEC202.prer: All of PHYS 153, MATH 101 and one of EECE 251, EECE 263, ELEC 201, ELEC 203.

ELEC203.name: Basic Circuit Analysis
ELEC203.desc: Ideal passive elements and sources; Kirchhoff's Laws; DC circuits; natural and complete response of first order circuits; operational amplifiers; impedance; phasors; complex power. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

ELEC204.name: Linear Circuits
ELEC204.desc: Basic concepts and analysis techniques in the context of electric and electronic circuits including Bode plots and the Laplace transform. Treatment of RLC circuits, phasors, op-amps. Introduction to nonlinear circuit elements, diodes, BJT, FET circuits.
ELEC204.prer: MATH 152 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 158, PHYS 153.

ELEC205.name: Electronics Laboratory
ELEC205.desc: Experiments involving electronic devices and circuits.

ELEC211.name: Engineering Electromagnetics
ELEC211.desc: Electrostatics, electric currents, dielectrics, capacitance, electrostatic potential, magnetostatics.
ELEC211.prer: One of MATH 263, MATH 253 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153, PHYS 158.

ELEC221.name: Signals and Systems
ELEC221.desc: Complex numbers, LTI systems, convolution sum, discrete-time Fourier series and transforms, z-transform, sampling, introduction to filtering and modulation, feedback systems, stability.

ELEC271.name: Selected Topics in Biomedical Engineering
ELEC271.desc: Effective communication in a multidisciplinary environment, introduction to emerging areas of biomedical engineering and biotechnology, ethics, and responsibility. Restricted to students admitted to the Biomedical Engineering program in Electrical Engineering.

ELEC281.name: Technical Communication
ELEC281.desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
ELEC281.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

ELEC301.name: Electronic Circuits
ELEC301.desc: Analysis and design of electronic circuits; biasing of and small-signal models for transistors; frequency response of amplifiers; feedback and stability aspects of amplifier design; OP-AMPs; active filters; oscillators; IC specification and selection. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 356, ELEC 301, and EECE 374.
ELEC301.prer: Either (a) one of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 263, ELEC 203 and one of EECE 253, ELEC 202;  or (b) one of EECE 252, ELEC 204.

ELEC302.name: Electronic Circuits for Electromechanical Design
ELEC302.desc: Semiconductor fundamentals; modelling of electronic devices including diodes and transistors; design of power supplies, waveform generators and logic circuits; signals in time and frequency domains; operational amplifiers; active filters; oscillators; device specification and selection.
ELEC302.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 263, ELEC 203, MECH 221.

ELEC311.name: Electromagnetic Fields and Waves
ELEC311.desc: Waves and propagation; Maxwell's equations; applications including transmission lines; impedance matching and Smith charts; reflection and refraction; waveguides and antennas.
ELEC311.prer: One of EECE 261, ELEC 211 and either (a) all of MATH 101, MATH 263, MATH 265, MATH 267 or (b) all of MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 264, MATH 265, MATH 267 or (c) all of MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 256, MATH 264.

ELEC315.name: Electronic Materials and Devices
ELEC315.desc: Fundamental aspects of electronic materials such as: semiconductors, metals, dielectrics, piezoelectrics, magnetic materials, and their applications in devices such as diodes, transistors, and transducers.

ELEC342.name: Electro-Mechanical Energy Conversion and Transmission
ELEC342.desc: Three phase power; transformers and harmonics; magnetic materials and circuits, electromechanical energy conversion; DC machines; rotating magnetic field, AC induction and synchronous machines; variable frequency operation, brushless DC machines; stepper and single-phase motors. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 373, ELEC 342, and EECE 374.
ELEC342.prer: PHYS 170 and one of EECE 253, EECE 263, ELEC 202, ELEC 203.

ELEC343.name: Electromechanics
ELEC343.desc: Electromechanical energy conversion; linear actuators; torque/speed of rotating devices; reluctance, stepper, permanent-magnet, induction, brushless-DC motors and DC motors; actuator/motor drive circuits/controllers. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 365, ELEC 344, EECE 370, EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 374, EECE 376, or ELEC 343.
ELEC343.prer: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202, EECE 363, ELEC 302.

ELEC344.name: Applied Electronics and Electromechanics
ELEC344.desc: Characteristics of semiconductor devices; analog circuits; force and torque production; motor principles and torque-speed characteristics; principles of power electronics. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.
ELEC344.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 263, ELEC 203, MECH 221.

ELEC352.name: Electric Energy Systems
ELEC352.desc: Balanced and unbalanced three phase energy systems. Modeling of generators, transmission lines, transformers and loads. High voltage transmission, low voltage industrial and domestic distribution.
ELEC352.prer: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202 and one of EECE 373, ELEC 342.

ELEC371.name: Biomedical Engineering Instrumentation
ELEC371.desc: Theory and experiments involving instruments for general, orthopedic, cardiac and minimally invasive surgery as well as sensors for respiratory, cardiac, bioelectric, biochemical and nervous system measurement. Restricted to students admitted to the Biomedical Engineering option in Electrical Engineering.
ELEC371.prer: Either (a) all of MATH 265, MATH 267 or (b) MATH 256;  and one of MATH 253, MATH 263;  and either (a) EECE 253 or (b) all of ELEC 202, EECE 259 or (c) all of CPEN 211, EECE 261 or (d) all of ELEC 211, EECE 282 or (e) ELEC 292.

ELEC401.name: Analog CMOS Integrated Circuit Design
ELEC401.desc: Design and analysis of analog integrated circuits, with emphasis on CMOS design techniques. Gain stages, opamp design, frequency compensation, oscillators, A/D, D/A converters, PLL, DLL.
ELEC401.prer: One of EECE 356, ELEC 301, EECE 363, ELEC 302, EECE 374.

ELEC402.name: Introduction to VLSI Systems
ELEC402.desc: Static CMOS combinational logic circuits. Standard cells design and layout. Memory element (flip-flop and latch) design. Dynamic logic families. Synchronous logic and timing analysis. Power, scaling, and industry trends. Verification. VHDL/Verilog design, layout and synthesis project using CAD tools.

ELEC403.name: Advanced Digital VLSI Systems
ELEC403.desc: Logical effort. Noise in digital systems. Low power techniques. Power distribution. SRAM and DRAM design. Non-volatile memory technologies. High speed adder, multiplier and divider design. Clock Trees. Synchronization and FIFO. Scaling, and industry trends. High-speed circuit design and layout project.

ELEC404.name: RF Integrated Circuits
ELEC404.desc: Introduction to radio-frequency (RF) communication systems; matching networks, transceiver architectures, low noise amplifiers, mixers, oscillators, etc.

ELEC411.name: Antennas and Propagation
ELEC411.desc: Basic antenna concepts; antennas for low, medium and high frequencies; terrestrial and satellite propagation links; environmental effects on electromagnetic radiation.
ELEC411.prer: One of EECE 364, ELEC 311, PHYS 301, PHYS 354.

ELEC412.name: Optical Waveguides and Photonics
ELEC412.desc: Planar dielectric waveguides; single mode optical fibers; integrated optics waveguides and devices; semiconductor lasers; optical detectors; optical communications links.

ELEC413.name: Semiconductor Lasers
ELEC413.desc: An introduction to lasers and applications. Theory, modeling, fabrication and performance of semiconductor lasers. Optical communications links.

ELEC415.name: Semiconductor Devices: Physics, Design and Analysis
ELEC415.desc: Physics of operation, and design and analysis of semiconductor devices of topical interest, e.g., solar cells, LEDs, high-speed MOSFETs, high-frequency HBTs, low-noise HEMTs.

ELEC421.name: Digital Signal and Image Processing
ELEC421.desc: DSP fundamentals; image processing; signal representation; digital filtering; statistical estimation; DSP applications.
ELEC421.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359, EECE 369.

ELEC422.name: Biosignals and Systems
ELEC422.desc: Data acquisition, time and frequency domain analysis, analog and discrete filter design, sampling theory, time-dependent processing, linear prediction, random signals, biomedical system modeling, and stability analysis; introduction to nonlinear systems.
ELEC422.prer: One of EECE 331, ELEC 371 and one of EECE 360, ELEC 341 and one of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359 and one of CPSC 260, CPSC 259 and one of STAT 251, MATH 318, MATH 302, STAT 302.

ELEC431.name: Communication Systems I
ELEC431.desc: Review of probability theory, signals and noise; digital communication over Gaussian noise channels, optimal receiver design, modulation techniques and error performance calculations; measure of information, source coding, symbol and stream codes; channel coding, capacity, simple linear block codes; practical applications.
ELEC431.prer: One of EECE 269, EECE 359, ELEC 221 and one of EECE 357, ELEC 321, MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 251, STAT 302, STAT 357.

ELEC432.name: Communication Systems II
ELEC432.desc: Communication over bandlimited additive white Gaussian noise channels; power spectra of digitally modulated signals; intersymbol interference; cyclic, convolutional, low-density parity check and turbo codes; trellis coded modulation; spread spectrum techniques; security; wireless communication systems and standards; practical applications.

ELEC433.name: Error Control Coding for Communications and Computers
ELEC433.desc: Design techniques, including Hamming, BCH, Reed-Solomon, LDPC and convolutional codes, ARQ techniques, and LFSR implementation of encoding-decoding algorithms.

ELEC434.name: Introduction to Optical Networks
ELEC434.desc: Wavelength division multiplexing, framing techniques, traffic grooming, virtual topology design, routing and wavelength assignment, protection and restoration, optical packet switching.
ELEC434.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359, EECE 369.

ELEC441.name: Control Systems
ELEC441.desc: Relationships between system parameters and system responses for linear control systems. Design specifications for dynamic and steady-state performance and realization by use of feedback control. Robust design of PID controllers and multivariable controllers.

ELEC442.name: Introduction to Robotics
ELEC442.desc: Common manipulator configurations, actuator and sensor technology. Efficient representations and computational methods for real-time microprocessor-based implementation of robot control algorithms. Robot control methods, network equivalents, impedance control. Introduction to teleoperation implementation aspects.

ELEC451.name: Power Electronics
ELEC451.desc: Power diodes, thyristors, transistors and FETs; analysis of idealized circuits with generalized loads; AC-DC, DC-DC, DC-AC, AC-AC converters, modulation techniques, gating circuits; practical design and applications.
ELEC451.prer: One of EECE 356, EECE 365, ELEC 301, ELEC 344, EECE 373, ELEC 342.

ELEC453.name: Power System Analysis
ELEC453.desc: Transmission and distribution; phasors, complex power; balanced/unbalanced three-phase operation; symmetrical components, sequence networks; voltage regulation; short circuit capacity; circuit breakers; transmission lines, series/shunt impedance; short, medium, and long line models.

ELEC454.name: Power System Analysis II
ELEC454.desc: Power system monitoring/control; large networks; automatic generation control; optimum power flow calculations; traveling wave transmission lines; EMTP and MATLAB programs for transients, short-circuit, and transient stability analysis.

ELEC455.name: Power Systems Protection
ELEC455.desc: Analysis of disturbances, security of power systems, cascading and blackouts; role and impact of protection; transducers and measuring elements; protection of transmission and distribution systems; protection of generators, substation equipment, special protection systems and relays.
ELEC455.prer: One of EECE 458, ELEC 453 and one of EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 374.

ELEC456.name: Decision Support Methods in Power Systems Operation
ELEC456.desc: Principles; acceptable regions of operation; energy management systems; load flow methods; static and dynamic security; contingency analysis; transient and voltage stability; on-line stability assessment.

ELEC457.name: Optimization of Power System Operation
ELEC457.desc: Application of linear and nonlinear optimization methods in power systems; constrained optimization; optimal power flow; economic dispatch; electricity market; local prices for active and reactive power; security-constrained OPF; state estimation, reliability analysis.

ELEC461.name: Nanotechnology in Electronics
ELEC461.desc: Topics of special importance to understanding and designing electronic devices in which quantum effects and the discrete nature of matter become important.
ELEC461.prer: One of CHEM 312, EECE 352, ELEC 315, PHYS 250, PHYS 304.

ELEC462.name: Sensors and Actuators in Microsystems
ELEC462.desc: The mechanisms, design, fabrication, and testing of microsensors, actuators, and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS).

ELEC463.name: Micro/Nanofabrication and Instrumentation Laboratory
ELEC463.desc: Microfabrication methods and nanofabrication techniques. Imaging and characterization of micro and nanostructures. Restricted to students admitted to the Nanotechnology and Microsystems Option in Electrical Engineering.

ELEC465.name: Microsystems Design
ELEC465.desc: Structured modeling and design practices; multiphysics at microscales; physical limitations in MEMS; interface with electronics; behavioural modeling languages for mixed analog-digital system design. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 489, ELEC 465, or EECE 581.

ELEC471.name: Medical Imaging
ELEC471.desc: Physical principles of ultrasound, magnetic resonance, computed tomography, X-ray projection imaging and molecular imaging in medical imaging for diagnostics, therapeutics, and interventions.
ELEC471.prer: One of EECE 331, ELEC 371 and one of EECE 360, ELEC 341 and one of EECE 364, ELEC 311 and one of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359.

ELEC473.name: Biological Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems
ELEC473.desc: Principles of sensors, actuators, microfluidics, biotechnology and nanotechnology, with applications in probing, detection, assaying and drug delivery.

ELEC474.name: Biophotonics
ELEC474.desc: Lens theory, light sources and detectors, image resolution and contrast, tissue absorption and scattering, fluorescence, microscopy, spectroscopy, optical imaging systems, and their applications to life sciences and medicine.

ELEC491.name: Electrical Engineering Capstone Design Project
ELEC491.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world electrical engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ELEC492.name: Electrical Energy Systems Capstone Design Project
ELEC492.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world electrical energy systems problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ELEC493.name: Nanotechnology and Microsystems Capstone Design Project
ELEC493.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world nanotechnology and microsystems engineering problem.  Projects are provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ELEC494.name: Biomedical Engineering Capstone Design Project
ELEC494.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world biomedical engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ENPH352.name: Laboratory Techniques in Physics
ENPH352.desc: Some of the experiments will be based on the lecture material for PHYS 301. Other techniques and subjects will also be covered. [0-3-0]

ENPH459.name: Engineering Physics Project I
ENPH459.desc: Project planning, management and reporting. This course involves writing a project proposal, carrying out an open-ended Engineering project, and reporting the results both orally and in writing.

ENPH479.name: Engineering Physics Project II
ENPH479.desc: Projects designed to give students research development and design experience. Projects are provided by research faculty in Science and Engineering and from local industry.

ENPH480.name: Engineering Physics Project III
ENPH480.desc: An optional course for those students wishing to continue their project work beyond the development in ENPH 479.

ENPH481.name: Entrepreneurial Projects I
ENPH481.desc: A project course for students pursuing entrepreneurial training within Engineering Physics, and wishing to further develop projects resulting from ENPH 459.

EOSC111.name: Laboratory Exploration of Planet Earth
EOSC111.desc: An examination of the processes that shape and change the planet earth.  This laboratory course accompanies any of EOSC 110, EOSC 112, EOSC 114, EOSC 116.  Course content is customizable at the individual student level. [0-3-0]
EOSC111.crer: One of EOSC 110, EOSC 112, EOSC 114, EOSC 116.

EOSC210.name: Earth Science for Engineers
EOSC210.desc: Focus on the interaction between society and the geologic environment.  Locating, assessing and developing natural resources; understanding and preparing for natural hazards, design of structures and waste disposal sites.  For applied science and forestry students only. [3-2-0]

EOSC212.name: Topics in the Earth and Planetary Sciences
EOSC212.desc: Cutting edge problems in earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences.  Topics will be introduced through discussions of the current literature. [3-0-0]
EOSC212.prer: Second-year standing in science or engineering.

EOSC213.name: Computational Methods in Geological Engineering
EOSC213.desc: Combining basic physical principles with their mathematical description and generating computational models that describe them. Introduction to basic building blocks in modeling, simulation and parameter estimation. [3-1-0]
EOSC213.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of APSC 160, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, EOSC 211.

EOSC220.name: Introductory Mineralogy
EOSC220.desc: Introduction to crystallography, physical and chemical properties of minerals. Recognition and identification of common minerals. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-3-0]

EOSC221.name: Introductory Petrology
EOSC221.desc: Optical mineralogy and the classification and genesis of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks. [2-3-0]

EOSC223.name: Field Techniques
EOSC223.desc: Introduction to the techniques of geological mapping and the interpretation of field data. Includes three one-day field trips on weekends plus a seven-day field school after Spring examinations. A fee is to be paid by January 31. [2-2-0]

EOSC240.name: Site Investigation
EOSC240.desc: Theory and practice of site investigation for geological engineers, including background studies, field work, remote sensing, development of ground models, importance of geological variability and uncertainty. Impacts on design, project risk and decision making. [2-2-0]

EOSC250.name: Fields and Fluxes
EOSC250.desc: Application of classical theory of scalar and vector fields to geophysical sciences. Conductive, convective and radiative energy flux, gravitation, electrostatics, and magnetostatics. Gauss' and Stokes' theorems. [3-0-0]
EOSC250.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157.
EOSC250.crer: MATH 200. One of PHYS 102, 108, 118, 158 is recommended.

EOSC270.name: Marine Ecosystems
EOSC270.desc: Introduction to diversity of marine habitats and ecosystems; hydrothermal vent, intertidal, coral reef, estuarine, deep sea, and polar ecosystems; impacts of ecosystem change; evolution of ocean plankton; invasive species; climate change; pollution. [3-0-0]
EOSC270.prer: One of SCIE 001, CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154.

EOSC311.name: The Earth and its Resources
EOSC311.desc: An introduction to the Earth with emphasis on its industrial and aesthetic resources. Rocks, minerals, gold, diamonds, sediments, fossils, oil and gas, canyons, and volcanoes and the processes that create them. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. No background in Science or Mathematics is required. [3-0-0]

EOSC314.name: The Ocean Environment
EOSC314.desc: An introduction to the oceans and the processes that have shaped them, their composition and movement, waves, tides, beaches, interactions with the atmosphere and human exploitation of the non-living resources. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science. No background in Science or Mathematics is required. [3-0-0]

EOSC320.name: Sedimentology
EOSC320.desc: Origin, diagenesis and geochemistry of sediments and sedimentary rocks. [2-2-0]
EOSC320.prer: EOSC 221 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.

EOSC321.name: Igneous Petrology
EOSC321.desc: The origin and formation of igneous rocks. [2-3-0]

EOSC322.name: Metamorphic Petrology
EOSC322.desc: Deciphering lithospheric processes as recorded by the mineralogy, chemistry and textures of metamorphosed rocks. [2-3-0]

EOSC323.name: Structural Geology I
EOSC323.desc: Analysis and interpretation of natural deformation. [2-3-0]
EOSC323.prer: All of EOSC 221, EOSC 223 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.

EOSC328.name: Field Geology
EOSC328.desc: Recording and processing geological data in the field. Held within the three weeks following April examinations after third year. A special fee is to be paid by January 31.
EOSC328.prer: All of EOSC 323, EOSC 330 and one of EOSC 321, EOSC 322.

EOSC329.name: Groundwater Hydrology
EOSC329.desc: Introduction to theory of groundwater flow; flow nets; regional groundwater resource evaluation; well hydraulics; role of groundwater in geologic processes. [2-3*-3*]
EOSC329.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

EOSC330.name: Principles of Geomorphology
EOSC330.desc: Landform development; morphological and historical analysis of landforms; applications in engineering and resource development. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2-0]

EOSC331.name: Introduction to Mineral Deposits
EOSC331.desc: Introduction to economic geology and models related to mineral exploration. Study includes typical deposit types and their plate tectonic setting. [2-3-0]

EOSC332.name: Tectonic Evolution of North America
EOSC332.desc: An overview of the geology and tectonic evolution of North America; comparisons and contrasts between Precambrian rocks of the North American craton and Phanerozoic belts of the Cordilleran, Appalachian, Ouachita and Innuitian orogens;  interrelations between sedimentation, deformation, metamorphism and magmatism in a plate tectonic context. [3-0-0]
EOSC332.prer: EOSC 323 or permission of the instructor.

EOSC333.name: Elemental and Isotopic Geochemistry
EOSC333.desc: Analytical methods in geochemistry, major and trace element geochemistry, radiogenic isotopes, geochemistry of seawater, the mantle, basalts, subduction zones, sedimentary rocks, continental crust. [2-3-0]

EOSC340.name: Global Climate Change
EOSC340.desc: Mechanisms and processes of past and future global environmental and climate change. [3-0-0]
EOSC340.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

EOSC350.name: Environmental, Geotechnical, and Exploration Geophysics I
EOSC350.desc: Principles of geophysical survey design, data acquisition, processing and interpretation with emphasis on near-surface problems. Magnetic, seismic reflection/refraction, electromagnetic and ground penetrating radar surveys. Case history analysis of environmental and geotechnical problems. [3-2-0]
EOSC350.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 253 and third-year standing or higher in Science or Applied Science.

EOSC352.name: Geophysical Continuum Dynamics
EOSC352.desc: Introduction to tensor calculus and continuum mechanics. Stress, strain and strain-rate tensors. Mass, momentum and energy balance. Applications to problems of geophysical heat transport, elasticity and fluid dynamics illustrated using MATLAB. [3-0]

EOSC353.name: Seismology
EOSC353.desc: Hooke's law for isotropic continua, elastic wave equation, reflection and refraction methods for imaging the Earth's internal structure, plane waves in an infinite medium and interaction with boundaries, body wave seismology, inversion of travel-time curves, generalized ray theory, crustal seismology, surface waves and earthquake source studies. [3-3*]

EOSC354.name: Analysis of Time Series and Inverse Theory for Earth Scientists
EOSC354.desc: Continuous and discrete Fourier transforms, correlation and convolution, spectral estimates, optimum least-squares filters, deconvolution and prediction, frequency-wave number filtering. A practical course on computer techniques applied to the analysis of a wide range of geophysical phenomena. [3-2-0]
EOSC354.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157.

EOSC420.name: Volcanology
EOSC420.desc: Field and lab-based studies in volcanology concentrating on physical and chemical aspects of volcanic processes. [2-3-0]

EOSC422.name: Structural Geology II
EOSC422.desc: Studies of natural deformation using advanced techniques. [2-3-0]

EOSC424.name: Advanced Mineral Deposits
EOSC424.desc: Advanced concepts in the processes that lead to the formation of mineral deposits. Introduction to the study of ore minerals using reflected light microscopy. [2-3-0]

EOSC425.name: Paleontology
EOSC425.desc: Paleobiogeography in the context of plate tectonics. Mass extinction events. Fossilization and biases in the fossil record. Species concepts in paleontology. Biostratigraphy. Paleontological evidence for early life; the colonization of oceanic and terrestrial environments and; the evolution of the primates. [2-3-0]

EOSC428.name: Field Techniques in Groundwater Hydrology
EOSC428.desc: Hydraulic head measurements, water-quality sampling, pump and slug testing, infiltration measurements, profiling techniques. Held over five days after spring term at the Richmond groundwater hydrology field-school site. Enrolment limitations.
EOSC428.prer: EOSC 329 or permission of the instructor.

EOSC429.name: Groundwater Contamination
EOSC429.desc: Contaminant transport processes in groundwater flow systems; aqueous and multiphase transport; mathematical models describing migration and chemical evolution of contaminant plumes; case studies. [2-2-0]

EOSC430.name: Aqueous Geochemistry
EOSC430.desc: Quantitative approaches to practical aqueous geochemistry problems. Equilibrium thermodynamics, kinetics, complexation, oxidation reduction, cation exchange, sorption and partitioning of organics. Case Studies. [2-2-0]
EOSC430.prer: Either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) CHEM 154.

EOSC442.name: Climate Measurement and Analysis
EOSC442.desc: Local climate time series collection and analysis. Retrieval and analysis of on-line climate data and model output. [0-3-0]
EOSC442.prer: EOSC 340 and one of CPSC 110, CPSC 301, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, BIOL 300.

EOSC445.name: Engineering Design Project
EOSC445.desc: Geological engineering design project from scope definition to final design.  Based on a problem from industry. [2*-3-0, 2*-3-0]

EOSC450.name: Potential Fields in Earth and Planetary Sciences
EOSC450.desc: Theory, application and quantitative interpretation of potential field methods in Earth and planetary sciences. Topics drawn from problems in geophysical exploration, geodesy, geodynamics of the planets, geomagnetism, planetary magnetic fields, heat flow and fluid flow. [3-0-0]
EOSC450.prer: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316, MATH 257 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, SCIE 001.

EOSC453.name: Physics of the Earth and Other Planets
EOSC453.desc: Identification and quantitative analysis of diverse physical problems in the earth, ocean, atmospheric, and planetary sciences. [3-0-0]

EOSC454.name: Applied Geophysics
EOSC454.desc: Using geophysics to characterize the Earth's subsurface for resource exploration, engineering, or environmental applications. Data acquisition, processing, and interpretation of geophysical surveys. Inversion examples drawn from potential (electrical, magnetic, gravity) or wave field (seismic, ground penetrating radar) surveys. [3-2-0]
EOSC454.prer: All of EOSC 352, EOSC 353, EOSC 450 and one of PHYS 301, PHYS 354.

EOSC470.name: Biological Oceanography
EOSC470.desc: A quantitative examination of processes regulating the abundance, distribution and production of phytoplankton, zooplankton, microbes and fish. Controls of primary and secondary production, ecosystem dynamics and foodwebs. [3-0-0]

EOSC471.name: Waves, Currents and Ocean Mixing
EOSC471.desc: Use of observations, theory and model results to solve physical oceanographic problems including applications to transport and mixing of pollutants or nutrients. [3-0-0]
EOSC471.prer: EOSC 211 and one of ATSC 201, EOSC 372, GEOB 200 and one of SCIE 001, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

EOSC472.name: Chemical Oceanography and Marine Geochemistry
EOSC472.desc: Controls on chemical composition and elemental distributions in seawater and marine sediments (including nutrient elements, dissolved gases, the carbonate system, marine organic matter, and trace metals); solution chemistry of seawater; isotopic tracers of rates and dates in marine systems; geochemical balance in the oceans. [3-0-2*]

EOSC473.name: Methods in Oceanography
EOSC473.desc: Methods of data acquisition, study and analysis required in solving oceanographic problems. Includes a field school held during the mid-term break. A fee is to be paid by January 31. Open to third- and fourth-year students in Oceanography, or with permission of the Department Head. [0-3-0]

EOSC474.name: Marine Pollution
EOSC474.desc: An interdisciplinary study of pollution, with examples drawn from coastal and oceanic environments, including areas of local interest. Intended for third and fourth year students with a background in the sciences. [3-0-0]

EOSC475.name: Marine Microbiology
EOSC475.desc: Advanced biology, ecology and diversity of marine microbes. Emphasis on the roles of bacteria and viruses in marine foodwebs and geochemical cycles. [3-0-0]
EOSC475.prer: A minimum of 6 credits of third-year level life science courses.

EOSC478.name: Introduction to Fisheries Science
EOSC478.desc: An introduction to the ecology and management of freshwater and marine fisheries. Topics include: population dynamics, species interactions, communities, environmental influences, stock assessment, economics and sociology of fisheries. Laboratories will consist of numerical analyses and simulations. [2-0-3]

FIPR101.name: Introduction to the History of Film Production
FIPR101.desc: The history of film and film production by decade with a strong emphasis on filmmakers and advances in production technology.

FIPR131.name: Introduction to Screen Acting
FIPR131.desc: Fundamental techniques used to create emotionally engaged and narratively effective performances for film and digital media.

FIPR133.name: Introduction to Film and Media Production
FIPR133.desc: A hands-on introduction to Film and Multi/New Media production, focusing on fundamental techniques for creating effective presentations.

FIPR230.name: Introduction to Motion Picture Directing
FIPR230.desc: The role and methods of the motion picture director.

FIPR233.name: Film and Media Production I
FIPR233.desc: Camera operation, lighting, sounds, and editing for film and media production.

FIPR234.name: Production Planning and Professional Practices
FIPR234.desc: Planning of film productions from concept to completion.

FIPR333.name: Film and Media Production II
FIPR333.desc: Intermediate film and media production. Open only to students in the Film Production BFA Program. Students who have not already completed FIPR 337, FIPR 338 must complete them at the same time as FIPR 333.

FIPR337.name: Cinematography and Lighting I
FIPR337.desc: Introductory cinematography and lighting techniques and aesthetics for 16mm film and digital media.

FIPR338.name: Motion Picture Sound
FIPR338.desc: An introduction to the technique and aesthetics of creating production and post-production sound for film and media.

FIPR339.name: Post-Production Techniques I
FIPR339.desc: Open only to students in the Film Production BFA Program.

FIPR434.name: Producing for Film and Television
FIPR434.desc: The creative and business aspects of producing for film and television.

FIPR437.name: Cinematography II
FIPR437.desc: Advanced camera operation, lighting, and shot design. Open only to students in the FILM BFA Program.

FIPR439.name: Post-Production Techniques II
FIPR439.desc: Advanced instruction in motion picture and sound editing practice. Open only to students in FILM BFA Production Program.

FIST100.name: Introduction to Film Studies
FIST100.desc: Basic aesthetic, economic, sociological, and technological aspects of film.

FIST200.name: Introduction to Canadian Cinema
FIST200.desc: History and aesthetics of Canadian cinema.

FIST210.name: Early Cinema
FIST210.desc: Aesthetics, economics, history, and technological characteristics of international early film.

FIST220.name: Hollywood Cinema 1930-1960
FIST220.desc: Analysis of the aesthetics, economics, history and technological characteristics of the Classical Hollywood period.

FIST230.name: Introduction to Asian Cinema
FIST230.desc: Overview of the cinemas of China, India, Japan, and Korea.

FIST240.name: Media Industries
FIST240.desc: Overview of today's film and media industries, and of the concepts governing their practices.

FIST331.name: Studies in Film Theory
FIST331.desc: A seminar introducing the many theoretical approaches to film: formalist, historical, Marxist, psychoanalytic, semiotic, and structuralist.

FIST334.name: Seminar in Documentary
FIST334.desc: An analysis of the representational strategies and ethics of the form.

FIST336.name: Seminar in European Cinema
FIST336.desc: Topics may include a study of a European national cinema.

FIST338.name: Asian and Australasian Cinema
FIST338.desc: Topics may include an analysis of a national cinema, such as that of China, India, or Australia.

FIST340.name: Media Audiences
FIST340.desc: Overview of approaches for studying audiences and receptions of film and contemporary media.

FIST436.name: Seminar in American Cinema Since 1960
FIST436.desc: Topics may include an analysis of a specific period.

FIST449.name: Honours Essay
FIST449.desc: A course allowing honours students to work with a faculty member on a major research paper.

FNEL101.name: Introduction to a Salish Language I
FNEL101.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures and listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed.

FNEL102.name: Introduction to a Salish Language II
FNEL102.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use.

FNEL141.name: Introduction to a Wakashan Language I
FNEL141.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL142.name: Introduction to a Wakashan Language II
FNEL142.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL180.name: Introduction to Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
FNEL180.desc: Foundational concepts in the critical study of cultural, historical, social, and political factors that impact language loss, retention, and revival. Introducing strategies and practical methodologies for collaborative, interdisciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization projects for First Nations and Indigenous languages.

FNEL201.name: Intermediate Salish Language I
FNEL201.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context.

FNEL202.name: Intermediate Salish Language II
FNEL202.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use.

FNEL281.name: Sounds of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
FNEL281.desc: Development of skills in the perception and transcription of speech sounds in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Aboriginal languages. Capacity-building techniques for digital recording, editing, analysis, and archiving; guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals.

FNEL380.name: Technologies for Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
FNEL380.desc: Digital tools for endangered language documentation, conservation, and revitalization. Overview of best practices, introduction to community engagement and capacity-building, protocols and ethics, project design, cultural context, orthographies, use of audio, video and still photography, data management, archiving and web publishing.

FNEL381.name: Biocultural Diversity: Language, Community, and Environment
FNEL381.desc: Critical exploration of the links between linguistic, biological and cultural diversity; including connections with linguistic relativity, linguistic identity, language and place; and strategies for collective, interdisciplinary action to promote and support the protection of languages, cultures, and the environment.

FNEL482.name: Applied Research in Endangered Language Reclamation
FNEL482.desc: Application of research skills and methodologies in the design and implementation of a research project relevant to endangered language conservation and/or revitalization. Project co-constructed in collaboration with a First Nations community, guided by community-based ethical protocols. FNEL 481 recommended.
FNEL482.crer: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282, FNEL 389. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 482.

FNH300.name: Principles of Food Engineering
FNH300.desc: Units and dimensions, mass balance, energy balance, steady state and transient heat flow, fluid handling and measurement. [3-0-1]

FNH301.name: Food Chemistry I
FNH301.desc: Constituents of food and related chemical physical properties including water, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, minerals, and vitamins. [3-0-1]
FNH301.prer: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

FNH302.name: Food Analysis
FNH302.desc: Principles of and procedures for analysis of the chemical and physical properties of food; proximate analysis; introduction to instrumental analysis; reporting and analysis of data. [3-0-1]
FNH302.prer: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

FNH303.name: Food Product Development
FNH303.desc: Introduction to and application of concepts involved in food product formulation and development.
FNH303.prer: One of LFS  252, BIOL 300, EPSE 482, FRST 231, STAT 200.

FNH309.name: Food Process Science
FNH309.desc: Preservation of tissue and fluid food systems by selected physical and chemical treatments with emphasis on product-process interactions. [3-0-1]

FNH313.name: Microorganisms in Food Systems
FNH313.desc: Microorganisms of importance in safety, spoilage and preservation of foods; factors affecting growth, survival and inactivation of microorganisms in fermented food systems; food processing plant cleaning and sanitation. [3-0-0]

FNH325.name: Food Science Laboratory I
FNH325.desc: Integrated laboratory introducing techniques used in food processing and analysis. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students. [0-3-1]
FNH325.prer: All of FNH  300, FNH  301, FNH  302. These courses can be taken as corequisites.

FNH326.name: Food Science Laboratory II
FNH326.desc: Integrated laboratory encompassing the processing and analysis of foods.  Enrolment restricted to Food Science students. [0-3-1]

FNH335.name: Introduction to Wine Science II
FNH335.desc: Review of diverse styles of wine with consideration of classic wine-producing areas. Concepts in wine microbiology/chemistry; overview of steps in grape processing for diverse wine styles. Comparison of regulations for Canadian VQA systems with international systems. Wine sensory analysis. [3-1-0]
FNH335.prer: FNH  330 and third-year standing or higher.

FNH340.name: Food Theory
FNH340.desc: Principles of food preparation based on the physical and chemical properties of food.
FNH340.prer: FNH  200 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123.

FNH341.name: Food Theory Applications
FNH341.desc: Experimental and practical application of scientific principles and theories to problems of food preparation. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe I certificate.

FNH342.name: Critical Perspectives on Consumer Food Practices
FNH342.desc: Personal, collective, and policy factors affecting food choices, including perceptions of healthy eating, gender, identity, family structures, and economic, sociocultural, and political forces. [3-0-0]
FNH342.prer: At least third year standing required.

FNH350.name: Fundamentals of Nutrition
FNH350.desc: Fundamentals of energy and macronutrient metabolism. [3-0-0]
FNH350.prer: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

FNH351.name: Vitamins, Minerals, and Health
FNH351.desc: Vitamin and mineral nutrition and their role in maintaining and promoting health. [3-0-0]
FNH351.prer: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

FNH370.name: Nutrition Assessment
FNH370.desc: The use of dietary, anthropometric, biochemical, and related information for the assessment of nutritional status of individuals and populations. [3-0-0]

FNH371.name: Human Nutrition Over The Life Span
FNH371.desc: Nutritional requirements and dietary patterns of healthy individuals throughout the life span. 3-0-0

FNH380.name: Professional Dietetic Practice I
FNH380.desc: Introduction to the profession of dietetics in Canada. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.

FNH398.name: Research Methods in Human Nutrition
FNH398.desc: Process of research; principles and processes in utilizing research. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program. [3-0-0]
FNH398.prer: FNH  250 and either (a) LFS  252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.

FNH402.name: Functional Foods and Nutraceuticals
FNH402.desc: Functional food and nutraceutical concepts related to ingredient safety and quality; examples of nutrient-disease relationships, requirements for standards of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional food and nutraceutical industries. [3-0-0]

FNH403.name: Food Laws, Regulations and Quality Assurance
FNH403.desc: Canadian and international laws governing food composition, grading, quality and safety; hazard analysis critical control points; statistical quality assurance. [3-0-1]
FNH403.prer: LFS  252 or equivalent background in statistics.

FNH405.name: Microbiology of Food and Beverage Fermentation
FNH405.desc: Fermentation methods, mechanism and microbiology of nonalcoholic fermented foods and alcoholic fermented beverages (beer, cider, sake).
FNH405.prer: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, BIOL 201, BIOL 203, BIOC 203. Third-year standing.

FNH413.name: Food Safety
FNH413.desc: Microbial and chemical factors that underlie public health challenges in the food supply chain; prevalence and nature of organisms which cause foodborne diseases; approaches and technologies for improvement of food safety.

FNH415.name: Business Concepts in Food, Nutrition, and Health
FNH415.desc: Introduction to and application of business activities in food, nutrition, and health settings. Credit will only be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515, or FRE 515.
FNH415.prer: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.

FNH425.name: Food Science Laboratory III
FNH425.desc: Integrated course designed to illustrate principles of research and product development in the food industry. [0-3-1]

FNH436.name: Integrated Functional Genomics
FNH436.desc: Global transcript, protein and metabolite profiling technologies, their integration, application, and furtherance of our understanding of how higher organisms function in general.

FNH440.name: Food Service Systems Management
FNH440.desc: Management responsibilities in quantity food production with emphasis on menu planning, purchasing and service. Includes planning and equipping food services. Restricted to students in the Dietetics major. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe II certificate.

FNH451.name: Nutrient Metabolism and Implications for Health
FNH451.desc: Integration of nutrient and energy metabolism on a whole-body and individual tissue basis and the implication for health. Emphasis will be on regulation of nutrient metabolism. [3]

FNH455.name: Applied International Nutrition
FNH455.desc: Applying nutrition concepts and principles in addressing problems of malnutrition and food insecurity in international settings.  Basics of developing culturally acceptable, sustainable nutrition intervention programs.

FNH470.name: Foundations of Nutrition Care I
FNH470.desc: Etiology and pathophysiology of and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions, and skill development related to the Nutrition Care Process. Restricted to students in year 4 of the Dietetics Major.

FNH472.name: Maternal and Fetal Nutrition
FNH472.desc: Metabolic adaptations, nutrient metabolism, and special issues during pregnancy that may influence the maternal-fetal nutritional supply. [3-0-0]

FNH473.name: Applied Public Health Nutrition
FNH473.desc: Theory and methods in public health nutrition and health promotion program planning to assess, plan, implement, and evaluate nutrition-related programs for communities and populations. Considers factors affecting behavior and the social determinants of health. [3-0-0]

FNH474.name: Sport Nutrition
FNH474.desc: Nutritional needs of athletes, including energy, carbohydrate and protein; hydration; pre-and post-event nutrition, weight management and body composition issues; ergogenic aids; sports-specific guidelines; and special athlete populations.

FNH475.name: Foundations of Nutrition Care II
FNH475.desc: Etiology and pathophysiology of and nutrition therapy for additional diseases and conditions, and further skill development related to the Nutrition Care Process. Restricted to students in year 4 of the Dietetics Major.

FNH477.name: Nutrition and Disease Prevention
FNH477.desc: Evidence-based examination of the role of nutrition in the prevention of chronic disease. [3-0-0]

FNH481.name: Dietetic Internship I
FNH481.desc: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.
FNH481.prer: Fifth-year standing in the Dietetics Major.

FNH482.name: Dietetic Internship II
FNH482.desc: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.

FRE295.name: Managerial Economics
FRE295.desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Organization of the firm, demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 201, ECON 206, FRE 295, COMM 295. [3-0-0]
FRE295.prer: Either (a) ECON 100 or (b) all of ECON 101, ECON 102;  and MATH 105.

FRE302.name: Small Business Management in Agri-food Industries
FRE302.desc: Emphasizes the building of a business plan by exploring topics such as the planning process and financing, marketing and human resource concepts, as applied to an agri-food business, domestically and internationally. [3-0-1]

FRE306.name: Introduction to Global Food Markets
FRE306.desc: An overview of global food markets including recent trends (e.g., vertical coordination, strategic alliances, multinationals and small firms in niche markets), marketing and trade institutions such as state-trading enterprises and WTO regulations, issues specific to developing nations, and case studies. [3-0-1]

FRE340.name: International Agricultural Development
FRE340.desc: Characteristics, processes and sources of economic growth, role of agricultural and resource sectors in economic growth, analysis of output and input markets in those sectors, policy failures, tools for empirical analysis of rural markets, growth, and the environment. [3-0]

FRE374.name: Land and Resource Economics
FRE374.desc: Willingness to pay, opportunity costs, externalities, and market failures in natural resource markets; dynamic efficiency; economic applications including mineral, marine, forest, land, water, and biodiversity. [3-0]

FRE385.name: Quantitative Methods for Business and Resource Management
FRE385.desc: Spreadsheet modeling and analysis of business and resource management problems: decision analysis, forecasting, linear programming, simulation modeling, and inventory management. [2-1-0]
FRE385.prer: One of ECON 101, ECON 310 and one of LFS  252, BIOL 300, FRST 231, STAT 200.

FRE420.name: The Economics of International Trade and the Environment
FRE420.desc: Market failure and gains from trade in the presence of natural resource externalities; the multilateral trading system and the environment; case studies in trade-related environmental impacts. [3-0]
FRE420.prer: One of ECON 301, FRE  295, COMM 295 or 6 credits of upper-level FRE or ECON.

FRE460.name: Economics of Food Consumption
FRE460.desc: Microeconomics of consumer decisions and public policy in food contexts; foodborne illness; economic causes and consequences of obesity; sin taxes and prohibitions; information campaigns and advertising; labeling; food waste and ethics. [3-0]

FRE490.name: Current Issues in Food and Resource Economics

FREN122.name: Contemporary French Language and Literature I
FREN122.desc: A review of French grammar and an introduction to contemporary literature written in French, with emphasis on essay writing and textual analysis.
FREN122.prer: One of FREN 12, FREN 112 or equivalent.

FREN123.name: Contemporary French Language and Literature II
FREN123.desc: Continuation of FREN 122 with emphasis on literature, essay writing and textual analysis.
FREN123.prer: FREN 122 or assignment based on placement test.

FREN124.name: Keeping Up Your French
FREN124.desc: Task-based entry-level course for non-specialists. Credits from this course may not count towards a Major or Minor in French, nor as prerequisite to subsequent core courses in French.
FREN124.prer: One of FREN 12, FREN 112 or equivalent.

FREN215.name: Oral French Practice
FREN215.desc: Opportunities for students already well-grounded in grammar to improve their oral skills. Credit will not be given for both FREN 215 and FREN 224 or FREN 225.

FREN221.name: Introduction to Modern Literature written in French and to Textual Analysis
FREN221.desc: Students will familiarize themselves with techniques of literary analysis, as applied to representative works from the 18th century to the present, including theatre, fiction, poetry and non-fiction prose.  To be taken by all students intending to proceed to the Minor, Major or Honours program.
FREN221.prer: FREN 123 or assignment based on placement test.

FREN222.name: French Language and Style I
FREN222.desc: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context.
FREN222.prer: FREN 123. Or assignment based on placement test.

FREN223.name: French Language and Style II
FREN223.desc: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context.
FREN223.prer: FREN 222. Or assignment based on placement test.

FREN224.name: An Interdisciplinary Approach to French I
FREN224.desc: French language for ex-immersion students. Credit will not be granted for both FREN 215 and FREN 224. Not available for credit to anyone who has received credit for FREN 222.

FREN225.name: An Interdisciplinary Approach to French II
FREN225.desc: French language for ex-immersion students. Credit will not be granted for both FREN 215 and FREN 225. Not available for credit to anyone who has received credit for FREN 223.

FREN329.name: Selected Works of European French Literature
FREN329.desc: Representative works viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

FREN330.name: Selected Works of Quebecois Literature
FREN330.desc: Representative works viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

FREN334.name: French Civilization II
FREN334.desc: A historically based approach to French civilization and culture from the Third Republic to the present, completed by a thematic study of contemporary French culture.
FREN334.prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223 or permission of the instructor.

FREN351.name: Corrective French Phonetics
FREN351.desc: Theory and practice of French pronunciation, corrective phonetics; foundation for the phonetic transcription of international French.

FREN353.name: French Grammar
FREN353.desc: Systematic study of the fundamental principles of French grammar.

FREN355.name: Advanced Composition
FREN355.desc: Development of essay writing skills in French.

FREN370.name: Introduction to French Linguistics
FREN370.desc: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French linguistics, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced language study in French.

FREN371.name: Introduction to French Literary Theory and Methodology
FREN371.desc: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French literary criticism, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced study of literature in French.

GERM200.name: Intermediate German I
GERM200.desc: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies.

GERM210.name: Intermediate German II
GERM210.desc: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies; introduction to German for professional purposes.

GERM300.name: Intermediate German III
GERM300.desc: Fluency in many relevant situations; competence in the most important areas of cultural life; familiarity with study resources and study skills. Review and expansion of grammar; fostering of speaking and writing skills.

GERM301.name: German Literature 1900 - 1945 (in English)
GERM301.desc: Reading and discussion of selected works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in twentieth-century Germany with special emphasis on plays and novels dealing with the First World War and Nazism.

GERM302.name: German Literature after 1945 (in English)
GERM302.desc: Reading and discussion of selected literary works from West, East, and the United Germany, as well as from Austria and Switzerland.

GERM303.name: German Literature Before 1900 (in English)
GERM303.desc: Reading and discussion of translated works from the German-speaking countries from the Middle Ages to 1900.

GERM304.name: German Cinema (in English)
GERM304.desc: Screening, discussion, and critical analysis of German cinema from the silent era to the 21st century.

GERM310.name: Intermediate German IV
GERM310.desc: Fostering of the ability to discuss controversial issues, express ideas clearly in writing and write essays on selected topics in German. Ongoing grammar review and expansion.

GERM313.name: Conversational German II
GERM313.desc: Emphasis on the study of oral communication skills and strategies. Fluency in many situations, communicative competence in important areas of cultural life, ability to participate in discussions of current as well as controversial issues to express ideas clearly in spoken word.

GERM314.name: Business German
GERM314.desc: Review of the most important grammatical patterns in application to business geography, import-export trade, marketing, finance, accounting, taxation, workplace conditions and requirements; oral and written forms of presentation for work with German business.

GERM325.name: German Translation
GERM325.desc: Theory, methodology, and practice of translation from German into English.

GERM360.name: Heaven and Earth: Studies in German Culture and Literature before 1700
GERM360.desc: Masterpieces and major trends of the German literature of the Middle Ages, Renaissance and Baroque against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

GERM380.name: Tradition and Change: Studies in the 19th Century
GERM380.desc: Masterpieces and major trends of ninteenth-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

GERM400.name: Advanced German I
GERM400.desc: Near-native competence and thorough understanding of critical contemporary topics in a limited number of areas fostering study skills. All skills will be fostered but the course focuses on accurate writing and conversation in particular.

GERM402.name: Words and Music in German Literature (in English)
GERM402.desc: Study of individual works and genres in which words and music together form a whole. Possible topics include the Lutheran Hymn, the Volkslied, the Romantic Lied and Brecht songs, operas by Mozart, Wagner and Strauss, and music and the musician as a subject in literature. No musical training is necessary to take this course.

GERM410.name: Advanced German II
GERM410.desc: Development of capabilities to deal with a variety of authentic texts from and about Germany, Austria and Switzerland; fostering of communicative skills, cross-cultural analysis and critical thinking; effective and accurate communication in both spoken and written German.

GERM411.name: Major Controversies in German Culture (in English)
GERM411.desc: Selected debates and controversies in the German-speaking countries.

GERM412.name: German Media Studies (in English)
GERM412.desc: Major themes and methods in German media studies.

GERM414.name: Business German
GERM414.desc: Review of the most important grammatical patterns in application to business geography, import-export trade, marketing, finance, accounting, taxation, workplace conditions and requirements; oral and written forms of presentation for work with German business. Formerly GERM 314.

GERM426.name: German Representations of the Holocaust (in English)
GERM426.desc: The German Nazi Holocaust in German literature and film.
GERM426.prer: Third Year Standing or permission of instructor.

GERM434.name: German for Reading Knowledge II (Languages for special purposes)
GERM434.desc: Multimedia teaching of reading skills in German for special purposes. Students are expected to work largely independently. Focuses on specific topics of the student's choice in the humanities, the natural sciences, economics/business and music and enhances skills in technical reading.
GERM434.prer: GERM 433 or no more than one year of beginner's German.

GREK101.name: First-Year Ancient Greek I
GREK101.desc: An introduction to Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part I.

GREK102.name: First-Year Ancient Greek II
GREK102.desc: An introduction to Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part II.

GREK201.name: Second-Year Ancient Greek I
GREK201.desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part I.

GREK202.name: Second-Year Ancient Greek II
GREK202.desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part II; introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Greek literature.

GREK351.name: Intermediate Ancient Greek: Prose
GREK351.desc: Readings in the major authors in Greek Prose.

GREK352.name: Intermediate Ancient Greek: Verse
GREK352.desc: Readings in the major authors in Greek Verse.

GRSJ102.name: Global Issues in Social Justice
GRSJ102.desc: Intersectional feminist theory and practice, focusing on contemporary issues in a transnational context. Credit will be granted for only one of WMST 100 or GRSJ 102.

GRSJ200.name: Gender and Environmental Justice
GRSJ200.desc: An interdisciplinary and cross-cultural overview of contemporary environmental issues, as they relate to gender equality and social justice challenges and initiatives that respond to ecological crises.

GRSJ235.name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Structures in Modern Asia
