GRSJ235.desc: Situates “Asia” in a global context and explores the complex relationships between gender, social structures, and social change.

GRSJ303.name: Gender, Race, Social Justice and the Law
GRSJ303.desc: A survey of feminist legal thought and recent developments in feminism and law, with a focus on Canada.
GRSJ303.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ305.name: Social Justice Issues in Community and International Organizing
GRSJ305.desc: Critical examination and practical applications of concepts, theories, methods, and strategies of gender-aware organizing at the community and international levels.
GRSJ305.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ306.name: Globalization and Social Justice: Gender, Race, and Sexuality in International Politics
GRSJ306.desc: Critical examination of the gender dimension of globalization and the theories, discourse, and practices in international politics using gender analysis.
GRSJ306.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ307.name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Popular Culture
GRSJ307.desc: Critical examination of mainstream and alternative media images of gender, race, and sexuality in the context of networked social media, film, music, and television.
GRSJ307.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ310.name: Gender, Race, Social Justice and Health
GRSJ310.desc: Interdisciplinary introduction to gender and health issues using selected theoretical frameworks.
GRSJ310.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ311.name: African/Black Women in the Americas
GRSJ311.desc: An interdisciplinary survey of gender studies and histories of African/Black women in the Americas from the beginning of the slave trade to the present.
GRSJ311.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ320.name: Feminist Anti-Racist Pedagogies
GRSJ320.desc: Feminist pedagogies and feminist debates about pedagogy in formal, nonformal, and informal educational settings.
GRSJ320.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ325.name: Anti-colonial and Feminist Qualitative Methodologies
GRSJ325.desc: Data collection techniques, the politics of interpretation, and the formulation of a research proposal using a feminist, anti-racist framework.
GRSJ325.prer: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ326.name: The Politics of Gender, Families, and Nation-Building
GRSJ326.desc: Investigation of historical and contemporary scholarship on the diversity of families, focusing on differences of gender, sexuality, race/ethnicity, and social class within and across national borders.
GRSJ326.prer: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ327.name: Theories of Representation and Difference
GRSJ327.desc: Feminist scholarship emphasizing languages and processes of representation and the construction of difference in cultural discourses and institutions.
GRSJ327.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ328.name: Theories of Subjectivity
GRSJ328.desc: How feminist scholarship has shaped and reinterpreted accounts of the subject, drawing on such traditions as structuralism, poststructuralism, psychoanalysis, postcolonialism, postmodernism, and Queer Theory.
GRSJ328.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ401.name: Body, Gender and Society
GRSJ401.desc: An interdisciplinary examination of the body, exploring how social relations and space are implicated in the constitution and experience of gendered bodies and identities, with an emphasis on feminist analyses of body-societal relations.
GRSJ401.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ410.name: Religious Feminism
GRSJ410.desc: Examines religious feminism from three Abrahamic traditions. An in-depth study of challenges various doctrinal discourses and practices pose for feminist projects.

GRSJ422.name: Advanced Research Seminar
GRSJ422.desc: Critical theories, methodologies, ethics and practices appropriate for advanced feminist research.
GRSJ422.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ480.name: Decolonizing Praxis: A Practicum in Social Justice
GRSJ480.desc: Connects feminist and critical race theory and practice through placement in a community organization. As is the case with all UBC practice-related courses, this course requires a Criminal Record Check. Open to GRSJ Majors or Minors. This course is graded Pass/Fail.
GRSJ480.prer: Either (a) two of GRSJ 325, GRSJ 326, GRSJ 327, GRSJ 328 or (b) two of WMST 325, WMST 326, WMST 327, WMST 328. Consult the department.

HEBR201.name: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew I
HEBR201.desc: The second year of Biblical Hebrew with emphasis on rapid reading of poetry and prose along with grammar.

HEBR202.name: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew II
HEBR202.desc: The second year of Biblical Hebrew with emphasis on rapid reading of poetry and prose along with grammar.

HGSE310.name: First Nations and Canada: (Re)writing History
HGSE310.desc: A survey of the history of Indigenous peoples in relation to the Canadian colonial state contrasting the Indigenous historical experience with conventional accounts of Canadian history.
HGSE310.crer: All of HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

HGSE311.name: Law and Governance: Indigenous and European Traditions
HGSE311.desc: Background on sources of Aboriginal and Canadian law; detail on section 35 of the Constitution Act; a review of relevant Canadian case law; insight on the importance of international law; and literature on governance.
HGSE311.crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 312, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

HGSE312.name: Perspectives on Reconciliation
HGSE312.desc: Notions of reconciliation and restitution that have emerged in Canada across space and time; key principles, discourses, legal and Constitutional mechanisms, actions and actors.
HGSE312.crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

HGSE313.name: Reconciliation and Resource Management
HGSE313.desc: Relationships and reconciliation processes between First Nations and other governments in the context of land and sea governance.
HGSE313.crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 314.

HGSE314.name: Reconciliation and Communities
HGSE314.desc: In-depth exploration of the communities of Haida Gwaii through community-based experiences and community service learning.
HGSE314.crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 313.

HGSE350.name: Case Studies in Haida Gwaii
HGSE350.desc: Integration of concepts of history, politics, First Nations, rural development, and forest ecology in natural resources management in Haida Gwaii.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

HGSE351.name: History and Politics of Resource Management
HGSE351.desc: Historical examination of resource management in Canada and conflicts arising therefrom, with emphasis on forests.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
HGSE351.crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 352, HGSE 353, HGSE 354.

HGSE352.name: First Nations Governance and Natural Resource Management
HGSE352.desc: The political, economic, and legal environment of Aboriginal-Canadian relations and its influence on resource use and management; review of historic relationships, emerging case law, and new reconciliation frameworks. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
HGSE352.crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 353, HGSE 354.

HGSE353.name: Rainforest Ecology and Management
HGSE353.desc: Ecology of the temperate rainforests of Haida Gwaii.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
HGSE353.crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 352, HGSE 354.

HGSE354.name: Diversifying Resource-Dependent Communities
HGSE354.desc: Examination of the forces that restructure local economies, both historically and contemporarily; link between rural economic development and the legacy of resource development in Aboriginal communities across British Columbia.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
HGSE354.crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 352, HGSE 353.

HGSE355.name: Applied Ecology of Coastal Terrestrial Ecosystems
HGSE355.desc: Processes that shape coastal terrestrial ecosystems through time and applications to current ecological reality.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
HGSE355.crer: All of HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

HGSE356.name: Biophysical Dynamics of the Marine-Terrestrial Interface
HGSE356.desc: Nutrient cycling between the marine environment and coastal forest ecosystems; how the physical characteristics of this interface affect inputs; which species play a pivotal role in driving interactions.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
HGSE356.crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 357, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

HGSE357.name: Ecology and Management of Island Wildlife
HGSE357.desc: Unique biological attributes of island wildlife, such as subspecies, isolated populations, and distinct evolutionary pathways, with a focus on endemic species on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 395 or HGSE 357.
HGSE357.crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

HGSE358.name: Systems Thinking for Resource Management
HGSE358.desc: Introduction to systems thinking and resilience to understand dynamics of social change and innovation; use of case studies to demonstrate applications of different types of ecological knowledge, including traditional knowledge and experiential knowledge. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
HGSE358.crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 359.

HGSE359.name: Ecosystem-Based Management Seminar
HGSE359.desc: History, definitions, and applications of EBM; challenges of achieving both economic and environmental well-being with a focus on resource use and management on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
HGSE359.crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 358.

HIST101.name: World History to Oceanic Contact
HIST101.desc: Origins and diffusion of the world's great religions; cultural contact along overland trade routes; emergence of civilizations such as the Inca, Chinese, and Christian European; ordering of societies and their political development.

HIST102.name: World History from 1500 to the Twentieth Century
HIST102.desc: The civilizations of Asia, Europe, Africa and the Americas, with emphasis on the political, economic, ecological and cultural links among them, and the impact of oceanic contact, imperialism, warfare, migration, and globalization.

HIST104.name: Topics in World History
HIST104.desc: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

HIST105.name: Contemporary Global Issues in Historical Perspective
HIST105.desc: Places issues and problems of current relevance such as disease, terrorism, drugs, or ethnic conflict in historical perspective. Each section will explore a single theme. Check with department for course offerings.

HIST235.name: History of Canada: Moments that Matter
HIST235.desc: An introduction to major turning points in Canadian history.  Exploration of the social, political, cultural, and environmental transformations/revolutions that have shaped Canada from early European colonialism to the twenty-first century.

HIST236.name: Public History in Canada: Memory, Representation, and Interpretation
HIST236.desc: An introduction to public history in Canada.  An exploration of the politics and practice of representing the past in a variety of sites, and questions of historical interpretation, memory, and audience.

HIST256.name: History of Africa
HIST256.desc: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism.

HIST260.name: Science and Society in the Contemporary World
HIST260.desc: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year.

HIST271.name: Japan and Global History, 1550 - 1900
HIST271.desc: Thematic study of comparisons and relations between Japan and the world outside (primarily Europe and China). Commercial expansion, systems of world order, social institutions, religious and ideological expression, and state organization.

HIST280.name: Islamic World History
HIST280.desc: The history of the Islamic world in its global dimensions from its origins to the present day through the themes of religion, law, politics, culture, and modernity.

HIST302.name: History of the Indigenous Peoples of North America
HIST302.desc: Indigenous peoples from pre-contact to the present in Canada and the U.S.  Topics include colonial frontiers, disease, fur trade, government policies, environment, gender, religion, oral narratives, activism, urbanization, and identity.

HIST311.name: The British Empire after 1850
HIST311.desc: Transformation of the British imperial system from the mid-nineteenth century to de-colonization and neo-colonialism after the second World War.

HIST312.name: Southern Africa
HIST312.desc: Pre-colonial, colonial, and contemporary, emphasizing South Africa.

HIST313.name: Africa from Imperialism to Independence
HIST313.desc: The history of Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: the growth of Islam and Christianity, the impact of European colonialism, the development of nationalism, and the variety of different political and social outcomes after independence.

HIST318.name: Early Twentieth-Century Britain
HIST318.desc: British society and politics in the era of the two world wars: the liberal reforms before the Great War, war experiences, the Great Depression, and the impact of new political movements.

HIST319.name: Britain, 1945 to the Present
HIST319.desc: Survey of recent British history, with emphasis on de-colonization, emergence of the welfare state, new social movements and patterns of immigration, and Britain's changing relationship with Europe.

HIST323.name: Empires, Wars, and Revolutions in Europe and the Americas,1763-1838
HIST323.desc: Political, social, cultural, and intellectual transformations that reshaped the Atlantic world between 1763 and 1838; special attention will be given to the American, French, and Haitian Revolutions, the Latin American Wars of Independence and Canadian rebellions.

HIST324.name: Inventing Canada, 1840-1896
HIST324.desc: An examination of political, cultural and national developments within the British North American colonies in the second half of the nineteenth century. Credit will not be granted for both HIST 324 or 326, if 326 was taken before 2007W.

HIST325.name: Canada 1896-1945: Boom, Bust and War
HIST325.desc: Includes Aboriginal policy, immigration and national identity; Canada, Britain and the US; World Wars; economic modernization; the Great Depression; regionalism; political and social movements; and the creation of 'Canadian' culture.  Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 325 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.

HIST331.name: The United States, 1865-1900: Labour, Race, Gender, and Empire
HIST331.desc: The complicated political, economic and social history of the United States in the three decades following the Civil War.

HIST334.name: Senegambia to South Carolina, Ghana to Georgia: African-American History, 1450 - 1850
HIST334.desc: The history of African Americans from the beginnings of the African slave trade in the 15th Century through the mid-1800s and the coming of the U.S. Civil War.

HIST335.name: From Slavery to Citizenship and Beyond: African-American History, 1850 to the Present
HIST335.desc: The history of African-Americans from the Civil War and emancipation through the present. Topics include the "Jim Crow" system; the Harlem Renaissance; the Civil Rights Movement; and the current economic and political status of Americans of African ancestry.

HIST350.name: The Soviet Union
HIST350.desc: Political, social, and cultural history of the Soviet Union and post-Soviet successor states from 1900 to the present.

HIST355.name: Nineteenth Century Germany
HIST355.desc: The political, social, and cultural history of modern Germany during the "long nineteenth century" (1780s to the early twentieth century).

HIST356.name: Twentieth-Century Germany
HIST356.desc: The political, social, and cultural history of Germany in the twentieth century.

HIST363.name: Europe in the Early Middle Ages
HIST363.desc: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 400 through about 1000 CE.

HIST364.name: Europe in the Late Middle Ages
HIST364.desc: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 1000 CE through the fourteenth century.

HIST365.name: Europe During the Renaissance
HIST365.desc: The interplay between new and traditional ideas, styles, and institutions from the fourteenth to the mid-sixteenth century, with emphasis upon the relationship of social, economic, and political factors to intellectual and cultural change.

HIST366.name: Europe During the Reformation
HIST366.desc: An examination of European history that place both the Protestant Reformation and the Catholic Reformation in the broader context of the political, social, cultural, and economic changes during the early modern era.

HIST367.name: Europe in the Age of the Enlightenment
HIST367.desc: Europe during the age of the Enlightenment, from the end of the religious wars to the French Revolution, with emphasis on political, social, cultural, and intellectual changes in their global context.

HIST368.name: Europe in the 19th Century
HIST368.desc: An investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the 20th century. Topics of particular importance are: domestic politics; the interaction of states; the formation of new states; social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization; major cultural expressions of the century.

HIST369.name: Europe, 1900-1950
HIST369.desc: Europe in the first half of the twentieth century. Themes include the imperialist system, two world wars and their aftermaths, political and social movements of the interwar years, the Depression, and the crisis of liberal democracy. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 369 or 462.

HIST370.name: Europe Since 1950
HIST370.desc: Europe since the middle of the twentieth century. Themes include the Cold War, the development of separate social and political systems in Western and Eastern Europe, the emergence of the welfare state, and the problems of European integration.

HIST373.name: History of Hong Kong
HIST373.desc: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present.

HIST376.name: Modern Japanese History Since 1800
HIST376.desc: The building of a modern state, its crisis in the 1930s, and its postwar recovery; topics include business institutions, politics, imperialism, intellectual syncretism, social change, and Japan's growing influence in the world.

HIST378.name: History of Early China
HIST378.desc: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang Empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society.

HIST382.name: Post-Colonial Southeast Asia
HIST382.desc: The history of the Japanese occupation, wars of independence, international relations of the independent nation-states, and internal armed conflicts. Special attention will be paid to the wars in Vietnam, Indonesia, and East Timor.

HIST385.name: India from Raj to Republic
HIST385.desc: Exploration of the rise of the East India Company as territorial power, the formation of a colonial society in India, competing responses to British rule, the struggle for independence, and the legacies of partition.

HIST387.name: Voices from Medieval India
HIST387.desc: History of medieval India explored through different stories from and about India's pre-modern past. Studies trends in society, religion, politics, and material life to reveal the dynamism of this period and to challenge simplified narratives of Hindu-Muslim confrontation.

HIST388.name: India in the Early Modern World: Mughals, Merchants, and Marauders
HIST388.desc: History of India during the period of Mughal rule (roughly 1500-1750). Studies the role of India and the Mughals within the global dynamics of the early modern world.

HIST391.name: Human Rights in World History
HIST391.desc: Changing ideas about humanity and rights. Considers the relationship between human rights and the nation-state, imperialism, and capitalism. Assesses the efforts to end large-scale human rights violations and the role of the United Nations.

HIST393.name: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
HIST393.desc: An examination of historical, conceptual, and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.

HIST394.name: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
HIST394.desc: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

HIST405.name: Diplomacy and Conflict in the Middle East, 1914 to the Present
HIST405.desc: International relations in the Middle East in the aftermath of the Ottoman Empire, with special attention to the conflicts between Jews of Palestine/Israel and their Arab neighbours.

HIST408.name: U.S. Foreign Relations from Independence to World War II
HIST408.desc: U.S. foreign policy and international history.  Examines the American rise to power and political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.

HIST409.name: U.S. Foreign Relations since 1945
HIST409.desc: U.S. foreign policy and international history.  Political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.

HIST413.name: Imagining the Nation: 19th- and 20th-Century Canada
HIST413.desc: The political and intellectual history of the concept of the nation in French and English Canada, and the different forms of nationalism it inspired from the middle of the nineteenth century to the 1995 Quebec Referendum.

HIST418.name: The 1960s in Global Perspective
HIST418.desc: The history of the 1960s from a transnational perspective: culture, social change, student activism, and global conflict.

HIST432.name: International Relations of the Great Powers in the Twentieth Century
HIST432.desc: The international relations of the great powers from the end of the First World War to the end of the Cold War.

HIST444.name: Slave Societies in the Americas
HIST444.desc: A comparative analysis of the institution of chattel slavery, its growth, its effects on slaves and masters, its relation to the larger society, and the causes of its decline, in the various cultures of the Americas.

HIST455.name: Gender and Sexuality in Latin America
HIST455.desc: The construction of gender ideologies and gendered and sexual identities, including masculine, feminine, and transgendered, in modern Latin America. [3-0-0]

HIST469.name: Aboriginal Title in British Columbia: History and Legacy
HIST469.desc: Colonial land policy, Indigenous resistance and organizing, treaties, and court decisions. Some previous knowledge of Indigenous history is strongly recommended.

HIST483.name: Asian Migrations to the Americas
HIST483.desc: Examines both the historical and contemporary contexts for migration from Asia to Canada and the Americas.

HIST484.name: East Asian Military systems and warfare China
HIST484.desc: Confucian societies are often thought of as ones in which the brush is mightier than the sword. In fact the military has been a crucial factor in East Asia, and warfare has been the engine which has driven many of the most significant changes in East Asian history. This course will look at the evolution of East Asian military systems, and at the impact of recurrent warfare on East Asia societies.

IGEN201.name: Integrated Technical Communication
IGEN201.desc: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material.  Restricted to students in second year of the Integrated Engineering Program.
IGEN201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

IGEN230.name: Introduction to Engineering Design
IGEN230.desc: Introduction to engineering design methods, problem solving, working individually and in teams, and methods of communication of results. Engineering design projects will be assigned. Restricted to students in the second year of the Integrated Engineering program.

IGEN330.name: Intermediate Engineering Design
IGEN330.desc: Intermediate level engineering design projects involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program.
IGEN330.prer: Third-year standing in the Integrated Engineering program.

IGEN340.name: Technology Entrepreneurship
IGEN340.desc: Theory and skills needed for engineers to capitalize on the opportunities that exist in commercializing technology, including the relationships between ideas and opportunities, customers and competition, and products and solutions.

IGEN430.name: Advanced Engineering Design Projects
IGEN430.desc: Projects involving all material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering Program. Students will be expected to propose a project and complete the design and construction of a prototype. Restricted to students in the fourth year of the Integrated Engineering program.

IGEN450.name: Pipeline Engineering
IGEN450.desc: Pipeline materials and material selection; fracture mechanics; manufacturing and processing; welding and corrosion; soil-pipe interactions; surveying and site investigations; slope stability; natural hazards; pipeline loads and response.
IGEN450.prer: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) APSC 278 and one of CIVL 215, MTRL 263 and one of CIVL 230, MECH 260.

IGEN451.name: Pipeline Systems and Infrastructure
IGEN451.desc: Energy infrastructure; pipe flows; equipment and facilities including compressors, pumping stations, coolers, and controls; terminals; pipeline integrity; corrosion control.
IGEN451.prer: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) APSC 278 and one of CIVL 215, MTRL 263 and one of CIVL 230, MECH 260.

IGEN452.name: Pipeline Design
IGEN452.desc: Pipeline and pipeline system design reflecting technical, regulatory, environmental, societal, professional, and economic aspects; pipeline design project.

ITAL201.name: Second-Year Italian I
ITAL201.desc: Reading, writing and oral practice, with constant and systematic reference to the grammatical structure of the language.
ITAL201.prer: ITAL 102. Or permission of the instructor.

ITAL202.name: Second-Year Italian II
ITAL202.desc: Reading, writing and oral practice, with constant and systematic reference to the grammatical structure of the language.
ITAL202.prer: ITAL 201. Or permission of the department.

ITAL301.name: Third-Year Italian I
ITAL301.desc: Reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on oral practice and on composition.
ITAL301.prer: One of ITAL 202, ITAL 203. Or permission of the department.

ITAL302.name: Third-Year Italian II
ITAL302.desc: Reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on oral practice and on composition.
ITAL302.prer: ITAL 301. Or permission of the department.

ITAL303.name: Italian Literature and Culture of the Medieval and Early Modern Period
ITAL303.desc: A thematic approach to Italian literary works from the origins to the end of the sixteenth century considered in a broad cultural context. Alternates with ITAL 304.
ITAL303.crer: ITST 231. Or permission of the Departmental Undergraduate Advisor in Italian.

ITAL304.name: Italian Literature and Culture of the Modern and Contemporary Age
ITAL304.desc: The development of modern and contemporary Italian literature and culture against the background of social and historical events. Alternates with ITAL 303.
ITAL304.crer: ITST 232. Or permission of Departmental Undergraduate Advisor in Italian.

ITAL403.name: Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy
ITAL403.desc: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works:

ITAL409.name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture
ITAL409.desc: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITST 419.

JAPN160.name: Intensive Beginning Japanese I
JAPN160.desc: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions. Offered in Term 1. Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 160 and 260 in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 160 or JAPN 150 or both JAPN 100, JAPN 101.

JAPN260.name: Intensive Beginning Japanese II
JAPN260.desc: Continuation of JAPN 160. Offered in Term 2. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 160 and 260 in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 260 or JAPN 151 or both JAPN 102, JAPN 103 or both JAPN 200, JAPN 201.

JAPN360.name: Intensive Intermediate Japanese I
JAPN360.desc: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and  cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Offered in Term 1. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 or JAPN 212 or both JAPN 210, JAPN 211 or both JAPN 320, JAPN 321.
JAPN360.prer: One of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260.

JAPN361.name: Intensive Intermediate Japanese II
JAPN361.desc: Continuation of JAPN 360. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 361 or JAPN 251 or both JAPN 212, JAPN 213 or both JAPN 322, JAPN 323.
JAPN361.prer: One of JAPN 211, JAPN 250, JAPN 321, JAPN 360.

JAPN400.name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing I
JAPN400.desc: Selected texts covering various aspects of Japanese cultural history and contemporary Japanese culture/society; emphasis on grammatical analysis and development of advanced competencies for reading and writing. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 400 or JAPN 300.
JAPN400.prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

JAPN401.name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing II
JAPN401.desc: Continuation of JAPN 301. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 401 or JAPN 301.

JAPN402.name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition I
JAPN402.desc: Improvement of speaking and writing skills through readings and discussions on a variety of social and cultural issues; emphasis on appropriate language use in formal situations. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 402 and JAPN 403 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 402 or JAPN 302.
JAPN402.prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

JAPN450.name: Advanced Oral Communication I
JAPN450.desc: Oral communication skills appropriate for studying and working in a Japanese-speaking environment either formal or informal. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 450 or JAPN 410.
JAPN450.prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 302, JAPN 402, JAPN 314, JAPN 424.

JAPN452.name: Readings in Modern Japanese Essays
JAPN452.desc: Advanced reading and analysis of scholarly texts in modern Japanese drawn from history, sociology, economics, etc. Advanced conversation, composition, and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to taking JAPN 452. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 452 or JAPN 406.

JAPN453.name: Readings in Modern Japanese Literature
JAPN453.desc: An advanced course in the reading and analysis of literary texts in modern Japanese. Advanced conversation, translation into English and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for advanced research in Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 453 or JAPN 408.

JAPN456.name: Newspaper Japanese I
JAPN456.desc: Developing fluency in reading contemporary Japanese newspapers; concentration on current and emerging vocabulary, evolving grammatical features, and style of presentation. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 456 or JAPN 416.
JAPN456.prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 302, JAPN 402, JAPN 314, JAPN 424.

KIN103.name: Active Health
KIN103.desc: Role of physical activity in the maintenance of a healthy life. Application of basic physical fitness and exercise methods, exercise techniques and fitness appraisal. [2-2]

KIN230.name: Human Motor Behaviour I
KIN230.desc: Processes underlying human movement and learning motor skills and factors influencing acquisition, performance, and movement control. [3-0-0]

KIN231.name: Sport and Exercise Psychology
KIN231.desc: Psychological theories and research related to sport and exercise behaviour. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477 [3-0-0]

KIN261.name: Health Policy and Society
KIN261.desc: Health policy and the social context in relation to active health. [3-0]

KIN284.name: Lifespan Motor Development
KIN284.desc: A lifespan approach to motor development that examines underlying factors affecting physical growth, physical activity behaviour, and human motor performance, while highlighting contemporary issues and trends in society. [3-0]

KIN303.name: High Performance Conditioning in Physical Activity and Sport
KIN303.desc: Conditioning methods, exercise techniques and appraisal methods for fitness in high performance physical activity and sport. [2-2]

KIN330.name: Human Motor Behaviour II
KIN330.desc: Acquisition, performance, and control of skilled movements. Processes and underlying mechanisms involved in learning and performing motor skills. Credit will be granted for only one of KIN 330 or KIN 468. [2-2]

KIN351.name: Biomechanics II Mechanical Properties of Tissues
KIN351.desc: Mechanics of muscular contraction and how the mechanical properties of the muscle, ligaments, tendons, and bone work synergistically. [2-0-2]

KIN360.name: Sport, Peace, and Conflict
KIN360.desc: Relationships that sport and leisure have with peace, conflict, and social inequality in Canada and internationally. [3-0]

KIN361.name: Introduction to Athletic Training
KIN361.desc: Recognition, prevention, and first aid treatment of common sports injuries. Laboratory sessions emphasize principles and techniques of basic protective taping and strapping. [2-2]

KIN362.name: Inclusive Physical Activity for Individuals with Special Needs
KIN362.desc: For persons with disabilities; a developmental, lifelong approach to programming. Includes field work. [2-0-2]

KIN365.name: Foundations of Coaching
KIN365.desc: Methods of athletic conditioning, planning the program, psychology of training and coaching, athletic evaluation. [3-0]

KIN366.name: Movement Experiences for Young Children
KIN366.desc: The design and implementation of movement experiences for children in early childhood years. [3-0]

KIN367.name: Leisure Services for Persons with a Disability
KIN367.desc: Policy issues relating to leisure opportunities for persons with disabilities. [3-0]

KIN369.name: Instructional Analysis and Design in Sport and Physical Activity Programs
KIN369.desc: Instructional design and technologies applied to sport and physical activity programs. [2-2]

KIN373.name: Research Methods in Kinesiology
KIN373.desc: Critical evaluation of research studies and methods with emphasis on the physical activity context. [3-0]

KIN381.name: Leisure, Sport and Popular Culture
KIN381.desc: Selected aspects of leisure and sport examined in relation to modern social structures and cultures. Credit will be granted for only one of KIN 281 or KIN 381. [3-0-0]

KIN382.name: Meaning and Values in Sport
KIN382.desc: An analysis of the experience of sports activities. [3-0]

KIN383.name: The Modern Olympics: Power, Politics, and Performance
KIN383.desc: Examination of the Modern Olympic Games as an event with important political, economic, environmental, and cultural ramifications. [3-0]

KIN389.name: Neuromuscular Integration of Human Movement
KIN389.desc: The neurophysiological and functional neuroanatomical processes involved in the sensory and motor control of movement, posture and balance in the human. Peripheral and central sensorimotor structures, and neurological diseases that effect human movement and balance control will be discussed. [2-2]

KIN390.name: Human Functional Musculoskeletal Anatomy
KIN390.desc: The musculoskeletal structures and neural innervations involved in the control of human movement. Attention will be given to the practical application of human anatomy as it pertains to clinical, athletic, or everyday situations.
KIN390.prer: Third-year standing. Restricted to students in the BHK and BKIN programs.

KIN400.name: Planning Physical Education, Sport and Exercise Programs
KIN400.desc: Processes, techniques and considerations in the planning, implementation and evaluation of physical education, sport and exercise programs in both public and private agencies. [3-0]

KIN415.name: Conceptual Approaches to Games Education
KIN415.desc: Examination of developmentally appropriate conceptual and tactical approaches to team game instruction. [2-2]

KIN425.name: Aging, Health, and the Body
KIN425.desc: The sociology of aging and the body. Focus on how older adults perceive and experience health and illness.

KIN456.name: Field Experiences in Physical Education Settings
KIN456.desc: Analytical observations and supervised professional practice in physical activity settings.
KIN456.prer: KIN  369. Third-year standing. Restricted to students in the BHK and BKIN programs.

KIN461.name: Prevention of Sports Injuries I
KIN461.desc: Training and safety strategies for the prevention of injuries to the musculoskeletal system and sense organs. [3-0]
KIN461.prer: One of KIN  361, HKIN 361 and third-year standing.

KIN462.name: Skeletal Muscle Physiology: From Generation to Regeneration
KIN462.desc: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of muscle adaptability to physical activity: muscle development, signaling cascades of hypertrophy and atrophy, and satellite cell contribution to muscle regeneration/repair; etiology of intramuscular fatigue. [3-0-1]
KIN462.prer: One of KIN  375, HKIN 375 and third-year standing.

KIN464.name: Health Promotion and Physical Activity
KIN464.desc: Current perspectives on health promotion and health education; design and implementation of health promotion strategies in a variety of arenas, particularly health promotion/education strategies aimed at encouraging physical activity. [3-0]

KIN465.name: Interculturalism, Health and Physical Activity
KIN465.desc: Examination of multiculturalism and interculturalism in the delivery of community-based physical activities for diverse populations; connections between physical activity and health in different cultural contexts.  Community service learning and participation in culturally unfamiliar physical activities are core elements.

KIN471.name: Prevention of Sports Injuries II
KIN471.desc: Training and safety strategies for the prevention of injuries or disorders of internal organs and central nervous system. Environmental and nutritional factors in conditioning and pre-event preparation. [3-0]

KIN473.name: Neuroanatomy of Human Movement
KIN473.desc: Neuroanatomy of human motion in healthy and clinical populations. [3-0]

KIN475.name: Pulmonary Physiology of Exercise
KIN475.desc: Operation of the lungs, chest wall, and ventilatory control mechanisms during dynamic whole-body exercise. [3-0]

KIN481.name: Sport Marketing and Communication
KIN481.desc: A seminar on the application of social science theories and methods to sport marketing and communication. [3-0]

LARC316.name: Trees and Shrubs in Landscape
LARC316.desc: Culture and identification of landscape materials with emphasis on woody plants. Elementary principles of landscape composition.  Suitable for students of other faculties and departments interested in landscape materials and their uses, but priority given to  Agroecology and Landscape Architecture students. [2-2]

LARC415.name: A Behavioural Approach to Planting Design
LARC415.desc: Functional, ecological, and behavioural theory and practice applied to planting design at different scales. [2-2]

LARC431.name: Landscape Technologies I: Site Engineering
LARC431.desc: Terrain design, drainage, and stormwater management. Open only to B. End. students. Credit will be given for only one of LARC 431, LARC 531.

LARC440.name: SITE ANALYSIS AND PLANNING II
LARC440.desc: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Open only to B.En.D. students. Credit will be given for only one of LARC 440, LARC 540.

LARC444.name: Green Network Planning
LARC444.desc: Theory and methods of long-range green space planning for urban areas.

LAST100.name: Introduction to Latin American Studies
LAST100.desc: An overview of the culture and society of Latin America from ancient to contemporary times and from Argentina to Mexico.

LAST201.name: Popular Culture in Latin America
LAST201.desc: The culture of everyday life, both rural and urban: issues of identity, popular memory, resistance, negotiation, as expressed through ritual, crafts, the body, social movements, films, music, and literature.

LAW201.name: Canadian Constitutional Law
LAW201.desc: Principles of Canadian constitutional law, including Canadian federalism, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and the unique constitutional status and rights of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada.

LAW211.name: Contracts
LAW211.desc: Historical development; formation and enforceability of contracts; parties; contractual terms; changes of circumstances; remedies for breach.

LAW221.name: Criminal Law and Procedure
LAW221.desc: Bases of criminal responsibility; principles and objectives of the criminal law and procedure; pre-trial procedure.

LAW231.name: Property Law
LAW231.desc: The legal concept of ownership and its changing nature and application, including equitable principles, the acquisition and transfer of interests, the regulation of use, Aboriginal title, and statute-based systems for registering interests in land.

LAW241.name: Torts
LAW241.desc: A study of the bases of civil liability for intentionally and accidentally caused harms.

LAW251.name: Public Law
LAW251.desc: An overview of the constitutional and statutory law governing the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government in Canada, including an introduction to statutory construction and analysis and the administration of law in Canada.

LAW261.name: Transnational Law
LAW261.desc: Introduction to principles of public and private international law and research methods for international legal materials.

LAW281.name: Legal Research and Writing
LAW281.desc: Introduction to legal research and writing skills and the use of legal databases.

LAW300.name: Jurisprudence and Critical Perspectives
LAW300.desc: Introduction to the basic principles of legal theory and critical perspectives on law. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 290 or LAW 300.

LAW303.name: Legal Traditions and Ideas of Law
LAW303.desc: Historical and comparative study of the evolution of legal systems from custom and proto law emphasizing influences and sharing ideas among traditions of the Ancient Near East, Athens, Roman Empire, Western Europe and China. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW305.name: Law, Society and State
LAW305.desc: Theories of the relationship between the legal system, social relations and the state. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW307.name: Women, Law and Social Change
LAW307.desc: A survey of feminist approaches to law, with reference to selected substantive areas of the law.

LAW316.name: International Law
LAW316.desc: The history, sources and evidence of international law and its relation to municipal law; international personality; state jurisdiction; and treaties. Students who have taken POLI 465 cannot take this course.

LAW325.name: Conflict of Laws
LAW325.desc: A study of the private legal problems arising in cases in which the relevant facts cut across provincial or national boundaries. Recommended to be taken in third year.

LAW334.name: Introduction to Asian Legal Systems
LAW334.desc: Introduction to the comparative study of legal systems of East and South-East Asia, including those of China and Japan.

LAW336.name: Chinese Law: Implications for Canada-China Relations
LAW336.desc: Overview of the laws and legal system in the People's Republic of China with some introduction to Taiwan law. Legal interpretation of implications for Canada-China relations.

LAW340.name: Comparative Law
LAW340.desc: Basic theory of comparative law and the differences between the civil law tradition and the common law tradition.

LAW352.name: Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Law
LAW352.desc: Survey of the history and present status of the legal relationships between Canada's Aboriginal peoples and the state. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 200 or LAW 352.

LAW356.name: First Nations and Economic Development
LAW356.desc: Legal issues affecting land use and economic activity involving First Nations' resources. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW359.name: Family Law
LAW359.desc: The law relating to family relationships, including the law of marriage, divorce, maintenance, custody, matrimonial property, and related matters. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 240 or LAW 359. [3-0]

LAW367.name: Reproduction and Law
LAW367.desc: Legal issues relating to human reproduction. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW374.name: Municipal Law
LAW374.desc: The municipality as a legal entity; its creation, operation and powers; by-laws and their validity; contractual liability; judicial review; business regulation; expropriation and land use control.

LAW377.name: Immigration Law
LAW377.desc: Admission of immigrants into Canada; refugee protection; practice and procedure before immigration tribunals and the courts.

LAW381.name: Disabilities and Law
LAW381.desc: Legal issues relating to people with disabilities. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW387.name: Environmental Law
LAW387.desc: A foundation course dealing with the regulatory and policy framework for the protection of the environment in Canada, such as pollution control and biodiversity conservation.

LAW390.name: Environmental Law Workshop
LAW390.desc: Legal research and writing for environmental agency or NGO under supervision of faculty member and lawyer. Not offered every year, consult Faculty.

LAW392.name: Natural Resources Law
LAW392.desc: A foundation course dealing with legal problems common to the management of natural resources such as fisheries, mines and minerals, petroleum, forests, and water resources.

LAW395.name: Forest Law
LAW395.desc: Acquisition of timber interests; development, financing and organization of timber companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year; consult Faculty.

LAW400.name: Advanced Criminal Procedure
LAW400.desc: Selected topics relating to procedural law and practice in criminal matters. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 260 or LAW 400.

LAW407.name: Taxation
LAW407.desc: A survey of the law and practice of income and capital gains taxes. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 220, LAW 407, or LAW 506. [3-0]

LAW408.name: Taxation of Corporations and Shareholders
LAW408.desc: The taxation of corporations, the taxation of shareholders, and the tax implications of the reorganization of corporations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 408 or LAW 562.

LAW409.name: Taxation of Partnerships and Trusts
LAW409.desc: Survey of statutory and judicial rules governing the taxation of income earned through partnerships and trusts. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 409 or LAW 563.

LAW410.name: International Taxation
LAW410.desc: The tax aspects of international transactions. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 410 or LAW 565.

LAW412.name: Taxation of Trusts and Estates
LAW412.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.  Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 412 or LAW 564.

LAW416.name: Labour Law
LAW416.desc: Union-management relations; the collective bargaining process; the collective agreement, arbitration and conciliation procedure. The relationship between the union and its membership. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 415 or LAW 416. [2-0] or [3-0]

LAW422.name: Intellectual Property
LAW422.desc: Copyright, patents, trade marks, industrial design, the protection of computer software, and torts such as passing-off and breach of confidence.

LAW424.name: Communications Law
LAW424.desc: Selected legal issues relating to the communications industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW430.name: Advanced Legal Research
LAW430.desc: Research using electronic databases, information systems, and non-legal databases relevant to the resolution of legal issues.

LAW434.name: Medical Negligence Law
LAW434.desc: Legal issues relating to tort claims in negligence and related causes of action against health care providers, with a primary focus on physicians and hospital authorities.

LAW437.name: Commercial Transactions
LAW437.desc: The law of sale of goods, bills of exchange, promissory notes, and cheques. [3-0]

LAW438.name: Secured Transactions
LAW438.desc: The law governing the creation, perfection and enforcement of security interests in personal property.

LAW439.name: Construction Law
LAW439.desc: Legal issues relating to the construction process. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW440.name: Insurance Law
LAW440.desc: The general legal principles of life, automobile, fire and other types of insurance; the regulation of the insurance industry.

LAW442.name: Condominium Law
LAW442.desc: Legal issues over the lifecycle of condominium/strata property from creation and development, through operating life, to termination.

LAW443.name: Creditors' Remedies
LAW443.desc: Remedies of an unsecured creditor; fraudulent conveyances and preferences; builders' liens; bankruptcy.

LAW444.name: Insolvency Law
LAW444.desc: The law relating to insolvency, receivership and bankruptcy. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW448.name: Sports Law
LAW448.desc: Legal issues relating to the sports industry and those who participate in it. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW449.name: Media and Entertainment Law
LAW449.desc: Selected legal issues relating to the media and entertainment industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW451.name: Trusts
LAW451.desc: History and nature of trusts; express, resulting, implied and constructive trusts; charitable and purpose trusts; administration of trusts; breach of trust. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 250 or LAW 451.

LAW452.name: Succession
LAW452.desc: The law of wills and intestate succession, variation of wills, principles of probate and administration of estates.

LAW453.name: Equitable Remedies
LAW453.desc: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing.

LAW455.name: Real Estate Transactions
LAW455.desc: The law relating to the sale and purchase of land, real estate agency, and mortgages.

LAW457.name: Real Estate Development
LAW457.desc: A study of the legal aspects of the development of real estate projects such as shopping centres, sports centres and condominiums. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW461.name: Corporate Transactions
LAW461.desc: Legal aspects of selected transactions relating to public corporations and corporate governance. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW462.name: Close Corporations
LAW462.desc: The corporation, taxation, accounting, insurance and estate planning aspects of the close corporation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW463.name: Securities Regulation
LAW463.desc: The law relating to the distribution of securities. Continuous and timely disclosure requirements and civil liability.

LAW464.name: Competition Policy
LAW464.desc: The law and policy relating to the regulation of competition in Canada and other jurisdictions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 414 or LAW 464.

LAW465.name: Introduction to Corporate Finance
LAW465.desc: Interdisciplinary elements of corporate finance and law, in both theory and practice.

LAW466.name: Business Law Capstone
LAW466.desc: Integration of theoretical and practical elements of business law. For students opting for the Business Law Concentration.
LAW466.prer: All of LAW  407, LAW  459, LAW  463. And 6 credits of other courses from the Concentration.

LAW468.name: Ethics and Professionalism
LAW468.desc: The ethical dimensions of legal practice in Canada, including legislation, regulations, rules of professional conduct and cases, and the roles of lawyers, the legal profession and the legal system including their role in securing access to justice.

LAW469.name: Civil Procedure
LAW469.desc: Problems in the conduct of civil litigation including: ethical considerations; substantive problems such as notice, pleading, and discovery; and selected procedural problems. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 270 or LAW 469. [2-0] or [3-0]

LAW470.name: Innocence Project
LAW470.desc: Clinical program giving hands-on experience in reviewing claims of innocence post-conviction. Not offered every year; consult Faculty.
LAW470.crer: One of LAW  280, LAW  476 and LAW  471.

LAW472.name: Advanced Trial Advocacy
LAW472.desc: Skills-training in all aspects of civil and criminal trial advocacy.
LAW472.prer: One of LAW  270, LAW  469. LAW 280 or LAW 476 is also recommended.

LAW473.name: Appellate Advocacy
LAW473.desc: Issues relating to advocacy before appellate courts; techniques of appellate advocacy. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW474.name: Trial Advocacy
LAW474.desc: Techniques of advocacy in civil and criminal cases including interviewing, pre-trial preparation, tactical analysis, development of facts, direct and cross examination and various ethical considerations.

LAW477.name: Negotiation and Dispute Resolution
LAW477.desc: Negotiation and bargaining; formulation of general principles governing the negotiation process; negotiation in legal practice; alternative means of dispute resolution.

LAW478.name: Foundations of Dispute Resolution
LAW478.desc: Theoretical premises underlying the dispute-resolving process; arbitration, other non-judicial means of resolving legal disputes, and their relationship to litigation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW490.name: Clinical Criminal Law
LAW490.desc: Dealing with criminal files under the supervision of experienced lawyers. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 488, LAW 490, or LAW 491. Pass/Fail.
LAW490.prer: One of LAW  260, LAW  400 and one of LAW  280, LAW  476.

LLED200.name: Introduction to Writing in Academic and Professional Registers
LLED200.desc: Examination of sociolinguistic knowledge and skills that are central to the production of academic and professional texts.

LLED201.name: Critical Reading and Writing in Academic and Professional Registers

LLED212.name: Introduction to Language Communities and Variation in Language Practices
LLED212.desc: Sociolinguistic analysis of language variation according to age, ethnicity, class, race, and gender, and how these variations function in both reflecting and constructing specific identities and memberships in society.

LLED213.name: Introduction to Intercultural Communication and Socialization in Multicultural Contexts
LLED213.desc: The processes by which individuals become competent members of society through the use of language.

LLED220.name: Introduction to Translating in a Globalized Society
LLED220.desc: Basic tenets of translation as a methodology for increasing students' sociocultural understanding, intercultural communication, pragmatics, and written English.

LLED222.name: Introduction to Public and Private Language Practices in a Globalized Society
LLED222.desc: Exploration of the interrelationships between language structure, usage and social context and the interpretive differences that may result from their interaction.

LLED223.name: Introduction to the Nature of World Englishes
LLED223.desc: Exploration of the emergence of new English varieties, as well as a critical examination of main reasons linked to the rise of English worldwide and its proposed role as a neutral global language.

LLED360.name: Classroom Discourses and Teaching English Language Learners: Secondary

LLED366.name: Teaching Literature
LLED366.desc: Curriculum and pedagogy related to the theories, concepts, and strategies relevant in secondary school classrooms.

LLED371.name: Foundations of Teaching French: Secondary
LLED371.prer: A completed concentration in French of permission of the Department Head.

LLED372.name: Teaching French Language and Literacy: Secondary
LLED372.desc: Language of instruction is French. Pass/Fail for B.Ed. students. Non-B.Ed. students are eligible for percentage grading or Credit/D/Fail grading.

LLED381.name: Foundations of Teaching Modern Languages: Secondary

LLED386.name: Secondary Theatre: Introduction to Curriculum & Pedagogy

LLED399.name: Practicum in Teaching English as a Second Language

LLED443.name: Teaching Folklore in the Elementary Classroom

LLED446.name: Teaching with Illustrated Materials, K-12: From Picture Books to Information Texts

LLED450.name: Teaching and Learning Language and Literacy: Kindergarten and Primary Grades
LLED450.prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course

LLED452.name: Disciplinary Literacies: Intermediate Through Secondary
LLED452.desc: How teachers can support students to develop disciplinary literacies that will enable them to understand, analyze, interpret and critique ideas, genres, and language in discipline-specific texts in and beyond the intermediate and secondary school contexts.

LLED459.name: Trends and Issues in Literacy Instruction
LLED459.prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

LLED479.name: The Education of Immigrant Students
LLED479.desc: An examination of the cultural backgrounds of major ethnic groups. Instructional techniques for meeting the needs of immigrant students in the regular classroom with respect to culture and language.

MATH001.name: Algebra
MATH001.desc: Numbers and their properties; exponents, radicals, absolute value, inqualities, functions and their graphs; factoring; solving polynomial, rational, and exponetial equations; and the sine and cosine law. Non-credit Math course offered by Continuing Studies in consultation with the Mathematics Department and taught by Continuing Studies instructors.

MATH190.name: Calculus Survey
MATH190.desc: Functions, derivatives, integrals, curve sketching growth functions, volume calculations.  Only for credit in the Faculty of Forestry.  Students with credit for MATH 100, 102, 104, 120, 180, or 184 cannot in the same term or later terms obtain credit for MATH 190. [3-0-2]
MATH190.prer: Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 and registration in the B.S.F. or B.Sc.N. programs.

MATH210.name: Introduction to Mathematical Computing
MATH210.desc: Introduction to numerical computation, computer algebra, mathematical graphics. Primarily for second year students taking a degree in mathematics. One hour laboratory each week. [3-1-0]
MATH210.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
MATH210.crer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

MATH301.name: Applied Analysis
MATH301.desc: Integrals involving multi-valued functions, conformal mapping and applications, analytic continuation, Laplace and Fourier transforms. [3-0-0]
MATH301.prer: One of MATH 300, MATH 305 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

MATH308.name: Euclidean Geometry
MATH308.desc: Classical plane geometry, solid geometry, spherical trigonometry, polyhedra, linear and affine transformations. Linear algebra proofs are used. It is suggested that MATH 307 be taken concurrently. [3-0-0]
MATH308.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

MATH320.name: Real Variables I
MATH320.desc: The real number system; real Euclidean n-space; open, closed, compact, and connected sets; Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem; sequences and series. Continuity and uniform continuity. Differentiability and mean-value theorems. [3-0-0]
MATH320.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 226 or (b) one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and a score of 80% or higher in MATH 220.

MATH321.name: Real Variables II
MATH321.desc: The Riemann or Riemann-Stieltjes integrals. Sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence. Approximation of continuous functions by polynomials. Fourier series. Functions from R

MATH322.name: Introduction to Group Theory
MATH322.desc: Groups, cosets, homomorphisms, group actions, p-groups, Sylow theorems, composition series, finitely generated Abelian groups. [3-0-0]
MATH322.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 223, MATH 310 or (b) one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and a score of 80% or higher in MATH 220.

MATH323.name: Introduction to Rings and Modules
MATH323.desc: Rings, ideals, unique factorization, Euclidean rings, fields, polynomial rings, modules; structure theory of modules over a principal ideal domain. [3-0-0]

MATH340.name: Introduction to Linear Programming
MATH340.desc: Linear programming problems, dual problems, the simplex algorithm, solution of primal and dual problems, sensitivity analysis. Additional topics chosen from: Karmarkar's algorithm, non-linear programming, game theory, applications. [3-0-0]

MATH342.name: Algebra and Coding Theory
MATH342.desc: Error-correcting codes via abstract and linear algebra.  Emphasis on proofs and computation.  Finite fields, Hamming distance and error-correction, upper and lower bounds on the size of a code, linear codes, groups and cosets, encoding and decoding schemes. [3-0-0]
MATH342.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

MATH345.name: Applied Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
MATH345.desc: Phase plane methods, bifurcation and stability theory, limit-cycle behavior and chaos for nonlinear differential equations with applications to the sciences.  Assignments involve the use of computers. [3-1-0]
MATH345.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

MATH360.name: Mathematical Modeling in Science
MATH360.desc: Principles of model selection and basic modeling techniques in biology, earth science, chemistry and physics. Optimization, dynamical systems and stochastic processes. Preference will be given to Combined Major in Science students, or to students in Year 3 or higher.
MATH360.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

MATH398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
MATH398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

MATH399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
MATH399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

MATH400.name: Applied Partial Differential Equations
MATH400.desc: Separation of variables, first order equations, Sturm-Liouville theory, integral transform methods. [3-0-0]
MATH400.prer: One of MATH 300, MATH 305 and one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316.

MATH412.name: Advanced Linear Algebra
MATH412.desc: Topics include decompositions of linear operators, multi linear algebra, bilinear forms, metric spaces. [3-0-0]
MATH412.prer: A score of 68% or higher in all of MATH 320, MATH 322.

MATH414.name: Mathematical Demonstrations
MATH414.desc: Students will prepare material illustrating ideas and applications of mathematics and present it to audiences outside the University. Intended for third or fourth year Mathematics students and Math/Science Education students. [2-0-0; 1-0-0] or [3-0-0]

MATH418.name: Probability
MATH418.desc: Probability spaces, random variables, distributions, expectation, conditional probabilities, convergence of random variables, generating and characteristic functions, weak and strong laws of large numbers, central limit theorem. [3-0-0]
MATH418.prer: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 321.

MATH419.name: Stochastic Processes
MATH419.desc: Random walks, Markov chains, branching processes, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, martingales, Brownian motion. [3-0-0]

MATH420.name: Real Analysis I
MATH420.desc: Sigma-algebras, Lebesgue measure, Borel measures, measurable functions, integration, convergence theorems, L
MATH420.prer: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 321.

MATH421.name: Real Analysis II
MATH421.desc: Banach spaces, linear operators, bounded and compact operators, strong, weak, and weak* topology.  Hahn-Banach, open mapping, and closed graph theorems.  Hilbert spaces, symmetric and self-adjoint operators, spectral theory for bounded operators. [3-0-0]

MATH422.name: Fields and Galois Theory
MATH422.desc: Field extensions, the Galois correspondence, finite fields, insolvability in radicals, ruler and compass constructions, additional topics chosen by instructor. [3-0-0]

MATH423.name: Topics in Algebra
MATH423.desc: Commutative algebra, algebraic geometry, algebraic number theory, Lie theory, homological algebra and category theory, or some other advanced topic in algebra. [3-0-0]
MATH423.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 412, MATH 422.

MATH425.name: Introduction to Modern Differential Geometry
MATH425.desc: Riemannian manifolds, tensors and differential forms, curvature and geodesics. [3-0-0]

MATH426.name: Introduction to Topology
MATH426.desc: General topology, combinatorial topology, fundamental group and covering spaces, topics chosen by the instructor. [3-0-0]
MATH426.prer: A score of 68% or higher in all of MATH 321, MATH 322.

MATH427.name: Topics in Topology
MATH427.desc: Homology theory, homotopy theory, manifolds, and other topics chosen by the instructor. [3-0-0]

MATH440.name: Complex Analysis
MATH440.desc: The residue theorem, the argument principle, conformal mapping, the maximum modulus principle, harmonic functions, representation of functions by integrals, series, and products. Other topics at the discretion of the instructor. [3-0-0]
MATH440.prer: MATH 300 and a score of 68% or higher in MATH 320.

MATH441.name: Mathematical Modeling: Discrete Optimization Problems
MATH441.desc: Formulation of real-world optimization problems using techniques such as linear programming, network flows, integer programming, dynamic programming. Solution by appropriate software. [3-0-0]

MATH442.name: Optimization in Graphs and Networks
MATH442.desc: Basic graph theory, emphasizing trees, tree growing algorithms, and proof techniques. Problems chosen from: shortest paths, maximum flows, minimum cost flows, matchings, graph colouring. Linear programming duality will be an important tool. [3-0-0]

MATH443.name: Graph Theory
MATH443.desc: Introductory course in mostly non-algorithmic topics including: planarity and Kuratowski's theorem, graph colouring, graph minors, random graphs, cycles in graphs, Ramsey theory, extremal graph theory. Proofs emphasized. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0]
MATH443.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121. And at least 6 credits of Mathematics courses numbered 300 or above.

MATH444.name: Mathematical Research and Writing
MATH444.desc: Current research topics in pure and applied mathematics are explored at the undergraduate level.  Technical communication and research skills are developed. [3-0-0]
MATH444.prer: One of MATH 220, MATH 226 and 6 credits of MATH courses numbered 300 or higher.

MATH450.name: Asymptotic and Perturbation Methods
MATH450.desc: Asymptotic expansions. Asymptotic evaluation of integrals; WKBJ methods. Regular and singular expansions. Boundary layer theory; matched asymptotic expansions. Multiple scale techniques. [3-0-0]

MATH462.name: Projects in Mathematical Biology
MATH462.desc: Development and analysis of mathematical models for complex systems in ecology, evolution, cell biology, neurophysiology, and other biological and medical disciplines. [3-0-0]

MATH498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
MATH498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3 1/2 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

MATH499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
MATH499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3 1/2 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

MECH220.name: Technical Skills Practicum
MECH220.desc: Engineering graphics, spatial visualization, CAD, equation solvers, machine shop practice, electronic circuit construction and troubleshooting, elements of engineering science.
MECH220.prer: All of MATH 101, MATH 152, PHYS 170 and one of APSC 150, APSC 151 and either (a) PHYS 153 or (b) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159.

MECH221.name: Engineering Science I
MECH221.desc: Rigid body kinetics and kinematics, basic electrical circuits, work and power, stress and strain, torsion, bending, engineering materials, probability and statistics. This course includes the content of ELEC 203.
MECH221.prer: All of MATH 101, MATH 152, PHYS 170 and either (a) PHYS 153 or (b) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159.
MECH221.crer: All of MECH 220, MECH 224 and one of ENGL 112, APSC 176.

MECH222.name: Engineering Science II
MECH222.desc: Fluid properties, equations of state. Pressure, buoyancy, hydrostatic forces. Conservation of mass, momentum, and energy. Work and heat; internal energy and enthalpy. Bernoulli's equation. Dimensional analysis, modeling. Turbulent flow in pipes; turbomachinery. Second law and the Carnot cycle; entropy; first and second law analysis of systems.

MECH223.name: Introduction to the Mechanical Design Process
MECH223.desc: Design methodology, synthesis and analysis. Design projects representing both mechanical mechanism design and thermofluid systems.

MECH226.name: Technical Communication for Mechanical Engineers
MECH226.desc: Written and oral communication. Preparation of design reports, business correspondence, verbal, online, and visual presentation of technical material.  Restricted to students in the second year of Mechanical Engineering.
MECH226.prer: A score of 65% or higher in one of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.
MECH226.crer: All of MECH 220, MECH 221, MECH 222, MECH 223, MECH 224, MECH 225.

MECH260.name: Introduction to Mechanics of Materials
MECH260.desc: Statically determinate frames and trusses; normal and shear stresses and strains; shear force and bending moment diagrams; theory of beam bending, torsion of circular rods; transformation of stress and strain in two and three dimensions, Mohr's circle; yield and ultimate failure criteria.

MECH280.name: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
MECH280.desc: Fluid properties; statics; kinematics, dynamics, energy, and momentum principles for control volumes; dimensional analysis and similarity; laminar and turbulent flow; pipe flow; principles of centrifugal pumps.
MECH280.prer: All of MATH 152, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 217, MATH 253 and either (a) all of PHYS 101, PHYS 102 or (b) PHYS 153 or (c) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159.

MECH305.name: Data Analysis and Mechanical Engineering Laboratories
MECH305.desc: The use of probability and statistical methods for engineering applications. Mechanics of materials, heat transfer, and fluid dynamics. Instrumentation, data acquisition, and data manipulation using modern computational tools.
MECH305.prer: All of MECH 220, MECH 223, MECH 224, MECH 225.

MECH306.name: Data Analysis and Mechatronics Laboratories
MECH306.desc: The use of probability and statistical methods for engineering applications. Mechanics of materials and heat transfer. Instrumentation, data acquisition, and data manipulation using modern computational tools. Common mechanical devices. For students in the Mechatronics Option only.
MECH306.prer: All of MECH 220, MECH 223, MECH 224, MECH 225.

MECH325.name: Mechanical Design I
MECH325.desc: Selection of flexible drives, bearings, hydraulic system components, and couplings. Design of bolted joints and power screws. Design and selection of gears, gear trains, and mechanisms.
MECH325.crer: MECH 360 and one of MECH 328, ENPH 253, IGEN 330.

MECH326.name: Mechanical Design II
MECH326.desc: Design of shafts and welded joints. Fatigue and fracture considerations in design: failure types, failure under static and dynamic loading, fatigue failure, crack initiation, and propagation. Introduction to the FEM in mechanical design.
MECH326.crer: All of MECH 325, MECH 360 and one of MECH 328, ENPH 253, IGEN 330.

MECH327.name: Thermodynamics II
MECH327.desc: Air standard and vapor cycles; first and second law of cycles. Exergy. Gas mixtures.  Energy conservation. Equilibrium. Reacting systems. Application to thermofluid systems such as power plants.
MECH327.prer: Either (a) MECH 225 or (b) one of CHBE 241, ENPH 257 and one of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280.
MECH327.crer: MECH 325 and one of MECH 328, ENPH 479, IGEN 330.

MECH328.name: Mechanical Engineering Design Project
MECH328.desc: Design project course linked to MECH 325, MECH 326, or MECH 327. Applying the design process, making educated assumptions and decisions, and working in teams to provide a new mechanical design. Weekly lecture discussing product development and various factors affecting the design.

MECH329.name: Materials for Mechanical Design
MECH329.desc: Selection of material properties and processing techniques for mechanical design. Properties of steel and other alloys. Heat treatment. Ceramics, composites, plastics.
MECH329.prer: Either (a) MECH 224 or (b) all of APSC 278, MECH 260.

MECH360.name: Mechanics of Materials
MECH360.desc: Beam deflections, singularity functions; use of tabulated solutions; column buckling; Castigliano's theorem, statically indeterminate beams, bending of beams with asymmetric cross-sections, shear centre; principal stresses and stress invariants in three dimensions.

MECH366.name: Modeling of Mechatronic Systems
MECH366.desc: Modeling of mechanical, electrical, thermal, fluid elements and mixed mechatronic systems. Signal processing, signal conditioning. Sensors, data acquisition systems, actuators.
MECH366.prer: Either (a) all of MECH 220, MECH 223, MECH 224, MECH 225 or (b) all of ENPH 253, MECH 260 and one of ELEC 201, EECE 251.

MECH368.name: Engineering Measurements and Instrumentation
MECH368.desc: Industrial measurement needs including: architecture of electronic instrumentation systems; electrical representation of physical quantities; sensors and actuators; analog signal processing using linear and non-linear circuits; computer based readout including programming for user-interface and data acquisition.
MECH368.prer: Either (a) two of MECH 220, MECH 224, ELEC 203 or (b) two of MECH 220, MECH 224, EECE 263.

MECH375.name: Heat Transfer
MECH375.desc: Steady and transient conduction. Radiation heat transfer. Convective heat and mass transfer in pipes and from external surfaces. Design of heat exchangers.
MECH375.prer: Either (a) MECH 225 or (b) one of CHBE 241, ENPH 257 and one of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280.

MECH380.name: Fluid Dynamics
MECH380.desc: Review of principles, compressible flow, potential flow, simple laminar viscous flow, boundary layers, flow around bluff bodies.
MECH380.prer: Either (a) MECH 225 or (b) MATH 255 and one of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280 and one of CHBE 241, ENPH 257.

MECH386.name: Industrial Fluid Mechanics
MECH386.desc: Analysis of piping networks. Review of pumps, turbines and hydraulic motors. Flow measurement devices such as flow meters and transducers for measuring velocity and pressure. Multiphase flows. Introduction to turbulence, mixing and buoyancy driven flows.

MECH392.name: Manufacturing Processes
MECH392.desc: Manufacturing characteristics of materials and their control. Metal forming processes, plastic deformations, rolling, forging, drawing, extrusion, sheet metal forming. Machining processes and machine tools, turning, milling, drilling, grinding. Metal fabrication, welding and casting. An introduction to process planning.

MECH420.name: Sensors and Actuators
MECH420.desc: Measurement of motion, stress, force, torque, temperature, flow and pressure; principles of sensors and signal conditioning methods; selection and sizing of actuators.
MECH420.prer: All of MECH 360, MECH 463, MECH 366 and one of ELEC 343, EECE 376.

MECH421.name: Mechatronics System Instrumentation
MECH421.desc: Architecture of mechatronics devices; integration of mechanical, electronics, sensors, actuators, computer and real time software systems; PLC and PC based systems; discrete and continuous automation system design.

MECH423.name: Mechatronic Product Design
MECH423.desc: Design of mechatronic systems for industrial and human-centric applications; compliant structures; electronic circuits to interface with sensors and actuators; embedded systems; precision timing and control; data acquisition and processing; user interfaces; and product innovation.
MECH423.prer: MECH 366 and one of ELEC 302, EECE 363. 4th year standing.

MECH431.name: Engineering Economics
MECH431.desc: Discounted cash flows. Sources of funds, cost of capital. Effects of depreciation, taxes, inflation. Evaluation and comparison of economic models for engineering projects. Replacement decisions. Public project analysis. Risk analysis. Project control, inventory analysis, simulation.

MECH433.name: Biofluids
