MECH433.desc: Review of principles, biorheology, circulatory biofluid mechanics, synovial fluid in joints, biofluid dynamics of the human brain, respiratory biofluid mechanics, flow and pressure measurement techniques in human body.

MECH435.name: Orthopaedic Biomechanics
MECH435.desc: Musculoskeletal anatomy. Muscle and joint loads. Muscle mechanics. Musculoskeletal dynamics. Gait. Tissue mechanics of tendon, ligament, articular cartilage, and bone. Biomaterials. Application examples in orthopaedics including joint replacement and fracture fixation.
MECH435.prer: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) all of APSC 278, MECH 260.

MECH436.name: Fundamentals of Injury Biomechanics
MECH436.desc: Introduction to injury biomechanics. Anatomy. Impact experiments. Multi-body dynamic simulation and finite element analysis. Skull, face, brain, spine, eye, pelvis, abdomen, and extremity injury. Anthropomorphic test devices, seat belts, airbags, child restraints, and helmets. Credit cannot be obtained for both MECH 436 and MECH 536.

MECH454.name: Thermofluids Capstone Design Project
MECH454.desc: A capstone course to provide students experience in the design/development of practical mechanical and thermofluids devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be given for only one of MECH 454, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496.
MECH454.prer: MECH 328 and fourth-year standing in the Thermofluids Option.

MECH457.name: Mechanical Engineering Design Project
MECH457.desc: A capstone design project designed to give students experience in the design/development of practical mechanical devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be given for only one of: MECH 454, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496.
MECH457.prer: MECH 328 and fourth-year standing in Mechanical Engineering.

MECH458.name: Mechatronics Design Project
MECH458.desc: A capstone design program designed to give students experience in the design/development of practical mechanical and mechatronics devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. Credit will be given for only one of: MECH 454, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496.
MECH458.prer: MECH 328 and fourth-year standing in the Mechatronics Option.

MECH459.name: Biomedical Design Project
MECH459.desc: A capstone design program designed to give students experience in the design and development of practical biomedical devices. Projects are provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories. For students in the Biomedical Option only. Credit will be given for only one of: MECH 454, MECH 457, MECH 458, MECH 459, or APSC 496.
MECH459.prer: MECH 328 and fourth-year standing in the Biomedical Option.

MECH460.name: Advanced Mechanics of Materials
MECH460.desc: Axisymmetric membrane stresses in thin shells of revolution, stresses in thick-walled cylinders and rotating disks, beams on elastic foundations, axisymmetric bending of cylindrical shells, axisymmetric bending of circular plates.

MECH462.name: Finite Element Analysis
MECH462.desc: Theory and element selection. Virtual work and weighted residual formulation. Linear elastic analysis. Heat transfer analysis. Isoparametic elements. Development of computer programs for simple problems. Utilization of existing computer packages. Application to mechanical engineering problems.

MECH463.name: Mechanical Vibrations
MECH463.desc: Theory of vibration of mechanical systems. Undamped 1 degree of freedom vibration, forced vibrations and resonance, damping, multiple degree of freedom systems, mode shapes and orthogonality, continuous systems, vibration measuring instruments and frequency spectrum analysis.

MECH464.name: Industrial Robotics
MECH464.desc: Definition and classification of industrial robotic devices. Selection and implementation issues. Workcell environments. Forward and inverse kinematics, dynamics, trajectory planning. Sensing and manipulation tasks. Control architectures. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 442, EECE 487, MECH 464, or MECH 563.

MECH466.name: Automatic Control
MECH466.desc: Process and system characteristics; transient response; the closed loop; block diagrams and transfer functions; control actions; stability; Nyquist diagrams; Bode diagrams; root locus methods; frequency response; system compensation; nonlinear control systems; digital computer control. Laboratory experiments to support the lecture content. Credit cannot be obtained for both MECH 466 and MECH 467.
MECH466.prer: Either (a) all of MECH 220, MECH 221, MECH 463 or (b) all of MATH 255, MECH 463 and one of ELEC 201, ELEC 202, EECE 251, EECE 253.

MECH467.name: Computer Control of Mechatronics Systems
MECH467.desc: Block diagrams and transfer functions, continuous and discrete domain transformations, feedback control system characteristics, control design in both continuous and discrete domain, absolute and relative stability, laboratory examples of Mechatronic systems design. Credit cannot be obtained for both MECH 466 and MECH 467.

MECH468.name: Modern Control Engineering
MECH468.desc: Introduction to state space control methods for linear systems including modal control, controllability, observability, linear quadratic regulators, optimal control.

MECH469.name: Dynamic System Modeling
MECH469.desc: Modeling of mechanical, electrical, fluid, and thermal systems; analytical models; model representations such as linear and bond graphs; response analysis; digital simulation.

MECH470.name: Energy Conversion Systems
MECH470.desc: Energy supply and demand. Energy conversion chain. Electrical power generation using thermal power plants, renewable energy, and fuel cells. Rankine cycle steam power. Brayton cycle gas turbine power plants, intercooling, reheat, and regeneration. Internal combustion engines. Exhaust gas after treatment. Combined and binary cycles. Nuclear power.

MECH473.name: Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning
MECH473.desc: Principles of air conditioning; psychometrics and refrigeration. Heat transfer through building materials. Estimation of heating and cooling loads including the use of current software. System design. Ground, air and water source heat pumps.

MECH478.name: Internal Combustion Engines
MECH478.desc: Analysis of spark and compression ignition engines. Calculation of fuel economy, power, and emission. Practical and regulatory considerations in engine design. Engine emission and control systems. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 478 or MECH 578.

MECH479.name: Computational Fluid Dynamics
MECH479.desc: Techniques for numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations, including an introduction to the finite difference, finite volume and finite element approaches. Simulation of laminar and turbulent flows, including common turbulent models. Validation techniques.

MECH481.name: Aerodynamics of Aircraft I
MECH481.desc: Low speed aerodynamics of airfoils, wings, wind tunnels.

MECH484.name: Aircraft Design: Aerodynamics
MECH484.desc: Aircraft performance, stability and control, loading and air worthiness. Detailed example.

MECH485.name: Aircraft Design: Structures
MECH485.desc: Development of aircraft wing structure, moments of inertia for complex shapes, crippling loads, shear lag.

MECH488.name: Introduction to Ship Hydrodynamics
MECH488.desc: Ship terminology, lines plans, ship hydrostatics, transverse and longitudinal stability of ships, dimensional analysis, ship resistance prediction; ship propulsion methods, propeller selection and design.
MECH488.prer: One of MECH 380, CIVL 315 or permission of instructor.

MECH489.name: Experimental Thermofluids
MECH489.desc: Experimental uncertainty. Design of experiments. Test facilities. Temperature and pressure measurement techniques and instrumentation. Velocity and flow rate measurement techniques. Flow visualization. Case studies of industrial and research experimental practice. Credit will not be given for both MECH 489 and MECH 582.

MECH491.name: Computer-Aided Manufacturing
MECH491.desc: NC programming and machining with interactive CAD/CAM systems. Curve and surface geometry for tool-path generation. Tool-path generation methodologies. Geometric modeling techniques for simulation and verification of manufacturing processes. Introduction to Computer-Aided Process Planning. Supplementary tutorial laboratory experiments.

MECH493.name: Introduction to Academic Research
MECH493.desc: Research project directed by a faculty member in Mechanical Engineeing.
MECH493.prer: Fourth-year standing and at least 80% average in third-year courses and permission of instructor.

MECH495.name: Industrial Engineering
MECH495.desc: Organizational structure. Manufacturing systems and group technology. Classification and coding. Scheduling and sequencing of operations. Forecasting. Quality control for variables and attributes. Plant location. System reliability analysis. Advanced manufacturing automation concepts.

MECH496.name: Engineering Management
MECH496.desc: Organization structures. Management styles. Cost systems and control. Financial statements; accounting procedures. Budgets and performance control. Project management. Human resources management.

MEDD411.name: Foundations of Medical Practice I
MEDD411.desc: Integrating foundational and clinical sciences and clinical practice themes. Case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Organized on the basis of clinical presentations. Pass/fail.

MEDD412.name: Foundations of Medical Practice II
MEDD412.desc: Increasingly complex clinical presentations through integration of foundational and clinical sciences and clinical practice themes. Developmental, case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Pass/fail.

MEDD419.name: Foundations of Scholarship and Flexible Enhanced Learning I
MEDD419.desc: Various medically-related learning experiences and scholarly activities. Emphasizes social accountability, introduces scholarly methods, and fosters innovation, creativity, and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, life-long learners, and leaders. Pass/fail.

MEDD421.name: Foundations of Medical Practice III
MEDD421.desc: Increasingly complex clinical presentations integrating foundational sciences and clinical practice themes. Developmental, case-based approach fostering the development of evidence-based clinical reasoning and clinical skills. Pass/Fail.

MEDD422.name: Transition into Clinical Education
MEDD422.desc: Prepares students to transition from classroom-based to clinical learning environments. Increasingly complex clinical presentations integrating foundational sciences and clinical practice themes. Prepares students for clinical practice in Year 3 Clerkship. Pass/Fail.

MEDD429.name: Flexible Enhanced Learning II
MEDD429.desc: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation, creativity, and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, life-long learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail.

MICB203.name: Basic Microbiology Laboratory
MICB203.desc: Procedures and principles associated with isolation, characterization and handling of microorganisms. Intended for students requiring a basic microbiology laboratory course. [1*-3-1*]

MICB302.name: Immunology
MICB302.desc: Cells, molecules, and mechanisms of innate and adaptive immunity. Antigen presenting cells and the major histocompatibility complex, T and B lymphocytes and their antigen receptors, T and B cell development, innate and adaptive immune responses against pathogens, diseases associated with aberrant immune responses. [3-0-1]

MICB306.name: Molecular Virology
MICB306.desc: Introduction to virus structure and replication. Detailed examination of selected viruses including polio, HIV and cancer-causing retroviruses. Development of vaccines and anti-viral drugs, the use of virus vectors to cure genetic diseases. [3-0-1]

MICB322.name: Molecular Microbiology Laboratory
MICB322.desc: Aseptic handling and characterization of microbes, growth properties, enzyme assays, protein analysis and plasmid isolation. Restricted to students in Microbiology and Immunology specializations. [2-4-0]
MICB322.prer: All of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 233, MICB 201, MICB 202.

MICB323.name: Molecular Immunology and Virology Laboratory
MICB323.desc: Genetic manipulations of bacteria, introductory immunological and virological procedures, tissue culture. Restricted to students in Microbiology and Immunology specializations. [2-4-0]

MICB353.name: Food Microbiology Laboratory
MICB353.desc: Procedures and principles associated with isolation, enumeration, characterization and handling of microorganisms. Restricted to students registered in the Food Science program. [1-2-0]

MICB401.name: Environmental Microbiology Laboratory
MICB401.desc: Microbiological analysis of environmental samples using culture-dependent and culture-independent methods. [2-4-0]

MICB404.name: Topics in Molecular Bacterial Pathogenesis
MICB404.desc: A lecture/discussion/library research course. Topics such as antibiotic resistance, pathogen genomics; host-pathogen interactions; evolution of pathogens; host responses to infection, invasive mechanisms, resistance mechanisms. [1-0-4]
MICB404.prer: MICB 302 and one of MICB 308, MICB 403, MICB 408.

MICB405.name: Bioinformatics
MICB405.desc: Computational methods to analyze genome and protein sequences to derive structural and functional information. Related topics in functional genomics. [3-0-1]
MICB405.prer: One of MICB 301, MICB 325, BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOL 335, BIOT 380.

MICB406.name: Topics in Molecular Virology
MICB406.desc: Presentations, library research, paper reviews, class discussions about current research in virology. Topics such as molecular targets in viral therapy; chronic viral infection; virus-host cell interaction. [1-0-4]

MICB412.name: Topics in Immunological Research
MICB412.desc: Presentations, library research, paper reviews and class discussion on selected areas of advanced molecular and cellular immunological research. [1-0-4]
MICB412.prer: MICB 302 and one of MICB 402, MEDG 410.

MICB418.name: Industrial Microbiology and Biotechnology
MICB418.desc: Exploitation of microbial and animal cells for the industrial production of chemicals ranging from alcohol to therapeutic proteins. Genetic manipulation of cellular characteristics, fermentation methods, patenting and governmental approval processes. [3-0-0]

MICB424.name: Cellular Dynamics of Pathogenic and Environmental Bacteria
MICB424.desc: Regulatory and signalling networks in bacterial cells with emphasis on how cellular and environmental cues are detected and integrated during different growth or life history stages of important pathogenic and environmental bacteria. [3-0-0]
MICB424.prer: Either (a) MICB 301 or (b) all of MICB 201, MICB 325.

MICB425.name: Microbial Ecological Genomics
MICB425.desc: Intrinsic and extrinsic forces driving prokaryotic genome evolution.  Gene transfer; microbial species concepts; community genome structure, function and dynamics; ecological impacts of microbial genome diversity.  Emphasis on problem solving and experimental design. [3-3-0]
MICB425.prer: One of BIOL 335, MICB 325. One of MICB 201 or MICB 301 is recommended.

MIDW101.name: Counselling for Maternity Care Providers
MIDW101.desc: Theory, knowledge, strategies, and skills of person-centered counselling including family systems, trauma theory, theory, grief counselling, motivational interviewing skills, self-awareness and mindfulness, interprofessional communication, and cultural competency in continuity of care.

MIDW102.name: Birth and its Meaning
MIDW102.desc: An interdisciplinary study of pregnancy and childbirth drawing on and integrating the disciplines of psychology, sociology, philosophy of science, anthropology, women's studies, and cultural studies.

MIDW103.name: Applied Health Services for Maternity Providers
MIDW103.desc: Introduction to diagnostics related to cellular and humoral immune responses in pregnant women and newborns, the properties of viruses, epidemiology, the principles of bacterial pathogenesis, and related physiologic responses.

MIDW104.name: Lactation Consultation for Maternity Care Providers
MIDW104.desc: Breastfeeding physiology, pathophysiology, and strategies for support of the dyad based on best-practice principles.  Discussion of major Canadian and international initiatives for the support and protection of breastfeeding.

MIDW106.name: Reproductive Anatomy and Physiology
MIDW106.desc: Physiology of conception, pregnancy, lactation, fetal growth, labour, birth, transition to extra-uterine life, postpartum. A series of lectures and lab sessions.

MIDW107.name: Physical Assessment
MIDW107.desc: Principles of physical assessment, physical and psychological assessment of the mother and neonate. A series of lectures and clinical lab sessions.

MIDW108.name: Foundations for Midwifery Practice
MIDW108.desc: Scope of practice of a midwife, regulatory framework, skills for basic midwifery practice. A series of lectures and clinical lab sessions.

MIDW115.name: Research Methods for Midwives
MIDW115.desc: Research designs used in midwifery research, types of studies reported in the midwifery and health care literature, research methodology and basic principles of epidemiology, biostatistics and social research.

MIDW125.name: Pharmacology for Maternity Care Providers
MIDW125.desc: An overview of basic concepts in pharmacology, pharmacy, and therapeutics relevant to the practice of midwifery in Canada.

MIDW215.name: Ethics in Maternity Care
MIDW215.desc: Ethics using ethical theory in health care and midwifery.

MIDW305.name: Midwifery Theory for Variations in Primary Care
MIDW305.desc: Theoretical principles of care for pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium with an emphasis on the recognition and management of variations of normal and findings outside of normal.  Consists of a one-week intensive time in Vancouver, during which emergency skills certification is acquired, and weekly web-based tutorials. [3-4-3]

MIDW320.name: Variations in Midwifery Clinical Care
MIDW320.desc: Clinical education experiences with the preventative and therapeutic midwifery care of pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium.  Emphasis on the recognition and management of variations of normal and findings outside normal.  A 12-week practicum in locations around the province.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW322.name: Midwifery Primary Care
MIDW322.desc: Clinical course focusing on consolidation of skills and knowledge of all aspects of midwifery care.

MIDW325.name: Professional Issues in Midwifery
MIDW325.desc: Professional issues in midwifery including responsibilities and conduct, self-care, peer review, inter-professional relations and communication, legal and business concepts, and continuous quality assurance and improvement in practice.  A series of lectures and workshops delivered in an intensive format over two weeks.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW360.name: Global Maternal Infant Health
MIDW360.desc: Social and economic determinants of maternal and fetal health worldwide, innovative public health strategies to reducing maternal and infant mortality and morbidity, and the impact of conflict on the health of mothers and babies.  Ethical considerations related to global clinical placements and medical tourism.  Theoretical course in preparation for global clinical placement.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW380.name: Midwifery in Special Contexts
MIDW380.desc: Clinical course providing opportunity to study midwifery in contexts beyond those usually offered on the program. Students select context and provide rationale for how the context will enhance their learning.

MIDW405.name: Advanced Topics in Midwifery Theory and Practice
MIDW405.desc: Theoretical principles for midwifery care of pregnancy, labour, birth, newborns, and the puerperium.  Emphasis on assessment and management skills for abnormal situations.  Includes a five-day intensive session in Vancouver, a series of online tutorials, and lab practice. [1-2-3]

MINE224.name: Mineralogy for Mining Engineering
MINE224.desc: Fundamentals of the main techniques used by the industry to characterize raw materials and troubleshoot processing plants.

MINE291.name: Introduction to Mining
MINE291.desc: Leading practices and technologies employed in the design, planning, and operation of mining systems. Life cycle of surface and underground mining systems.

MINE292.name: Introduction to Mineral Processing
MINE292.desc: Overview; extracting a mineral or final product from an ore.

MINE293.name: Seminar
MINE293.desc: Oral presentation of topics by students. Graded on basis of report and presentation.

MINE302.name: Underground Mining and Design
MINE302.desc: Selection, design and development of underground mining methods based upon physical, geological, economical and environmental constraints. Underground materials handling (ore, waste, slurry, water) with equipment selection, production requirements, performance and costs.

MINE303.name: Rock Mechanics Fundamentals
MINE303.desc: The study of the mechanical and structural properties of rock materials at the laboratory and field level. The relevance of such studies to common mining, geological and civil engineering problems. Credit will be granted for only one of MINE 303 or MINE 305.
MINE303.prer: One of CIVL 230, MECH 260. MINE 290 is recommended.

MINE304.name: Rock Fragmentation
MINE304.desc: Theory and practice of rock fragmentation by drilling and blasting; introduction to explosives and initiation systems; design of surface and underground blasts; machine excavation systems for tunneling and stoping; environmental impacts, safety, and risk assessment.

MINE310.name: Surface Mining and Design
MINE310.desc: Surface mining methods, production planning and scheduling; slope design and drainage; wall control; materials handling and equipment selection; production control and automation, waste disposal and closure.

MINE331.name: Physical Mineral Processes
MINE331.desc: Mineral processing unit operations and sampling, crushing, grinding, screening, classification, gravity separation, magnetic separation, electrostatic separation, concentrate dewatering practices.

MINE333.name: Flotation
MINE333.desc: Theory and technology of flotation and ancillary processes.

MINE350.name: Modeling and Simulation
MINE350.desc: Methods for determining the behaviour of large scale industrial systems and their application to the design and analysis of such systems.

MINE393.name: Seminar
MINE393.desc: Oral presentation of topics by instructor and guest lecturers.

MINE396.name: Engineering Economics
MINE396.desc: Discrete and continuous cash flow models, discounted cash flow analysis, effects of depreciation and taxes, economic analysis of projects, sensitivity and risk analysis, financing and cost of capital.

MINE402.name: Mine Ventilation and Occupational Health and Safety
MINE402.desc: Design and analysis for ventilation systems for mining. Topics such as ventilation design, ventilation surveys, thermodynamic aspects, psychrometry of air and air conditioning.

MINE403.name: Rock Mechanics Design
MINE403.desc: The design of rock slopes and underground openings with respect to stress, structure and the rock mass. Stabilization and monitoring of rock movement.

MINE404.name: Mine Management
MINE404.desc: Human relations in an organization; types of organizations; personnel evaluations and job rating systems; impact of manpower planning on decision-making; union negotiations; public relations; dealing with the media; corporate responsibilities to society and employees.
MINE404.prer: Third- or Fourth-year standing in Mining Engineering.

MINE406.name: Mine Project Valuation and Risk Assessment
MINE406.desc: Mineral economics and finance. Analytical tools and techniques used in the valuation of mining companies and the financial analysis and risk assessment methods. [2-2-0]

MINE432.name: Mineral Process Control
MINE432.desc: Automatic control theory, PID control, Laplace and z-transforms, loop tuning, frequency response, stability analysis, control strategies in flotation, comminution, dewatering, reagent and bin/sump levels, automated load-haul-dump and drilling equipment, instrumentation and soft sensors.

MINE434.name: Processing Precious Metal Ores
MINE434.desc: Process alternatives and mineralogical considerations; physical and chemical recovery technologies; environmental protection; flowsheet studies.

MINE438.name: Advanced Process Mineralogy
MINE438.desc: Textural parameters, such as mineral liberation size and mineral associations in connection with the mineral processing techniques for mineral recovery.

MINE455.name: Mine Water Management
MINE455.desc: Mine water management covering integrated water resource management, water balances, sources, water use optimization, water quality and treatment and long term stewardship. [2-2-0]

MINE462.name: Coal Preparation Technology
MINE462.desc: Thermal and metallurgical coals: objectives of their cleaning; coal washability and flotability fundamentals; coal preparation unit operations; performance characteristics of coal washing equipment; products dewatering; plant flowsheets.

MINE465.name: Materials Handling
MINE465.desc: Knowledge and understanding of equipment used in mining operations, including diesel, electro-mechanical, hydraulic and pneumatic equipment as well as conveyors, load-haul-dump trucks and pumps. [2-2-0]

MINE480.name: Mine Waste Management
MINE480.desc: Basic geotechnical, hydrological, and water management aspects of mine waste management.

MINE482.name: Maintenance Engineering
MINE482.desc: Analytical foundation for maintenance of industrial plant equipment and mobile equipment in various production environments; maintenance planning and management, life cycle analysis, reliability theory, total quality maintenance, condition monitoring.

MINE485.name: Cave Mining Systems: Design and Planning
MINE485.desc: Designs, planning, and leading practices are applied to underground mining systems reliant on induced and controlled rock mass caving.

MINE486.name: Mining and The Environment
MINE486.desc: Environmental topics of importance to engineers practicing within the mining, metallurgical and related industries including technical practices, regulatory and public issues.

MINE488.name: Heavy Oil Sand Mining and Processing
MINE488.desc: Life cycle of the production of Oil Sands resources, including mining, bitumen extraction, and reclamation.

MINE491.name: Mine and Plant Feasibility Study
MINE491.desc: Design of a mining operation or a mineral processing plant as part of a realistic feasibility study project.
MINE491.prer: All of MINE 302, MINE 303, MINE 304, MINE 310, MINE 331, MINE 333, MINE 350, MINE 396. Fourth-year standing in Mining Engineering is required.

MINE493.name: Seminar
MINE493.desc: Oral presentation of a technical nature. Use of closed circuit television for personal evaluation.

NEST101.name: Introduction to Near Eastern and Egyptian Archaeology
NEST101.desc: An overview of the past two centuries of archaeological investigations of the civilizations of the ancient Near East and Egypt.

NEST301.name: Early Empires of the Ancient Middle East
NEST301.desc: A history from 3100-333 BC with emphasis on Mesopotamia.

NEST303.name: History of Ancient Egypt
NEST303.desc: History and culture of Ancient Egyptian civilization from political, intellectual, social and environmental perspectives

NEST304.name: Ancient Egypt: The Archaeology of the Land of the Pharoahs
NEST304.desc: The material remains of the ancient Egyptians from monumental tombs and temples to the artifacts of daily life; the development of Egyptian civilization from the rise of the first rulers to its incorporation into the Roman Empire.

NEST312.name: Religion in Ancient Egypt
NEST312.desc: A survey of the religious beliefs, cults, and religious institutions in Pharaonic Egypt.

NEST313.name: Introduction to Middle Egyptian
NEST313.desc: Language of Ancient Egypt and the main literary texts composed during the Middle Kingdom.

PCTH201.name: Drugs and Society
PCTH201.desc: Introductory principles of drug action. Historical and present day medical and non-medical use of drugs. [3-0]
PCTH201.prer: One of Biology 12, BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155, or SCIE 001.  Second-year standing is required.

PCTH302.name: Introductory Pharmacology Laboratory
PCTH302.desc: A series of experimental demonstrations and individual laboratory experiments illustrating the basic principles of pharmacology. [1-3*]

PCTH325.name: Rational Basis of Drug Therapy
PCTH325.desc: The principles and applications underlying the action and disposition of therapeutic agents (including alternative medicines) in the body.  Use of drugs as tools in experimental research. [3-0]
PCTH325.prer: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOC 300.

PCTH400.name: Systematic Pharmacology
PCTH400.desc: Lectures and discussions in scientific pharmacology. All aspects of the study of drugs will be covered, but the course will concentrate on the scientific aspects of the pharmacology of neurohumoral transmission, mathematics of pharmacology, cardiovascular and clinical pharmacology, and to a lesser extent on the pharmacology of various organs and tissues. [3-0-1*]

PCTH402.name: Systematic Pharmacology Laboratory
PCTH402.desc: A series of demonstrated, group, and individual laboratory experiments designed to illustrate the concepts and hypotheses of pharmacology. The course is restricted to Honours students in Pharmacology, but may be taken by others with permission of the department head. [0-9; 0-9]

PCTH404.name: Drug Assay and Pharmacometrics
PCTH404.desc: The techniques, including methods of statistical analysis, used to detect and measure the actions of endogenous or exogenous chemicals, using chemical assays and bioassays as appropriate. Enrolment limited to students in Pharmacology and others with permission of the department head. [1-0; 2-0]

PHAR400.name: Pharmacy Management
PHAR400.desc: Application of management principles to pharmacy operations.

PHAR406.name: Drug Safety
PHAR406.desc: Pharmacist knowledge and skills in relation to current issues in drug safety.

PHAR408.name: Clinical Pharmacokinetics
PHAR408.desc: Lectures and discussions of topics on the application of pharmacokinetic principles and the use of therapeutic drug level monitoring in clinical pharmacy practice.
PHAR408.prer: Successful completion of all required courses in the first three years of the pharmacy curriculum.

PHAR409.name: Renal Pharmacotherapeutics
PHAR409.desc: Case-based approach to the pathophysiology, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapy in nephrology with emphasis on the integration and application of fundamental principles to clinical situations in class and during their experiential component.
PHAR409.prer: Successful completion of all required courses in the first three years of the pharmacy curriculum.

PHAR440.name: Pain Research and Therapy
PHAR440.desc: A multidisciplinary course dealing with basic mechanisms and the clinical management of acute and chronic pain.

PHAR448.name: Environmental and Cellular Toxicology
PHAR448.desc: Basic principles of toxicology; toxicity of drugs and environmental chemicals, including pesticides.

PHAR456.name: Applied Pharmacoeconomics
PHAR456.desc: Principles and methods of economic assessments to determine the value of health technologies, with a focus on pharmaceuticals and services provided by pharmacists.

PHAR457.name: Pharmaceutical Care in Aboriginal Health
PHAR457.desc: Aboriginal health in Canada and the role a culturally-competent pharmacist can have in collaborating with other health professionals and Aboriginal communities in providing care and healing.

PHAR458.name: Pharmacotherapy in Oncology
PHAR458.desc: Common oncological diseases and their drug treatment.

PHAR489.name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Institutional
PHAR489.desc: A 160-hour pharmacy clerkship emphasizing integration of knowledge and skills in developing and assessing therapeutic plans for patients in institutional practice.

PHAR499.name: Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences IV
PHAR499.desc: Case studies and other activities integrating scientific and clinical concepts.

PLAN211.name: City-Making: A Global Perspective
PLAN211.desc: Contemporary city development trends, policies, and practices across the globe as explored against the backdrop of culture and technology. Includes hands-on learning.
PLAN211.prer: Second-year standing or above in any program.

PLAN221.name: City Visuals
PLAN221.desc: An exploratory journey through the vast world of visualizing the city and ways of representing the built environment, including how to both interpret and use visualizations to read the city.
PLAN221.prer: Second-year standing or above in any program.

PLAN331.name: The Just City in a Divided World
PLAN331.desc: Considers the city as a terrain for the manifestation and mediation of social justice. Explores how the allocation of land, goods, and services in cities (re)produces social stratification, and how institutions and civil society negotiate just and unjust outcomes.
PLAN331.prer: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.

PLAN425.name: Urban Planning Issues and Concepts
PLAN425.desc: Evolution, practice and future of urban planning and development, with emphasis on institutional arrangements, housing, transportation, urban design and development control. For third- and fourth-year undergraduate students interested in urban planning.

POLI220.name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
POLI220.desc: A comparative analysis of foreign governments. Specific countries to be covered will vary according to section; consult the brochure issued by the Department.

POLI303.name: Federalism in Canada
POLI303.desc: Theory and practice of federalism; cultural duality, social stresses, and problems of flexibility. The constitution and role of the courts.

POLI304.name: British Columbia Government and Politics
POLI304.desc: An examination of the party system, and other institutions and processes of the British Columbia political system.

POLI309.name: Canadian Perspectives on Human Rights
POLI309.desc: Key issues in the theory and practice of human rights in Canada. Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI310.name: Parliament and Party: The Strategy of Politics
POLI310.desc: Parliamentary and party politics, showing how politicians in Canada and other countries strike bargains with allies, outmanoeuvre opponents in debates, and manipulate institutional rules.

POLI327.name: European Integration
POLI327.desc: Post-1945 integration of Europe, comparison of national politics and attitudes to integration, and the history and institutions of the European Union.

POLI332.name: Politics and Government of Latin America
POLI332.desc: A comparative examination of democracy and authoritarianism in Latin America: populism, corporatism, bureaucratic authoritarianism, transitions from authoritarianism, and contemporary debates on the quality and diversity of democratic institutions.

POLI345.name: Gender and Politics: Political Thought and Practice
POLI345.desc: The role of gender in Western political theory and the implications for the practice of politics.

POLI366.name: International Political Economy
POLI366.desc: An analysis of governmental policies and international political bargaining in regard to such issues as international investment, trade, and monetary relations. Pre-requisite: ECON 100 or 309 are recommended.

POLI377.name: Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
POLI377.desc: Evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
POLI377.prer: Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. progrm, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program

POLI390.name: Honours Seminar
POLI390.desc: An examination of the dimensions of Political Science and the major debates within the discipline.

POLI461.name: Peace and Conflict Studies
POLI461.desc: A seminar on a selected topic concerning the causes of war and strategies for the promotion of peace. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI461.prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

POLI462.name: International Relations Theory
POLI462.desc: This seminar examines some of the major theoretical approaches to the study of international relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI462.prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

POLI463.name: International Interdependence
POLI463.desc: This seminar analyses issues relating to the politics of international economic relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the brochure issued by the Department.
POLI463.prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370. 6 credits of ECON are recommended.

POLI492.name: Honours Thesis
POLI492.desc: In consultation with faculty, students develop a research project, report on their project during seminars, give feedback on their fellow students' projects, and write a thesis.

RELG101.name: Introduction to the Western (Abrahamic) Religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam
RELG101.desc: An overview of the three main western monotheistic (Abrahamic) religions, together with the concepts used in studying religion, The focus will be on the origins and representative texts along with some historical development and current experience of each religion.

RELG201.name: Near Eastern and Biblical Mythology
RELG201.desc: An introduction to the world of Near Eastern mythology, from the Gilgamesh Epic to the Book of Genesis and beyond.

RELG203.name: Scriptures of the Near East
RELG203.desc: An introduction to the scriptures of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

RELG207.name: Classical Islam
RELG207.desc: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Islamic societies from 700-1500; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

RELG208.name: Modern Islam
RELG208.desc: The history and culture, values, and socio-political movements of the Islamic world from 1500 to the modern day; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in modern Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

RELG209.name: Eden to Exile: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
RELG209.desc: An overview of the Hebrew Bible ("Old Testament"), with emphasis on its ancient Near Eastern context; its competing religious perspectives; and its limits as a historical source.

RELG306.name: Archaeology and the Bible
RELG306.desc: The impact of archaeological research on understanding the history and religion of ancient Israel.

RELG307.name: Sex, Lies, and Violence in the Hebrew Bible
RELG307.desc: An exploration of the Bible's "dark side," with emphasis on texts that center on sex, deceit, and murder.

RELG317.name: The Origins of Christianity: Social, Religious, and Political Milieux
RELG317.desc: The origins of Christianity as reflected in early Christian literature of the first and early second centuries (including the New Testament).

RELG330.name: The Origins of Judaism
RELG330.desc: Surveys the history of Jews and Judaism in the Second Temple era, from the destruction of the First Jerusalem Temple (586 B.C.E.) to the beginnings of the rabbinic movement (200 C.E.).

RELG414.name: The Gospels and the Historical Jesus
RELG414.desc: The canonical and apocryphal gospels and the life and teachings of the historical Jesus.

RELG415.name: The Life and Thought of Paul of Tarsus
RELG415.desc: The life and literature of Paul in the Roman imperial world: letter writing, patronage and power; Roman imperial iconography; Paul and community formation.

RELG448.name: Seminar in the History of the Religion of Islam
RELG448.desc: A topic relevant to the study of Islam as a religion: e.g., the text and doctrines of the Qur'an; the Hadith (or Traditions) of the Prophet; Islamic Law; mysticism in Islam; the Shi'ah and the Isma'ilis. Not offered every year. Consult the departmental brochure for the topic to be offered.

RMST221.name: Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World I: Medieval to Early Modern
RMST221.desc: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe as its different national identities emerged in the Mediterranean sphere.

RMST222.name: Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World II: Modern to Post-Modern
RMST222.desc: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe in the age of the nation state, imperialism, colonization, and decolonization.

SOCI101.name: Social Interaction and Culture
SOCI101.desc: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.

SOCI201.name: Ethnic Relations
SOCI201.desc: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

SOCI220.name: Sociology of Indigenous Peoples
SOCI220.desc: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.

SOCI285.name: Citizenship and Identity
SOCI285.desc: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).

SOCI324.name: Sociology of the Life Course
SOCI324.desc: Individuals and families through the life course.
SOCI324.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI342.name: Consumers and Consumption
SOCI342.desc: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption.

SOCI364.name: Built Environments
SOCI364.desc: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning.

SOCI370.name: Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches
SOCI370.desc: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372.

SOCI372.name: Contemporary Directions in Theory
SOCI372.desc: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370.

SOCI382.name: Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
SOCI382.desc: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals.
SOCI382.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI387.name: Drugs and Society
SOCI387.desc: Social dimensions of the causes, consequences, regulation, and treatment of substance abuse and addiction from Canadian and international perspectives.

SOCI416.name: Selected Topics in Sociological Theory
SOCI416.desc: An in-depth examination of selected sociological theories. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

SOCI423.name: Sociology of Food
SOCI423.desc: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender.  Food-related social movements will be included.

SOCI441.name: Society, Economy and Family
SOCI441.desc: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440.
SOCI441.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI442.name: Families and Work
SOCI442.desc: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442.
SOCI442.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI444.name: Sociology of Aging
SOCI444.desc: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations.
SOCI444.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI490.name: Contemporary Chinese Society
SOCI490.desc: Current social topics in Chinese society; perspectives on gender, inequality, culture, and social relations.

SPAN206.name: Conversational Spanish I
SPAN206.desc: Emphasizes communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; developing oral fluency and listening comprehension, through discussion of written texts and films. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

SPAN207.name: Conversational Spanish II
SPAN207.desc: Builds on communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; exploration of cultural topics through discussion of written texts and other media. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

SPAN221.name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature
SPAN221.desc: Major texts, authors, periods, and genres of Hispanic literature; key concepts, terminology, and practices of literary analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish literature courses.

SPAN222.name: Introduction to Hispanic Culture
SPAN222.desc: Media, figures, periods, and genres of Hispanic culture; key concepts, theories, and practices of cultural analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish culture courses.

SPAN301.name: Advanced Spanish I
SPAN301.desc: Advanced grammar structures in context, lexical repertoire, fluency and cultural awareness to broaden and develop language skills.

SPAN302.name: Advanced Spanish II
SPAN302.desc: Advanced grammar structures in context; students expand lexical repertoire, and gain fluency and flexibility as they deepen cultural awareness through reading, listening, discussion, and writing.

SPAN321.name: Tradition and Diversity in Spanish History and Culture
SPAN321.desc: Conservation and progress on the Iberian Peninsula, from the Middle Ages to the present. Includes the first modern European state and its diverse cultures.

SPAN357.name: The Golden Age of Peninsular Literature and Culture
SPAN357.desc: Tradition, faith, conflict, prosperity, and decadence in literature and everyday life from the Middle Ages to 1700.

SPAN358.name: Divergent Visions: Peninsular Literature and Culture since 1700
SPAN358.desc: Modern Spanish literature and culture, from Empire to the European Union. Includes Romanticism, Modernism, Republicanism, and Separatism.

SPAN364.name: Colonial Encounters in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
SPAN364.desc: Spanish colonialism in the Americas from the Conquest to the 1820's and the dawn of Independence. Includes coloniality, hybridity, subalternity, and autonomy.

SPAN365.name: Modern Magics: Spanish-American Literature and Culture since the 1820s
SPAN365.desc: Literary engagements with modernity in the Spanish Americas, from the 1820's to the present. Includes civilization, progress, politicization, and violence.

SPAN402.name: Advanced Spanish III
SPAN402.desc: Developing linguistic proficiency and effective and accurate communication in both spoken and written Spanish. Includes close reading of texts, advanced written composition, cross-cultural analysis, and conversational skills.

SPAN411.name: Hispanic Linguistics
SPAN411.desc: Spanish as a linguistic system. Includes the structure of Spanish words and sentences, dialectal varieties in both Spain and Latin America, and linguistic theory.

SPAN495.name: Research Intensive Seminar in Hispanic Literature and Culture
SPAN495.desc: Theories and methodologies of the discipline. Consult the Department for this year's offering.

SPPH300.name: Working in International Health
SPPH300.desc: This is a tutored, web based Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course on planning/preparing for work in a developing country. Causes of ill health amongst populations living in poverty; analysis of available solutions. Health Science background not essential. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 300 or IHHS 300.

SPPH302.name: Topics in Health Informatics for Health/Life Sciences Students
SPPH302.desc: Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 302 or IHHS 302.

SPPH400.name: Statistics for Health Research
SPPH400.desc: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples primarily from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and non-parametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Class size may be limited. [3-0]
SPPH400.prer: Ability to use high school Algebra and simple graphs.

SPPH410.name: Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions
SPPH410.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course promotes collaborating interprofessionally. Each student team will identify and research a critical public health issue, and develop a detailed practical and effective intervention. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 410 or IHHS 410.

SPPH411.name: Violence Across the Lifespan
SPPH411.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers violence in families across the lifespan. Particular emphasis on intersections of race, class, and gender; the long-term impact of childhood exposure to violence; and prevention-focused initiatives. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 411 or IHHS 411.

VANT148.name: UBC Vantage College Projects
VANT148.desc: Projects linked to topics explored in the UBC Vantage College International Program curricula. [1-0-1; 1-0-1]

VANT150.name: Sustainability and Engineering Design
VANT150.desc: Topics in sustainability, including the impact of technology on the environment and society, and fundamentals of engineering design. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [1-0-1; 1-0-1]

ASTU204.name: Topics in Interdisciplinary Arts Studies
ASTU204.desc: Selected interdisciplinary topics in Arts studies.  For upcoming offerings including course descriptions and possible enrolment restrictions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule.

ASTU210.name: Global Citizenship, Part 1: Introduction
ASTU210.desc: Themes of global citizenship, sustainability, and civil society, and barriers and bridges to global thinking.

ASTU211.name: Global Citizenship, Part 2: Community Service Learning and Capstone Conference

ASTU400.name: Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts
ASTU400.desc: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

ASTU401.name: Special Topics in Arts Studies
ASTU401.desc: Selected topics offered by a distinguished visitor to the campus. For upcoming offerings including course descriptions and possible enrolment restrictions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule.

ACAM300.name: Dis/Orienting Asian Canada
ACAM300.desc: The histories, cultures, social dynamics, and life experiences of Asian communities in Canada in the context of global migrations. Restricted to students with second year status or higher.

ACAM320.name: Selected Topics in ACAM Studies
ACAM320.desc: Selected Asian Canadian Asian Migration topics. Consult acam.arts.ubc.ca for this year's offerings.
ACAM320.prer: Restricted to students with at least Second year standing; a previous course in Asian Canadian and Asian Migration Studies is recommended.

ACAM447.name: Directed Studies in Asian Canadian and Asian Migration
ACAM447.desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking within the scope of Asian Canadian and Asian Migration.
ACAM447.prer: Permission of the Chair of the ACAM program.

KIN115.name: Performance Analysis of Selected Individual Sports and Activities
KIN115.desc: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 115 and 215 can be taken in any order. [2-2]

KIN215.name: Performance Analysis of Selected Team Sports and Activities
KIN215.desc: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 115 and 215 can be taken in any order. [2-2]

KIN343.name: Biology of Human Athletic Performance
KIN343.desc: Basics of exercise physiology and related issues pertaining to sports and athletic performance for non-Kinesiology students.  Not for credit in the B.Kin. Program. [3-0]

KIN353.name: Human Body Composition
KIN353.desc: Examination of techniques for measuring the amounts of adipose tissue, muscle and bone in the body, and factors affecting body composition, with particular emphasis on physical activity. [3-0]

KIN392.name: The Leisure and Sport Industry
KIN392.desc: Economic and financial issues in the leisure and sport industry. Topics include entrepreneurship, economic impact, commercialization, patterns of ownership and control, and selected financial practices. [3-0]

KIN403.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN403.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.

KIN454.name: Field Experience
KIN454.desc: Students have the opportunity to develop their leadership, instruction, and professional skills in a variety of supervised fieldwork settings. Students should select the section of the course (A, B) most relevant to their program of study and career goals.

KIN455.name: Field Work and Field Research Practicum
KIN455.desc: Field work and a field research project will be undertaken concurrently in a cooperating leisure, sport or other agency over one term in fourth year (30 hours per week). Students will also attend weekly seminars to discuss field work and the field research projects. Limited enrolment.
KIN455.prer: One of KIN  371, HKIN 371. Fourth-year standing and approval from KIN Program Coordinator.

KIN469.name: Chronic Health Issues, Physical Activity, and Community Practice
KIN469.desc: Issues related to physical activity and public health. Focus on community interventions.  Creation of activity plans that promote physical, mental, and/or social well-being in persons dealing with chronic health issues. Community service-learning component. [3-0]

KIN489.name: Seminar
KIN489.desc: Current topics and research in specific areas. [3-0-0]
KIN489.prer: Fourth-year standing. Consult with Advisor for specific prerequisites.

GERM213.name: Refresher I
GERM213.desc: Grammar-based course for students with previous untutored  exposure to German and students with a first-year knowledge in need of grammar review.

GERM305.name: The Culture of Nazism (in English)
GERM305.desc: Literature, film and ideology in the Third Reich.

GERM318.name: Introduction to German Linguistics
GERM318.desc: Basic theories and methodologies of modern German linguistics.

GERM319.name: Canadian German Cultural Dialogues
GERM319.desc: Analysis of intercultural theory; examination of Canadian and German print and video materials.  Includes direct audio/visual intercultural online discussion with German-speaking students at the University of Kiel.

GERM370.name: Reason and Revolution: Studies in the 18th Century
GERM370.desc: Masterpieces and major trends of eighteenth-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

GERM390.name: Progress and Disaster: Studies in the 20th and 21st Centuries
GERM390.desc: Masterpieces and major trends of 20th and 21st-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

GERM401.name: The Cult of the Hero and its Parody in German Literature
GERM401.desc: The glorification and satirization of heroes and heroism in a variety of genres and periods. Works and authors to be studied might include Nibelungenlied, Faust, Gryphius, Kleist, Fontane, Brecht, Remarque.

GERM403.name: Studies in Modern German Culture (in English)
GERM403.desc: Topics of special interest, varying from year to year.

GERM405.name: The Literature of Growing Social Consciousness
GERM405.desc: Concentrates on the late 18th to the early 20th century. This course traces the reflections in German literature of changes in social, political, cultural and gender concepts. Readings are drawn from a variety of genres.

GERM406.name: Selected Topics in German Literature
GERM406.desc: A study in depth of one topic of special interest, varying from year to year depending on interests of faculty and students. Possible topics: literature and film, the image of the outside world in German literature, individualism and conformism.

GERM407.name: The German Lyric from Goethe to the Present
GERM407.desc: Reading and discussion of selected texts against their cultural, social and political background.

GERM408.name: Selected Issues in German Culture
GERM408.desc: In depth study of one topic from German cultural history, varying from year to year. Possible topics: Germany of the New Europe; Gender and nation in German culture; topics from theory, such as the Frankfurt School.

GERM409.name: Special Topics in German Cinema (in English)
GERM409.desc: Themes, traditions and techniques specific to German cinema.

GERM420.name: Advanced German III
GERM420.desc: Near-native competence and an advanced and transferable understanding of contemporary issues.

GERM430.name: Advanced German IV
GERM430.desc: Near-native competence and an advanced and transferable understanding of contemporary issues, intercultural comparisons and analyses in a variety of fields using German as the focus and means of communication.

SLAV105.name: Introduction to Russian and Slavic Culture
SLAV105.desc: Cultural developments from the medieval period to the present.

SLAV307.name: Literature and Film in Eastern Europe
SLAV307.desc: Films and translated literature by Slavic writers with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

EOSC256.name: Earthquakes
EOSC256.desc: Characteristics, types, plate tectonics, faults, earth stresses and strains, seismic waves, magnitude scales, instrumentation, hazard mapping, prediction, and forecasting. [3-0-0]
EOSC256.prer: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157;  or (b) SCIE 001.

EOSC327.name: Geochemical Thermodynamics
EOSC327.desc: Application of chemical thermodynamics to problem solving in the earth sciences.  Geochemical tools are developed for: low-T aqueous geochemistry, high-T, high-P processes in the lithosphere, ore-deposit formation, and for prediction of geochemical reaction rates in all environments. [2-2-0]

EOSC355.name: The Planets
EOSC355.desc: Diversity among the planets and moons of the solar system; integrating concepts across scientific disciplines, including geology, geophysics, and atmospheric science to understand how planets evolve. [3-0]
EOSC355.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

EOSC421.name: Advanced Sedimentology
EOSC421.desc: Description and interpretation of ancient and modern sediments, with emphasis on the origin, composition, textures, structures, diagenesis and chemistry of biogenic sediments. [2-2-0]

EOSC426.name: Fundamentals of Geomicrobiology
EOSC426.desc: Foundational knowledge of the interactions between microorganisms and Earth's surface chemistry.
EOSC426.prer: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 121, CHEM 111, CHEM 121, EOSC 110, EOSC 112. Third year standing in Science.

EOSC431.name: Groundwater Remediation
EOSC431.desc: Methods for containment and remediation of subsurface contaminants; including groundwater control, groundwater extraction, and in situ treatment. Experience with common design approaches. [2-2-0]

EOSC432.name: Fossil Fuels
EOSC432.desc: Origin, geochemistry and distribution of petroleum and coal in the stratigraphic record. Sedimentation of organic matter, organic diagenesis, migration and accumulation of hydrocarbons. Principles of exploration and development. Techniques for measurement of organic maturation and source rock analyses. [2-2-0]

EOSC448.name: Directed Studies
EOSC448.desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of an undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

EOSC490.name: Student Directed Seminars in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
EOSC490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in earth, ocean and atmospheric sciences, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars (www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/sds/sds_handbook.pdf).

ARBC420.name: Supervised Study in Classical Arabic
ARBC420.desc: Religious and literary Arabic texts pertaining to the early and medieval Islamic world.

ELEC361.name: Molecules to Mechanisms
ELEC361.desc: Forces, scaling, thermal, fluidic, and mechanical properties relevant to the design of emerging devices and systems whose basic structures are at micrometer and nanometer scales.

ELEC400.name: Topics in Electrical Engineering
ELEC400.desc: Lectures or projects on subjects of current interest.

ELEC416.name: Quantum Dots and Device Applications
ELEC416.desc: Theory and modeling techniques of 0-dimensional structures. Electronic, magnetic, and optical properties of quantum dots. Current and future applications of quantum dots including: single electron transistors, quantum dot lasers, optical detectors.

ELEC452.name: Industrial Drives
ELEC452.desc: Typical mechanical loads; dynamic and static characteristics and analysis of DC and AC drives; microprocessor-based controllers; commercial choices of drives for various applications.
ELEC452.prer: One of EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 376, ELEC 343.

ELEC464.name: Nanotechnology and Nature
ELEC464.desc: Examples of nature's fabrication methods, sensors, actuators, energy harvesting, signaling and information processing, and comparisons with artificial methods.

ELEC472.name: Biomechatronics
ELEC472.desc: Design of mechatronic systems to measure and manipulate biological materials and processes; compliant structures; bioelectronic circuits; biomedical embedded systems and BioMEMS.  Example applications from clinical medicine and biomedical research.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 423 or EECE 424.
ELEC472.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 253, ELEC 202 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of EECE 360, ELEC 341.

ELEC499.name: Undergraduate Thesis
ELEC499.desc: Project in electrical engineering or computer engineering involving design, experimental and/or computer simulation work as selected from topics supplied by faculty members. An individual project thesis is to be prepared according to specifications available from the departmental office.

ASLA300.name: Studies in an Asian Language (Basic Course)
ASLA300.desc: Introduction to the fundamentals of an Asian language not normally taught in the Department. Not given every year. Consult the Department for details.

ASLA400.name: Studies in an Asian Language (Intermediate Course)
ASLA400.prer: ASLA 300. Permission of the instructor is also acceptable.

JAPN204.name: Basic Japanese Grammar
JAPN204.desc: Emphasis on grammar, writing and reading Intended for students with a background in spoken Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 204 or JAPN 104.

JAPN261.name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning Japanese
JAPN261.desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 261 or JAPN 161.

JAPN342.name: Reading Course in Japanese for Honours Students

JAPN403.name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition II
JAPN403.desc: Improvement of speaking and writing skills through readings and discussions on a variety of social and cultural issues; emphasis on the development of formal presentation skills. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 402 and JAPN 403 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 403 or JAPN 303.

JAPN422.name: Classical Japanese I
JAPN422.desc: The grammar, orthography, and literary style of pre-modern Japanese (bungo).  It is strongly recommended that students have 12 credits of JAPN, or equivalent, prior to registration. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 422 or JAPN 311.

JAPN423.name: Classical Japanese II
JAPN423.desc: A continuation of JAPN 422.  Focus on reading pre-modern primary sources and producing English translations. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 423 or JAPN 312.

JAPN424.name: Japanese for Professional Life I
JAPN424.desc: Technical Japanese as it is used in business, commerce, industry, etc. Emphasis on specialized current vocabulary and on the development of communicative competence relevant for workplaces in these fields. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 424 or JAPN 314.
JAPN424.prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

JAPN425.name: Japanese for Professional Life II
JAPN425.desc: Continuation of JAPN 424. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 425 or JAPN 315.

JAPN451.name: Advanced Oral Communication II
JAPN451.desc: A continuation of JAPN 450. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 451 or JAPN 411.

JAPN457.name: Newspaper Japanese II
JAPN457.desc: A continuation of JAPN 456. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 457 or JAPN 417.

JAPN459.name: Topics in Japanese Language, Culture, and Society
JAPN459.desc: Advanced Japanese language course combined with analysis of various media in literary, journalistic, and popular genres drawn from history, sociology, cultural studies, etc. Practice in the use of standard reference tools prepares students for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to JAPN 459. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 459 or JAPN 419.
JAPN459.prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and permission from instructor.

JAPN460.name: Grammatical Analysis of Japanese I
JAPN460.desc: Analysis of the grammatical structure of modern Japanese. Contrastive analysis of Japanese and English as well as error analysis. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 460 or JAPN 420.
JAPN460.prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 303, JAPN 403.

JAPN461.name: Grammatical Analysis of Japanese II
JAPN461.desc: A continuation of JAPN 460. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 461 or JAPN 421.

JAPN462.name: Researching Modern Japanese Religions
JAPN462.desc: Research tools and approaches to the interdisciplinary study of modern Japanese religions (nineteenth century to the present) including state-of-the-field works in English, and locating primary and secondary materials in Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 462 or JAPN 452.
JAPN462.prer: 6 credits of 200- or 300-level courses in Asian religions; 3 credit writing-intensive course in Asian Studies; ability to read modern Japanese or 18 credits of Japanese language courses and permission of instructor.

JAPN470.name: Supervised Study in the Japanese Language
JAPN470.desc: Primarily for graduate students. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 470 or JAPN 440.

JAPN472.name: Tutorial in Japanese for Honours Students
JAPN472.desc: This course will require the presentation of at least one research paper. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 472 or JAPN 442.

PCTH425.name: Medical Pharmacology
PCTH425.desc: A lecture and laboratory course covering the fundamental pharmacological action of drugs.  Both terms.

PCTH448.name: Directed Studies in Pharmacology
PCTH448.desc: Advanced investigation of a specific topic in Pharmacology.

PCTH449.name: Honours Thesis
PCTH449.desc: A research problem directed by a faculty member. Restricted to Honours Pharmacology students.

PCTH451.name: Review of Clinical Pharmacology
PCTH451.desc: This course has been designed as a basic science elective for third-year medical students.

PCTH453.name: Advanced Therapeutics
PCTH453.desc: A lecture, assigned problems, and discussion course dealing with practical aspects of therapeutics. This course is designed to give fourth-year medical students some practical experience in the science of drug prescribing.

MICB430.name: Seminar in Microbiological Literature
MICB430.desc: Student seminars on selected papers from the microbiological literature. Compulsory for Honours students. Major students may enrol with permission of the department head.

MICB448.name: Directed Research
MICB448.desc: A library (3 credits) or laboratory (3 or 6 credits) project. Requires permission of the Undergraduate Advisor. The results are presented in a written report to be reviewed by oral examination.
MICB448.prer: Either (a) MICB 323 or (b) all of MICB 322, MICB 399.

CNRS335.name: Practicum in Classical or Near Eastern Archaeology
CNRS335.desc: Training in excavation techniques and interpretation through participation in the excavation of a Greek, Roman, or Near Eastern site in Europe or the Middle East. The minimum length of the course is three weeks; it may be repeated once.

BMEG101.name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
BMEG101.desc: Core principles of biomedical engineering from a clinical perspective. Sensors and instrumentation, bioelectric phenomenon, biosignals, physiological modeling, biomechanics, biomaterials, tissue engineering, the principles of and design for medical imaging equipment, clinical engineering, moral and ethical issues.
BMEG101.prer: All of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, MATH 100, MATH 101.

BMEG102.name: Biomedical Engineering Lab
BMEG102.desc: Rapid prototyping of mechanical, electrical and electromechanical systems. Building parts with state of the art software and 3-D printing. Use of laboratory equipment and instrumentation.

BMEG150.name: The Fundamental Units of Life: From Cells To Systems
BMEG150.desc: The structure and function of cells and how they are organized to generate tissues and organ systems [3-3*-0]

BMEG201.name: Technical Communication for Biomedical Engineers
BMEG201.desc: Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation in biomedical engineering specific cases and projects. Credit will not be granted for both BMEG 201 and APSC 201.

BMEG210.name: Thermodynamics in Biomedical Engineering
BMEG210.desc: Work, heat and energy; material and energy balances; the first law and second law of thermodynamics; entropy and process reversibility; availability (energy) analysis; Hess's Law; thermodynamic properties of fluids; and applications to biomedical systems.

BMEG220.name: Circuits and Electromagnetics with Application to Biomedical Engineering
BMEG220.desc: Electromagnetic phenomena in the  body; bioinstrumentation; electrostatic and electromagnetic fields, forces, capacitance and inductance; bio-effects of electromagnetic fields; and modelling electrical components of physiological and biomedical systems.
BMEG220.prer: All of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, MATH 100, MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 256.

BMEG230.name: Biomechanics I
BMEG230.desc: Integrating the study of two dimensional movement of animals and humans with the study of the manner in which forces on biomechanical structures such as bones, ligaments, tendons, muscles and joints cause motion. Techniques of solid mechanics and two dimensional rigid body dynamics.

BMEG250.name: Cellular  Physiology  and Biophysics
BMEG250.desc: Cellular structure and mechanisms of membrane transport, signal transduction, muscle mechanochemistry and neurotransmission. Structure and hierarchical organization up to the level of tissues. Light and electron microscopy.

BMEG257.name: Biomedical Engineering Design I
BMEG257.desc: Engineering design process for medical technologies. Clinical practice, the healthcare system, medical approach to diagnosis, ethics and regulations for clinical trials, medical technology management, medical device development and standards, use of statistics for evaluating medical technologies.

BMEG310.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics
BMEG310.desc: Principles behind the methods of bioinformatics. The use of bioinformatics databases and tools for solving problems in genomics, proteomics, structural biology and evolutionary biology.

BMEG320.name: Bioengineering Feedback Systems and Controls
BMEG320.desc: Modeling, analysis and simulation of dynamic systems; system modeling by state space; linearization; feedback, stability and sensitivity; control system design. Examples from biological systems, assistive systems and biomedical equipment
BMEG320.prer: All of PHYS 157, MATH 253, MATH 256, BMEG 220.

BMEG330.name: Biomechanics II
BMEG330.desc: Principles and common elements of sports-, orthopaedic-, injury- and cellular length-biomechanics. Improving sports performance and preventing overuse injuries through sports biomechanics, designing orthopaedic implants through orthopaedic biomechanics, preventing injuries through injury biomechanics and identifying and filtering cancerous blood cells through cellular biomechanics.

BMEG350.name: Human Structure/Function from Cells to Systems
BMEG350.desc: Human anatomy, histology and physiology with examples from biomedical engineering. Anatomical compartmentation and function regulation; homeostatic control systems, sensors and effectors; intercellular communication strategies; and cellular and organ function assessment.

BMEG357.name: Biomedical  Engineering Design II
BMEG357.desc: Creating innovations in medical technologies. Case studies in need clinical identification. Supervised design process, building and testing prototypes with potential users.

BMEG370.name: Cellular  Responses  to Forces and Biomaterials
BMEG370.desc: Mechanical forces and biomaterials regulating cellular functions critical to tissue development, regeneration and repair.

BMEG371.name: Transport Phenomena within Cells and Tissues
BMEG371.desc: Fluid flow and mass transport analysis within healthy and diseased cells and tissues using mathematics. Drug delivery and tissue engineering.
BMEG371.prer: All of MATH 100, MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 256.

BMEG372.name: Biomedical Materials and Drug Delivery
BMEG372.desc: Biomaterials science/engineering applied to design and synthesis of drug delivery systems. Biomaterial types, synthesis and testing; the use of biomaterials; biological response; biocompatibility and degradation; drug delivery systems; nanocarriers; modification of polymers; liposomes and micelles; nucleic acid, transdermal and oral delivery.

BMEG373.name: Microfludics
BMEG373.desc: Advantages and disadvantages of miniaturization of complex fluid flow processes. Manipulating liquid flow; electrophoretic velocity and mobility; serial dilution; capillary electrophoresis; integrated microfluidic platforms; and blood and the motility of bacteria.

BMEG390.name: Medical Imaging
BMEG390.desc: Physical principles of ultrasound, magnetic resonance, computed tomography, X-ray projection imaging and molecular imaging in medical imaging for diagnostics, therapeutics and interventions.

BMEG430.name: Economics of Healthcare Solutions
BMEG430.desc: Canadian and USA engineering economics in BME and healthcare systems.  Economic equivalence, cost estimation, risk assessment, regulatory frameworks, economic optimization, intangible factors, ethics, sustainability, financial tools, commercialization and regulator regimes.

BMEG450.name: Biomedical Engineering Design Project
BMEG450.desc: Capstone design and development of a practical biomedical device or system. Projects provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories.

BMEG474.name: Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine
BMEG474.desc: Biology and applications of stem cells in regenerative medicine. Modeling human biology and disease in vitro and in vivo. Regulatory and commercialization pathways for regenerative medicine innovations.

FREN280.name: Introduction to Québécois Literature in Translation
FREN280.desc: An overview of the novel and theatre of Quebec in the 1960s, 70s, and 80s.

FREN328.name: Selected Works of African and Caribbean Literature
FREN328.desc: Representative works from different genres, viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

FREN333.name: French Civilization I
FREN333.desc: A historically based approach to French civilization and culture from their origins to the Third Republic (1875).
FREN333.prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223. Or permission of the instructor.

FREN335.name: French-Canadian Civilization
FREN335.desc: A thematic approach to selected topics in French-Canadian culture and civilization.
FREN335.prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223 or permission of the instructor.

FREN336.name: The Francophone World in Images
FREN336.desc: A socio-cultural study of francophone communities of Canada, the Caribbean, Europe, and North and Sub-Saharan Africa as seen through their films and other visual forms.

FREN344.name: Techniques of Oral Expression in French I
FREN344.desc: Training in formal oral presentation in French. Emphasis on structured expression and oral delivery. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours Program in French.
FREN344.prer: One of FREN 215, FREN 225. 68% or better in FREN 215 is recommended.

FREN345.name: Techniques of Oral Expression in French II
FREN345.desc: Further training in formal oral presentation in French.  Emphasis on structured expression and oral delivery. Not available for credit toward the Honours Program in French.

FREN346.name: French at Work
FREN346.desc: Communicative French for students preparing for a career in the francophone world. Not available for credit toward a Minor, Major, or Honours degree in French. Language of instruction is French.

FREN348.name: French Literatures in Translation I
FREN348.desc: Literary works from the Middle Ages to the French Revolution. Not available for credit towards a Minor, Major or Honours program in French.
FREN348.prer: Second year standing or higher. At least 6 credits of English, or equivalent, is strongly recommended.

FREN349.name: French Literatures in Translation II
FREN349.desc: Literary works since the French Revolution.  Topics may include literature from France, Quebec, Africa, the Caribbean.  Not available for credit towards a Minor, Major or Honours program in French.
FREN349.prer: Second year standing or higher. At least 6 credits of English, or equivalent, is strongly recommended.

FREN357.name: Translation I
FREN357.desc: Comparative study of French and English through translation.

FREN360.name: Introduction to Old French
FREN360.desc: The phonetics, grammar, and vocabulary of major Old French dialects; corpus of various literary texts (842-1300).
