FREN380.name: Foundations of French Cultural Identity (in English)
FREN380.desc: Aspects of French culture through a set of key concepts that cut across French history, politics, and social structures. Not available for credit toward a Minor, Major or Honours program in French.

FREN407.name: Studies in Medieval French Literature
FREN407.desc: Literary texts from the eleventh to the fifteenth century. Topics may include the epic, Tristan texts, Arthurian texts, the short narrative, satirical texts, religious drama, secular drama, lyric poetry, didactic poetry, François Villon.
FREN407.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN408.name: Studies in French Literature of the Sixteenth Century
FREN408.desc: Topics may include works by Rabelais, Montaigne, Scève, Labé, Ronsard, and DuBellay.
FREN408.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN409.name: Studies in French Literature of the Seventeenth Century
FREN409.desc: Topics may include works by Corneille, Racine, Molière, Descartes, Pascal, La Fontaine, and Mme de la Fayette.
FREN409.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN410.name: Studies in French Literature of the Eighteenth Century
FREN410.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN413.name: Studies in French Literature of the Nineteenth Century
FREN413.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN416.name: Studies in French Literature since 1900
FREN416.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN418.name: Studies in African and/or Caribbean Literatures of French Expression
FREN418.desc: An introduction to representative works. Topics include Negritude, the evolution of post-colonial literature, and the socio-historical context of each work.
FREN418.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN419.name: Studies in Women's Writing
FREN419.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN420.name: Selected Topics in French Literature and Culture
FREN420.desc: Course content will vary. May be taken up to 3 times, with different content, for a maximum of 9 credits.
FREN420.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN423.name: Studies in Theatre
FREN423.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN424.name: Studies in Prose Fiction
FREN424.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN425.name: Studies in French Autobiography
FREN425.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN427.name: Studies in Cinema
FREN427.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN429.name: Studies in Non-fiction Prose
FREN429.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN430.name: Studies in Quebecois Literature
FREN430.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330, FREN 335.

FREN460.name: Studies in Historical French Linguistics
FREN460.desc: Topics may include historical phonetics and phonology, morphology and syntax, lexicology.

FREN470.name: Studies in Modern French Linguistics
FREN470.crer: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor of FREN 470.

FREN472.name: Morphology of the French Language
FREN472.desc: The morphological markings of French (gender, number, tense, mode, person, etc) and their underlying semantic systems.
FREN472.crer: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

FREN473.name: Syntactic Description of the French Language
FREN473.desc: The syntactic markings of French (word order, agreement, pronominalisation, etc) and their underlying semantic systems.
FREN473.crer: FREN 353 and 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

FREN474.name: Synchronic Lexicology
FREN474.desc: An introduction to the study of the vocabulary of modern French, focusing on basic principles in lexical semantics, lexicology, phraseology, lexicography, terminology and new technologies, neology.
FREN474.crer: FREN 353 and 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor of FREN 474.

FREN475.name: Canadian French: A Descriptive Approach
FREN475.desc: The phonetics, phonology, lexicon, and syntax of spoken and written Canadian French.
FREN475.crer: FREN 351 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.

FREN481.name: Studies in Literature and the Arts
FREN481.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN482.name: Studies in Literature and Philosophy
FREN482.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN483.name: Studies in Literature and History
FREN483.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN484.name: Studies in Book Culture
FREN484.desc: A historical approach to the social transformations of the book trade in France.
FREN484.crer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN495.name: Research Seminar in French
FREN495.desc: Research on critical topics related to selected literary works. Limited enrolment: required of honours, but open to majors students in French.
FREN495.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN498.name: Directed Reading
FREN498.desc: For fourth-year students. Focus on a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required.

MATH267.name: Mathematical Methods for Electrical and Computer Engineering
MATH267.desc: Fourier series and transforms, wave equation, d'Alembert's solution, modes. Discrete Fourier tranform. Recurrence relations, z-transform, generating functions, applications. [3-0-1*]
MATH267.prer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

MATH309.name: Topics in Geometry
MATH309.desc: Topics chosen by the instructor. These may include conic sections, projective configuration, convexity, non-Euclidean geometries, fractal geometry, combinatorial problems of points in the plane. [3-0-0]
MATH309.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

MATH361.name: Introduction to Mathematical Biology
MATH361.desc: Mathematical modeling of basic biological processes in ecology, physiology, neuroscience and genetics. Dynamic behavior of difference equations, differential equations, and partial differential equations, explained with reference to concrete biological examples. [3-0-0]
MATH361.prer: One of BIOL 301, MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

MATH402.name: Calculus of Variations
MATH402.desc: Classical variational problems; necessary conditions of Euler, Weierstrass, Legendre, and Jacobi; Erdmann corner conditions, transversality, convex Lagrangians, fields of extremals, sufficient conditions for optimality, numerical methods; applications to classical mechanics, engineering and economics. [3-0-0]
MATH402.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 301, MATH 320.

MATH403.name: Stabilization and Optimal Control of Dynamical Systems
MATH403.desc: Dynamical systems; stability by Liapunov's direct method; controllability and eigenvalue assignment for autonomous linear systems; linear-quadratic regulator, time optimal control, Pontryagin maximum principle, dynamic programming; applications in engineering, economics and resource management. [3-0-0]
MATH403.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 301, MATH 320. MATH 402 is recommended.

MATH424.name: Classical Differential Geometry
MATH424.desc: The differential geometry of curves and surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space. Mean curvature and Gaussian curvature. Geodesics. Gauss's Theorema Egregium. [3-0-0]
MATH424.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 223 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 152, MATH 221;  and either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 227 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 217, MATH 263, MATH 317.

MATH428.name: Mathematical Classical Mechanics I
MATH428.desc: Newton's equation, conservation laws, the Euler-Lagrange equation; Hamilton's principle of least action, Hamilton's equations, Lagrangian mechanics on manifolds. [3-0-0]
MATH428.prer: MATH 215 and one of PHYS 216, PHYS 306.

MATH430.name: Special Topics in Analysis
MATH430.desc: The student should consult the Mathematics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]

MATH432.name: Special Topics in Algebra
MATH432.desc: The student should consult the Mathematics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]

MATH446.name: Topics in the History of Mathematics I
MATH446.desc: Historical development of concepts and techniques in areas chosen from Geometry, Number Theory, Algebra, Calculus, Probability, Analysis. The focus is on historically significant writings of important contributors and on famous problems of Mathematics. [3-0-0]

MATH448.name: Directed Studies in Mathematics
MATH448.desc: Introduction to the methods of mathematical research through an exploration of a mathematical topic under the supervision of a faculty member.  Written report required. [3-0-0]
MATH448.prer: Third- or fourth-year standing and permission of the Department Head.

MATH449.name: Honours Reading
MATH449.desc: Independent reading by Honours students in Mathematics under the direction of a faculty member. Written report required.

LARC421.name: Creativity and Design Applied
LARC421.desc: An exploration of creativity and design and their application to a number of design disciplines. Web based. [3-0-0]

COMM126.name: Data: Description, Display, and Inference
COMM126.desc: Introduction to the use of data and statistics to convey information on important issues of the world economy. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 126 or COEC 126.

COMM201.name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
COMM201.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

COMM300.name: Study Abroad, Commerce
COMM300.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

COMM301.name: Study Abroad, Commerce
COMM301.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between the Sauder School of Business and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.  Pass/Fail.

COMM302.name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
COMM302.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

COMM303.name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
COMM303.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between the Sauder School of Business and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.  Pass/Fail.

COMM310.name: Simulation Models in Business Decision-Making
COMM310.desc: Computer simulation, simulation languages. Typical business applications in financial planning, waiting line problems and other operating problems.

COMM342.name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management I - Study Abroad

COMM343.name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management II - Study Abroad

COMM344.name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management III - Study Abroad

COMM345.name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management IV - Study Abroad

COMM349.name: Logistics Services Management
COMM349.desc: Overview of the characteristics and commercial environment of logistics and transportation services; service operations planning and design, costing, pricing and quality management.
COMM349.crer: One of COMM 204, COMM 296, COMM 396, COMM 399.

COMM376.name: Financial Institutions I
COMM376.desc: The financial systems in Canada; the practices of the major financial institutions; and theories of financial processes.

COMM379.name: Introduction to Pensions and Insurance
COMM379.desc: Financial dimensions and institutional structure of the pension and insurance industry; calculation of annuities and other aspects of actuarial science based on probability distributions and asset returns. Suitable for students in mathematics who have taken basic finance and for commerce students in finance, accounting and related areas.

COMM411.name: Intermediate Business Statistics
COMM411.desc: Statistical techniques useful in business environments. Includes regression analysis, analysis of variance, forecasting, and logit and probit analysis. Credit may be obtained for only one of STAT 300, 306, and COMM 411.

COMM425.name: Research Methods for Human Resource Management
COMM425.desc: Techniques for collection and analysis of data in organizations to support adoption and administration of human resource management.

COMM428.name: Selected Topics in Human Resource Management

COMM441.name: Advanced Business Logistics
COMM441.desc: Analysis of logistics systems within firms and across supply chains. The formulation of corporate logistics strategies.

COMM446.name: Transportation Economics
COMM446.desc: Economic characteristics of passenger and freight transportation services; market structure of the transportation industry; economic impact of public regulation and promotion and the role of economic analysis in resolving problems of Canadian policy. Credit may be obtained for only one of COMM 446, ECON 480.
COMM446.prer: One of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301, ECON 206.

COMM448.name: Business Logistics and Logistics Services Management
COMM448.desc: General services management including warehousing, transportation, intermodal, order-fulfillment, dispatching, and more.

COMM456.name: Information Technology Risks, Protection and Audit
COMM456.desc: Business risks associated with the use of information technology. Controls for integrity, security safety, and privacy of hardware, software, data and communications. Methods for auditing information systems and their controls.

COMM463.name: Special Topics in Marketing
COMM463.desc: An investigation of current developments in both retailing and wholesaling fields and their application to marketing institutions.

COMM488.name: Public Sector Management
COMM488.desc: This course focuses on some of the distinctive aspects of managing in the public sector.

COMM490.name: Directed Studies in Commerce
COMM490.desc: An investigation and report on a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and a senior student.

COMM492.name: Management Simulation
COMM492.desc: Student teams manage hypothetical firms in a complex simulation, coordinating production, finance, marketing and strategic planning in competition with other teams.
COMM492.prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

COMM495.name: Business and Sustainable Development
COMM495.desc: An overview of environmental issues, focusing on corporate strategy, government policy and interactions between these two sectors of the economy.

CLCH399.name: Introduction to Classical Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
CLCH399.desc: Practice and expansion of the grammar skills learned in CLCH 389; reading of additional and longer passages from the classical canon. Credit will be granted for only one of CLCH 399 or ASIA 399.

CLCH401.name: Advanced Readings in Classical Chinese
CLCH401.desc: Focus on reading longer texts in Classical Chinese, producing careful and polished translation, using appropriate reference works and appreciating nuances of style and genre. Transition from textbook-based study to independent reading and scholarly translation necessary for advanced study and research.

MIDW200.name: Introduction to Midwifery Clinical Care
MIDW200.desc: Clinical care of women experiencing normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium.  Clinical education experiences in preventative and therapeutic midwifery care with emphasis on prenatal and postnatal midwifery care.  Clinical practice education opportunities within the province.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW201.name: Clinical Skills for Midwifery Practice
MIDW201.desc: Online situation-based learning tutorials occurring simultaneously with MIDW 200 clinical placement.

MIDW210.name: Evidence-Informed Midwifery
MIDW210.desc: Principles of evidence-informed midwifery, what counts as evidence? Making sense of the evidence, applying the evidence in practice.

MIDW230.name: Midwifery Theory for Primary Care
MIDW230.desc: Care of normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium with an empahsis on the intrapartum period and assessment and management skills.  Inludes a four-week intensive session in Vancouver, a series of online tutorials, and simulation and skills lab practice.

MIDW435.name: Comprehensive Midwifery Theory and Practice
MIDW435.desc: Theoretical principles and evidence basis for comprehensive midwifery care. Tutorials are carried out in an online live classroom setting.

SPPH301.name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
SPPH301.desc: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200. [3-0-0]

SPPH381.name: Selected Topics
SPPH381.desc: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

SPPH404.name: First Nations Health: Historical and Contemporary Issues
SPPH404.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) covers an epistemological approach that considers the determinants of health and spiritual-environmental-cultural perspectives. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 404 or IHHS 404. [3-0-0]

SPPH406.name: Aging from an Interdisciplinary Perspective
SPPH406.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers issues associated with aging in our society. For students registered in health and human services programs only. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 406 or IHHS 406.

SPPH408.name: Topics in Aboriginal Health: Community-based Learning Experience
SPPH408.desc: In-depth cultural and interprofessional learning experience that enables students to live and study in BC First Nations communities while learning about health, wellness, and community strengths from a local perspective. Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 408 or IHHS 408.

SPPH409.name: International Indigenous Experiences of Colonization
SPPH409.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course is an online, interprofessional, comparative inquiry of indigenous experiences of global colonization and the manifestations of that experience in the contemporary socio-cultural environment. Informed and guided by indigenous knowledge and drawing upon a range of disciplines such as public health, history, sociology and public policy. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 409 or IHHS 409.

SPPH481.name: Special Topics in Population and Public Health
SPPH481.desc: Selected topics will vary.  Multiple versions may be taken. This course takes an interprofessional approach and population/public health perspective in addressing current issues in healthcare and health-related fields.

HIST107.name: Global Indigenous Histories
HIST107.desc: An introduction to the experiences of Indigenous peoples and the nature of colonialisms around the world since 1500, and an introduction to historical practices and perspectives.

HIST108.name: Global History of Capitalism
HIST108.desc: The history of capitalism in its global dimension from the beginnings to the age of industrialization.  An investigation of economies - in both their practices and cultures - around the world and across the ages from ancient times to the modern era.

HIST109.name: Cultural Histories of Media: From Writing to Tweeting
HIST109.desc: The history of different forms of media in global perspective, with particular attention to audiovisual electronic media.

HIST200.name: Asia and the World
HIST200.desc: The political, economic, social, cultural, and human interactions between Asia and the world, inter-Asian relations, Asian diaspora, colonialism, war and the social consequences of conflict, decolonization, industrial growth, and developing world issues.

HIST202.name: Gateway to the Middle Ages
HIST202.desc: Problems and themes of medieval European History through the close study of the people and cultures that produced them.

HIST205.name: Introduction to Historical Archaeology
HIST205.desc: An introduction to the study of medieval and modern material culture, with special emphasis on Canada, using archaeological evidence to illustrate the principles, aims, and techniques of historical archaeology and related disciplines.

HIST220.name: History of Europe
HIST220.desc: Selected themes and historical approaches in European history; may include Europe's history of religious conflict, state formation, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, revolution, total war, globalization, genocide, or environmental change.

HIST237.name: History of the United States
HIST237.desc: Survey from colonial period to present examining political system, slavery, Civil War, race relations and civil rights, westward expansion, industrialization, feminism, expanding international presence, Cold War, and modern culture.

HIST250.name: Latin American History
HIST250.desc: Exploring themes of colonialism, indigenous life, national imaginaries, dictatorships and transitions to democracy through different forms of telling Latin American history. Includes epistolary writing, maps, eyewitness accounts, chronicles, actions, novels, films, built environment and city plans, testimonios, and plays.

HIST252.name: Modern Caribbean History
HIST252.desc: A survey of social, cultural and political history of Anglophone, Francophone and Spanish Caribbean from the Haitian Revolution to the present.

HIST259.name: Science, Medicine, and Technology in the Ancient and Medieval Worlds
HIST259.desc: The history of science, medicine, and technology, emphasizing networks, exchanges, and encounters in a global context.

HIST270.name: China in World History
HIST270.desc: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China.

HIST273.name: History of India
HIST273.desc: Societies, cultures, and politics of the Indian subcontinent from its ancient civilizations to the formation of the modern nation-states of South Asia.

HIST303.name: History of the Canadian West
HIST303.desc: Selected topics in the history of the Canadian West with an emphasis on the prairie west: the Indian and the fur trade, Louis Riel, prairie settlement, and western social and political protest.

HIST304.name: Researching Local History from the Ground Up
HIST304.desc: Sources and methods for reconstructing local history that can be used by Social Studies teachers in B.C. The aim is to develop an appreciation of the formative processes and past experiences that created one's familiar community.

HIST305.name: British Columbia
HIST305.desc: Selected themes in the history of the region, primarily during the post-confederation years. Topics will emphasize changes in the economic, social, and institutional structures of the province. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 305 or 404, if 404 was taken before 2007W.

HIST306.name: History of France, 1461-1715
HIST306.desc: The development of absolute monarchy in France, with emphasis on change and conflict in French society; spiritual and intellectual "crisis"; the place of France in the emerging European state system; and opposition to the monarchy.

HIST307.name: French North America to 1803
HIST307.desc: Historical background for understanding the French-speaking peoples of North America: Acadians, Franco-Quebecois, French-Canadians and Cajuns. It also deals extensively with French-Indigenous relations and introduces the student to the historiography of French North America.

HIST308.name: Quebec from the End of the 18th Century to the Present
HIST308.desc: Relations between the English and the Canadians prior to the Rebellions of 1837-38, the emergence of French Canadian nationalism after 1840, the impact of State formation and  industrialization in Quebec, the Quiet Revolution, and the independence movement.

HIST309.name: Topics in Sub-Saharan African History
HIST309.desc: Examination of a major theme in the history of Sub-Saharan Africa.

HIST310.name: The British Empire to 1850
HIST310.desc: Rise of the British imperial system within a global context from its beginnings to 1850. Focuses on economic and social themes with emphasis on settlements in the southern hemisphere as well as the West Indies.

HIST314.name: Early Modern Britain
HIST314.desc: The social, economic, political, religious, cultural, and intellectual history of Britain between the Reformation and the Industrial Revolution, emphasizing the rise of modern industrial society.

HIST315.name: Britain 1750-1850
HIST315.desc: Emergence of the world's first industrial society, and the political, economic, and cultural struggles accompanying this transformation.

HIST317.name: Britain, 1850-1918
HIST317.desc: Britain from the Great Exhibition to the Great War: the creation of a mass electorate, the "New Imperialism," the "New Woman," and the ways that class, race, gender, and sexuality shaped modern Britain.

HIST327.name: Colonial America: Encounter and Settlement, 1607 - 1763
HIST327.desc: Encounters between European, African, and Indigenous North American peoples as well as the history of the colonies within the Atlantic world, from the late sixteenth century to the eve of the American Revolution.

HIST328.name: Rebels in America: Revolution to Civil War, 1763 - 1865
HIST328.desc: Issues in U.S. history from the colonial era through the Civil War,  including the causes of the American Revolution; slavery; aboriginal peoples; labour, gender, and industrialization.

HIST329.name: Canadian Lives: A Social and Cultural History
HIST329.desc: A survey of Canadian society from colonial times to post-industrialization through the lenses of race, class, and gender. Topics include colonialism, slavery, immigration, religion, industrialization, citizenship, sexuality, social movements, and moral regulation.

HIST338.name: American Modernity: The United States, 1890-1945
HIST338.desc: U.S. emergence as an industrial powerhouse and, eventually, a global superpower; responses to industrial society, meaning of "modern times," economic upheaval and social change, U.S.'s role as a world power, and politics of race, ethnicity, and gender.

HIST341.name: Medieval Jewish History
HIST341.desc: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.

HIST342.name: Modern Jewish History
HIST342.desc: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, social and cultural transformations.

HIST344.name: Ancien Regime France
HIST344.desc: The political, social and/or cultural history of early modern France before the Revolution.  Topics may include: the changing significance of the monarchy; the Enlightenment critique of the Catholic Church and religion; the 'pre-revolution'. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 344 or 406.

HIST346.name: France Since the Revolution
HIST346.desc: The political, social and/or cultural history of France after the Revolution, possibly including nation building and regional identities; the Dreyfus affair; France as a colonial power; decolonization; the two world wars; the EU.

HIST347.name: Medieval and Imperial Russian History, 998 to 1800
HIST347.desc: Russian politics, society, culture, and empire, beginning with the medieval period extending through the era of Peter the Great's modernization efforts and the Enlightenment.

HIST349.name: Imperial Russian History, 1800 to 1917
HIST349.desc: History of Russia from the time of Catherine the Great to the Russian Revolution with particular focus on social and cultural history.

HIST351.name: East Central Europe in the 19th and 20th Centuries
HIST351.desc: Covers the region between Germany and Russia as well as Southeast Europe. Emphasis on comparisons with Western Europe and features that make the area significant to Europe as a whole.

HIST358.name: State and Society in 20th century Cuba
HIST358.desc: The history and historiography of 20th century Cuba, with particular attention to changing state structures and their impact on everyday life.

HIST359.name: A History of Brazil: From Colony to Nation
HIST359.desc: The cultural and political history of Brazil, from the earliest arrival of the Portuguese to Brazil’s emergence as one of the economic powerhouses of the twenty-first century.

HIST379.name: History of Later Imperial China
HIST379.desc: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understant the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China.

HIST380.name: The Making of Modern China: Nationalism, War, Revolution
HIST380.desc: The history of China from 1800 to the present including the decline of the Qing empire, the rise of modern nationalism, foreign invasion, and China's multiple revolutions.

HIST381.name: Imperialism and Nationalism in Southeast Asia
HIST381.desc: The history of European imperial rule, the forms of resistance to it, and the formation of nationalist movements in Southeast Asia. The countries studied include Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Burma, and Thailand.

HIST386.name: Korea Since 1860
HIST386.desc: An examination of the political, economic, social, and cultural transformations of Korea since the late nineteenth century. Topics include the end of the Choson Dynasty, the history of Japanese colonial rule, the Korean war, and the two Koreas in the international system.

HIST389.name: The Sikhs: History, Religion and Society
HIST389.desc: A historical study of the social and cultural forces that helped shape Sikh religious beliefs and ritual practices over the past four centuries. In dealing with the evolution of Sikh identity, attention will be given to Sikh ideals, social organization, religious institutions and sacred literature.

HIST390.name: Topics in History
HIST390.desc: Small-group instruction in a seminar format on a variety of historical topics. Check with the department for course offerings. This course does not satisfy the History Majors Research Seminar (490) requirement.

HIST392.name: Scientific Revolution: Circulation of Knowledge in the Early Modern World
HIST392.desc: The profound transformation of knowledge about the world in the context of the first global encounter of civilizations between 1450 and 1800. Explores the foundations for modern science.

HIST395.name: The Nuclear Century: Scientists, Atoms, and the World Order Since 1900
HIST395.desc: Science and the military-industrial complex; quantum and relativistic revolutions in physics; nuclear energy and weapons of mass destruction; international tensions, environmental damage, and global perils.

HIST396.name: Environmental History of North America
HIST396.desc: Overview of land use and environmental change in Canada and the United States; examines ideas and practices that shaped indigenous and non-indigenous resource exploitation, management, and activism to the end of the twentieth century.

HIST398.name: The History of Modern Medicine
HIST398.desc: The history of health and disease in the modern world, focusing in particular on the emergence and history of modern biomedicine.

HIST399.name: Theory and Practice of History
HIST399.desc: Approaches to the history of historical inquiry, with particular attention to theoretical and methodo-logical debates among historians. Recommended for history majors. Not open to Department of History honours students.

HIST401.name: Seafaring in the Age of Sail
HIST401.desc: Humankind’s encounter with its ocean frontier through exploration, trading, fishing, whaling, piracy, and naval warfare from 1400 to 1850.

HIST402.name: Problems in International Relations
HIST402.desc: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.

HIST403.name: Seminar in the History of International Relations
HIST403.desc: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Priority for registration will be given to fourth-year majors in the International Relations and History programs.

HIST411.name: Development of Canadian External Policy Since Confederation
HIST411.desc: Examines the history of Canada's external relations since Confederation with particular emphasis on Canada's changing international status and role in the twentieth century.

HIST414.name: Constitutions in Canadian History: From Pre-Contact to the Charter of Rights
HIST414.desc: European precedents, Colonial self-government, Canadian Confederation, and issues such as gay rights, abortion, and First Nations land rights.

HIST419.name: Crime and Punishment in Canadian History
HIST419.desc: The relationship between law and society; the development of legal institutions and the evolving character of crime in Canada.

HIST420.name: Topics in Canadian History
HIST420.desc: May include immigration, French-English relations, the growth of the state, health and welfare, or the family.

HIST423.name: Economic and Business History of Modern Japan
HIST423.desc: From 1800 to the present; emphasis on the business strategies of Japan's largest companies; attention also to broader economic topics such as international trade, government policy, social impact of industry, business and politics, labour, and post-1971 multi-nationalism.

HIST424.name: Economic History of Pre-Modern Europe
HIST424.desc: This course traces the roots of the “Rise of the West” through long-term economic, social, and political developments in European and global history.

HIST435.name: Gender and Sexuality in the Modern U. S
HIST435.desc: Gender roles and gender relations from the Gilded Age to the present day. Topics include political movements such as suffrage and feminism; labour and recreation; marriage, family, and children's socialization; sexuality; and popular culture.

HIST436.name: European Social History
HIST436.desc: A study of the changes in economic activity, social structure, family life, religious attitudes, and popular behaviour which accompanied the transformation of Europe from a pre-industrial to an industrial society.

HIST439.name: Politics and Culture in Fin-de-Siècle Europe (1890-1914)
HIST439.desc: Explores relationships between politics, culture, and social change in Europe. Topics include the changing role of intellectuals: literary aestheticism, painting, design and the city, origins of psychology.

HIST440.name: History of Health in the Modern West
HIST440.desc: Changing conditions of health in Europe and North America from the beginning of the modern mortality decline to the recent past.

HIST443.name: History of North American Children and Youth
HIST443.desc: Children’s history from settler days to the present. Topics include education, work and play, ideologies of childhood and adolescence, children’s material and popular culture, and differences of identity based on region, class, race, and gender.

HIST447.name: Selected Topics in United States History
HIST447.desc: Examines in depth a significant period, theme, or topic in the history of the United States. Possible subjects include The West, the Great Depression, the Sixties, and Class, Race, and Gender.

HIST450.name: Selected Topics in Latin American History
HIST450.desc: A study in depth of one major topic (such as the Cuban Revolution or Peronismo) in the recent history of Latin America.

HIST451.name: Family and Community in Latin America
HIST451.desc: The role of family and community from the colonial period to the present. Emergence of the nation state as it affected community and family structures.

HIST453.name: Class and Culture in Latin America
HIST453.desc: The relationship between culture and class formation from the late colonial period to the present.

HIST456.name: Race in the Americas
HIST456.desc: Legacies of African, European, and Asian migrations, and colonial encounters with indigenous peoples in the Americas. Includes the creation of racial categories, the making of transnational and transracial families, and the emergence of race-based social and cultural movements.

HIST460.name: Revolution and Resistance in the Third World
HIST460.desc: Revolutionary movements in the Third World during the second half of the twentieth century; the radicalisation of anticolonial nationalism; the impact of anticolonial radicalism in the developed world; the decline of Marxism as a revolutionary inspiration.

HIST464.name: First Contacts in the Pacific
HIST464.desc: An interdisciplinary history of early European contact with the Indigenous peoples of the northwest coast of  North America and the Pacific Islands.

HIST466.name: Topics in Indigenous History of Canada
HIST466.desc: Selected interdisciplinary topics in the history of Canada's Indigenous peoples after European contact, including historical demography, economic interdependency, missionary encounters, gender relations, and interactions with colonial powers and the nation state. Recommended: HIST 302 or other background in the field.

HIST467.name: Topics in Indigenous History of the United States
HIST467.desc: Interdisciplinary topics in the history of the United States' Indigenous peoples from before European contact. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended.

HIST468.name: Topics in Comparative Indigenous History
HIST468.desc: Comparative  interdisciplinary analysis of selected topics in Indigenous history in North America and beyong. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended.

HIST470.name: Seminar in Medieval History
HIST470.desc: Annually changing topics of medieval studies with special attention to research methods on primary sources.

HIST473.name: Women in the Middle Ages
HIST473.desc: A study of women's roles in the family, society, law, religion, the economy, and literature from about 500 to 1500 CE.

HIST474.name: Ideas and Religions of the Middle Ages
HIST474.desc: A survey and exploration of the development, interpenetration, conflict, and transformation of various intellectual and religious traditions during the Middle Ages.

HIST476.name: Law and Society in the Middle Ages
HIST476.desc: The history of law in the Middle Ages, including English common law, civil (Roman) law, and canon law, and how changes in both medieval law and society affected the development of each.

HIST477.name: Constitutional History of Medieval Europe
HIST477.desc: The evolution of political institutions, the emergence of royal governments as well as representative assemblies and urban republic and conflicts within and among them leading to the emergence of modern structures.

HIST478.name: Medieval Portraits and Personalities
HIST478.desc: The lives of leading and controversial figures in the Middle Ages and the means by which they have portrayed themselves and been portrayed by others.

HIST479.name: Cultural History of Imperial China
HIST479.desc: An in-depth examination of the construction, transmission, and transformation of Chinese culture(s) prior to 1800. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 479 or ASIA 440.

HIST480.name: Social History of Modern China
HIST480.desc: Changes and continuities in Chinese society and culture from the late imperial period to the present; rural and urban life, social stratification, social movements and ideology, family and community, popular beliefs and cultural values.

HIST481.name: Education and Society in Modern China
HIST481.desc: The relationship between education and society in China since 1600; classical learning and the civil service examination system; popular literacy; sino-foreign interactions in education; education and gender; nationalism and education; the education revolution in China after 1949.

HIST485.name: Asian Migrant Communities in Vancouver
HIST485.desc: This course will examine the history of Asian migration to Vancouver and British Columbia, focusing on the development of local communities and provide a background in historical research methods that will enable the students to conduct research on the history of these communities.

HIST487.name: History of Alternative and Complementary Medicine: Acupuncture to Yoga
HIST487.desc: Alternative and complementary healing in history, including Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), yoga, meditation, and alternative drug therapies. Specific themes may vary from year to year.

HIST490.name: Seminar for Majors in History
HIST490.desc: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

HIST491.name: Science and the Enlightenment
HIST491.desc: Examines the relationship between science and society in the long eighteenth century. Topics include empiricism, classification, academies, print culture, and voyages of exploration.

HIST493.name: History and Social Relations of Modern Sciences
HIST493.desc: Science and society in the 19th to 21st Centuries. [3-0-0]

HIST494.name: Machines, Media, and Modernity: Frankenstein to Cinema
HIST494.desc: The cultural contexts and consequences of science and nineteenth century technology. European and North American developments.

HIST495.name: Evolution and the Sciences of Mind, Brain, and Behaviour
HIST495.desc: Examines how Darwin's theory of evolution changed the investigation of human nature. Questions will be historical and scientific, but will also concern the social, ethical, and existential stakes raised by the human mind as a product of evolution.

RELG102.name: Introduction to the Major Eastern Religions
RELG102.desc: An introduction to the major Asian religious traditions (Hinduism, Sikhism, Jainism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism, Shintoism, and Shamanism; including religious life in South Asia – devotionalism in Islam, Hinduism, Sikhism) which employs theoretical models drawn from religious studies.

RELG204.name: Introduction to Asian Religions
RELG204.desc: The religions of India, China, and Japan in their interactions and cultural contexts, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.

RELG206.name: Introduction to Judaism and its Texts
RELG206.desc: What is Judaism? An overview of the key texts that have defined the Jewish religion, from the Hebrew Bible through works of contemporary thinkers. Recommended as a basis for upper-level courses in religious studies.

RELG210.name: History of Christianity I (1st C. C.E. - 14th C. C.E.)
RELG210.desc: An introduction to the history of Christianity from the post-Biblical period to the colonial expansion of Christianity under Spain and Portugal.

RELG211.name: History of Christianity II (15th C. C.E. - present)
RELG211.desc: The history of Christianity from the Reformation to the present day. Provides an historical overview of Christian thought and its institutions and significant people during the rise of the Reformation in various locales of Europe and beyond (Germany, France, Great Britain, Switzerland, and Scandinavia).

RELG302.name: Death and Afterlife in Western Religious Tradition
RELG302.desc: A survey of traditional attitudes toward death and beliefs regarding human existence after death in Western religions.

RELG305.name: The Prophetic Personality in Ancient Israel
RELG305.desc: An exploration of the unique phenomenon of the biblical prophet in its wider Near Eastern context.

RELG308.name: Talmud, Midrash and the Rabbinic Imagination
RELG308.desc: The Talmud, Midrash, and other late-antique (3rd - 7th centuries) rabbinic writings, focusing on biblical interpretation and narratives.

RELG309.name: Jews and Christians
RELG309.desc: Aspects of Jewish-Christian relations from the beginnings of Christianity to the present day. Emphasis on the study of Christian and Jewish texts in translation.

RELG310.name: Jewish Responses to Catastrophe
RELG310.desc: Topics include the destruction of the Second Temple, the Crusades, the expulsions from Spain and Portugal, and the Holocaust. A study of texts in translation.

RELG311.name: Jewish Literature in Translation
RELG311.desc: A survey of Jewish literature in medieval and modern times.

RELG312.name: Jews and Judaism in Canada
RELG312.desc: The history of the Jewish community in Canada, from New France to the present. Emphasis on the relationship between immigration and religious transformation, Jewish-Christian relations, the development of community structures.

RELG313.name: Modern Jewish Ethics in Historical Perspective
RELG313.desc: Readings from key texts in English translation, tracing how Jewish approaches to ethical issues evolved from biblical times to the present.

RELG315.name: History of Christian Thought
RELG315.desc: Selected topics with special emphasis on doctrinal change and development, orthodoxy and heresy, tradition and authority, and Church and State in the Patristic, Medieval, Reformation, and Modern periods.

RELG316.name: The Origins of Christianity: Literary Contexts
RELG316.desc: The origins of Christianity as reflected in the New Testament and contemporaneous literature.

RELG321.name: Prophetic Figures in the Christian Tradition
RELG321.desc: Examined in their historical context and in terms of their continuing significance. Selection will vary from year to year, but may include Augustine, Thomas Aquinas, Martin Luther, and Teresa of Avila.

RELG323.name: Christianity in the Modern World
RELG323.desc: The interaction between Christianity and the major intellectual, social, and cultural developments since 1648 with special attention to the expansion of Christianity and its encounter with urban industrial society.

RELG328.name: Medieval Philosophy
RELG328.desc: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the fourteenth century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham.

RELG331.name: Medieval Jewish History
RELG331.desc: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.

RELG332.name: Modern Jewish History
RELG332.desc: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present, with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, and social and cultural transformations.

RELG335.name: Jewish Law
RELG335.desc: History, sources, theoretical issues and current state of research about early Jewish legal traditions, focusing on close readings of classic primary texts in English translations.

RELG341.name: Art and Architecture in the Islamic World
RELG341.desc: A thematic study of visual arts, architecture, and objects from the Islamic world.

RELG365.name: Daoist (Taoist) Religion and Its Philosophical Background
RELG365.desc: A study of the Daoist religious traditions from their beginnings in the second century C.E. in cultural, intellectual and social contexts.

RELG366.name: Buddhism in China
RELG366.desc: History, thought and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century.

RELG370.name: Concepts and Methods in the Study of Religion
RELG370.desc: Required of Major and Honours students in their third year. Open to others by permission of the instructor.

RELG385.name: Mystical Traditions: Jewish and Christian
RELG385.desc: Methodology, textual study and scholarly analysis of selected texts from these traditions.

RELG407.name: Topics in Early Judaism
RELG407.desc: Judaism and Hellenism, the rise of the synagogue, Jewish sects, the development of Mishnah and Talmud.

RELG408.name: Topics in Medieval Judaism
RELG408.desc: The work of Maimonides and other Jewish philosophers, early developments in Jewish mysticism, the Jews as a minority culture in Islamic and Christian lands.

RELG409.name: Topics in Modern Judaism
RELG409.desc: The Jews in the ghetto culture, Hasidism, the Emancipation, Reform, Orthodox, and Conservative Movements.

RELG420.name: Religion in Canada
RELG420.desc: An examination of Canadian religious development with special reference to the separation of church and state, the rise of denominationalism and religious pluralism, secularization and ecumenicity, and the emergence of new religious movements.

RELG452.name: Readings in Hindu Religious Texts
RELG452.desc: Representative texts, in translation, of the Vedic, Epic, Puranic, Classical, Medieval, and Modern periods. Emphasis in the second term on texts of particular periods, movements, or sects, depending on the students' needs and interests. Those with the necessary preparation may read some texts in the original languages.

RELG475.name: Topics in Religion
RELG475.desc: Consult the course registration information each year for offered topics.

RELG479.name: Directed Studies
RELG479.desc: Reading and, where appropriate, other research on a topic arising in the discipline, arranged by agreement between the student and the instructor.

RELG480.name: Women and Religion
RELG480.desc: A study of the roles of women in the literature of one or more religious traditions.

RELG485.name: Images of Eve
RELG485.desc: The story of Adam and Eve, and its influence on the role and image of women in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

FIST332.name: Studies in Genre or Period
FIST332.desc: A seminar examining one or more genres or periods, such as the Western, Film Noir, Science Fiction, Films of the 1980's. Also includes study of national cinemas.

FIST430.name: Studies in Auteurism
FIST430.desc: A seminar examining the work of one or more directors, such as John Ford, Francois Truffaut, Denys Arcand, Margarethe Von Trotta, or of a screenwriter over many films.

FIST434.name: Studies in Film
FIST434.desc: A seminar devoted to a topic of current interest in film. Topic will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

FIST438.name: Seminar in Canadian Cinema
FIST438.desc: Topics may include an analysis of the Canadian Governmental agencies supporting Film Production.

CDST250.name: Introduction to Canada
CDST250.desc: Approaches to the study of Canada from an interdisciplinary perspective, including cultural, political, historical, and economic dimensions.

CDST350.name: Canadian Studies
CDST350.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to Canadian studies. Required of all Canadian Studies Majors.

CDST450.name: Senior Seminar in Canadian Studies
CDST450.desc: The Canadian experience from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Offered by the McLean Chair in Canadian Studies. Required of all Canadian Studies Majors.

CPEN400.name: Topics in Computer Engineering
CPEN400.desc: Lectures or projects on subjects of current interest.

CPEN412.name: Microcomputer Systems Design
CPEN412.desc: Microprocessor and system buses; advanced I/O methods; priority interrupts; event/exception handling; serial I/O; computer networking; memory system design; interaction of hardware and software, microprocessor comparison, testability issues, safety critical systems.
CPEN412.prer: One of EECE 353, CPEN 311 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

CPEN422.name: Software Testing and Analysis
CPEN422.desc: Different levels of testing including unit, integration, system, performance and regression levels. Requirements flowdown. Problem tracking. Coverage criteria. Static methods. Tools support. Specialized techniques. Assessment of correctness, reliability, safety.
CPEN422.prer: One of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, EECE 310, CPEN 321, CPSC 210, CPSC 310.

CPEN423.name: Software Architecture
CPEN423.desc: Software architecture as a bridge from requirements to implementation. Architectural description and patterns. Iterative development. Use of commercial off-the-shelf products.
CPEN423.prer: One of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, EECE 310, CPEN 321, CPSC 310.

CPEN499.name: Undergraduate Thesis
CPEN499.desc: Project in electrical engineering or computer engineering involving design, experimental and/or computer simulation work as selected from topics supplied by faculty members. An individual project thesis is to be prepared according to specifications available from the departmental office.

CHEM309.name: s- and p-Block Elements: Chemistry and Applications
CHEM309.desc: Synthesis, structures, bonding and characterization of compounds of the s- and p-block elements. Industrial uses discussed include: hydrogen-based fuels, materials and high performance polymers. [3-0-0]

CHEM310.name: d- and f-Block Elements: Chemistry and Applications
CHEM310.desc: Representative chemistry of d- and f-block elements interpreted in terms of structure, mechanisms, and theoretical principles.  Applications discussed include: organometallic catalysis, bioinorganic chemistry and materials. [3-0-0]

CHEM333.name: Spectroscopic Techniques in Organic Chemistry
CHEM333.desc: Application of mass spectrometry, and NMR, UV/visible, and IR spectroscopies to organic chemical problems. [3-0-0]
CHEM333.prer: Either (a) all of CHEM 203, CHEM 204 or (b) all of CHEM 233, CHEM 205 or (c) CHEM 213.

CHEM404.name: Computational Chemistry
CHEM404.desc: Application of numerical techniques to study chemical systems; molecular simulation. Computer programming experience is not required.
CHEM404.prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 154 and one of PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and Third-year standing.

CHEM419.name: Establishing a Career in Chemical Research
CHEM419.desc: Current research and career perspectives in chemistry.  Restricted to Honours students with fourth year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory fourth year standing.

CHEM430.name: Developments in Contemporary Chemistry
CHEM430.desc: A review of modern developments in general chemistry for teachers of Secondary School chemistry (Not for credit in the Faculty of Science). Course is offered periodically in extra-sessional sessions.

CHEM445.name: Projects in Experimental Chemistry
CHEM445.desc: Principles of experimental design, practice and problem solving in chemistry, including the opportunity to pursue projects in a research setting. [0-8-0]
CHEM445.prer: CHEM 345 or CHEM 335 and fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization.

CHEM448.name: Directed Studies in Chemistry
CHEM448.desc: Students will undertake an investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Open to third- and fourth-year chemistry students.

FNH290.name: Introductory Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health
FNH290.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition, and health. Topics will vary from year to year.

FNH430.name: Enology and Wine Biotechnology
FNH430.desc: Yeasts and bacteria involved in wine making, metabolic pathways leading to the production of flavour and spoilage compounds, genetic improvement of wine yeasts, and red and white wine fermentations. Approaches and technologies for the improvement of wine safety. Sensory evaluation of wines.

FNH454.name: Fish Nutrition
FNH454.desc: Physiology of digestion and excretion, nutrient requirements, sources of nutrients, diet formulation, feeding management. [3-0-0]

FNH490.name: Advanced Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health
FNH490.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition and health.

FNH497.name: Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health

SOCI210.name: Canadian Social Structure
SOCI210.desc: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.

SOCI240.name: Introduction to Social Interaction
SOCI240.desc: A general introduction to research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour. Topics include: status, power and prestige, distributive justice, marginality and social control, authority relations, and group structure and membership, all to be studied in the context of a variety of groups (such as families, formal organizations, communities and friendship groups) and cultures.

SOCI250.name: Crime and Society
SOCI250.desc: Crime as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on the changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change in Canadian and other societies. The scope and nature of the crime problem, the growth of criminology as a science and profession, and relationships between components of state criminal justice systems.

SOCI260.name: Technology, Work and Society
SOCI260.desc: The social forces responsible for changing patterns of technological innovation and work organization in modern industrial societies. Emphasis on the organization of work and the labour force. Topics may include division of labour, professionalization, labour movements, management techniques and bureaucracy, the social context of research and development initiatives, the effects of new technologies (e.g., automation) on the work place and social aspects of technological development in the Third World.

SOCI301.name: Sociology of Development and Underdevelopment
SOCI301.desc: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Major themes stress the relationship between urbanization and industrialization; modernization and ethnic conflict; imperialism, neo-colonialism, and foreign aid; and intra-national modernization problems such as regional underdevelopment in industrial societies.

SOCI302.name: Ethnic and Racial Inequality
SOCI302.desc: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels.

SOCI303.name: Sociology of Migration
SOCI303.desc: Sociological approaches to the movement of peoples and its impact over time.

SOCI310.name: Canadian Society
SOCI310.desc: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class.

SOCI344.name: Sociology of Aging
SOCI344.desc: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 344 and SOCI 444.
SOCI344.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI352.name: Organization of Work
SOCI352.desc: The meaning of work and leisure. Properties of work organization: division of labour and specialization; technology and working knowledge; means of coordinating work, such as cooperation, authority, and exchange. Research problems concerning work in households, offices, and industry, division of labour by gender, industrial democracy and the relation of work and social inequality.

SOCI354.name: Community Studies
SOCI354.desc: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks.

SOCI360.name: Sociology and Natural Resources
SOCI360.desc: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. May also include examination of social aspects of resource development in the Third World.

SOCI361.name: Social Inequality
SOCI361.desc: Tendencies toward equality and inequality; manifestations of inequality (occupation, education, gender, ethnicity, income, power) and their consequences; caste and class features of major stratification systems; theories of social class; stratification profile of contemporary industrial societies.

SOCI369.name: Sociology of Sexualities
SOCI369.desc: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century.
SOCI369.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI381.name: Sociological Methods: Experimental and Mixed Methods
SOCI381.desc: Experimental methods in sociology integrating quantitative and qualitative approaches. Emphasis is on research design to inform policy and decision making.
SOCI381.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI383.name: Sociological Methods: Historical Research
SOCI383.desc: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history.
SOCI383.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI410.name: Selected Topics in Canadian Society
SOCI410.desc: Selected areas of study relating to Canadian society such as BC Studies; French Canada's demographic problems; rural communities; social welfare and community programs in Canada. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SOCI414.name: Feminist Theory
SOCI414.desc: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. The social basis and development of feminist thought from critiques of scholarship and research to contemporary debates will be addressed.

SOCI415.name: Theories of Family and Kinship
SOCI415.desc: Theoretical approaches to the study of the family and family forms.
SOCI415.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI418.name: Social Statistics II
SOCI418.desc: Primary emphasis on applications of statistical techniques to data in Sociology.
SOCI418.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.

SOCI420.name: Sociology of the Environment
SOCI420.desc: Sociological approaches to the study of environmental conflicts, issues, movements, impact of changing technology, economic development on the environment.

SOCI425.name: Urban Sociology
SOCI425.desc: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods.

SOCI430.name: Global Citizenship
SOCI430.desc: Sociology approaches to global citizenship, including its contested nature and intellectual lineage.

SOCI433.name: Directed Studies
SOCI433.desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student.
SOCI433.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. And permission of the Department.

SOCI435.name: International Service Learning
SOCI435.desc: International field placement normally for eight to ten weeks; pre-departure seminars (eight to twelve seminars or equivalent) with student presentation seminars upon return from the field.

SOCI440.name: Economic Sociology
SOCI440.desc: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology.

SOCI449.name: Honours Tutorial
SOCI449.desc: Requires the presentation of at least one research paper. Restricted to students in the Sociology Honours program.

SOCI461.name: Political Sociology
SOCI461.desc: The social and economic bases of political power. May include studies of the state and interstate relations, ideology and control, alienation and anomie, political movements and social revolutions, political violence and terrorism, and the political economy of world conflict.

SOCI464.name: Social Movements
SOCI464.desc: A study of the sources, stages, and effects of social movements in developing and modernized societies.

SOCI465.name: Sociology of the Arts
SOCI465.desc: An examination of the arts as social practices from the standpoint of the relationships among artists, critics, patrons, and public; and the social institutions through which these relationships are structured.

SOCI466.name: Sociology of Education
SOCI466.desc: Examines the role of schooling in modern society including links with inequality, knowledge production, socialization and the economy.

SOCI469.name: Queer Theory and Politics
SOCI469.desc: Empirical expressions and political possibilities of queer theory.
SOCI469.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 369.

SOCI470.name: Sociology of Crime and Justice
SOCI470.desc: Critical examination of specific forms of crime and delinquency in relation to the criminal justice system including law, enforcement, and corrections. Issues selected for study will be further scrutinized within the cultural framework of ethics, morality, and social justice.

SOCI473.name: Sociology of Mental Illness
SOCI473.desc: A sociological approach to the meaning of mental illness; the organization of psychiatric treatment; problems in the explanation of the distribution of mental illness in a population.

SOCI479.name: Social Determinants of Health
SOCI479.desc: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations.

SOCI480.name: Urban Ethnographic Field School (UEFS)
SOCI480.desc: Approximately 50 hours of volunteering and fieldwork based in community organizations with theoretical approaches to urban spaces. Students will engage in collaborative research while considering a range of theoretical and methodological approaches.
SOCI480.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. Or permission of the instructor(s)

SOCI484.name: Sociology of Health and Illness
SOCI484.desc: Sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care as represented in classic and contemporary sociological studies of selected topics such as illness experience, social aspects of the practice of health professionals, training of health professionals, and the social organization of health delivery systems.

SOCI495.name: Advanced Studies in Sociology
SOCI495.desc: An intensive examination of selected topics in Sociology. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

GRSJ205.name: Gender, Race and Colonialism in Canada
GRSJ205.desc: The historical foundations of colonialisms in Canada from just prior to the establishment of New France to the end of World War One.

GRSJ210.name: Gender, Race and Colonialism in the Americas
GRSJ210.desc: Interdisciplinary exploration of the ways gender, class, sexuality and race shape modern histories in Canada, and transnationally, from 1920 to the present.

GRSJ224.name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice in Literature
GRSJ224.desc: Techniques of literary study, with emphasis on intersectionality and the ways in which gender is represented in literature and contributions of feminism and gender studies to literary studies.

GRSJ230.name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Representation in Modern Asia
GRSJ230.desc: The complex relationships between mechanisms of power, gender, and representation in Asia in different spaces examined through an interdisciplinary lens.

GRSJ301.name: Gender, Race and Indigeneity in Canada
GRSJ301.desc: Gender and indigeneity in the documented histories and narrated lives of Indigenous people in Canada.
GRSJ301.prer: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ302.name: Pedagogies of Social Justice
GRSJ302.desc: The intersections of gender, education, and work using sociological and economic frameworks.
GRSJ302.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ425.name: Special Topics in Gender, Race, and Sexuality
GRSJ425.desc: Examination in depth of selected topics in gender, race, and sexuality. Consult the Student Service Centre course schedule for course offerings. May be repeated for credit.
GRSJ425.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ450.name: Directed Studies
GRSJ450.desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under supervision of, a faculty member selected by the student and approved by the GRSJ Undergraduate Advisor. A written paper or equivalent will be required. Open to GRSJ majors or minors.

PHTH301.name: Physical Therapy Foundations
PHTH301.desc: Builds on prerequisite concepts in anatomy, physiology, and physics taken at undergraduate and high school level to apply basic theories and principles of anatomy, human physiology, pathophysiology, biomechanics, and physics to essential rehabilitation concepts.

FNEL111.name: Introduction to an Algonquian Language I
FNEL111.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures and listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL112.name: Introduction to an Algonquian Language II
FNEL112.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL121.name: Introduction to a  Dene (Athapaskan) Language I
FNEL121.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures and listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL122.name: Introduction to a Dene (Athapaskan) Language II
FNEL122.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL131.name: Introduction to a Tsimshianic Language I
FNEL131.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL132.name: Introduction to a Tsimshianic Language II
FNEL132.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL151.name: Introduction to the Haida Language I
FNEL151.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL152.name: Introduction to the Haida Language II
FNEL152.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL161.name: Introduction to the Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language I
FNEL161.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL162.name: Introduction to the Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language II
FNEL162.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL191.name: Introduction to an Indigenous Language I
FNEL191.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL192.name: Introduction to an Indigenous Language II
FNEL192.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.
FNEL192.prer: 3 credits of FNEL 191 in the same language.

FNEL211.name: Intermediate  Algonquian Language I
FNEL211.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL212.name: Intermediate Algonquian Language II
FNEL212.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL221.name: Intermediate Dene (Athapaskan) Language I
FNEL221.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL222.name: Intermediate Dene (Athapaskan) Language II
FNEL222.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL231.name: Intermediate Tsimshianic Language I
FNEL231.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL232.name: Intermediate Tsimshianic Language II
FNEL232.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL241.name: Intermediate Wakashan Language I
FNEL241.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL242.name: Intermediate Wakashan Language II
FNEL242.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL251.name: Intermediate Haida Language I
FNEL251.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL252.name: Intermediate Haida Language II
FNEL252.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL261.name: Intermediate Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language I
FNEL261.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL262.name: Intermediate Ktunaxa Language II
FNEL262.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL282.name: Structures of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
FNEL282.desc: Development of skills in the documentation, transcription and analysis of grammatical structures in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Aboriginal languages. Applied techniques in documentation, workflow and multi-media digital annotation, guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals.

FNEL291.name: Intermediate Indigenous Language I
FNEL291.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL292.name: Intermediate Indigenous Language II
FNEL292.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL301.name: Advanced Salish Language I
FNEL301.desc: Emphasis on advanced comprehension and production skills. Extended focus on skills in oral traditions, transcription, literacy, and on deepening the understanding of grammatical structures and dialectal variation. Not offered every year.

FNEL302.name: Advanced Salish Language II
FNEL302.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL382.name: Lexicography for Endangered Languages
FNEL382.desc: Foundational concepts in the discipline of compiling, editing, managing and hosting dictionaries, also known as lexicography. Special focus on the technical and ethical considerations for community-based lexicography projects for endangered and BC First Nations languages.
