FNEL389.name: Collaborative Heritage Research in First Nations Languages: Practicum & Workshop
FNEL389.desc: Hands-on experience planning and producing a Breath of Life Language Reclamation Workshop for endangered BC First Nations languages, during which community-based researchers access and interpret relevant heritage resources at UBC and other local institutions for the revitalization of their languages.
FNEL389.crer: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 389.

FNEL448.name: Directed Research in First Nations Languages
FNEL448.prer: Agreement of Supervisor and approval of Chair of FNEL program.

FNEL480.name: Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
FNEL480.desc: Critical study of the historical, social, cultural, political, and economic factors impacting on language loss, retention, and revival. Research on and application of methodologies for collaborative, trans-disciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization of BC's Indigenous linguistic heritage.

FNEL481.name: Heritage Resources in Endangered First Nations Language Revitalization
FNEL481.desc: Examines the complementary and intersecting roles of libraries, archives, and museums in collections acquisition, development, curation, preservation, and access traditions pertaining to First Nations languages, to explore how each can contribute to endangered language and cultural heritage sustainability.
FNEL481.crer: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 481.

FNEL489.name: Topics in First Nations and Endangered Languages
FNEL489.desc: Selected topics will vary. Multiple versions of this course may be taken, under consultation with the FNEL program advisor, for up to a maximum of 12 credits.

MEDD439.name: Flexible Enhanced Learning III
MEDD439.desc: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419 and 429, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, life-long learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail.

MEDD441.name: Senior Elective
MEDD441.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD442.name: Senior Elective
MEDD442.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD443.name: Senior Elective
MEDD443.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD444.name: Senior Elective
MEDD444.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD445.name: Senior Elective
MEDD445.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD446.name: Senior Elective
MEDD446.desc: A senior clinical or academic elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and/or academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD448.name: Transition into Postgraduate Education and Practice
MEDD448.desc: Enables students to effectively transition from medical school to residency and medical practice. Complex clinical presentations that integrate foundational sciences and practice themes. Prepares students for practice as residents and physicians. Pass/Fail.

MEDD449.name: Flexible Enhanced Learning III
MEDD449.desc: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419 and 429, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, life-long learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail.

RMST420.name: Studies in Romance Languages and Literature

RMST468.name: Romance Linguistics
RMST468.desc: The Indo-European background; Classical and Vulgar Latin; the origin, development and spread of the Romance languages; their vocabulary, phonology, morphology, syntax; vernacular Latin texts and Romance texts.
RMST468.prer: Two years study of each of two Romance languages or two years of one Romance language and one year of Latin.

RMST495.name: Research Intensive Seminar in Romance Studies

MINE395.name: Mineral Deposit Modeling
MINE395.desc: Types of mineral deposits. Exploration and sampling methods. Methods for data analysis and computer modeling of mineral deposits and their use in production planning and design.

MINE435.name: Plant and Process Design
MINE435.desc: Design of unit operations in a mineral processing plant including crushing, grinding, classification, gravity separation, magnetic separation, flotation, thickening and filtration. Equipment selection and sizing, flowsheet design, circuit analysis and processing options.

MINE497.name: Directed Studies
MINE497.desc: Requires approval of the department head.

INDO100.name: Introductory Indonesian I
INDO100.desc: Spoken and written Indonesian. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 100 or INDO 102.

INDO101.name: Introductory Indonesian II
INDO101.desc: Continuation of INDO 100. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 101 or INDO 102.

INDO102.name: Introductory Indonesian
INDO102.desc: Spoken and written Indonesian. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of INDO 100/101 or INDO 102.

INDO200.name: Intermediate Indonesian
INDO200.desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Indonesian literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of INDO 201/202 or INDO 200.

INDO201.name: Intermediate Indonesian I
INDO201.desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Indonesian literature. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 201 or INDO 200.

INDO202.name: Intermediate Indonesian II
INDO202.desc: Continuation of INDO 201. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 202 or INDO 200.

LIBE477.name: Special Topics in Teacher Librarianship
LIBE477.desc: In-depth study of selected topics in library education. [3-0-0]

ARTH251.name: Asian Arts: From Chinese Warriors to Bollywood Posters
ARTH251.desc: A thematic examination of Asian arts, such as historic, religious, and secular painting and sculpture to contemporary visual culture.

ARTH261.name: Pre-Hispanic Arts of Central and South America
ARTH261.desc: The relevance of various arts to social institutions in ancient societies of Peru and Mesoamerica.

ARTH262.name: Native Arts of North America
ARTH262.desc: Men's and women's arts produced by Aboriginal Peoples of North America from pre-contact times to the present.

ARTH310.name: Art and the Christian Transformation of the Roman Empire
ARTH310.desc: Visual culture and the rise of Christianity; social, political and religious contexts of art, including diverse viewing practices and cultural frameworks. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 310 or ARTH 330.

ARTH312.name: Medieval Art in the Age of Monasticism
ARTH312.desc: Art in Western Europe between 1000 and 1200; the role of monasteries as leading institutions and patrons of art and large scale architecture. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 312 or ARTH 332.

ARTH313.name: Art, Church, Society and their Margins in the Later Middle Ages
ARTH313.desc: Diversification of the arts and architecture with the expansion of patronage in late medieval society. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 313 or ARTH 333.

ARTH319.name: The Archaeology of Ancient Iraq and Syria: Babylon and Beyond
ARTH319.desc: An overview of the archaeology of the ancient Near East, with special emphasis on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, from the appearance of the first cities (c. 3400 BCE) to the end of the Persian period (c. 330 BCE).

ARTH320.name: Art and Architecture in Spain and the New World (1500-1700)
ARTH320.desc: Role of visual art and culture within Catholic Spain and colonial Latin America is surveyed, with emphasis on transculturation from mudejar to mestizaje.

ARTH322.name: Early Modern Italian Art and Culture (ca. 1550-1700)
ARTH322.desc: Focus primarily on Rome as the center of artistic, cultural, economic, and religious power in the seventeenth century.

ARTH323.name: Northern European Art and Culture I (1400-1600)
ARTH323.desc: Early Modern painting, sculpture, and the graphic arts from the great devotional triptychs, through the Reformation, to the emergence of a secular art.

ARTH324.name: Northern European Art and Culture II (1600-1700)
ARTH324.desc: The role of visual art within Early Modern court cultures, commercial urban centres, and emergent nation states.

ARTH325.name: Ancient Egypt: The Archaeology of the Land of the Pharaohs
ARTH325.desc: The material remains of the ancient Egyptians from monumental tombs and temples to the artifacts of daily life; the development of Egyptian civilization from the rise of the first rulers to its incorporation into the Roman Empire.

ARTH329.name: Greek and Roman Art
ARTH329.desc: Emphasis on the architecture, sculpture, painting, and decorative arts of Greece and Rome.

ARTH342.name: Latin American Art: Modern and Contemporary
ARTH342.desc: Analyses of specific works and texts will emphasize visual inventions and meaning in the light of recent theoretical debates

ARTH343.name: Art and Photography in Canada to 1920
ARTH343.desc: Art, artists, and art institutions from the establishment of the French and English colonies to the founding of the Group of Seven: issues of race, wilderness, and colonial expansion.

ARTH346.name: Architecture in Europe: Building the Fabric of the Modern State (1715-1837)
ARTH346.desc: The role of architecture within the development of the modern state.  A survey of broad cultural dynamics, particular building projects and design careers.

ARTH347.name: Architecture in Europe: Modern Paradigms of Design (1837-present)
ARTH347.desc: An examination of new requirements imposed on architecture by the consolidation of a capitalist economy, industrialization, new technologies and scientific methods.

ARTH348.name: Architecture in North America: Colonial Projects and Disruptions (1605-1867)
ARTH348.desc: The role of architecture in the imposition of European governance within North America;  the modification of received conventions in relation to topographical, ethnic-religious and political factors.

ARTH349.name: Architecture in North America: Independent Design Idioms (1867-present)
ARTH349.desc: The emergence of a distinctive architecture that superseded British and European agendas; the growth of private and public patronage and the establishment of modern design and practice.

ARTH350.name: Grounding the Islamic Image
ARTH350.desc: Contextualizing the complex language of images in the Islamic world.

ARTH351.name: Art and Architecture in the Islamic World
ARTH351.desc: A thematic study of visual arts, architecture, and objects from the Islamic world.

ARTH354.name: Mughal India:  Art, Architecture and the Spectacle of Empire
ARTH354.desc: The complex relationship of Mughal imperial architecture and painting with those of the Hindu Rajput courts.

ARTH355.name: Modern and Contemporary India: Art in Colonial and Independent India
ARTH355.desc: The development of a new Indian art during the colonial period and nationalist movement; the construction of India's contemporary visual culture.

ARTH357.name: Chinese Art and Architecture: Patronage and Collecting
ARTH357.desc: The commission, production, preservation, and transmission of Chinese monuments and artworks focusing on the court and questions of cultural policies.

ARTH360.name: Chinese Painting: Word and Image
ARTH360.desc: Analyses visual narratives and relationships between painting, calligraphy, and poetry in court and literati painting.

ARTH361.name: Chinese Modern and Contemporary Art
ARTH361.desc: Chinese art and its global entanglements from Qing Encounters to the 21st century.

ARTH362.name: Art in Japan: Objects and Spaces
ARTH362.desc: Changing relationship between art objects and the built environment in the Japanese archipelago, in its social and historical context.

ARTH369.name: Art in Japan: Modern Visual Culture
ARTH369.desc: Self and community in the art and visual culture of modern Japan.

ARTH370.name: Arts of Mexico's Early Peoples
ARTH370.desc: Pre-Aztec monumental and portable arts of the Olmec, Zapotec, Teotihuacan and Classic Veracruz peoples.

ARTH371.name: Arts of the Aztec period in Mexico
ARTH371.desc: Symbolic meanings and political agendas of Aztec architecture, sculpture and manuscript illustration investigated using Spanish accounts.

ARTH372.name: Maya Public Ritual Arts
ARTH372.desc: Architecture, sculpture, costume, and visual productions associated with Maya public ritual, including the ancient ball game and modern cofradía dances.

ARTH373.name: Maya Arts of Everyday Life
ARTH373.desc: Social context and meaning of the Maya's elaborate architecture, sculpture, mural paintings, jewelry, ceramics, figurines, and textiles, ancient and modern, of residences from humble to palatial.

ARTH376.name: Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The North
ARTH376.desc: The histories, historiography and cultural diversity of the Northern Northwest Coast region; persistence and innovation in the arts in communities, and in cross-cultural and market spheres.

ARTH382.name: Is Art History Queer?
ARTH382.desc: Issues in the history of art through the lens of queer theory.

ARTH410.name: Seminar in African Art
ARTH410.desc: Key debates in the art of Africa and the African diaspora

ARTH429.name: Studies in the Art and Archeology of Greece and Rome

ARTH440.name: Seminar in Modern and Contemporary Art

ARTH442.name: Seminar in Contemporary Latin American Art

ARTH445.name: Film and the City
ARTH445.desc: The complex interrelations between film and the city; dominant urban theories, film technologies and viewing practices and the intersections between them.

ARTH450.name: Seminar in Art in the Islamic World
ARTH450.desc: Key debates in the field of art and architecture in the Islamic World.

ARTH476.name: Seminar in North American Aboriginal Art

ARTH490.name: Art History Internship
ARTH490.prer: ARTH 300 and departmental approval. Interested students may contact the department for details on how to proceed.

HEBR101.name: Elementary Biblical Hebrew Part I
HEBR101.desc: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew grammar. Includes translation of prose and poetry from the Hebrew Bible.

HEBR102.name: Elementary Biblical Hebrew Part II
HEBR102.desc: A continuation of HEBR 101: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew grammar. Includes translation of prose and poetry from the Hebrew Bible.

PHAR303.name: Pharmacy Skills II
PHAR303.desc: Legal, technical and professional aspects of dispensing prescriptions and providing pharmaceutical care, primarily for community pharmacy practice.

PHAR315.name: Pharmacokinetics
PHAR315.desc: Pharmacokinetics and clinical applications of pharmacokinetic principles.

PHAR321.name: Biophysical Pharmacy I
PHAR321.desc: Applications of the physical chemical properties of drugs to oral drug delivery systems.

PHAR323.name: Biophysical Pharmacy II
PHAR323.desc: Applications of the physical chemical properties of drugs to non-oral drug delivery systems.

PHAR330.name: Pharmacogenomics: Genetics and Drug Action
PHAR330.desc: Application of genetic information to drug therapy.

PHAR341.name: Pharmacology I
PHAR341.desc: Pharmacological principles and the pharmacology of selected agents.

PHAR342.name: Pharmacology II
PHAR342.desc: Principles of chemotherapy and drug resistance and the pharmacology of selected drug classes.

PHAR351.name: Therapeutics I
PHAR351.desc: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

PHAR352.name: Therapeutics II
PHAR352.desc: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

PHAR361.name: Non-Prescription Products and Self-Care of the Patient I
PHAR361.desc: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

PHAR362.name: Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient II
PHAR362.desc: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

PHAR369.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience I
PHAR369.desc: A 160-hour pharmacy clerkship providing exposure to legal, technical, and professional aspects of community practice.

PHAR399.name: Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences II
PHAR399.desc: Case studies and other activities integrating scientific and clinical concepts. [1-0-3; 1-0-3]

PHAR401.name: Pharmacy Skills III
PHAR401.desc: Legal, technical and professional aspects of dispensing prescriptions and providing pharmaceutical care, primarily for community pharmacy practice.

PHAR404.name: Peer Teaching in Pharmacy Skills II
PHAR404.desc: Development and delivery of patient counselling role-playing activities in PHAR 303.

PHAR405.name: Directed Studies in Clinical Pharmacy
PHAR405.desc: Individual assignments involving library and clinical investigation of specific problems relating to drug utilization and information topics.

PHAR410.name: Pharmaceutical Research: From Bench to Bedside and Beyond
PHAR410.desc: Basic, translational, clinical, and community-based research.

PHAR415.name: Topics in Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
PHAR415.desc: A study of selected topics in the field of pharmaceutics and biopharmaceutics. Registration restricted. Permission of instructor required.

PHAR420.name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Education
PHAR420.desc: Individual assignments involving library and scholarly inquiry related to pharmacy education.

PHAR430.name: Biomolecular Pharmaceutical Chemistry I
PHAR430.desc: Chemical principles and their application to drugs used to regulate enzyme activity.

PHAR434.name: Essential Medicinal Chemistry Concepts for Pharmacists
PHAR434.desc: Applying selected chemical concepts to understand drug structure and properties, using frequently encountered drugs as examples. Examining how drugs are used to inhibit enzyme activity.

PHAR435.name: Biomolecular Pharmaceutical Chemistry II
PHAR435.desc: Chemical principles and their application to drugs used to regulate receptor activity.

PHAR441.name: Pharmacology III
PHAR441.desc: The pharmacology of selected drug classes.

PHAR442.name: Pharmacology IV
PHAR442.desc: The pharmacology of selected drug classes.

PHAR451.name: Therapeutics III
PHAR451.desc: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

PHAR452.name: Therapeutics IV
PHAR452.desc: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

PHAR453.name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Practice
PHAR453.desc: Individual assignments involving library and field work investigations of problems associated with pharmacy practice.

PHAR454.name: Pediatric and Geriatric Drug Therapy
PHAR454.desc: Drug therapy considerations in pediatric and geriatric patients.

PHAR460.name: Natural Health Products in Pharmacy Practice
PHAR460.desc: An evidence-based analysis of the efficacy and safety of natural health products used in pharmacy practice.

PHAR461.name: Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient III
PHAR461.desc: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

PHAR462.name: Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient IV
PHAR462.desc: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

PHAR498.name: Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences III
PHAR498.desc: Case studies and other activities integrating scientific and clinical concepts.

AUDI400.name: Introduction to Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology
AUDI400.desc: Frameworks from linguistics, psychology, and speech and hearing sciences as applied to communication disorders, clinical populations and practices. [3-0]

CHIN144.name: Intensive Basic Chinese I (Heritage)
CHIN144.desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and in reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 144 or CHIN 114 or both CHIN 111, CHIN 113, or both CHIN 141, CHIN 143..

CHIN161.name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning Chinese
CHIN161.desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Mandarin Chinese.

CHIN244.name: Intensive Basic Chinese II (Heritage)
CHIN244.desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 244 or CHIN 118 or both CHIN 115, CHIN 117 or both CHIN 241, CHIN 243.
CHIN244.prer: One of CHIN 113, CHIN 114, CHIN 143, CHIN 144.

CHIN334.name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN334.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 334 or CHIN 204 or both CHIN 201, CHIN 203 or both CHIN 331, CHIN 333.
CHIN334.prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234.

CHIN338.name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN338.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 338 or CHIN 208 or both CHIN 205, CHIN 207 or both CHIN 335, CHIN 337.
CHIN338.prer: One of CHIN 203, CHIN 204, CHIN 333, CHIN 334.

CHIN344.name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese I (Heritage)
CHIN344.desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 344 or CHIN 214 or both CHIN 211, CHIN 213 or both CHIN 341, CHIN 343.
CHIN344.prer: One of CHIN 117, CHIN 118, CHIN 243, CHIN 244.

CHIN348.name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese II (Heritage)
CHIN348.desc: Communication skills. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 348 or CHIN 218 or both CHIN 215, CHIN 217 or both CHIN 345, CHIN 347.
CHIN348.prer: One of CHIN 213, CHIN 214, CHIN 343, CHIN 344.

CHIN380.name: Reading Course in Chinese for Honours Students

CHIN381.name: Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers I
CHIN381.desc: Strictly for Cantonese speakers from Hong Kong who cannot speak Mandarin but who have advanced Chinese reading and writing skills (2,000 characters). Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 381 or CHIN 221.

CHIN383.name: Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers II
CHIN383.desc: Continuation of CHIN 381. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 383 or CHIN 223.

CHIN404.name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing (Non-Heritage)
CHIN404.desc: Reading and writing skills addressing social, cultural, and economic issues. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 408. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 404 or CHIN 304 or both CHIN 301, CHIN 303 or both CHIN 401, CHIN 403.
CHIN404.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN408.name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing (Non-Heritage)
CHIN408.desc: More formal styles of oral and written communication. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 404. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 408 or CHIN 308 or both CHIN 305, CHIN 307 or both CHIN 405, CHIN 407.
CHIN408.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN415.name: Media Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN415.desc: Reading and understanding Chinese as used in newspapers, radio/TV, and the internet news. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 415 or CHIN 309.
CHIN415.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN422.name: Twentieth-Century Chinese Literature
CHIN422.desc: Selected short stories, novels, plays, essays, and poems from 1917 to the end of the twentieth century.  For students who have a good reading knowledge of modern Chinese.
CHIN422.prer: 12 credits at CHIN 300 level or above is recommended.

CHIN444.name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing (Heritage)
CHIN444.desc: Transition from language to literature. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 448. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 444 or CHIN 314 or both CHIN 311, CHIN 313 or both CHIN 441, CHIN 443.
CHIN444.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN447.name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Heritage)
CHIN447.desc: Continuation of CHIN 445. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 437and/or CHIN 443. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 447 or CHIN 317 or CHIN 448.

CHIN448.name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing (Heritage)
CHIN448.desc: Public-speaking and writing skills at an advanced level. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 438 and/or CHIN 444. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 448 or CHIN 318 or both CHIN 315, CHIN 317 or both CHIN 445, CHIN 447.
CHIN448.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN451.name: Introductory Modern Chinese Literature I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN451.desc: A reading-intensive introduction to modern Chinese literature from 1900 to 1949, with a focus on fiction. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 451 or CHIN 411.
CHIN451.prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

CHIN453.name: Introductory Modern Chinese Literature II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN453.desc: A reading-intensive introduction to modern Chinese literature from 1949 to the present, with a focus on fiction. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 453 or CHIN 413.

CHIN455.name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Early Periods) (Non-Heritage)
CHIN455.desc: Early fiction, including tales of the supernatural and romance, to the Tang Dynasty. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 455 or CHIN 421 or CHIN 458.
CHIN455.prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

CHIN457.name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Later Periods) (Non-Heritage)
CHIN457.desc: Texts in vernacular Chinese, including drama and fiction, from the Yuan to the Qing Dynasties. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 457 or CHIN 423 or CHIN 458.
CHIN457.prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

CHIN458.name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Intensive)
CHIN458.desc: Covers a range of stories, fiction, and drama to the Qing Dynasty. Only for students who did not have a good reading knowledge of modern Chinese before entering university. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 458 or CHIN 424 or both CHIN 421, CHIN 423 or both CHIN 455, CHIN 457.
CHIN458.prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

CHIN480.name: Tutorial in Chinese for Honours Students
CHIN480.desc: Will require the presentation of at least one research paper. Review the course section information or consult the Department for details. May be taken for up to a total of 12 credits. Restricted to students in the Honours Asian Area Studies or Asian Language and Culture programs.

CHIN482.name: Supervised Study in the Chinese Language

CHIN494.name: Intensive Classical Chinese (Heritage)
CHIN494.desc: A combination of CHIN 491 and 493. Readings on classical philosophy, history, literature, and culture. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 494 or CHIN 434 or both CHIN 431, CHIN 433 or both CHIN 491, CHIN 493.
CHIN494.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

FIPR235.name: Image Concepts for Filmmakers
FIPR235.desc: The theory and practice involved in creating images for film and media.

FIPR269.name: Special Topics in Film Production
FIPR269.desc: A topic of current interest in film production.  Topic will change from year to year.

FIPR299.name: Directed Studies: On-Campus Research
FIPR299.desc: On-campus film production field research. Based on film project work on campus productions. Restricted to Film Production students except with permission. Contact department.

FIPR399.name: Directed Studies: Off-Campus Research
FIPR399.desc: Off-campus film production field research. Based on film project work outside the university.

FIPR435.name: Alternative Cinema Production
FIPR435.desc: Experimental approaches to content, structure, technology and style in film and media production. Students who have not yet completed FIPR 233, 234, 337, 339, must complete them at the same time as FIPR 333.
FIPR435.crer: All of FIPR 233, FIPR 234, FIPR 337, FIPR 339.

FIPR436.name: Documentary Development and Production
FIPR436.desc: Documentary concept development, essential production techniques, and marketing.

FIPR469.name: Special Projects
FIPR469.desc: Advanced film production, including interdisciplinary projects.

SPAN280.name: Revolution! (in English)
SPAN280.desc: Concepts, theories, and practice of protest, revolt, and revolution in the Hispanic world, highlighting the intersection of politics and culture through novels, poetry, letters, diaries, and/or historical accounts of specific revolutionary uprisings.

SPAN303.name: Conversational Spanish for Advanced Speakers
SPAN303.desc: Expands the comprehension and communicative skills of upper-level students and heritage speakers through  topics drawn from Hispanic culture and current events.
SPAN303.prer: One of SPAN 207, SPAN 302. Or placement test for heritage speakers.

SPAN308.name: Spanish for Business
SPAN308.desc: Language of commerce, finance, marketing, and economics. Competence in business practices of the Hispanic world.

SPAN309.name: Business Spanish of International Trade in the Hispanic World (in Spanish)
SPAN309.desc: Language of international commerce through real world business practices in the Hispanic world; key issues concerning business practices, engaging with real-world materials, and interacting with professionals specializing in trade with the Hispanic world.

SPAN312.name: Hopscotch: Topics in Hispanic Literature (in English)
SPAN312.desc: Spain and Latin America's contributions to global culture through popular Hispanic literature in translation.

SPAN322.name: Dependency and Revolution in Latin American History and Culture
SPAN322.desc: Continuities and changes in the Americas from before Columbus to the present. Includes the first modern global empire and its ambivalent legacies.

SPAN401.name: Translation
SPAN401.desc: Purpose, practice, and methodologies of translation from Spanish into English and back. Includes translation theory, translation from a variety of sources (i.e. literary, journalistic, legal, technical).

SPAN403.name: History of the Spanish Language
SPAN403.desc: Major features of the development of the Spanish language, from its origins to the present. Includes the history of Spanish phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and dialectology.

SPAN404.name: From World to Screen: Topics in Hispanic Cinema
SPAN404.desc: Selected areas of study relating to Hispanic Cinema. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN405.name: Celebrating Diversity: Topics in Peninsular and Latin-American Culture
SPAN405.desc: Selected topics relating to the diversity of cultural production in Peninsular and Latin American Culture.  Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN406.name: Breaking the Mold: Gender Representation(s) in Hispanic Literature and Culture
SPAN406.desc: Gender and sexuality in Spain and Latin America.

SPAN410.name: Multicultural Beginnings: Topics in Medieval Literature and Culture
SPAN410.desc: Selected areas of study relating to literature and culture of the Iberian Peninsula to the 15th century. Consult the Department for this year'ss offerings.

SPAN420.name: Ascent and Decline: Topics in Golden-Age Peninsular Literature and Culture
SPAN420.desc: Selected areas of study relating to sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Spain. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN430.name: Modernization and Autonomy: Topics in Peninsular Literature and Culture since the 18th Century
SPAN430.desc: Selected areas of study relating to the literature and culture of modern Spain. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN450.name: Discourse and Dialect: Topics in Spanish Language
SPAN450.desc: Selected areas of study relating to Spanish linguistics or its relation to other languages spoken in the Hispanic world. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN470.name: Imperial Eyes and Foundational Fictions: Topics in Spanish-American Colonial and Nineteenth-Century Culture
SPAN470.desc: Selected areas of study relating to colonial and/or nineteenth-century Spanish America. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN490.name: Peoples and Nations: Topics in Twentieth- and Twenty-First Century Spanish-American Culture
SPAN490.desc: Selected areas of study relating to modern and/or contemporary Spanish America. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN498.name: Directed Reading
SPAN498.desc: Focus on a topic agreed on by both Faculty Supervisor and student. Restricted to students with 4th year standing and permission from both the Department Head and Faculty Supervisor.

LAST205.name: Issues of Development in Modern Latin America
LAST205.desc: Theory of development in the Latin American context: current problems and development alternatives.

LAST301.name: Human and Civil Rights in Latin America
LAST301.desc: Focuses on human rights movements; state violence and impunity; reform of criminal justice systems; rights of indigenous peoples, women, and minorities; international protection of human rights; the UN and inter-American systems.

LAST303.name: Indigenous Peoples of Latin America
LAST303.desc: Ethnohistory and contemporary cultures of the indigenous peoples of Mexico, Middle America, and South America. Different cultural areas or regions may be selected to illustrate the course's principal themes.

LAW301.name: Philosophy of Law
LAW301.desc: An examination of the principal schools of legal theory, such as legal positivism, legal realism, sociological jurisprudence, and contemporary rights theory. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW302.name: Fundamental Concepts of Law
LAW302.desc: A study of some of the fundamental principles and ideas that cut across many areas of the substantive law, including such concepts as fault, intent, legal personality, possession, ownership, justice, and causation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW306.name: Corporate Social Responsibility and the Law

LAW308.name: Feminist Legal Theory
LAW308.desc: Recent developments in feminist legal theory. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW309.name: Topics in Feminist Legal Studies
LAW309.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW310.name: Economic Analysis of Law
LAW310.desc: Economic analysis used to explore, describe, evaluate and offer prescriptive suggestions for legal decision-making. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW311.name: Property Law and Theory
LAW311.desc: The idea of property, its origins, its justifications, its uses, its effects, and the rules that surround and create it.

LAW312.name: Topics in Philosophy of Law and Theoretical Perspectives
LAW312.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW313.name: Legal History

LAW315.name: Topics in Legal History
LAW315.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW318.name: Marine Resources Law

LAW319.name: International Human Rights

LAW320.desc: The legal situation of indigenous peoples in various states and in modern international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW321.name: Law of Armed Conflict
LAW321.desc: The legal basis for armed conflict or military operations; the rights and obligations of combatants and civilians in a region of armed conflict; war crimes.

LAW322.name: International Law Problems
LAW322.desc: Selected issues in international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW323.name: International Environmental Law
LAW323.desc: Customary international law and treaties relating to the environment; institutional structures. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW324.name: Topics in International Law and Transactions
LAW324.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW327.name: International Trade Law

LAW328.name: International Business Transactions

LAW329.name: International Commercial Disputes

LAW330.name: Cultural Property and Art Law

LAW331.name: Topics in Cultural Heritage and Art Law
LAW331.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW337.name: Trade and Investment in The People's Republic of China

LAW338.name: Japanese Law

LAW339.name: Human Rights in Asia
LAW339.desc: Legal issues relating to civil, political, social and cultural rights in particular areas in Asia. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW341.name: European Union Law
LAW341.desc: The legal system of the European Union as created by the treaties establishing the Union and by the Union's institutions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW342.name: Topics in Comparative Law
LAW342.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW343.name: Topics in Public Law
LAW343.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW344.desc: Emerging interdisciplinary scholarship on regulation, governance, and institutional design.  Examination of research and experience around both formal and legal regulatory strategies, and other informal, decentred, or non-state-based methods of ordering individual and organizational behaviour.

LAW348.name: Comparative Constitutional Law
LAW348.desc: Comparison of the constitutional history, government structure and powers, and protection of individual rights between the United States and Canada.

LAW349.name: Topics in Constitutional Law
LAW349.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW350.name: Issues of Equality and Social Justice
LAW350.desc: Selected topics related to the Charter right to equality and other rights related to social justice. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW351.name: Topics in Human Rights
LAW351.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW353.name: Aboriginal and Treaty Rights
LAW353.desc: Rights of Aboriginal people stemming from their aboriginal status and from treaties. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW354.name: First Nations Self-Government
LAW354.desc: Issues relating to First Nations' assumption of self-government powers. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW355.name: First Nations and the Administration of Justice
LAW355.desc: The justice system and its operation in relation to First Nations people. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW358.name: Topics in First Nations Law
LAW358.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW362.name: Topics in Family Law
LAW362.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW363.name: Racism and Law

LAW364.name: Topics in Race and Law
LAW364.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW368.name: Sexuality and Law
LAW368.desc: Legal issues relating to sexual activity, orientation and identification. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW370.name: Topics in Social Justice
LAW370.desc: Not offered every year; consult the Faculty.

LAW371.name: Topics in Law and Social Relations
LAW371.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW373.name: Topics in Administrative Law
LAW373.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW375.name: Land Use Planning
LAW375.desc: The legal and administrative aspects of the regulation of land use and development, especially at the local level. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW376.name: Topics in Municipal and Planning Law
LAW376.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW379.name: Externship

LAW379.prer: Either (a) one of LAW  280, LAW  476 and either (a) LAW  240 or (b) all of LAW  359, LAW  260 or (c) all of LAW  400, LAW  270 or (d) LAW  469; ;  or (b) one of LAW  387, LAW  392 or (c) one of LAW  230, LAW  459. Or other studies that provide adequate preparation for the program.

LAW380.name: Externship Reflection
LAW380.desc: Structured reflective exercises on the LAW 379 Externship experience.

LAW382.name: Health Law

LAW383.name: Mental Health Law

LAW391.name: Topics in Environmental Law
LAW391.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW397.name: Oil and Gas Law

LAW398.name: Topics in Natural Resources
LAW398.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW399.name: Advanced Criminal Law

LAW405.name: Topics in Criminal Law

LAW406.name: Topics in Criminal Justice

LAW413.name: Tax Administration and Dispute Resolution
LAW413.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 413 or LAW 567.

LAW417.name: Labour Law and Policy
LAW417.desc: The role of the law in the operation of the labour market. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW418.name: Resolution of Labour Disputes

LAW419.name: Individual Employment Law

LAW421.name: Topics in Labour Law
LAW421.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW423.name: Topics in Intellectual Property

LAW425.name: Cyberspace Law
LAW425.desc: Legal issues arising from the development of the Internet and cyberspace.

LAW426.name: Topics in Law and Technology
LAW426.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW432.name: Topics in Private Law
LAW432.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW435.name: Topics in Tort Law
LAW435.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW436.name: Restitution

LAW447.name: Topics in Commercial Law
LAW447.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW450.name: Topics in Sports, Media, Entertainment or Communications Law

LAW454.name: Topics in Trusts and Estates
LAW454.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW458.name: Topics in Real Property
LAW458.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW460.name: Advanced Corporate Law
LAW460.desc: Selected topics such as the nature of shares, equity financing, corporate structure and reorganization, and shareholder squeezeouts.

LAW467.name: Topics in Corporate Law
LAW467.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW471.name: Preventing Wrongful Convictions
LAW471.desc: Substantive legal principles and rules of evidence that can cause or help to prevent wrongful convictions or other miscarriages of justice. Roles of the participants in the criminal justice system. Not offered each year; consult Faculty.

LAW475.name: Competitive Trial Advocacy Credit
LAW475.desc: Trial advocacy. Restricted to students participating in one or more faculty approved trial advocacy competitions. Students enrolled in this course must also be enrolled in LAW 474.

LAW479.name: Mediation
LAW479.desc: Mediation of legal disputes; negotiation theory and practice as they relate to mediation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW481.name: Topics in Litigation, Dispute Resolution and the Administration of Justice
LAW481.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW482.name: Topics in Procedure and Evidence
LAW482.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW483.name: Competitive Moots and Advocacy Credit A
LAW483.desc: Appellate and related forms of advocacy. Restricted to students representing the Faculty for the first time in an approved advocacy competition.

LAW485.name: Client Counselling Competition Credit
LAW485.desc: Interviewing, counselling and negotiating. Restricted to students representing the Faculty in an approved client counselling competition.

LAW486.name: Law Review Credit
LAW486.desc: Editing and business operations by senior editors or the business manager for UBC Law Review, Canadian Journal of Family Law or any other equivalent legal journal based in the Allard School of Law. One time credit only; cannot be repeated.

TIBT100.name: Introduction to Tibetan I

TIBT101.name: Introduction to Tibetan II
TIBT101.desc: Focus on grammar, syntax, and structures to improve comprehension and communication skills. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview.

LLED206.name: Language Field Experience
LLED206.desc: Guided individual and group projects related to concurrent studies. Field-based assignments related to language study.

LLED210.name: Introduction to Analyzing Meanings of Images in Texts
LLED210.desc: Systematic analysis of visual and verbal modalities in academic and professional registers through a "grammar" designed for this purpose.

LLED211.name: Field Research in Social Processes of Inclusion and Exclusion: Discourse Perspectives
LLED211.desc: Roles that social discourses of inclusion and exclusion play in intercultural integration.

LLED221.name: Language Maintenance and the Integration of Immigrants in Canada: An Introduction
LLED221.desc: The concept of societal and individual bilingualism/multilingualism in a variety of settings, including Canada in particular.

LLED226.name: Introduction to Language Across the Curriculum
LLED226.desc: Understanding text structure within, and language diversity among, subject areas. Analysis of oral and written language from various curriculum areas in which English is the medium of instruction; implications for learning and instruction. [1.5-3-0]

LLED300.name: Foundations of Language and Literacy Education: Elementary and Middle Years

LLED301.name: Language Across the Curriculum in Multilingual Classrooms: Secondary

LLED310.name: Introduction to Reading and Language Arts Instruction: Elementary and Middle Years

LLED312.name: Curriculum and Instruction in French: Secondary
LLED312.prer: A completed concentration in French or permission of the Head.

LLED313.name: Curriculum and Instruction in Theatre and Drama: Secondary
LLED313.prer: A completed concentration in theatre or drama or permission of the Head.

LLED315.name: English as a Second Language - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

LLED318.name: Curriculum and Instruction in Modern Languages: Secondary
LLED318.desc: A completed concentration in a modern language (Chinese, German, Italian, Japanese, Russian, Spanish, or Punjabi) or permission of the Head. Pass/Fail.

LLED320.name: Curriculum and Instruction in Language and Literacy Education: Elementary and Middle Years

LLED323.name: Teaching and Learning Modern Languages: Elementary and Middle Years
LLED323.desc: Curriculum and methods of teaching in modern languages (including Chinese, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Punjabi, Russian, and Spanish).

LLED324.name: Teaching and Learning French: Elementary and Middle Years
LLED324.desc: An introduction to communicative core French teaching and learning for generalists. Pass/Fail.
LLED324.prer: French 12, or equivalent prior French experience.

LLED325.name: Teaching and Learning French in Elementary Schools
LLED325.desc: Taught in French. Strategies, theoretical foundations, and approaches related to teaching elementary French (Immersion, Core, Intensive) programs. Pass/Fail.
LLED325.prer: A completed concentration in French or permission of the Head.

LLED326.name: Introduction to Teaching and Learning Mandarin: Elementary/Secondary
LLED326.desc: Pass/Fail for B.Ed. students.  Non-B.Ed. students are eligible for percentage grading or Credit/D/Fail.

LLED336.name: Communication: Voice, Audience, Message
LLED336.desc: Knowledge and development of skills necessary to create a transactional style of teaching.

LLED363.name: Teaching and Learning English as an Additional Language: Secondary

LLED368.name: Multiliteracies in English Language Arts Classrooms

LLED382.name: Teaching Language and Literacy - Modern Languages: Secondary
LLED382.desc: Pass/Fail for B.Ed. students.  Non-B.Ed. students are eligible for percentage grading or Credit/D/Fail grading.

LLED391.name: Theory and Practice in Reading Instruction
LLED391.desc: Credit may be obtained for only one of LLED 310, 391, 300.

LLED420.name: Using Canadian Children's Literature in the French Education Classroom
LLED420.desc: Taught in French. Credit will be given for one of LLED 440, LLED 420.

LLED421.name: Gramligne: Learning and Teaching Grammar in Text for the Second Language Classroom

LLED422.name: Language Assessment in the French as a Second/Additional Language Classroom
LLED422.prer: A completed concentration or major in French or permission of Department Head.

LLED426.name: Principles and Practice of French Program Development
LLED426.desc: Taught in French. The development and implementation of French Immersion, Program Cadre, and French as a Second language Programs for preschool, elementary, secondary, or adult.

LLED428.name: Applied Linguistics for Teachers of French
LLED428.prer: Either (a) FREN 220 or (b) all of FREN 222, FREN 223.

LLED429.name: Advanced Studies in Modern Language Education
LLED429.desc: Credit will be given for only 6 credits of LLED 480 and LLED 429.

LLED435.name: Drama in Education: Community, Inquiry, and Performance

LLED440.name: Using Canadian Children's Literature in the Classroom

LLED442.name: Trends and Issues in Teaching Children's Literature

LLED451.name: Teaching and Learning Language and Literacy: Intermediate and Middle Years
LLED451.prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

LLED453.name: Materials and Texts of Literacy Instruction: Elementary
LLED453.prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

LLED454.name: Adolescent Literacies: Processes and Practices
LLED454.prer: or corequisite: an introductory-level reading, language arts, or English education course.

LLED455.name: Supporting Language and Literacy for First Nations Learners (K-12)

LLED456.name: Identifying and Supporting Learners with Literacy Difficulties
LLED456.desc: Individualized assessment, diagnosis, and instructional planning for students with literacy difficulties. Intensive practicum is included in the 6-credit version of this course.
LLED456.prer: An introductory- level reading or language arts course; successful completion of an extended practicum or one year of teaching experience.

LLED478.name: Introduction to Teaching English as a Second Language

LLED480.name: Advanced Studies in Language and Literacy Education
LLED480.desc: Credit will be given for only 6 credits of LLED 480 and 429.

LLED487.name: Special Topics in English Education
LLED487.prer: An introductory-level reading, language arts, or English education course.

LLED493.name: Supervised Study in Modern Languages Education

BIOC448.name: Directed Studies in Biochemistry
BIOC448.desc: A library (3 credits) or a laboratory project with written report (3 or 6 credits) allowing a student to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty and student.
BIOC448.prer: Permission of the Department Head is required.

BIOC449.name: Honours Thesis
BIOC449.desc: A research problem under the direction of a faculty member. Restricted to Honours students.

BIOC490.name: Student Directed Seminars
BIOC490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". Not given every year. [3-0-0]

VANT140.name: Content and Language Enrichment Tutorials
VANT140.desc: Sustained language support for linked content courses in International Program. Students develop strategies for self-directed learning.

NEST310.name: History of Women in Early to Late Medieval Muslim Societies
NEST310.desc: Realities of Muslim Women's lives are reconstructed through a critical examination of a variety of literary and material sources.

NEST311.name: Prehistoric Egypt
NEST311.desc: A survey of the development and evolution of prehistoric humans and their material culture in Egypt from the Lower Paleolithic to the Chalcolithic.

NEST315.name: Introduction to Akkadian
NEST315.desc: The basic grammar and introduction to the cuneiform writing system of the Akkadian language of the Ancient Near East.

NEST317.name: Introduction to Coptic
NEST317.desc: An introduction to Coptic, the language of Christian Egypt from 100 AD.

NEST318.name: Egyptomania
NEST318.desc: The adaptation and appropriation of ancient Egypt in ancient and modern art, architecture, film, and music; the development of Egyptology since the 19th century.

NEST319.name: The Archaeology of Ancient Iraq and Syria: Babylon and Beyond
NEST319.desc: An overview of the archaeology of the ancient Near East, with special emphasis on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, from the appearance of the first cities (c. 3400 BCE) to the end of the Persian period (c. 330 BCE).

NEST400.name: Materials and Technologies of the Ancient Near East and Egypt
NEST400.desc: The natural resources and production technologies of the ancient Near East and Egypt.  Credit will be  granted for only one of NEST 400 or 504.

NEST401.name: Literature of Ancient Egypt or the Ancient Near East
NEST401.desc: The main genres and texts of Egyptian and Ancient Near Eastern Literature and their modern Interpretation. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 401 or 505.

NEST402.name: The Archaeology of the City in the Ancient Near East
NEST402.desc: The material manifestations of urbanism in the ancient Near East, from the 4th millennium BC up to the 1st millennium BC. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 402 or 506.

CLST308.name: Roman Law
CLST308.desc: The development of Roman private law during the classical period with special attention to family law, contract and delict.

CLST311.name: Women in the Bronze Age, Classical Greek and Hellenistic Cultures
CLST311.desc: The images projected in mythology, literature, and art are compared with realities of women's lives insofar as they can be reconstructed from historical, legal, and archaeological records.

CLST314.name: Latin Epic
CLST314.desc: The development of the epic genre in Latin, with detailed study of Vergil's

CLST318.name: Classical Comedy
CLST318.desc: The plays of the Greek and Roman comic dramatists: Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus and Terence, in translation.

CLST319.name: The Roman Army
CLST319.desc: Rome's military from the early Republic to the Imperial period. Topics range from those of a military nature such as equipment and strategy to social topics such as policing and marriage of soldiers.

CLST320.name: Slavery in the Ancient Greek and Roman World
CLST320.desc: The study and history of slavery in the Greek and Roman worlds as a political, legal, economic, social, and cultural phenomenon.

CLST334.name: Roman Religion
CLST334.desc: Roman religions between the ninth century BC and the second century AD, including mystery religions, love magic, emperor worship, and early Christianity, with particular attention devoted to the primary sources. Some knowledge of ancient Rome is recommended.

CLST352.name: The Roman Republic
CLST352.desc: Rome from the foundation to the Augustan settlement. Constitutional development; the workings and failure of the Republican political system; acquisition and growth of Empire; the political, social, and economic consequences of imperialism.

CLST360.name: Life and Society in Classical Antiquity
CLST360.desc: Topics in Greek and Roman life and society.

CLST401.name: Seminar in Classical History
CLST401.desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman history, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

CLST402.name: Seminar in Classical Literature
CLST402.desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman literature, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

CLST403.name: Seminar in Classical Art and Archaeology
CLST403.desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman art and archaeology, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

CLST404.name: Seminar in the Reception of the Classical World
CLST404.desc: Selected topics in the reception of the classicial world in its own time and in later eras, with an emphasis on research. Prerequisite: at least one 3-credit upper-level course of content appropriate for the topic of the seminar (to be established by individual instructors). Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

POLI301.name: Canadian Political Parties
POLI301.desc: The organization and operation of party politics and the systems of party competition in Canada. The focus is on national-level politics.

POLI302.name: Public Administration
POLI302.desc: The structure and organization of the administrative branch of government in theory and practice. Administrative powers and policy-making in the modern state. Examples of the administrative processes are drawn from Canada and other countries.

POLI305.name: Canadian Political Ideas
POLI305.desc: Political theories and ideologies in Canada.

POLI306.name: Local Government and Politics in Canada
POLI306.desc: Local and regional political institutions and processes in Canada, with particular attention to those of Vancouver and other British Columbia localities.

POLI307.name: Quebec Government and Politics
POLI307.desc: The nature of politics and the conduct of government in contemporary Quebec. The course is open to students from fields other than political science.

POLI308.name: Issues in Canadian Politics
POLI308.desc: An examination of one or more major issues in Canadian politics (e.g., the Charter, electoral reform). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI316.name: Global Indigenous Politics
POLI316.desc: The political dynamics of Indigenous peoples’ politics on the global level; the legal and practical realities of colonization as a global Indigenous experience; current global Indigenous political issues and avenues of Indigenous resistance.

POLI320.name: Government and Politics of the United States of America
POLI320.desc: The distinctive political system of the U.S. Covers all major institutions and processes, focusing on contemporary issues. Comparisons with the Canadian system. Sources of political failure and possible reform.

POLI321.name: Chinese Politics and Development
POLI321.desc: The course will explore various aspects of Chinese politics and the dynamics of China’s development since 1949.  Topics include: the Cultural Revolution, political reform and protest, and economic reform policies and their consequences.

POLI322.name: Japanese Government and Politics
POLI322.desc: A general introduction to modern Japanese politics from various theoretical and comparative perspectives.

POLI323.name: South Asian Government and Politics
POLI323.desc: Comparative analysis of politics and government in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka. Imperial legacies and nationalist movements; political institution-building amidst socio-cultural diversity; parties and interest groups; elections and leadership crises; military intervention; ethnic and class conflicts; foreign policy.

POLI324.name: Southeast Asian Government and Politics
POLI324.desc: The political systems of contemporary Southeast Asia.

POLI325.name: Communist and Post-Communist Politics
POLI325.desc: An examination of the origins, development, and demise of Communist political systems, as well as the nature of post-Communist politics, with special emphasis on the Soviet Union and its successor states.

POLI328.name: Topics in Comparative Politics
POLI328.desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI329.name: Gender and Politics
POLI329.desc: Relations between gender and political processes and institutions, including the impact of globalization and economic development.

POLI330.name: Japanese Political Economy
POLI330.desc: Issues in contemporary Japanese political economy, including industrial policy, the Keiretsu groupings, the main-bank system, trends toward deregulation, and business-labour relations.

POLI331.name: Korean Government and Politics
POLI331.desc: An introduction to the politics of Korea. The evolution of Korean politics from authoritarian rule to democratic transition, focusing on present and future political, economic and social issues.

POLI333.name: Issues in Comparative Politics
POLI333.desc: An examination of a major issue in comparative politics (e.g., the media, gender, nationalism, ethnic conflict). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI334.name: Comparative Democratization
POLI334.desc: Literatures and theories on regime democratization around the world; the roles of political, economic, social, and international factors in encouraging or impeding democratization.

POLI335.name: Comparative Federalism
POLI335.desc: An empirical and normative analysis of federalism as a way of structuring political life in industrialized democracies, investigating explanations for the design, persistence and operation of federal systems.

POLI336.name: Associations and the State in Comparative Perspective
POLI336.desc: How organised groups (civil society organizations, NGOs, interest groups) interact with governments in a variety of countries.

POLI337.name: The U.S. Presidency in Comparative Perspective
POLI337.desc: Executive leadership of the U.S. presidency in comparison to the leadership of other Anglo-American systems, including the U.K., Canada, and Australia.

POLI340.name: History of Political Ideas
POLI340.desc: An introduction to the political ideas of leading political philosophers from Ancient Greece to the 19th century.

POLI341.name: Contemporary Political Theory
POLI341.desc: Topics may include freedom, colonialism, capitalism, Critical Theory and ideology, power and knowledge, social justice, rationalism, gender and identity politics, and the "political."

POLI342.name: Modern Political Theory: Analysis of a Selected Theorist
POLI342.desc: A detailed examination of an acknowledged masterpiece of modern political theory. The text and attendant literature vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI343.name: Theories of State and Society
POLI343.desc: Classical origins of contemporary theories of the state, market, and civil society, focused on the relationship between social order, politics, and democracy. Readings from Smith, Toqueville, Weber, and contemporary sources.

POLI344.name: Social and Political Thought
POLI344.desc: An examination of some of the major concepts in political philosophy such as justice, equality, rights, obligation, liberty in the context of both classical and contemporary political thought.

POLI346.name: Democratic Theory
POLI346.desc: An examination of both classical and contemporary theories of democracy. Representative democratic theory, participatory democratic theory, and their relationship to twentieth century concepts of democracy.

POLI347.name: Law and Political Theory
POLI347.desc: An examination of law and political theory that considers topics such as sovereignty, constitutionalism, civil disobedience, rights and the political role of judges.

POLI348.name: Political Theory and Public Policy
POLI348.desc: Application of frameworks to policy questions that factor in debates about citizenship and social inclusion, and an examination of contemporary normative frameworks that fall along, and transcend, the left-right political spectrum.

POLI350.name: Public Policy
POLI350.desc: An introduction to public policy: rationales for government intervention, the influence of interest groups and political institutions on policy outcomes, and the various stages in the policy process.

POLI351.name: Environmental Politics and Policy
POLI351.desc: Domestic and international determinants of environmental policy; alternative approaches to environmental protection. The sustainable development paradigm; public opinion and interest group pressures; risk assessment; mandatory, voluntary and market-based policy instruments.

POLI352.name: Comparative Politics of Public Policy
POLI352.desc: Policy making across industrialized democracies, with a focus on North America and Europe.

POLI360.name: Security Studies
POLI360.desc: The contemporary international security context: reorientation of the study of security, patterns of inter- and intrastate conflict and communal violence, dilemmas of international response and conflict management.

POLI361.name: International Violence and Its Control
POLI361.desc: A study of the nature of international violence from guerrilla to nuclear war; a survey of theories of the causes of interstate war; recent research findings on the causes of war and conditions for peace; a comparative analysis of strategies for controlling violence through disarmament and the promotion of alternative means of conflict resolution.

POLI362.name: The Great Powers and International Politics
POLI362.desc: An examination of the changing nature of Great Power relations, including procedures and institutions for managing their conflicts, in the pre-Cold War, Cold War, and post-Cold War international systems.

POLI363.name: Canadian Foreign Policy
POLI363.desc: An analysis of Canadian foreign policy on important international issues since the 1960s and of the policy-making process. Issues may include defence commitments, economic relations, activities of international organizations, and relations with the US, Europe, USSR, Asia and the Third World.

POLI364.name: International Organizations
POLI364.desc: Analysis of the activities and influence of modern international organizations in international security, economic, and social issue areas. The course will focus on organizations associated with the United Nations, but other world and regional bodies will be analysed as well.

POLI365.name: Asian International Relations
POLI365.desc: Analysis of the foreign policies of one or more of the states of East, Southeast, and South Asia; their relations with other states in the region as well as with major outside powers.

POLI367.name: International Relations Theory and the International System
POLI367.desc: The evolution of the international system and empirical and normative theories of international relations such as realism, liberalism, and Marxism.

POLI368.name: Japan's Foreign Relations
POLI368.desc: Japan's security policy, aid policy, relations with the United States and with neighbouring Asian nations, role in the United Nations and other international institutions.

POLI369.name: Issues in International Security
POLI369.desc: An examination of issues such as interstate conflicts, terrorism, environmental change, international crime. Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI370.name: Issues in International Conflict Management
POLI370.desc: Problems of managing conflict in the international system (e.g., intervention, mediation, sanctions). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI374.name: International Peacekeeping
POLI374.desc: The development of peacekeeping within and outside the United Nations system and as an instrument of conflict management.

POLI375.name: Global Environmental Politics
POLI375.desc: Ecological consequences of the global political economy.

POLI376.name: International Law
POLI376.desc: The nature, sources, and sanctions of international law; the notion of nationhood with particular reference to the status of the British Dominions; territorial and extra-territorial jurisdiction; diplomatic and sovereign immunities; international delinquency; treaties; settlement of disputes; international organizations. This course  may not be taken for credit in both Arts and Law.

POLI381.name: Topics in Quantitative Analysis
POLI381.desc: Application of quantitative techniques to selected topics in Political Science. Topics vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI385.name: Public Opinion and Elections
POLI385.desc: Psychological and social foundations of public opinion; quality of democratic decision-making; how voters make up their minds; impact of electoral systems; social bases of party systems; campaigns and the mass media. The Canadian experience in comparative context.

POLI401.name: Canadian Provincial and Regional Politics
POLI401.desc: Seminar examines political parties, processes, and institutions in the provincial political systems and regional arrangements between provinces.
POLI401.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI402.name: Law and Politics of the Canadian Constitution
POLI402.desc: Seminar on the origins and development of the Canadian Constitution: the political aspects of federalism and the legal consequences of the Charter of Rights.
POLI402.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI403.name: The Political Economy of Canada
POLI403.desc: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the interplay of economic and social factors in the shaping of Canadian politics: the major issues and strains in the functioning of the Canadian polity.
POLI403.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI404.name: Public Policy and Its Administration
POLI404.desc: Political and administrative aspects of public policy, particularly in Canada.
POLI404.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308, POLI 350, POLI 351, POLI 352.

POLI405.name: Topics in Canadian Politics
POLI405.desc: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
POLI405.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI406.name: Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Politics
POLI406.desc: Seminar in political structures, activities, and demands of aboriginal peoples; policies of federal, provincial, and territorial governments; relations between these governments and aboriginal peoples; role of the courts and the Constitution.
POLI406.prer: POLI 101 and at least 3 credits from POLI 301–308.

POLI420.name: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics
POLI420.desc: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI420.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI421.name: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics: Non-Western
POLI421.desc: A seminar devoted to comparative analysis of politics in non-western states. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI421.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI422.name: Selected Problems in Comparative Politics
POLI422.desc: A seminar devoted to intensive analysis of a contemporary political problem from a comparative perspective, e.g., ethnic politics, class politics, the politics of post-industrial society. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI422.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI423.name: Issues in Comparative Politics
POLI423.desc: Seminar in comparative analysis of constitutionalism, authoritarianism, democracy, etc. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI423.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI426.name: Seminar on Comparative Parties and Party Systems
POLI426.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI427.name: Issues in Chinese Politics and Development
POLI427.desc: Seminar examines one issue in Chinese politics (e.g., environmental politics, local government, state-society relations) from a broadly comparative perspective.

POLI429.name: Seminar in Issues in Gender and Politics
POLI429.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 345, POLI 350, POLI 351.

POLI440.name: Contemporary Political Theory
POLI440.desc: This seminar examines the political ideas of leading political philosophers of the twentieth century. Consult the departmental website.

POLI441.name: Interpretation and Criticism in Political Theory
POLI441.desc: Approaches to political criticism: Critical Theory, Foucauldian genealogy, critical realism, and feminism, including forms of domination, which shape people's beliefs and self-conceptions.

POLI442.name: Contemporary Political Theorists: Analysis of a Selected Theorist
POLI442.desc: This seminar examines in detail the political ideas of an important political philosopher of the twentieth century. The theorist studied varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI443.name: MODERN WESTERN POLITICAL THOUGHT
POLI443.desc: Seminar: Texts in the history of modern Western political thought, such as works by Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Karl Marx, Alexis de Tocqueville, John Stuart Mill, Friedrich Nietzsche, Max Weber, and Sigmund Freud.

POLI445.name: Critical Theory: Policitical Theory and the Problems of Race
POLI445.desc: Traditions of critical social theory, broadly construed, to examine the modern politics of 'race,' racism, and racialized identities.

POLI446.name: Multiculturalism and Identity Politics
POLI446.desc: Seminar will examines how "identity" is theorized in contemporary political thought, beginning with the role that identity plays in the "western" canon and proceeding to examine feminist, multicultural, queer, and post-colonial theories of citizenship along with their critics.

POLI448.name: Democratic Theory
POLI448.desc: Overview of traditional democratic theory with close readings of several contemporary theories, such as those of Habermas, Rawls, and Arendt. Readings are drawn from complete original texts, and assessment is based on a research essay.

POLI450.name: Policy Analysis
POLI450.desc: Practical skills for generating written and oral analysis for a client or supervisor.
POLI450.prer: Either (a) POLI 101 and one of POLI 302, POLI 306, POLI 350;  or (b) all of POLI 350, POLI 352.

POLI460.name: Foreign Policy Analysis
POLI460.desc: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the foreign policies of one or more states, as well as to the study of literature pertaining to foreign policy analysis. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI460.prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

POLI464.name: Problems in International Relations
POLI464.desc: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

POLI466.name: The Politics of International Law
POLI466.desc: Seminar on the origins and politics of international law, and its impact on international affairs; the laws of war, human rights, environment, law of the sea, and international criminal law.

FRE402.name: Market Research and Analysis in Agri-Food Industries
FRE402.desc: Macro and micro aspects of agri-food market and industry analysis, market strategy, consumer behaviour, secondary market research, quantitative and qualitative market research. [3-0-0]

OHS430.name: Operative Dentistry
OHS430.desc: The art and science of diagnosing and treating single tooth defects. [0-4.5-0]

OHS431.name: Orthodontics
OHS431.desc: Differential diagnosis, treatment planning, biomechanical principles and clinical treatment. [1-2-0]

OHS435.name: Prosthodontics I
OHS435.desc: The art and science of restoring and replacing teeth and surrounding tissues.

OHS440.name: Advanced Operative Dentistry
OHS440.desc: The art and science of diagnosing and treating single tooth defects. [0-3-0]

OHS444.name: Practice Management
OHS444.desc: Ethics, jurisprudence, practice management, intra- and interprofessional relationships. [2-0-0]

OHS445.name: Prosthodontics II
OHS445.desc: The art and science of restoring and replacing teeth and surrounding tissues.

GREK401.name: Greek Prose
GREK401.desc: Studies in history, philosophy and/or oratory. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to GREK 401.

GREK402.name: Greek Verse
GREK402.desc: Studies in epic, tragedy and/or comedy. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to GREK 402.

BIOT201.name: Lab Safety
